0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Nuclear Receptor Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor Interacts with HIV-1 Tat and Stimulates Viral Replication in Human Microglial Cells* Olivier Rohr , Christian Schwartz, Christiane Hery , Dominique Aunis, Marc Tardieu , and Evelyne Schaeffer.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the  Unite 338 INSERM, 5 rue Blaise Pascal, 67084 Strasbourg Cedex, France and the   Laboratoire Virus, Neurone et Immunite, CRI 96-12, Faculte de Medecine Paris-Sud, 63 rue Gabriel Peri, 94276 Le Kremlin-Bicetre, France.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	3	Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infects the central nervous system and plays a direct role in the pathogenesis of AIDS dementia.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	4	 However, the molecular mechanisms underlying HIV-1 expression in the central nervous system are poorly understood.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We have recently reported that the nuclear receptor chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF), an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, is an activator of HIV-1 gene transcription.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Here, our results show that COUP-TF stimulates HIV-1 transcription in primary cultured human microglial cells, the primary target for HIV-1 infection in brain.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Run-on assays indicated that COUP-TF acts on the initiation step of transcription.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Results from reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and immunocytochemistry analysis further revealed the importance of this factor by demonstrating that overexpression of COUP-TF leads to initiation of viral replication in primary HIV-infected human microglia.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In addition, COUP-TF is able to physically interact and cooperate with the viral transactivator Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The combination of COUP-TF and Tat leads to NF-B- and Sp1-independent enhanced transcriptional stimulation.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In vitro binding studies showed that COUP-TF interacts with Tat through amino acids within the N-terminal DNA-binding domain of COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Amino acids 48-72 in the basic and C-terminal regions of Tat are required for the binding of Tat to COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These results suggest that COUP-TF is an essential transcription factor involved in HIV-1 expression in microglia and reveal a novel interplay of Tat and COUP-TF during regulation of viral expression.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	14	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	15	Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1)1 infects the central nervous system (CNS) and leads to a wide range of neurological complications (1, 2).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Although astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and perhaps neurons are capable of harboring a restricted infection with HIV-1 (3-5), the CNS-resident macrophages or microglial cells (6) are the primary target of HIV-1 infection in brain (7-10).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	17	 HIV-1 infection is established in the CNS by viruses present early in infection (11).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Macrophage-tropic isolates infect microglial cells more efficiently than do lymphotropic isolates (12).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	19	 We have therefore performed our studies with both a macrophage-tropic and a lymphotropic strain.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	20	The regulation of HIV-1 gene expression is governed by interactions of viral and host cell transcription factors with the long terminal repeat (LTR) region (for review, see Refs.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Recent studies have focused on cellular factors that regulate HIV-1 expression in CNS cells (15-18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Our previous studies have highlighted the importance of members of the steroid/thyroid/retinoid receptor family in the regulation of HIV-1 gene transcription in brain cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	23	 We have shown that the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF/Ear3 (19) function as a potent HIV-1 transcriptional activator in different human brain cell lines.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Whereas in oligodendrocytes, COUP-TF acts by direct interaction with the nuclear receptor-responsive element located in the 352/320 LTR region (17), in microglial cells, COUP-TF enhances transcription via the minimal 68/+29 LTR region by direct association with the Sp1 protein (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	25	These transcription factors activate LTR-driven transcription in the immediate-early phase of HIV infection, in which viral transcription proceeds at a low rate through dependence solely on cellular transcription factors.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This leads to the early phase, in which a dramatic increase in transcription results from the accumulation of the primary transactive viral protein Tat (14, 20).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A number of studies have shown that Tat increases the rate of transcription initiation, elongation and translation of TAR-containing mRNAs.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The ability of Tat to function as a transcriptional activator is mediated by the interaction with a number of different cellular proteins (for review, see Ref.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The general transcription factors TBP/TFIID (21) and TFIIH (22) and the elongation factors TAK/PTEFb (23, 24) and cyclin T (25) associate with Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In addition, transcriptional activation by Tat requires the concerted action of Tat and factors binding to the Sp1 and B LTR region.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The importance of the Sp1 factor for Tat-mediated transactivation is well established (26, 27); a direct interaction occurs between Sp1 and amino acids 30-72 of Tat during transactivation (26, 28, 29).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Specific NF-B subunits also act in concert with Tat to enhance LTR-driven transcription (30, 31).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Moreover, the thyroid hormone receptor T3R, a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, was found to interact with Tat through amino acids located in the DNA-binding domain of T3R and through amino acids 49-72 in the basic and C-terminal region of Tat (32).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	34	 These data explain why mutations within the LTR sequence decrease or abolish Tat-mediated activation (33, 34).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Interestingly, TAR-independent Tat transactivation has also been described, in the presence of an intact NF-B element (35, 36).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	36	In this report, we have investigated the functional effect of the nuclear receptor COUP-TF on HIV-1 gene expression in primary cultured human microglial cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Our results reveal the importance of COUP-TF as an activator of HIV-1 gene transcription and replication in primary microglia.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	38	 In addition, we provide evidence for a novel functional and physical interaction between COUP-TF and Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	39	 This interaction leads to enhanced synergistic NF-B and Sp1-independent transactivation of the LTR.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Our data suggest a model of an alternative pathway for Tat transactivation in microglia that is independent of both NF-B and Sp1, through direct interactions of Tat with the nuclear receptor COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	41	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	42	Plasmids-- LTR-chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) vectors were described previously (16-18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	43	 LTR-CAT Sp1mut and LTR-CAT B/Sp1 and pCMVp53 were a gift from Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The GST-COUP-1 and GST-COUP-3 vectors were described (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	45	 To construct T7-Tat, the Tat fragment was excised from pCMV-Tat vector (gift of Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Israel, Institut Pasteur, Paris France) and subcloned into the pCDNA3 vector (Invitrogen).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	47	 To construct T7-COUP-TF, the plasmid RSV-COUP-TF (gift of Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Tsai, Houston, TX) was digested with EcoRI and the COUP-TF insert was subcloned into the EcoRI site of pCDNA3.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	49	 To construct pCMV-Tat 72R P18IS, the Tat 72R P18IS sequence (from Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Rice, AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, Division of AIDS, NIAID, National Institutes of Health) was excised from GST-Tat 72R P18IS vector and subcloned into the pCDNA3 vector.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	51	 To construct the 40/+80-SV40 TATA-CAT vector, the 40/+80 HIV-1 LTR containing the HIV-1 LAI TATA box (TATAAGC) was mutated by PCR into the SV40 virus TATA box (TATTTAT) and subcloned into the pMOSBlue T-vector (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	52	6-kilobase region containing the CAT reporter gene and polyadenylation signals was subcloned in the HindIII site in front of the modified 40/+80 LTR.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	53	Cell Culture, Transfections, and CAT Assays-- Two types of microglial cell cultures were tested: primary cells and a cell line.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Primary human fetal microglial cells were prepared as described previously (37).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	55	 They were plated in 6-cm-diameter dishes and were transfected either by the calcium phosphate precipitation method or with the Escort reagent (Sigma) following the manufacturer's instructions.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The human microglial cell line (38) was grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum and 10 mM HEPES in the presence of penicillin-streptomycin (100 units/ml) and was transfected by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	57	Cells were either transfected with 1 pmol of plasmid reporter DNA or cotransfected with 1 pmol of reporter DNA and 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	58	5 pmol of the indicated expression vector: RSV-COUP-TF (gift of Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Tsai, Houston, TX), CMV-p53 (gift of Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Sawaya, Philadelphia, PA), pEF-NF-IL6 (gift of Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Akira, Hyogo, Japan), or CMV-Sp1 (gift of Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Each transfection was done in duplicate and repeated a minimum of three separate times with two different plasmid preparations.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	63	 CAT assays were done using standard techniques (16).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	64	Infection of Cells and RT-PCR Analysis-- Primary cells (3-4  x  105) were incubated with HIV-1 LAI or 95.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	65	33 (titer of 15-20 ng/ml of p24) for 18 h at 37  degrees C and then washed four times to remove residual virus.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	66	 When indicated, cells were transfected 18 h postinfection.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	67	 At 24 and 48 h posttransfection, total RNA was prepared with the RNable kit (Eurobio), and gp120 mRNA detection was performed by RT-PCR analysis, using gp120 5' biotinylated primer, TAGGACGAGCAATGTATGCC, (0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	68	25 pmol) and 3' primer, TATATAATTCACTTCTCCAATTGTCCCTCAT (0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	69	 PCR was performed in a 50- microl PCR mixture containing 10 nmol of each dNTP, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	70	25 units of Taq DNA polymerase (AmpliTaq gold, Perkin Elmer).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	71	 PCR products were visualized after ethidium bromide staining and agarose gel electrophoresis.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	72	Immunocytochemistry-- Primary cells incubated with HIV-1 (LAI) and transfected as described above were tested by immunochemistry after 24 h posttransfection and fixation in acetone for 8 min.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Primary antibodies were mouse IgG1 directed against HIV-1 p24 and HIV-1 Tat (1:200, AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, Rockville, MD).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The immunostaining was revealed by secondary peroxidase-conjugated antibodies and visualized with diaminobenzidine (0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	75	GST Pull-down Assays-- GST and GST fusion proteins were expressed in Escherichia coli BL-21(DE3).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	76	 GST-Tat expression vectors were obtained through the AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, Division of AIDS (NIAID, National Institutes of Health) from Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Overnight cultures of bacteria that were newly transformed with the plasmids were diluted with 20 volumes of medium, cultured for several hours to an absorbance at 600 nm of 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	78	4 mM isopropyl -D-thiogalactopyranoside at 37  degrees C for 3 h.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Bacteria from 125 ml of culture were harvested and resuspended in 1.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	80	5 ml of NETN (20 mM Tris, pH 8, 100 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	81	5% Nonidet P-40, 10  microg of leupeptin per ml, 10  microg of pepstatin per ml, 10  microg of aprotinin per ml, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The lysates were sonicated and after centrifugation, the supernatants were mixed with glutathione-Sepharose 8A beads (40  microl, Pharmacia) at 4  degrees C overnight in NETN buffer.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The 35S-labeled input Tat or COUP-TF protein was prepared by in vitro translation using the TNT T7 system (Promega) according to the manufacturer's suggestions.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The coated beads (40  microl) were washed with NETN and further incubated for 2 h at 4  degrees C with 15  microl of the total in vitro translated protein reaction mixture in a final volume of 300  microl of binding buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	85	02% bovine serum albumin) containing antiproteases as in NETN.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	86	 After extensive washing with washing buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	87	02% Tween 20) containing the antiproteases, the bound proteins were dissociated by boiling for 3 min in Laemmli sample buffer and subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	88	Immunoprecipitations and Western Blot Analysis-- Lysates were prepared from cells plated in a 10-cm dish, as described (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Cell lysates were resuspended in 400  microl of TNE (50 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	90	0, 1% Nonidet, 2 mM EDTA, and a mixture of protease inhibitors), mixed with protein A-agarose beads (20  microl), and gently shaken for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The suspension was briefly centrifuged, and the supernatant was mixed with 3  microl of monoclonal antibodies against HIV-1 (BH10) Tat (obtained through the AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, Division of AIDS, NIAID, National Institutes of Health, from Drs.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	92	 After overnight incubation at 4  degrees C, protein A-agarose (30  microl) was added and mixed for 2 h.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	93	 After extensive washing of the beads with TNE, 15  microl of beads were mixed with 5  microl of Buffer Z (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	94	5 mM EDTA, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol) and processed for Western blotting, with COUP-TF antibodies (a gift from Dr.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Karathanasis; Philadelphia, PA).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	96	Run-on Analysis-- Microglial cells were harvested, suspended in lysis Buffer A (0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	97	3 M sucrose, 60 mM KCl, 15 mM NaCl, 15 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	98	5 mM EGTA, 14 mM -mercaptoethanol), and spun down at 1500  x  g for 5 min.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The pellet was resuspended in 3 ml of Buffer B (Buffer A plus 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	100	1% Triton X), poured gently on 4 ml of Buffer C (Buffer A with 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	101	7 M sucrose), and spun down at 2500  x  g for 10 min.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The permeabilized nuclei were resuspended in storage Buffer D (50 mM HEPES, pH 8, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	103	5 mM dithiothreitol, 1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, and 25% glycerol) and stored at 80  degrees C.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	104	1  microg of CAT (LTR-CAT HindIII-excised total CAT gene), 1  microg of CAT I (40/+79 LTR-CAT AlwNI/HindIII fragment), and 1  microg of CAT II (+79/+229 HindIII/PvuII CAT fragment) were excised from the LTR-CAT vector, single-stranded and applied onto a nitrocellulose filter preincubated in 2 M ammonium acetate.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	105	 After 2 h in a vacuum oven at 80  degrees C, filters were washed with 1 x  SSC, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	106	1% SDS and prehybridized for 1 h in reaction buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 8, 1 mM MgCl2, 2 mM MnCl2, 4 mM dithiothreitol, 200 mM KCl, 300 mM NH4Cl) containing 20  microg/ml tRNA.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Filters were boiled for 1 min and cooled in ice-cold water before use or were stored in a plastic bag at 4  degrees C.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	108	The elongation reaction was carried out with 50  microl of isolated and permeabilized nuclei for 20 min at 26  degrees C in reaction buffer supplemented with 1  microg of LTR-CAT vector, 200  microCi of [32P]UTP, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	109	5 mM of other NTP, and 30 units of RNasin inhibitor (New England Biolabs).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The mRNA transcripts were phenol extracted and precipitated successively with 10% (w/w) trichloroacetic acid and ethanol.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The pellet was dissolved in 10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	112	5, supplemented with 1% SDS, applied to the previously prepared nitrocellulose filters in hybridization buffer (0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	113	5 mM NaCl, 50 mM PIPES, pH 7, 33% formamide, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	114	4% SDS, 2 mM EDTA, and 20  microg/ml tRNA), and incubated at 45  degrees C for 72 h.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Filters were washed twice with 2 x  SSC, 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	116	1% SDS at room temperature for 30 min and twice with 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	117	1% SDS at 55  degrees C for 15 min.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Filters were exposed overnight on a BIOMAX MR film (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	119	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	120	COUP-TF Stimulates HIV-1 Transcription in Primary Human Microglial Cells-- We have previously shown that the transcription factor COUP-TF stimulates HIV-1 LTR-driven transcription in a microglial cell line (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Because we also detected endogenous COUP-TF in primary cultures of microglial cells (results not shown), it appeared essential to examine how COUP-TF regulates HIV-1 gene transcription and viral replication in these cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Transfection experiments were performed with a LTR-CAT reporter vector in primary cultures of microglial cells containing the CAT gene under the control of the HIV-1 LTR region.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	123	 When cells were cultured in the absence of cytokine stimulation and transfected with the calcium coprecipitation method, the basal transcriptional activity was barely detectable (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	124	 This is consistent with our recent results, which showed that HIV-1 expression in cultured microglial cells is dependent on prestimulation with proinflammatory cytokines (37).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Upon cotransfection with the COUP-TF expression vector, LTR-driven CAT expression was induced 20-fold.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	126	 As a control, overexpression of the tumor suppressor p53, which is known to repress HIV-1 transcription (41), did not induce any CAT activity (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	127	 When cells were transfected with a cationic liposome (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	128	 1B), the transfection efficiency was better.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The basal transcription activity remained quite low.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Interestingly, the level of induction following COUP-TF overexpression was 19-fold, similar to the one obtained in Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Moreover, upon overexpression of the positive transactivators Sp1 and NF-IL6, CAT activity was induced 25- and 27-fold.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	132	 These results confirm that, similar to the situation observed in brain cell lines, COUP-TF, Sp1, and NF-IL6 function as HIV-1 transcriptional activators in primary microglia.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	133	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	134	   COUP-TF stimulates HIV-1 LTR-driven transcription in primary cultured human microglial cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Transfection experiments were performed in primary microglia with the HIV-1 LTR-CAT vector in the absence or presence of a vector expressing COUP-TF, p53, NF-IL6, or Sp1, as indicated.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	136	 One typical CAT assay is shown after transfection by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method (A) and with the Escort reagent (Sigma) (B).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	137	 At the top of the autoradiograms are indicated the percentage of conversion into the acetylated forms of chloramphenicol and the CAT activities expressed relative to the value obtained with the LTR-CAT reporter vector alone.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	138	COUP-TF Stimulates the Initiation Step of HIV-1 Gene Transcription-- To investigate at which step COUP-TF enhances HIV-1 gene expression, we performed run-on assays using isolated nuclei from microglial cells that had been transfected with COUP-TF or left untransfected (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In the absence of COUP-TF overexpression, transcription in the CAT reporter gene was low; overexpression of COUP-TF led to a large increase in the transcription rate (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	140	 2A), confirming its transcriptional stimulatory activity.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	141	 To test whether COUP-TF acted on the initiation or the elongation step of transcription, run-on assays were performed with CAT I (40/+79 LTR-CAT AlwNI/HindIII fragment) and CAT II (+79/+229 HindIII/PvuII CAT fragment).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	142	 COUP-TF increased the amount of small mRNAs because the amount of transcripts of CAT I was higher than that of CAT II (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	143	 This result indicates that COUP-TF acts on the initiation step of transcription.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	144	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Microglial cells were transfected with COUP-TF expression vector (+) or left untransfected ().
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Nuclei were permeabilized and subjected to a 15-min in vitro transcription assay.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	147	 A, two aliquots of 1  microg of the CAT gene (excised from LTR-CAT vector) were spotted onto nitrocellulose papers and used in hybridization assays as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	148	" B, aliquots of 1  microg of CAT I (40/+79 LTR-CAT AlwNI/HindIII DNA fragment) and CAT II (+79/+229 HindIII/PvuII LTR-CAT DNA fragment) were spotted onto nitrocellulose paper as indicated under "Materials and Methods" and used in hybridization assays.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	149	COUP-TF Stimulates Replication in Primary Human Microglial Cells-- To investigate the effect of COUP-TF on viral replication itself, we devised a novel experimental procedure.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Primary cultures of microglial cells were first infected with either the lymphotropic LAI or the macrophage-tropic 95.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	151	 After 18 h, cells were either treated with the transfection reagent alone or transfected with the COUP-TF vector.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Expression of the viral gp120 mRNA after 24 and 48 h was monitored by RT-PCR analysis.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Results clearly showed that overexpression of COUP-TF induces gp120 expression, peaking at 24 h, similar to the expression obtained in T lymphocytes (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	154	 As a control, transfection with a vector expressing the tumor suppressor p53, known to repress LTR-driven transcription (42) did not induce any gp120 expression (results not shown).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	155	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	156	   COUP-TF stimulates HIV-1 mRNA production in primary cultured human microglial cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Cells (4  x  105) were infected with HIV-1(LAI) and after 18 h were transfected with the COUP-TF vector or left untransfected.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Expression of HIV-1 gp120 mRNA was measured 24 and 48 h posttransfection by RT-PCR analysis.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	159	 PCR products were visualized by gel electrophoresis.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	160	 HIV-1 gp120 mRNA was detected as a 160-base pair fragment (160 base pairs).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	161	 mRNA from infected T cells was used as a control.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	162	In addition, we performed immunocytochemistry experiments with primary cultured microglial cells infected with HIV-1 and transfected with the COUP-TF vector or left untransfected.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The percentage of transfected cells with the Escort reagent, determined by transfection of the green fluorescent protein, was between 5 and 10% (results not shown).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Results showed that cells transfected with COUP-TF expressed HIV-1 antigen proteins p24 (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	165	 As a control, cells that were infected, but not transfected with COUP-TF, did not express any HIV-1 antigen (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	166	 4, B-D, we have selected an area of transfected cells, because cells expressing viral antigens were found mostly in clusters, scattered on the preparation.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Taken together, these findings demonstrate that, consistent with the effect on transcription, overexpression of COUP-TF is able to initiate viral replication.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Interestingly, this effect was observed with both a lymphotropic strain of HIV-1 that otherwise replicates very poorly in microglia and a macrophage-tropic strain.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (160K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	170	   COUP-TF stimulates HIV-1 replication in primary cultured human microglial cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Immunostaining by anti-p24 HIV-1 antigen of microglial cells infected with HIV-1 (LAI) and either left untransfected (A) or transfected with COUP-TF (B).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Photographs at a low magnification ( x  100) show the staining (brown) of a cluster of transfected cells, whereas control infected cells remained unstained.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	173	 At a higher magnification ( x  400), aspect of infected and transfected cells stained either with anti-p24 HIV-1 antigen (C) or with anti-Tat HIV-1 antigen (D).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	174	Effect of COUP-TF on HIV-1 Expression in the Presence of Viral Tat-- It is well established that in the early phase of HIV infection, a dramatic increase in transcription results from the accumulation of the viral protein Tat (14, 20).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	175	 We therefore investigated how COUP-TF affects LTR-driven transcription in the presence of Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Because our transcription results obtained in primary cells could be compared with those obtained with the microglial cell line (38), we used the cell line to perform a series of experiments that necessitated a large number of cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Microglial cells were transfected with various LTR-CAT reporter vectors, presented in Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	178	 5, either alone or in the presence of vectors expressing COUP-TF, Tat, or a combination of both vectors.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	179	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	180	   Tat and COUP-TF synergistically activate HIV-1 gene transcription directed from a NF-B and Sp1-deleted or mutated LTR region.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Microglial cells were cotransfected with the indicated LTR-CAT expression vectors (1 pmol) in the presence or absence of vectors expressing COUP-TF (2  microg) and Tat (10 ng), as indicated.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Histograms represent CAT activities expressed relative to the value obtained with the corresponding LTR-CAT reporter vector.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments done in duplicate.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	184	With LTR-CAT containing the full-length 489/+80 LTR region, COUP-TF alone activated transcription 4-fold.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Tat alone or in combination with COUP-TF activated transcription 30-fold (results not shown).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	186	 As shown previously, the truncated 68/+80 region, containing two Sp1 sites and the TATA box, was still able to mediate COUP-TF responsiveness (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5, lane 2), as a result of the direct interaction of COUP-TF with the Sp1 protein (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	188	 With this 68/+80 LTR-CAT vector, Tat alone or in combination with COUP-TF stimulated CAT activity 35-fold (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	189	Deletion of the TAR region, the binding site of Tat (43) in 68/+29LTR-CAT, did not significantly affect COUP-TF-mediated stimulation (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	190	 5, lane 6), and as expected, it abolished Tat-induced activation (lanes 7 and 8).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Deletion or mutation of the Sp1 sites in the truncated 40/+80 LTR, in 283/+80 LTRSp1mut, or in 283/+80B/Sp1 led to the abolition of COUP-TF-induced activation (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	192	 5, lanes 10, 14, and 18) because Sp1 is required for COUP-TF transactivation in microglial cells (18); similarly, Tat-induced activation was abolished (lanes 11, 15, and 19), because Sp1 is required for efficient Tat transactivation (26, 28).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Surprisingly, overexpression of the combination of Tat and COUP-TF resulted in a 8-14-fold transcriptional stimulation (lanes 12, 16, and 20).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	194	To determine whether this COUP-TF/Tat cooperation requires the cognate HIV-1 TATAA region, we constructed a vector containing the 40/+80 LTR region in which the HIV-1 TATA sequence (TATAAGC) was replaced with the SV40 TATA box (TATTTAT).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Transfection experiments performed with the 40/+80-SV40-TATA-CAT vector showed that COUP-TF or Tat overexpression was unable to stimulate transcription, similar to the results obtained with the nonmutated vector.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	196	 However, overexpression of both COUP-TF and Tat in the presence of the mutated vector did not lead to any increase in CAT activity, indicating that COUP-TF is able to discriminate between different versions of TATAAs (result not shown).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	197	These findings reveal a functional synergism between COUP-TF and Tat, able to transactivate the LTR in the absence of NF-B and Sp1 sites.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	198	 These results further suggest that Tat and COUP-TF are able to interact, directly or indirectly.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	199	Domains of COUP-TF and Tat Involved in the Synergistic Transcriptional Activation-- To investigate which region of COUP-TF was involved in the synergistic effect with Tat, we used the pRSV-COUPdel148 vector expressing a C-terminal truncated form of COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Transfection experiments were performed with 68/+80 LTR-CAT and pRSV-COUPdel148 in the presence or absence of CMV-Tat (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The truncated COUP-TF was unable to stimulate CAT activity (lane 2), because we have shown previously that the C-terminal domain of COUP-TF is essential for its transcriptional activity (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Interestingly, in the presence of Tat, overexpression of the truncated COUP-TF led to a 50% inhibition of Tat-mediated activation (lane 4).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	203	 This result reveals the dominant negative role of the C-terminal truncated protein on Tat activity as well as the importance of the C-terminal region for the synergistic effect with Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	204	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	205	   Domains of COUP-TF and Tat involved in the synergistic transcriptional activation.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	206	 A, microglial cells were transfected with 1 pmol of 68/+80 LTR-CAT vector and 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	207	5 pmol of pRSV-COUPdel148 (lane 2) in the presence (lane 4) or absence (lane 3) of 10 ng of CMV-Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	208	 B, cells were transfected with 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	209	5 pmol of pCMV-Tat 72RP18IS vector, expressing a transactivation-negative Tat protein, in the presence (lane 4) or absence (lane 3) of 0.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Histograms represent CAT activities expressed relative to the value obtained with the corresponding 68/+80 LTR-CAT reporter vector.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments done in duplicate.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	212	To examine the role of a transactivation negative form of Tat on COUP-TF activity, we performed cotransfection experiments using the 68/+80 LTR-CAT and pCMV-Tat 72RP18IS, expressing a transactivation negative Tat protein, in the presence or absence of RSV-COUP-TF (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	213	 As expected, the transactivation negative Tat mutant was unable to stimulate CAT activity (lane 3).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Interestingly, overexpression of this Tat mutant led to a 50% inhibition of COUP-TF-mediated transcriptional stimulation (lane 4).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	215	 This result suggests that the mutated form of Tat is able to inhibit the binding of COUP-TF to Sp1 proteins either by masking the DBD domain of COUP-TF or by competing for interactions with Sp1.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	216	COUP-TF and Tat Interact in Vitro and in Cells-- To decipher the mechanism whereby COUP-TF and Tat mediate a Sp1- and B-independent transcriptional synergistic activation, we examined whether COUP-TF and Tat interact in vitro.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We performed GST pull-down experiments with GST-COUP fusion proteins and 35S-labeled Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Results showed that 35S-labeled Tat (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	219	 7B, lane 1) associates with the GST-COUP-1 fusion protein (lane 3).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Under the experimental conditions, about 1-2% of the total added Tat bound to GST-COUP.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	221	 This association was specific, because Tat bound to GST-COUP-1, but not to the control GST protein alone (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	222	 To localize the domain of COUP-TF that mediates interaction with Tat, we used the GST-COUP-3 expression vector encoding residues 49 to 148 of COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The truncated GST-COUP-3 was still able to mediate association with Tat (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	224	 7A, lane 4), indicating that the N-terminal part of COUP-TF containing the DNA-binding domain (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	225	 7A) is sufficient for interaction with Tat in vitro.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	226	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	227	   The viral protein Tat and the nuclear receptor COUP-TF interact in vitro and in vivo.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	228	 A, schematic representation of the domains present in the Tat protein and in the GST-COUP-TF constructs.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	229	 B, GST-COUP-1 and -3 fusion proteins interact with in vitro translated 35S-Tat in GST pull-down assays.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	230	 35S-Tat (1  microl) (lane 1) was translated in wheat germ lysate using the TNT kit (Promega) and incubated with bacterially expressed GST (5  microg) (lane 2) or GST-COUP-1 and -3 (3  microg) (lanes 3 and 4) immobilized on glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	231	 After extensive washing, the bound proteins were eluted and analyzed by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis followed by autoradiography.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Lane 1, input Tat (1  microl); lanes 2-4, GST and GST-COUP incubated with 35S-Tat (15  microl).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	233	 C, interactions of in vitro translated 35S-COUP-TF with different GST-Tat mutants in GST pull-down assays.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	234	1  microl) (lane 1) was incubated with GST (5  microg) (lane 2) or GST-Tat proteins (3  microg) (lanes 3-7) immobilized on glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	235	 After washing, the bound proteins were eluted and analyzed by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis followed by autoradiography.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	236	1  microl); lanes 2-7, GST and GST-Tat mutants incubated with 35S-COUP-TF (15  microl).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	237	 D, co-immunoprecipitation of Tat and COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Nuclear extracts from microglial cells, previously transfected or not with CMV-Tat, were immunoprecipitated with monoclonal anti-Tat antibodies.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Nuclear protein extracts (10  microg) (lane 1) and immunoprecipitates from 50  microg of nuclear proteins (lanes 2 and 3) were analyzed for the presence of COUP-TF by Western blot analysis.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	240	The Tat protein is composed of distinct structural domains, presented in Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	241	 We examined which domain of Tat associates with COUP-TF, by using various GST-Tat mutants.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	242	 7C shows that the GST fusion proteins containing 86R Tat (lane 3), the truncated 72R Tat (lane 4), and the mutant 72RP18IS Tat containing exon 1 and an insertion between amino acids 18 and 19 (lane 5) were all able to interact with COUP-TF; in contrast, GST fusion proteins Tat 48 and 48P18IS, truncated after amino acid 48, were unable to bind COUP-TF (lanes 6 and 7), similar to the GST control (lane 2).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	243	 About 1-2% of the total added COUP bound to GST-Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	244	 These results indicate that in vitro association of Tat with COUP-TF does not depend on exon 2 and requires the Tat region located between amino acids 48 and 72.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This region is formed by the basic domain, at amino acids 48-58, which is known to mediate specific binding to TAR RNA, and the C-terminal domain, at amino acids 58-72.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	246	We next investigated whether COUP-TF and Tat were able to associate within cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Microglial cells were transfected with the CMV-Tat expression vector (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	248	 7D, lane 3) or left untransfected (lane 2).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Nuclear extracts were used for co-immunoprecipitation experiments.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The ability of monoclonal anti-Tat antibodies to coimmunoprecipitate the COUP-TF protein was visualized by Western blotting with COUP-TF antibodies (Fig.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	251	 These data confirm the existence of a direct association between Tat and COUP-TF within cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	252	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	253	In the present work, we have established the importance of the nuclear receptor COUP-TF as an activator of HIV-1 gene transcription and replication in primary microglia, the main target of HIV-1 in brain.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Overexpression of COUP-TF is able to stimulate viral expression of not only the macrophage-tropic 95.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	255	33 strain but also of the lymphotropic LAI HIV-1 strain, previously described to poorly replicate in microglia (44).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Our findings highlight the unexpected role of COUP-TF, which appears to possess a transactive ability similar to that of the transcription factors Sp1 and NF-IL6.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	257	 These nuclear factors are essential for inducing HIV-1 gene transcription in the immediate-early phase of HIV infection, when viral transcription proceeds at a low rate prior to the participation of viral activating proteins.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Our run-on data show that COUP-TF stimulates transcription by acting at the level of initiation.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	259	The action of these cellular proteins leads to the early phase of HIV infection and to the production of the viral protein Tat (14, 20).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	260	 By a series of in vitro and in vivo experiments, we have demonstrated the existence of a novel physical and functional interaction between the transcription factor COUP-TF and the viral transactivator Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	261	 In vitro GST pull-down experiments indicate that the N-terminal part of COUP-TF containing the DNA-binding domain is sufficient for interaction with Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	262	 In vitro association of Tat with COUP-TF does not depend on exon 2 and requires the Tat region located between amino acids 48 and 72 (formed by the basic domain, which mediates specific binding to TAR RNA) and the C-terminal domain (amino acids 58-72).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Interestingly, the regions involved in the protein-protein interaction are similar to those described for the thyroid hormone receptor, another member of the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	264	 T3R also interacts with Tat through amino acids present in the DNA-binding domain of the receptor; the basic and C-terminal regions of Tat are involved in the binding to T3R (32).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	265	 In addition, our data obtained with microglial cells transfected with a Tat expression vector confirm that Tat and COUP-TF are able to interact directly within cells.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Recent data showed that Sp1 binds Tat amino acids 20-55 (45).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	267	 When these data are considered together, one could suspect that a ternary complex of COUP-TF, Sp1, and Tat represents the functionally important molecule.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	268	 However, we show here that a synergistic effect between COUP-TF and Tat is observed only in the absence of Sp1 sites, whereas the Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins lead to a synergistic transcriptional increase in the presence of Sp1 sites (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	269	 This suggests that COUP-TF interacts preferentially with either Sp1 bound to its DNA site or to Tat bound to the TAR element.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Moreover, Tat and Sp1 both interact with the same N-terminal region of COUP-TF, which further strengthens the idea that the binary complexes COUP-TF/Sp1 and COUP-TF/Tat are functionally important.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	271	A number of reports have demonstrated that the Sp1 and B sequences are required for TAR-dependent transactivation by Tat (26, 28-31, 33).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Here, our studies with various LTR mutants reveal that an interaction between COUP-TF and Tat can lead to NF-B- and Sp1-independent enhanced transactivation of the HIV-1 LTR, in the presence of an intact TAR element.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Previous reports have shown that replication of HIV-1 of which the Sp1 sites had been deleted was efficient in MT4 lymphocytes and in activated peripheral blood lymphocytes and appeared to require NF-B as a substitute for Sp1 (46).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Here, our data suggest an alternative regulatory pathway for Tat transactivation in microglia that is independent of both NF-B and Sp1, through direct interactions of Tat with the nuclear receptor COUP-TF.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	275	The following model may account for the interaction of the nuclear receptor COUP-TF and viral Tat in regulating the HIV-1 LTR.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In the presence of Sp1 sites, the DNA-binding domain of COUP-TF associates with the Sp1 protein bound to its DNA binding site (18).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	277	 In such a situation, COUP-TF is unable to interact with Tat and thus is unable to synergize with Tat.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	278	 In contrast, in the absence of Sp1 sites, COUP-TF appears to be able to recruit Tat and to substitute for the Sp1 protein.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	279	 However, this effect is TAR-dependent and requires binding of Tat to TAR.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	280	 As shown here, the DNA-binding domain of COUP-TF binds to Tat, whereas the C terminus of COUP-TF interacts with the general transcription factor TFIIB, as described previously (47).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	281	 These interactions may thus anchor Tat to the transcriptional apparatus.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	282	 However, this recruitment is insufficient for Tat activity as it does not permit a TAR independent transactivation.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	283	 It is clear that the precise molecular mechanisms need to be further investigated.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	284	The nuclear receptor COUP-TF is known to be ubiquitously expressed, including in T lymphocytes, the main target of HIV-1 in the immune system.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Similar to its action in microglia, COUP-TF functions as a transcriptional activator in lymphocytes, by acting through the Sp1 element of the HIV-1 LTR (48).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Because our data in CNS cells revealed the unexpected role of COUP-TF in the presence of Tat, it will be interesting in further studies to examine the role of COUP-TF in the regulation of various HIV-1 strains in cells of the immune system.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Israel for providing the vector containing the LAI LTR.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Sawaya for providing expression vectors for COUP-TF and LTR-CAT mutants and to K.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Karathanasis for providing the COUP-TF antibodies.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	290	* This work was supported by INSERM (U338 and CRI 96-12), the Agence Nationale des Recherches sur le SIDA, the Fondation pour la Recherche Medicale, Universite Paris-Sud, and the association "Le Cercle d'Emeraude.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	291	"The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	292	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	294	  Recipient of financial support from the association "Ensemble contre le SIDA" and Fondation pour la Recherche Medicale (Sidaction).
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	295	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Gladstone Institute of Virology and Immunology, P.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Box 419100, San Francisco, CA 94141-9100.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	297	: 415-695-3806; Fax: 415-826-1514; E-mail: eschaeffer@gladstone.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	298	The abbreviations used are: HIV-1, human immunodeficiency virus type 1; CNS, central nervous system; LTR, long terminal repeat; COUP-TF, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; PIPES, 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid.
0.30958837.10644726.html.plaintext.txt	299	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.
