0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	350	2 kb full-length clone isolated from a rat liver cDNA expression library (46).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	351	 This cDNA recognizes a single transcript (5.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	352	2 kb) for the 2M message by Northern analysis in tissues examined to date.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Kodak film XAR-5 was from Eastman Kodak Co.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	354	 COUP-TFI cDNA was kindly provided by Dr.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Ming-Jer Tsai, Baylor College of Medicine (Houston, TX).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	356	 cDNA of Stat 5b and its splice variant, Stat 5b40C, were generous gifts from Dr.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Fey, Department of Genetics, University of Erlangen-Nurenberg (Erlangen, Germany).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	358	 A rabbit antiserum IgG fraction generated against the C-terminal peptide of Stat 5a was generously provided by Dr.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Jeffrey Rosen, Baylor College of Medicine (Houston, TX).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Antibodies to phosphotyrosine (PY20) were obtained from Transduction Laboratory (Lexington, KY).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Antibodies were obtained from several sources.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Antibodies to Stat 5b were generous gifts from Dr.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	363	 Lothar Henninghausen, Laboratory of Biochemistry and Metabolism, National Institute of Diabetes, Digestive and Kidney Diseases, NIH (Bethesda, MD); antibodies to SF-1 (Ad4BP) from Dr.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Ken-ichirou Morohashi, Kyushu University (Fukuoka, Japan); and antibodies to COUP-TF from Dr.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Ming-Jer Tsai, Baylor College of Medicine (Houston, TX).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	366	Animals Intact immature Sprague Dawley (23 days old) female rats were obtained from Harlan (Indianapolis, IN) and maintained under a 16-h light, 8-h dark schedule, with food and water ad libitum.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Animals were treated in accordance with the NIH Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	368	 All protocols were approved by the Institutional Committee on Animal Care and Use, Baylor College Of Medicine (Houston, TX).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Rats were delivered on day 23 of age and weighed 50 to 55 g.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Rats were injected sc on days 24 to 26 with 1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	371	Granulosa Cell Culture Ovaries isolated from immature rats primed with 17ss-estradiol were punctured with a 22-gauge needle to isolate granulosa cells.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	372	 The granulosa cells were pooled and treated with trypsin (20  microg/ml) for 1 min, followed by the addition of soybean trypsin inhibitor (300  microg/ml) and DNAse (100  microg/ml) to remove necrotic cells (47).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	373	 After washing the cells twice, they were cultured for 48 h in DMEM-Ham s F12 (DMEM:F12; 1:1) supplemented with a low dose of oFSH (50 ng/ml) and T (10 ng/ml) at 37 C in 95% air and 5% CO2.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Granulosa cells were cultured for 24 h in the absence of FSH and T or for 48 h in the presence of FSH and T (47, 48).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	375	 At each time period, cells were treated with PRL (1  microg/ml) or forskolin (10  microM).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	376	 At indicated time points, total RNA was isolated for Northern analyses, WCEs were prepared for EMSAs, and immunoblots or the cells were used for transient transfections of various expression vectors.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	377	RNA Isolation and Northern Analysis Extraction buffer containing 1% Nonidet P-40 was used for isolation of cytoplasmic RNA from granulosa cells (49).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	378	 RNA samples were extracted with phenol-chloroform, ethanol precipitated, resuspended in water containing 0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	379	1% dimethyl pyrocarbonate, and quantitated by measuring the absorbance at 260 nm.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	380	 For Northern blot analyses, 20  microg RNA were denatured at 55 C for 15 min in 45% formamide-5.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	381	4% formaldehyde and resolved by electrophoresis at room temperature in a formaldehyde-agarose gel.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	382	 To confirm equal loading of RNA samples and to determine the migration of the standards in the RNA ladder, the gel was stained with acridine orange.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	383	 After transfer of the RNA to nylon membranes, the blots were baked, prehybridized, and hybridized with P32-labeled 2M cDNA probe.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	384	 Blots were washed four times, 5 min/wash at room temperature in 2x saline sodium citrate, 0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	385	1% SDS, followed by two washes, 15 min each, in 0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	386	1% SDS at 55 C and exposed to film at -80 C.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	387	Immunoprecipitations and Immunoblot Analyses Protein A on tryacryl beads (30  microl) was incubated with 200  microg WCEs for 1 h at 4 C with shaking.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	388	 After a brief spin, the supernatant was incubated with 1  microl Stat 5b antibody and 20  microl diluted beads for 24 h at 4 C with shaking.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Each of the samples was then washed three times with WCE buffer to remove unbound protein.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Bound proteins were eluted from the beads by addition of an equal volume of SDS-loading buffer and boiled at 100 C for 10 min.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Samples were resolved by 10% one-dimensional SDS-PAGE at 20 mA for 6 to 7 h.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	392	 Electrophoretic transfer to Immobilon polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane was performed at 12 V overnight at 4 C.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	393	 After blocking with 5% milk for 2 h, filters were incubated with PY20 antiphosphotyrosine antibody (1:250).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	394	 The filters were then washed with Tris-buffered saline, 0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	395	05% Tween (20 mM Tris, 150 mM NaCl, pH 7.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	396	 The blots were incubated with 1:10,000 of antirabbit-horseradish peroxidase or antimouse-horseradish peroxidase.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	397	 Filters were then washed six times for 5 min each with TBST.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	398	 ECL reagents were used to detect specific proteins as described by Amersham.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	399	 The same blot was stripped (2% SDS, 50 mM ss-mercaptoethanol, 50 mM Tris, pH 6.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	400	 After extensive washes with TBST, the blot was reprobed with anti-Stat 5b antibody (1:10,000).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	401	Plasmid Constructs The luciferase constructs pSVoA1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	402	2 kb2M (from -1152 to +54 bp) and the Stat mutants have been described previously (16).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	403	 All the luciferase constructs in Fig.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	404	 1 were generated by initially isolating the 1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	405	2-kb HindIII fragment from pSVoA1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	406	2 kb2M and ligating it to pGL3 basic luciferase vector from Promega to obtain 1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	407	 -3712M was generated by ligating the 425-bp fragment (StuI:HindIII digest of the 1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	408	2-kb fragment) to pGL3 Basic SmaI:HindIII site.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	409	 -209 2M was generated by ligating the 298-bp fragment (RsaI:HindIII digest of the 1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	410	2-kb fragment) to pGL3 Basic SmaI:HindIII site.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	411	 -1592M was generated by digesting -3712M with EcoRI and SacI, which deletes the PRLRE.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	412	 -209 2M was digested with EcoRI:PvuII to generate -2092M in which the ORRE is deleted.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	413	 -482M, the minimal 2M promoter, was created by a PvuII digest of -3712M.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	414	 4XGAS2M, containing four copies of the proximal Stat-binding site, has been described previously (16, 24).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	415	 Stat 5b and a splice variant of Stat 5b (Stat 5b-40C) were cloned to the expression vector pSVsport GIBCO BRL (Grandland, NY) and have been described previously (32).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	416	The mutations (indicated in lower case) within the ORRE (Fig.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	417	 5a) of the 2M promoter were created by PCR using the -317 2M as a template.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	418	 The primers used include mutant antisense oligonucleotides to either the COUP-TF (M1) site or the SF-1 site (M2) and the external sense and antisense primers that would hybridize at each end of the promoter region.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	419	 The double mutant was generated with the same external primers, mutant oligonucleotide, and the COUP-TF mutant construct as the template.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	420	 The sequence of the oligonucleotides is as follows:.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	421	mCOUP-TF: 5'-ATtGttTAATTAttGCCAAGGTTAATTCCT-aAttCGTTAGtCAG-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	422	mSF-1: 5'-ATGGCCTAATTACCGCCAAttTTAATTCCTGA-CCCGTTAGTCCAG-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	423	double mutant: 5'-ATTGCCAAttTTAATTCCTAA-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	424	sense: 5'-CGGGGTACCCCGCCTCCTTGCCAACTATT-CC-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	425	antisense: 5'-GTGCAAACAGCTGCTCCCACCC-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	426	Figure 11 is a schematic representation of the PCR-directed mutagenesis.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	427	 The cloning procedure was as described in PCR protocols (50).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	428	 The PCR products were separated and purified by 1.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	429	5% low-melt agarose gel using an overnight ss-agarase digestion (50).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	430	 After the second round of PCR, the purified products were isolated, digested with KpnI and PvuII, and ligated using sites present in the multiple cloning cassette of -371 2M construct.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	431	 All plasmids were sequenced in both directions by Sanger s dideoxy method (50).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	432	View larger version (8K):    Figure 11.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	433	  Transient Transfection Assay Plasmid DNA was purified from bacteria by alkaline lysis and centrifugation on CsCl gradients (51).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	434	 Differentiated granulosa cells in culture were transfected with different plasmid constructs using a calcium phosphate precipitation technique (52).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	435	 After 30 min incubation at room temperature, 300  microl of the precipitate were added to the cultures (3 ml) and incubated for 4 h at 37 C.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	436	 Each construct was transfected in triplicate for each treatment.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	437	 SV40 luciferase construct containing the SV40 promoter enhancer elements was used as a positive control in each of the transfection experiments.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	438	 Cells were then washed twice with Ca++- and Mg++-free HBSS before feeding with fresh DMEM/F12 media containing FSH (50 ng/ml) and T (10 ng/ml) with or without PRL (1  microg/ml) or forskolin (10  microM) for 6 h.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	439	 Cells were then washed with 1x PBS and lysed with lysis buffer (0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	440	 The soluble protein obtained after centrifugation was assayed for luciferase activity using a Monolight 2010 Luminometer (Analytical Luminesence Laboratories, San Diego, CA).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	441	 The luciferase activity in 20  microl of each sample was normalized to the amount of protein, as measured by the Bradford assay (Bio-Rad), and expressed as relative light units/ microg protein.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	442	Oligonucleotides and Nomenclature The functionally active PRLRE of the 2M promoter contains two Stat- binding sites, AACTGGAAA and TTCTGGGAA (GAS) sequences, as described previously (24, 10).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	443	 The sequence of 2MGAS2 oligonucleotide used in EMSA is 5'-GATCATCCTTCTGGGAATTCTGATATCCTTCTGGGAATTC-TG3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	444	 The ORRE sequence shown in Fig.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	445	 5A was used to generate mutant oligonucleotides:.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	446	M1: 5'-CTGaCTAACGaaTtAGGAATTAACCTTGGCAATAA-TTAaaCaAT-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	447	M2: 5'-ATGGCCTAATTACCGCCAAttTTAATTCCTGACCC-GTTAGCCAG-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	448	Sequences of other oligonucleotides used in EMSAs are as follows:.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	449	DR1SF-1: 5'-CTGGCTAACGGGTCAGGAATTAACCTTGG-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	450	DR2SF-1: 5'-GGAATTAACCTTGGCGGTAATTAGGCCAT-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	451	Consensus COUP-TF: 5'-TGTCTTAGAGGTCAAAGGTCAAAT-3' (28).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	452	Hexameric SF-1: 5'-GAGTCTCCCAAGGTCATCCTTGT-TT-3' (6).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	453	Oligonucleotides were synthesized, purified, and provided by Genosys, Inc.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	454	Whole Cell Extracts and EMSA Granulosa cells were cultured with FSH and T for 24 h or 48 h and then treated with or without PRL (1  microg/ml) for 15 min, 6 h, and 20 h.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	455	 The cells were harvested by scraping and lysed by three cycles of freeze thawing to prepare soluble extracts (53).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Protein samples were measured (Bradford; Bio-Rad).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	457	 All samples were stored at -70 C until EMSA and immunoblot analyses were done.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	458	 EMSAs were performed as described previously (54).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	459	 Briefly, WCE (10 to 15  microg per lane) were incubated for 30 min at room temperature with 50,000 to 60,000 cpm of end-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide with or without the competitor DNA and 5  microg poly(deoxyinosinic-deoxycytidylic)acid in a final volume of 20  microl in a buffer containing 100 mM KCl, 15 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	460	5), 5 mM dithiothreitol, 1 mM EDTA, 5 mM MgCl2, and 12% glycerol.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	461	 When antibodies were used, WCEs were incubated with 1  microl of the antiserum for 30 min on ice before addition of the labeled probe.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	462	 Binding reactions were resolved by 5% acrylamide, 0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	463	 Gels were dried under vacuum and heat and exposed to Kodak XAR film at -80 C.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	464	RT-PCR For each RT reaction, 350 ng RNA were reverse transcribed as previously described (55, 56).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	465	 PCR was performed as previously described (55).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	466	 The sequence of primers used for the PRLRs is as follows:.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	467	Forward primer: 5'-ATACTGGAGTAGATGGAGCCAGGAGAGTTC-3' and specific.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	468	Reverse LPRLR: 5'-CTTCCGTGACCAGAGTCACTGTCG-GGATCT-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	469	Reverse SPRLR: 5'-TCCTATTTGAGTCTGCAGCTTCAGTAGTCA-3'.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	470	Primers for L19 were used as an internal control.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	471	 PCR was performed for 20 cycles (Perkin-Elmer/Cetus, Norwalk, CT) with a denaturing temperature of 92 C (1 min), an annealing temperature of 60 C (2 min), and an extension temperature of 72 C (3 min).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	472	 Reaction (20  microl) was electrophoresed on a 5% polyacrylamide gel in 0.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	473	 The gels were dried and the bands quantified with Storm860 PhosphoImager (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	474	 Specific PCR products amplified for the LPRLR-422 bp and the SPRLR-332 bp were normalized to the L19 band from the same sample.
0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	475	 Gels were also exposed to HyperFilm (Amersham) for 6 to 24 h at room temperature.

0.35218814.9731707.html.plaintext.txt	541	 Endocrinology 134:2336 to 2346[Abstract].
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	0	Suppression of Hepatitis B Virus Core Promoter by the Nuclear Orphan Receptor TR4* Wen-Jye Lin , Jie Li  , Yi-Fen Lee, Shauh-Der Yeh, Saleh Altuwaijri, Jing-Hsiung Ou , and Chawnshang Chang.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the  George Whipple Lab for Cancer Research, Departments of Pathology, Urology, Radiation Oncology, and the Cancer Center, University of Rochester Medical Center, Rochester, New York 14642 and the   Department of Molecular Microbiology and Immunology, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, California 90033.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, June 14, 2002, and in revised form, January 8, 2003.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	4	The TR4 orphan receptor is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily that modulates gene expression via binding to the AGGTCA direct repeat hormone response element.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Here we report a functional study of TR4 interaction with the core promoter of the hepatitis B virus (HBV).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The electrophoretic mobility shift assay shows that TR4 can bind to the direct repeat 1 sequence element (AGGTTAAAGGTCT, nucleotide coordinates 1757-1769, TR4RE-HBV) on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	7	 TR4 also can enhance the activity of a synthetic luciferase reporter linked with four copies of TR4RE-HBV in either liver HepG2 or non-liver H1299 cells in a dose-dependent manner.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Surprisingly, TR4 represses the activity of a luciferase reporter containing the entire HBV genome sequences.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Moreover, mutation of this TR4RE-HBV site in the HBV core promoter diminishes the TR4 suppression effect.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This TR4-induced suppression of HBV core promoter activity is further confirmed by primer extension analysis of the HBV core RNAs, showing that TR4 represses both pre-core and core mRNAs.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Further dissection of this repressive mechanism indicates that TR4 may suppress the HBV core promoter activity via repressing HNF4-mediated transactivation by protein-protein interactions without inhibition of HNF4 DNA binding.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Furthermore, our results indicate that the N- and C-terminal regions of TR4 protein are required for TR4-HNF4 interaction.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	13	 It is possible that TR4-HNF4 interaction may block the HNF4 function that results in the suppression of HBV gene expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Together, these results demonstrate that TR4 can serve as a negative modulator in the transcriptional regulation of HBV core gene expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	15	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	16	Hepatitis B virus (HBV)1 is a small virus with a 3.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	17	2-kb partially double-stranded DNA genome, containing four open reading frames: the surface antigen, the core antigen, the polymerase, and the X protein (1, 2).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	18	 HBV is a major pathogen causing acute and chronic liver diseases, such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (3, 4).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	19	 HBV transcripts are regulated by the transcriptional control of four different promoters and two enhancer elements (5).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	20	 HBV is replicated from a RNA intermediate as a template for reverse transcription (1).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The core promoter controls the expression of the 3.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	22	5-kb core mRNA (C mRNA) as the template for replication, and the expression of the pre-core mRNA (pre-C mRNA) for the translation of the HBeAg precursor (6).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Recently, multiple binding sites for liver-specific or ubiquitous transcription factors and several hormone response elements (HRE) have been identified in the core promoter region, including Sp1 (7, 8), TATA-binding protein (9), HNF3 (10), HNF4 (11), C/EBP (12), and other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, such as the retinoid X receptor (RXR), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR), COUP-TF1, and ARP1 (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	24	 For example, HNF4 and RXR/PPAR can stimulate the expression of the 3.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	25	5-kb core RNA, COUP-TF1 suppresses the expression of both the pre-C RNA and C RNA, and TR2 preferentially represses the expression of the pre-C RNA (14).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	26	 These findings suggest that these nuclear receptors may play important roles in viral transcription.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The detailed mechanisms of how the core promoter is differentially regulated by these nuclear receptors remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	28	The testicular orphan receptor 4 (TR4) (NR2C2) is an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily (15-17).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	29	 This family includes classic steroid hormone receptors, the thyroid hormone receptor, the retinoid receptors, and many nuclear orphan receptors whose physiological ligands have not been identified (18).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Members of this superfamily typically contain two major conserved domains, the DNA-binding domain (DBD) and the ligand-binding domain (LBD) (18).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Most nuclear receptors bind to their cognate ligands, translocate into the nucleus, and bind to the specific HREs to turn on their downstream target genes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	32	 TR4 was isolated from human prostate and testis cDNA libraries and is considered to be an orphan receptor, because its ligand has not been found (15).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Our previous data showed that TR4 recognizes different AGGTCA direct repeat (DR) sequences either inducing or suppressing its target genes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For example, TR4 induces reporters containing the DR1 site of human ciliary neurotrophic factor  receptor promoter and the DR4 site of the -myosin heavy chain promoter (19, 20).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In contrast, TR4 suppresses RXR/retinoic acid receptor (DR1), vitamin D3 receptor (DR3), and RXR/PPAR (DR1)-mediated transactivation as shown by the reporter assay (21-23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	36	 These results suggest that TR4 may act as a negative regulator of its target genes containing hormone response elements (HREs) by competition with other nuclear receptors for binding to the HREs (21, 23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	37	 In addition, our previous data showed that TR4 could also suppress androgen receptor-mediated transactivation via protein-protein interaction (22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	38	The distribution of TR4 expression is ubiquitous in many tissues, including the central nervous system, adrenal gland, spleen, thyroid gland, and liver (16, 19, 23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Also, there are many other nuclear receptors expressed in the liver, such as HNF4 (24) and RXR/PPAR (25, 26).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	40	 These findings suggest that these nuclear receptors in the liver can coordinately regulate gene expression by interacting with HRE sequences in the promoters of their target genes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Our data show that TR4 can interfere with a number of other nuclear receptors by competing for binding to the same HREs (21, 22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	42	In this report, we have analyzed the DR1 site in the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	43	 We tested whether the TR4 plays a role in regulating the activity of the core promoter through binding to the HRE-DR1 site.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	44	 We showed that TR4 binds to the DR1 site in the HBV core promoter and strongly activates a reporter containing synthetic DR1 response elements.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Moreover, we demonstrated that TR4 could suppress both pre-C and C RNA expression, which was also confirmed by the luciferase assay using a reporter containing the entire core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Our data further suggest that TR4 may suppress HBV core promoter activity via the interruption of HNF4-induced HBV core promoter by protein-protein interaction with HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	47	 These data demonstrate that TR4 can function as a repressor in liver cells to suppress HBV gene expression and replication.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	48	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	49	Plasmids-- The plasmids CpFL(4)LUC, CpLUC, XpHNF4LUC, and CpM2LUC were gifts from Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	50	 McLachlan (The Scripps Research Institute) and were described previously (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The plasmid pCDNAI-HNF4 was a gift from Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Hadzopoulou-Cladaras (Boston University, Boston, MA).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Guan (University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The pCMX-TR4, pET14b-TR4, pSG5-VDR, and pCMV-TR2 plasmids were constructed as described previously (27, 28).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	55	 pWTDHBV contains the head-to-tail dimer of the wild type HBV genome DNA (adw2) (8).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The GST-TR4, TR4-N-DBD, and TR4-LBD fusion constructs were described in our previous study (29).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The GAL4-HNF4 expression plasmid for one-hybrid assay was made by inserting the PCR-generated BamHI/XbaI fragment (amino acids 1-465) of HNF4 from pCDNAI-HNF4 into pM containing the GAL4 DBD-(1-147) (Invitrogen).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	58	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay-- The EMSA reaction was performed as described previously (20).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Briefly, TR4 and HNF4 proteins for EMSA were transcribed and translated in TNT reticulocyte lysates (Promega), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The oligonucleotide probes for EMSA were end-labeled with [-32P]ATP by T4 polynucleotide kinase (New England BioLabs).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	61	 HepG2 cell nuclear extracts were prepared according to the procedure of Andrew and Faller (30).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The EMSA reactions were performed with 10  microg of nuclear extracts or 2  microl of TNT lysates in an EMSA buffer containing 10 mM Hepes (pH 7.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	63	9), 6% (v/v) glycerol, 2% (v/v) Ficoll, 100 mM KCl, 0.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	64	5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM dithiothreitol.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The reaction mixtures of the proteins and DNA were incubated for 15 min at room temperature.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	66	 For the antibody supershift assay, the mixtures were incubated for another 15 min in the presence or absence of mouse anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody (#15).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The protein DNA complexes were analyzed on a 5% native polyacrylamide gel.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	68	Cell Culture, Transfections, and Luciferase Assays-- HepG2 cells, Huh7 (human differentiated hepatoma cells), H1299 cells, or HepG2.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	69	1 cells (human de-differentiated hepatoma cells) were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium or RPMI supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 2 mM glutamine, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100  microg/ml streptomycin (31).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The cells were plated at 105/well in 12-well dishes (Falcon) and transfected with 1.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	71	2  microg of DNA/well using SuperFect according to the manufacturer's protocol (Qiagen).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The internal control plasmid pRL-TK (Promega) was co-transfected in all transfection experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	73	 After 48 h of transfection, the cells were harvested, and luciferase assays were performed using the Dual-Luciferase kit (Promega).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The HBV transfection experiment was carried out as described previously (8).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	75	Primer Extension Assay-- The primer to map the C gene transcripts was 5'-GGTGAGCAATGCTCAGGAGACTCTAAGG-3', which corresponds to coordinates 2024-2051 of the HBV genomic sequence.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The reaction was performed as previously described (32).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Briefly, The HBV DNA pWTD containing the wild type HBV genome (adw2) was co-transfected with the nuclear receptors into Huh7 hepatoma cells using the calcium phosphate precipitation method.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The pXGH vector served as an internal control for the normalization of transfection efficiency.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	79	 After 48 h of transfection, the RNA was isolated for the primer extension assay (32).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	80	GST Pull-down Assay-- The GST-TR4 fusion protein and GST protein were purified by glutathione-Sepharose beads according to the manufacturer's instructions (Amersham Biosciences).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	81	 HNF4 was synthesized using the in vitro TNT translation system (Promega) in the presence of [35S]methionine, and 5  microl of HNF4 protein was incubated with GST-TR4, TR4-N-DBD, TR4-LBD, or GST beads for the GST pull-down assay as described previously (22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	82	Co-immunoprecipitation of TR4 and HNF4 Proteins-- COS1 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and co-transfected with 10  microg of pCMX-TR4 and either 10  microg of pCDNAI or pCDNAI-HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	83	 48 h after the transfection, the cells were lysed in immunoprecipitation buffer (10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	84	5% Nonidet P-40) containing 1  microg/ml protease inhibitors (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) on ice for 30 min.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The cellular lysates were centrifuged at 12,000  x  g for 10 min.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The protein concentration was measured using the Bradford reagent (Bio-Rad), 500  microg of protein was precleared using protein A/G-Sepharose beads (Santa Cruz Biotechnology), and then the mixture was immunoprecipitated with either an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody or normal mouse IgG (1:100) at 4  degrees C overnight.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Protein A/G beads were added, and the protein lysates were rotated at 4  degrees C for another hour.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The immunocomplexes bound by beads were pelleted and washed with immunoprecipitation buffer three times and then subjected to SDS-PAGE for Western blot analysis using a goat anti-HNF4 polyclonal antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The results were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The same blot was stripped in 62.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	91	8), 2% SDS at 65  degrees C for 30 min and then blotted with an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	92	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	93	TR4 Protein Binds Specifically to the TR4RE-HBV Consensus Site of the HBV Core Promoter-- Previous studies showed that the activity of the HBV core promoter could be differentially regulated by RXR or PPAR via recognizing consensus binding sites on the HBV core promoter (13, 14).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Our previous data also showed that the TR4 has a better affinity than RXR to recognize the DR1-HRE in the promoter of the cellular retinol-binding protein II gene (21).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	95	 To examine whether TR4 can bind to the potential DR1-HRE (named TR4RE-HBV, nucleotide coordinates 1751-1778 of the HBV ayw DNA sequence) on the HBV core promoter (13), the electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) was performed with in vitro translated TR4 protein, using radiolabeled TR4RE-HBV oligonucleotides as probes.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	96	 1, no specific supershift complex was seen with an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody when using mock lysates (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In contrast, the TR4-CpFL supershift complex was observed in the presence of an anti-TR4 antibody using in vitro translated TR4 lysates (lanes 3 and 4).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Moreover, when we replaced wild type TR4RE-HBV with various mutants, we found that TR4 could only bind specifically to the wild type TR4RE-HBV, but not to other mutated TR4RE-HBVs, except for the M3 mutant, which has marginal binding (lanes 5-10).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The M1 double mutant with nucleotides changed from A to T (1765) and G to A (1767) represents the HBV mutant frequently found in the patients with chronic hepatitis (33).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	100	 TR4 was not able to bind to the M1 and M2 mutants (lanes 5 and 6), indicating that the second mutated nucleotide of the DR1-AGGTCA motif is essential for TR4 binding to the TR4RE-HBV.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In addition, a TR4-specific antibody can supershift the TR4 TR4RE-HBV complex (lane 4), and this binding can be reduced in the presence of 100-fold unlabeled TR4RE-HBV probe but not the probe with an androgen response element probes or TR4RE-HBV mutant probes (lanes 11-15), suggesting that the binding between TR4 and TR4RE-HBV is specific.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	102	View larger version (65K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	103	   TR4 binds to the CpFL element of the HBV core promoter in vitro.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	104	 TR4 proteins were in vitro synthesized in TNT reticulocyte lysates (Promega) and then incubated with CpFL or CpFL mutant probes for 30 min in the presence or absence of an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody or various 100-fold unlabeled probes as indicated.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The reaction mixtures were resolved on a 5% acrylamide native gel, and results were visualized by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	106	 ARE denotes the androgen response element.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	107	To further examine whether endogenous TR4 protein can interact with the TR4RE-HBV, nuclear extracts isolated from human HepG2 cells were used in the same EMSA.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	108	 2, no supershift complex was seen when the nuclear extracts were incubated with the double-mutant M1 probe in the presence of an anti-TR4 antibody (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The wild type TR4RE-HBV probe clearly binds with TR4 as indicated by the TR4 TR4RE-HBV antibody supershift complex (lanes 3 and 4).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	110	 This result shows that TR4 protein is present in liver cells and interacts with TR4RE-HBV, suggesting that this interaction may play a role in regulating HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	112	   The nuclear orphan receptor TR4 is an endogenous DR-1 binding protein in HepG2 cells.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The CpFL probe containing the DR-1 site (nucleotide coordinates 1751-1780) or the M1 mutant probe were incubated with 10  microg of protein of nuclear extracts isolated from HepG2 cells.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The EMSA reaction was carried out at room temperature for 30 min in the presence or absence of anti-TR4 or anti-HNF4 antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The reaction complexes were analyzed on 5% acrylamide with 0.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	116	25 x  TBE gels, and the results were visualized by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	117	TR4 Enhances the Activity of a Luciferase Reporter Linked to TR4RE-HBV in Liver HepG2 and Non-liver H1299 Cells-- Our previous data showed that the DR1 consensus sequence (RXRE) from the promoter of cellular retinol-binding protein II could be recognized and suppressed by TR4 (21).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	118	 We were interested in determining whether the binding of TR4 to the TR4RE-HBV could also allow TR4 to regulate HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	119	 A reporter construct containing four synthetic copies of the TR4RE-HBV, CpFL(4)Luc, including the HNF4 consensus binding site, was used to determine the role of TR4 (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	120	 CpFL(4) plasmids were co-transfected with either the parental vector or a TR4 expression vector in liver HepG2, HepG2.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	121	 TR4 can transactivate CpFL(4)Luc activity in a dose-dependent fashion in HepG2, HepG2.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To confirm that the increase in reporter activity is not due to nonspecific activation by TR4, we also used the TR4 deletion mutants and VDR in this reporter assay.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	123	 3 (A-C) the activity of the reporter was only induced in the presence of full-length functional TR4, but not in VDR or the presence of TR4 mutants lacking the C terminus or N terminus, suggesting that the CpFL (TR4RE-HBV) elements of the core HBV promoter may be sufficient for TR4 to regulate HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	124	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	125	   Effects of TR4 on a reporter containing the CpFL(DR1) element of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	126	 A, HepG2 cells were co-transfected with 500 ng of CpFL(4)Luc reporter and increasing amounts of TR4 or VDR (100, 200, and 400 ng).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The cells with VDR transfection were treated with 100 nM vitamin D for 24 h, then harvested for the luciferase assay.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The luciferase assay was performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	129	1 cells were transfected with CpFL(4)Luc and TR4 or VDR, treated, and harvested as in A.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	130	 C and D, HepG2 cells and H1299 cells were co-transfected with CpFL(4)-Luc and the full-length TR4, N/C-terminal deletion of TR4 (TR4/delN and TR4/delC).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The reporter assay was carried out as described in A.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Data represent the means  plus or minus  S.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	133	 of three independent experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	134	TR4 Directly Suppresses HBV Core Promoter Activity through the TR4RE-HBV Site-- The EMSA and reporter assay with CpFL(4)Luc suggest that TR4 may have a significant role in the transcriptional regulation of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	135	 However, the functional role of TR4 in a synthetic promoter context does not necessarily reveal TR4 action in the natural HBV core promoter context.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We therefore examined the effects of TR4 on a reporter construct containing the whole context of the HBV genome sequence (CpLuc) (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Unexpectedly, TR4 suppressed CpLuc reporter activity in HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	138	 In contrast, co-transfection of another nuclear receptor, HNF4, induced CpLuc reporter activity, consistent with an earlier report (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	139	 To confirm that the suppression was mediated by TR4 through binding to the TR4RE-HBV of the HBV core promoter, we also used CpM2Luc containing the mutated TR4RE-HBV to analyze TR4 suppression (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	140	 4B, TR4 suppression of the reporter activity was abolished by mutation of the TR4RE-HBV site.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In contrast, HNF4 was able to induce mutant CpM2Luc reporter activity, possibly due to the presence of another functionally intact HNF4-binding site (lane 4 versus 6) (13, 34).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	142	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	143	   TR4 represses HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	144	 A, HepG2 cells were co-transfected with 750 ng of CpLuc and 250 ng of TR4 or HNF4 vectors or the combination of these two nuclear receptors.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The luciferase activity was measured 48 h after the transfection.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	146	 B, the reporters CpLuc (750 ng) or CpM2Luc were co-transfected with TR4 (250 ng) or HNF4 (250 ng) as indicated, then harvested for the luciferase activity 48 h after the transfection.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Data represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	148	 of three independent experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	149	 PSp, Sp, Xp, and Cp represent the promoters of the genes encoding the HBV surface antigen, X protein, and core/e antigens, respectively.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	150	Because the responsiveness of the HBV core promoter to TR4 was abrogated by this mutation, it is possible that the TR4-mediated suppression of the HBV core promoter is mainly dependent upon the binding between TR4 and the TR4RE-HBV.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Because earlier reports and our current data show that both TR4 and HNF4 can bind to the TR4RE-HBV site, which is overlapped with the HNF4 consensus binding site (13), we postulated that TR4 may exert its repressive effects on the core promoter through competition with other nuclear receptors such as HNF4 for binding to TR4RE-HBV.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	152	 We therefore examined their potential mutual influence on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	153	 When we co-transfected equal amounts of HNF4 and TR4 with the CpLuc reporter in HepG2 hepatoma cells, TR4 repressed HNF4-induced HBV core promoter activity (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	154	 4A, column 3 versus 4), suggesting that HNF4 and TR4 may compete for the same consensus binding site on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Similar suppression of HNF4-mediated transactivation also occurred when we used another reporter containing the HNF4 binding site found in the HBV enhancer I/X promoter overlapped with enhancer I (XpHNF4Luc, HBV coordinates 1133-1159, data not shown) (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	156	Using EMSA with in vitro translated TR4 and HNF4 in the presence of [32P]TR4RE-HBV, we also found that the binding between [32P]TR4RE-HBV and TR4 protein was suppressed by the addition of HNF4 (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	157	 5 demonstrates that TR4 and HNF4 can both bind to the TR4RE-HBV site, and the DNA binding activity of TR4 was markedly reduced in the presence of HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In contrast, we did not observe any change in HNF4 binding when we added TR4, implying that the simple competition may not fully account for TR4-mediated repression of HNF4 function.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	159	 This raises the possibility that TR4 may directly block HNF4 transactivation through protein-protein interactions with HNF4 instead of competing for DNA binding sites.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	160	 4 and 5 suggest that TR4 can bind to the same TR4RE-HBV site as well as interact with HNF4 to influence HBV core promoter expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	162	   HNF4 suppresses TR4 binding to the CpFL element of the HBV core promoter in vitro.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	163	 TR4 and HNF4 proteins were in vitro synthesized in TNT reticulocyte lysates (Promega).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	164	 1  microl of TR4 protein was then incubated with CpFL probes for 15 min in EMSA reaction buffer (10 mM Hepes, pH 7.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	165	9/6% (v/v) glycerol, 2% (v/v) Ficoll, 100 mM KCl, 0.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	166	5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM dithiothreitol) in the presence or absence of the HNF4 protein.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The reaction mixtures were resolved on a 5% acrylamide native gel, and results were visualized by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The double asterisks indicate that the repression of TR4 DNA by HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	169	Interaction between HNF4 and TR4-- The data shown above suggest that TR4 may regulate the transcriptional activity of HNF4 by a mechanism that is independent from the competition for DNA binding.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	170	 To prove this hypothesis, we constructed a plasmid encoding GAL4-HNF4 fusion protein and examined the effect of TR4 expression on HNF4-mediated transactivation in the GAL4 one-hybrid system (35).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	171	 In this assay, the transcriptional activity of GAL4-HNF4 is independent of the binding of HNF4 and TR4 to their cognate binding site, DR1-HRE.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	172	 If TR4 can directly regulate HNF4 transcriptional activity, we should see the activity of GAL4-HNF4 would be significantly changed in the presence of TR4 expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	173	 HepG2 cells were co-transfected with GAL4-HN4 and the pG4LUC reporter in the presence or absence of the expression of the TR4 N- or C-terminal deletion of TR4 mutants.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	174	 6A, the reporter activity with GAL-HNF4 alone was increased about 3-fold, which was similarly shown by the previous study (35).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Interestingly, the expression of TR4 significantly increased the GAL4-HNF4-mediated transcriptional activation (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	176	 6A), indicating that TR4 can directly regulate the transcriptional activity of HNF4, which is independent of the event of the DNA binding and possibly mediated by protein-protein interactions.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	177	 As expected, the PG4LUC reporter activity with the GAL4 and TR4 was not increased at any significant level (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	178	 6A, columns 1 versus 6), suggesting TR4 influences HNF4 transcriptional activity in a specific manner.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Nevertheless, it is not clear how this regulation involving the interaction between TR4 and HNF4 would result in either activation or suppression of HNF4 function.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	180	 In contrast, the N- or C-terminal deletion of TR4 mutants did not show any effects on the GAL4-HNF4-mediated transactivation, suggesting that these two regions of TR4 protein may be required for TR4 action in this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	182	   Interaction between TR4 and HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	183	 A, diagrammatic representation of the GAL4 hybrid assay.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	184	 This assay was used to test the effect of TR4 on HNF4-mediated transcriptional activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	185	 HepG2 cells were co-transfected PG4LUC, which contains four tandem repeats of the GAL4-binding sites, with GAL4-HNF4, TR4, or TR4 deletion mutants.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	186	 B, in vitro synthesized [35S]methionine-labeled HNF4 protein was incubated with GST, GST-TR4, GST-TR4-N-DBD, and GST-TR4-LBD fusion protein bound to glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The beads were extensively washed after the reaction and applied to 12% SDS-PAGE followed by autoradiography.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	188	 C, COS1 cells were transfected pCMX-TR4 with either parental vector or pCDNAI-HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	189	 After the transfection, the cells were cultured for 48 h, lysed for the immunoprecipitation assay, and the HNF4 signal was detected by Western blotting with a goat anti-HNF4 antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The results were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Then, the same blot was stripped and blotted with an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	192	 D, HepG2 cells were transfected CpLUC with HNF4, TR4, or TR4 deletion mutants as described in Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	193	Next, we hypothesized that TR4 may directly regulate HNF4 transcriptional activity through interacting with HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	194	 To test this hypothesis, we applied the GST pull-down assay to determine the potential interaction between HNF4 and TR4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	195	 6B, HNF4 protein was pulled down and detected by SDS-PAGE from the mixture of 35S-labeled in vitro translated HNF4 protein incubated with GST-TR4, GST-TR4-N-DBD, or GST-TR4-LBD fusion protein immobilized on glutathione-linked Sepharose beads.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	196	 6B (lane 3) clearly demonstrated that HNF4 interacts with TR4 in vitro.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	197	 However, the interaction of the deletion mutants of GST-TR4 fusion protein with HNF4 is much weaker, suggesting that instead of direct competition for binding to the TR4RE-HBV, TR4 may interact with HNF4, which could possibly result in the repression of HNF4 function.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	198	 To further confirm this interaction in liver cells, we co-transfected TR4 and HNF4 into COS1 cells and used a co-immunoprecipitation assay to immunoprecipitate the TR4 and HNF4 complex by an anti-TR4 monoclonal antibody.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	199	 6C (lane 4), we can clearly observe HNF4 bands in the precipitated complex by Western blotting when co-expressing TR4 and HNF4 proteins in COS1 cells.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	200	 This result suggests that TR4 can bind to HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	201	In summary, the results presented above demonstrate that TR4 is capable of regulating HNF4 transcriptional activity by interacting with HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Also, the full-length of TR4 is essential for this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	203	 We further compared the effects of TR4 on HNF4-mediated transactivation on the CpLUC reporter with deletion mutants of TR4 in HepG2 cells using transient transfection assay (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	204	 As expected and similar to the result shown in Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	205	 4A, TR4 suppresses HNF4-mediated transactivation (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	206	 However, the N- or C-terminal deletion of TR4 did not exhibit similarly suppressive effects as those of the full-length TR4 did (column 4 versus 7 and 8), implying that these two domains are essential in the protein-protein interaction of TR4 and HNF4, and this interaction is required for the repressive action of TR4 on the transcriptional activity of HNF4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	207	Suppression of HBV Pre-core and Core mRNA Expression by TR4-- To further confirm the suppression of HBV core promoter activity by TR4, we applied a primer extension assay to see if TR4 can also influence mRNA expression of two HBV transcripts from the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The first transcript is pre-C mRNA, which is the precursor of HBeAg; the other transcript is C mRNA, serving as the template for reverse transcription (6, 36).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	209	 HBV RNA extracted from Huh-7 after the co-transfection of TR4 and HBV vectors was mapped with radiolabeled HBV primer at position 2024-2051 of the HBV genome (8).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	210	 7, the expression of both pre-C and C mRNAs was decreased in the presence of TR4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	211	 This result therefore confirms the reporter assays showing that TR4 can suppress HBV core promoter transcription via binding to the TR4RE-HBV site on the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	212	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	213	   Primer extension analysis of the effect of TR4 on HBV pre-core and core RNA expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	214	 HBV RNA isolated from Huh-7 cells transfected with HBV DNA and TR4 or the parental vector of TR4 as indicated was analyzed by primer extension assay as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	215	" Briefly, the products of the primer extension were subjected to electrophoresis on an 8% sequencing gel.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The locations of the core, pre-core, and human growth hormone (hGH) RNA are indicated.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The hGH served as an internal control.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The results were visualized by autoradiography and quantified by Sigma scan software.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The value of the quantification represents three independent experiments.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	220	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	221	Earlier studies have identified two consensus DR1 binding sites for nuclear receptors in the HBV promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	222	 One such site (TGAACCTTTACCC, nucleotide coordinates 1138-1150), is located in the core domain of enhancer I and is recognized by HNF4, COUP-TF1, and RXR-PPAR (37).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The other site (AGGTTAAAGGTCT, nucleotide coordinates 1757-1769) is located in the core promoter that can be recognized by HNF4 and TR4 as described in current studies (13).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The detailed mechanisms of how these nuclear receptors modulate HBV gene expression via these two DR1 sites remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Our data strongly suggest that TR4 preferentially binds the DR1 site of the core promoter, because TR4 suppression is abrogated if this site is mutated (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	226	 The selective binding of TR4 to the 2nd DR1 site may be a key step for TR4 to prevent other nuclear receptors from binding to this site, thereby repressing transcription.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	227	 However, we cannot rule out the possibility that TR4 may also regulate HBV gene expression through the DR1 site of enhancer I, because our data indicate that TR4 can recognize this site (data not shown).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Moreover, because TR4 binding to the 2nd DR1 site is prevented by two mutations ((1756 (A to T) and 1767 (G to A)), which are frequently found in patients with chronic hepatitis, one may speculate that HBV may utilize these two mutations to escape suppression mediated by TR4 and/or other transcriptional repressors.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Alternatively, creation of new mutations at these consensus DR1 sites may be able to increase the opportunity for other modulators to regulate HBV expression via these mutated DR1 sites (32).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	230	TR4 is highly homologous with another orphan receptor, TR2 (15).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Earlier studies indicated that TR2 and TR4 could modulate the expression of a set of genes through binding to the same HREs (19, 38).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	232	 (14) reported that TR2 could only repress pre-C RNA, but not C RNA expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Our current data show that TR4 can repress both pre-C RNA and C RNA expression.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Moreover, compared with the marginal suppression of TR2 on CpLuc reporter activity, TR4 has a much stronger suppressive effect on CpLuc reporter activity (data not shown), suggesting that TR4 may play a significant role in this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Also, our data suggest that simple competition for binding to the DR1 site by these two nuclear receptors may not fully account for their distinct regulation of HBV core gene expression, because both nuclear receptors regulate target genes through binding to the DR sites (19, 38).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The detailed mechanisms underlying the distinct regulation of HBV gene expression by these two closely related orphan receptors remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The interaction of TR4 and HNF4 suggests that the TR4 affects HBV gene expression at multiple levels, most importantly, including the DNA binding and protein-protein interactions.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Nevertheless, previous reports also suggested that COUP-TF could differentially modulate target gene expression via similar HREs.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	239	 For example, COUP-TF1 can induce the 7-hydroxylase promoter activity via the DR4 binding site and repress myosin heavy chain promoter activity via a similar DR4 binding site (39).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Similar differential modulation of target gene expression also occurred with TR4, via binding to similar DR1 binding sites (21, 23).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	241	The contrasting effects of TR4 on the synthetic TR4RE-HBV versus the entire HBV promoter (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	242	 3 versus 4) suggest that promoter context, especially sequences other than the TR4RE-HBV, may also play important roles for TR4 to modulate HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	243	 It is possible that sequences flanking the TR4RE-HBV may recruit one or more repressors that can cooperate with TR4 to form a protein complex to repress HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In addition, we have examined the effects of TR4 on HBV core promoter activity in non-liver cells and found that TR4 was able to induce the luciferase activity of the Cpluc reporter in H1299 cells (data not shown).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This interesting finding implies that some cellular factors in liver cells may modulate the transcriptional activity of TR4 in the regulation of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	246	 However, the detailed mechanisms of this distinct regulation by TR4 remain unclear.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	247	TR4 may modulate its target gene expression via two distinct mechanisms.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	248	 First, TR4 can suppress target gene expression via competition with other nuclear receptors, such as RXR (DR1), VDR (DR3), and retinoic acid receptor  (DR5), for the same consensus HRE sites (21, 22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Previous studies showed that ligand-activated RXR/PPAR or PPAR can increase HBV core promoter activity through the TR4RE-HBV site (DR1) (13, 14).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Therefore, it appears that TR4 may compete for the same binding site with these nuclear receptors resulting in repression of HBV core promoter activity, which this regulation does not involve in any interaction between TR4 and other nuclear receptors (21, 22).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Second, TR4 can also modulate gene expression via protein-protein interactions with other nuclear receptors.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	252	 For example, TR4 can suppress androgen target genes through interactions with the androgen receptor (40).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	253	 In the current study, we found TR4 cannot only bind to the same DR1 site on HBV core promoter as HNF4 (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	254	 5), but also interact with HNF4 (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The TR4-mediated repression resulted from this interaction was confirmed by using TR4 deletion mutants in several parallel experiments and may further support that there might be multiple mechanisms by which TR4 proceeds in this repressive regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Previous studies showed that TR2, a close member of TR4 family, and RIP140 (receptor-interacting protein 140), one of TR4-interacting proteins, can interact and recruit histone deacetylases for gene silencing (22, 41, 42).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	257	 It is possible that TR4 may carry out this repression through similar mechanisms, which would be an interesting direction for our future study to test the involvement of histone deacetylases in this regulation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	258	On the other hand, in HBV-infected liver cells, the repressive function of TR4 may be unfavorable to the HBV replication because the core promoter controls the transcription of the template C RNA for viral DNA synthesis.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	259	 We speculate that the functional association of TR4 and HNF4 could be a unique way to relieve TR4-mediated repression, because HNF can reduce TR4 binding to the DR1 site through either competition for DNA binding or protein-protein interactions (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The underlying mechanisms of how these nuclear receptors differentially influence the transcription activation of HBV genes during infection will require more extensive study.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	261	 8, TR4 can directly bind to the TR4RE-HBV and therefore prevent other nuclear receptors from activating the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Alternatively, TR4 can interact with nuclear receptors, such as HNF4, to form an inactive protein complex.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Either of these two activities may result in the suppression of HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	264	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	265	   Schematic diagram of the regulation of the HBV core promoter by TR4 through the DR1 (TR4RE-HBV) site.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	266	 This figure depicts a simple model of the HBV core promoter and the regulation of this promoter via TR4RE-HBV by TR4.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	267	 A, The binding of TR4 to the TR4RE may restrict the accessibility of this site to other essential nuclear receptors for transcriptional activation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Also, the interaction of HNF4 and TR4 inhibits HNF4 transcriptional activity and results in the suppression of the HBV core promoter activity.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	269	 B, during natural infection, by an unknown mechanism, the interaction of HNF4 and 2R4 may prevent TR4 from binding to the DR1 site (Fig.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Therefore, this regulation can relieve TR4-mediated repression and allow HNF4 or other nuclear receptors to proceed to the transcriptional activation.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	271	In conclusion, this study provides evidence that TR4 is a transcriptional repressor of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The interaction of TR4 and HNF4 further extends the scope of nuclear receptor regulation of the HBV core promoter.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The transcriptional activation of the core promoter is a key step to initiate the life cycle of HBV during the infection (34).
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	274	 By identifying of physiological ligand(s) for TR4, we may be able to control agonist or antagonist binding to TR4 to modulate HBV gene expression, which may provide a novel strategy to develop anti-HBV drugs.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Alan McLachlan for the HBV reporter plasmids, Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Margarita Hadzopoulou-Cladaras for the HNF4 plasmid, and Dr.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Kung-Liang Guan for the pG4LUC.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	278	 We are grateful to Karen Wolf and Erik R.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Sampson for the preparation of the manuscript.

0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	281	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.

0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	286	: 585-273-4500; Fax: 585-756-4133; E-mail: chang@urmc.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	287	Published, JBC Papers in Press, January 8, 2003, DOI 10.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	288	The abbreviations used are: HBV, hepatitis B virus; TR4, testicular receptor 4; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 ; DR, direct repeat; RXR, retinoid X receptor; PPAR, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor ; TR2, testicular receptor 2; C mRNA, core mRNA; pre-C mRNA, pre-core mRNA; C, core; HRE, hormone response element; COUP-TF1, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor 1; VDR, vitamin D receptor; DBD, DNA-binding domain; LBD, ligand-binding domain; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; GST, glutathione S-transferase.
0.40115005.12522137.html.plaintext.txt	289	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.
