0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	0	Regulation of Retinoic Acid-induced Inhibition of AP-1 Activity by Orphan Receptor Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor* Feng Lin, Siva Kumar Kolluri, Guo-quan Chen, and Xiao-kun Zhang.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Burnham Institute, Cancer Center, La Jolla, California 92037.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, February 25, 2002, and in revised form, April 2, 2002.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	4	Retinoids are therapeutically effective in the treatment of various cancers, and some of the therapeutic action of retinoids can be ascribed to their potent inhibition of AP-1 activity that regulates transcription of genes associated with cell growth.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We recently reported that the expression of orphan receptor chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor (COUP-TF) plays a role in mediating the growth inhibitory effect of trans-retinoic acid (trans-RA) in cancer cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	6	 To gain insight into the molecular mechanism by which COUP-TF regulates trans-RA activity, we evaluated the effect of COUP-TF on antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Our results demonstrated a positive correlation between COUP-TF expression and the ability of trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity in various cancer cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In transient transfection assay, expression of COUP-TF strongly inhibited tumor promoter 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate-induced AP-1 transactivation activity and transactivation of c-Jun/c-Fos in both a trans-RA-dependent and -independent manner.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In vitro studies demonstrated that the addition of COUP-TF inhibited c-Jun DNA binding through a direct protein-protein interaction that is mediated by the DNA binding domain of COUP-TF and the leucine zipper of c-Jun.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231 breast cancer cells restored the ability of trans-RA to inhibit 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate-induced c-Jun expression.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The effect of COUP-TF in enhancing the trans-RA-induced antagonism of AP-1 activity required expression of retinoic acid receptors (RARs), since stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative HT-1376 bladder cancer cells, which do not express RAR and RAR, failed to restore trans-RA-induced AP-1 repression.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Thus, COUP-TF, through its physical interaction with AP-1, promotes anticancer effects of retinoids by potentiating their anti-AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	13	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	14	Retinoids, the natural and synthetic vitamin A analogs, exert profound effects on many biological processes, including cell proliferation and differentiation (1, 2), and are recognized as promising agents for the prevention and treatment of various cancers.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The effects of retinoids are mainly mediated by two nuclear receptor classes, the retinoic acid receptor (RAR)1 and retinoid X receptor (RXR) (3-5).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Both are encoded by three different genes (, , and ) and function as ligand-inducible transcription factors in vivo mainly as RXR/RAR heterodimers.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	17	 trans-Retinoic acid (trans-RA) binds RARs, whereas 9-cis-RA binds both RARs and RXRs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Binding of retinoids to their receptors induces receptor conformational changes that switch on transcription of genes containing RA response elements (RAREs) (3-5).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In addition to their positive regulation of RARE-containing genes, retinoid receptors, in response to their ligands, can inhibit effects induced by the tumor promoter 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA) and the transcriptional activity of the proto-oncogenes c-Jun and c-Fos (6), which are components of the AP-1 complex, which often has a role in cancer cell proliferation (7).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The activation of AP-1-responsive genes by TPA or c-Jun/c-Fos through TPA response elements (TREs) is repressed by retinoid receptors in a ligand-dependent manner (8-10).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Conversely, AP-1 represses transactivation of retinoid receptors (8, 9).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This mutual antagonism appears to play a critical role in regulating cell growth and differentiation (6).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	23	 For example, overexpression of c-Jun conferred retinoid resistance to breast cancer cells (11), while overexpression of retinoid receptors enabled trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity in ovarian cancer cells and their growth (12).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The functional interaction between AP-1 and retinoid receptors is also observed for other nuclear receptors, including glucocorticoid receptor (13-16), thyroid hormone receptor (17), vitamin D receptor, estrogen receptor (18, 19), and androgen receptor (AR) (18).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	25	The anti-AP-1 activities shown by liganded retinoid receptors appear to contribute significantly to the therapeutic efficacy of retinoids against hyperproliferative diseases (6).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Transcription of various AP-1-responsive genes, such as collagenase and stromelysin, which have roles in tumor progression and invasiveness (20), is inhibited by retinoids (8-10) and has been reported to contribute to their reversal of human bronchial epithelial squamous differentiation (21).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Retinyl methyl ether, which effectively prevents mammary cancer in animals, strongly suppressed AP-1 activity in breast cancer cell (22).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Interestingly, RAR, a negative regulator of cancer cell growth (23), potently inhibits AP-1 activity and collagenase expression in both breast and lung cancer cells (24).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Recent studies demonstrate that retinoids that specifically inhibit AP-1 activity but antagonize RAR transactivation on RAREs inhibited the growth of many different types of cancer cells (25-27).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Anti-AP-1 retinoids inhibited squamous differentiation of human bronchial epithelial cells (21), TPA-induced transformation and the clonal growth of the promotion-sensitive JB6 mouse epidermal cell line (28), and papilloma formation in animals (29).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Thus, anti-AP-1 activity of retinoids contributes to their chemopreventive and chemotherapeutic effects, presumably by blocking the processes of tumor promotion and cell transformation.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	32	The mechanism by which retinoids inhibit AP-1 activity remains largely unclear.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Unlike the effect of retinoid receptors on RAREs, inhibition of AP-1 activity by retinoid receptors is independent of retinoid receptor-RARE interaction (8-10).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Previous studies suggested several possible mechanisms for AP-1 inhibition by retinoid receptors.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	35	 First, retinoid receptors are reported to physically interact with c-Jun and/or c-Fos (8, 9).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	36	 This interaction results in the mutual inhibition of their DNA binding and transactivation functions and could explain the cross-talk occurring between AP-1 and retinoid signaling.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	37	 However, a large excess of either retinoid receptor protein or c-Jun and c-Fos proteins was required to inhibit in vitro binding to the TRE or RARE, respectively (8, 9).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Because the in vivo footprint assay for glucocorticoid receptor and AP-1 interaction did not reveal any effect on DNA binding (30), whether RAR and AP-1 directly interact in vivo remains to be established.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Subsequently, it was suggested that blocking activation of the Jun N-terminal kinase signaling pathway that activates AP-1 might be responsible for AP-1 inhibition by retinoid and other nuclear receptors (31).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Although this mechanism may explain how retinoids inhibit AP-1 activity under some conditions, it does not address how mutual inhibition occurs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Recent results suggest that the molecular basis of receptor-mediated inhibition of AP-1 transcriptional activation might be due to competition for a common coactivator, such as the cAMP-response element-binding protein (CBP), which is required for transcriptional activation by both the AP-1 complex and RARs (32).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	42	 However, a domain of RAR capable of inhibiting AP-1 activity, such as the DNA-binding domain (33), does not interact with CBP (32).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The development of retinoids that specifically inhibit AP-1 activity without transactivating RARs (25, 26) also argues against the involvement of RAR coactivators in RARs-AP-1 cross-talk.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Thus, the availability of CBP is unlikely to be the sole modulator of RAR and AP-1-signaling pathways, and other adapter proteins may be involved in the antagonism of AP-1 activity by RARs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	45	Recent studies demonstrate that orphan receptor COUP-TF is involved in regulation retinoid responses (34, 35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	46	 COUP-TF is encoded by two distinct genes, COUP-TFI (EAR-3) (36, 37) and COUP-TFII (ARP-1) (38).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Both show exceptional homology and overlapping expression patterns, suggesting their redundant functions (39).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	48	 COUP-TF can modulate retinoid responses through either its high affinity binding to various RAREs or its heterodimerization with RXR (40-43).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	49	 We previously reported that COUP-TF expression was required for cancer cell growth inhibition by trans-RA (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	50	 We further demonstrated that the effect of COUP-TF is partly due to its induction of RAR that mediates growth inhibition by retinoids in various cancer cells (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	51	To further understand how COUP-TF is involved in the regulation of trans-RA activity in cancer cells, we investigated the effect of COUP-TF on antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Our data demonstrate that COUP-TF expression in various cancer cell lines correlated with the ability of trans-RA to suppress AP-1 transcriptional activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In addition, we found that COUP-TF effectively suppressed AP-1 transcriptional activity by interacting with c-Jun to cause loss of c-Jun DNA binding.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	54	 This interaction required COUP-TF DNA-binding domain and the c-Jun leucine-zipper domain.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Although AP-1 inhibition by COUP-TF did not require trans-RA, COUP-TF strongly potentiated the AP-1 antagonism by trans-RA when RARs were expressed.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Our results demonstrate that interaction between COUP-TF and AP-1 is involved in regulating anti-AP-1 activity of retinoids in cancer cells and suggest that COUP-TF plays a role in the cross-talk between retinoid and AP-1 signalings.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	57	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	58	Cell Culture-- HeLa ovarian and MDA-MB231 breast cancer cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS); Calu-6 lung cancer and HT-1376 bladder cancer cells were grown in MEM containing 10% FCS; and T-47D and ZR-75-1 breast cancer and H292 lung cancer cells were grown in RPMI-1460 medium with 10% FCS.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	59	Plasmid Construction-- CAT reporter constructs TRE-tk-CAT and 73Col-CAT have been described (8, 17, 22, 24), as have expression vectors for RAR, COUP-TF, c-Jun, and c-Fos (8, 17, 22, 24, 44).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	60	 pcDNA3-COUP-TFII C-terminal deletion mutants pcDNA3-COUP-TFII7, pcDNA3-COUP-TFII30, and pcDNA3-COUP-TFII108 were generated as described (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	61	 pcDNA3-COUP-TFII N-terminal deletion mutants were constructed by cloning PCR products from COUP-TFII into pcDNA3 (Stratagene) using the following forward primers: TATAGGTACCATGGCGCCGCCCGTGCCC for pcDNA3-COUP-TFIIN25; ATATGGTACCATGACGCCAGCCCAGACG for pcDNA3-COUP-TFIIN50; AATTGGTACCATGCACATCGAGTGCGTG for pcDNA3-COUP-TFIIN75; and ATTAGGTACCATGCACCATCGCAACCAG for pcDNA3COUPTFIIN125.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The oligonucleotide GTGGCAGTTGAGGGGATCC was used as the reverse primer for these mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	63	Transient and Stable Transfection Assays-- HeLa cells (1  x  105 cells/well) were plated in 24-well plates for 16-24 h before transfection as described (34, 35, 45), and other cancer cells (5  x  105 cell/well) were seeded in six-well plates.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	64	 A modified calcium phosphate precipitation procedure was used for transient transfections (34, 35, 45).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Briefly, 200 ng of reporter plasmid, 100 ng of -galactosidase of expression vector (pCH 110; Amersham Biosciences), and various amounts of each expression vector were mixed with carrier DNA (pBluescript) to give 1000 ng of total DNA/well.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	66	 CAT activity was normalized for transfection efficiency to the responding -Gal activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	67	 For stable transfections, the pRC/CMV-COUP-TF recombinant was transfected into MDA-MB231 and HT-1376 cells by the calcium phosphate precipitation method, and the stable clones were screened with G418 (Invitrogen) as described (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Integration and expression of transfected cDNA were determined by Southern blotting and Northern blotting, respectively.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	69	Preparation of Receptor Proteins-- Receptor proteins for RAR, TR3, COUP-TF, and its mutants were synthesized by in vitro transcription-translation using rabbit reticulocyte lysates (Promega) as described previously (34).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Amounts of translated proteins were determined by [35S]methionine incorporation and SDS-PAGE with quantitation by incorporated radioactivity after normalization relative to methionine content.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	71	Gel Retardation Assay-- A fragment of the collagenase promoter region 73 to +63 containing one AP-1-binding site (TRE) was excised from a collagenase-CAT construct (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In addition, the AP-1 binding sequence 5'-GATCCGGATGAGTCACCA-3' was synthesized.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Two fragments were labeled with [32P]dCTP for use as probes for protein-DNA interaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In vitro translated protein was incubated with the probe in a 20- microl reaction mixture containing 10 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	75	9, 50 mM KCl, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 2.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	76	5 mM MgCl2, 10% glycerol, and 1  microg of poly(dI-dC) at 25  degrees C for 15 min.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	77	 DNA-protein complexes were resolved on 5% nondenaturing polyacrylamide gels, and then gels were dried and analyzed by autoradiography.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	78	GST Pull-down Assay-- To prepare glutathione S-transferase (GST)-c-Jun or GST-c-Jun mutant fusion proteins, each c-Jun DNA or c-Jun mutant fragment was cloned in frame into the expression vector pGEX-3X (Amersham Biosciences).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Fusion proteins were expressed in bacteria using the manufacturer's procedure and analyzed by gel retardation assays and Western blotting (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	80	 To determine the interaction between COUP-TF and c-Jun, the fusion proteins were immobilized on glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The vector protein (GST), prepared under the same conditions as a control, was also immobilized.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Beads were preincubated with bovine serum albumin (1 mg/ml) at room temperature for 5 min.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	83	 35S-labeled in vitro translated COUP-TF proteins (2-5  microl, depending on translation efficiency) were then added to the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The beads in 200  microl in EBC buffer (140 mM NaCl, 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	85	5% Nonidet P-40, 100 mM NaF, 200 mM sodium orthovanadate, and 50 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	86	0) were rocked continuously for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	87	 After washing 5 times with NETN buffer (100 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	88	5% Nonidet P-40), bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	89	Northern Blotting-- For Northern analysis, total RNAs were prepared using an RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Total RNA (30  microg) from different cell lines treated with or without trans-RA (106 M) in the presence or absence of TPA (100 ng/ml) was analyzed by Northern blotting as described (46).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	91	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	92	Correlation between COUP-TF Expression and Inhibition of AP-1 Activity by trans-RA-- We recently reported that expression of COUP-TF is required for growth inhibition and apoptosis induction by trans-RA in various cancer cells (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Since inhibition of AP-1 activity by retinoids is known to contribute to their anticancer effects, we studied whether COUP-TF expression was involved in the process.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The effect of trans-RA on inhibiting AP-1 activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	95	 1A) was evaluated in COUP-TF-positive T-47D and ZR-75-1 breast cancer and Calu-6 lung cancer cell lines and in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231 breast cancer, H292 lung cancer, and HT-1376 bladder cancer cell lines (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	96	 AP-1 activity induced by TPA was determined by transient transfection using the reporter 73Col-CAT, which contains a TRE that binds AP-1 (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	97	 TPA-induced reporter activity was strongly inhibited in a trans-RA-dependent manner in the COUP-TF-positive ZR-75-1, T-47D, and Calu-6 cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In contrast, trans-RA showed very little effect on TPA-induced 73Col-CAT activity in the COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376 cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Thus, COUP-TF expression correlates positively with the ability of trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 transcriptional activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (40K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	101	   COUP-TF expression and trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity correlate in cancer cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A, inhibition of TPA-induced collagenase promoter activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected into the indicated cancer cell lines.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	104	 After transfection, the cells were incubated in DMEM medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	105	5% FCS for 24 h and treated with either TPA (100 ng/ml) alone or with the indicated concentrations of trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	106	 After 12 h, the cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The activities of cotransfected -galactosidase were used as controls for transfection efficiency.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	108	 B, effect of COUP-TF expression in COUP-TF-negative cancer cell lines on inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected with or without COUP-TF into COUP-TF-negative cancer cell lines (MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Cells were incubated in medium (see "Experimental Procedures") containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	111	5% FCS for 24 h and then treated with either TPA (100 ng/ml) alone or with 106 M trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	112	 After 12 h, cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The activities of cotransfected -galactosidase were used as reference values.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	114	Trans-RA-dependent and -independent Antagonism of AP-1 Activity by COUP-TF-- The positive association between COUP-TF expression and trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity suggested that COUP-TF was required for trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity and that the absence of COUP-TF expression in MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376 cells might be responsible for the lack of trans-RA activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Therefore, we transiently transfected the COUP-TF expression vector and the 73Col-CAT reporter into the COUP-TF-negative cell lines, in which trans-RA did not inhibit AP-1 transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Upon COUP-TF transfection, trans-RA inhibited TPA-induced reporter activity in both MDA-MB231 and H292 cells in a COUP-TF concentration-dependent manner.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Interestingly, COUP-TF transfection alone produced some inhibition of AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	118	 This observation suggested that COUP-TF inhibited AP-1 activity in both trans-RA-dependent and -independent manners in MDA-MB231 and H292 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	119	 When evaluated in HT-1376 cells, COUP-TF expression was able to inhibit AP-1 activity independently of trans-RA (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	120	 However, it failed to confer the ability of trans-RA to inhibit TPA-induced reporter activity, even at high transfection levels, suggesting that trans-RA-dependent inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF is impaired in this cell line.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	121	The above results suggested that COUP-TF alone inhibited AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	122	 We then examined the anti-AP-1 activity of COUP-TF in HeLa cells, in which TPA strongly induced the transcription of the transfected 73Col-CAT reporter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Similar to that observed in other cancer cell lines (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	124	 1B), COUP-TFI cotransfection inhibited TPA-induced reporter activity in a COUP-TFI concentration-dependent manner (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Cotransfection of COUP-TFII produced almost identical results (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Activation of collagenase promoter by TPA occurs mainly through induction of AP-1 activity that activates the TRE in the promoter (7).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We therefore examined whether COUP-TF expression also interfered with transactivation activity of c-Jun homodimer and c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimer.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Cotransfection of 73Col-CAT with the c-Jun expression vector into HeLa cells led to about 5-fold induction of reporter expression (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	129	 2B), presumably due to activation of the collagenase promoter by the c-Jun homodimer.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The c-Jun-induced 73Col-CAT reporter activity was repressed when COUP-TFI expression vector was cotransfected.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Similarly, 73Col-CAT reporter activity induced by c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimers was inhibited by COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	132	 To determine that inhibition of collagenase promoter activity by COUP-TF was mediated by the TRE, we evaluated how COUP-TFI affected the TRE-tk-CAT reporter, which has a TRE sequence fused to the thymidine kinase promoter (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Our result showed that cotransfection of COUP-TFI significantly inhibited c-Jun-induced TRE-tk-CAT activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	134	 These results clearly demonstrate that COUP-TF inhibits transcriptional activity of c-Jun homodimer and c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimer and that the inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF on the TRE is responsible for its antagonism of TPA activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	136	   Inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	137	 A, inhibition of TPA-induced collagenase promoter activity by COUP-TF in HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was cotransfected without or with COUP-TFI expression vector (10, 20, or 50 ng) or the control pcDNA3 vector into cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	139	 After transfection, cells were incubated in DMEM medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	140	5% FCS for 24 h and then treated with or without TPA (100 ng/ml).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	141	 After 12 h, the cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	142	 B, inhibition of c-Jun-induced 73Col-CAT and TRE-tk-CAT activity by COUP-TF in HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The 73Col-CAT or TRE-tk-CAT reporter was cotransfected with/without c-Jun in the presence or absence of COUP-TFI expression vector (10, 20, and 50 ng) into cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	144	 After transfection, cells were incubated in DMEM medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	145	5% FCS for 24 h, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	146	 C, inhibition of c-Jun and c-Fos activities by COUP-TF in HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was cotransfected with/without c-Jun (50 ng) and/or c-Fos (50 ng) expression vectors either in the presence or absence of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFII expression vector (10, 20, and 50 ng) into HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The cells were then harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	149	Inhibition of c-Jun Binding to DNA by COUP-TF-- Inhibition of AP-1 activity by several nuclear receptors has been shown to be due to their inhibition of AP-1 binding to DNA (8, 9, 13-15, 17, 22, 47).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	150	 To study whether inhibition of AP-1 DNA binding by COUP-TF was involved in its inhibition of AP-1 activity, the purified collagenase promoter fragment was used as a probe in gel shift assays for binding of in vitro synthesized c-Jun protein in the absence or presence of COUP-TF protein (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	151	 c-Jun alone formed a strong complex with the promoter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	152	 However, upon preincubation with COUP-TF protein, c-Jun binding was significantly inhibited.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The addition of COUP-TF protein did not show any new complex formed with the collagenase promoter, indicating that the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF is not due to its direct binding to the collagenase promoter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	154	 We also studied the effect of COUP-TF on binding of c-Jun to the TRE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Preincubation with COUP-TF protein similarly inhibited c-Jun binding to the TRE derived from the collagenase promoter (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	156	 As a comparison, preincubation of c-Jun with TR3 orphan receptor (34) that could not antagonize c-Jun transactivation (data not shown) did not inhibit c-Jun binding to the TRE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This result demonstrated that the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF on c-Jun binding to the collagenase promoter is not due to regions other than the TRE in the promoter.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Next, we compared the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF with that of RAR that is known to repress AP-1 activity and inhibit c-Jun binding to TRE (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Whereas an equal amount of COUP-TF significantly inhibited c-Jun binding to the collagenase promoter, an equal amount of RAR did not show any detectable inhibition (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Inhibition of c-Jun binding required a 5-fold excess of RAR, similar to that observed before (8).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The addition of trans-RA did not enhance the inhibitory effect of RAR (Ref.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Together, these results demonstrate that the inhibition of c-Jun binding to the TRE contributes to its suppression of AP-1 transcriptional activity by COUP-TF and that COUP-TF is a more effective inhibitor than RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	163	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	164	   Inhibition of c-Jun binding to DNA by COUP-TF.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	165	 In vitro synthesized c-Jun was preincubated with the indicated molar excess of COUP-TF, RAR, or TR3.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Unprogrammed reticulocyte lysate was added to maintain an equal protein concentration in each reaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Following preincubation, the reaction mixtures were incubated with 32P-labeled collagenase promoter (A) or the TRE (B) and analyzed by gel retardation.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The arrowhead indicates the c-Jun-binding complex.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	169	Interaction of c-Jun and COUP-TF-- Our observation that COUP-TF inhibits transactivation and DNA binding by c-Jun prompted us to examine whether COUP-TF and c-Jun interact directly using GST pull-down assay (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	170	 In vitro synthesized radiolabeled COUP-TFII was specifically pulled down by bacterially expressed GST-c-Jun hybrid protein but not by GST protein (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	171	 4B), demonstrating that COUP-TF and c-Jun interact in solution.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	172	 To identify the domain of COUP-TFII responsible for interacting with c-Jun, COUP-TFII deletion mutants (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	173	 4A) were constructed and analyzed on the 73Col-CAT reporter for antagonism of AP-1 activity in HeLa cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	174	 4A) and for their interaction with c-Jun using the GST pull-down assay (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Cotransfection of the c-Jun expression vector alone induced reporter transcription (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	176	 4A), whereas cotransfection with one of the C-terminal deletion mutants COUP-TFII7, COUP-TFII30, or COUP-TFII108 strongly inhibited c-Jun-induced reporter activity, as was observed using the wild-type COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	177	 N-terminal domain deletion mutants, such as COUP-TFIIN25, COUP-TFIIN50, and COUP-TFIIN75, also retained the inhibitory effect on AP-1 activity by COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In contrast, partial (COUP-TFIIN125) or complete deletion of the DNA-binding domain (COUP-TFIIDBD) abrogated anti-c-Jun activity completely.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In the GST pull-down assay, COUP-TFII mutants that effectively suppressed AP-1 activity, such as COUP-TFII7, COUP-TFII30, COUP-TFII108, COUP-TFIIN25, COUP-TFIIN50, and COUP-TFIIN75, were pulled down by GST-c-Jun protein, whereas COUP-TFIIDBD, which failed to suppress AP-1 activity, was not (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Thus, inhibition of AP-1 transcriptional activity by the COUP-TFII mutants correlated with their ability to interact with c-Jun.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	181	 These observations further suggest that a direct c-Jun/COUP-TF interaction accounts for the inhibition of AP-1 activity by COUP-TF and that the DBD of COUP-TF is essential.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	182	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	183	   Interaction of c-Jun and COUP-TF and their domain requirements.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	184	 A, inhibition of transcriptional activity of AP-1 by COUP-TF mutants in HeLa cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Left, schematic representation of COUP-TFII and its mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The DNA binding domain (DBD) and ligand-binding domain (LBD) of COUP-TFII are indicated.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Right, effect of COUP-TFII mutants on AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was cotransfected without or with c-Jun (100 ng) alone or together with the indicated COUP-TFII mutants (50 ng).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	189	 After transfection, cells were incubated in DMEM containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	190	 After 12 h, the cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Reporter activity is shown as percentage of inhibition.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	192	 B, interaction between c-Jun and COUP-TFs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	193	 c-Jun was synthesized in bacteria using pGEX-3X expression vector.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	194	 GST-c-Jun fusion protein was immobilized on the glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	195	 As a control, the same amount of glutathione S-transferase was also immobilized on the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In vitro translated 35S-labeled COUP-TF and its mutant proteins were then mixed with the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	197	 After extensive washing, the bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The input proteins are shown for comparison.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	199	We also identified the region of c-Jun required for COUP-TF interaction (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Deletion of amino acids 73-232 from c-Jun (c-JunAvaI) did not affect its ability to pull down COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In contrast, deletion of the C-terminal domain of c-Jun from amino acid 191 to 331 (c-JunbZIP), which encompasses the leucine-zipper region and basic region, completely abolished its ability to pull down COUP-TFII.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Thus, the C-terminal domain, but not the N-terminal domain, of c-Jun is responsible for COUP-TF interaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	203	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	204	   The domain of c-Jun required for interaction with COUP-TF.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	205	 A, schematic representation of c-Jun and its mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The amino terminus (NH2), the basic region, the leucine zipper (bZIP), and the carboxyl terminus (C) are indicated.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	207	 B, interaction between COUP-TF and c-Jun mutants.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	208	 c-Jun and its mutant proteins were synthesized in bacteria using the pGEX-3X expression vector (Amersham Biosciences).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	209	 GST-c-Jun and the mutant fusion proteins (GST-c-JunAvaI and GST-c-JunbZIP) were immobilized on the glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	210	 As a control, the same amount of glutathione transferase was immobilized on the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	211	 In vitro translated 35S-labeled COUP-TFII was then mixed with the beads.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	212	 After extensive washing, bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Input proteins are shown for comparison.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	214	Stable Expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231 Cells Restores the Ability of trans-RA to Inhibit AP-1 Activity-- To further examine the role of COUP-TF in trans-RA-induced inhibition of AP-1 activity, we analyzed the effect of trans-RA on TPA-induced c-Jun expression in MDA-MB231 breast cancer cells and MDA-MB231 cells stably transfected with COUP-TF (MB231/COUP#16) (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Treatment of both cell lines with TPA strongly induced c-Jun expression as determined by Northern blotting (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Induction of c-Jun expression by TPA was probably due to an AP-1-binding site in the c-Jun promoter (7).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Treatment with trans-RA did not affect basal c-Jun expression in both lines and did not inhibit TPA-induced c-Jun expression in MDA-MB231 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	218	 However, pretreatment of MB231/COUP#16 cells with trans-RA completely abolished TPA-induced c-Jun expression.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	219	 These results demonstrate that COUP-TF expression is required for inhibition of AP-1 activity in MDA-MB231 cells by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	220	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	221	   Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative, RAR-positive MDA-MB231 cells restores the ability of trans-RA to inhibit AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Total RNAs prepared from MDA-MB-231 or MDA-MB231 cells stably expressing COUP-TF (MB231/COUP#16) (35) treated with or without the indicated agents were analyzed for the expression of c-Jun.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The expression of -actin is shown to confirm the similar loading of RNA in each lane.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	224	Stable Expression of COUP-TF Does Not Lead to trans-RA-dependent Inhibition of AP-1 Activity in HT-1376 Cells Lacking RAR/ Expression-- We also evaluated whether stable expression of COUP-TF affected TPA-induced c-Jun expression in HT-1376 bladder cancer cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The stable clone, HT-1376/COUP#7, which expresses high levels of COUP-TF, was analyzed for the effect of trans-RA on TPA activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	226	 About a 4-fold induction of c-Jun expression by TPA was observed in HT-1376 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	227	 However, the induction of c-Jun expression was largely reduced in HT-1376/COUP#7 cells, with only about a 2-fold induction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Interestingly, the basal level of c-Jun expression was also slightly reduced in HT-1376/COUP#7 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Despite the reduction of c-Jun expression in the absence or presence of TPA, trans-RA failed to inhibit basal and TPA-induced c-Jun expression in both wild-type and COUP-TF-expressing cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Thus, COUP-TF expression is not sufficient to confer trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity in HT-1376 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	231	View larger version (80K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	232	   Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF and RAR-negative HT-1376 cells does not lead to trans-RA-dependent inhibition of AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Total RNAs prepared from HT-1376 or HT-1376 cells stably expressing COUP-TF (HT-1376/COUP 7) treated with or without the indicated agents were analyzed for the expression of c-Jun, RAR, and RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The expression of -actin is shown to confirm similar loading of RNA in each lane.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	235	RAR Expression Is Required for COUP-TF to Facilitate Antagonism of AP-1 Activity by trans-RA-- Our observations that transient (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	236	 7) expression of COUP-TF in HT-1376 cells failed to modulate antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA led us to investigate RAR expression.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Unlike MDA-MB231 cells that express RAR (48) and RAR when COUP-TF is expressed (35), HT-1376 cells did not express detectable RAR or RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	238	 7), although RAR was expressed (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	239	 This result suggested that modulation of trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity by COUP-TF might require RAR or RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The effect of RAR expression on the ability of COUP-TF to regulate trans-RA activity was then examined using transient transfection in HT-1376 cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected into HT-1376 cells with or without c-Jun and COUP-TF and/or RAR vector.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Transfected cells were treated with or without trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	243	 8A, transfected COUP-TF repressed AP-1 activity in the absence of trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In contrast, transfected RAR (10 ng) led to inhibition of AP-1 activity in a trans-RA dependent manner.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The addition of COUP-TF significantly enhanced the trans-RA-induced inhibition of AP-1 activity by RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Similar results were observed using HeLa cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Thus, efficient inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA activity by COUP-TF requires both COUP-TF and RAR.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	248	View larger version (23K):    Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	249	   Effect of COUP-TF and RAR coexpression on antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The 73Col-CAT reporter was transfected together with c-Jun alone or together with COUP-TF and/or RAR expression vectors into HT-1376 (A) or HeLa (B) cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	251	 After transfection, the cells were incubated in medium containing 0.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	252	5% FCS for 24 h and then treated with or without trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	253	 After 12 h, the cells were harvested, and CAT activity was determined.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The top panels show the percentage of inhibition of c-Jun activity by trans-RA based on data shown in the bottom panels, in which filled bars represent control and open bars represent trans-RA treatment.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	255	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	256	Retinoids are effective growth inhibitors of cancer cells.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Inhibition of AP-1 activity has been proposed as one mechanism by which retinoids exert their anticancer effects (6).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Despite extensive studies in the last few years, how retinoids specifically antagonize AP-1 activity remains largely unknown.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Here, we provide evidence that COUP-TF is involved in regulating the antagonism of AP-1 transactivational activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	260	 COUP-TF, by physically interacting with c-Jun, inhibits AP-1 DNA binding and transactivation and is required for efficient inhibition of AP-1 activity by liganded RARs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Our results suggest that COUP-TF plays a role in the cross-talk between retinoid and AP-1 signaling pathways.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	262	We recently reported that the expression of COUP-TF positively correlates with the inhibition of the growth of various cancer cell lines by trans-RA and that COUP-TF is underexpressed in many trans-RA-resistant cancer cell lines (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Stable expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative cancer cells restores their sensitivity to trans-RA, demonstrating that COUP-TF can mediate anticancer effects of trans-RA (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	264	 By studying anti-AP-1 activity of trans-RA in various cancer cell lines, we found a close correlation between COUP-TF expression and the anti-AP-1 activity of trans-RA (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	265	 In COUP-TF-positive ZR-75-1, T-47D, and Calu-6 cancer cell lines (35), trans-RA strongly inhibited the ability of TPA to activate transcription of the collagenase promoter, whereas in COUP-TF-negative MDA-MB231, H292, and HT-1376 cell lines, trans-RA failed to suppress TPA activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	266	 This finding is consistent with a previous study showing that trans-RA effectively inhibited AP-1 activity in ZR-75-1 and T-47D cells but not in MDA-MB231 cells (49).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The requirement of COUP-TF in trans-RA-mediated AP-1 inhibition was further demonstrated by our findings that transient expression of COUP-TF in COUP-TF-negative cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	268	 1B) restored the ability of trans-RA to inhibit TPA-induced AP-1 transactivation and that stable expression of COUP-TF in MBA-MB231 cells enabled trans-RA to inhibit TPA-induced c-Jun expression (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	269	We have reported that COUP-TF expression contributes to growth inhibition by trans-RA in cancer cells because COUP-TF on binding to the RAR promoter induces RAR expression (35).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	270	 RAR is reported to be a potent AP-1 inhibitor (24), suggesting that COUP-TF-induced RAR probably contributes to the inhibition of AP-1 activity (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Our observations that COUP-TF can effectively interact with c-Jun in vitro (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	272	 3 and 4) and inhibit AP-1 transcriptional activity on transient transfection (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	273	 2) also suggest that COUP-TF is directly involved in antagonizing AP-1 activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	274	Inhibition of AP-1 activity appears to be a common characteristic of nuclear receptors, as has been demonstrated for the progesterone, estrogen, androgen, thyroid hormone, glucocorticoid, and retinoid receptors, which can functionally interact with the AP-1 complex.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	275	 This study reveals that the orphan receptor COUP-TF behaves similarly.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The molecular basis of the interaction between nuclear receptors and AP-1 pathways remains largely unknown.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Models proposed include direct protein-protein interaction (8, 9, 13-15), inhibition of Jun N-terminal kinase activity (31), and competition for CBP (32).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Our results of GST pull-down assays (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	279	 4B and 5) and mutation analysis (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	280	 4 and 5) support the first model.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The requirement for the COUP-TF DBD for c-Jun binding is similar to observations that the DBDs of glucocorticoid receptor (14, 15) and RAR (47) are essential for their interaction with AP-1.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Interestingly, the in vitro DNA-binding study showed that COUP-TF is a more effective inhibitor of AP-1 binding than RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	283	 3) on the basis of the levels of each receptor to exert this effect.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	284	In contrast to inhibition of AP-1 activity by other receptors that require their respective ligands, COUP-TF effectively inhibited AP-1 transactivation in the absence of any ligand (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Such a ligand-independent inhibition of AP-1 activity may restrict expression levels of AP-1-responsive genes in cancer cells (Figs.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Interestingly, we observed that COUP-TF expression potentiates antagonism of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	287	 However, regulation of trans-RA activity by COUP-TF appears to require RAR or RAR, because transiently transfected COUP-TF was unable to confer anti-AP-1 activity to trans-RA in HT-1376 cells lacking RAR or - (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	288	 8B) unless RAR was cotransfected.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In addition, stable expression of COUP-TF restored trans-RA-induced anti-AP-1 activity in MDA-MB231 cells (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	290	 6) having RARs (48) but not in HT-1376 cells lacking RAR and - (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Thus, expression of both RAR/ and COUP-TF is required for optimal inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	292	Although we do not fully understand how COUP-TF and RAR coexpression maximizes inhibition of AP-1 activity by trans-RA, our finding of physical interaction between COUP-TF and RAR (35, 50) suggests its involvement in this process.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Based on our observation that COUP-TF more effectively inhibits c-Jun binding to DNA than RAR (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	294	 3), it is tempting to speculate that COUP-TF, with its ability to interact with both RAR (35, 50) and c-Jun (Fig.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	295	 3), may function as a bridging factor to mediate RAR/AP-1 interaction.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	296	 In this model, the COUP-TF/RAR heterodimer would strongly interact with AP-1 in the presence of trans-RA to inhibit the DNA binding of AP-1 and its transactivation.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Similarly, COUP-TF, by interacting with c-Jun, might also potentiate the inhibition of RAR/ transactivation by AP-1.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Unfortunately, perhaps due to rapid formation of the COUP-TF homodimer after COUP-TF expression in vitro (40, 51), we were unsuccessful in demonstrating the interaction between RAR/COUP-TF heterodimer and c-Jun in gel shift or GST pull-down assays (data not shown).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Another possible mechanism for inhibiting AP-1 transactivation by COUP-TF may involve its recruiting of a transcriptional corepressor.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	300	 COUP-TF has been widely considered as a potent negative transcriptional regulator (40-43) due to its effective interaction with corepressors, such as N-CoR and SMRT (52).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	301	 The interaction between COUP-TF and both RAR and AP-1 may recruit transcriptional corepressors to the complex, thereby enhancing the mutual repression of AP-1 and RAR transcriptional activity.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Interestingly, COUP-TF interacts with a variety of nuclear receptors, including RXR (41), TR (40, 50), estrogen receptor (53, 54), and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (55).
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	303	 It remains to be determined whether and how COUP-TF is involved in modulating the anti-AP-1 activity by their ligands.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Dawson for reviewing the manuscript.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	305	* This work is supported in part by grants from the National Institutes of Health and the United States Army Medical Research and Material Command (to X.

0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	311	Published, JBC Papers in Press, April 4, 2002, DOI 10.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	312	The abbreviations used are: RAR, retinoic acid receptor; RXR, retinoid X receptor; RA, retinoic acid; RARE, RA response element; TPA, 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate; TRE, TPA response element; CBP, cAMP-response element-binding protein; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; FCS, fetal calf serum; GST, glutathione S-transferase.
0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	313	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.

0.37651846.11934895.html.plaintext.txt	355	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2002 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	0	The orphan nuclear receptor, COUP-TF II, inhibits myogenesis by post-transcriptional regulation of MyoD function: COUP-TF II directly interacts with p300 and MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	1	Peter Bailey, Vittorio Sartorelli1, Yasou Hamamori1 and George E.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	2	University of Queensland, Centre for Molecular and Cellular Biology, Ritchie Research Laboratories, B402A, St Lucia, 4072 Queensland, Australia and 1University of Southern California, Institute of Genetic Medicine #140,2250 Alcazar Street, Los Angeles, CA 90033, USA.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received June 11, 1998; Revised and Accepted October 15, 1998.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	4	COUP-TF II is an orphan nuclear receptor that has no known ligand in the `classical sense'.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	5	 COUP-TF interacts with the corepressors N-CoR, SMRT and RIP13, and silences transcription by active repression and trans-repression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Forced expression of the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF II in mouse C2 myogenic cells has been demonstrated to inhibit morphological differentiation, and to repress the expression of: (i) the myoD gene family which encodes myogenic basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) proteins; and (ii) the cell cycle regulator, p21Waf-1/Cip-1.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In the present study, we show that COUP-TF II efficiently inhibits the myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells by post-transcriptional mechanisms.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Furthermore, repression of MyoD-dependent transcription by COUP-TF II occurs in the absence of the nuclear receptor cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The inhibition of MyoD-mediated trans-activation involves the direct binding of the DNA binding domain/C-region and hinge/D-regions [i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	10	 amino acid (aa) residues 78-213] of COUP-TF II to the N-terminal activation domain of MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Over-expression of the cofactor p300, which functions as a coactivator of myoD-mediated transcription, alleviated repression by COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Further binding analysis demonstrated that COUP-TF II interacted with the N-terminal 149 aa residues of p300 which encoded the receptor interaction domain of the coactivator.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Finally we observed that COUP-TF II, MyoD and p300 interact in a competitive manner, and that increasing amounts of COUP-TF II have the ability to reduce the interaction between myoD and p300 invitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The experiments presented herein suggest thatCOUP-TF II post-transcriptionally regulates myoD activity/function, and that crosstalk between orphan nuclear receptors and the myogenic bHLH proteins has functional consequences for differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	15	The process of skeletal muscle differentiation involves the activation and induction of a large array of muscle-specific genes, and exit from the cell cycle.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The myoD gene family encodes myogenic specific basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) proteins that activate and control this process (reviewed in 1-3).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	17	 MyoD plays a dual role during myogenesis, activating both muscle specific gene transcription and promoting cell cycle exit by inducing the expression of p21Cip-1/Waf-1, an inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases and cellular proliferation (4-6).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Transactivation by MyoD involves: (i) the bHLH domain, that is involved in both DNA binding and dimerisation; (ii) the heterodimerisation of MyoD with the ubiquitously expressed E2A gene products, E12 and E47 (7); (iii) the binding of MyoD-E2A heterodimers to specific E-box motifs (CANNTG) in muscle-specific enhancers (reviewed in 1-3); and (iv) the recruitment of the cofactors p300 and PCAF (8-10).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The cofactors p300 and PCAF are critical coactivators for MyoD during myogenic commitment and differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD directly interacts with p300 and recruits PCAF to form a ternary multimeric complex on promoter elements (8,11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These events lead to hyper-acetylated and transcriptionally-permissive chromatin.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Moreover, p300 and PCAF coactivate myoD-mediated trans-activation of the p21 gene, and are necessary for MyoD-mediated cell cyle arrest (11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	23	The transcriptional activity of MyoD is modulated by environmental cues related to the concentration of growth factors, receptors and oncogene products which promote cell division (reviewed in 12).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These agents inhibit the transcriptional activity of MyoD by promoting: (i) the direct phosphorylation of the bHLH region and/or the interaction with c-jun, which prevent DNA binding; (ii) the activation of inhibitor of differentiation expression (Id), a bHLH protein that lacks DNA binding ability, and functions as a dominant negative; and (iii) the suppression/sequestering of myogenic specific transcription factors and cofactors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	25	The orphan nuclear receptors COUP-TF II, Rev-erbA and RVR are members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, and are abundantly expressed in proliferating myoblasts (12-15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	26	 However, the expression of this group of receptors is repressed during differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Constitutive expression of COUP-TF II cDNA in mouse C2 myogenic cells blocks morphological differentiation by suppressing the levels of myoD mRNA, increasing cyclin D1 protein levels, and blocking the induction of myogenin and p21 mRNAs after serum withdrawal (14,16).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The molecular basis for these effects has not been elucidated.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	29	COUP-TF IIis ubiquitously expressed in adult tissues, and regulated by the morphogen, sonic hedgehog (17).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	30	 During embryogenesis, COUP-TF II is expressed in the developing CNS in a spatio-temporal manner (18,19), and in the dermatomial region of the somite at 10 days post coitum, which will give rise to the axial skeletal and tongue muscle (20).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	31	 COUP-TF proteins are highly expressed in many other developing organs and the expression level decreases with completion of differentiation, suggesting that COUP-TF is involved in organogenesis (21,22).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	32	 COUP-TF binds to direct and inverted repeats of the RGGTCA motif spaced by 0-12 nt (23-26).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	33	COUP-TF isoforms I and II have been demonstrated to: (i) repress hormonal trans-activation of target genes by the nuclear receptor family (23-26); (ii) repress trans-activation by the potent GAL4VP16 chimera (16); (iii) interact with TFIIB; and (iv) negatively regulate the transcription of many other genes(e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Apolipoprotein AI gene) (21,27-29).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Inhibition of trans-cription by COUP-TF II has been shown to be mediated by two main mechanisms, active repression and transrepression (30).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Active repression by COUP-TF involves direct binding and competition for the occupancy of a common response element (31).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Transrepression involves inhibition of transcription by COUP-TF II in the absence of its cognate binding motif, or independent of nucleic acid binding (30).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Interestingly, we (16) and Achatz et al.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	39	 (30) have demonstrated that the DNA binding domain (DBD)/C-region of COUP-TF II is necessary for transrepression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The molecular mechanism underlying COUP-TF II transrepression is unclear; however, it has been suggested that direct protein-protein interactions between COUP-TF and essential cofactors may be involved.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Whether COUP-TF II directly regulates the transcription of the bHLH regulators is unclear.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Furthermore, the fact that COUP-TF II represses transcription in the presence and absence of its cognate binding motif raises the scenario that COUP-TF II may control MyoD activity or the formation of the functional MyoD ternary complex.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	43	Active repression by COUP-TF II is mediated by the nuclear corepressors (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	44	 N-CoR/RIP13 and SMRT/TRAC-2) (16,32-35).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Corepressors actively repress transcription by: (i) interacting with Sin3A/B and recruiting histone deacetylases (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	46	 HDAc-1 or Rpd3) which actively promote chromatin condensation via hypo-acetylation of the chromatin (36-39); and (ii) binding key components of the basal transcriptional machinery (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	47	 TFIIB, TAFII32 and TAFII70) (40).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	48	 In the present study, we demonstrate that that repression of MyoD-mediated transactivation by COUP-TF II involves direct binding to MyoD and p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	49	Vectors used in transfection experiments and GST-pulldowns are described in detail elsewhere (8,16).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The construction of new plasmids is described herein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The oligonucleotides GMUQ371 5[prime]-GCGGTCGACATATGTGCCGCCTCAAAAAGTGCCTC-3[prime] and GMUQ372 5[prime]-GCGGTCGACTTATTTATTGAATTGCCATATACGG-3[prime] were synthesised to allow PCR amplification of the COUP-TF II region spanning amino acids (aa) 134-414.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The oligonucleotides GMUQ371 and GMUQ373 5[prime]-GCGGTCGACCTAGGTTTTACCTACCAAACGG-3[prime] were used to amplify the region spanning aa 134-389.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	53	 PCR amplification was performed with Pfu DNA polymerase (Stratagen, La Jolla, CA) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The resulting DNA fragments were digested with SalI and ligated to SalI-digested pNLVP16.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The plasmids are described as VP16-COUP-TF II 1/2 (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	56	 aa 134-414) and VP16-COUP-TF II 1/3 (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	57	 aa 134-389) throughout the text.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The oligonucleotides GMUQ272 and QMUQ273 (described in 16) were used to generate the COUP-TF II CD region.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The resulting product was digested with EcoRI and end-filled with Klenow DNA polymerase according to the manufacturer's directions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The COUP-TF II CD end-filled fragment was then cloned into a pNLVP16 vector which had been cleaved with NdeI and end-filled with Klenow DNA polymerase.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	61	 To generate the pSG5-COUP-TF II AB, ABCD and CDE expression vectors GAL4-COUP-TF II plasmids encoding the AB, ABCD and CDE domains were digested with EcoRI and the resulting fragments cloned into the EcoRI site of pSG5.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	62	 pSG5-COUP-TF II CD was generated by digesting the COUP-TF II CD PCR fragment with EcoRI and again directly cloning into the EcoRI site of pSG5.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	63	 To create the plasmids encoding GST-COUP-TF II AB, ABCD, CDE and DE, GAL4-COUP-TF II plasmids encoding the AB, ABCD, CDE and DE domains were digested with EcoRI and the resulting fragments cloned into the EcoRI site of pGEX-1[lambda]T.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	64	 GST-COUP-TF II CD wasgenerated by digesting the CD PCR fragment with EcoRI and cloning into the EcoRI site of pGEX-1[lambda]T.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	65	 VP16, GAL and GSTchimeras were sequenced to confirm the orientation and reading frame.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	66	JEG-3 cells were cultured for 24 h in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle's Medium (DMEM) containing 5% charcoal stripped fetal calf serum in 6% CO2 at 37 degrees C prior to transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	67	 JEG-3 cells grown in 6-well dishes to 60-70% confluence were transiently transfected with 3  microg of the reporter plasmid DNA G5E1b-CAT, 1  microg of either GAL4-p300-aa 1-149, GAL4-p300-aa 595-1240, or GAL4-p300-aa 1030-2414 and 1  microg of either VP16O, VP16 COUP-TF II, VP16 COUP-TF II AB, VP16 COUP-TFII ABCD, VP16 COUP-TF II CD, VP16 COUP-TF II CDE, VP16 COUP-TF II DE, VP16 COUP-TF II 1/2 or VP16 COUP-TF II 1/3 by the DOTAP/DOSPER (Boehringer Mannheim) mediated procedure as described previously (41).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The DNA/DOTAP/DOSPER mixture was added to the cells in 3 ml of fresh medium.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The medium was replaced 24 h after transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Cells were harvested and assayed for CAT enzyme activity as previously described after a further 24 h.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Each transfection experiment was performed at least three times in order to overcome the variability inherent in transfections.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	72	 NIH3T3 fibroblasts were grown to confluence (~5  x  106 cells) in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Cells were transfected by the calcium phosphate precipitation procedure as previously described.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	74	 One  microg of the 4RE-tkLUC reporter was coprecipitated with either 100 ng of EMSV, 200 ng p300 and/or 100-500 ng of the pSG5-COUP-TF II `sense'/pSG5-COUP-TF II `anti-sense'plasmid.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	75	5 mg of the CMV-LacZ plasmid was included in each transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Luciferase activity was assayed as previously described (8) and corrected for with respect to the transfection efficiency by the [beta]-galactosidase assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Thequantitative [beta]-galactosidase assay was performed with the chlorophenol red-[beta]-d-galactopyranoside substrate (CPRG; Boehringer Mannheim) as previously described (8).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Each transfection experiment was performed at least three times in order to overcome the variability inherent in transfections.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	79	C3H10T1/2 cell myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	80	For the myogenic conversion assay, C3H10T1/2 fibroblasts were grown to 60% confluence in 12-well dishes.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Cells in each well were transfected by the DOTAP/DOSPER (Boehringer Mannheim) mediated procedure, using 1  microg of EMSV-MyoD in combination with either 1  microg of pSG5-COUP-TF II, pSG5-COUP-TF II AB, pSG5-COUP-TF II ABCD, pSG5-COUP-TF II CDE or pSG5 carrier DNA so as to total 2  microg per transfection.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	82	4  microg each of EMSV-MyoD, EMSV-Myf-5, EMSV-Myogenin and EMSV-MRF4 were cotransfected with either 0.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	83	4  microg of pSG5 or pSG5-COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Twenty-four hours after transfection, cells were reefed on 10% DMEM until 100% confluent, whereupon the media was changed to DMEM plus 2% horse serum.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Cells were grown under these conditions for 6 days, with media changes occurring every 2 days.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Immunostaining was then performed using a monoclonal antibody directed towards the fast isoform of the major thick filament protein, skeletal myosin heavy chain (MHC) (Sigma; clone MY32).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	87	 This procedure is described in detail elsewhere (8).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	88	GST and GST fusion proteins were expressed in Escherichia coli (BL21) and purified using glutathione-agarose affinity chromatography as described previously (15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The GST fusion proteins were analysed on 10% SDS-PAGE gels for integrity and to normalise the amount of each protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The Promega (Madison, WI) TNT-coupled transcription-translation system was used to produce [35S]methionine-labelled MyoD and COUP-TF II proteins that were visualised by SDS-PAGE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	91	 In vitro binding assays were performed with glutathione agarose beads (Sigma, St Louis, MO) coated with ~500 ng GST fusion protein and 2-30  microl [35S]methionine-labelled protein in 200 ml of binding buffer containing 100 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	92	5 % NP-40, 5  microg of ethidium bromide and 100  microg of BSA.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The reaction was allowed to proceed for 1-2 h at room temperature with rocking.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The affinity beads were then collected by centrifugation and washed five times with 1 ml of binding buffer without the ethidium bromide or BSA.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The beads were then resuspended in 20 ml of SDS-PAGE sample buffer and boiled for 5 min.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The denatured proteins were run on a 10% SDS-PAGE gel which was subsequently treated with Amersham Amplify fluor (Amersham, Arlington Heights, IL), dried and autoradiographed.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	97	RESULTS COUP-TF II inhibits myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	98	We have previously demonstrated that proliferating C2C12 myoblasts express COUP-TF II mRNA and that constitutive expression of COUP-TF II cDNA in mouse C2 myogenic cells blocks morphological differentiation by suppressing the expression levels of the myoD gene family and critical cell cycle regulators (14,15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Moreover, preliminary evidence suggests that COUP-TF II directly regulates the transcription of the bHLH/contractile gene families and/or the cell cycle regulators (P.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	100	 However, the fact that COUP-TF II represses transcription in the presence and absence of its cognate binding motif, and interacts with the corepressors N-CoR and SMRT, raises the scenario that COUP-TF II may control MyoD activity or function by post-transcriptional mechanisms, which include transrepression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	101	We tested this hypothesis by investigating the impact of SV40-driven COUP-TF II expression on the MyoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In this system, transient transfection of an EMSV-MyoD expression vector under the control of a moloney sarcoma virus promoter leads to the phenotypic/myogenic conversion of these cells as scored by immunostaining with a monoclonal antibody directed against a muscle-specific marker.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The antibody is against the fast isoform of the major thick filament protein, skeletal MHC.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	104	 MHC is associated with the contractile phenotype and is expressed during the process of muscle differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Utilisation of an EMSV-driven MyoD expression vector, which is essentially refactory to repression by COUP-TF II, assured that any observed affects of COUP-TF II on phenotypic conversion were independent of myoD down-regulation, and mediated by post-transcriptional events.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	106	 We demonstrated that the identical moloney sarcoma virus promoter linked to the CAT reporter in the same vector was not affected/regulated by COUP-TF II expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	107	 We cotransfected increasing amounts of either pSG5, the SV40 expression vector alone, or pSG5-COUP-TF II with EMSV-CAT.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	108	 We observed that at the concentrations of DNA transfected in this experiment, neither the vector alone nor pSG5-COUP-TF II affected the activity of the EMSV promoter (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	109	In the initial experiment, C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with EMSV-MyoD in combination with either pSG5 (vector/vehicle only) or pSG5-COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	110	 As expected, cells transfected with EMSV-MyoD and pSG5 were found to be positively stained with the MHC antibody.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	111	 In stark contrast, cells that were transfected with both MyoD and wild type COUP-TF II did not undergo myogenic conversion (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	112	To delimit the region within COUP-TF II which is involved in the ablation of the MyoD-mediated acquisition of the myogenic phenotype, we cotransfected 10T1/2 cells with EMSV-MyoD and expression vectors encoding the AB, ABCD and CDE regions of COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	113	 After immunostaining, it was found that the ABCD and CDE regions were sufficient to inhibit myogenic conversion (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In contrast, the AB region of COUP-TF II failed to ablate the MyoD-mediated acquisition of the contractile phenotype (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	115	 This is in agreement with previous studies that show that the CD region of COUP-TF II (encoding the DBD and hinge domain) blocks the trans-activation of GAL4-dependent reporter genes by the potent chimeric trans-activator GAL4VP16 (16).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	116	 (A) COUP-TF II expression does not affect the activity of the EMSV promoter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	117	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently co-transfected with EMSV-CAT in combination with either increasing quantities (0.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	118	0  microg) of pSG5 alone or pSG5-COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	119	 They were subsequently assayed for CAT activity; results shown are mean  plus or minus  standard deviation and were derived from three independent transfections.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	120	 (B) COUP-TF II inhibits the myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The ABCD and CDE regions of COUP-TF II are sufficient to inhibit myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	122	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with EMSV-MyoD in combination with either pSG5 alone (panel b), pSG5-COUP-TF II (panel c), pSG5-COUP-TF II AB (panel d), pSG5-COUP-TF II ABCD (panel e) or pSG5-COUP-TF II CDE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Myogenic conversion was then scored with respect to the untransfected control cells (panel a) by immunostaining with a monoclonal antibody directed towards the fast isoform of the major thick filament protein, skeletal [alpha]MHC after 4 daysin 2% horse serum.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (C) Diagrammatic representation of COUP-TF II, highlighting the key domains: AB domain(i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	125	 aa 79-144); D domain or Hinge (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	126	 aa 145-213); and E domain of putative LBD (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	127	 (D) Inhibition of 10T1/2 myogenic conversion by COUP-TF II is not overcome by the forced expression of the myogenic factors myoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	128	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with expression vectors for the myogenic factors MyoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4 in the absence (panel b) and presence (panel c) of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	129	 As before, myogenic conversion was scored with respect to the untransfected control cells (panel a) by immunostaining with an MHC antibody.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	130	 MHC-positive cells are stained red and highlighted by an arrow.
