0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	131	We then examined whether forced expression of the myogenic factors myoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4 could overcome the block mediated by COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	132	 C3H10T1/2 cells were transiently transfected with expression vectors for the myogenic factors myoD, myogenin, myf-5 and MRF-4 in the presence and absence of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	133	 It was found that although cotransfection of C3H10T1/2 cells with the complete repertoire of myogenic factors results in very efficient myogenic conversion, as scored by positive [alpha]MHC immunostaining, COUP-TF II still blocks the acquistion of the contractile phenotype (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	134	In summary, the experiments presented above suggest that the CDE region of COUP-TF II is involved in the inhibition of myoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential C3H10T1/2 cells.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Furthermore, the orphan nuclear receptor abrogates 10T1/2 myogenic conversion in the absence of its cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The ability of COUP-TF II to over-ride the entire repertoire of myogenic factors also suggests that it may sequester or bind essential cofactors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	137	COUP-TF II inhibits myoD-mediated trans-activation of a reporter gene downstream from a MyoD-dependent heterologous promoter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	138	The immunohistochemical analysis suggested that COUP-TF II acts to repress 10T1/2 myogenic conversion by a mechanism which is independent of MyoD gene expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Hence, it was of interest to determine whether COUP-TF II could repress MyoD-dependent transcription in the absence of its cognate binding site.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	140	 To achieve this we utilised a 4RE-tkLUC reporter construct, in which four copies of the right E box (CANNTG motif) of the muscle specific MCK enhancer are placed upstream of a minimal thymidine kinase promoter linked to the LUC reporter gene.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This reporter construct does not contain a cognate binding site for COUP-TF II, and has been demonstrated to facilitate MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	142	C3H10T1/2 cells were cotransfected with the 4RE-tkLUC reporter in combination with either EMSV-MyoD and/or COUP-TF II sense and anti-sense expression vectors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	143	 As expected, co-transfection of the reporter with EMSV-MyoD alone activated the expression of the LUC reporter gene very efficiently (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	144	 However, cotransfection of 10T1/2 cells with EMSV-MyoD and increasing quantities of the pSG5 COUP-TF II expression vector (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	145	 100, 300 and 500 ng) significantly repressed MyoD-mediated trans-activation in a dose-dependent fashion (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In contrast, cotransfection of EMSV-MyoD with the anti-sense COUP-TF II construct did not have any affect on MyoD trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This result clearly shows that COUP-TF II is capable of blocking MyoD-mediated trans-activation in a dose-dependent manner via a trans-repression mechanism which is independent of COUP-TF II DNA binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (A) COUP-TF II inhibits the MyoD-dependent transactivation of a 4RE reporter construct via a mechanism that is independent of DNA binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	149	 NIH 3T3 cells were transiently transfected with the 4RE-tkLUC reporter (1  microg) in combination with either MyoD (100 ng), COUP-TF II sense `S' (100, 300 or 500 ng) or COUP-TF II anti-sense `AS' (500 ng) as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	150	 After 48 h, cells were harvested and assayed for luciferase activity as described in the Methods and Materials.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (B) COUP-TF II directly interacts with MyoD in vitro; the CD region of COUP-TF II alone is capable of mediating this interaction.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	152	 MyoD was radiolabelled with [35S]methionine by in vitro transcription/translation [the input (lane 1) represents ~10% of the total protein] and was assayed for its ability to interact with glutathione-immobilised GST alone (lane 2), GST-COUP-TF II (lane 3), GST-COUP-TF II AB (lane 4), GST-COUP-TF II ABCD (lane 5), GST-COUP-TF II CD (lane 6), GST-COUP-TF II CDE (lane 7) and GST-COUP-TF II DE (lane 8).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The retained proteins are shown in lanes 3-8.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	154	 COUP-TF II directly interacts with MyoD: the CD region of the nuclear receptor mediates the interaction.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	155	We postulated that COUP-TF II could be functioning to repress MyoD activity/function by directly interacting with MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	156	 To determine this we utilised the in vitro GST pulldown assay, in which glutathione agarose-immobilised GST-COUP-TF II was incubated with in vitro 35S-radiolabelled full-length MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	157	 This assay clearly showed that COUP-TF II and MyoD were indeed capable of a direct interaction in vitro (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	158	To map the region within COUP-TF II that was involved in mediating this interaction, a variety of COUP-TF II domains were sub-cloned into the GEX-1 expression vector, producing the fusion protiens GST-COUP-TF II AB, GST-COUP-TF II ABCD, GST-COUP-TF II CD, GST-COUP-TF II CDE and GST-COUP-TF II DE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The full-length and deleted GST-COUP-TF II chimeric proteins were then incubated with in vitro translated MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Interestingly, the COUP-TF II domains ABCD, CD and CDE interacted strongly with full-length MyoD (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In contrast, neither the AB region nor the DE region retained the ability to interact with full-length MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	162	 This demonstrated that the CD region of COUP-TF II, which spans aa 78-213 and encodes the DBD and hinge region, is required for MyoD binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	163	 This observation was also confirmed by examining the ability of in vitro translated full-length COUP-TF II to interact with GST-MyoD (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	164	 As expected, we observed specific binding between 35S-radiolabelled COUP-TF II and GST-MyoD in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These experiments suggested protein-protein interactions were involved in the transrepression of myoD-mediated transcription.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD mediates the interaction with COUP-TF II in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	167	 (A) GST pulldown showing an interaction between 35S-radiolabelled COUP-TF II and glutathione agarose-immobilised GST-MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The input lane represents ~10% of the total protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	169	 (B) Diagrammatic representation of the MyoD protein, highlighting key regulatory domains.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	170	 (C) Glutathione agarose-immobilised GST and GST-COUP-TF II proteins were incubated with either 35S-radiolabelled full-length MyoD, N-terminal MyoD (aa 1-100) or C-terminal MyoD (aa 162-318).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The input lanes represent ~10% of the total protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	172	 (D) COUP-TF II directly interacts with the N-terminal of MyoD in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The CDE domain of COUP-TF II was radiolabelled with [35S]methionine by in vitro transcription/translation [the input (lane 1) represents ~10% of the total protein] and assayed for its ability to interact with glutathione-immobilised GST alone (lane 2), GST-MyoD full-length (lane 3), GST-MyoD N-terminal (lane 4), GST-MyoD C-terminal (lane 5) and GST-MyoD bHLH (lane 6).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The retained proteins are shown in lanes 3-6.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD mediates the interaction with COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	176	To identify the domain within MyoD (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	177	 3B) which interacts with COUP-TF II, immobilised GST-COUP-TF II was incubated in combination with either 35S-radiolabelled N-terminal MyoD (aa 1-100) or C-terminal MyoD (aa 162-318).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	178	 It was found that the N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD, but not the C-terminal region, interacted with COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	179	 It should be noted that the N-terminal activation domain of MyoD has also been demonstrated to interact with p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	180	To rigorously confirm that the N-terminal of MyoD interacts with COUP-TF II, we examined the ability of a number of GST-MyoD fusion chimeras containing functional subdomains of MyoD and immobilised on glutathione agrose beads [i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	181	 GST-MyoD (aa 1-318), GST-N terminal MyoD (aa 1-100), GST-bHLH (aa 102-161) and GST-C-terminal MyoD (aa 162-318)] to interact with the 35S-radiolabelled CDE region of COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	182	 As expected, MyoD and the N-terminal of MyoD linked to GST interacted strongly with in vitro translated COUP-TF II-CDE (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In contrast, the GST-MyoD-C-terminal and -bHLH regions did not support any significant interaction with the CDE domain of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	184	 These experiments suggest that the N-terminal acid-rich activation domain of MyoD, which is represented by the first 100 aa of the protein, is required for COUP-TF II binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	185	The coactivator p300 alleviates COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	186	Nuclear receptors have been demonstrated to inhibit AP-1 function, in the absence of any observable affects on DNA recognition, by competing for limiting amounts of p300/CBP (42).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Competition for p300 in this case involves direct binding between p300 and nuclear receptors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In the context of muscle differentiation, p300 functions as a coactivator for MyoD-mediated trans-activation, and has been demonstrated to augment the trans-activation of genes which contain E-box elements in their enhancer regions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It was therefore of some interest to determine whether COUP-TF II could be functioning to repress MyoD-dependent trans-activation by competing for limiting amounts of p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	190	 In doing so, we examined the effect of p300 over-expression on COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	191	 NIH 3T3 cells were cotransfected with the 4RE-tkLUC construct and COUP-TF II in the presence of either MyoD or MyoD and p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	192	 If competition for limiting quantities of p300 also accounts for the inhibitory effect of COUP-TF II on MyoD transcriptional activity, then increased levels of p300 should restore/alleviate COUP-TF II-mediated repression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	193	 We found that cotransfection of p300 with COUP-TF II and MyoD almost completely rescued myoD transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	194	 4A), suggesting that repression by COUP-TF II involves competition for limiting amounts of p300, presumably through protein-protein interactions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The coactivator p300 alleviates COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	196	 NIH 3T3 cells were transiently transfected with 1  microg of the 4RE-tkLUC construct, 100 ng of CMV-MyoD, 200 ng of CMV-[beta]p300 and 300 ng of COUP-TF II as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	197	 After 48 h, cells were harvested and assayed for luciferase activity.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	198	 COUP-TF II interacts with the N-terminal 149 aa receptor interaction domain (RID) of the cofactor p300 in vivo.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	199	Nuclear receptors have been shown to directly interact with the N-terminal RID encoded by aa residues 1-149 of p300 in vivo (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	200	 To determine if COUP-TF II also interacts with p300 in vivo, we utilised the mammalian two-hybrid assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In this assay, the GAL4 DBD-p300 domain fusion chimeras, GAL4-p300-aa 1-149, -p300-aa 595-1240, and -p300-aa 1030-2414 were independently cotransfected in JEG-3 cells with either full-length VP16-COUP-TF II, VP16-COUP-TF II AB or VP16-COUP-TF II CDE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The capacity of the GAL-p300 and VP16-COUP-TF II fusion products to physically interact in vivo was then assessed by their ability to trans-activate a CAT reporter gene placed downstream of GAL4 binding sites linked to the E1b promoter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	203	 It was found that, like other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, full-length COUP-TF II strongly interacts (~20-fold) with only the N-terminal RID of p300 (aa 1-149) (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In comparison, with the nuclear receptor RXR[gamma] (in the presence of ligand), the interaction of the N-terminal region of p300 with full-length COUP-TFII, is stronger [~5-fold; data not shown, and similar to that reported by Chakravarti et al.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	205	 It was also found that the RID of p300 interacted efficiently with the C-terminal region of COUP-TF II which encodes the CD and E domains [i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	206	 DBD, hinge and putative ligand binding domain (LBD)].
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In contrast, the AB region of COUP-TF II did not interact with the RID of p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (A) Diagrammatic representation of the p300 protein, highlighting regions involved in protein-protein interactions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	209	 (B) COUP-TF II interacts with the RID of p300 in vivo.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	210	 JEG-3 cells were transiently transfected with the G5e1bCAT reporter construct and expression vectors encoding either GAL4-p300-aa 1-149, GAL4-p300-aa 595-1240, GAL4-p300-aa 1030-2414, VP16-COUP-TF II full-length, VP16-COUP-TF II AB or VP16-COUP-TF II CDE as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	211	 After 48 h on 10% charcoal stripped medium, cells were harvested and assayed for CAT activity.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Results shown are mean  plus or minus  standard deviation and were derived from at least three independent experiments.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In each case, fold activation is relative to GAL4-p300 chimera/VP160 CAT activity, which is arbitrarily set at 1.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	214	 (C) The CD region of COUP-TF II, which spans aa 78-213, interacts with the N-terminal 149 aa of p300 in vivo.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	215	 JEG-3 cells were transiently transfected with the 3 mg G5e1bCAT reporter construct, 1 mg GAL4-p300-aa1-149 and 1 mg of the VP16-COUP-TF II chimeras as indicated (+).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The results are presented as the mean  plus or minus  standard deviation and were derived from at least three independent experiments.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	217	 In each case, fold activation is relative to GAL4-p300-aa 1-149/VP160 CAT activity, which is arbitarily set at 1.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	218	 (D) Direct binding between the CD region of COUP-TF II and full-length p300 in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	219	 p300 was radiolabelled with [35S]methionine by in vitro transcription/translation and assayed for its ability to interact with glutathione-immobilised GST, GST-COUP-TF II, GST-COUP-TF II AB, GST-COUP-TF II ABCD, GST-COUP-TF II CD, GST-COUP-TF II CDE and GST-COUP-TF II DE.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The cofactor p300 directly interacts with the COUP-TF II CD region in vivo and in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	221	To delimit the region within COUP-TF II which interacts with the p300 RID in vivo, we again utilised the mammalian two-hybrid assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In doing so, the VP16 chimeras VP16-COUP-TF AB, ABCD, CDE, CD, DE, 1/2 and 1/3 (depicted in Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	223	 5C) were independently cotransfected with GAL RID p300 and assayed for their ability to trans-activate the G5e1bCAT reporter.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	224	 It was found that the CD region of COUP-TF II, which encodes the DBD and hinge (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	225	 aa 78-213), was sufficient to interact with the RID of p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Interestingly, the VP16-COUP-TF II chimeras 1/2 and 1/3, which contain only part of the DBD (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	227	 from aa 134), were not able to interact with the RID of p300, suggesting that the entire DBD is required for binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	228	To confirm that COUP-TF II and p300 interact directly, we used the in vitro GST pulldown assay.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Equal quantities of glutathione agarose-immobilised GST (negative control) and GST-COUP-TF II full-length and various sub-domains (GST-COUP-TF II AB, GST-COUP-TF II ABCD, GST-COUP-TF II CD, GST-COUP-TF II CDE and GST-COUP-TF II DE) were incubated with in vitro 35S-radiolabelled full-length p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The resulting pulldown clearly showed a direct interaction between full-length COUP-TF II and in vitro translated p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Furthermore, the CD region of COUP-TF II, spanning aa 78-213, is required for the interaction with p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Interestingly, this is the same region that interacts with MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	233	 It should be noted that the ABCD and CDE regions of COUP-TF II are also sufficient to repress the MyoD-dependent conversion of C3H10T1/2 cells and that the DBD of COUP-TF II (aa 79-144) is essential for the repression of trans-activation in the absence of the cognate binding motif and nucleic acid binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	234	COUP-TF II, p300 and MyoD interact in a competitive manner.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	235	We then embarked on experiments designed to analyse whether competitive binding between these interacting proteins was an issue with respect to the formation of a ternary complex.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	236	 We examined the ability of increasing amounts of COUP-TF II CDE to affect the efficiency of interaction between GST-MyoD and radiolabelled p300 (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	237	 We observed that increasing amounts of radiolabelled COUP-TF II CDE reduced the ability of a fixed amount of 35S-labelled p300 to interact with GST-MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Similarly, we observed that increasing amounts of myoD reduced the ability of p300 to interact with COUP-TF II (Fig.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	239	 COUP-TF II, p300 and MyoD interact in a competitive manner in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	240	 (A) Glutathione-immobilised GST-MyoD protein was incubated with 0.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	241	5  microl of 35S-radiolabelled p300 and either 2, 4 or 8  microl of radiolabelled COUP-TF II CDE as indicated.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	242	 In each pulldown, the input lanes represent ~10% of the total protein.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	243	 (B) Glutathione-immobilised GST-COUP-TF II protein was incubated with 1  microl of 35S-radiolabelled p300 and either 2, 4 or 8  microl of radiolabelled MyoD as indicated.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	244	This suggested that the interaction between COUP-TF II, p300 and myoD is competitive in nature, and that COUP-TF II may be involved in the process that regulates the interaction between MyoD and its cofactor, p300, which is essential for trans-activation of gene expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	245	The regulation of myogenesis (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	246	 muscle differentiation) is intimately controlled by a group of muscle specific bHLH proteins encoded by the myoD gene family (myoD, myogenin, myf-5, MRF-4) (reviewed in 1-3).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The products of the myoD gene family are involved in a variety of protein-protein interactions with many factors that mediate transcription [e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	248	 E12 and E47, TFIIB; 7,44], control the cell cycle (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	249	 RB; 45), and regulate chromatin accessibility and architecture (p300 and PCAF; 11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These protein-protein interactions regulate cellular proliferation and activate myogenic specific transcription that encodes the contractile phenotype.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Insights into the process of myogenesis have been provided by the myoD gene family of transcription factors, because they function at the nexus of command circuits that control the mutually exclusive events of division and differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	252	The nuclear receptor superfamily are potent regulators of development, differentiation, homeostasis and organ physiology; however, their functional role in mammalian muscle differentiation, regulation of MyoD and myogenesis has only been resolved at a descriptive level.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The classical ligand activated nuclear receptors (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	254	 thyroid hormone receptor) promote differentiation and muscle maturation in vivo (12,46).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	255	 However, the orphan nuclear receptors including Rev-erb[alpha], RVR and COUP-TF II, which are abundantly expressed in skeletal muscle and proliferating myogenic cells, antagonistically regulate muscle differentiation and appear to be involved in the maintenance of the proliferative state (13-15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	256	This study was directed toward identifying some of the mechanistic aspects of orphan nuclear receptor-mediated repression of muscle differentiation and myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Our work suggested that repression of MyoD-mediated trans-activation and myogenic conversion by COUP-TF II involves direct interactions with MyoD and its coactivator, p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Furthermore, the study provides another line of evidence in a biological context which demonstrates that COUP-TF II-mediated repression of MyoD-dependent trans-activation occurs in the absence of the orphan receptor cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	259	 This observation strengthens the view that trans-repression by COUP-TF II has a functional role during mammalian muscle differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Finally, it demonstrates that direct crosstalk between the orphan nuclear receptor and bHLH pathways has functional consequences for the regulation of differentiation and phenotypic acquisition.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	261	 This mode of action and crosstalk between two central regulatory components may turn out to be utilised in other pathways of mammalian differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	262	Specifically, our study showed that COUP-TF II could repress MyoD-mediated myogenic conversion of pluripotential 10T1/2 cells, when myoD expression was driven by a viral promoter refractory to COUP-TF II action.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This immunochemical analysis suggested that the CDE region (but not the N-terminal AB region) of COUP-TF II was necessary for the repression of myoD-mediated myogenic conversion.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	264	 In particular, the C and D regions of the orphan receptor, between aa residues 78 and 213, which encode the DBD and hinge region, respectively, were specifically involved in these events.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	265	 We observed that a MyoD-dependent reporter gene driven by four multimerised MyoD binding sites (from the MCK-enhancer), cloned upstream of the herpes simplex thymidine kinase promoter, was specifically inhibited by COUP-TF II expression.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Our study suggested that one of the mechanisms involved in this process of repression was the direct interaction between MyoD and COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Additional in vitro experiments demonstrated that the interaction was mediated by the acid-rich N-terminal activation domain of MyoD (which also mediates p300 binding) and the CD region of COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Furthermore, COUP-TF II interacted with the N-terminal RID (aa 1-149) of the cofactor p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	269	 This is perhaps not surprising, since many other classical ligand activated nuclear receptors (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	270	) interact with the coactivator p300 (42).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, the fact that the DBD (C-region) and hinge/D-region of COUP-TF II mediate the interaction to p300 and MyoD is novel, and perhaps suprising.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	272	 With respect to the in vitro and in vivo requirement of the COUP-TF II DBD and hinge region (aa 79-213) as a dimerisation interface for myoD and p300, it should be mentioned that this domain contains the DR and T box motifs, which have been implicated as dimerisation interfaces in RXR (and other nuclear receptors).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Furthermore, they are highly homologous to the similar motifs found in RXR, which is expected, since COUP-TF II and RXR belong to the same nuclear receptor sub-family (47,48).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The DR box has been strongly implicated in the heterodimerisation of TR and RAR with RXR.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The DR boxes in RXR[gamma] and COUP-TF II are highly homologous.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Similarly, the T-box sequence that forms a third helix in RXR, and is implicated in homo- and heterodimerisation, is very similar in COUP-TF II and RXR (49-53).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Recently, COUP-TF II and SpI have been demonstrated to synergistically regulate the transcription of the HIV type I LTR (54).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	278	 In support of our observations, they demonstrated that the in vitro and in vivo physical interaction with SpI is mediated by the DBD of COUP-TF.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Furthermore, the Octamer transcription factors are recruited by the C-region (DBD) of the glucocorticoid receptor (55).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	280	COUP-TF II-mediated repression of trans-activation involves the cofactor p300, since co-expression with p300 alleviates the silencing of transcription.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Our study suggested that repression may involve sequestration of this vital cofactor for myoD-mediated trans-activation, since COUP-TF II directly interacts with p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Whether inhibition of MyoD-dependent trans-activation by COUP-TF II binding is a result of: (i) a conformational change in MyoD (which is detrimental to function); (ii) a prevention of p300/cofactor/coactivator binding; (iii) and/or sequestering of cofactors (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	283	 p300) by COUP-TF II is unclear at present.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	284	 However, the in vitro GST-pulldown data does suggest that MyoD, COUP-TF II and p300 interact in a competitive manner, and that increasing amounts of COUP-TF II have the ability to reduce the interaction between myoD and p300 in vitro.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	285	Achatz and colleagues have demonstrated that repression of transcription by COUP-TF II activity is dependent on the DBD and a segment spanning aa residues 193-399 (30).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Single point mutations in the DBD that ablated sequence-specific binding did not affect the silencing of transcription.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	287	 (16) demonstrated that the repression of GAL4VP16-mediated trans-activation involves the DBD of COUP-TF II in the absence of its cognate binding motif.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Achatz suggested that the regions critical for repression of trans-activation by COUP-TF II were involved in mediating protein-protein interactions.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In the present study, we show that the DBD and hinge region of COUP-TF II alone are sufficient to bind either MyoD or p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Deletions of COUP-TF II that contain only part of the DBD (i.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	291	 from aa 134), however, are not able to interact with the RID of p300, suggesting that the entire DBD is required for binding.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Although the DBD and hinge region functions as a dimerisation interface in COUP-TF II, we also observed that the presence of the E-region strengthens the specificity of the interaction (G.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	293	 While this manuscript was being reviewed, it was demonstrated by Froeschle et al.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	294	 (56) that the DBD of the retinoic acid receptor also directly interacts with MyoD.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Our data and the above data suggested that the DBD of the nuclear receptors may also encode a dimerisation interface for the bHLH family of proteins.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	296	Forced expression of COUP-TF II in C2 myogenic cells blocks differentiation and in particular ablates the induction of p21 mRNA expression (14).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Moreover, in normal proliferating C2 cells, COUP-TF II mRNA is expressed, however, during cell cycle withdrawal and differentiation, the mRNA levels are repressed (15).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Transcription of the p21 gene is specifically stimulated by MyoD during myogenic differentiation, and is coactivated by a transcriptional complex that contains both p300 and PCAF (11).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	299	 In the present study, we show that MyoD-mediated transcription is significantly repressed by COUP-TF II.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	300	 This suggests that COUP-TF II is involved in the maintenance of the proliferative state, by controlling the trans-activation of the p21 gene.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	301	Nuclear receptors have also been shown to interact with a growing family of PAS/bHLH domain coactivators (e.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	302	 SRC1/N-CoA-1, TIF-2/GRIP-1, ACTR/RAC-3/pCIP) (57-59).
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	303	 However, the N-terminal bHLH/PAS domains in these coactivators function as activation domains, interact with other proteins or are involved in target gene specificity.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	304	 There has been no documented interactions between these regions of the cofactors and the nuclear receptors.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	305	In conclusion, the present study provides evidence that suggests that one of the mechanisms that mediates repression of muscle differentiation and myogenic conversion by COUP-TF II involves direct interactions with MyoD and its coactivator, p300.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Whether the direct crosstalk between the orphan nuclear receptor and bHLH pathways has target gene specificity in a developmental context remains to be elucidated, and will be a focus of future studies in the context of mammalian differentiation.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	307	This investigation was supported by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) of Australia, and the University of Queensland Enabling Fund.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	308	 is an NHMRC Supported Senior Research Fellow.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	309	 The Centre for Molecular and Cellular Biology is the recipient of an Australia Research Council (ARC) special research grant.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	310	 (1995) Science, 267, 1018-1021.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	311	 (1995) Science, 267, 1024-1027.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	312	 (1997) Science, 278, 1947-1950.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	313	 (1994) Development, 120, 25-36.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	314	 (1993) Science, 260, 1117-1121.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	315	 (1998) Oncogene, 16, 3369-3378.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	316	 (1995) Science, 270, 1354-1357.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	317	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Tel: + 61 7 3365 4492; Fax: +61 7 3365 4388; Email: g.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	319	au This page is run by Oxford University Press, Great Clarendon Street, Oxford OX2 6DP, as part of the OUP Journals Comments and feedback: www-admin{at}oup.
0.24778366.9826778.html.plaintext.txt	320	uk' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> Last modification: 21 Nov 1998 Copyright Oxford University Press, 1998.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	0	Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 Regulates the Expression of Pancreatic -Cell Genes Implicated in Glucose Metabolism and Nutrient-induced Insulin Secretion* Haiyan Wang, Pierre Maechler, Peter A.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Division de Biochimie Clinique, Department de Medecine Interne, Centre Medical Universitaire, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, July 25, 2000.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	4	Mutations in the HNF4 gene are associated with the subtype 1 of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY1), which is characterized by impaired insulin secretory response to glucose in pancreatic -cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is a transcription factor critical for liver development and hepatocyte-specific gene expression.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	6	 However, the role of HNF4 in the regulation of pancreatic -cell gene expression and its correlation with metabolism secretion coupling have not been previously investigated.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The tetracycline-inducible system was employed to achieve tightly controlled expression of both wild type (WT) and dominant-negative mutant (DN) of HNF4 in INS-1 cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The induction of WT-HNF4 resulted in a left shift in glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, whereas DN-HNF4 selectively impaired nutrient-stimulated insulin release.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Induction of DN-HNF4 also caused defective mitochondrial function substantiated by reduced [14C]pyruvate oxidation, attenuated substrate-evoked mitochondrial membrane hyperpolarization, and blunted nutrient-generated cellular ATP production.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Quantitative evaluation of HNF4-regulated pancreatic -cell gene expression revealed altered mRNA levels of insulin, glucose transporter-2, L-pyruvate kinase, aldolase B, 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase E1 subunit, and mitochondrial uncoupling protein-2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The patterns of HNF4-regulated gene expression are strikingly similar to that of its downstream transcription factor HNF1.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Indeed, HNF4 changed the HNF1 mRNA levels and HNF1 promoter luciferase activity through altered HNF4 binding.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These results demonstrate the importance of HNF4 in -cell metabolism-secretion coupling.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	14	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	15	The hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4),1 a transcription factor of the nuclear hormone receptor superfamily, is expressed in liver, kidney, gut, and pancreatic islets (1-3).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Mutations in the human HNF4 gene lead to maturity onset diabetes of the young subtype 1 (MODY1), which is characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance and impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion from pancreatic -cells (4-6).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These MODY1 mutations located in various domains of the HNF4 protein result in defective function of the transcription factor (6).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The clinical phenotype of MODY1 patients is indistinguishable from that of MODY3 patients who carry mutations in the HNF1 gene (5, 6).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	19	 HNF4 acts upstream of HNF1 in a transcriptional cascade that drives liver-specific gene expression and hepatocyte differentiation (7-9).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	20	 A naturally occurring mutation in the HNF4-binding site of the HNF1 promoter identified in a MODY3 family (10) suggests that the transcriptional hierarchy could also be involved in pancreatic -cell gene expression and function.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	21	HNF4 defines the expression of liver-specific genes encoding apolipoproteins, serum factors, cytochrome P-450 isoforms, and proteins involved in the metabolism of glucose, fatty acids, and amino acids (reviewed in Ref.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	22	 However, clinical characterization of MODY1 subjects reveals that the primary defect is impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion from pancreatic -cells rather than liver dysfunction (5, 12-14).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Unfortunately, little is known as to how HNF4 regulates -cell-restricted gene expression and glucose metabolism and associated insulin secretion.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Targeted disruption of the hnf4 gene results in defective gastrulation of mouse embryos due to dysfunction of the visceral endoderm (15).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	25	 This early embryonic lethality prevents further analysis of the HNF4 function in pancreatic -cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The precise role of HNF4 in pancreatic -cells would best be examined by conditional -cell-specific deletion of the mouse hnf4 gene.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Another alternative is to up- and down-regulate HNF4 function in pancreatic -cell lines through gene manipulation.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	28	In the present study, the wild type HNF4 (WT-HNF4) and its dominant-negative mutant (DN-HNF4) could be induced in INS-1 cells under tight control of the reverse tetracycline-dependent transactivator (16).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	29	 DN-HNF4 represents the epitope Myc-tagged truncated HNF4 mutant protein lacking the first 111 amino acids (myc111HNF4) (17).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The HNF4 protein consists of an N-terminal ligand-independent transactivation domain (amino acids 1-24), a DNA binding domain containing two zinc fingers (amino acids 51-117), and a large hydrophobic portion (amino acids 163-368) composed of the dimerization, ligand binding, cofactor binding, and ligand-dependent transactivation domain (18, 19).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	31	 DN-HNF4 therefore suppresses the endogenous WT-HNF4 transcriptional activity by the formation of heterodimers lacking DNA binding capacity (17).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	32	 We have investigated in a quantitative manner the consequences of altered HNF4 function on -cell-specific expression of genes implicated in glucose metabolism and insulin secretion.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	33	 This allowed us to elucidate the molecular basis and HNF4 target genes responsible for impaired metabolism secretion coupling in -cells deficient in HNF4 function.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	34	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	35	Generation of Stable Cell Lines-- The rat insulinoma INS-1 cell line-derived stable clones were cultured in RPMI 1640 in 11 mM glucose, unless indicated otherwise (20).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The establishment of the first step stable clone INS-r3, which expresses the reverse tetracycline-dependent transactivator, was reported previously (21).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Plasmids used in the secondary stable transfection were constructed by subcloning the cDNAs encoding the rat WT-HNF4 (a generous gift from Dr.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	38	, New York) and DN-HNF4 into the expression vector PUHD10-3 (a kind gift from Dr.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Bujard, University Heidelberg, Germany).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	40	 DN-HNF4 was PCR-amplified from WT-HNF4 using the following primers, ctaggatccttccgggctggcatgaagaaagaagcc and ccagaattcctgcagatggttgtcctttag.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The PCR fragment was subcloned into pcDNA3.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	42	1myc (Invitrogen, Netherlands) and sequenced.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Transfection, clone selection, and screening procedures were described previously (21).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	44	Immunoblot-- Immunoblotting procedures were performed as described previously using enhanced chemiluminescence (Pierce) for detection (22).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Dilutions for antibody against HNF4 (kindly supplied by Dr.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Sladek, University of California, Riverside, CA) and anti-Myc tag (9E10) in myeloma SP2/0 culture medium were 1:6,000 and 1:10.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	47	Insulin Secretion and Cellular Insulin Content-- Cells in 24-well dishes were cultured in 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	48	5 mM glucose medium with or without indicated doses of doxycycline for 14 or 48 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Insulin secretion was measured over a period of 30 min, in Krebs-Ringer/bicarbonate-HEPES buffer (KRBH, 140 mM NaCl, 3.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	50	5 mM CaCl2, 2 mM NaHCO3, 10 mM HEPES, 0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	51	1% bovine serum albumin) containing indicated stimulators.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Insulin content was determined after extraction with acid ethanol following the procedures of Asfari et al.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Insulin was detected by radioimmunoassay using rat insulin as standard (22).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	54	Intracellular ATP-- Cells in 6-well dishes were cultured in 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	55	5 mM glucose medium with or without 500 ng/ml doxycycline for 48 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The production of ATP was measured during 8 min of stimulation in KRBH.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	57	 ATP assay was performed as reported previously (22).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	58	[14C]Pyruvate Oxidation-- The production of 14CO2 from [1-14C]pyruvate or [2-14C]pyruvate was measured over 1 h in KRBH containing either 0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	59	0 mM pyruvate as described previously (23, 24).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	60	Mitochondrial Membrane Potential (m)-- After a 48-h culture period in 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	61	5 mM glucose medium with or without 500 ng/ml doxycycline, cells were trypsinized (0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	62	27 mM EDTA), and the cell suspension was maintained for 2 h in a spinner culture with 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	63	5 mM glucose RPMI 1640 plus 1% newborn calf serum at 37  degrees C.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Mitochondrial membrane potential (m) was measured as described (25).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Briefly, after the spinner culture period, cells were loaded with 10  microg/ml rhodamine-123 (Rh-123) for 10 min at 37  degrees C.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After centrifugation, the cells were resuspended and transferred to the fluorimeter cuvette at 37  degrees C with gentle stirring in an LS-50B fluorimeter (PerkinElmer Life Sciences), and fluorescence, excited at 490 nm, was measured at 530 nm.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	67	Total RNA Isolation and Northern Blotting-- Cells in 10-cm dishes were cultured in 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	68	5 mM glucose medium with or without 500 ng/ml doxycycline for 14 or 48 h, followed by an additional 8 h in culture medium with 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Total RNA was extracted and blotted to nylon membranes as described previously (22).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The membrane was prehybridized and then hybridized to 32P-labeled random primer cDNA probes by the technique of Sambrook et al.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	71	 To ensure equal RNA loading and even transfer, all membranes were stripped and re-hybridized with the "housekeeping gene" probes such as -actin or cyclophilin.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	72	 cDNA fragments used as probes for L-pyruvate kinase (L-PK), glucose transporter-2 (GLUT-2), glucokinase, insulin, PDX1, HNF4, upstream stimulatory factors (USF), c-Jun, and C/EBP mRNA detection were digested from corresponding expression vectors kindly provided by Drs.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	73	 cDNA probes for rat aldolase B, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, dimerization cofactor for HNF1 (DcoH), mitochondrial adenine nucleotide translocator 1 and 2 (ANT1 and ANT2), mitochondrial uncoupling protein-2 (UCP-2), mitochondrial 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase (OGDH) E1 subunit, glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), Pax4, Pax6, Nkx2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	74	1, Isl1, insulin receptor substrate-2 (IRS2), cyclin-dependent kinase-4 (Cdk4), and cyclophilin were prepared by reverse transcriptase-PCR and confirmed by sequencing.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	75	Nuclear Extract Preparation and Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA)-- Cells in 10-cm dishes were grown in culture medium with or without 500 ng/ml doxycycline for 48 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The following double-stranded oligonucleotides were used as probes, 5'-GGCTGAAGTCCAAAGTTCAGTCCCTTCGC-3' (8).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	77	 EMSA procedures including conditions for nuclear extract preparation, probe labeling, binding reactions, unlabeled-probe competition, and antibody supershift were performed as reported previously (22).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	78	Transient Transfection and Luciferase Assay-- The HNF1 gene promoter luciferase reporter plasmids, WT-HNF1Luc (wild type) and AHNF1Luc (HNF4-binding site deleted), were kindly provided by Dr.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Miura (Akita University, Japan) (27).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	80	Transient transfection experiments and luciferase reporter enzyme assays were carried out as previously reported (22).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	81	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	82	WT-HNF4 or DN-HNF4 Protein Was Induced in INS-1 Cells in a Dose- and Time-dependent Manner-- We have obtained 10 and 8 clones positively expressing WT-HNF4 and DN-HNF4, respectively.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The clones designated as WT-HNF4-28 and DN-HNF4-26 that displayed highest induction levels of transgene proteins were chosen for the present study.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The time course and dose response of doxycycline effect on WT-HNF4 and DN-HNF4 expression are illustrated in Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	85	 WT-HNF4 protein could be induced within a range from 2- to 50-fold above the endogenous protein level (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Thus, graded overexpression of WT-HNF4 could be achieved by culturing the WT-HNF4-28 cells with varying doses of doxycycline in a defined period.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Similar induction of DN-HNF4 protein was detected in the nuclear extracts from DN-HNF4-26 cells (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	88	 No leakage of this doxycycline-dependent promoter was observed, since the expression of DN-HNF4 protein was not detectable in non-induced DN-HNF4-26 cells (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Therefore, the dominant-negative suppression of HNF4 function in INS-1 cells could be rapidly achieved by culturing the DN-HNF4-26 cells with a maximum dose of doxycycline (500 ng/ml).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	90	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	91	   Dose response and time course of doxycycline effect on WT-HNF4 (A) and DN-HNF4 (B) expression.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	92	 For studying dose response, cells were cultured with the indicated doses of Dox for 48 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	93	 For studying time course, cells were cultured in medium containing 500 ng/ml doxycycline and harvested for nuclear extracts at the indicated times.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Nuclear extracts from WT-HNF4-28 (50  microg/lane) (A) and DN-HNF4-26 (10  microg/lane) (B) were resolved in 9% SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, transferred to nitrocellulose, and immunoblotted with antibodies against HNF4 (A) and the Myc-tag (B), respectively.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	95	Effects of WT-HNF4 and DN-HNF4 on Insulin Secretion-- Impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion from pancreatic -cells is the primary defect causing hyperglycemia in MODY1 patients carrying HNF4 mutations.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	96	 We therefore examined the consequences of induction of WT-HNF4 and DN-HNF4 on insulin secretion in INS-1 cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The graded overexpression of WT-HNF4 led to a left shift of glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	98	 However, the maximal (above 12 mM) glucose-elicited insulin secretion remained unchanged (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	99	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	100	   HNF4 regulates nutrient-evoked insulin secretion in INS-1 cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Insulin secretion was quantified as described under "Experimental Procedures" and normalized by cellular DNA content.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A, glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in WT-HNF4-28 cells induced with indicated doses of doxycycline for 14 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Data represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	104	 of six independent experiments.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Statistical significance between doxycycline-induced and non-induced cells was obtained at 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	106	001, unpaired Student's t test).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	107	 B, glucose-, leucine-, and K+-elicited insulin secretion in DN-HNF4-26 cells induced with 500 ng/ml doxycycline for 48 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Insulin secretion was measured during 30 min of incubation with 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	109	5 mM (Basal) and 24 mM glucose in KRBH, or with 20 mM leucine and 20 mM KCl added in KRBH containing 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Data are the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Statistical significance between doxycycline-induced and non-induced cells was observed at 24 mM glucose- and 20 mM leucine-stimulated conditions (p  <  0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Insulin content was reduced by 30  plus or minus  8.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	113	Glucose generates ATP and other metabolic coupling factors important for insulin secretion through glycolysis and mitochondrial oxidation (28).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The physiological insulin secretagogue, leucine, is transported directly into mitochondria to provide substrates for the tricarboxylic acid cycle (28).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	115	 K+ causes insulin secretion by depolarization of the -cell membrane, resulting in an increase in cytosolic Ca2+ (28).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	116	 We therefore examined the insulin secretory responses to these three secretagogues that act at different levels of the signal transduction cascade following induction of DN-HNF4.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	117	 2B, DN-HNF4 selectively inhibited glucose- and leucine-stimulated insulin secretion.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	118	 This could be explained by defective glucose and leucine metabolism.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	119	Effects of DN-HNF4 on Cellular ATP Production and Mitochondrial Oxidation-- To investigate whether impaired nutrient-evoked insulin secretion is correlated to defective cellular ATP production, we analyzed the impact of DN-HNF4 expression on the level of ATP generated by glucose and leucine.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	120	 3A, induction of DN-HNF4 indeed abolished the ATP generation by glucose and leucine.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Since the mitochondrial substrate leucine failed to generate ATP after induction of DN-HNF4, it would seem that HNF4 is required for maintaining normal mitochondrial function.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	122	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	123	   Induction of DN-HNF4 impairs cellular ATP production and mitochondrial oxidation.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	124	 A, cellular ATP levels in DN-HNF4-26 cells were measured after 8 min of incubation with 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	125	5 (Basal) and 24 mM glucose in KRBH or 20 mM leucine and 20 mM KCl added in KRBH containing 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Data represent mean  plus or minus  S.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	127	 of three independent experiments.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Glucose- and leucine-stimulated ATP production was significantly inhibited after treatment with 500 ng/ml doxycycline for 48 h (p  <  0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	129	 B, [2-14C]pyruvate oxidation was measured during 1 h of incubation in KRBH containing 0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Data represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	131	 performed in triplicate from one of four similar experiments.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	132	 C, [1-14C]pyruvate oxidation was measured with identical conditions in the same preparation of cells as in B.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Data represent the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	134	 performed in triplicate from one of three similar experiments.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	135	To test this hypothesis, we examined the consequences of DN-HNF4 induction on mitochondrial oxidation of pyruvate.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Pyruvate-derived carbons enter the tricarboxylic acid cycle as either acetyl-CoA, catalyzed by pyruvate dehydrogenase, or oxaloacetate via pyruvate carboxylase.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	137	 By using pyruvate radiolabeled at either the first or second carbon, the putative defects at various steps in pyruvate metabolism can be assessed.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The radiolabeled carbon of [1-14C]pyruvate is lost to CO2 at the pyruvate dehydrogenase step as pyruvate is converted into acetyl-CoA.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Alternatively, if pyruvate enters the tricarboxylic acid cycle via oxaloacetate, the label is lost to CO2 at isocitrate dehydrogenase within one turn of the cycle.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Radiolabeled CO2 is generated from 2-14C at either OGDH or isocitrate dehydrogenase when pyruvate enters the tricarboxylic acid cycle as acetyl-CoA.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Overexpression of DN-HNF4 reduced CO2 formation from [2-14C]pyruvate by 41% (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	142	 3B), whereas CO2 formation from [1-14C]pyruvate was not different between non- and induced conditions (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	143	 These results suggest that the defect in mitochondrial metabolism is not at the point of entry of pyruvate into the tricarboxylic acid cycle, rather that the defect appears in reactions within the tricarboxylic acid cycle.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This is in full agreement with the impairment of leucine stimulation of insulin secretion since leucine metabolism bypasses pyruvate and enters the tricarboxylic acid cycle solely as acetyl-CoA.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Decreased isocitrate dehydrogenase activity would also be unlikely since impairment at this step would be observed by both [1-14C]pyruvate and [2-14C]pyruvate oxidation.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	146	 These oxidation experiments suggest that steps following this reaction beginning with OGDH may be responsible for impaired [2-14C]pyruvate oxidation.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	147	Effect of DN-HNF4a on Mitochondrial Membrane Potential (m) in INS-1 Cells-- The m was measured in a suspension of INS-1 cells by monitoring rhodamine-123 fluorescence.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In control cells (Dox) addition of 10 mM glucose (12.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	149	5 mM final) potently hyperpolarized m, whereas 1  microM of the protonophore FCCP depolarized m (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In cells expressing DN-HNF4 (+Dox), the glucose response was inhibited by 65% (p  <  0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Impaired hyperpolarization of m was also observed when the glycolysis was bypassed by stimulating cells with the end product of glycolysis pyruvate (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	152	 4B), indicating mitochondrial dysfunction.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Direct activation with methyl succinate of the electron transport chain at complex II resulted in a diminished response in DN-HNF4-induced cells (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The amplitude of complete m depolarization by FCCP was also reduced in cells treated with doxycycline (43%; p  <  0.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	155	01), suggesting that the mitochondria were partially uncoupled by suppression of HNF4 function (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	156	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	157	   Effect of DN-HNF4 on mitochondrial membrane potential (m) in INS-1 cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The m was measured in a suspension of 2  x  106 INS-1 cells per 2 ml of KRBH using rhodamine-123 (Rh-123) fluorescence after a spinner culture period.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	159	5 mM final) hyperpolarization of m was tested followed by the complete depolarization of m using 1  microM of the uncoupler FCCP.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	160	 B, the end product of glycolysis pyruvate (10 mM) was added 10 min before FCCP.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	161	 C, the mitochondrial substrate methyl succinate (10 mM) was tested.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The effects of these various substrates (5 min after addition) as well as that of FCCP are summarized with statistics in D.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Each trace (A-C) is representative of 4-8 independent experiments.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	164	Effects of WT-HNF4 and DN-HNF4 on Pancreatic -Cell Gene Expression-- The expression of genes involved in glucose metabolism (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	165	 5, A and B) or in pancreatic -cell development and differentiation (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	166	 5, C and D) was quantitatively evaluated in WT-HNF4-28 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	167	 5, A and C) and DN-HNF4-26 cells (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	168	 5A, WT-HNF4 mRNA could be induced by 2-, 8-, and 50-fold above the endogenous level.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	169	 This graded overexpression of WT-HNF4 resulted in a stepwise increase in the expression of three glucose-responsive genes encoding, respectively, GLUT-2, L-PK, and aldolase B (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	170	 However, the mRNA level of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, which is also responsive to glucose, remained unaltered (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Induction of WT-HNF4 also caused incremental expression of OGDH E1 subunit transcript (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Consistently, The mRNA levels of GLUT-2, aldolase B, L-PK, and OGDH E1 subunit were significantly reduced after induction of DN-HNF4 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	173	 On the other hand, induction of DN-HNF4 led to increased UCP-2 mRNA expression (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Therefore, HNF4 regulates the expression of genes involved in both glycolysis and mitochondrial metabolism.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The profile of HNF4-targeted genes is strikingly similar to that of HNF1 (29).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	176	 HNF4 may regulate the expression of genes implicated in glucose metabolism through HNF1 function as in hepatocytes (7-9).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	177	View larger version (55K):    Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	178	   Effects of WT-HNF1 and DN-HNF1 on pancreatic -cell gene expression.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Northern blotting was used to quantify the gene expression in WT-HNF4-28 (A and C) and DN-HNF4-26 (B and D) cells induced with indicated doses of doxycycline and cultured at given concentrations of glucose (detailed under "Experimental Procedures").
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	180	 RNA samples were analyzed by hybridization with the indicated cDNA probes.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	181	Since HNF4 is required for liver development and hepatocyte differentiation (9), we investigated whether HNF4 regulates the expression of genes important for the pancreatic -cell phenotype.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	182	 5D) did not alter the expression patterns of PDX1, Pax4, Pax6, NKx2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	183	1, and Isl-1, which are necessary for normal pancreatic cell development or differentiation (30).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Moreover, HNF4 did not regulate the mRNA levels of USF, c-Jun, and C/EBP (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The expression of these transcription factors appeared to be responsive to glucose (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The expression of another glucose-responsive transcription factor, DcoH, was slightly affected by induction of WT-HNF4 but not by expression of DN-HNF4 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5, C and D), suggesting the involvement of an indirect mechanism.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Both Cdk4 and IRS2 are involved in pancreatic -cell development (31, 32), but their expression was not regulated by HNF4 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Induction of DN-HNF4 for 48 h caused 50% reduction in insulin mRNA levels (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	190	 This may be secondary to decreased HNF1 function, since HNF1 is required for insulin gene transcription (29).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	191	HNF4 Regulates Pancreatic -Cell Gene Expression through HNF1 Function-- We performed EMSA for studying HNF4 binding activity to HNF1 promoter, luciferase reporter enzyme assay for HNF1 promoter activity, and Northern blotting for the HNF1 mRNA expression.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Nuclear extracts were prepared from WT-HNF4-28 and DN-HNF4-26 cells cultured for 48 h in the presence or absence of 500 ng/ml doxycycline.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The murine HNF1 promoter segment, which contains the HNF4-binding site, was used as probe (8).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Induction of WT-HNF4 resulted in a dramatic increase in the signal density of HNF4 binding (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	195	 On the other hand, induction of DN-HNF4 almost completely abolished the binding activity of endogenous HNF4 to the HNF1 promoter (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	196	 DN-HNF4 exerts its dominant-negative function by forming DN-HNF4/WT-HNF4 heterodimers that lack DNA binding capacity (11).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The retarded DNA binding complexes corresponding to endogenous WT-HNF4 and/or induced transgene WT-HNF4 homodimers were supershifted by a specific antibody against HNF4 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	198	View larger version (43K):    Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	199	   Induction of WT-HNF1 and DN-HNF1 regulates the HNF1 mRNA expression and HNF1 promoter luciferase activity through altered HNF4 binding.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	200	 EMSA (A), Northern blotting (B), and luciferase enzyme reporter activity (C) assays were performed in WT-HNF4-28 and DN-HNF4-26 cells cultured in the presence or absence of 500 ng/ml doxycycline for 48 h.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	201	 A, for EMSA, the oligonucleotide duplex corresponding to the murine HNF1 promoter fragment containing HNF4-binding site was used as probe.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	202	 B, for Northern blot analysis, cells were cultured in 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	203	5 mM glucose medium for 48 h and continued for 8 h with indicated glucose concentrations.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	204	 RNA samples from WT-HNF4-28 (upper panel) and DN-HNF4-26 (lower panel) cells were hybridized with HNF1 cDNA probe.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	205	 C, cells were transiently transfected with HNF1Luc or AHNF1Luc by calcium phosphate-DNA co-precipitation.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Luciferase activity measured in non-induced cells was defined as 100%.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Data are the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	208	Consistently, induction of WT-HNF4 resulted in a 2-fold increase in endogenous HNF1 mRNA level, whereas DN-HNF4 completely eliminated the HNF1 expression (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	209	 To confirm that HNF4 directly regulates HNF1 transcription, we transiently transfected WT-HNF4-28 and DN-HNF4-26 cells with a luciferase reporter construct containing either the wild type HNF1 gene promoter (HNF1Luc) or a promoter that lacks a functional HNF4-binding site (AHNF1Luc).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	210	 6C, overexpression of WT-HNF4 caused a 2.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	211	5-fold increase in the luciferase reporter enzyme activity in WT-HNF4-28 cells transfected with HNF1Luc.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Deletion of the HNF4-binding site in the HNF1 promoter (AHNF1) abolished the activation induced by WT-HNF4 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In contrast, induction of DN-HNF4 caused a 71% reduction in wild type HNF1 promoter activity (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The inhibitory effect of DN-HNF4 was no longer present in DN-HNF4-26 cells transfected with AHNF1Luc (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Therefore, HNF4 directly controls HNF1 gene expression in pancreatic -cells as it does in hepatocytes.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	216	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	217	It has been demonstrated that HNF4 controls the expression of a large array of liver-specific genes encoding several apolipoproteins, metabolic proteins, and serum factors that are essential for hepatocyte differentiation and liver development (9).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	218	 HNF4 is also required for HNF1 expression in hepatocytes (7-9).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Another study in embryonic stem cell-differentiated embryoid bodies (33) shows that the absence of HNF4 affects the expression of genes encoding GLUT-2, aldolase B, and L-PK, which are involved in glucose transport and glycolysis.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	220	 However, little is known as to how HNF4 regulates pancreatic -cell gene expression.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The primary cause of the MODY1 phenotype is impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion from pancreatic -cells (5).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The present study was therefore designed to investigate the role of HNF4 in the regulation of the expression of -cell genes implicated in glucose metabolism and associated insulin secretion.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	223	We found that overexpression of WT-HNF4 caused a left shift of glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, whereas dominant-negative suppression of HNF4 selectively blunted the insulin release induced by glucose and leucine but not by K+ depolarization.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The diminished nutrient-evoked insulin secretion is associated with reduced ATP production in DN-HNF4-expressing cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The physiological insulin secretagogue leucine raises the cytosolic and mitochondrial Ca2+ concentrations through mitochondrial metabolism downstream of glycolysis (28, 34).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Therefore, we suggest that loss of HNF4 function leads to defective mitochondrial metabolism and, as a consequence, impaired insulin secretion.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The reduced mitochondrial oxidation of [2-14C]pyruvate and the abrogation of mitochondrial membrane hyperpolarization elicited by glucose, pyruvate, and methyl succinate indicate impaired mitochondrial tricarboxylic acid cycle enzyme activity and partial uncoupling of the mitochondrial respiratory chain.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	228	Quantitative Northern blot analysis allows us to identify HNF4 target genes responsible for defective metabolism-secretion coupling.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	229	 HNF4 indeed regulates the expression of genes encoding GLUT-2, aldolase B, and L-PK in pancreatic -cells (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	230	 5), as inferred from previous studies in hepatocytes and embryonic stem cell-differentiated embryoid bodies (8, 9).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Most importantly, we demonstrate that HNF4 alters the mRNA expression of mitochondrial OGDH E1 subunit and UCP-2 (Fig.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	232	 5), which may indeed contribute more significantly to the impaired metabolism-secretion coupling.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The phenotype and gene expression patterns in DN-HNF4-expressing cells are strikingly similar to those of DN-HNF1-expressing cells (22, 29).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	234	 This prompted us to investigate whether HNF4 regulates -cell expression through HNF1 function, as in hepatocytes (9).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	235	 We provide unprecedented evidence that HNF4 is required for HNF1 expression in pancreatic -cells.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	236	This conclusion is based on the use of an artificial dominant-negative hnf4 mutation.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The naturally occurring human mutations of HNF4 do not function in a dominant-negative manner (6, 35).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	238	 It is to be expected that a mutation with such repressive action on the endogenous HNF4 function would cause embryonic lethality, as is the case in the hnf4 knock-out mouse (15).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Haploinsufficiency or reduced gene dosage of HNF4 may thus explain the mechanism leading to the MODY1 phenotype (33).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The INS-1 cell line expressing DN-HNF4 provides a convenient model to explore the impact of impaired HNF4 function on -cell gene expression and metabolism-secretion coupling.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	241	 This goal cannot be achieved by the introduction of one of the human HNF4 mutations into -cell lines.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	242	 In fact, the induction of a nonsense mutation HNF4Q268X to a level similar to DN-HNF4 had no detectable consequences on -cell gene expression and metabolism-secretion coupling.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	243	MODY1 patients display secretory defects not only in -cells but also in the glucagon-secreting -cells and the pancreatic polypeptide-secreting cells (36, 37).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	244	 However, this general effect on islet hormone release does not seem due to an effect on the development and differentiation of the endocrine pancreas, since altered HNF4 function did not affect the expression of PDX1 and other transcription factors determining pancreatic phenotype.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	245	 On the other hand, loss of HNF4 function may cause reduced -cell insulin content secondary to defective HNF1 function (22, 29).
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Sarret for expert technical assistance.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Iynedjian (glucokinase cDNA), U.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Bujard (PUHD 10-3 plasmid), and N.
0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	249	* This work was supported by Swiss National Science Foundation Grant 32-49755.

0.278518.10967120.html.plaintext.txt	251	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
