0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase Gene Glucocorticoid Response Unit: Identification of the Functional Domains of Accessory Factors HNF3ss (Hepatic Nuclear Factor-3ss) and HNF4 and the Necessity of Proper Alignment of Their Cognate Binding Sites Jen-Chywan Wang, Per-Erik Stromstedt1, Takashi Sugiyama and Daryl K.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Molecular Physiology and Biophysics Vanderbilt University Medical School Nashville, Tennessee, 37232-0615.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Complete induction of hepatic phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) gene transcription by glucocorticoids requires a complex glucocorticoid response unit (GRU).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	3	 The GRU is comprised of two glucocorticoid receptor (GR)-binding sites (GR1 and GR2) and four accessory factor-binding sites [AF1, AF2, AF3, and cAMP response element (CRE)] that bind distinct transcription factors.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) and chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF) bind to the AF1 element and account for AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Members of the hepatic nuclear factor 3 (HNF3) family bind to the AF2 element and provide AF2 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In this report, we show that the functions of AF1 and AF2 are dependent on their positions in the promoter, since they cannot substitute for each other nor can they be exchanged without a reduction in the response to glucocorticoids.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We also identified the domains of HNF4 and HNF3ss that are required for the AF1 and AF2 activities, respectively.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The carboxy-terminal transactivation domain of HNF4 (amino acids 128 to 374) confers most of the AF1 activity, while the carboxy-terminal transactivation domain of HNF3ss (amino acids 361 to 458) mediates AF2 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These domains of HNF4 and HNF3ss appear to have distinct roles in the response to glucocorticoids, as there are unique structural requirements for each, as judged by the failure of most other classes of transactivation domains to serve as accessory factors.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These results suggest that the regulation of the PEPCK gene by glucocorticoids requires specific interactions between GR, accessory factors, and coactivators, and that the transactivation domains of AF1 and AF2 are of fundamental importance in the assembly of this multiprotein complex.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	11	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The hepatic phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) gene, which encodes a rate-controlling enzyme of hepatic gluconeogenesis, is under multihormonal control at the transcriptional level (1, 2).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Transcription of the PEPCK gene is stimulated by glucocorticoids, retinoic acids, and glucagon (via cAMP), while insulin and glucose repress PEPCK gene transcription (1, 2, 3, 4, 5).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	13	 A complex glucocorticoid response unit (GRU) in the PEPCK gene promoter is required for a complete glucocorticoid response.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The GRU consists of two adjacent glucocorticoid receptor (GR)-binding sites (GR1 and GR2) and four accessory elements: AF1, AF2, AF3, and the cAMP response element (CRE) (see Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	15	 GR1 and GR2, alone or in combination, are unable to confer a glucocorticoid response when placed in the context of a heterologous promoter (9).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Although none of the four accessory elements mediates a glucocorticoid response itself, deletion or mutation of any accessory element in the PEPCK promoter causes about a 50 to 70% reduction in the glucocorticoid response (6, 8, 10).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Furthermore, any combination of two mutations of AF1, AF2, or AF3 essentially abolishes the glucocorticoid response (6).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Thus, the PEPCK GR1 and GR2, unlike simple glucocorticoid response elements (GREs) that can mediate a glucocorticoid response, are inactive in the absence of at least two accessory elements.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	19	View larger version (10K):    Figure 1.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Schematic Diagram of the PEPCK GRU.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	21	The PEPCK GRU includes two GR-binding sites (GR1 and GR2) and four accessory elements (AF1, AF2, AF3, and the CRE) and their associated trans-acting factors (lower panel).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The position of each cis-element, relative to the transcription initiation site, is indicated above the figure.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	23	  AF1 activity is provided by either of two members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4), or chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF) (11).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	24	 COUP-TF also binds to the AF3 element and serves as an accessory factor for the glucocorticoid response (6).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Members of the hepatic nuclear factor 3 (HNF3) and CCAAT enhancer binding protein (C/EBP) families bind to the AF2 element (12, 13).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The binding of HNF3, but not C/EBP, to this element correlates with AF2 activity (14).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Hence, HNF3 has been identified as an accessory factor for the glucocorticoid response.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Finally, the CRE binding protein (CREB) and C/EBP family members bind to the CRE (12, 15, 16).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Although a physical interaction between GR and CREB has been identified in vitro (8), it appears that C/EBPss functions as the accessory factor for the glucocorticoid response through the CRE (16A ).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	30	In experiments reported in this paper, we show that AF1 cannot substitute for AF2, and vice versa, as the exchange of these elements in the PEPCK GRU results in about a 50% reduction of the glucocorticoid response.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Thus, AF1 and AF2 both function in a position-dependent manner.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	32	 We also identify the domains within HNF4 (the AF1 factor) and HNF3ss (the AF2 factor) required for accessory factor activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In both cases, previously identified transactivation domains are critical for accessory factor activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Several distinct transactivation domains identified in other proteins cannot replace the HNF3 and HNF4 activities in the context of the PEPCK GRU.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	35	 These results indicate that glucocorticoid-stimulated PEPCK gene transcription requires functional interactions between GR and the transactivation domains of at least two accessory factors, or between these two components and a third, coregulatory protein, and that these interactions require a specific spatial organization of the components of the GRU.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	36	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   AF1 and AF2 Function in a Position-Dependent Manner Constructs were made with various combinations of AF1 and AF2 substitutions in the context of the wild-type PEPCK promoter ligated to the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) reporter gene (pAF1 to 2, also referred to as pPL32 in this and previous publications) to compare the roles of AF1 and AF2 in the PEPCK GRU (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	37	 When the AF2 element was replaced by an AF1 element (pAF1 to 1) or, conversely, when the AF2 element was put at the AF1 site (pAF2 to 2), glucocorticoid responses were 60 to 70% lower than those obtained from the wild-type pAF1 to 2 reporter (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	38	 These responses are equivalent to the glucocorticoid response obtained when either AF1 or AF2 is deleted or mutated (7, 10).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Thus, these results show that the AF1 element is inert at the position of the AF2 element, and the AF2 element is inactive at the AF1 site in the PEPCK GRU, and suggest that AF1 and AF2 have distinct functions.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	40	 These results are consistent with our previous observations (17).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Next, the AF1 element and the AF2 element were switched with each other (pAF2 to 1, Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	42	 2) to determine whether their relative positions within the GRU are critical.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	43	 If a specific spatial alignment between AF1, AF2, and the other members of the GRU is not important for a complete glucocorticoid response, and only the presence of these transcription factors is required, this construct should confer a glucocorticoid response similar to that of the wild-type pAF1 to 2 reporter.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	44	 However, the pAF2 to 1 reporter construct conferred a much weaker glucocorticoid response than did pAF1 to 2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Thus, the positional alignment of AF1 and AF2 in the PEPCK gene promoter appears to be critical for mediating optimal accessory factor activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	46	View larger version (16K):    Figure 2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The Alignment of AF1 and AF2 Is Critical.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	48	H4IIE cells were cotransfected with 10  microg of various reporter constructs [either pAF1 to 2 (pPL32), pAF1 to 1, pAF2 to 2, or pAF2 to 1] and 5  microg of an expression plasmid that encodes the GR.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Cells were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone (DEX) for 18 to 24 h, and CAT activity was measured.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Results are presented relative to the wild-type glucocorticoid response (pPL32) and represent the mean  plus or minus  SE of the number of experiments indicated.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	51	  The Carboxy-Terminal Transactivation Domain of HNF3ss Confers AF2 Activity The distinct and specific roles of AF1 and AF2 in the GRU suggested by the results obtained in the previous experiment prompted us to localize the domains required for the accessory factor activities in HNF4 and HNF3.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	52	 We first focused our attention on HNF3.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	53	 A reporter construct was made wherein the AF2 element was replaced by a yeast GAL4-binding site (pGAL4AF2, Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	54	 3A) in the context of the wild-type promoter construct.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The response to dexamethasone in cells transfected with pGAL4AF2 was about 30% that of the wild-type pPL32 (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	56	 3A) and is similar to that obtained when the AF2 element is deleted or mutated (a 50 to 70% reduction) (7, 10).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Cotransfection of the pGAL4AF2 construct with expression vectors that encode the GAL4 DNA-binding domain (DBD) ligated to various domains of HNF3ss was performed to identify the region(s) within HNF3ss required for AF2 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	58	 HNF3ss was used in this study because it represents the major constituent that binds to the AF2 element in H4IIE hepatoma cells (14).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	59	View larger version (23K):    Figure 3.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The C-Terminal Transactivation Domain of HNF3ss Is Sufficient for AF2 Activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	61	A, H4IIE cells were transfected with pPL32, the wild-type PEPCK promoter reporter construct or with pGAL4AF2, wherein the AF2 element is replaced with a GAL4-binding site.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	62	 In this and subsequent experiments, the amount of DNA transfected is described in Materials and Methods.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	63	 All cells were cotransfected with the GR expression vector.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Cells were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone (DEX) for 18 to 24 h, and CAT activity was measured.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Results are presented as the fold induction and represent the average  plus or minus  SE.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	66	 of the number of experiments indicated in parenthesis.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	67	 B, Expression plasmids encoding one of the various GAL4 HNF3ss fusion proteins and the GR expression vector were cotransfected with pGAL4AF2, and the cells were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The results are presented as described above.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The schematic structure of HNF3ss protein is also shown.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The shaded areas represent the domains critical for the transactivation activity of HNF3ss (20 ).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The conserved regions of HNF3, -ss, and - (I-IV) are also shown.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	72	  Cotransfection of H4IIE cells with the pGAL4AF2 reporter construct and an expression plasmid that encodes full-length HNF3ss fused to GAL4 DBD had no effect on the glucocorticoid response, as CAT expression was equivalent to that detected in cells transfected with a simple GAL4 DBD construct (data not shown).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	73	 This result is perhaps not surprising since the GAL4 HNF3ss chimeric protein contains two separate DBDs.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A similar phenomenon, very low transcriptional activity, was observed when chimeric proteins that contain the GAL4 DBD and either full-length C/EBP, C/EBPss, and ATF-2 are tested (18, 19).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Strong transcriptional activity is observed only when the DBDs of C/EBP, C/EBPss, and ATF-2 are deleted (18, 19).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	76	 We therefore constructed a series of expression plasmids that encode proteins in which the GAL4 DBD is ligated to various segments of HNF3ss, all of which lack the DBD of the latter.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	77	 GAL4 HNF3ss (1 to 157), like the GAL4 DBD, did not influence the glucocorticoid response (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	78	 In contrast, cotransfection of cells with the pGAL4AF2 construct and an expression plasmid encoding GAL4 HNF3ss(257 to 458) restored the glucocorticoid response to a level near that found in cells transfected with pPL32 (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Thus, the C-terminal domain of HNF3ss mediates most of the AF2 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Two additional plasmids, wherein smaller segments of the C-terminal portion of HNF3ss were fused to the GAL4 DBD, were cotransfected with pGAL4AF2 to further localize the minimal domain required for AF2 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	81	 While the expression of GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 458) provided a robust glucocorticoid response in H4IIE cells, nearly the equal of that obtained from pPL32, GAL4 HNF3ss(257 to 360) expression failed to enhance the glucocorticoid response (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Hence, the accessory activity of AF2 is conferred by the region located between amino acids 361 to 458 (a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	83	The 361 to 458 domain includes the primary transactivation domain of HNF3ss (20).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Two regions within this domain are highly conserved among HNF3 family members: a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	85	 369 to 387 (conserved box II) and a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	86	 445 to 458 (conserved box III) (see Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The transactivation capacity of HNF3ss is severely reduced when either of these two conserved boxes is deleted or mutated (20).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	88	 We therefore made the expression plasmid GAL4 HNF3ss(388 to 458), wherein conserved box II is deleted, and GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 442), wherein conserved box III is deleted (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Cotransfection of GAL4 HNF3ss(388 to 458) with pGAL4AF2 into H4IIE cells provided a partial glucocorticoid response, but cotransfection of GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 442) did not provide any accessory factor activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	90	 These data suggest that, although box III contributes most of the activity of AF2, boxes II and III are both required for full AF2 activity (compare lines 2 and 4, Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	91	View larger version (18K):    Figure 4.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Conserved Regions II and III in HNF3 Are Required for AF2 Activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	93	A, H4IIE cells were transfected with pPL32, the wild-type PEPCK promoter reporter construct, or with pGAL4AF2, wherein the AF2 element is replaced with a GAL4-binding site.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	94	 All cells were cotransfected with the GR expression vector.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Cells were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone (DEX) for 18 to 24 h, and CAT activity was measured.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Results are presented relative to the wild-type glucocorticoid response (pPL32; top panel) and represent the average  plus or minus  SE of the number of experiments indicated.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	97	 B, An expression plasmid encoding one of the various GAL4 HNF3ss fusion proteins was cotransfected with the GR expression vector and with pGAL4AF2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Cells were treated and results are presented, with or without 500 nM dexamethasone, as described above.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The schematic structure of HNF3ss protein is shown, as described in Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	100	  The inherent capacity for the activation of basal transcription by each of the GAL4 HNF3ss fusion protein expression vectors was monitored by cotransfecting them with a CAT reporter plasmid that contains five copies of a GAL4-binding site positioned upstream of a E1B TATA box [(GAL4)5E1bCAT, Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	101	 HepG2 cells, previously used to map the transactivation domain of HNF3ss (20), were also used in this study since transfection of large amounts of DNA were required to detect basal activity in H4IIE cells.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The relative activity of each of the GAL4 HNF3ss chimeric proteins is presented in Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	103	 For comparison, a qualitative indication of AF2 activity of the same constructs is also presented.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The activity of GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 458) is 2-fold higher than that of GAL4 HNF3ss(388 to 458) and 15-fold higher than that of GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 442) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Thus, the transactivation capacity of these three GAL4 HNF3ss fusion proteins correlates well with their ability to support AF2 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Interestingly, expression of GAL4 HNF3ss(257 to 458), which mediates AF2 activity, provided little basal activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	107	 5, line 3); perhaps there is a repression domain for basal activity located between a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The N-terminal portion of HNF3ss contains a region that is conserved among HNF3 family members (box IV, a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	109	 14 to 93), and this may be important for transactivation activity (34, 37).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	110	 However, GAL4 HNF3ss(1 to 157) did not mediate AF2 activity nor did it activate the (GAL4)5E1bCAT reporter gene (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	111	 This is consistent with previous results, which also suggest that this conserved region cannot function as an independent activation domain (20).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The expression of the GAL4 HNF3ss chimeric proteins was confirmed in an independent gel mobility shift experiment using nuclear extracts prepared from GAL4 HNF3ss fusion protein-expressing cells.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	113	 COS cells were used for this experiment because of the very low transfection efficiency of H4IIE hepatoma cells.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	114	 All of the chimeric proteins were expressed efficiently, albeit at somewhat different levels (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	115	 In fact, GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 458), which provides the strongest AF2 activity, was expressed at a low level relative to the other GAL4 HNF3ss chimeric proteins (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (16K):    Figure 5.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Comparison of the Basal Transactivation and AF2 Activities of Various GAL4 HNF3ss Fusion Proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	118	5  microg) that encode the GAL4 HNF3ss fusion constructs were cotransfected into HepG2 cells with a reporter construct (2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	119	5  microg) that contains five tandem copies of the GAL4-binding site inserted into the E1b promoter [(GAL4)5E1bCAT)].
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Results are presented relative to the activity of GAL4 DBD protein and are the average  plus or minus  SE of at least five experiments.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The AF2 activity of each GAL4 HNF3ss fusion protein is also shown.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The schematic structure of the HNF3ss protein is shown, as described in Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	123	  View larger version (56K):    Figure 6.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Expression and DNA Binding of Various GAL4-HNF3ss Fusion Proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	125	COS cells were transfected with expression plasmids (40  microg) that encode various GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs [1: GAL4DBD; 2: GAL4 HNF3ss(1 to 157); 3: GAL4 HNF3ss(257 to 458); 4: GAL4 HNF3ss(257 to 360); 5: GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 458); 6: GAL4 HNF3ss(361 to 442); and 7: GAL4 HNF3ss(388 to 458)].
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Whole-cell extracts were prepared, and the gel mobility shift assay was used to analyze expression levels (as described in Materials and Methods).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The arrow indicates the various GAL4 HNF3ss fusion proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Each protein was supershifted by prior incubation with an antibody directed against the GAL4 DBD.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	129	  The Transactivation Domain of HNF4 Provides AF1 Activity The approach described above was also used to localize the functional domain(s) of HNF4 required for AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The glucocorticoid response in H4IIE cells transfected with a pPL32-derived reporter construct in which the AF1 element is replaced with a GAL4-binding site (pGAL4AF1) was 60 to 70% that of wild type (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	131	 7A), an effect similar to that seen when AF1 is deleted or mutated (7, 10).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The glucocorticoid response did not change when cells were cotransfected with pGAL4AF1 and a plasmid that encodes the GAL4 DBD (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	133	 However, the glucocorticoid response was strongly enhanced when a plasmid that encodes a chimeric protein consisting of the full-length HNF4 and the GAL4 DBD [GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455)] was cotransfected into cells with pGAL4AF1 (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Cotransfection of a GAL4DBD HNF4 chimeric protein that lacks the C-terminal 81 amino acids [GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374)] with the pGAL4AF1 reporter construct into cells provided a slightly greater glucocorticoid response than did GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	135	 segment of HNF4 is dispensable for AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Since the entire C-terminal transactivation domain of HNF3ss is required for AF2 activity, it was of interest to determine whether the two transactivation domains of HNF4 are critical for AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	137	 One of these domains is located within the first 24 amino acids of the N-terminal region of the protein, and the second resides between amino acids 128 to 370 (21).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Therefore, GAL4 HNF4(1 to 45), which contains the N-terminal transactivation domain, or GAL4 HNF4(128 to 374), which contains the C-terminal transactivation domain, was independently cotransfected with pGAL4AF1 into H4IIE cells to determine whether either transactivation domain harbors AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Expression of GAL4 HNF4(1 to 45) in cells provided no significant AF1 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In contrast, the glucocorticoid response in cells transfected with GAL4 HNF4(128 to 374) was similar to that observed in cells that express GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Thus, the C-terminal transactivation domain of HNF4 provides most of the AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	142	 361- 366 is a highly conserved motif among members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, and it is essential for activity mediated through the C-terminal transactivation domain (21).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Cotransfection of GAL4 HNF4(1 to 360), an expression plasmid that lacks this region, with the pGAL4AF1 reporter construct did not enhance the glucocorticoid response (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	144	 A single-point mutation, L366E, causes a severe reduction in the transactivation activity of HNF4 (21).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The same mutation, in the fusion construct GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374/L366E), also abolishes AF1 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In conclusion, these data indicate that the C-terminal transactivation domain of HNF4 is indeed critical for its ability to serve as accessory factor 1 in the glucocorticoid response.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (24K):    Figure 7.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The C-Terminal Transactivation Domain of HNF4 Is Sufficient for AF1 Activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	149	A, H4IIE cells were transfected with pPL32, the wild-type PEPCK promoter reporter construct, or pGAL4AF1, wherein the AF1 element is replaced with a GAL4-binding site.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	150	 All cells were cotransfected with the GR expression vector and were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone (DEX) for 18 to 24 h.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	151	 CAT activity was then measured as described above.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Results are presented relative to the wild-type glucocorticoid response (pPL32; top panel) and represent the average  plus or minus  SE of the number of experiments indicated.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	153	 B, An expression plasmid encoding one of the various GAL4 HNF4 fusion proteins and the GR expression vector were cotransfected with pGAL4AF1.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	154	 A schematic representation of the structure of the HNF4 protein is shown.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The shaded areas represent the transactivation domain of HNF4 (21 ).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The asterisk (*) indicates the mutation site (L366E) in one of the GAL4 HNF4fusion proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	157	  A comparison of basal transactivation with AF1 activity was performed by cotransfecting the various GAL4 HNF4 fusion protein plasmids with the (GAL4)5E1bCAT reporter construct into H4IIE cells.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In general, the transactivation capacities of GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374), (1 to 360), and (1 to 374/L366E) correlate with their ability to provide AF1 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Interestingly, GAL4 HNF4(1 to 45) was the strongest activator of the (GAL4)5E1bCAT reporter gene, but it demonstrated very low AF1 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In contrast, GAL4 HNF4(128 to 374) mediates AF1 activity, but its transactivation activity is 8-fold lower than that of GAL4 HNF4(1 to 45) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	161	 These results suggest that a specific domain, rather than general transactivation capacity, is the determinant of AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Although GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455), (1 to 360), and (1 to 374/L366E) provided similar basal transcriptional activity, only GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455) mediates AF1 activity, and it is the only one of these three constructs that contains the C-terminal transactivation domain.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The basal transcriptional activity of GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455) is 4-fold lower than GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	164	 This result is consistent with the presence of a repression domain for basal transcriptional activity located between a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	165	 However, this repression domain has only a slight effect on AF1 activity (Figs.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The expression of the GAL4 HNF4 chimeric proteins was confirmed by an independent assessment in which gel mobility shift experiments were performed using nuclear extracts from COS cells that expressed distinct GAL4 HNF4 fusion proteins (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	167	 GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374), which provides the strongest AF1 activity, was expressed at a level similar to that of GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374/L366E) and GAL4 HNF4(1 to 360) and was expressesed at a level lower than GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455), GAL4 HNF(1 to 45), and GAL4 HNF4(128 to 374) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	168	 These results indicate that the inability of GAL4 HNF(1 to 45), GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374/L366E), and GAL4 HNF4(1 to 360) to confer AF1 activity is not due to inadequate expression in the cells.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (16K):    Figure 8.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Comparison of the Basal Transactivation and AF1 Activities of Various GAL4 HNF4 Fusion Proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	171	Expression plasmids (2  microg) that encode various GAL4 HNF4 fusion constructs were cotransfected into H4IIE cells with a reporter construct (5  microg) that contains five tandem copies of the GAL4-binding site inserted into the E1b promoter [(GAL4)5E1bCAT].
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Results are presented relative to the activity of GAL4 DBD protein and represent the average  plus or minus  SE of at least five experiments.

0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	175	  View larger version (44K):    Figure 9.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Expression and DNA Binding of Various GAL4-HNF4 Fusion Proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	177	COS cells were transfected with expression plasmids (40  microg) that encode various GAL4 HNF4 fusion constructs [1: GAL4 DBD; 2: GAL4 HNF4(1 to 455); 3: GAL4 HNF4(1 to 45); 4: GAL4 HNF4(128 to 374); 5: GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374); 6: GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374/L366E); and 7: GAL4 HNF4(1 to 360)].
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Whole-cell extracts were prepared, and the gel mobility shift assay was used to analyze expression levels (as described in Materials and Methods).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The result using the GAL4 DBD was also shown in Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The arrow indicates the various GAL4 HNF4 fusion proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Each protein was supershifted by prior incubation with an antibody directed against the GAL4 DBD.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	182	  The Activity of Other Transactivation Domains at AF1 and AF2, Respectively Plasmids that encode fusion proteins of the GAL4 DBD and various transactivation domains were cotransfected with either pGAL4AF1 or pGAL4AF2 reporter genes (Figs.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	183	 10 and 11), to determine whether other classes of transactivation domains can substitute for the accessory factor activities of HNF3 and HNF4.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Cotransfection of H4IIE cells with the pGAL4AF1 construct and an expression plasmid that encodes GAL4 E1A, which consists of the GAL4 DBD and the CR3 region of adenovirus E1A protein, provided a 2- to 3-fold induction of the basal promoter activity (data not shown), and the glucocorticoid response was similar to that obtained from GAL4 HNF4(1 to 374) (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	185	 GAL4 E1A also provided a 3- to 5-fold increase of basal promoter activity and conferred some AF2 activity when cotransfected with pGAL4AF2 into the cells (data not shown and Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	186	 GAL4 VP16, which contains the GAL4 DBD and the C-terminal acidic transactivation domain of herpes simplex virus VP16 protein, also resulted in a 2- to 3-fold increase of basal promoter activity from pGAL4AF1 and a 3- to 5-fold increase from pGAL4AF2 (data not shown).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	187	 However, GAL4 VP16 conferred only partial AF1 activity and failed to provide AF2 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	188	 GAL4 SP1, which consists of the glutamine-rich activation domain of SP1 fused to the GAL4 DBD, and GAL4 CTF, which consists of the proline-rich activation domain of NF1/CTF fused to the GAL4 DBD, did not increase the basal promoter activity (data not shown) or provide accessory factor activity from either element (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Hence, among these four distinct classes of transactivation domains, only the E1A CR3 region provided strong AF1 activity, and none afforded complete AF2 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	190	 These results suggest there is a high degree of specificity associated with the transactivation domains of HNF4 and HNF3ss in their roles as accessory factors in the PEPCK GRU.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	191	View larger version (18K):    Figure 10.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Domain Specificity of AF1 Activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	193	A, H4IIE cells were transfected with pPL32, the wild-type PEPCK promoter reporter construct or with pGAL4AF1, wherein the AF1 element is replaced with a GAL4-binding site.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	194	 All cells were cotransfected with the GR expression vector.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Cells were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone (DEX) for 18 to 24 h, and CAT activity was measured.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Results are presented relative to the wild-type glucocorticoid response (pPL32) and represent the average  plus or minus  SE of the number of experiments indicated.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	197	 B, An expression plasmid, encoding one of the various GAL4 DBD and transactivation domain fusion proteins, and the GR expression vector were cotransfected with pGAL4AF1.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Other details are as described in panel A.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	199	  View larger version (18K):    Figure 11.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Domain Specificity of AF2 Activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	201	A, H4IIE cells were transfected with pPL32, the wild-type PEPCK promoter reporter construct, or with pGAL4AF2 wherein the AF2 element is replaced with a GAL4-binding site.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	202	 All cells were cotransfected with the GR expression vector.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Cells were treated with or without 500 nM dexamethasone (DEX) for 18 to 24 h and CAT activity was measured.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Results are presented relative to the wild-type glucocorticoid response (pPL32) and represent the average  plus or minus  SE of the number of experiments indicated.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	205	 B, An expression plasmid, encoding one of the various GAL4 DBD and transactivation domain fusion proteins, and the GR expression vector were cotransfected with pGAL4AF2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Other details are as described in panel A.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	207	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Much has been learned from the analysis of simple hormone response elements (HREs) placed, as single or multimerized copies, in the context of heterologous promoter reporter gene constructs.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	208	 It is not clear, however, whether such receptor-binding elements are sufficient for function in native promoters.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Multicomponent assemblies, including the HRE and cis-elements with associated DNA-binding proteins (so-called accessory factors), in an arrangement referred to as a hormone response unit (HRU), appears to be much more common (22).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Additional complexity is provided by a number of coregulators, which can bind to the hormone receptor and/or the accessory factors to modulate the rate of transcription of a given gene.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	211	 A specific HRU thus consists of a number of protein-DNA and protein-protein interactions involving the hormone receptor, accessory factors ( > 30 have been identified) and coregulators.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	212	The PEPCK gene GRU is an example of the HRU described above.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	213	 A complete response of the PEPCK gene to glucocorticoids requires the presence of four accessory factor elements and associated proteins (AF1, AF2, AF3, CRE) and two GREs (GR1 and GR2) with associated ligand-receptor complexes (see Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The loss of function of any one of these accessory element factor complexes results as a 50% reduction of the glucocorticoid response (6, 8, 10).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Loss of function of any combination of two results in a complete loss of the glucocorticoid response.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Similarly, a partial response is obtained if either of the GREs is deleted, but GR1 is quantitatively more important than GR2 (9).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	217	 It is evident that considerable redundancy has been built into this system.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Having defined the components of the GRU, we can now begin to address several key questions.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	219	 For example, are there unique structural requirements with respect to the orientation, positioning, and spacing of the accessory factors with respect to each other and the GREs? What domains are responsible for the accessory factor action of these proteins? Are coregulatory proteins involved? And finally, how does all of this come together to control the rate of transcription of the PEPCK gene? The work in this paper addresses the first two of these questions.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	220	In the studies described above, it is apparent that AF1 cannot substitute for AF2, and vice versa.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Also, the two elements do not work well when inverted with respect to the rest of the GRU (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Therefore, it appears that a specific spatial organization of AF1 and AF2 within the PEPCK gene GRU is critical for the complete glucocorticoid response.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	223	 These results also suggest that AF1 and AF2 have distinct functions.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	224	 If so, specific domains that either activate transcription directly, or through a coregulatory intermediate, should be present in the accessory factors that bind to these elements, namely HNF4 and HNF3.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	225	AF1 activity is conferred by the carboxy-terminal transactivation domain of HNF4 (a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	226	 It is not known whether this domain functions directly or indirectly.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The fact that this accessory function can be assumed by the activation domains of E1A or VP16, which have no obvious similarity to the HNF4 domain (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	228	 9A), suggests that a protein-protein interaction is involved.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	229	 HNF4 binds to TFIIB and facilitates formation of the preinitiation complex (23); however, an HNF4 mutant that lacks the C-terminal activation domain still binds to TFIIB (23), so the effect may be mediated through the N-terminal transactivation domain, a region not necessary for accessory factor action in our studies (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Several coactivators, such as steroid receptor coactivator-1 (SRC-1) (24), CBP/p300 (25, 26, 27), glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein 1 (GRIP1)/TIF2 (28, 29, 30), and RAC3/ACTR (31, 32, 33), associate with the C-terminal activation domain of various members of the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	231	 These proteins, including HNF4, have very similar C-terminal transactivation domains (21).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Indeed, we and others have recently shown that SRC-1, GRIP1, and CBP/p300 function as coactivators for HNF4 (34, 35).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The CR3 region of E1A exhibits AF1 activity, so this domain and the C-terminal region of HNF4 may interact with a common coactivator.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The CR3 domain associates with a wide variety of transcription factors and components of the basal transcription machinery, including the TATA-box binding protein (TBP), certain TBP-associated factors (TAF) such as human TAF 135 (36), Drosophila TAF 110, and TAF 250 (37), and several other DNA binding proteins, including ATF2, USF, and SP1 (38).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	235	 However, the interaction between the CR3 region of E1A and SRC-1, GRIP1, and CBP/p300 has not been reported.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Therefore, it is also possible that distinct coactivators provide AF1 activity in the context of the PEPCK GRU; thus, HNF4 and E1A may each interact with different coactivators.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	237	 COUP-TF also serves as accessory factor 1 for the PEPCK glucocorticoid response through both the AF1 and AF3 elements (6, 11).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	238	 COUP-TF functions as both a positive and negative regulator of gene transcription (39), and it is not known whether COUP-TF uses the same mechanism as HNF4 to provide AF1 activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	239	 We are currently identifying the domain(s) that provide AF1 activity in COUP-TF, and this analysis should clarify the issue of whether unique or common coactivators are involved.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	240	AF2 activity is provided by the C-terminal transactivation domain of HNF3ss, which contains two regions that are conserved in the various members of the HNF3 family of transcription factors (20).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	241	 445 to 458) contributes most of the AF2 activity, although region II (a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	242	 369 to 387) is required for complete AF2 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	243	 These regions do not have amino acid sequence motifs common to known transactivation domains (20).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	244	 However, region III is a potent transactivator when fused to the GAL 4 DBD (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	245	 No coactivator has been identified to date that specifically interacts with the C-terminal transactivation domain of HNF3ss.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The CR3 domain of E1A provides substantial AF2 activity (Fig.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	247	 11), but VP16, in contrast to the case with AF1, is inactive.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Future experiments should clarify whether this distinction is important.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Furthermore, we have recently found that HNF3ss and GR interact in vitro (17).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	250	 However, the C-terminal transactivation domain of HNF3ss does not interact with GR in glutathione-S-transferase pull-down experiments (J.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Granner, unpublished observation).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	252	 More studies will be required to determine whether the previously noted interaction between HNF3ss and GR is physiologically important.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	253	The identification of the domains of HNF4 and HNF3ss necessary for accessory factor activity brings us a step closer to understanding how the GRU works.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In a previous paper we suggested that AF1 might stabilize the binding of GR to GR1, and that AF2 could be required for achieving the maximal transactivation potential of the GRU (9).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	255	 This hypothesis is based on the observation that the AF1 element is no longer required for the PEPCK gene glucocorticoid response when GR1, a low-affinity GR-binding site, is replaced by a strong GR-binding site (9).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	256	 In contrast, the AF2 element is still required for a complete glucocorticoid response in this situation.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The observation that AF1 and AF2 cannot substitute for one another, and that these elements must be oriented in a certain way with respect to each other and with the GR-binding sites, coupled with the identification of the transactivation domains of HNF4 and HNF3ss, should allow us to test the hypothesis that the assembly of a stereospecific nucleoprotein complex results in the stabilization of GR binding to the promoter and allows for efficient activation of the basal transcription machinery.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	258	 GR may act as a signal transducer that triggers the assembly of this nucleoprotein complex rather than as a transactivator, since neither GR1 nor GR2 can mediate a glucocorticoid response by themselves.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Alternatively, the transactivation domain of GR may contribute to the overall transcriptional capacity of the PEPCK GRU, but only in the presence of the interaction and/or transactivation domains of the accessory factors.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	260	The PEPCK gene GRU is conceptually similar to the interferon ss (IFNss) enhanceosome.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Viral induction of the IFNss gene requires the functional interaction of several regulatory elements, designated PRD I, II, III, and IV.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	262	 PRD II, III, and IV bind the transcription factors NFB, IRF1, and an ATF/c-Jun heterodimer, respectively.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Substitution of PRD IV with PRD II markedly reduces the viral induction (40) just as substitution of the AF1 and AF2 elements reduces the glucocorticoid response of the PEPCK gene.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Interestingly, when the transactivation domains of either NFB or IRF1 are replaced by the transactivation domain of VP16, viral induction of IFNss enhanceosome is markedly decreased even though these constructs provide much stronger basal transcription activity (41).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Furthermore, replacement of the transactivation domain of p65 by IRF1 reduces viral induction of IFNss enhanceosome activity (41), a result also similar to those described in this paper.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	266	 The assembly of a high-order nucleoprotein complex is required for the highly specific activation of IFNss enhanceosome, and CBP/p300 serves as an integrator in this complex (41, 42, 43).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	267	 It is conceivable that the activation of PEPCK gene transcription by glucocorticoids may use a similar mechanism.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The next challenge will be the identification of coactivators that interact with the functional domains of HNF3ss and HNF4 and mediate AF1 and AF2 activities.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	269	The multicomponent GRU may have evolved to provide both tissue-specific expression and versatile hormonal regulation of hepatic PEPCK gene transcription in response to a wide variety of environmental cues.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	270	 For example, PEPCK gene transcription is positively regulated by glucocorticoids in liver and negatively regulated in adipose tissue (1, 44).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The liver-enriched transcription factors, HNF3 and HNF4, serve as AF2 and AF1, respectively, but these factors are not present in adipose tissue.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Thus, tissue-specific accessory factors may allow for differential regulation of PEPCK gene transcription by the same effector in different tissues.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	273	A simple GRE represents either an "all or none" or "on and off" switch, whereas the GRU allows for a graded response, and the multiple GR-binding sites and accessory factors provide inherent intraunit redundancy.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Interestingly, the PEPCK GRU is part of a much more complex assembly of elements and factors, which we have termed a metabolic control domain (MCD) (45).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The MCD consists of the response units for several hormones and metabolites, and it provides an integrated response to the demands of the organism for tightly regulated gluconeogenesis.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In addition to their role in the glucocorticoid response, the AF1 and AF3 elements also function as retinoic acid response elements (RARE 1 and 2) by binding a heterodimeric complex that consists of the retinoic acid receptor and 9-cis-retinoic acid receptor (RAR/RXR) (5, 46, 47).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	277	 RARE1 and RARE2 collectively constitute an RARU and mediate the retinoic acid response that is necessary for gluconeogenesis (48).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The CRE is an accessory element in the glucocorticoid response, and is part of a cAMP response unit that mediates the stimulatory effect of glucagon (15, 49, 50), which is the primary hormonal stimulator of gluconeogenesis.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Finally, the AF2 element, as part of a multicomponent IRU, also mediates the repressive effect of insulin by binding an, as yet unidentified, protein (51) and thus participates in the down-regulation of gluconeogenesis.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Thus, the different sets of proteins that bind to the PEPCK MCD, of which the GRU is an integral part, determine the direction and magnitude of PEPCK gene transcription and provide for additivity, synergism, intra- and inter-unit redundancy, and the dominance of one effect over another.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	281	 This complex system has presumably evolved to provide the array of responses necessary to maintain a rate of gluconeogenesis compatible with the adaptive needs of the organism.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	282	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Plasmid Constructions Oligonucleotides used in plasmid constructions (listed in Table 1) were synthesized by an Expedite 8909 oligonucleotide synthesizer (Perceptive Biosystems, Framingham, MA).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The plasmids pGAL4AF1, pGAL4AF2, pAF1 to 1, and pAF2 to 2 were derived from pPL32 by PCR-based mutagenesis using the corresponding oligonucleotides and a 3'-chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) primer.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	284	 pPL32 is a fusion gene construct that contains the PEPCK gene promoter sequence from nucleotides -467 to +69 (relative to the transcription start site) ligated to the CAT reporter gene (52).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	285	 pPL32 was cleaved with HindIII and BglII, and the wild-type PEPCK sequence was replaced with the various PCR-derived sequences.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The entire sequence of the subcloned DNA fragment was confirmed by sequencing.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The plasmid pAF2 to 1 was generated by the same method, using the pAF1 to 1 reporter plasmid as a template and oligonucleotide AF2 to 2 as a primer.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The reporter plasmid (GAL4)5E1bCAT has been previously described (53).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Oligonucleotides Used in This Study.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	290	  The expression plasmids for GAL4 HNF4 chimeras were generated in two steps.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	291	 First, the nucleotide sequences of rat HNF4 corresponding to a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	292	 1 to 45, 1 to 455, 1 to 374, 1 to 360, and 128 to 374 were generated by PCR using primers H4/N/1 and H4/C/45, H4/N/1 and H4/C/455, H4/N/1 and H4/C/374, H4/N/1 and H4/C/360, and H4/N/128 and H4/C/374, respectively.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	293	 A single point mutation of amino acid 366 (L366E) in the nucleotide sequence corresponding to a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	294	 1 to 374 was generated by PCR using primers H4/N/1 and H4/C/374/M366.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	295	 These PCR fragments were then digested with BamHI and KpnI, or BamHI and XbaI for the 1 to 45 fragment, and subcloned into the simian virus 40 (SV40) enhancer-driven GAL4 expression plasmid pSG424 (54).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	296	 The expression plasmids for GAL4 HNF3ss were generated by the same method.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The nucleotide sequences of rat HNF3ss that correspond to a.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	298	 1 to 157, 257 to 458, 257 to 360, 361 to 458, 361 to 442, and 388 to 458 were generated by PCR using primers H3/N/1 and H3/C/157, H3/N/257 and H3/C/458/X, H3/N/257 and H3/C/360, H3/N/361 and H3/C/458, H3/N/361 and H3/C/442, and H3/N/388 and H3/C/458/K, respectively.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	299	 These PCR fragments were then digested with BamHI and KpnI, or BamHI and XbaI for the 1 to 157 and 257 to 458 fragments, and subcloned into pSG424.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	300	 The sequence of all subcloned DNA fragments was verified by DNA sequencing.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	301	 The expression plasmids, GAL4 VP16, GAL4 E1A, GAL4 SP1, and GAL4 CTF/NF1, have been described previously (53, 55, 56).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	302	 pSV2GR, which expresses the rat GR under control of the SV40 promoter, was provided by K.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Yamamoto (University of California at San Francisco).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	304	 RSV (Rous sarcoma virus)-ss-galactosidase was provided by M.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Magnuson (Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	306	Cell Culture, Transient Transfection, and CAT Assays The methods of transfection and maintenance of H4IIE and HepG2 hepatoma cells have been described previously (7, 13).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	307	 In the experiments performed with H4IIE cells, the dexamethasone response varied from 7- to 20-fold (with dexamethasone/without dexamethasone).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	308	 The variation was passage and batch dependent.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	309	 For this reason, we expressed the data as a percentage of the wild-type dexamethasone response, which gave much more consistent results.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	310	 For experiments that map the accessory domains of HNF3ss and HNF4, 10  microg of the reporter construct (pGAL4AF2 or pGAL4AF1) were cotransfected with 5  microg of GR expression vector, and 1, 2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	311	5, 5, or 10  microg of expression plasmid encoding the various GAL4 HNF3ss or GAL4 HNF4 fusion proteins.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The optimal hormonal responses from each titration experiment were pooled.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	313	 The optimal concentration for the expression plasmids encoding the GAL4 HNF4 fusion proteins was consistently 1  microg.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	314	 However, the concentration required for an optimal glucocorticoid response using the GAL4 HNF3ss expression plasmids encoding the various GAL4DBD and transactivation domain fusion proteins ranged from 5 to 10  microg.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	315	 In the experiments using HepG2 cells, CAT activity was normalized to ss-galactosidase activity.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	316	 ss-Galactosidase activity was measured by adding 25  microl cell extract to 175  microl assay of buffer (60 mM Na2HPO4, 40 mM NaH2PO4, 10 mM KCl, 1 mM MgSO4, and 50 mM ss-mercaptoethanol), and 80  microl o-nitrophenol-ss-D-galactopyranoside (ONPG) solution (4 mg/ml ONPG, 72 mM Na2HPO4, 200 mM NaH2PO4).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	317	 ss-Galactosidase activity was monitored by absorbance at 420 nm.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	318	 COS-1 cells were grown in DMEM containing 10% FCS (GIBCO/BRL, Gaithersburg, MD).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	319	 The calcium phosphate method was used to transfect COS cells.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Briefly, the calcium chloride-plasmid DNA precipitate was added to 1 to 1.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	321	 After incubation at 37 C for 18 to 20 h, cells were washed with PBS and then placed in fresh culture medium and incubated for an additional 24 h.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Whole-cell extracts of COS cells were prepared as described previously (57).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Briefly, the cells were washed with PBS, collected by centrifugation, and resuspended in 50 to 60  microl of lysis buffer [20 mM HEPES (pH 7.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	324	4 M NaCl, glycerol 25%, 1 mM EDTA, 2.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	325	5 mM dithiothreitol, and 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride].
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Cells were kept on ice for 15 to 20 min, frozen at -70 C, and thawed on ice.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The cell suspension was then centifuged for 10 min in a microfuge at 4 C.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	328	 The supernatant was used in the gel mobility shift experiments.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	329	Gel Mobility Shift Assays The gel mobility shift assays were performed as described previously (58) with certain modifications.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Briefly, whole-cell extracts (5  microg) were incubated in the presence or absence of a GAL4 DBD antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA) in a 10- microl reaction for 10 to 15 min and then mixed with 10  microl of a reaction buffer containing 30,000 cpm 32P-labeled DNA probe (5'-CACACGGAGGACTGTCCTCCGACCA-3'), 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	331	7, 100 mM NaCl, 5 mM MgCl2, 10  microM ZnCl2, 6% glycerol, 0.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	332	6  microg poly(dI dC) (Pharmacia, Piscataway, NJ), and 2  microg salmon sperm DNA, for another 10 to 15 min at room temperature.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	333	 The reaction mixtures were then loaded onto a 4.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	334	5x Tris-borate/EDTA electrophoresis buffer (TBE).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	335	 After electrophoresis at 20 mA for 150 min at room temperature, the gels were dried and exposed to an x-ray film (Eastman Kodak, Rochester, NY).
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	336	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Drs.
0.37755975.10194766.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Frances Sladek and Rob Costa for providing HNF4 and HNF3ss cDNA, respectively.

0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	0	Polyamines Modulate the Interaction between Nuclear Receptors and Vitamin D Receptor-Interacting Protein 205 Yutaka Maeda, Christophe Rachez1, Leo Hawel, III, Craig V.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	1	Environmental Toxicology Graduate Program (Y.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	2	), Departments of Cell Biology and Neuroscience (F.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	3	), University of California, Riverside, California 92521; and Cell Biology Program (C.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	4	), Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, New York 10021.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Frances M.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	6	, Department of Cell Biology and Neuroscience, University of California, Riverside, Riverside, California 92521.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	7	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Nuclear receptors (NR) activate transcription by interacting with several different coactivator complexes, primarily via LXXLL motifs (NR boxes) of the coactivator that bind a common region in the ligand binding domain of nuclear receptors (activation function-2, AF to 2) in a ligand-dependent fashion.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, how nuclear receptors distinguish between different sets of coactivators remains a mystery, as does the mechanism by which orphan receptors such as hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) activate transcription.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In this study, we show that HNF4 interacts with a complex containing vitamin D receptor (VDR)-interacting proteins (DRIPs) in the absence of exogenously added ligand.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	10	 However, whereas a full-length DRIP205 construct enhanced the activation by HNF4 in vivo, it did not interact well with the HNF4 ligand binding domain in vitro.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In investigating this discrepancy, we found that the polyamine spermine significantly enhanced the interaction between HNF4 and full-length DRIP205 in an AF-2, NR-box-dependent manner.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Spermine also enhanced the interaction of DRIP205 with the VDR even in the presence of its ligand, but decreased the interaction of both HNF4 and VDR with the p160 coactivator glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein 1 (GR1P1).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We also found that GR1P1 and DRIP205 synergistically activated HNF4-mediated transcription and that a specific inhibitor of polyamine biosynthesis, -difluoromethylornithine (DFMO), decreased the ability of HNF4 to activate transcription in vivo.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These results lead us to propose a model in which polyamines may facilitate the switch between different coactivator complexes binding to NRs.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	15	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   NUCLEAR RECEPTORS (NRs) comprise a family of transcription factors that play a role in nearly every aspect of growth, development, and disease processes (reviewed in Refs.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The best characterized members of the family, such as the steroid and thyroid hormone and vitamins A and D receptors, are known to regulate transcription by binding their cognate lipophilic ligands and subsequently undergoing a conformational change that alters their ability to interact with coregulatory proteins.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These coregulatory proteins typically consist of complexes that either repress (corepressors) or activate (coactivators) transcription.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The coactivator complexes can be crudely divided into complexes that either contain histone acetyl transferase (HAT) activity [e.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	19	 the p160-p300/CBP-PCAF complexes] or ones that do not [e.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	20	 the vitamin D receptor (VDR)-interating protein (DRIP)/thyroid hormone receptor associated protein (TRAP)/ARC/mediator complexes].
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	21	 We and others have proposed previously that nuclear receptors interact first with the coactivator complexes that contain HAT activity, allowing for acetylation and hence decondensation of the chromatin, and that subsequently the other coactivator complexes bind the receptors and interact with the basal transcription machinery to initiate transcription (reviewed in Refs.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	22	An increasing amount of evidence indicates that both types of coactivators interact with the activation function-2 (AF-2) region of the ligand binding domain (LBD) of the NRs via LXXLL motifs (NR interaction regions or NR boxes).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	23	 p160 family members glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein 1 (GRIP1) and steroid receptor coactivator-1 (SRC1) bind the AF-2 and help recruit p300/CBP, which has also been found to bind via the AF-2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	24	 DRIP205 (also known as TRAP220, RB18A, PBP, TRIP2), a component of the DRIP/TRAP complex, also interacts with the AF-2 via LXXLL motifs (6, 7, 8).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	25	 However, what is not clear is how a given nuclear receptor makes the switch from the p160/p300 complex to the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Whereas the switch from corepressor to coactivator binding is apparently made by a conformational change in the receptor upon ligand binding, both types of coactivators bind liganded receptor and bind principally via the AF-2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	27	 This suggests that perhaps a change not in the receptor but in the coactivators is required to make the switch from one complex to another.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	28	 However, what might cause that switch is completely unknown at this point.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	29	In an attempt to answer some of these questions, we examined the interaction between an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4, NR2A1) and the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	30	 HNF4 is a somewhat unusual receptor in that it activates transcription in a constitutive fashion (i.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	31	 in the absence of exogenously added ligand).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	32	 HNF4, a highly conserved member of the superfamily, is critical to early development and is directly linked to several human diseases including diabetes and hemophilia (reviewed in Ref.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Whereas an endogenous ligand has not yet been definitively identified for HNF4 (10, 11), we and others (12, 13, 14, 15, 16) have shown that HNF4 interacts with coactivators GRIP1 and p300/CBP in the absence of added ligand and that transactivation by HNF4 is completely dependent upon the AF-2.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	34	In this study, we show that the HNF4 LBD also interacts with a complex containing DRIP proteins in the absence of exogenously added ligand.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In investigating this interaction, we found that the polyamine spermine enhanced the interaction between DRIP205 and not only the HNF4 but also the VDR LBD.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In contrast, spermine decreased the interaction of both receptors with p160 family member GRIP1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These and other results lead us to propose a model in which polyamines such as spermine help promote the switch from the p160/p300 complex to the DRIP complex.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	38	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   HNF4 Interacts with the DRIP Complex in the Absence of an Exogenously Added Ligand To determine whether HNF4 could interact with the DRIP complex in the absence of exogenously added ligand, a pull-down assay using Namalwa B cell nuclear extracts and glutathione S-transferase (GST).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	39	 1) was performed in a fashion similar to that originally used to identify the DRIP complex (17, 18).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The results indicate that the HNF4 LBD pulled down a complex that was similar but not identical with that pulled down by the VDR LBD in the presence of its ligand, 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D3 [1,25-(OH)2D3; Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	41	 2A, top, compare lane 4 with lane 2].
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Immunoblot analysis indicated that DRIP205, DRIP130, and, to a lesser extent, DRIP150 were present in the HNF4 complex (Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Transient cotransfection analyses verified that the interaction with the DRIP complex is a functional one.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Transfected DRIP205 wild type (DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	45	wt) stimulated the ability of HNF41 to activate a reporter gene in the absence of added ligand 4.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	46	 2B, compare lane 4 with lane 3).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Removal of the region C terminal to the LBD, the F domain, resulted in a greater degree of stimulation by DRIP205 (6.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	48	1-fold; lanes 7 and 8), just as was found previously for GRIP1 and CBP (12).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The AF-2 was required for the stimulation by DRIP205.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	50	wt, as it was for all other transactivation activity (lanes 5 and 6).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	51	View larger version (25K):    Figure 1.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	52	Top, wt rat HNF41, from which all HNF4 constructs were derived.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Numbering indicates aa residues; A to F, conventional nomenclature for NR domains; DBD, DBD consisting of the zinc fingers (Zn2+) and hinge region (domain D).
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	54	wt is the full-length, wt human DRIP205 sequence.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	55	mut contains double mutations in the two NR boxes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	56	box encompasses aa 527 to 714 and contains the two wt NR boxes.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	57	  View larger version (22K):    Figure 2.

0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	59	5 mg of Namalwa B cell nuclear extracts in the presence or absence of 1  microM 1,25-(OH)2D3 (+D3) and the indicated GST fusion proteins (VDR LBD, HNF4 DBD and LBD, GST control; see Fig.
0.2994644.12089346.html.plaintext.txt	60	 1) as described in Materials and Methods.
