0.3133714.11145965.html.plaintext.txt	333	Copyright   2001 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of the Human PPAR Promoter: Identification of a Functional Nuclear Receptor Response Element Ines Pineda Torra, Yalda Jamshidi, David M.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Flavell, Jean-Charles Fruchart and Bart Staels.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	2	545 Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale (I.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	3	), Departement d Atherosclerose, Institut Pasteur de Lille, 59019 Lille, and the Faculte de Pharmacie, Universite de Lille II, 59006 Lille, France; and Centre for Cardiovascular Genetics (Y.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	4	), Department of Medicine, Royal Free and University College London Medical School, The Rayne Institute, London WC1E 6JJ, United Kingdom.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Bart Staels, U.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	6	545 INSERM, Institut Pasteur de Lille, 1 Rue Calmette BP245, 59019 Lille, France.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	7	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   PPAR is a nuclear receptor that controls lipid and glucose metabolism and exerts antiinflammatory activities.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The factors regulating human PPAR (hPPAR) gene expression remain largely unexplored.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	9	 To study the mechanisms controlling hPPAR expression, the hPPAR gene promoter was identified and characterized.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	10	 First, an alternatively spliced exon within the 5'-untranslated region of the hPPAR gene was identified by RT-PCR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Next, the transcription start site was mapped and the hPPAR gene promoter was cloned and functionally analyzed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Because PPAR levels are elevated in tissues expressing the hepatocyte nuclear factor-4 (HNF4), such as liver, the regulation of hPPAR by HNF4 was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Transient transfections in HepG2 and Cos cells showed that HNF4 enhances hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	14	 5'-Deletion and mutation analysis of the hPPAR promoter identified a regulatory element (RE) consisting of a degenerate hexamer repeat with a single nucleotide spacer (direct repeat 1), termed HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Gel shift assays demonstrated that HNF4 binds to this HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Furthermore, HNF4 increased the activity of a heterologous promoter driven by two copies of the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The nuclear receptor COUP-TFII also bound this site and down-regulated basal as well as HNF4-induced hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Finally, PPAR was shown to bind the HNF4-RE, leading to an induction of PPAR expression in hepatocytes.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In summary, the organization of the 5'-flanking and untranslated region of the hPPAR gene was characterized and the hPPAR promoter region has been identified.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Furthermore, these data demonstrate that the hPPAR gene is regulated by nuclear receptors, such as HNF-4, COUP-TFII, and PPAR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	21	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   PPAR [NR1C1] IS a ligand-activated transcription factor belonging to the nuclear receptor superfamily that regulates gene transcription by heterodimerizing with RXR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	22	 PPAR/RXR heterodimers bind to PPAR response elements (PPREs) consisting of a direct repeat of the core AGGTCA sequence spaced by 1 or 2 bp [direct repeat 1 or 2 (DR1 or DR2)] preceded by a 5'-A/T-rich flanking sequence (1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In addition, PPAR represses gene transcription by interfering with the nuclear factor B (NFB) and activating protein 1 (AP1) signaling pathways in a DNA binding-independent fashion (2).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	24	PPAR-mediated transcriptional regulation of target genes is tightly controlled by ligand activation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Fatty acid (FA) derivatives and the hypolipidemic fibrates are natural and synthetic PPAR ligands, respectively (3).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	26	 PPAR mediates the action of fibrates on plasma lipid levels by regulating the transcription of genes controlling lipoprotein metabolism (4).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Moreover, PPAR is a pivotal modulator of intracellular lipid metabolism by regulating the gene expression of proteins involved in FA uptake, FA esterification, FA entry into the mitochondria, peroxisomal and mitochondrial FA catabolism, and ketone body synthesis (1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In addition to intra- and extracellular lipid metabolism, glucose and energy homeostasis as well as body weight were also reported to be influenced by PPAR activators (5, 6).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Furthermore, PPAR is an important regulator of vascular inflammation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	30	 PPAR inhibits the expression of various inducible factors implicated in the promotion of a local inflammatory response within the developing atherosclerotic plaque (2).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In addition, PPAR regulates the expression of lipoprotein receptors and cholesterol transporters involved in the reverse cholesterol transport pathway in macrophages (7, 8).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	32	 PPAR activators reduce plasma concentrations of inflammatory cytokines in vivo (9, 10) and reduce the progression of coronary atherosclerosis in humans (11, 12, 13, 14).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	33	In addition to ligand activation, transcriptional control of PPAR target genes depends on its expression levels.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	34	 High levels of PPAR expression are observed in tissues with elevated FA catabolic rates, such as liver, heart, kidney, muscle, and the large intestine (15, 16, 17).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In rodents, PPAR is regulated by stress (18) and by different hormones, such as GH, glucocorticoids, insulin, and leptin (19, 20, 21, 22).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	36	 PPAR expression oscillates diurnally (18), is diminished with age (23), and is induced during brown adipocyte differentiation (24).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Furthermore, starvation increases PPAR expression levels in liver leading to changes in mRNA levels of PPAR target genes (25).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Low PPAR mRNA levels result in decreased PPAR activity in pancreatic islets of obese Zucker diabetic (fa/fa) rats (22), in rat cardiomyocytes during cardiac hypertrophy (26), in livers of male Syrian hamsters upon lipopolysaccharide administration (27), and in intestinal epithelial cells during hypoxia (28).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Moreover, PPAR expression levels correlate with human apo AI gene induction in response to fibrate treatment as demonstrated in human apo AI transgenic mice crossed with PPAR-deficient mice (29).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	40	However, to date, studies addressing the regulation of PPAR gene expression have been largely performed either in rodent cells or in animal models.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Although the regulation of PPAR expression in humans remains largely unknown, the observation that hepatic PPAR mRNA levels vary significantly among individuals (30, 31) suggests that PPAR is also regulated at the transcriptional level in humans.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Indeed, hPPAR mRNA levels are induced during monocyte differentiation into macrophages (32), and high glucose concentrations up-regulate PPAR gene expression in human macrophages from healthy control subjects as well as from type 2 diabetic patients (33).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	43	To understand the molecular mechanisms governing PPAR regulation, we decided to identify and functionally characterize the 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	44	 In the present manuscript the transcription start site was determined, and the upstream 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene was identified and cloned and its transcriptional activity was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	45	1 In the course of these studies the sequence of the 5'-untranslated region (UTR) of the hPPAR gene was completed and an alternatively spliced exon within the 5'-UTR of the gene was identified.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Finally, hPPAR promoter activity was shown to be regulated by the nuclear receptors hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4), chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II (COUP-TFII), and PPAR itself.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	47	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Characterization of the 5'-UTR Structure of the hPPAR Gene and Identification of an Alternatively Spliced 5'-UTR Variant The hPPAR gene contains at least eight exons in which exons 1 and 2 and the 5'-end of exon 3 and the 3'-end of exon 8 are not translated (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The aim of our study was to determine the 5'-UTR structure of the hPPAR gene and to identify and characterize the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	49	 To identify noncoding exons within this region, different primers were designed and PCRs were carried out on reverse transcribed human liver RNA from two different subjects.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Using this approach, a novel exon was discovered.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	51	 When PCR was performed using a primer designed at the 3'-end of exon 2 (primer 13, Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	52	 1A) and a primer hybridizing the 3'-end of exon 1 (primer 15C, Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	53	 1A), a fragment of 158 bp containing both exon 1 and exon 2 was amplified (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Additionally, a second fragment 150 bp longer was repeatedly coamplified even at stringent PCR conditions.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Similar results were obtained with four other human liver and adipose tissue mRNA samples (data not shown), indicating that the unexpected additional PCR product corresponded to a rather common transcript.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Cloning and sequencing of this PCR fragment revealed the presence of 156 bp of novel sequence downstream of the sequence previously known as exon 1 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Furthermore, when PCR was performed using a primer within the novel sequence (primer IP3) and the exon 1-specific primer 15C, a fragment was amplified, further indicating the existence of this additional exon (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The novel sequence was located between exon 1 and 2 in a bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clone containing the hPPAR gene and was flanked by ag/gt consensus acceptor and donor splice sites, respectively (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The newly identified exon was named exon 1b, by analogy to the nomenclature used for the alternatively spliced exon present in the 5'-UTR of the mouse PPAR gene (36), whereas the previously known exon 1 was renamed exon 1a (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	60	 In addition, when 5'-RACE (rapid amplification of cDNA ends) reactions were carried out using primer IP3 located in exon 1b as gene-specific primer, a fragment covering the novel exon plus a sequence corresponding to exon 1a was amplified (data not shown), corroborating the existence of a second alternative transcript containing exon 1b in addition to exon 1a.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	61	 This suggests that exon 1b is spliced out alternatively giving rise to two different transcripts with distinct 5'-UTRs (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Thus, both mouse and human PPAR (hPPAR) genes display a similar 5'-UTR genomic organization.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	63	 However, the noncoding exons do not show a significant degree of sequence homology among species (38% for exon 1a and 29% for exon 1b).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	64	View larger version (29K):    Figure 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Intron-Exon Structure of the 5'-UTR of the hPPAR Gene and Identification of an Alternative Spliced 5'-UTR Variant.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	66	A, Schematic representation of the 5'-UTR of the hPPAR gene and the identified spliced variants.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The first coding exon (filled box) and the 5'-noncoding exons (hatched boxes) are depicted.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Numbers over the boxes represent the exon length in base pairs.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Oligonucleotides used for RT-PCR analysis are indicated by arrows.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	70	 B, RT-PCR analysis on human liver RNA isolated from two different subjects.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Total RNA was extracted, reverse transcribed, and amplified using primers 15C and 13 (left) or 15C and IP13 (right).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	72	 -PCR corresponds to a PCR carried in the absence of RT product.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	73	 C, Genomic sequence corresponding to the alternatively spliced exon 1b.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Oligonucleotides IP3 and IP7 used for 5'-RACE analysis are indicated by arrows.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The acceptor and donor splice sites are depicted in bold.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Nucleotides in uppercase and lowercase letters correspond to exon and intron sequences, respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	77	  Determination of the Transcription Start Site To determine the hPPAR transcription start site, 5'RACE-PCR analysis was performed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Genomic sequence upstream of the previously reported exon 1a sequence (37) was obtained by primer walking the BAC clone containing the hPPAR gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Despite the overall low degree of homology shown by the PPAR 5'-UTRs among different species, a sequence of around 60 bp was found to be 88% homologous to a region close to the transcription start site in the mouse PPAR 5'-UTR (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	80	 This prompted us to examine whether the transcription start site in the human gene could also be upstream of this region.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Accordingly, a primer close to that sequence (primer IP18, Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	82	 2A) was used as gene-specific primer in a 5'-RACE-PCR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	83	 A 213-bp DNA fragment was amplified from human liver RNA (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	84	 2B) and subsequently sequenced.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The most 5'-nucleotide before the poly-dC tail introduced by the 5'-RACE procedure mapped to a T and was designated as nucleotide +1 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Similar results were obtained when a different gene-specific primer (primer 5-GSP) was used in the 5'-RACE-PCR (data not shown).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	87	 To confirm the results of the 5'-RACE experiments, ribonuclease (RNase) protection analysis was performed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	88	 RNase mapping with a 337-nucleotide labeled cRNA probe complementary to bp -22 to +213 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	89	 2C) gave a major protected band of 213 bp (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	90	 2D), thus confirming the transcription start site that had been identified by 5'-RACE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	91	 These data indicate that exon 1a is considerably longer than the partially sequenced exon 1 that had been previously reported (34, 35, 37) and than the exon 1a identified in the mouse PPAR gene (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	92	View larger version (64K):    Figure 2.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Mapping of the Transcription Start Site of the hPPAR Gene by 5'-RACE and RNase Protection Analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	94	A, Sequence corresponding to exon 1a in the 5'-UTR region.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The oligonucleotides YGSP1, IP24, IP18, and 5-GSP used for 5'-RACE, RNase protection analysis, and cloning are indicated by arrows.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The donor splice site is depicted in bold lowercase.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The previously reported 5'-UTR sequence (37 ) is indicated in italics.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Transcription start site (+1) is shown by an arrow.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The sequence in bold uppercase represents a region showing 88% homology with both rat and mouse 5'-UTRs (see text for of the 5'-RACE products on an agarose gel.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Total RNA from human liver was reverse transcribed and the cDNA was poly-(dC) tailed with terminal deoxynucleotide transferase (TdT) as described in Materials and Methods.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	101	 dC-tailed cDNA (TdT+) or untailed cDNA (TdT-) were amplified using an universal primer (AAP) and a gene-specific primer (IP18).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	102	 C, Schematic representation of the probe used for RNase protection analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	103	 A genomic DNA fragment (-22 to +213) was amplified with oligonucleotides IP24 and IP18 (depicted in panel A) and cloned into pBluescript SK+.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Subsequently an antisense RNA probe was transcribed.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The size of the protected fragment, as predicted by the 5'-RACE experiment shown in panel B, is indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	106	 D, Mapping of the transcription start site by RNase protection analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Autoradiograph of RNase protection analysis carried out on 20  microg of human liver total RNA extracted from two different subjects.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The protected probe fragments (indicated by an arrow) correspond to those predicted in panel B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	109	  Cloning and Analysis of the 5'-Flanking Region of the hPPAR Gene To identify potential binding sites for transcription factors that may be important in the regulation of hPPAR gene expression, 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	110	6 kb of hPPAR sequence upstream of the transcription start site were cloned.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	111	 No consensus TATA or CCAAT boxes were found within the first 100 bp, although a CCAAT box was observed at -472 bp (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Furthermore, this region possesses the characteristics of a TATA-less promoter, namely, GC-rich sequences and multiple putative Sp1 binding sites.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Computer-assisted analysis (38) revealed several potential transcription factor binding sites including AP2, Egr-1, Egr-2, E box, NFB, and MZF-1 among others (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (57K):    Figure 3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Nucleotide Sequence of the 5'-Flanking Region of the hPPAR Gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	116	Numbers are relative to the transcription start site (+1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The putative HNF4-RE is underlined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Putative transcription factor binding sites are indicated by open boxes.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	119	  Functional Characterization of the hPPAR Promoter To determine the ability of hPPAR 5'-flanking region to drive basal transcriptional activity, sequences were fused to a luciferase reporter gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Because hPPAR is highly expressed in liver (17), the 1,664-bp promoter-containing plasmid, p(H-H)-pGL3, was transiently transfected into human HepG2 hepatoma cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Activity of this construct was about 8-fold the activity of the parental promoterless construct (pGL3 basic) in these cells (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Next, the promoter activity of different 5'-deletion constructs was evaluated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Deletion from -1,664 to -1,206 did not significantly affect the promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Truncation to -648 significantly reduced the luciferase activity in HepG2 cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	125	 By contrast, in agreement with hPPAR tissue-selective expression, luciferase activities of the p(H-H)-pGL3 construct and its 5'-deletion mutants were only 2-fold higher than pGL3 basic in Cos-1 cells, a cell line that does not express PPAR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	126	 These experiments suggest that these cells are devoid of the factors driving basal hPPAR expression compared with HepG2 cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The shortest construct, p(P-H)-pGL3, containing the GC-rich proximal promoter was only 2-fold more active relative to pGL3 basic vector in both cell lines compared with the 6-fold activity shown by the p(E-H)-pGL3 construct, which suggests that sequences between -536 and -1,664 may contain binding sites for key transcription factors driving basal hPPAR gene expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	128	View larger version (11K):    Figure 4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Functional Analysis of hPPAR Promoter 5'-Deletion Mutants.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	130	The region spanning 1,664 bp of promoter and the first 83 bp of exon 1a was progressively deleted from its 5'-end, fused to the pGL3 basic vector, and transfected into the indicated cell types as described in Materials and Methods.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Values (mean  plus or minus  SD) represent firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Luciferase activities are shown relative to the activity of the pGL3 basic vector, which was arbitrarily set to 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	133	  Identification of a Functional HNF4 Regulatory Element (HNF4-RE) in the hPPAR Promoter Because hPPAR is highly expressed in liver and the hPPAR 5'-flanking region shows significant promoter activity in HepG2 cells, the regulation of hPPAR promoter activity by HNF4, a nuclear receptor that is abundantly expressed in liver, was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	134	 To this purpose, transient transfection studies were performed with the p(H-H)-pGL3 construct in HepG2 cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In the presence of increasing concentrations of HNF4, hPPAR promoter activity was induced in a dose-dependent fashion (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	136	 To localize the region that confers HNF4 responsiveness within the hPPAR promoter, cotransfection assays were repeated with a series of 5'-deletion hPPAR promoter constructs (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	137	 These experiments revealed that the HNF4 responsive region resides within the fragment flanked by HindIII and XhoI sites.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Analysis of the sequence in this region of the hPPAR promoter revealed two potential hexamer binding sites separated by a single nucleotide between nucleotide -1,492 to -1,483 (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	139	 3), conforming to the DR1 response elements for HNF4 (HNF4-RE).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	140	 To unequivocally characterize the imperfect DR1 as an HNF4 response element, HepG2 and Cos cells were transfected with a hPPAR promoter construct bearing two nucleotide mutations in the 5'-hexamer of the DR1 element, p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In contrast to the wild-type promoter construct p(H-H)-pGL3, the mutated promoter was not influenced by HNF4 cotransfection in both cell lines (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	142	 5C), thus demonstrating that the hPPAR HNF4-RE (HNF4-RE) indeed confers HNF4 response to the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	143	View larger version (17K):    Figure 5.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	144	 HNF4-Mediated Transcriptional Regulation of hPPAR via a DR1 Element.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	145	A, HNF4 increases hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	146	 HepG2 cells were transfected with the indicated reporter construct in the presence or absence of increasing amounts (3, 10, and 30 ng) of the HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	147	 When the hPPAR promoter plasmid was not cotransfected, pGL3 basic empty vector was added to the transfection mixture.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Relative luciferase activities are shown as described in Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	149	 B, Deletion analysis of the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	150	 HepG2 cells were transfected with the indicated reporter constructs in the presence or absence of 30 ng of HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Relative luciferase activities in the presence of HNF4 are shown as fold induction of the activity of the reporter constructs in the absence of HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	152	 C, Schematic representation of the constructs p(H-H)-pGL3 and p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The bases mutated in p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3 are underlined.

0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	155	 HepG2 and Cos cells were transfected with the indicated reporter constructs in the presence or absence of the HNF4 expression plasmid (50 ng).

0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The data presented in panels A, B, and D represent the mean  plus or minus  SD of the firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	158	  Binding Analysis of HNF4 to the DR1 Element To demonstrate direct binding of HNF4 to the HNF4-RE, EMSAs were performed with a radiolabeled DR1 oligonucleotide probe and in vitro translated HNF4 proteins.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	159	 6, HNF4 bound the HNF4-RE (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	160	 6A, lane 4) and the well characterized C3P site present in the apo CIII promoter (39) with similar efficacy (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	161	 DNA binding was almost completely abolished when two-point mutations were introduced into the HNF4-RE-labeled oligonucleotide (GCAGCAAAGTTCA instead of GGGGCAAAGTTCA where the underlined letters indicate the mutated nucleotides) (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Furthermore, the specificity of the HNF4-DR1 interaction was demonstrated by competition studies.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Inhibition of formation of the complex was shown by the addition of increasing concentrations of either the unlabeled HNF4-RE (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	164	 6B, lanes 9 to 11) oligonucleotides, whereas competition with an equivalent amount of unlabeled mutated HNF4-RE did not significantly displace the labeled wild-type element (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	165	View larger version (69K):    Figure 6.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	166	A, HNF4 binds the HNF4-RE and C3P oligonucleotide probes with similar efficacy.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Autoradiograph of EMSA performed on end-labeled oligonucleotides (probe) using in vitro translated HNF4.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	168	 B, Competition experiments were performed in the presence of 1-, 10-, and 100-fold molar excess of the indicated unlabeled oligonucleotides on a HNF4-RE radiolabeled probe.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	169	  The HNF4-RE Confers HNF4 Responsiveness to a Heterologous Promoter To explore the activation of the HNF4-RE by HNF4 in the context of a heterologous promoter, cotransfection studies were performed with the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct, which contains two copies of the DR1 in the sense orientation in front of the thymidine kinase (TK) promoter (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Upon cotransfection of HNF4 into both HepG2 and RK13 cells, the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 transcriptional activity was significantly enhanced (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	171	 By contrast, the reporter activity of a similar heterologous promoter construct containing two copies of the mutated HNF4-RE was not influenced by HNF4 cotransfection (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Taken together, these data show that the DR1 site is a bona fide HNF4-RE that mediates HNF4 induction of hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	173	View larger version (17K):    Figure 7.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The HNF4-RE Confers HNF4 Responsiveness to a Heterologous Promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	175	A, Schematic representation of the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 and the HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3 constructs.

0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The data represent the mean  plus or minus  SD of the firefly luciferase activity normalized relative to a Renilla luciferase transfection internal control and are shown as described in Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	183	  COUP-TFII Binds the HNF4-RE and Represses Basal and HNF4-Induced hPPAR Promoter Activity DR1 elements can be recognized not only by HNF4, but also by other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, including the transcription factor COUP-TFII, also known as apo A-1 regulatory protein 1 or ARP1 (40).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In addition, COUP-TFII has been shown to actively repress or modulate the effects of HNF4 on the transcription of several genes in liver (39, 41, 42, 43, 44).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Therefore, the ability of COUP-TFII to bind the HNF4-RE was evaluated by gel shift analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	186	 COUP-TFII proteins bound to the radiolabeled HNF4-RE probe, and competition with 50-fold molar excess of unlabeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide completely inhibited the formation of the COUP-TFII -DNA complex (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (29K):    Figure 8.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	188	 COUP-TFII Binds the DR1 and Modulates Basal and HNF4-Induced hPPAR Promoter Activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	189	A, EMSA performed on end-labeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide in the presence of in vitro translated COUP-TFII.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The unlabeled oligonucleotide (50-fold molar excess) was added to the binding reactions when indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	191	 B, The indicated reporter constructs were cotransfected into either HepG2 or Cos cells with or without HNF4 and COUP-TFII as indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	192	 When either the HNF4 or COUP-TFII expression plasmids were not cotransfected, pSG5 or pCDNA3 empty vectors, respectively, were added to the transfection mixture.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Relative luciferase activities (mean  plus or minus  SD) are shown as fold induction of the activity of the p(H-H)-pGL3 reporter construct in the absence of both HNF4 and COUP-TFII.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	194	  The influence of COUP-TFII on the hPPAR promoter activity was then investigated by cotransfection experiments in HepG2 and Cos cells.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Transient transfection of COUP-TFII alone decreased the activity of the hPPAR promoter construct containing the HNF4-RE site in both HepG2 and Cos cells (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	196	 As previously observed, upon cotransfection of HNF4, hPPAR promoter activity was induced in both cell lines.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	197	 However, overexpression of COUP-TFII in the presence of HNF4 abrogated the HNF4-induced transcriptional activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	198	 On the contrary, when identical experiments were performed with a promoter construct bearing a mutation in the HNF4-RE, promoter activity was not affected by cotransfection of either COUP-TFII or HNF4 alone or added together (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	199	 These data demonstrate that the repression of the PPAR promoter by COUP-TFII and the antagonism of the HNF4 induction are dependent on the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Altogether these results indicate that COUP-TFII negatively regulates PPAR gene transcription.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	201	hPPAR Binds the HNF4-RE and Regulates Its Own Expression Next, direct binding of PPAR/RXR heterodimers to the hPPAR HNF4-RE was examined.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	202	 To this purpose, gel shift analysis was performed with the radiolabeled HNF4-RE probe and in vitro translated PPAR and RXR proteins.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	203	 PPAR/RXR heterodimers bound the HNF4-RE oligonucleotide (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	204	 DNA binding could be competed with increasing amounts of unlabeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	205	 9A, lanes 3 to 5), whereas incubation with a mutated HNF4-RE oligonucleotide did not compete for binding (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	206	View larger version (28K):    Figure 9.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	207	 PPAR Positively Regulates Its Own Expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	208	 EMSA performed on end-labeled HNF4-RE oligonucleotide in the presence of in vitro translated PPAR and RXR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Competition experiments were performed in the presence of 10-, 25-, and 50-fold molar excess of the indicated unlabeled oligonucleotides.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	210	 B, PPAR modulates hPPAR promoter activity via the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Cos cells were transfected with either the p(H-H)-pGL3 hPPAR or the p(H-H) HNF4-REmut-pGL3 hPPAR promoter construct, with or without a PPAR expression plasmid in the presence or absence of 100  microM Wy 14,643 as indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Relative luciferase activities (mean  plus or minus  SD) for each construct are shown relative to the promoter activity in the absence of PPAR and activator, which was arbitrarily set to 1.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	213	 C, The HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 plasmid was transfected in Cos cells with or without PPAR in the presence or absence of 50  microM Wy 14,643 as indicated.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Relative luciferase activities (mean  plus or minus  SD) are shown as in panel B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	215	 D, Fenofibric acid enhances hPPAR mRNA levels in primary cultures of human hepatocytes.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Human hepatocytes were isolated and treated for 24 h with (FF) or without (CON) 250  microM fenofibric acid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	217	 One microgram of total RNA was reversed transcribed and subjected to Real Time PCR analysis as described in Materials and Methods.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Specific hPPAR mRNA normalized to 28S content is expressed relative to untreated cells (mean  plus or minus  SD, n = 3).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	219	  To determine the effect of PPAR on hPPAR promoter activity, transient transfection assays were performed using the hPPAR promoter construct containing the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Cotransfection of PPAR induced hPPAR reporter activity approximately 2-fold, an effect that was enhanced in the presence of Wy 14,643.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	221	 By contrast, no effect by either PPAR or its ligand could be observed when a construct containing the mutated HNF4-RE was employed, indicating that an intact HNF4-RE site is required for the PPAR-mediated induction.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	222	 To investigate whether the HNF4-RE could function as a PPRE in front of a heterologous promoter, transient transfection assays were performed using the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Incubation of cells with Wy 14,643 in the presence of cotransfected PPAR resulted in a 5-fold activation of the HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 construct, indicating that the HNF4-RE site is a functional PPRE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	224	Finally, to analyze whether hPPAR mRNA expression is regulated by PPAR agonists, primary hepatocytes isolated from human liver were cultured for 24 h in medium containing fenofibric acid.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	225	 hPPAR mRNA levels were markedly up-regulated upon treatment with fenofibric acid (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Taken together, these data show that PPAR positively autoregulates its expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	227	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   PPAR is a transcription factor that regulates lipid, glucose, and energy homeostasis and controls body weight and vascular inflammation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Thus, PPAR may play a modulatory role in the onset and evolution of different metabolic and vascular disorders such as dyslipidemia, obesity, insulin resistance, and atherosclerosis (1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Dysregulation of PPAR expression may contribute to the development of these disorders as well as the response to its fibrate agonists.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Indeed, PPAR expression levels have been shown to influence its transcriptional activity as well as the response to fibrate treatment in rodents (22, 25, 26, 27).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	231	 However, the study of the molecular mechanisms governing PPAR regulation in humans has not been addressed to date.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	232	To study PPAR regulation in humans, we characterized the 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene and identified the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The genomic organization of hPPAR was recently reported (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The hPPAR gene contains at least eight exons in which exons 1 and 2, the 5'-end of exon 3, and the 3'-end of exon 8 are not translated (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	235	 As an initial step in our study, the 5'-UTR of the hPPAR gene was further characterized, resulting in the completion of the 5'-end sequence of exon 1, renamed exon 1a, and in the identification of an alternatively spliced 5'-variant.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	236	 An alternatively spliced exon in the mouse PPAR 5'-UTR has been previously reported (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	237	 However, alignment of both mouse and human 5'-UTR sequences revealed no significant degree of homology between them despite the coding exons being very similar between species.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	238	The transcription start site of the hPPAR gene was mapped.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The proximal promoter of the hPPAR gene contains no typical TATA or CCAAT boxes and has a high GC content, including several consensus Sp1 sites, features that are also present in the mouse PPAR promoter (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Excluding the proximal GC-rich region, both promoters do not show a high degree in sequence homology (40%).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	241	 However, only a small fragment of the mouse PPAR promoter has been sequenced to date (36).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	242	 This sequence disparity in both the 5'-UTR and the promoter regions may indicate that PPAR gene expression among species could be regulated in a different manner although sufficient data to establish a thorough comparison between species are lacking at this stage.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	243	Computer-assisted analysis of the hPPAR promoter sequence identified various putative transcription factor binding sites, such as sites for members of the early growth response (Egr) gene family, which are involved in the induction of monocytic differentiation (45).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Egr proteins could thus be involved in the up-regulation of hPPAR expression upon monocyte differentiation into macrophages (32) although further studies are needed to confirm this hypothesis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Furthermore, potential sites for NFB and AP1, factors involved in the transduction of several cytokine and proinflammatory signals, as well as for the myeloid zinc finger gene, MZF-1, were found in the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	246	 PPAR inhibition of NFB- and AP1-induced expression of inflammatory response genes (46) lies at the basis of its antiinflammatory activities.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	247	 It is tempting to speculate that hPPAR expression, in its turn, is controlled by inflammatory cytokines.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Because rodent PPAR mRNA levels are increased by glucocorticoids (20, 21), putative GR response elements were searched for.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	249	 No obvious GR response element could be detected within the hPPAR regulatory region analyzed; however, regulation studies in human tissues or cell lines would be necessary to determine whether hPPAR expression is also modulated by glucocorticoids in humans.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	250	HNF4 is a nuclear receptor that plays a key role in liver-specific gene expression (47) and is required for mammalian hepatocyte differentiation and for normal metabolic regulation in liver (48).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	251	 HNF4 is expressed at high levels in liver, kidney, and intestine (47).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	252	 It binds as homodimers to DR1-like response elements, thereby modulating the expression of several liver-enriched genes encoding apolipoproteins, coagulation factors, serum proteins, proteins of the cytochrome P450 family, and genes involved in FA and glucose metabolism (49).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Regulation of hPPAR by HNF4 is consistent with the tissue-expression pattern shown by PPAR.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In the present study induction of hPPAR promoter activity by HNF4 is reported.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	255	 A HNF4-RE was identified at nt -1,492 to -1,483 within the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	256	 This element closely resembles several HNF4-REs found in other genes and the GGGGCA A AGGTCA consensus HNF4 binding site (50).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Moreover, the regulation of PPAR gene expression by HNF4 in vivo in mice was recently demonstrated using HNF4-deficient mice (51).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	258	 These mice display significantly lower PPAR mRNA levels compared with the wild-type mice, thus demonstrating that PPAR expression is regulated by HNF4 also in mice.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Nevertheless, the promoter experiments performed with the hPPAR promoter indicate that the HNF4 site identified is not responsible for the activity of the hPPAR promoter in liver because the promoter construct lacking this site still possesses a significant activity in HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	260	 This may suggest that this site binds as well other factors, such as COUP-TF, present in these cells that negatively regulate the hPPAR promoter either as a result of a direct repression of the promoter or due to competition with factors, such as HNF4, for binding to the site.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	261	 In addition, negative factors may bind to sites located between -1,664 and -1,206 bp in the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Future studies on the regulation of this promoter will be required to elucidate the factors governing hPPAR gene expression in liver.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	263	Members of the COUP-TF family of orphan nuclear receptors have been reported to bind DR1 sites that are also recognized by HNF4 (52).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	264	 COUP-TF actively represses or antagonizes HNF4-mediated transcriptional activation of several genes (39, 41, 42, 43, 44).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	265	 COUP-TF II has been shown to play a role in cardiac energy metabolism and heart development (53, 54).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	266	 In this study, COUP-TFII was also shown to bind the HNF4-RE within the hPPAR regulatory region and to repress both basal and HNF4-induced hPPAR promoter activity.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The COUP-TFII antagonism may finely tune HNF4-dependent gene expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The expression level of a COUP-TFII/HNF4 target gene would therefore depend on the relative concentrations of both transcription factors in a given cell type or during a certain condition.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	269	 For instance, the age-dependent diminution of apo AI gene expression has been shown to occur at the transcriptional level and to be associated with a decrease in the binding capacity and expression of HNF4 and a parallel increase in COUP-TFII binding and concentration levels (55).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Interestingly, PPAR gene expression is also diminished in aged rats (23).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Further studies are required to demonstrate whether the molecular mechanisms described for the age-dependent decline of apo AI can also explain the decreased expression of PPAR with age.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	272	Finally, PPAR is also capable of binding to the HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Induction of PPAR gene expression by PPAR agonists has been reported in different rodent cell lines (22, 24, 56).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Our data indicate that PPAR agonists, such as fenofibrate, induce hPPAR mRNA levels in primary cultures of human hepatocytes as well as hPPAR promoter activity, suggesting that these effects are exerted at the transcriptional level.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Furthermore, induction of hPPAR promoter activity is dependent on the identified HNF4-RE.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Autoregulation is a common feature among nuclear receptors.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	277	 For instance, GRs are regulated by glucocorticoids, and glucocorticoids exert these actions mainly at the level of transcription (57).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	278	 AR is another nuclear receptor that is autoregulated (58), and three different ER promoters have been shown to be regulated by estrogens (59).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	279	The coding exons of the hPPAR gene have been screened for polymorphisms.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	280	 A leucine-to-valine missense mutation at codon 162 in exon 5 of the hPPAR gene (L162V) was recently identified (34, 35).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	281	 This polymorphism shows an enhanced transactivation activity (34) and has been associated with altered plasma lipid and lipoprotein concentrations in type 2 diabetic subjects (34), supporting a role for PPAR in dyslipidemia and diabetes in humans also.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Variants have been identified in other exons and introns of the hPPAR gene (Ref.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Staels, unpublished observations).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	284	 However, these polymorphisms either show low frequency in the populations studied or they do not directly affect PPAR activity due to their location in intronic sequences of the gene.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Thus, it will be interesting to search for polymorphisms in the promoter sequences of the gene that may affect PPAR expression and function.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	286	Taken together, the 5'-flanking region of the hPPAR gene has been characterized, cloned, and functionally studied.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	287	 HNF4 induces hPPAR expression via a DR1 element present in the hPPAR promoter, whereas this effect is antagonized by the orphan receptor COUP-TFII.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	288	 In addition, PPAR itself modulates its own expression.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Knowledge of the hPPAR promoter structure will allow further studies of the molecular mechanisms governing hPPAR gene regulation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	290	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   DNA Sequencing Sequencing of a BAC clone containing the hPPAR gene (kind gift of B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	291	Wilkinson; Glaxo Welcome, Research Triangle Park, NC) was performed using the dRhodamine terminator cycle sequencing kit on an ABI Prism 377 DNA sequencer (Perkin-Elmer Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	292	Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends (5'-RACE) PCR and RT-PCR Analysis Total human liver RNA was isolated using the guanidinium isothiocyanate method (61).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	293	 5'-RACE was performed on 1  microg total RNA using the 5' RACE-System for Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends kit (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	294	, Gaithersburg, MD) according to the manufacturer s instructions.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	295	 For the determination of the 5'-end of exon 1a, first-strand synthesis of hPPAR cDNA was carried out using the IP7 oligonucleotide (5'-CAAGCAGTCCTCCTACCTCAGCCTTCCAAG-3') located in exon 1b (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	296	 After RNase H treatment and poly(dC)-tailing of the cDNA with a terminal deoxynucleotide transferase, the resulting cDNA (5  microl) was amplified in a PCR using the Abridged Anchor Primer (AAP) and the internal gene-specific primer YGSP1 (5'-AGTTCTGAGCTTCTCTTGCCACAAACAGTTGAGTCC-3') located in exon 1a (Fig.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	297	 PCR cycling parameters were as follows: initial denaturation at 95 C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles of 1 min at 95 C, 40 sec at 57 C, and 40 sec at 72 C with a final elongation at 72 C for 3 min.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	298	 The PCR product was then diluted 100-fold, and the diluted PCR (5  microl) was used for a nested PCR under the same conditions described above with the Abridged Universal Amplification Primer (AUAP) (nested to AAP) and oligonucleotide IP18 (5'-AGAGTCGCTGCGGTCCCCAGAC-3') (nested to YGSP1).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Oligonucleotides AUAP and AAP were provided in the 5'-RACE kit.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	300	 PCR products were visualized on a 2% agarose gel and sequenced as described above.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	301	 RT-PCR amplification of the hPPAR 5'-UTR was performed as described (31) using oligonucleotides 15C (5'-CAGGGCCCTGTCTGCTCTGTGCA-3'), 13 (5'-CTCTTATCTATGAAGCAGGAAGCACG-3'), and IP3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	302	RNase Protection Analysis The RNase protection probe used to map the transcription initiation site of the hPPAR gene was amplified by PCR from the BAC-hPPAR clone using oligonucleotides IP24 (5'-CGCGGGGCCCGGGGTCTCGGGGTCTCCG-3') and IP18 and cloned into the EcoRV site of pBluescript SK+ (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	303	 After linearizing with XhoI, antisense RNA was transcribed with T3 polymerase using the Maxiscript Kit (Ambion, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	304	, Austin, TX) as described by the manufacturer.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	305	 This 337-nucleotide probe contains cRNA complementary to the hPPAR 5'-flanking region (bp -22 to +213) and to the polylinker of the pBluescript SK+ vector (102 bp).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	306	 RNase protection analysis was carried out using the Hybspeed RNase protection Kit (Ambion, Inc.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	307	Real-Time PCR mRNA Quantification PPAR and 28S mRNAs were quantified by reverse transcription followed by Real-Time PCR using a LightCycler (Roche Diagnostics, Meylan, France) with oligonucleotide primers specific for hPPAR (5'-ATATCTCCCTTTTTGTGGCTGCTA-3' and 5'-TCCGACTCCGTCTTCTYGATGA-3') and 28S (62).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Reactions were carried out in a 20- microl reaction containing a 500-nM concentration of each primer, 4 mM MgCl2, and the LightCycler-FastStart DNA Master SYBR Green I mix as recommended by the manufacturer with the following conditions: 95 C for 8 min, followed by 40 cycles of 10 sec at 95 C, 10 sec at 55 C and 14 sec (for hPPAR) or 15 sec (for 28S) at 72 C.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	309	 hPPAR mRNA levels were normalized to 28S mRNA.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	310	Cloning of the hPPAR Promoter and Construction of Reporter Plasmids Genomic sequences between -3,593 and +83 (numbered on the basis of the distance from the transcription initiation site) obtained by direct sequencing of the BAC-hPPAR clone were amplified by PCR using oligonucleotides IP34 (5'-GCCAGGAGCAGCCACCAGGGAAATC-3') and 5-GSP (5'-AGTCCTCGGTGTGTGTCCTCGCTCCTC-3') from BAC clone DNA.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	311	 The resulting product was cloned blunt into the EcoRV site of pBluescript SK+ (Stratagene).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	312	 Reporter constructs were generated thereafter by digestion using restriction sites within the hPPAR promoter.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	313	 The pBS(IP34 to 5GSP) construct was digested with HindIII or both HindIII and XhoI, and the resulting promoter digestion products were gel purified and cloned into a HindIII or XhoI plus HindIII-digested pGL3 basic plasmid (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	314	, Madison, WI), creating the reporter vectors p(H-H)-pGL3 and p(X-H)-pGL3, respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Plasmids p(E-H)-pGL3 and p(P-H)-pGL3 were generated by digestion of p(X-H)-pGL3 with EcoRI plus XhoI or PstI plus XhoI, Klenow fill in of cohesive ends, and subsequent ligation of the obtained blunt ends.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	316	 HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 and HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3 were created by ligating two copies of the corresponding double-stranded oligonucleotides (5'-GATCCTGGAGGGTGGGGCAAAGTTCACCATAGGTA-3' for HNF4-REx2S-TKpGL3 and 5'-GATCCTGGAGGGTGCAGCAAAGTTCACCATAGGTA-3' for HNF4-REmutx2S-TKpGL3) in the sense orientation into the BamHI site of TK-pGL3.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	317	 All constructs were verified by restriction site digestion and sequence analysis.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Transcription factor analysis of the promoter was performed using the MatInspector program (http://genomatix.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	319	de/cgi-bin/matinspector/matinspector.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	320	Site-Directed Mutagenesis To create p(H-H)HNF4-REmut-pGL3, mutation of the HNF4-RE was generated using the QuikChange Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit (Stratagene) and oligonucleotide (5'-GGTGTCTGGAGGCTGCAGCAAAGTTCACCATAG-3') and its complementary oligonucleotide according to the manufacturer s recommendations.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	321	Cell Culture and Transient Transfection Assays Human liver specimens were collected for transplantation at the Moscow Center, and hepatocytes were obtained by a two-step collagenase perfusion as previously described (63).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Donors were physically healthy subjects who died after traumatic brain injury.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Permission to use the remaining untransplanted donor liver for scientific research purposes was obtained from the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	324	 After 20 h of culture the medium was discarded and 250  microM fenofibric acid (Laboratories Fournier, Daix, France) or vehicle was added at the indicated concentration in serum-free medium for 24 h.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	325	 HepG2 (human hepatoblastoma), RK13 (rabbit kidney), and Cos cells were cultured as previously described (31).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	326	 HepG2 (105), RK13 (8 x 104), and Cos (4 x 104) cells were transfected using the cationic lipid RPR 120535B (kind gift of Aventis, Vitry, France) as described previously (64).
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	327	 One hundred nanograms of the indicated pGL3 basic firefly luciferase reporter constructs or 10 ng of the TK-pGL3 reporters were cotransfected with or without 30 to 50 ng of pSG5-hHNF41 (termed HNF4 throughout this manuscript, kindly provided by B.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Laine), pcDNA3-COUP-TFII [subcloned from pMT2-COUP-TFII (65) into pcDNA3] or pSG5-hPPAR, and either 20 ng or 5 ng of the internal control Renilla luciferase reporter plasmids, pRL-Null (when basal promoter activities of the different deletion constructs were examined) (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	329	) and pRL-C+ (for the remaining transfection experiments), respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	330	 pRL-C+ was obtained by replacing the luc + cassette in pGL3-C+ (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	331	 When either HNF4 or COUP-TFII plasmid was not cotransfected, pSG5 (Stratagene) or pcDNA3 (Invitrogen) empty vectors were added to the transfection mixture.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Luciferase activity was assayed 36 h later using the Dual-Luciferase Reporter Assay System (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Transfections were carried out in triplicate, and each experiment was repeated at least twice.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	334	EMSAs HNF4, COUP-TFII, PPAR, and RXR were synthesized in vitro using the TNT Quick Coupled Transcription/Translation System (Promega Corp.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides were end-labeled with [-32P]ATP by using T4-polynucleotide kinase.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	336	 Proteins (2  microl) were incubated for 15 min at room temperature in a total volume of 20  microl with 2.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	337	5  microg poly (dI-dC) and 1  microg herring sperm DNA in binding buffer (10 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	338	1 mM EDTA; 10% glycerol; 1 mg/ml BSA; and 0.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	339	5 mM dithiothreitol) before the radiolabeled probe (0.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Binding reactions were further incubated for 15 min and resolved by 4% nondenaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in 0.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	341	25x Tris-borate-EDTA buffer at room temperature.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	342	 For competition experiments, increasing amounts of unlabeled oligonucleotide HNF4-RE, HNF4-REmut, or C3P (39) were included in the binding reaction just before addition of the labeled oligonucleotide.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	343	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Christian Duhem, Odile Vidal, and Eric Raspe for their expert technical assistance.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	344	 We are grateful to Lluis Fajas, Raphael Darteil, and Olivier Barbier for their helpful advice and discussions.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	345	   FOOTNOTES   This work was supported by European Community Grant ERBFMBICT983214 (to I.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	346	) and BIOMED 2 Grant PL963324 (to Y.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	347	 is also supported by British Heart Foundation Grant FS/98058.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	348	Abbreviations: AP1 or 2, Activating protein 1 or 2; AAP, abridged anchor primer; BAC, bacterial chromosomal clone, COUP-TFII, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II; DR1, direct repeat-1, FA, fatty acid; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4; HNF4-RE, HNF4 regulatory element; NFB, nuclear factor B; PPRE, PPAR response element; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; RNase, ribonuclease; TK, thymidine kinase; UTR, untranslated region.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	349	1 The sequence data for the hPPAR exon 1a, 1b, and promoter have been submitted to the GenBank database under GenBank accession numbers AF323915, AF323916, and AF323917, respectively.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	350	Received for publication August 31, 2001.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Accepted for publication January 17, 2001.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	352	   REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Desvergne B, Wahli W 1999 Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors: nuclear control of metabolism.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Endocr Rev 20:649 to 688[Abstract/Free Full Text] Chinetti G, Fruchart JC, Staels B 2000 Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs): nuclear receptors at the crossroads between lipid metabolism and inflammation.
0.37514272.11981036.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Inflamm Res 49:497 to 505[CrossRef][Medline] Willson TM, Brown PJ, Sternbach DD, Henke BR 2000 The PPARs: from orphan receptors to drug discovery.
