0.33547345.15611122.html.plaintext.txt	456	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2005 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	0	Haploinsufficiency of Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor II in Female Reproduction Norio Takamoto, Isao Kurihara, Kevin Lee, Francesco J.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	1	 DeMayo, Ming-Jer Tsai and Sophia Y.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	2	Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology and Program of Development, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	3	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Sophia Y.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	4	, Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	5	edu' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> or mtsai{at}bcm.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	6	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor II, COUP-TFII, is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor transcription factor family.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Genetic ablation of COUP-TFII results in early embryonic lethality and demonstrates that this gene is required for cardiac and vascular development.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Expression of COUP-TFII persists throughout postnatal life in various tissues including the female reproductive tract.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, the physiological function of COUP-TFII in female reproduction has not been extensively analyzed.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Here, we provide phenotypic evidences that haploinsufficiency of COUP-TFII in mice demonstrates an important role of COUP-TFII for normal female reproduction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	11	 COUP-TFII +/ to  females show significantly reduced fecundity, irregular estrus cycles, delayed puberty, and retarded postnatal growth.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Analysis of the reduced fertility revealed that although ovarian function was normal with respect to ovulation, the ovaries have reduced ability to synthesize progesterone in response to exogenous gonadotropins.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	13	 This reduction is due to the reduction of the expression of steroidogenic enzymes important for progesterone synthesis and the reduction of vascularization in COUP-TFII heterozygotes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Analysis of uterine function demonstrated a reduced response to an experimentally induced decidual cell reaction indicating that the ability of the uterus to support embryo implantation was reduced.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Taken together, our data show global impact of gene dosage effects of COUP-TFII on female postnatal life and indicates requirement of COUP-TFII in normal female reproduction, in particular for uterine endometrial functions during the periimplantation period.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	16	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   CHICKEN OVALBUMIN upstream promoter transcription factors (COUP-TFs; NRF2) are orphan members of the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor superfamily (1).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Two highly conserved COUP-TF genes, COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII, have been identified in mammals (1).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Biochemical studies showed that these proteins bind promiscuously to direct repeat motifs, with preference of DR1 sequences and can negatively or positively regulate a large number of genes (2).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The expression patterns of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII are distinctly different.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	20	 COUP-TFI is expressed at high levels in the neural system, whereas COUP-TFII is expressed in the mesenchyme of developing organs (3).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Consistent with their expression pattern, deletion of the COUP-TFI in mice results in perinatal lethality with mutants exhibiting neuronal deficits (4, 5, 6).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	22	 COUP-TFII null mutant mice die before embryonic d 10.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	23	5 with angiogenic and cardiogenic defects (7).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The embryo lethal phenotype of COUP-TFII impeded the analysis of the role of this transcription factor in the adult physiology; however, COUP-TFII +/ to  mice exhibit several phenotypes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The analysis of the haploinsufficiency phenotype of the COUP-TFII +/ to  may shed light on the role of this orphan nuclear receptor in the adult.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	26	Haploinsufficiency that is caused by heterozygosity of a targeted null allele occasionally reveals the overall impact of a gene dosage effect as a traceable trait.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Many COUP-TFII +/ to  mutants die before weaning suggesting a haploinsufficiency phenotype of the COUP-TFII gene (7).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Upon analyzing the mating patterns of COUP-TFII +/ to  mice, we found that the COUP-TFII +/ to  females have reduced reproductive function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	29	 COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice exhibited reduced fecundity characterized by reduced litter size, and genotype-dependent reduction in growth in the progeny.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Because normal female reproduction requires functional coordination throughout female hypothalamo-hypophyeal-ovarian endocrine axis, as well as an endocrinological link between ovary and uterus, subtle defects in multiple organs of this axis, could significantly alter the normal reproduction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Therefore, we investigated the ovarian and uterine physiology of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice to determine the cause of this reduction in female fecundity.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	32	Here, we report on the phenotypic analysis of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse, specifically related to female ovarian and uterine function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Analysis of ovarian function was conducted by challenging COUP-TFII +/ to  and control mice with a superovulatory regimen of gonadotropins and assaying the ability of the ovary to ovulate and produce ovarian steroids.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse showed normal ovulation of oocytes but demonstrated a reduced capability for synthesizing sex steroid hormones.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This reduction is due to the reduction of the expression of steroidogenic enzymes important for P4 synthesis and the reduction of vascularization in COUP-TFII heterozygotes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Analysis of uterine function in the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice was accomplished by assaying the response of the uterus to an endocrine induction of the decidual reaction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	37	 COUP-TFII +/ to  showed a reduced decidual cell reaction in response to the artificial stimulation, indicating a defect in endometrial function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Analysis of the expression of COUP-TFII +/ to  in the endometrium demonstrated steroid hormone-dependent changes in expression of COUP-TFII in the uterine endometrial stroma.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	39	 This analysis demonstrates that COUP-TFII is important in the regulation of ovarian and uterine function and indicates that COUP-TFII is required for normal female reproductive functions.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	40	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   COUP-TFII +/ to  Female Mice Exhibit Reduced Fertility In maintaining the COUP-TFII mutant mouse colony, it was noticed that COUP-TFII +/ to  exhibited reduced fertility.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To quantify the reduction of fertility, the overall reproductive performance of the COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice was assessed by continuous mating.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	42	 COUP-TFII +/+ male and COUP-TFII +/+ or COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice were continuously mated for 3 months.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The numbers of litters and pups born were counted.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The data are summarized in Table 1.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Although the first litter did not show significant difference between COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  females, the second and third litter from the COUP-TFII +/ to  females showed a significant decrease in litter size in contrast to the slight increase in COUP-TFII +/+ control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	46	 This result indicates that the heterozygous females exhibit abnormal fertility with increase in age.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Overall Reproductive Performance of COUP-TFII Heterozygous Female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	48	  Delayed Puberty and Growth Retardation and Abnormal Estrus Cycles in COUP-TFII +/ to  Female Mice To further ascertain the underlying cause of reduced fertility of COUP-TFII +/ to  females, we examined the timing of vaginal openings as an indication of onset of puberty.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The results of this analysis are shown in Table 2.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	50	 COUP-TFII +/ to  females exhibited slightly delayed vaginal opening at 30.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	51	6 d after birth, as compared with 27.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	52	9 d after birth in wild-type females (Table 2).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The delay in puberty may be a result of delayed growth of the COUP-TFII +/ to mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The postnatal growth of COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  pups nursed by COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  mothers was measured.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The results of this analysis are shown in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Significant growth retardation of COUP-TFII +/ to  was clearly shown in mutants as compared with the wild-type controls nursed by either COUP-TFII +/+ or COUP-TFII +/ to  mothers (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	57	 However, growth of COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  were both significantly lower when nursed by COUP-TFII +/ to  as compared with COUP-TFII +/+ moms.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Therefore, the growth retardation is a consequence of both the genotype of the pup, as well as the ability of the mother to nurture the development of the pup.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Delayed Onset of Puberty in COUP-TFII Heterozygous Female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	60	  View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Growth Retardation and Delayed Onset of Puberty in COUP-TFII Heterozygotes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	62	A, Gene dosage effect of COUP-TFII on postnatal growth rate was assessed by daily monitoring of body weight of progeny from wild-type male X heterozygote female (for wild-type or heterozygous pups nursed by heterozygous mother) or heterozygous female X wild-type female (for wild-type or heterozygous pups nursed by wild-type mother).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Normal growth was assumed in wild-type pups nursed by wild-type female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Significantly retarded growth rate was seen in heterozygous pups nursed by wild-type mother, but better than wild-type pups nursed by heterozygous mother.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Most severe growth defect was seen in heterozygous pups nursed by heterozygous mother.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	66	 B, Estrus cyclicity was assessed by daily inspection of vaginal smear of 20-wk-old virgin females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Wild-type female shows regular cyclicity, but heterozygous female showed irregular estrus cycles.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	68	 P, Proestrus; E, estrus; M, metestrus; D, diestrus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	69	  In the analysis of the fecundity of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice, the ability of the females to have normal reproductive cycles were monitored by recording the estrus cycles of 3-month-old females through daily inspection of vaginal smears.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The diagnostic difference was facilitated by modified Papanicolou staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	71	 A representative estrus cycle was schematized in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	72	 COUP-TFII +/+ females showed regular cyclicity, whereas COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice showed prolonged diestrus or metestrus, or lack of obvious estrus phase.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Thus, estrus cycles of female heterozygote were found to be irregular.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	74	To ensure the expression of COUP-TFII expression is reduced in the heterozygote, we isolated protein extracts from ovariectomized wild-type and COUP-TFII+/ to  uteri and performed Western blot analysis using COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Figure 2 shows that the expression of COUP-TFII is greatly reduced in comparison to the control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The bar graph indicates that the expression levels of COUP-TFII are reduced approximately 2-fold in COUP-TFII+/ to  mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Similar level of reduction in COUP-TFII expression was also shown in the ovaries of COUP-TFII +/ to  in comparison to the controls (data not shown).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The above results indicate that COUP-TFII expression correlates with the loss a single allele in the COUP-TFII+/ to  mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	79	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Western Blot Analysis of COUP-TFII Expression Level in the Uteri of COUP-TF Heterozygous and Wild-Type Mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	81	A, Representative data of COUP-TFII and ss-actin expression in the uterus of wild-type and COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice 2 wk after ovariectomized are shown.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	82	 B, COUP-TFII expression level was normalized by ss-actin.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Bar height represents the ratio of COUP-TFII heterozygote to control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	84	 COUP-TFII expression was reduced to about half in COUP-TFII +/ to  mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	85	  Expression of COUP-TFII in Female Reproductive Axis The above analysis demonstrates that COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice shows abnormal reproductive cycles and delayed puberty.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Part of this phenotype may be due to expression of COUP-TFII in the uterus because previous analysis has shown COUP-TFII is expressed in the adult female endometrium (8).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	87	 However, to determine where else COUP-TFII may be acting, the expression of COUP-TFII in the female reproductive axis was assessed.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	88	 This was accomplished using a genetically engineered mouse in which the LacZ reporter had been knocked into the COUP-TFII gene (9).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	89	 This mouse allows for the rapid and sensitive assay of the expression pattern of COUP-TFII.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Histological sections from hypothalamus, pituitaries, ovaries, and uteri from COUP-TFII-LacZ mice were analyzed by X-gal staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The results of this analysis are shown in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	92	 COUP-TFII expression, as seen by X-gal staining, was found in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	93	 3A), whereas no specific staining was detected in the pituitary gland (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	94	 In the adult ovary, strong staining was found in the theca cells, the layer surrounding the granulosa cells of ovarian follicles, but not detected in the granulosa cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Weaker staining was detected in mesenchymal cells surrounding the corpus luteum (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	96	 To ensure that the X-gal staining faithfully recapitulated the endogenous COUP-TFII expression, we used COUP-TFII-specific antibody in immunostaining to assess the expression of COUP-TFII in the ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Again, strong staining was found in the theca cells, weak staining in the corpus luteum, and no detectable staining in the granulosa cells (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The patterns of COUP-TFII expression using immunostaining are virtually identical with that shown using X-gal staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Thus, X-gal staining could be used as an alternative assays to assess endogenous COUP-TFII expression patterns.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (130K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Expression of COUP-TFII in Female Reproductive Tract.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	102	Expression of COUP-TFII in female reproductive tract was assessed with LacZ knock-in mice or assessed by immuohistochemical staining using COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Cryosections of various tissues from LacZ knock-in female mice were stained for LacZ expression as described in Materials and Methods.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	104	 A, Coronal section of 3-wk-old female brain showed specific staining in VMH.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	105	 B, Mid-sagittal section of embryonic d 14.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	106	5 embryo brain showing abundant expression in hypothalamus (H) and mesenchyme surrounding pituitary gland, but not in pituitary gland (Pit).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	107	 C, Ovary from 8-wk-old randomly cycling female showing strong expression in theca cell surrounding follicles.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Note, no specific staining in corpus luteum (CL) and granulosa cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	109	 D, Endogenous expression pattern of COUP-TFII was examined by immunohistochemical staining using COUP-TFII-specific antibody and ovarian section of 8-wk-old female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	110	 COUP-TFII was highly expressed in theca cells surrounding follicles, weakly expressed in corpus luteum, but no staining was detected in granulosa cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	111	 E, Sagittal section of uterus from 8-wk-old randomly cycling female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	112	 High expression in both longitudinal and circular smooth muscle cells was evident, and scattered staining was seen in endometrial stromal cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Glandular and luminal epithelial cells also showed weak staining.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	114	 AM, Antimesometrium; Mes, mesometrium; arrowheads, luminal epithelium; arrows, glandular epithelial cells; smc, smooth muscle cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	115	 F, Antimesometrial portion of gestational d 8 deciduas shows strong nuclear staining of decidualized cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	116	  In the uterus of randomly cycling females, strong staining was evident in the myometrium, weaker staining was seen in endometrial stromal cells, and very weak positive staining was shown in glandular and luminal epithelial cells (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	117	 There was no significant difference in COUP-TFII expression between mesometrium and anti-mesometrium portions of the uterus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	118	 COUP-TFII expression was assessed by LacZ activity during decidualization using gestational d 8 uteri, and the decidualized cells in antimesometrium stained strongly positive (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	119	Because uterine gene expression is regulated by steroid hormones, we also examined the effects of exogenous steroid hormones and exogenous gonadotropins on COUP-TFII expression in the uterine endometrium (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	120	 In ovariectomized females, COUP-TFII expression was high in endometrial stroma (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	121	 4A), whereas treatment with 17ss-estradiol (E2) for 48 h drastically reduced COUP-TFII expression (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Treatment with P4 prevented the reduction of COUP-TFII expression by E2 in the endometrial stroma (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Note that COUP-TFII expression in the myometrium was not obviously altered by exogenous steroid treatment.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The expression of COUP-TFII after E2 and P4 treatment was similar to that observed in the nonpregnant uterine horn of a gestational d 10 pregnant female mouse (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	125	 We also examined COUP-TFII expression after the administration of exogenous gonadotropins (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Twenty-four hours after pregnant mare s serum gonadotropin (PMSG) injection, COUP-TFII expression in endometrial stroma was obviously decreased (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	127	 4E), whereas 48 h after PMSG injection, COUP-TFII expression in the endometrium recovered partially (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	128	 A further increase of COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma was found 24 and 48 h after human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) injection (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	129	View larger version (138K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Hormonal Regulation of COUP-TFII Expression in Endometrial Stroma.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	131	Effect of steroid hormones on expression of COUP-TFII in endometrial stroma was examined using ovariectomized LacZ knock-in mice of COUP-TFII.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Effect of gonadotropins (PMSG and hCG), that alter endogenous ovarian steroids, were also examined using intact LacZ knock-in mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	133	 A, COUP-TFII was highly expressed in the endometrial stroma of ovariectomized mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	134	 B, Expression of COUP-TFII was drastically reduced in the endometrial stroma after E2 treatment for 48 h.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	135	 C, Expression of COUP-TFII was restored partially in the endometrial stroma after P4 treatment in addition to E2 for 48 h.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	136	 D, COUP-TFII expression in nonpregnant horn of gestational d 10 female.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	137	 E, Expression of COUP-TFII was low at 24 h after PMSG.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	138	 F, Expression of COUP-TFII increased at 48 h after PMSG.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	139	 G, Expression of COUP-TFII became high at 24 h after hCG.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	140	 H, Expression of COUP-TFII further increased at 48 h after hCG.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	141	 L, Lumen; S, endometrial stroma; g, endometrial glands.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	142	 I, Expression of COUP-TFII was examined by immunohistochemical staining in wild-type uterus 2 wk after ovariectomy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	143	 COUP-TFII was highly expressed in endometrial stroma and myometrium but very low in grandular and luminal epithelial cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	144	  The expression pattern of COUP-TFII in the uteri was further confirmed by immunostaining using COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Strong staining was found in endometrial stromal cells as well as myometrium, whereas weaker staining was seen in glandular and luminal epithelial cells of the ovariectomized COUP-TFII+/ to  uteri (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The endogenous COUP-TFII expression patterns are indistinguishable from the X-gal expression pattern shown in Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	147	Normal Ovarian Function but Reduced Progesterone Levels Are Found in COUP-TFII +/ to  Females The above analysis determined that COUP-TFII is expressed in the hypothalamus, ovary, and uterus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Therefore, the reduction in fertility in the COUP-TFII +/ to  may be due to deficiencies in any of these three organs.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	149	 To determine whether the cause of the reduced fertilely may be due to a reduction in ovarian function, ovarian function was assayed by determining the ability of the ovaries to respond to a superovulatory regimen of hormones and determining the number of oocytes ovulated, as well as the production of progesterone after superovulation, as well as during pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The results of this analysis are shown in Tables 3 and 4, respectively.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	151	 There was no significant difference between COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ in the number of oocytes ovulated in response to gonadotropins.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Although the ability of the COUP-TFII +/ to  mice to ovulate is normal, perturbation in the level of progesterone, P4, production may contribute to the reduced fertility.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	153	 As shown in Table 4, P4 levels were significantly decreased in COUP-TFII +/ to  females subsequent to exogenous hCG stimulation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Measurement of P4 and pregnenolone (P5) levels in pregnant (gestational d 15) females, were shown to be lower in heterozygous females, although statistically not significant.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Therefore, the ovaries of COUP-TFII +/ to females are able to undergo normal ovulation, but the reduction in fertility may be due to impairment of the corpus luteum of COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse ovaries to produce P4 in early pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Normal Ovulation in Response to Exogenous Gonadotropins.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Circulating Ovarian Steroids in COUP-TFII Heterozygous Females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	158	  Reduction of Expression Levels of Steroidogenic Components Critical to P4 Synthesis We showed that the predominant site of expression of COUP-TFII in the ovary is the theca interna, but not in the granulosa cells.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Theca cells are responsible for synthesizing precursor C19 steroids in the preovulatory follicle in response to LH, and granulosa cells aromatize the precursor steroids in vivo under the regulation of FSH (10).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In the corpus luteum, however, large luteal cells that are believed to be derived from the granulosa cells are capable of synthesizing P4 from circulating low-density lipoprotein (LDL) (10).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Thus, vascularization of corpus luteum upon ovulation is considered to be important to supply the luteal cells with the substrates to synthesize P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	162	Considering the importance of COUP-TFII in angiogenesis (7), we conducted microscopic examination of COUP-TFII+/ to  and wild-type super ovulated ovaries to determine whether vascularization is perturbed.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Although no obvious microscopic abnormality could be detected in the COUP-TFII+/ to  ovaries, we noted the lumen of vessels in COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries is not as dilated as the COUP-TFII +/+ control, suggesting that COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries might not be well supplied with blood (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	164	 We then used an endothelial-specific marker, platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM), in immunostaining to examine the vessel more closely.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	165	 A considerable reduction in CD31 (PECAM-1)-positive stained vessels was seen in the COUP-TFII +/ to  corpus luteum (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	166	 5, B and C), suggesting that vascularization is compromised in COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	167	 This could contribute at least partly to the reduction of observable progesterone levels in super ovulated COUP-TF +/ to  female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	168	View larger version (49K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Defective Vascularization of Corpus Luteum and Reduced Expression of Cyp11a1, Hsd3b1, and StAR in COUP-TFII +/ to  ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	170	A to C, Microscopic evaluation of vascularization in superovulated COUP-TFII heterozygous and wild-type ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Dilated vessels were not seen in COUP-TFII heterozygous ovaries.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	172	 B, Vascularization as assessed by immunofluorescent signal using CD31 (PECAM-1-specific antibody).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Reduced vascularization was seen in COUP-TFII +/ to  corpus luteum.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	174	 C, Nuclear staining with DAPI on the same slide as B.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	175	 D, The mRNA for COUP-TFII, CYP11a1, HSD3b1 and StAR were quantified with TaqMan-based RT-PCR.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	176	 All mRNA quantities were normalized against 18S RNA using ABI rRNA control reagents.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	177	 All experiments were performed in triplicate and verified with a duplicate set of mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Means for mRNA expression between WT and COUP-TFII +/ to  mice were compared using a Student s t test, and the P values are present in the figure.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	179	  The impaired steroid production in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice could also be due to alteration in the expression levels of steroidogenic components critical for P4 biosynthesis.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The impact of COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency on the expression levels of genes involved in steroid hormone biosynthesis in the ovaries of COUP-TFII+/ to  and wild-type ovaries administered a superovulatory regimen of gonadotropin was assayed by quantitative RT-PCR assays.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	181	 As a control, we first examined the mRNA expression levels of COUP-TFII and showed that COUP-TFII mRNA level was reduced to 30% in the heterozygote in compared with the wild-type controls (Fig 5D).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Similarly, a significant reduction (40%) of cytochrome P450, family 11, subfamily a, polypeptide 1 (Cyp11a1), mRNA levels was detected (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In addition, steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (StAR), hydroxy--5-steroid dehydrogenase, 3ss- and steroid -isomerase 1 (Hsd3b1) mRNA levels were also greatly reduced in COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice to less than 30% of the controls (Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The reduction of mRNA expression of all these components important for P4 biosynthesis will no doubt also contribute to the observed reduction of P4 levels in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	185	Defective Uterine Function in COUP-TFII +/ to  Females COUP-TFII is expressed in the endometrium of the uterus, as well as the endometrial decidual cells during pregnancy (Figs.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	186	 A defect in the ability of the endometrium to undergo decidualization may greatly affect reproductive performance.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	187	 To assay the ability of the uterus to undergo decidualization, independent of hypothalamus and ovarian function, COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ mice were challenged with artificial decidual stimulus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This stimulus consisted of administering a mechanical trauma, a burred needle scratch, to the uterus of ovariectomized mice treated with exogenous E2 and P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	189	 In each animal, the left horn was given the mechanical trauma after hormonal treatment, whereas the right horn was not traumatized and could serve as a control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	190	 After the experiments, wet weight of each horn was determined and the ratio of scratched vs.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	191	 6, uterus from COUP-TFII +/ to  female mice exhibited significantly reduced decidual cell reaction when compared with COUP-TFII +/+ mouse uteri.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	192	 This above analysis indicates that the reduced fertility in COUP-TFII +/ to  mice may be in part due to a reduced ability of the endometrial stroma to undergo the necessary differentiation to support embryo implantation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	193	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Reduced Decidual Cell Reaction in COUP-TFII Heterozygote.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	195	Decidual cell reaction was induced by traumatizing left uterine horn (L) after hormonal treatment of ovariectomized wild-type or heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Right horn (R) was left intact for control.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	197	 A, Typical deciduoma formation in the left uterine horn of wild-type female is shown on the top panel, whereas limited decidual cell reaction was seen in the left uterine horn of heterozygous female shown in the bottom panel.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	198	 B, Wet weight of left horn and right horn from each animal was weighted and ratio between left stimulated horn and right control horn (L/R ratio) were calculated.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	199	 There was significant decrease (P = 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	200	018) in L/R ratio for COUP-TFII heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	201	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The above data demonstrate that ablation of one allele of COUP-TFII significantly impacts the reproductive performance of female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	202	 This altered reproductive performance is seen as a delay in puberty and an age-dependent reduction in litter size.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Haploinsufficient phenotypes are rarely reported or result in subtle phenotypes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This phenomenon usually results if the gene in question is subject to imprinting or holds a rate limiting step in a pivotal pathway.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The above COUP-TFII haploinsufficient phenotype is independent of the parent transmitting the mutant allele (data not shown).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Therefore, imprinting of the COUP-TFII allele is not the cause of this phenotype.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The expression level of COUP-TFII is reduced to about half as measured by Western blot analysis, corresponding to a loss of a single allele in the COUP-TFII+/ to .
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The reduction of COUP-TFII expression could affect the function of the reproductive axis.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Because female reproduction is regulated by interactions in the endocrine system at the level of the hypothalamus, pituitary, ovary and uterus and expression of COUP-TFII was found in hypothalamus (VMH), theca cells, and the uterine endometrial stroma, it is not surprising that haploinsufficiency reproductive phenotype is seen in COUP-TFII heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	210	There is abundant expression of COUP-TFII in the VMH of the central nervous system.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Although the significance of VMH expression is not clear, several of the observed haploinsufficiency phenotypes (e.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	212	 growth retardation and delayed puberty) are consistent with the idea that the COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse may suffer from mild hypopituitarism.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	213	 However, there was no significant decrease in IGF-I in heterozygotes (data not shown), which is indicative of other potential growth perturbation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	214	 COUP-TFII has been implicated to interfere with the function of the orphan nuclear receptor steroidogenic factor 1 (SF1) (11).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	215	 SF1 null mice resulted in defective development of VMH (12).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Rescue experiments using SF1 null mutants indicated SF1 functions in VMH to regulate late onset obesity (13).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Thus, it might be interesting to speculate that COUP-TFII and SF1 reciprocally regulate growth in VMH.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Future specific deletion of COUP-TFII could elucidate this aspect of COUP-TFII function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	219	Although the role of COUP-TFII in the VMH is speculative, the role of COUP-TFII in the ovary was investigated.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	220	 COUP-TFII mice did not demonstrate impairment in ovulation but did show impairment in the ability of P4 production.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The reduced capability to synthesize P4 in response to exogenous gonadotropin suggests potential defects in the ovarian function of COUP-TFII +/ to .
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Theca cells in the ovaries are responsible for synthesizing precursor C19 steroids in the preovulatory follicle in response to LH, and granulosa cells aromatize the precursor steroids in vivo under the regulation of FSH (11).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In the corpus luteum, however, large luteal cells that are believed to be derived from the granulosa cells are capable of synthesizing P4 from circulating LDL (11).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Thus, vascularization of corpus luteum upon ovulation is considered to be important to supply the luteal cells with the substrates to synthesize P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The high expression of COUP-TFII in the theca cells, but not in granulosa cells, suggests COUP-TFII might be involved in a steroidogenic pathway, or it might have a significant role during vascularization of the corpus luteum.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Here, we showed that vascularization as measured by PECAM immunostaining is perturbed in COUP-TFII +/ to  mice as compared with the controls.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	227	 This might lead to inefficient delivery of LDL to the large luteal cells resulting in the reduced ability of the corpus luteum to synthesize P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	228	 In addition, we also show that the expression levels of mRNA of CYP11a1, HSD3b1, and StAR are significantly reduced in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	229	 All of these genes are important for the biosynthesis of P4.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Thus, the reduction in the expression of these genes will directly contribute to the observable reduced P4 levels in the COUP-TFII+/ to  female mice, and the decrease in circulating P4 in pregnant COUP-TFII +/ to  females might result in the reduced ability of the uterus to support pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	231	The reduced levels of P4 in early pregnancy may impact on COUP-TFII expression in the uterus during early pregnancy.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Analysis of the expression of COUP-TFII in the uterus shows that E2 treatment caused drastic decrease of COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma, whereas P4 treatment with E2 attenuates E2 action, restoring COUP-TFII expression in the stroma.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	233	 COUP-TFII expression was low after treatment with PMSG, which induces ovarian E2 synthesis, and COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma increased expression after hCG, which induces ovarian P4, are consistent with steroid hormone regulation in hormone-treated ovariectomized females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The lower levels of P4 in the COUP-TFII +/ to  mouse combined with the loss of one COUP-TFII allele in the uterine stromal cell may be the partial cause of the haploinsufficient decrease in uterine function in these mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	235	 However, reduced uterine stromal cell function was still observed after exogenous administration of P4 indicating that part of the haploinsufficient phenotype is specific to the uterus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	236	During implantation, the endometrial stromal cells undergo a series of complex processes called decidualization (14, 15).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The process of decidualization involves concurrent cell proliferation, differentiation, as well as angiogenesis.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Based on our findings, it is evident that uterine function is significantly affected in COUP-TFII heterozygous females.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The relatively high expression of COUP-TFII in endometrial stromal cells, the steroid regulation of COUP-TFII expression in the endometrial stroma, and the reduced decidual cell reaction all support this notion.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Identification of the role of COUP-TFII in the process of decidualization may be discerned from the analysis of what other genes have been shown to regulate this process.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	241	Several targeted null mutant mice, including progesterone receptor (PR) (16), Hoxa-10 (17), and 11 (18) exhibited defects in decidual cell reaction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Consistent with the notion that P4 is required for decidualization in human endometrium, decidual cell reaction was absent in PRKO female mice (16).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	243	 One of the potential key genes that are regulated by P4 is Indian hedgehog (IHH) (8), a well-known morphogen.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Hedgehog signaling is known to regulate cell proliferation and differentiation during embryonic development (19).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The fact that IHH is expressed at preimplantation endometrial epithelial cells and its expression is rapidly induced by P4 (8) further implicates its role in mediating PR function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Importantly, it has been demonstrated that COUP-TFII is regulated by hedgehog signaling (20).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	247	 One of the intriguing possibilities is that P4 regulates IHH in the luminal epithelium, priming stroma cells for decidualization.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	248	 COUP-TFII, a downstream target of IHH could mediate IHH signaling in the endometrium during periimplantation (8).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Importantly, both IHH and COUP-TFII had been implicated in angiogenesis (7, 21).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	250	 It is our speculation that during artificially induced decidualization or repeated remodeling of endometrium after first conception, normal vascularization is moderately, but functionally significantly affected by COUP-TFII.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	251	Taken together, phenotypic analysis using the haploinsufficiency model of COUP-TFII indicated several functions of this gene in the female reproductive tract.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Combination of those haploinsufficiency phenotypes throughout the female reproductive axis might additively affect female reproductive function.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Although use of this model might be limited for overall phenotypic analysis, it, perhaps, could reveal the global impact of a gene dosage effect (as in human genetic conditions) on female reproduction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	254	 We propose that COUP-TFII plays an important role in the endometrial stroma during the periimplantation period.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Detailed molecular and cellular mechanisms could be elucidated by conditional gene targeting approaches, such as using endometrial-specific Cre recombinase.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	256	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Animals and Phenotypic Analysis Targeted null mutants of COUP-TFII were generated as described previously (7).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The COUP-TFII-LacZ knock-in mice were generated by homologous recombination in ES cells and described previously (9).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	258	 These mice were maintained as a mixed genetic background (129S6/C57B6) under the care of the Center for Comparative Medicine at Baylor College of Medicine according to the institutional guidelines for the care and use of laboratory animals.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Mating pairs of COUP-TFII +/+ male crossed with COUP-TFII +/+ females or COUP-TFII +/ to  females (12 wk old) were continuously mated in a cage for 3 months, and numbers of newborn at birth were counted.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Postnatal growth was assessed by weighing pups from the above matings from postnatal d 1 to 21 daily, then weaned on d 21 and genotyped by PCR of tail DNA (7).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The estrus cycle of 20-wk-old females (three wild-type and 10 heterozygous females) was monitored by daily inspection of vaginal smears (22).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Vaginal openings were recorded by daily inspection from postnatal d 14 until natural opening was observed.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Circulating P4 levels were analyzed by RIA at the laboratory of Dr.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	264	 David Hess (Oregon Health Science University, Portland, OR).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	265	LacZ Staining LacZ staining of various tissues from LacZ knock-in mice were performed as described previously (23).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Tissues from heterozygous for COUP-TFII-LacZ knock-in were dissected and fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde for 30 min at room temperature.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	267	 After washing in PBS, embryos were cryopreserved in 30% sucrose, and then embedded in OCT compound (Sakura Finetek USA, Torrance, CA).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Cryostat sections (20  microm) were incubated at room temperature for 2 h with staining solution containing 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	269	02% Nonidet P-40, 5 mM potassium ferricyanide, 5 mM potassium ferrocyanide, and 1 mg/ml X-gal.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Sections were counterstained with Eosin Y (Sigma, St.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Nuclear localization signal used for LacZ localization in the nucleus facilitated identification of specific staining in all the tissues except for neural tissues, and control sections from wild-type mice did not show any specific staining with the condition used in this study.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	272	Superovulation, Artificial Decidual Cell Reaction, and Steroid Hormone Induction Superovulation was achieved by treating 21-d-old female virgin mice with PMSG (5 IU, ip) (Sigma) followed 48 h later with hCG (5 IU, ip) (Sigma).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The mice were euthanized and ova were harvested from the oviducts 24 h after hCG administration.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Induction of the artificial decidual cell reaction was induced as described previously (16).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Briefly, 8-wk-old COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ females were ovariectomized on d 0, treated with E2 (0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	276	1  microg per mouse per day) from d 10 to 12, and treated with P4 (1 mg per mouse per day) and E2 (6.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	277	7 ng per mouse per day) from d 16 to 23.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Mechanical decidualization in the left uterine horn was performed 6 h after hormone injection on d 18.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	279	 The whole uterus was dissected 6 h after hormone injection on d 23.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	280	 The ratio of the weights of the stimulated to the unstimulated (control) horns was calculated.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Steroid hormone regulation of COUP-TFII in the mouse uterus was analyzed by administering steroid hormones to COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ female mice as follows.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Hormone treatment was conducted on 6-wk-old COUP-TFII +/ to  and COUP-TFII +/+ female mice after bilateral ovariectomy 2 wk before the commencement of the hormone treatment.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Mice were then treated with E2, 5 ng sc, P4 1 mg, sc, or 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Animals were anesthetized with Avertin (2,2,2-tribromoethyl alcohol; Sigma) and killed by cervical dislocation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	285	Immunohistochemical Staining Tissues from COUP-TFII +/+ and COUP-TFII +/ to  mice were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 1 h at 4 C, cryopreserved in 30% sucrose, then embedded in OCT compound (Sakura Finetek USA).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Cryostat sections (7  microm) were incubated in blocking buffer [PBS, 1% BSA, 5% normal donkey serum, 10  microg of Fab fragment donkey antimouse IgG (heavy and light chains) per ml, 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	287	02% Triton X-100] for 1 h at room temperature followed by incubation with the primary antibody [monoclonal anti-COUP-TFII (1:100,000)] overnight at 4 C.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	288	 After incubation with primary antibody, slides were incubated with biotin-SP-conjugated donkey antimouse IgG (heavy and light chains; Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories) for 1 h at room temperature, then with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated strepavidin (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) for 1 h at room temperature.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Signals were visualized using DAB Kit (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA) and counterstained with hematoxylin.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	290	 For immunofluorescence, cryosections were incubated with biotin-conjugated polyclonal rat anti-CD31 (PECAM-1) antibody (BD Biosciences Pharmingen, San Diego, CA) [1:1000] for 2 h and signals were developed using TSA kit no.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	291	 22 (Molecular Probes) in accordance with the manufacturer s instruction.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	292	Western Blot Analysis Isolated tissues were homogenized in buffer composed of 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	293	25 M sucrose, 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	294	5), 25 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 0.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	295	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Protein concentrations were determined by the BCA protein assay system (Pierce, Rockford, IL).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Ten micrograms of protein were mixed with 2x Laemmli Sample Buffer (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) and separated on 7.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	298	5% polyacrylamide gels, then electroblotted onto nitrocellulose membranes.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Membranes were incubated with the primary antibody followed by incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated antimouse IgG antibody.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Signals were visualized with ECL plus Western Blotting Detection System (Amersham Biosciences, Amersham, Buckinghamshire, UK).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Intensities of the bands were analyzed with National Institutes of Health Image software and normalized by ss-actin expression level.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	302	Quantitative RT-PCR Assays Total mRNA was isolated from snap frozen superovulated ovarian samples using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) according to manufacturer s instructions.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The mRNA for genes of interest were quantitated with TaqMan-based RT-PCR using the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	304	 RT-PCRs were performed using One-step RT-PCR Universal Master Mix reagent and TaqMan Gene Expression Assays (Applied Biosystems) according to the manufacturer s instructions.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Cycling conditions were 95 C for 1 min, followed by 40 cycles at 95 C for 15 sec and 60 C for 1 min.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	306	 All mRNA quantities were normalized against 18S RNA using ABI rRNA control reagents.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The TaqMan Gene Expression Assays used include: Mm00490735_m1 (Cyp11a1); Mm00441558_m1 (StAR); Mm00476184_g1 (Hsd3b1); Mm00772789_m1 (Nr2f2, COUP-TFII), and Eukaryotic 18S rRNA (4319413E).
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	308	 All experiments were performed in triplicate and verified with a duplicate set of mice.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Means for mRNA expression between WT and COUP-TFII +/ to  mice were compared using a Student s t test.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	310	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Wei Qian, Chen Liu, and Grace Chen for excellent technical help.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	311	   FOOTNOTES   This work was supported by National Institutes of Health Grants DK55636 (to S.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	312	), and U01DK62434 (Functional Atlas) (to S.

0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Mol Endocrinol 16:2338 to 2348[Abstract/Free Full Text] Lee CT, Li R, Takamoto N, Martin JF, DeMayo FJ, Tsai M-J, Tsai SY 2004 The nuclear orphan receptor COUP-TFII is required for limb and skeletal muscle development.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Mol Cell Biol 24:10835 to 10843[Abstract/Free Full Text] Richards JS 1994 Hormonal control of gene expression in the ovary.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Endocr Rev 15:725 to 751[CrossRef][Medline] Zeitoun K, Takayama K, Michael MD, Bulun SE 1999 Stimulation of aromatase P450 promoter (II) activity in endometriosis and its inhibition in endometrium are regulated by competitive binding of steroidogenic factor-1 and chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor to the same cis-acting element.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Mol Endocrinol 13:239 to 253[Abstract/Free Full Text] Ikeda Y, Luo X, Abbud R, Nilson JH, Parker KL 1995 The nuclear receptor steroidogenic factor 1 is essential for the formation of the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Mol Endocrinol 9:478 to 486[Abstract] Majdic G, Young M, Gomez-Sanchez E, Anderson P, Szczepaniak LS, Dobbins RL, McGarry JD, Parker KL 2002 Knockout mice lacking steroidogenic factor 1 are a novel genetic model of hypothalamic obesity.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Endocrinology 143:607 to 614[Abstract/Free Full Text] Christian M, Mak I, White JO, Brosens JJ 2002 Mechanisms of decidualization.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Reprod Biomed Online (4 Suppl 3):24 to 30 Dunn CL, Kelly RW, Critchley HO 2003 Decidualization of the human endometrial stromal cell: an enigmatic transformation.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Reprod Biomed Online 7:151 to 161[Medline] Lydon JP, DeMayo FJ, Funk CR, Mani SK, Hughes AR, Montgomery Jr CA, Shyamala G, Conneely OM, O Malley BW 1995 Mice lacking progesterone receptor exhibit pleiotropic reproductive abnormalities.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Genes Dev 9:2266 to 2278[Abstract] Benson GV, Lim H, Paria BC, Satokata I, Dey SK, Maas RL 1996 Mechanisms of reduced fertility in Hoxa-10 mutant mice: uterine homeosis and loss of maternal Hoxa-10 expression.
0.2717503.15890675.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Development 122:2687 to 2696[Abstract/Free Full Text] Gendron RL, Paradis H, Hsieh-Li HM, Lee DW, Potter SS, Markoff E 1997 Abnormal uterine stromal and glandular function associated with maternal reproductive defects in Hoxa-11 null mice.
