0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	382	 15, 1747 to 1758[Abstract] Duong, D.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	383	 277, 32234 to 32242[Abstract/Free Full Text] Brummelkamp, T.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	384	 (2002) Science 296, 550 to 553[Abstract/Free Full Text] Pitot, H.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	385	 276, 39885 to 39891[Abstract/Free Full Text] Chen, J.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	386	 (1995) Nature 377, 454 to 457[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Schulman, I.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	387	 16, 3807 to 3813[Abstract] Deleted in proof Granner, D.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	388	 (1983) Nature 305, 545 to 549[Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Blanco, J.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	389	 12, 1638 to 1651[Abstract/Free Full Text] Scribner, K.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	390	 133, 4112 to 4117[Abstract/Free Full Text] Kung, A.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	391	 14, 272 to 277[Abstract/Free Full Text] Ugai, H.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	392	 77, 481 to 494[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Veitia, R.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	393	 78, 149 to 170[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Yie, J.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	394	 18, 3074 to 3089[Abstract/Free Full Text] Ganss, R.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	395	 8, 895 to 903[Abstract] Schweizer, M.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	396	 30, 1070 to 1072[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Yamada, K.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	397	 337, 1 to 11[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Goswami, R.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	398	 (1994) Endocrinology 134, 736 to 743[Abstract] Suwanichkul, A.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	399	 269, 30835 to 30841[Abstract/Free Full Text] Vander Kooi, B.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	400	 278, 11782 to 11793[Abstract/Free Full Text] Herzog, B.
0.21842672.15166231.html.plaintext.txt	401	 18, 807 to 819[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	0	The activation function 2 domain of hepatic nuclear factor 4 is regulated by a short C-terminal proline-rich repressor domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	1	Chemical Pathology Unit, Sir William Dunn School of Pathology, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3RE, UK.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received January 26, 1998; Revised and Accepted March 19, 1998.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	3	Hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is a transcription factor whose expression is crucial for mouse embryonic development, for liver-specific gene expression and for the prevention of one form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Its domain structure has been defined previously and is similar to other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	5	 A repressor domain has now been localised to a region of 14 amino acids (residues 428-441) near the C-terminus of HNF4 and is sufficient by itself to repress the activity of the activation function 2 (AF2) domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Multiple mutations within this repressor domain enhance activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Interestingly, this repressor domain shares homology with a repressor domain in the progesterone receptor.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In a detailed mutagenesis study of the AF2 core, we demonstrate that L 366, which is conserved in the AF2 core between HNF4 and a number of orphan nuclear receptors, is essential for the full activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Furthermore, a double mutation of E 363 and L 366 suggests that these residues might act in a cooperative manner.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	10	Hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) was first isolated as a protein involved in regulating a number of liver-specific genes (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	11	 It shares amino acid sequence homology with the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Since no ligand has yet been found for HNF4, it is classified as an orphan nuclear receptor.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	13	Extensive work carried out on nuclear receptors (e.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	14	 oestrogen and retinoic acid receptors) has shown that they have a modular structure, with distinct regions carrying out specific functions (2).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The N-terminal region (A/B) contains an activation function 1 (AF1) whose activity can be cell-type as well as promoter-context specific (3).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	16	 A highly conserved zinc finger domain, required for DNA binding, is present in region C, with region D acting as a hinge (2).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The C-terminal half of these receptors contains a long hydrophobic domain (region E), which encodes various functions.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	18	 These include receptor dimerisation, ligand binding and a ligand-dependent activation function 2 (AF2) (2).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The AF2 domain contains a core region of seven amino acids [Phi][Phi][KHgr]a[Phi][Phi]a/L (where `[Phi]' is a hydrophobic residue, `[KHgr]' any residue, `a' an acidic residue and L = leucine) which is critical for activation and is conserved in many nuclear receptors (4).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The extreme C-terminal region of these receptors (region F) varies in length between receptors and its function is unknown.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In HNF4, this region is extended and contains a proline-rich domain (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	22	HNF4 is expressed in many tissues including liver, kidney, pancreas and intestine (1,5,10).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	23	 There are a number of isoforms generated by alternative splicing (5).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	24	 For example, the HNF4[alpha] gene in humans encodes three isoforms, [alpha]1, [alpha] 2 and [alpha]4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	25	 There is, in addition, a distinct [gamma] subtype encoded by the HNF4[gamma] gene (5).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The rat HNF4 isoforms 1-455 and 1-465 are equivalent to human [alpha]1 and [alpha]2 respectively (1,6).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In Xenopus laevis, HNF4 is encoded by two distinct ([alpha] and [beta]) genes (7).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	28	Deletion of HNF4 is embryonic lethal in mice, since it resulted in the induction of cell death in embryonic ectoderm and impairment of gastrulation of mouse embryos carrying a homozygous (-/-) knockout of the HNF4[alpha] gene (8).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In the regulation of the factor IX gene, point mutations which disrupt an HNF4 binding site result in haemophilia B (9,10).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Recently, heterozygotes carrying mutations in the HNF4[alpha] allele were linked to one form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY1) (11).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	31	 HNF4 is also involved in the regulation of a number of genes required for both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism as well as erythropoiesis (1,12).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These genes include apolipoprotein CIII, pyruvate kinase, [alpha]1-antitrypsin and erythropoietin.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	33	Previous work aimed at investigating the C-terminal activation domain of HNF4 in transcription showed that large deletions in the C-terminal region abolished transactivation (12,13).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	34	 HNF4 was also shown to interact with the basal transcription factor TFIIB (13).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Recent evidence has suggested that E363 and L366 of the AF2 core are important for the activity of the AF2 domain (14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	36	 However, this study was limited to single mutations at either position in the context of GAL4-HNF4 deletion fusion constructs (amino acids 128-370) which lacked other essential domains (the N-terminal AF1 domain, the DNA binding domain, and the repressor domain in the extended C-terminal region which is characterised in this report).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	37	In this report, we demonstrate by extensive mutagenesis in the context of both full-length HNF4 and full-length HNF4 fused to the GAL4 DNA binding domain that Leu 366 of the AF2 core is essential for full AF2 activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	38	 By investigating the effect of a double mutation involving both E363 and L366, we show that these residues may act cooperatively.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In addition, we have precisely mapped the location of a repressor domain (initially described in ref.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	40	 14 and postulated to lie between residues 371 and 455) to amino acids 428-441 and have defined amino acid residues within this domain which are required for its activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	41	MATERIALS AND METHODS Reporter plasmids and GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	42	Reporter plasmids pCAT4 and pAPF1-HIV-CAT (1,15) were used to determine the transactivation activities of GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs and native HNF4 constructs, respectively.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	43	 pCAT4 is a reporter plasmid with four GAL4 response elements, an inverted CCAAT box, and a TATA element controlling the CAT reporter gene in the pBluescript backbone; pAPF1-HIV-CAT contains two HNF4 response elements in a direct repeat, and the -57 to +80 of the HIV LTR controlling the CAT reporter gene.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	44	 To monitor transfection efficiency, the internal control plasmid pGLtkLUC (16) was used.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The plasmid pGAL4 1-147 (17) contains the DNA-binding domain (DBD) of the yeast GAL4 protein driven by the immediate-early human cytomegalovirus (CMV) promoter.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The GAL4-HNF4 full-length fusion constructs, and all C-terminal deletion constructs of HNF4 were constructed by PCR amplification of the appropriate fragment of HNF4 derived from the plasmid, pCB6HNF4 (16), using Pfu polymerase (Stratagene).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After purification of the PCR products, a BamHI/KpnI restriction digest was carried out, followed by an in-frame ligation with the GAL4-DBD using the BamHI/KpnI restriction sites in pGAL4 1-147.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	48	All GAL4-HNF4 full-length fusion proteins carrying a point mutation at E 363 or L 366, and the repressor domain mutants, were constructed by PCR-based mutagenesis using Pfu polymerase (Pritlove, unpublished data).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Native (as opposed to GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs) full-length HNF4 constructs with point mutations at E 363 or L 366 were constructed by removing the GAL4-DBD (GAL4 1-147) from the appropriate GAL4-HNF4 fusion construct by a HindIII/BamHI restriction digest.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The fusion construct GAL4-HNF4 1-372+428-441 was made by first amplifying the pGAL4-HNF4 1-372 fragment, followed by a ligation step to insert a double-stranded oligonucleotide of the repressor domain of HNF4 (residues 428-441).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The sequence of all constructs were verified by fluorescent dideoxy sequencing.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	52	Cell culture, transient transfections, enzymatic and gel mobility shift assays.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	53	HeLa and HepG2 cells were cultured using 60 mm dishes in minimal essential medium (MEM) supplemented with 10% foetal calf serum.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Transient transfections were carried out using the standard calcium-phosphate precipitation method (10).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Briefly, a total of 15  microg of DNA was transfected, consisting of 10  microg of the reporter plasmid, 2  microg of the expression plasmid, 2  microg of the internal control plasmid and 1  microg of salmon sperm DNA (Sigma).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Sixteen hours after transfection, the cells were washed twice with PBS and fresh medium added.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Cells were harvested 48 h post-transfection.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Luciferase assays were carried out according to the manufacturer using a luciferase assay kit (Promega) and quantitated using a Wallac LKB 1250 luminometer.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Chloramphenicol acetyl transferase assays were performed by standard methods (10) to determine the reporter activity of each construct.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	60	TLC plates were quantitated using a Storm phosphorimager and analysed using the Image Quant software.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Gel mobility shift assays were performed essentially as described (17) using a DNA probe containing a single GAL4 binding site, and the same HeLa cell extracts that were used to determine the relative transactivation activities of the constructs in Figure 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	62	P values were calculated using student's t-test when comparing the mean and standard deviation of mutants.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	63	 When comparing mutants with the full-length fusion protein or native wild-type full-length HNF4 protein, P values were calculated from z values.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	64	RESULTS Mapping the C-terminal activation function 2 (AF2) of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	65	Analysis of the amino acid sequence of rat HNF4 identified a consensus amino acid sequence ([Phi][Phi][KHgr]a[Phi][Phi]a/L, amino acid residues 360-366) found in a number of orphan and ligand nuclear receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	66	 This conserved sequence, known as the activation function 2 (AF2) core, is known to form an amphipathic [alpha]-helix required for ligand-dependent activation of nuclear receptors, e.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	67	 1) revealed that the Leu at position 366 (the last residue in the AF2 core) in HNF4 is conserved in a number of orphan receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	68	 1, underlined L), whereas an acidic residue (an E or D) is found at the corresponding position in a number of nuclear receptors with known ligands.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In addition, the extreme C-terminal region of HNF4, specifically amino acids 400-447, is rich in proline residues and was previously proposed to contain a proline-rich activation domain (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Alignment of the amino acid sequence around the activation function 2 (AF2) core of HNF4 from different species with a number of orphan nuclear receptors (above) and receptors with known ligands (below).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	71	 `[Phi]' represents a hydrophobic residue, `[KHgr]' any amino acid residue and `a' an acidic residue.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The invariant glutamic acid (E) conserved between all nuclear receptors with known ligands and HNF4 is highlighted in bold.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The leucine (L) conserved between HNF4 and a number of orphan nuclear receptors is underlined.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	74	laevis; d, Drosophila; h, human; m, mouse.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The definitions of the symbols, ARP1, EAR, COUP-TF1, Svp, TR, VDR, RAR, RXR and their accession numbers can be found in ref.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Mapping the C-terminal activation function 2 (AF2) of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	77	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL4 DBD, the full-length HNF4 fusion and HNF4 C-terminal deletion fusions from 366 to 455 at 15 amino acids intervals.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	78	 (B) Transactivation in HeLa (dotted histogram) and HepG2 (blank histogram) cells, relative to the full-length HNF4 fusion (which is set at 100% in all experiments).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The mean of three independent transfection experiments is shown,  plus or minus  standard deviation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In the context of GAL4-HNF4 fusion constructs, `F' is used to represent GAL4 1-147.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	81	 pCAT4 (see Materials and Methods) is a transfection control.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	82	In order to determine if the proline-rich region contained an activation domain, and establish the role of the conserved amino acid sequence between 360 and 366, GAL4-HNF4 fusion proteins were constructed with successive 15 amino acid deletions from the C-terminus of HNF4 up to residue 366 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Unexpectedly, deletions up to residue 381 produced fusion proteins with higher activities than the full-length fusion protein in both HeLa and HepG2 cells (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	84	 For example, the activity of deletion F 1-410 was three and half times that of the full-length fusion protein in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	85	 However, when amino acids 366-380 were deleted (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	86	 2B, F 1-365) the activity decreased to 12% of full-length fusion protein.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	87	 These results suggested there was a repressor domain spanning residues 380-455.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	88	 However, there was no evidence of a proline-rich activation domain between residues 400 and 447 as previously suggested (1).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The fact that transactivation was reduced to near background level when residues 366-380 were deleted suggested that Leu 366, conserved in a number of orphan receptors and the last residue in the consensus sequence [Phi][Phi][KHgr]a[Phi][Phi]a/L (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	90	 To exclude the possibility that the increased activities of the C-terminal deletion fusions was due to higher levels of protein expression in some constructs than others, a gel mobility shift assay was carried out as described in Materials and Methods.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	91	 As shown in Figure 3, gel shifted fusion complexes of all constructs were present in comparable amounts, with insufficient variation in yield to account for the difference in activity observed in Figure 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Thus, no further gel shift analysis of protein levels was carried out on further constructs in this report.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	93	 A gel mobility shift assay using HeLa cell extracts to determine the protein expression levels of the full-length and C-terminal deletion fusion constructs shown (except F 1-425) in Figure 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Lane 1, HeLa cell extract from cells transfected with the reporter (pCAT4) and internal control (pGLtkLUC) plasmids; lane 2, GAL 1-147; lane 3, F 1-455; lane 4, F 1-365; lane 5, F 1-380; lane 6, F 1-395; lane 7, F 1-410; lane 8, F 1-440.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The position of the gel shifted `fusion complexes' is shown, free probe and the position of a presumptive degradation products comigrating with the GAL4 1-147 (the DNA binding domain of GAL4) are indicated by arrows.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	96	To identify the critical residue(s) in the region between residues 359 and 380, fusion proteins with deletions at three amino acid intervals between residues 359 and 380 were constructed and tested in the transient transfection assay in HeLa cells (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Deleting amino acids 369-380 had no effect on the activity of the C-terminal activation domain (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	98	 4B, compare F 1-380 and F 1-368).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Deleting the next three amino acids, 366-368, resulted in a significant decrease in activity to background level (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Two further deletions, F 1-362 and F 1-359, also had background activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	101	 We conclude that the region between amino acids 365 and 368 is critical for transactivation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Leu (L) 366 is the last amino acid residue in the proposed amphipathic [alpha]-helix formed by the AF2 core (Fig, 1; 18) and thus may be an important residue.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Determining the critical amino acid residues in the AF2 core of HNF4 in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	104	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL4 DBD, the full-length HNF4 fusion and C-terminal deletion fusions from 359 to 380 at three amino acid intervals.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Intermediate constructs between 368 and 380 are not shown since the activities of these constructs were not significantly different to fusion F 1-368 (results not shown).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	106	 (B) Transactivation relative to the full-length HNF4 fusion set at 100% (see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	107	To investigate the significance of L366 in more detail, point mutations of L 366 to A, D, Q and I were made both in the context of GAL4-DBD full-length HNF4 fusion proteins (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	108	 5A) and in the context of native full-length HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	109	 All mutations at L366 resulted in decreased activity compared to wild type GAL4-DBD-HNF4 fusion protein or native HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In the context of native HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	111	 5D), the activity of mutant L 366 I (which of all the mutants differed least in activity from the wild-type), was still statistically significantly different (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	112	01) from wild-type in a z value test (Materials and Methods).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	113	 When the activities of mutants 366 A and Q were compared to that of mutant 366 I, they were also found to be statistically significantly different(P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	114	 However, the transactivation activities of mutants 366 D and I were not statistically significantly different (P > 0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Comparing the activities of the same set of point mutants at L 366 in the context of the GAL4-HNF4 fusion (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	116	 5B) shows that mutants 366 Q and D were statistically significantly different from I (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	117	01 in both cases), although no significant difference was seen between 366 I and A (P > 0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	118	05) or between mutants 366 A, D and Q.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	119	 These results show that L 366 is critical for full transactivation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The roles of L366 and E363 in the activity of the C-terminal AF2 domain of HNF4 in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	121	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL4 DBD, the wild-type GAL4-HNF4 full-length fusion construct with arrows showing the point mutations of L366->A, D, Q or I.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	122	 F E363->A shows the GAL4-HNF4 full-length construct with the bolded 363E->A mutation of the AF2 core.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	123	 F E363A/L366A shows the double mutant (B) Relative transactivation (see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (C) Schematic representation of the native full-length HNF4 and mutants studied as in (A) above.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	125	 (D) Transactivation relative to wild-type native full-length HNF4 set at 100%.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	126	 APF1-HIV-CAT is a transfection control (see Materials and Methods).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	127	Position 4 (E 363 in HNF4) of the consensus AF2 core is an acidic residue in both orphan and nuclear receptors with known ligands (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	128	 From the crystal structure of the ligand binding domain of RAR[gamma] bound to all-trans retinoic acid, this position is critical for the formation of a salt bridge between helix 4 and 12 (18), essential for AF2 activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Thus, we investigated the point mutant 363 E->A in HNF4 in the context of both a GAL4-HNF4 fusion protein (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Transactivation was statistically significantly lower than that of the wild-type fusion protein in both cases (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	131	 These results indicate that the E at 363 is also important for full transactivation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	132	We next determined the effect of a double mutation of E363A/L366A in the context of a GAL4 full-length HNF4 fusion (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Unexpectedly, the activity of the double mutant was comparable to that of the single mutants at either position (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	134	 5B, F E363A/L366A compared to F L366A or F E363A), suggesting that E363 and L366 may act cooperatively in regulating the activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The AF2 activity of HNF4 is regulated by a repressor domain near the C-terminus.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	136	A repressor domain near the C-terminus of the progesterone receptor (PR) was recently shown to inhibit the activity of PR in the absence of progesterone (19).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Alignment of the PR repressor domain sequence (residues 917-928) with the entire HNF4 protein sequence identified a potential 12 amino acid long sequence homology (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	138	 6A, boxed region) near the C-terminus of HNF4 (residues 430-441).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	139	 This potential repressor region showed 40% identity to the sequence of the repressor domain of PR, which is also near its C-terminus.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	140	 This homology and our previous results defining a repressor domain between residues 380 and 455 (see above), prompted us to investigate the effect of fusing a short region of HNF4 containing residues 430-441 downstream of a high activity C-terminal deletion mutant.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Thus, when a 14-long peptide (residues 428-441) of HNF4 was fused in-frame downstream of GAL4-HNF4 1-372 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	142	 6B), its activity was reduced from 300 to 22% of the full-length fusion protein [Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	143	 6C, compare F 1-372+428-441 to F 1-455 (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This suggested the peptide 428-441 may function as a repressor domain in isolation.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	145	 A study of the C-terminal repressor of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	146	 (A) Homology (boxed) between the C-terminal repressor domain of PR and a potential repressor domain in the extended C-terminal region of HNF4 (see text).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	147	 * indicates the C-terminus of PR.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Amino acids are numbered in HNF4 above and PR below.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (B) Schematic representation of the GAL DBD, the full-length fusion (F 1-455), the 1-371 C-terminal deletion fusion and a 1-372 C-terminal deletion fusion containing an in-frame fusion with the proposed repressor domain (428-441) of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	150	 (C) Transactivation in HeLa cells relative to the full-length fusion set at 100% (see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	151	The role of this repressor domain was further investigated by mutagenesis in the context of the full-length HNF4 fusion protein.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Two constructs with multiple point mutations (a run of five or six alanine residues) in the proposed repressor domain (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The activity of the N-terminal mutant [YKLLPG->AAAAAA, (427-432)] increased 2.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	154	3 times when compared to the wild-type full-length fusion (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The C-terminal mutation [ITTIV->AAAAA, (434-438)] showed an increase in activity which was 3.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	156	5 times that of the wild-type full-length fusion protein (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Both mutants are significantly different from wild-type (P  <  0.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	158	 These results confirm the presence of a repressor domain between amino acids 428 and 441.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Mutation of amino acids in the repressor domain of HNF4 enhances activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (A) Schematic representation of the GAL 4 DBD, the full-length HNF4 fusion (F 1-455) and two full-length HNF4 fusions with multiple mutations to alanine (as shown) in the repressor domain of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	161	 (B) Transactivation in HeLa cells relative to the wild-type full-length HNF4 fusion.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	162	 (For further details see legend to Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	163	In this report we have studied the C-terminal activation region of HNF4, concentrating our attention on two short regions.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These are firstly, the well-known AF2 core, which is conserved in nuclear receptors (4) and secondly, a novel short repressor domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These regions were studied either by deletion analysis or by site-directed mutagenesis of HNF4 fused to the GAL4 DNA binding domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Cotransfection of such fusion constructs with a chloramphenicol acetyl transferase reporter plasmid containing upstream GAL4 binding sites into either HeLa or HepG2 cells transiently, was used to study the activities of the deleted or mutated constructs (Materials and Methods).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	167	Previous studies of the C-terminal activation domain of HNF4 suggested that the AF2 core (residues 360-366) was important for activity (12-14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Furthermore, a mutation of L366->E, in an HNF4 deletion fusion construct (amino acids 128-370) suggested that residue 366 was important for the activity of the AF2 domain (14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	169	 However, this result is preliminary because it was studied on a HNF4 deletion construct which lacked three essential domains, the N-terminal AF1 domain, the DNA binding domain and the C-terminal repressor domain (see below).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	170	 It is arguable that the results might not be typical of intact HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Another potential criticism of a previous study (14) is that the conclusions as to the importance of particular amino acid residues of the AF2 core particular were based on studies of a single point mutant at each position, 363 and 366, which might not be representative had other mutants been studied.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Here we set out to study multiple mutations at position 366 of the AF2 core and to study a double mutant involving both positions 363 and 366 to gain further insight into the role of the AF2 core.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	173	The results of successive C-terminal deletions (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	174	 2) and fine deletion mapping (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	175	 4) initially suggested that L366 might be important for the activity of the C-terminal AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Therefore, four different point mutations (L->A, D, Q or I) were constructed to definitively assess the role of L 366 in both full-length HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	177	 5C and D) and GAL4 full-length HNF4 fusion constructs (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	178	 All mutations decreased the transactivation activity, indicating that Leu 366 is required for full activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	179	 However, in contrast to a previous report where the activity of a mutant at 366 was reduced to [sim]5% of wild-type, we detected activities varying from [sim]35 to 75% of wild-type.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	180	 This suggested, surprisingly, that transactivation activity is not absolutely dependent on Leu 366, even although it is conserved in a number of orphan receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	181	 A, D, Q and I were clearly functional at least in our transient transactivation assay.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	182	 This result is not an artefact of the fusion of intact HNF4 to the GAL4 DNA binding domain, since essentially similar quantitative results were obtained irrespective of whether full-length HNF4, or full-length HNF4 fused to GAL4 DNA binding domain, were studied (compare Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	183	 However, the fact that a conservative amino acid substitution 366 (L->I) showed the highest activity in our assay ([sim]60-70%), whereas non-conservative amino acid substitutions 366 (L->A, D, Q) showed lower activities (35-60%) still argues for the functional importance of Leu at 366 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	184	E363 is also highly conserved between HNF4 and all nuclear receptors with known ligands, although it is substituted by a D in some orphan receptors (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	185	 E363 was selected for mutation because it is known to be involved in the formation of a salt-bridge and is critical for transactivation in RAR[gamma] (18).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Mutation of E363->A in HNF4 here (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5) indicated that this residue, like residue 366, was required for full activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Our result at this position differed from a previous report (where activity was reduced to  < 5% of wild-type; 14) in that significant residual activity was observed (between 50 and 70% of wild-type; Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	189	 5C and D) depending on whether with the full-length HNF4 construct or the GAL4 full-length HNF4 fusion construct was used in the transactivation assay.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	190	 We attribute this difference to the fact that full-length HNF4 was used in our studies, whereas HNF4 deletion constructs were used in the previous report (14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	191	It is significant that a double mutant of 363 and 366 also retained [sim]50% activity in our assay (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The fact that the double mutant failed to demonstrate an additive effect over and above that of the two point mutants assayed separately is consistent with E363 and L366 cooperating to regulate the activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	193	 These experiments illustrates both the importance of E363 and L366 of the AF2 core, yet also demonstrate the core is partly redundant at least in our transactivation assay.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	194	 It remains possible that the redundancy observed in the mutations studied here results from a compensatory effect of the AF1 domain, which is known to transactivate (14) and is present in our full-length HNF4 constructs.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	195	Our initial C-terminal deletion experiments suggested the presence of a repressor activity within residues 380-455 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	196	 2B, and previously proposed to lie between residues 371 and 455; 14).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	197	 By aligning the amino acid sequence of the PR repressor domain (19) with the entire HNF4 sequence, a short region (residues 430-441) showing 40% identity to a previously characterised repressor domain in PR was localised in HNF4 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This presumptive repressor domain was first shown to confer repressor activity by itself (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Thus, when a short peptide from amino acid 428 to 441 containing the HNF4 repressor domain was fused in-frame downstream of a high activity C-terminal deletion fusion construct, transactivation was severely inhibited, decreasing from >300 to 22%.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	200	 This is unlikely to be the result of decreased protein expression of this particular fusion construct, since a gel shift analysis of a panel of deletion constructs all showed reasonably similar levels of protein expression (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	201	 3) This implied that the peptide containing amino acids 428-441 was sufficient, by itself, to act as a repressor.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Further evidence for this repressor domain came from a study of two constructs with multiple point mutations (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	203	It is interesting to note that in the experiment where the isolated repressor domain was fused to F 1-372 (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	204	 6B), the AF2 core was intact; hence an activity closer to the that of the full-length fusion (100%) might have been expected, whereas an activity of 22% was observed (Fig.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This suggests the repressor domain had a more potent inhibitory effect when fused closer to the AF2 core, than if it were in its normal location.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Perhaps the close proximity of the repressor domain to the AF2 core may restrict the accessibility of potential coactivator proteins to the AF2 core, either by binding a corepressor protein or simply by masking critical residues in the AF2 core.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In the case of the PR repressor domain, the repressor domain was shown to mediate its function through an unknown corepressor (19).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Experiments in an attempt to determine if the HNF4 repressor domain functioned through a corepressor were unfortunately inconclusive (data not shown).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	209	It is obviously interesting to know how the repressor domain in HNF4 functions and if it is required to regulate the activity of HNF4 in vivo.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	210	 An attractive, but speculative mechanism might involve the phosphorylation of threonine residues in the sequence ITTI (residues 434-437).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	211	 A corepressor might bind to the repressor domain in the phosphorylated state and dissociate in the dephosphorylated state.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Thus mutations which disrupt these threonine residues would prevent phosphorylation, thus preventing repression and thereby enhancing the activity of HNF4.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	213	In summary, our characterisation of the AF2 domain in the C-terminal region of HNF4 has given new insights into the function of residues 363 and 366.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	214	 By extensive mutagenesis we have shown that L366 is essential for full AF2 activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	215	 An E363A/L366A double mutant suggested that E363 and L366 may act cooperatively to regulate the activity of the AF2 domain.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	216	 We have also shown that the activity of the AF2 domain is regulated by a repressor domain located within a proline-rich region.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We have localised this repressor domain to within amino acid residues 428-441 of HNF4, and showed it was necessary and sufficient for repressor activity in transient transfection studies in HeLa cells.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Furthermore, multiple point mutations within this repressor domain in the context of the full-length HNF4 fusion construct abolished repressor activity.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The repressor domain shares homology with a recently reported C-terminal repressor domain in the progesterone receptor (19).
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	220	This work was supported by the MRC (VPI) and the Wellcome Trust (NHD  and  GGB) grant number 049537/Z/96.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Murphy for helpful discussions and the provision of pGAL4 1-147, Dr M.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	222	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.3009156.9547266.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Tel: +44 1865 275559; Fax: +44 1865 275556; Email: george.
