0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Steroids 68:1125 to 1134[CrossRef][Medline] Rust W, Stedronsky K, Tillmann G, Morley S, Walther N, Ivell R 1998 The role of SF-1/Ad4BP in the control of the bovine gene for the steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein.
0.22347338.15375188.html.plaintext.txt	345	 J Mol Endocrinol 21:189 to 200[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	0	Gene Silencing by Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor I (COUP-TFI) Is Mediated by Transcriptional Corepressors, Nuclear Receptor-Corepressor (N-CoR) and Silencing Mediator for Retinoic Acid Receptor and Thyroid Hormone Receptor (SMRT) Hirotaka Shibata, Zafar Nawaz, Sophia Y.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factors (COUP-TFs) are orphan receptors that belong to the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor (TR) superfamily and can repress the transcriptional activity of several target genes; however, the precise mechanism of this repression is unknown.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Transfection of a Gal4 DNA-binding domain fused to the putative ligand-binding domain of COUP-TFI (Gal4-COUP-TFI) significantly represses the basal transcriptional activity of a reporter gene containing Gal4-binding sites.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Cotransfection of COUP-TFI can relieve the Gal4-COUP-TFI repression in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In contrast, COUP-TFI35, which lacks the repressor domain (the C-terminal 35 amino acids), fails to relieve this repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This finding suggests that the repressor domain of COUP-TFI may squelch a limiting amount of corepressor in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In addition, increasing concentrations of TRss also can relieve the COUP-TFI repression in a hormone-sensitive manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Similarly, overexpression of increasing concentration of COUP-TFI, but not COUP-TFI35, can squelch the silencing activity of the unliganded TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Collectively, these results indicate that COUP-TFI and TRss share a common corepressor(s) for their silencing activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	10	 To determine which corepressor is involved in the COUP-TF-silencing activity, we used a yeast two-hybrid and in vitro GST pull-down assays to demonstrate that COUP-TFI can interact with the fragment of N-CoR (nuclear receptor-corepressor) encoding amino acids 921-2453 and the fragments of SMRT (silencing mediator for retinoic acid receptor and TR) encoding amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1289, respectively.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Interestingly, the fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495, which strongly interacts with TRss, interacts very weakly with COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Furthermore, overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT potentiates the silencing activity of COUP-TFI and can relieve the COUP-TFI-mediated squelching of Gal4-COUP-TFI activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Therefore, our studies indicate that N-CoR and SMRT act as corepressors for the COUP-TFI silencing activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	14	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Steroid/thyroid hormone receptors are ligand-dependent transcription factors that regulate diverse aspects of growth, development, and homeostasis by binding as monomer, homodimers, or heterodimers to their cognate DNA response elements to modulate transcription of target genes (1, 2, 3).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Thyroid hormone (TR) and retinoic acid receptors (RAR) bind to cognate DNA response elements and repress basal promoter activity in the absence of ligand (3, 4, 5).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The region important for repression may represent a unique interaction surface for contacting a particular target within the basal transcriptional machinery.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Highly charged regions are a common feature of other repression motifs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	18	 These charged regions consist of basic residues (6) or acidic residues (7, 8).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In contrast to these well-defined small repression motifs, the homologous repression regions of TR and RAR are large and appear to include multiple regions within the ligand-binding domains (LBDs) and hinge regions.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Many interacting proteins have been identified and proposed to be important for mediating the repressor function.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The identified molecular targets of repressors can be categorized into three groups (9): basal transcription factors, activators, and coregulators, such as coactivators and corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	22	Silencing activity of unliganded TR and RAR requires limiting factors termed corepressors (5).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Recently, two corepressors that bind to unliganded TR and RAR have been cloned using a yeast two-hybrid screen: N-CoR (nuclear receptor-corepressor) (10, 11) and SMRT (silencing mediator for RAR and TR) (12, 13, 14, 15).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Binding of these corepressors is necessary for unliganded receptors to silence the activity of target promoters.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Prevailing evidence suggests that binding of hormone changes the conformation of the receptors, which results in the release of the corepressor and recruitment of coactivators, thereby abolishing their silencing activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	26	 These two corepressors exhibit significant sequence homologies in their receptor-interacting domains, suggesting the existence of a corepressor gene family.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	27	 COUP-TFs (chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factors) belong to the steroid receptor superfamily and are classified as orphan receptors because their ligand has yet to be defined.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	28	 There are two COUP-TF genes in mammals, COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	29	 COUP-TFs have been implicated in neurogenesis, organogenesis, and cell fate determination (16, 17, 18, 19).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	30	 COUP-TFs can form stable homodimers and bind to a variety of hormone response elements recognized by other members of the steroid receptor superfamily, such as RAR, retinoid X receptor (RXR), TR, vitamin D receptor (VDR), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor, and hepatocyte nuclear factor 4.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	31	 COUP-TFs can thereby inhibit transcriptional activities of these receptors on both consensus and natural response elements (17, 20).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Four mechanisms have been proposed to address COUP-TF s ability to inhibit the transactivation function of other members of the steroid receptor superfamily.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	33	 First, COUP-TFs repress the hormone-dependent transactivation of target genes by VDR, TR, and RAR through direct competition for occupancy of their response elements (21, 22, 23).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Second, COUP-TFs heterodimerize with RXR to reduce the available concentration of RXR for heterodimerization with TR, VDR, RAR, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor and thus indirectly interfere with these receptors to transactivate their target genes (21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Third, COUP-TFs can tether to DNA via LBD-LBD interactions with TR, RAR, and RXR to transrepress their activities (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Finally, COUP-TFs have been shown to repress basal and activator-dependent transcriptional activities of various promoters when their binding site is placed upstream or downstream of these promoters (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The silencing domain in COUP-TFs was localized to the C terminus of the putative LBD, which can be transferred to the heterologous Gal4 DNA-binding domain (DBD).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Activators that can be repressed by COUP-TFs include acidic (Gal4-RII), glutamine-rich (Gal4-ftzQ), proline-rich (Gal4-CTF1P), and Ser/Thr-rich (Gal4-ZenST) transactivators (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Because COUP-TF can repress such a diverse group of transactivators, it is unlikely that COUP-TF s repression is through direct quenching of these transactivators or by interfering with their respective targets.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	40	 It is rather likely that COUP-TFs interact with a common target, a putative corepressor(s) that mediates their repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	41	To substantiate this hypothesis, we address two major questions in this paper; 1) Does COUP-TFI-mediated repression require corepressors? and 2) If it does, does COUP-TFI share corepressors with other receptors, such as TR and RAR? To answer these questions, we first examined whether cofactors are involved in COUP-TFI-mediated repression using either self-squelching or TR/COUP-TF-mediated mutual squelching experiments.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Next, we examined whether COUP-TFI can interact with N-CoR or SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Finally, we examined whether N-CoR or SMRT can function as a corepressor in COUP-TFI-mediated repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Results from these experiments indicate that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI-mediated repression of target genes.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	45	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   COUP-TFI-Mediated Transcriptional Repression Requires Corepressor(s) The putative LBD of the COUP-TFI (amino acid 184 to 423) has been previously shown to contain a transcriptional repression domain.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	46	 To repress transcription, it is generally believed that the COUP-TFI interacts with the basal transcriptional machinery either directly or indirectly through other cofactor molecules.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	47	 To determine whether a cofactor(s) is required for this repressor activity, we carried out transfection experiments.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Transfection of a Gal4 DBD fused to the COUP-TFI (amino acid 184 to 423) cDNA, designated as Gal4-COUP-TFI, significantly repressed basal promoter activity of the 17 mer x 4-thymidine kinase promoter-linked luciferase reporter DNA as shown previously (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	49	 This repression activity can be reversed by the exogenously expressed LBD of COUP-TFI (184 to 423), which does not bind to the reporter construct, in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The observed release of repression cannot be attributed to the nonspecific effect of overexpression of COUP-TFI on Gal DNA-binding activity because overexpression of COUP-TFI had little effect on the basal promoter activity when cotransfected with the Gal4 DBD alone (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In contrast, COUP-TFI mutant, COUP-TFI35 (amino acid 184 to 388), which does not contain a repressor domain, cannot reverse Gal4-COUP-TFI-mediated repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Overexpression of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFI35 does not affect the basal promoter activity of Gal4 (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	53	 These results clearly indicate that a limiting factor, termed corepressor(s), is required for the activity of COUP-TFI-mediated repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	54	 These results also suggest that the C-terminal 35 amino acids are required for interaction with the putative corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	55	View larger version (14K):    Figure 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	56	 COUP-TFI Is Able to Squelch the Repressor Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	57	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	58	1  microg Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	59	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFI35 expression plasmid (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	60	1  microg) was transfected instead of Gal4-COUP-TFI in lane 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	61	  COUP-TFI Shares Common Corepressor(s) with TRss To elucidate whether COUP-TFI shares common corepressors with TRss, squelching experiments were performed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Overexpression of TRss in the absence of T3 can reverse the basal repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI by squelching endogenous corepressors in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	63	 In contrast, the liganded TRss cannot squelch the repression (lines 3 to 8, Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Similarly, overexpression of TR mutant, TR168 to 456(V174A/D177A), which loses its silencing activity but retains hormone-dependent transactivation (28), cannot relieve the basal repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI (lines 9 to 11, Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	65	 These findings strongly suggest that TRss- and COUP-TFI-mediated repression share the same corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	66	View larger version (17K):    Figure 2.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Unliganded TRss, but Not Liganded TRss or TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A), Is Able to Squelch Repressor Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	68	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	69	1  microg Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	70	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of TRss or TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A) expression plasmids (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Cells were treated with 10-7 M T3 for 24 h in lanes 6 to 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	72	1  microg) was transfected instead of Gal4-COUP-TFI in lane 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	73	  In a reverse experiment, we examined whether COUP-TFI can squelch the repression activity of Gal4-TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	74	 3, transfection of Gal4-TRss into HeLa cells significantly repressed the basal promoter activity of the reporter construct.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Overexpression of COUP-TFI can reverse this repression in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	76	 As expected, we observe no reversal of TRss-mediated repression by overexpression of the repression-defective COUP-TFI mutant, COUP-TFI35.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	77	 These results further suggest that common corepressors are shared by COUP-TFI and TRss for their repression activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (14K):    Figure 3.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	79	 COUP-TFI, but Not COUP-TFI35, Is Able to Squelch the Repressor Activity of Gal4-TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	80	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	81	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFI35 (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	82	1  microg) was transfected instead of Gal4-COUP-TFI in lane 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	83	  Both N-CoR and SMRT Interact with COUP-TFI Using the LBD of TRss as a bait in a yeast two-hybrid screen, the TR-interacting protein, SMRT, has been cloned (12, 14, 15).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	84	 (10) have cloned another TR-interacting protein, N-CoR, which has sequence similarity to SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Both N-CoR and SMRT have been identified as corepressors for TR and RAR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	86	 We asked whether these two corepressors can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	87	 First, we examined whether COUP-TFI can interact specifically with these authentic corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Using a yeast two-hybrid assay, we confirmed that these corepressors can interact with TRss in a hormone-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	89	 4, A and B, a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 921-2453 and fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 565-1495 and 1192 to 1495 can interact with TRss in a hormone-dependent manner as previously described (10, 12, 14).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	90	 It should be pointed out that, to our surprise, a larger fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453, which contains a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 921-2453, cannot interact with TRss in a yeast two-hybrid assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Although the reason for this discrepancy is not clear at present, it is possible that the N-terminal repression domain of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190 to 920 is very potent and overrides the activation function of Gal4 in a yeast two-hybrid assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	92	 This notion is further supported by our observation that a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 can interact with TRss in vitro (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (34K):    Figure 4.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Interaction of TRss or COUP-TFI with N-CoR or SMRT in Yeast Two-Hybrid Assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	95	A, Various fragments of SMRT and N-CoR constructs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564, 565-1289, 565-1495, and 1192 to 1495 were constructed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495 was obtained by yeast two-hybrid screen as a bait of the LBD of TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The fragments of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 and 921-2453 were constructed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	99	 In N-CoR, there are two repression domains (RD1 and RD2) as shown in the N-terminal region.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The acidic-basic motif (AB) and the serine-glycine-rich domain (SG) in the central region are indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Glutamine-rich regions (Q) and predicted amphipathic -helix (H) regions are also indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The most N-terminal region of SMRT (amino acids 1 to 483) contains four putative repeated motifs, and it has 44% identity with N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	103	 A series of deletion mutants of N-CoR or SMRT (illustrated in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	104	 4A) were created and tested for interaction in the yeast two-hybrid system with TRss (B) or COUP-TFI (C).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	105	 For the experiments presented here, Gal4 DBD-TR168 to 456 or Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI constructs were coexpressed with Gal4 AD-N-CoR or SMRT deletion mutants.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Each two-hybrid pair was transformed into the yeast y190, the transformants were propagated, and the ss-galactosidase activity was determined.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The effects of T3 on the TR/N-CoR or SMRT interaction in the presence of 1  microM T3 in the culture medium was also tested.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Cotransformation of Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI and Gal4 AD-TFIIB was used as a positive control.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	109	 At least two independent yeast transformants were analyzed, and the results were determined as mean  plus or minus  SEM.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	110	  Next, we examined the interaction between COUP-TFI and N-CoR or SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	111	 We first demonstrated that no interaction between Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI (amino acids 184 to 423) fusion and Gal4 activation domain (AD) (empty vector) was shown as a negative control (lane 1 in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	112	 In contrast, as a positive control, we showed a strong interaction between Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI and Gal4 AD-TFIIB (lane 7 in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	113	 We then examined the interaction of various deletion fragments of N-CoR or SMRT with COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In a yeast two-hybrid assay system, the interaction of COUP-TFI with N-CoR or SMRT was detected when COUP-TFI was bound to DNA response element.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	115	 In the absence of DNA response element, no interaction was observed (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	116	 A fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 921-2453 strongly interacts with COUP-TFI; however, a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 does not interact with COUP-TFI in a yeast two-hybrid assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Similar to the TRss interaction study (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	118	 4B), the repression domains of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190 to 920 may interfere with the Gal4 activation domain function in a yeast two-hybrid assay; thus, a fragment of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 is not able to activate ss-galactosidase activity of the reporter.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	119	 However, both N-CoR fragments encoding amino acids 190-2453 and 921-2453 were found to interact with COUP-TFI in an in vitro glutathione S-transferase (GST) pull-down assay because these in vitro interactions are presumably not influenced by the repressor function of N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Thus, a fragment of COUP-TFI encoding amino acids 56 to 423 can interact specifically with N-CoR in yeast and in vitro.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	121	 On the other hand, fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1495 strongly interact with COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In contrast, a fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495, which interacts well with TR, interacts only weakly with COUP-TFI in a yeast two-hybrid assay (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	123	 These results suggest that the COUP-TFI-interacting domain of SMRT is located mainly at amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1191.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	124	 These interaction data in yeast are further supported by the in vitro protein-protein interactions as shown in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Both fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564 and 565-1289 are able to interact with GST-COUP-TFI, whereas a fragment of SMRT encoding amino acids 1192 to 1495 fails to interact with GST-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	126	View larger version (39K):    Figure 5.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Interaction between COUP-TFI and N-CoR or SMRT in in Vitro GST Pull-Down Assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	128	Radiolabeled N-CoR, SMRT, or TFIIB were tested for their abilities to bind to an immobilized GST-COUP-TFI fusion protein or to GST control protein.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	129	 GST or GST-COUP-TFI fusion protein were expressed in yeast and purified by adsorption to a glutathione-Sepharose beads.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	130	 A, The fragments of N-CoR encoding amino acids 190-2453 and 921-2453 and TFIIB, translated in vitro, were incubated with the GST control protein (lanes 2, 5, and 8) or GST-COUP-TFI (lanes 3, 6, and 9) for 30 to 60 min at 4 C with rocking.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The GST or GST-COUP-TFI Sepharose beads were then extensively washed, and radiolabeled corepressor proteins (lanes 3 and 6) or TFIIB (lane 9) bound to the matrix were eluted with SDS loading buffer and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Lanes 1, 4, and 7 represent each input protein.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	133	 B, The fragments of SMRT encoding amino acids 29 to 564 (lanes 1 to 3), 565-1285 (lanes 4 to 6), and 1192 to 1495 (lanes 7 to 9) were radiolabeled and tested for their abilities to bind to an immobilized GST-COUP-TFI (lanes 3, 6, and 9 or to GST control protein (lanes 2, 5, and 8), while Lanes 1, 4, and 7 represent each input protein.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The molecular weight of each protein is indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	135	  N-CoR and SMRT Potentiate the Basal Repression by Gal4-COUP-TFI From the above studies, we have shown that N-CoR and SMRT can interact with COUP-TFI specifically.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We then asked whether these two corepressors are required to mediate COUP-TFI repression activity in mammalian cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	137	 6, neither N-CoR nor SMRT have a significant effect on transcription activity of the reporter construct in the absence of cotransfected Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	138	 However, both N-CoR and SMRT can potentiate the repressor function of Gal4-COUP-TFI in a dose-dependent manner in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	139	 These data suggest that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors of COUP-TFI in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Thus, it is likely that they are the endogenous corepressors of COUP-TFI in HeLa cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (9K):    Figure 6.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	142	 N-CoR and SMRT Can Potentiate Basal Repression Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	143	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	144	1  microg Gal4 or Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	145	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, and increasing amounts of N-CoR or SMRT expression plasmid (0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	146	  N-CoR and SMRT Can Reverse the Squelching of COUP-TFI-Mediated Repression As shown earlier (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	147	 1), overexpression of COUP-TFI can squelch the repressor activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	148	 If N-CoR and SMRT are the limiting factors required for COUP-TFI-mediated repression, we expect that overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT should reverse this squelching activity.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	149	 7, overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT was able to relieve the squelching effects of COUP-TFI on Gal4-COUP-TFI repression function in a dose-dependent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	150	 On the other hand, overexpression of N-CoR or SMRT had no significant effect on transcription activity of the reporter construct in the absence of cotransfected Gal4-COUP-TFI (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Therefore, both N-CoR and SMRT can substitute for the endogenous corepressor(s) in mediating COUP-TFI s repressor function.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (17K):    Figure 7.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Reversal of COUP-TFI-Mediated Squelching of Basal Repression Activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	154	HeLa cells were transfected with 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	155	1  microg Gal4 or Gal4-COUP-TFI cDNA, 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	156	3  microg 17 mer x 4-tk-luciferase reporter DNA, 1.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	157	0  microg COUP-TFI cDNA, and increasing amounts of N-CoR or SMRT expression plasmid (50, 100, and 200 ng).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	158	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   We have shown that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI-mediated gene silencing.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Since COUP-TFI has been shown to interact with TFIIB in vitro (29, 30), it is proposed that COUP-TFI can interact with TFIIB in a nonproductive manner to interfere with the basal transcription.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	160	 However, many coactivators and corepressors have been identified as positive and negative cofactors in the transcriptional control of target genes by members of the steroid/TR superfamily (15, 31).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Therefore, it is tempting to speculate that some of the cofactors may also be involved in gene-silencing mechanisms of orphan receptors, such as COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Initial evidence for mediators of nuclear receptor transactivation came from the finding that transiently transfecting increasing amounts of an ER-expressing plasmid into cultured cells results in a bell-shaped curve of transcriptional activation and was attributed to the squelching of a coactivator(s) by the excessive amounts of estrogen receptor (32).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	163	 By analogy with that, we demonstrated that a putative corepressor(s) may be involved in COUP-TFI-mediated basal repression because overexpression of COUP-TFI, but not COUP-TFI35 (which has lost its repression domain), can squelch the repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Previously, we showed that a 15-amino-acid deletion from the C terminus (Gal4-COUP-TF15) had little effect on Gal4-COUP-TF activity, whereas a 25-amino-acid (Gal4-COUP-TF25) or a 35-amino-acid (Gal4-COUP-TF35) deletion largely impaired its active repression function (27).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Therefore, these data suggested that the C-terminal border of the major active repression function of COUP-TF is located within amino acids 408 and 398, and it is this region that may interact with the corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	166	 In addition, the repressor domain of COUP-TFI may directly target the basal transcriptional machinery.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	167	To examine whether a corepressor(s) can be shared between TRss and COUP-TFI, squelching experiments were performed.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	168	 2, unliganded but not liganded TRss can squelch the basal repression of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The evidence that the TR mutant, TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A) (28), which does not interact with the putative corepressors, cannot squelch the basal repression of Gal4-COUP-TFI further supports the notion that common corepressors may be involved in basal repression between TRss and COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Furthermore, overexpression of COUP-TFI, but not COUP-TFI35, can squelch the basal repression activity of Gal4-TRss, also suggesting that common corepressors can function for both COUP-TFI and TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Theoretically, the target of transcriptional interference may be either a basal transcription factor(s) or a corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Transfection of COUP-TFI or TRss did not change the basal transcription of a PRE-tk-luciferase reporter lacking a proper response element (data not shown), suggesting that squelchers are unlikely to interfere directly with the function of any basal transcriptional machinery.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Therefore, the target(s) of interference between COUP-TF and TRss is likely to be one or more transcriptional corepressor protein(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	174	Because COUP-TFI can form homodimers by itself or form heterodimers with TRss (27), it is possible that the squelchers can form non-DNA-binding heterodimers with the repressors used in Figs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	175	 1, 2, and 3 (Gal4-COUP-TFI/COUP-TFI for Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	176	 2, and Gal4-TRss/COUP-TFI for Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	177	 If this is the case, inhibition of repressor activity may be due to inhibition of DNA binding rather than to squelching of a limiting corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	178	 However, several lines of evidence suggest that this is not the case.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	179	 First, both COUP-TFI and TRss have the ability to bind specifically to corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Second, a mutant form of TRss (TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A)), which loses its ability to interact with corepressor but retains its intact dimerization domain, is not able to inhibit the repression activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Third, COUP-TF mutant (COUP-TFI35), which loses its ability in silencing, also loses its ability to squelch repressor activity of TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Finally and most importantly, we have demonstrated directly that both N-CoR and SMRT can mediate repressor activity of COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	183	 6) and reverse the self-squelching activity (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Therefore, inhibition of repression activity by squelchers in Figs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	185	 1, 2, and 3 indeed results from squelching of a limiting corepressor(s).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	186	Because squelching experiments showed that COUP-TFI may share a corepressor(s) with TRss, we examined protein-protein interaction between COUP-TFI and N-CoR or SMRT in a yeast two-hybrid assay and in in vitro GST pull-down assays as shown in Figs.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The amino acid 921-2453 fragment of N-CoR interacts with COUP-TFI.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This result is consistent with what has been observed in TR interaction studies (10, 33).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Interaction between COUP-TFI and the amino acid 190-2453 fragment of N-CoR was not detected in a yeast two-hybrid assay, but was detected in an in vitro GST pull-down assay.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	190	 This discrepancy is likely due to the potent repressor domain of the N-terminal portion of N-CoR, which suppresses the Gal4 activation function, resulting in interference with ss-galactosidase expression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Consistent with this interpretation, Seol et al.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (33) also recently demonstrated that the repressor domain of N-CoR strongly interferes with the mammalian two-hybrid assay to study the protein-protein interaction between N-CoR and TR or RAR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	193	 On the other hand, the amino acid 29 to 564 and amino acid 565-1289, but not amino acid 1192 to 1495, fragments of SMRT strongly interact with COUP-TF in yeast and in vitro assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Based on these data, we concluded that there are at least two COUP-TFI-interacting domains within the SMRT molecules.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The lack of interaction between COUP-TFI and SMRT (1192 to 1495) is surprising because this region interacts very strongly with TRss.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Thus, different repressors may interact differentially with SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Finally, the corepressor-interacting region in COUP-TFI is localized in the extreme C terminus, which is quite different from the region of TR and RAR where hinge and N-terminal portions of LBD are involved in this interaction.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Thus, repression function of COUP-TFs may act in a different way from that of TR and RAR (Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	199	View larger version (27K):    Figure 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Structure Domains of Repressors and Corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	201	A, Functional domains of COUP-TFI, TRss, and RevErb A.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	202	 A/B, C, D, E/F are functional domains of receptors (3).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	203	 CID (corepressor-interacting domain) is a sequence important for repressor function and contains a region that interacts with corepressors.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The CoR box is a conserved region of human TR, TRss, RAR, and RevErb A.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The CoR box of TRss is a repressor domain that interacts with corepressors; however, CIDs of RevErb A are different from the region of CoR box.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	206	 B, Receptor-interacting domains of SMRT and N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Receptor-interacting domains of corepressors are indicated below each scheme of SMRT and N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In N-CoR, there are two repression domains (RD1 and RD2) as shown in the N-terminal region.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The most N-terminal region of SMRT (amino acids 1 to 483) contains four putative repeated motifs and it has 44% identity with N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The acidic-basic motif () and the serine-glycine-rich domain (SG) in the central region are indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Glutamine-rich regions (Q) and predicted amphipathic -helix (H) regions are also indicated.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	212	  In support of this observation, N-CoR has been shown to function as a corepressor for RevErb A (34).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	213	 However, a region homologous to the CoR box in the RevErb A, which is necessary for TR and RAR to interact with N-CoR, is not required for RevErb A-mediated repression.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	214	 N-CoR contains two adjacent but distinct interaction domains, amino acids 2040 to 2239 and 2239 to 2296.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The former fragment of N-CoR strongly interacts with both TR and RevErb A; however, the latter fragment of N-CoR interacts weakly and preferentially with RevErb A.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Taken together, these data suggest that different nuclear receptors, utilizing different amino acid sequences, repress transcription by interacting with different region of N-CoR or SMRT as shown in Fig.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	217	Recently, an activator for COUP-TFII has been identified using a yeast two-hybrid screen, designated ORCA (orphan receptor coactivator) (35), and this factor is identical to a recently described ligand (p62) of tyrosine kinase- signaling molecule p56lck, suggesting that ORCA may link COUP-TFII and cell surface signal transduction pathways.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This integrating role may be similar to what is observed with cAMP response element-binding protein CBP and the related protein p300.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	219	 CBP plays a role in integrating cAMP second messenger and nuclear hormone receptor signal transduction pathways.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Of interest, ORCA/p62 shares a small region of homology with CBP, suggesting a potential similarity in their mechanism of action.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	221	 However, based on their data, ORCA/p62 does not bind directly to COUP-TFII-binding sites and COUP-TFII/ORCA complex is not detected in gel retardation assays.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Therefore, it is possible that ORCA/p62 may function directly or indirectly by phosphorylating COUP-TFII or ORCA/p62 may overcome the function of a specific COUP-TFII-associated corepressor.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Because ORCA/p62 can convert COUP-TFII into a transcriptional activator in a ligand-independent manner in mammalian cells, it is possible that COUP-TFI can also be activated by a coactivator(s) in a ligand-independent manner.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Our preliminary data showed that overexpression of hSRC-1a (36), which is a general coactivator for members of steroid receptors, cannot relieve the repressor activity of Gal4-COUP-TFI in HeLa cells (data not shown).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	225	In conclusion, we demonstrated that corepressors are involved in the mechanisms of COUP-TFI-mediated gene silencing, and that both N-CoR and SMRT can function as corepressors for COUP-TFI in mammalian cells.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Therefore, orphan receptors such as COUP-TFI and RevErb A can function as a repressor in vivo by utilizing corepressors that are common for members of the TR and RAR subfamily.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	227	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Mammalian Cell Culture, Transient Transfections, and Luciferase Assays HeLa cells were routinely maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Twenty-four hours before transfection, 2 x 105 cells were plated per well on a six-well dish in DMEM containing 5% dextran-coated charcoal-stripped serum.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Cells were transfected with the indicated DNAs using Lipofectin (Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY) according to the manufacturer s guidelines.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	230	8  microg of total DNA including 0.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	231	0  microg of expression vector were used per 35-mm diameter dish.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Within 24 h, the DNA/Lipofectin mixture was removed and cells were fed with DMEM containing 5% stripped serum and the indicated hormones; cells were harvested 24 h later.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Cells extracts were assayed for luciferase activity using the Luciferase Assay System (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Data are presented as an average of three separate experiments  plus or minus  SEM.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	235	 All transfections were performed at least three times in triplicate.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	236	Cloning of SMRT by Yeast Two-Hybrid System Yeast strains used are as follows.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	237	 y190: MATa, leu2 to 3, 112, ura3 to 52, trp1 to 901, his2-D200, ade2 to 101, gal4gal180URA3 GAL-lacZ, LYS GAL-HIS3, cyhr.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	238	 y187: MAT, gal4, gal80, his3, trp1 to 901, ade2 to 101, ura3 to 52, leu2 to 3, -112, URA3 GAL-lacZ met-.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	239	 BJ2168: MATa, prc1 to 407, Prb1 to 1122, pep4 to 3, leu2, trp1, ura 3 to 52.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Yeast-selective media and plates were prepared according to Guthrie and Fink (37).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The yeast strain y190 containing pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456 was transformed with a human brain cDNA library in pGAD10 (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) and plated on synthetic complete medium lacking tryptophan, leucine, and histidine (containing 25 mM 3-aminotriazole) as described by Durfee et al.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	242	 His+ colonies exhibiting ss-galactosidase activity using the filter lift assay were further characterized.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	243	 ss-Galactosidase activity was determined using chlorophenol red ss-D galactopyranoside as described (38).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	244	 To recover the library plasmids, total DNA from yeast was isolated and used to transform Escherichia coli (HB101) which lacks leu2 gene.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Transformants were identified on minimal medium lacking leucine and containing ampicillin.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	246	 To ensure that the correct cDNAs were identified, library plasmids isolated were retransformed into y190 containing pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456, and ss-galactosidase activity was determined.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The specificity of the interaction of cor 10.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	248	1 (SMRT 1192 to 1495), one of the 12 positive clones, with TR was determined by mating y190 containing pGAD10-cor 10.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	249	1 with the strain y187 containing either pAS1-SNF, pAS1-cdk2, pAS1-p53, or pAS1-lamin.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The ss-galactosidase activity of these diploids was examined using the filter lift and chlorophenyl red ss-D galactopyranoside methods.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	251	1 clone was identical to recently identified corepressor SMRT.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The yeast two-hybrid system was also used to determine protein-protein interaction between COUP-TFI and SMRT or N-CoR.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	253	Protein-Protein Interaction by GST-Pulldown Assay GST-COUP-TFI (pCBGST1-COUP-TFI) fusion protein was expressed and extracted in yeast strain BJ2168 as described previously (39).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	254	 GST-pulldown assay was performed as described with modifications (4, 39): 30  microl glutathione-Sepharose beads stored in NENT buffer (500 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	255	5% NP-40, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 6 mM MgCl2, and 8% glycerol) were incubated with yeast extracts containing GST-fusion proteins in a 1:1 vol ratio together with NENT buffer for 30 to 60 min at 4 C.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Preparation of yeast extracts containing GST-fusion protein was described previously (39).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Subsequently, the supernatant was removed and the beads were washed twice with 1 ml NENT buffer and twice with 1 ml transcription washing buffer (60 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 20 mM Tris, pH 8.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	258	05% NP-40, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 6 mM MgCl2, and 8% glycerol).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	259	 In vitro-translated and -radiolabeled proteins were obtained using TNT Coupled Reticulocyte Lysate Systems (Promega).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Five to 10  microl crude lysate were incubated with the beads in 200  microl transcription washing buffer for 2 h at 4 C.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Finally, the beads were washed five times with 1 ml NENT buffer and proteins were solubilized in SDS loading buffer and analyzed on SDS-PAGE.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The input lane contains 10% of the labeled protein used for binding.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	263	Plasmids Mammalian Expression Vectors The expression plasmids pABgal147, pABgal, pABgalTRss, pABgalTRss, pABgal-TR168 to 456 (V174A/D177A), pRSV-COUP-TFI, pRSV-COUP-TFI35, and pRSVgalCOUP-TFI were described previously (5, 20, 21, 27, 28, 40).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	264	 pCMX-N-CoR (10) and pCMX-SMRT (12) were generous gifts from Dr.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The 17 mer x 4-tk-LUC reporter gene contains four copies of a 17-mer upstream activating sequence located upstream of the thymidine kinase promoter and luciferase gene.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	266	 pCR3-SMRT565 to 1289 was constructed by TA Cloning (Invitrogen) of PCR-amplified product with primers 5'-AGCTGACGTCGACGCCTCGTG-3' and 5'-CTGCACCGCCTGGCTTCTAT-3' in which template cDNA was made by reverse transcription of human skeletal muscle mRNA (Clontech) with primer 5'-GCTGGCATGTTCCTGCACCG-3'.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	267	 pCR3-SMRT565 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the EcoRI (filled)-BglII fragment of pGAD10-SMRT1192 to 1495 into the BglII-EcoRV site of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1289.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	268	 pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 was constructed by TA Cloning (Invitrogen) of PCR-amplified product with primers 5'-AAGATTCCGAGCTCTGCTAC-3' and 5'-CACGAGGCGTCGACGTCAGC-3' in which template cDNA was made by reverse transcription of human skeletal muscle mRNA (Clontech) with primer 5'-GTGCGGGGACTTGGCGATCT-3'.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	269	 pCR3-SMRT29 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the SalI fragment of pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 into the SalI site of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1495.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	270	 pABgalSMRT29 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the SalI (partial)-XbaI fragment into the PvuII site of pABgal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	271	 All PCR generates clones were sequenced to ensure that no mutation occurred during PCR reactions.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	272	Yeast Vectors The Gal4 DBD-TRss168 to 456 yeast expression plasmid (pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456) was constructed by inserting the HindIII-SmaI blunt-ended fragment of pABgalTR168 to 456 into the SmaI site of pAS1cyh2 (38).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The Gal4 DBD-COUP-TFI56 to 423 yeast expression plasmid (pAS1cyh2-COUP-TFI) was constructed by inserting the EcoRI-SmaI (filled) fragment of pGEM7Zf(+)-COUP-TFI into the SmaI site of pAS1cyh2.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Yeast expression plasmid, pCBGST1-COUP-TFI56 to 423, was constructed by inserting the EcoRI-SmaI (filled) fragment (amino acids 56 to 423) of pGEM7Zf(+)-COUP-TFI into the SmaI site of pCBGST1 (39).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Yeast expression plasmid, pACTII-N-CoR190 to 2453, was constructed by inserting the PvuI-SalI (filled) fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the NcoI-XhoI site (filled) of pACTII (38).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Yeast expression plasmid, pACTII-N-CoR921 to 2453, was constructed by inserting the HincII-SalI (filled) fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the SmaI site of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	277	 pACTII-SMRT29 to 564 was constructed by inserting the SalI fragment (filled) of pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 into the NcoI (filled) site of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	278	 pACTII-SMRT565 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the SalI-XhoI fragment of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1495 into the NcoI (filled) site of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Yeast expression plasmid, pGAD10-SMRT1192 to 1495, was recovered from a yeast two-hybrid screen using pAS1cyh2-TR168 to 456 as a bait.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Yeast expression plasmid, pACTII-TFIIB, was constructed by inserting the NcoI (partial)-EcoRI fragment of pGST-TFIIB (4) into the NcoI-EcoRI sites of pACTII.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	281	In Vitro Transcription and Translation Vectors pT7-N-CoR190 to 2453 was constructed by inserting the PvuI-SalI fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the NcoI site (filled) of pT7ssSal (41).
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	282	 PT7-N-CoR921 to 2453 was constructed by inserting the HincII-SalI fragment of pCMX-N-CoR into the AccI site (filled) of pT7ssSal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	283	 pT7-SMRT29 to 564 was constructed by inserting the SalI fragment (filled) of pCR3-SMRT29 to 564 into the NcoI-EcoRI (filled) site of pT7ssSal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	284	 pT7-SMRT565 to 1289 was constructed by inserting the SalI-EcoRV fragment of pCR3-SMRT565 to 1289 into the NcoI-EcoRI (filled) site of pT7ssSal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	285	 PT7-SMRT1192 to 1495 was constructed by inserting the EcoRI fragment (filled) of pGAD10-SMRT1192 to 1495 into the HincII site of pT7ssSal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	286	 pT7-TFIIB was constructed by inserting the NcoI (partial)-EcoRI fragment (filled) of pGST-TFIIB (4) into the AccI site (filled) of pT7ssSal.
0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	287	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank members of our laboratories for critically reading this manuscript.

0.2712022.9171235.html.plaintext.txt	335	 EMBO J 11:1015 to 1023[Abstract] Norman C, Runswick M, Pollock R, Treisman R 1988 Isolation and properties of cDNA clones encoding SRF, a transcription factor that binds to the c-fos serum response element.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	0	Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 Is a Central Regulator of Bile Acid Conjugation* Yusuke Inoue, Ai-Ming Yu, Junko Inoue, and Frank J.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Laboratory of Metabolism, Center for Cancer Research, NCI, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, October 7, 2003 , and in revised form, October 24, 2003.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) has an important role in regulating the expression of liver-specific genes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Because bile acids are produced from cholesterol in liver and many enzymes involved in their biosynthesis are preferentially expressed in liver, the role of HNF4 in the regulation of bile acid production was examined.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In mice, unconjugated bile acids are conjugated with taurine by the liver-specific enzymes, bile acid-CoA ligase and bile acid-CoA:amino acid N-acyltransferase (BAT).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Mice lacking hepatic HNF4 expression exhibited markedly decreased expression of the very long chain acyl-CoA synthase-related gene (VLACSR), a mouse candidate for bile acid-CoA ligase, and BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	7	 This was associated with markedly elevated levels of unconjugated and glycine-conjugated bile acids in gallbladder.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	8	 HNF4 was found to bind directly to the mouse VLACSR and BAT gene promoters, and the promoter activities were dependent on HNF4-binding sites and HNF4 expression.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In conclusion, HNF4 plays a central role in bile acid conjugation by direct regulation of VLACSR and BAT in vivo.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Bile acids (BAs)1 are synthesized from cholesterol mainly in hepatocytes by a cascade of enzyme reactions.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In humans, these reactions are initiated by steroid nucleus and side chain hydroxylation of cholesterol and followed by -oxidation of the side chain and resulting in the production of the primary BAs cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid (1, 2).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In mice, cholic acid and -murichoric acid are the predominant primary BAs (3).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Following BA biosynthesis, BAs are conjugated with glycine or taurine resulting in conjugates that are exported from hepatocytes via hepatic BA transporters such as the bile salt export pump located at the apical or canalicular membrane (1, 4 to 6).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These BAs are stored in gallbladder and then transported into the small intestine.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	15	 BAs are biological detergents that serve to solubilize fats, sterols, and fat-soluble vitamins in the intestine.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Most BAs are recycled from the jejunum and ileum by transporters, such as apical sodium-dependent bile acid transporter (4, 7), and then transported back into hepatocytes from the portal circulation by transporters including sodium taurocholate cotransporter polypeptide (NTCP) and organic anion transporter polypeptide 1 (OATP1) located at the basolateral membrane (4).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	17	Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is an orphan member of the nuclear receptor hormone superfamily that is mainly expressed in liver, intestine, kidney, and pancreas and regulates expression of target genes including several serum proteins such as apolipoproteins, blood coagulation factors, P450s, and enzymes involved in glucose, lipid, ammonia, steroid, and fatty acid metabolism by binding to direct repeat-1 elements in their promoter or enhancer regions (8, 9).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Indeed, the expression of hepatic apolipoproteins, including A-II, A-IV, C-II, and C-III, ornithine transcarbamylase involved in ureagenesis, and CYP3A associated with xenobiotic metabolism, was significantly reduced in livers of liver-specific HNF4-null mice (10 to 12).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	19	 A second line of liver-specific HNF4-null mice was established where Cre recombinase was placed under the control of the albumin promoter and the -fetoprotein enhancer (13).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	20	 These mice exhibited a marked reduction in the expression of hepatic glycogen synthase, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase, and glucose-6-phosphatase, involved in gluconeogenesis, and reduced levels of E-cadherin, ZO-1, and CEACAM1 proteins that are critical for normal liver morphology (13).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	21	Liver-specific HNF4-null mice in the adult exhibited increased serum BAs, and expression of the BA transporters, NTCP and OATP1, was also reduced in these mice (10).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Whereas BA biosynthesis and transport are controlled to some degree by HNF4, it remains unknown whether HNF4 regulates the BA conjugation pathway.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Nuclear receptors are involved in the control of the BA biosynthesis and transport system (6, 14, 15), but the mechanism regulating BA conjugation pathways have not been analyzed.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	24	 BA conjugation reactions are catalyzed by two liver-enriched enzymes, bile acid-CoA ligase (BAL) and bile acid-CoA:amino acid N-acyltransferase (BAT) (1, 14).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	25	 BAL activities are associated with rat BAL protein (16) and human very long chain acyl-CoA synthase homolog 2 (VLACSR-H2) protein (17), but enzymatic analysis of BAL protein has not been performed in the mouse.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Because the mouse very long chain acyl-CoA synthase-related (VLACSR) gene, which is highly expressed only in liver (18) as well as rat BAL and human VLACSR-H2 genes, has a high homology to these proteins (16), it was reasonable to assume that the VLACSR gene might be the mouse homolog for the BAL gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	27	 On the other hand, BAT genes have been cloned from mouse (19), rat (20), and human (21).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The human BAT protein has conjugation activity with both taurine and glycine as substrates (21), but the mouse BAT protein only uses taurine as a substrate (19).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	29	In the present study, the biological function of HNF4 was investigated in vivo and in vitro using liver-specific HNF4-null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	30	 These mice exhibit increased unconjugated and glycine-conjugated BAs in gallbladder bile and decreased expression of VLACSR and BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Expression of the VLACSR and BAT was shown to be regulated directly by HNF4 via HNF4-binding sites in their promoter regions.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These results indicate that HNF4 has an important role in the maintenance of BA homeostasis by regulating BA conjugation pathways.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	33	   EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Animals and Treatment Liver-specific HNF4-null mice were generated as described previously (10).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	34	 All experiments were performed with 45-day-old HNF4flox/flox x albumin-Cre+ (KO) and HNF4flox/flox x albumin-Cre to  (FLOX) mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Mice were housed in a pathogen-free animal facility under standard 12-h light/12-h dark cycle with water and chow ad libitum.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	36	 All experiments with mice were performed under Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care guidelines with the approval of the NCI Animal Care and Use Committee.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	37	Northern Blot Analysis Total liver RNA (10  microg), extracted with Trizol reagent (Invitrogen), was fractionated by electrophoresis through a formaldehyde-agarose gel and transferred to GeneScreen Plus membranes (DuPont).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Blots were hybridized at 68  degrees C in PerfectHyb plus solution (Sigma) with random primer-labeled cDNA probes and exposed to a PhosphorImager screen cassette followed by visualization using a Storm 860 PhosphorImager system (Amersham Biosciences).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	39	 All probes were amplified from a mouse cDNA library using gene-specific primers and cloned into the pCR II vector (Invitrogen).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Sequences were verified using CEQ 2000 Dye Terminator cycle sequencing kits (Beckman Coulter, Fullerton, CA) and a CEQ 2000XL DNA Analysis System (Beckman Coulter).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	41	Extraction of Bile Acids from Bile Three  microl of bile or a 1/100 dilution (in methanol) was added into 200  microl of acetonitrile containing 20  microl of 50  microM dehydrocholic acid.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The sample was vortexed for 10 s and then subsequently centrifuged at 14,000 x g at 4  degrees C for 5 min.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The supernatant was transferred to a new glass tube and extracted with 2 ml of a mixture of ethyl acetate and t-butyl methyl ether (2/1, v/v).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	44	 After centrifugation at 3,000 x g at 4  degrees C for 15 min, the organic phase was evaporated under a stream of nitrogen gas.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The residue was reconstituted in 60  microl of a 50% methanol solution containing 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Ten  microl of each reconstituted sample was injected for liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) analysis.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	47	Identification and Quantitation of Intact Free and Conjugated Bile Acids by LC-MS/MS LC-MS/MS analysis was performed on a PE SCIEX API2000 ESI triple-quadrupole mass spectrometer (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) controlled by Analyst software.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	48	 A Phenomenex Luna C18 3- microm 100 x 2 mm inner diameter column (Torrance, CA) was used to separate free bile acids.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The flow rate through the column at ambient temperature was 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	50	2 ml/min, and optimal resolution was achieved by elution with a linear gradient of water containing 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	51	1% formic acid (45 0%) and methanol (55 100%) for 10 min at room temperature.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Separation of glycine- and taurine-conjugated bile acids was performed on an Aquasil C18 5- microm 50 x 2 mm inner diameter column (Keystone Scientific Operations, Bellefonte, PA), and the high pressure liquid chromatography system was operated isocratically at a flow rate of 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	53	2 ml/min with the mobile phase (acetonitrile/water/methanol = 30/45/25, v/v/v) containing 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The mass spectrometer was operated in the turbo ion spray mode with positive ion detection.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The turbo ion spray temperature was maintained at 350  degrees C, and a voltage of 4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	56	8 kV was applied to the sprayer needle.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Nitrogen was used as the turbo ion spray and nebulizing gas.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The detection and quantification of free and conjugated bile acids and the internal standard were accomplished by multiple reactions monitoring with the transitions m/z 403.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	59	2 for deoxycholic acid, chenodeoxycholic acid, hyodeoxycholic acid, ursodeoxycholic acid, and murideoxycholic acid; 373.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	60	3 for cholic acid, hyocholic acid, - and -muricholic acid (MCA); 391.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	61	4 for glycodeoxycholic acid (GDCA) and glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA), 516.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	62	4 for taurocholic acid (TCA) and tauro--muricholic acid (T--MCA); and 500.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	63	4 for taurodeoxycholic acid (TDCA) and taurochenodeoxycholic (TCDCA).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	64	 All raw data were processed using Analyst software.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Calibration curves were linear for free deoxycholic acid, chenodeoxycholic acid, hyodeoxycholic acid, ursodeoxycholic acid, and murideoxycholic acid concentrations ranging from 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	66	05 to 10  microM; free cholic acid, hyocholic acid -, -, and -MCA from 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	67	2 to 20  microM, GDCA and GCDCA from 0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	68	1 to 10  microM; TDCA and TCDCA from 1.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	69	0 to 200  microM; and glycocholic acid, TCA, and T--MCA from 2.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	70	Determination of the Transcription Start Sites of the Mouse VLACSR and BAT Genes 5'-Rapid amplification of cDNA ends was performed to determine the transcription start site of the mouse VLACSR and BAT genes using GeneRacer kit (Invitrogen).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	71	 PCR products were cloned into pCR TOPO II, and 20 individual clones were sequenced.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Based on these results, the major transcription start site was determined.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	73	Construction of the Mouse VLACSR and BAT-Luciferase Reporter Plasmids The mouse VLACSR ( to 2219,  to 1435,  to 1014,  to 256,  to 220,  to 194, and  to 146/ to 47 bp from translation start site) and BAT ( to 1972,  to 1567,  to 1447,  to 1322,  to 602,  to 505,  to 136, and  to 52/+178 bp from transcription start site) promoters were amplified by PCR using sequence data derived from the Celera data base (Celera Genomics, Rockville, MD) and cloned into KpnI and XhoI sites of the pGL3/basic vector (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Mutations were introduced into the putative HNF4-binding site in the VLACSR-luciferase constructs by PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis using the following primer pair: 5'-acaaaCTGACAGAGTCCAtgggt-3' and 5'-acccaTGGACTCTGTCAGtttgt-3' (M2; mutations in the HNF4-binding site are boldface and underlined).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Similarly, mutations were introduced into an Sp1-binding site in the VLACSR-luciferase constructs by PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis using the following primer pair: 5'-tgtccaagTAAAGAAGTGag-3' and 5'-ctCACTTCTTTActtggaca-3' (mutations in the GC box are boldface and underlined).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Similarly, mutations were introduced into an HNF4-binding site in the BAT-luciferase constructs by PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis using the following primer pair: 5'-agtccaCTTTCCAAGGTCTtagtct-3' and 5'-agactaAGACCTTGGAAAGtggact-3' (mutations in the HNF4-binding site are boldface and underlined).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Sequences were verified using a CEQ 2000XL DNA Analysis System (Beckman Coulter).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	78	Transient Transfection Assay HepG2 and CV-1 cell lines were cultured at 37  degrees C in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (HyClone, Logan, UT) and 100 units/ml penicillin/streptomycin (Invitrogen).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Cells were seeded in 24-well tissue culture plates and grown to 90 to 95% confluency.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	80	 For transfections, 500 ng/well pGL3 basic or the wild-type or mutated BAL and BAT promoters and 200 ng/well pRL/TK (Promega) were used with the total amount of DNA adjusted to 900 ng by the addition of pUC19 as a carrier DNA.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	81	 For cotransfections, 200 ng/well of the rat HNF4 expression plasmid, pSG5/HNF4, was used.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	82	 All transfections were performed using LipofectAMINE 2000 reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	83	 After 48 h, the cells were washed with phosphate-buffered saline and assayed for dual luciferase activity using commercial kits (Promega).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	84	Gel Shift Analysis Crude nuclear extracts were prepared, and gel shift analysis was carried out as described previously (11).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The following three double-stranded probes were used: HNF4-binding site for the mouse VLACSR promoter (wild-type), 5'-acaaaAGGACAGAGTCCAtgggt-3' and 5'-acccaTGGACTCTGTCCTtttgt-3', the mouse VLACSR promoter (mutant), 5'-acaaaCTGACAGAGTCCAtgggt-3' and 5'-acccaTGGACTCTGTCAGtttgt-3' (mutations in the HNF4-binding site are boldface and underlined); GC box for the mouse VLACSR promoter (wild-type), 5'-tgtccaagGGGGCGGGGCag-3' and 5'-ctGCCCCGCCCCcttggacaC-3', HNF4-binding site for the mouse VLACSR promoter (mutant), 5'-tgtccaagTAAAGAAGTGag-3' and 5'-ctCACTTCTTTActtggaca-3' (mutations in the GC box are boldface and underlined); the mouse BAT promoter (wild-type), 5'-agtccaAGTTCCAAGGTCTtagtct-3' and 5'-agactaAGACCTTGGAACTtggact-3', and the mouse BAT promoter (mutant), 5'-agtccaCTTTCCAAGGTCTtagtct-3' and 5'-agactaAGACCTTGGAAAGtggact-3' (mutations in the HNF4-binding site are boldface and underlined).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	86	 End-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide (2 x 105 cpm) was added, and the reaction mixture was incubated at room temperature for 30 min.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For competition experiments, a 25-fold excess of unlabeled oligonucleotide was added to the reaction mixture, and the mixture was incubated at room temperature for 20 min prior to the addition of a 32P-labeled oligonucleotide probe.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	88	 For supershift analysis, 1  microg of anti-HNF4 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) was added to the reaction mixture, and the mixture was incubated at room temperature for 30 min after the addition of a 32P-labeled oligonucleotide probe.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	89	Statistical Analysis All values are expressed as the means  plus or minus  S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	90	 3, 4, 6, and 7) or standard deviation (S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	91	 All data were analyzed by the unpaired Student's t test for significant differences between the mean values of each group.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	92	View larger version (38K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Promoter analysis of the mouse VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	94	 A, luciferase reporter plasmids containing the mouse VLACSR promoter ( to 146,  to 194,  to 220,  to 256,  to 1014,  to 1435, and  to 2219/ to 47 bp from translation start site) were transfected into HepG2 cells.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The normalized activity  plus or minus  S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	96	 (n = 4) of each construct is presented as arbitrary units.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	97	 B, CV-1 cells were cotransfected with the HNF4 expression vector, as indicated.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The normalized activity  plus or minus  S.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	99	 (n = 4) of each construct is presented as arbitrary units.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	100	 C, nuclear extracts (2  microg) from liver of H4Flox (left panel) and H4LivKO (right panel) mice were incubated with the labeled HNF4-binding site oligonucleotide of the mouse VLACSR promoter in the absence (lanes 1 and 6) or presence of a 25-fold excess of each unlabeled oligonucleotide (lanes 2 and 7 for the wild-type of the HNF4-binding site of the mouse VLACSR promoter, and lanes 3 and 8 for the mutated site).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Similarly, the labeled mutated HNF4-binding site oligonucleotide of the mouse VLACSR promoter was incubated with nuclear extracts from H4FLOX (lane 5) and H4LivKO (lane 10) mice.

0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	128	View this table:    TABLE I Analysis of free bile acids in gallbladder bile of liver-specific HNF4-null and control mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	129	Amounts of - and -MCA were combined.
