0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	135	 (FLOX (n = 7 to 8) and KO (n = 6 to 8)).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Significant differences compared with FLOX mice: *, p  <  0.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	137	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Expression of Genes Involved in BA Conjugation Is Reduced in Liver-specific HNF4a-null Mice Free BAs are at first esterified with acetyl-CoA by BAL, and the esterified BAs are conjugated with glycine or taurine by BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The enzyme activity of BAL has not been analyzed in mouse, but the mouse VLACSR gene might be a candidate for a mouse BAL since VLACSR has high homology to both the rat BAL and human VLACSR-H2 that have BAL activities.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Human BAT is able to conjugate both glycine and taurine (21), but mouse BAT has conjugation specificity toward taurine and not glycine (19).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Northern blots were performed to determine whether the expression of VLACSR and BAT is significantly different between liver-specific HNF4-null (HNF4-floxed/floxed, albumin-Cre; H4LivKO) and control (HNF4-floxed/floxed, without albumin-Cre; H4Flox) mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Expression of VLACSR and BAT was markedly reduced in the livers of H4LivKO mice as compared with H4Flox mice (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	142	 It is also noteworthy that the expression of alanine:glyoxylate aminotransferase and taurine transporter, two enzymes that determine the levels of cytosolic glycine and taurine, were unchanged.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	143	View larger version (95K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Northern blot analysis of VLACSR and BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Total liver RNA was isolated, and 10  microg was subjected to electrophoresis on a 1% agarose gel, transferred to a nylon membrane, and hybridized with the indicated 32P-labeled cDNA probes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	146	 TAUT, taurine transporter; AGXT, alanine:glyoxylate aminotransferase.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	147	  Free BAs and Glycine-conjugated BAs Are Increased in Gallbladder Bile of Liver-specific HNF4-null Mice Because the expression of VLACSR and BAT was decreased in H4LivKO mice, it was expected that free BAs are increased and conjugation patterns are altered in H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Most BAs in the H4Flox mice are also found as conjugated derivatives in gallbladder bile because only small amounts of free BAs were detected (Table I).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	149	 However, free BAs were significantly increased in the gallbladders of H4LivKO mice (Table I), indicating that the conjugation enzymatic machinery of the BAs might be impaired by decreased expression of VLACSR in the livers of H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	150	The conjugation pattern of BA in gallbladder bile was further determined by LC-MS/MS (Table II).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In male H4Flox mice, taurocholic acid (TCA) and tauro--muricholic acid (T--MCA) were the predominant BAs.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The concentrations of these BAs (Table II, upper) were decreased in H4LivKO mice, but the total amounts (Table II, lower) were almost unchanged (TCA) or increased (T--MCA).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Most mammals secrete BAs conjugated with taurine and/or glycine, but mouse gallbladder bile contains only the taurine-conjugated forms (18).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	154	 However, small amounts of glycine-conjugated BAs including glycocholic acid, glycodeoxycholic acid (GDCA), and glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA) were detected in the H4Flox mice, and their levels were much lower as compared with their taurine-conjugated derivatives.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In contrast to the results with control mice, taurodeoxycholic acid (TDCA), GDCA, taurochenodeoxycholic acid (TCDCA), and glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA) were increased in H4LivKO mice with GDCA and GCDCA being markedly elevated.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	156	 These results indicate that the conjugation pattern of BAs in H4LivKO mice is significantly different from H4Flox mice because of decreased expression of BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Because glycine-conjugated BAs are increased and taurine-conjugated BAs are maintained in H4LivKO mice, an unidentified BAT that can use both glycine and taurine as substrates might play an important role in H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	158	Expression of the Mouse VLACSR Gene Is Directly Regulated by HNF4 To investigate why expression of VLACSR was reduced in H4LivKO mice, the promoter region of the mouse VLACSR gene was cloned (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	159	 A transcription start site was determined by 5'-rapid amplification of cDNA ends, and five major sites were identified between  to 143 and  to 85 from translation start site (+1).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	160	 A putative HNF4-binding site and a GC box were found between  to 162 and  to 150 and  to 238 and  to 229, respectively (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	161	 To determine whether HNF4 has the potential to activate the mouse VLACSR promoter, several VLACSR promoter-luciferase reporter plasmids were constructed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	162	 When HepG2 cells, which express HNF4, were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the  to 194-bp fragment containing a putative HNF4-binding site was higher than that of the promoterless construct (pGL3/basic) and the  to 146-bp fragment (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The promoter activities of the  to 220-bp fragment was higher than  to 194-bp fragment, indicating that the nucleotide sequence between  to 220 and  to 195 bp, which are GC-rich regions similar to the GC box between  to 238 and  to 229 bp, might be important for promoter activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Furthermore, the promoter activities of the  to 256-,  to 1014-,  to 1435-, and  to 2219-bp fragments, which contain an HNF4-binding site and GC-rich sequences, were much higher than that of  to 194- and  to 220-bp fragments.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	165	 To determine whether HNF4 positively regulates the promoter activity, CV-1 cells, which do not express HNF4, were used.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The promoter activity of the  to 146-bp fragment was unchanged by cotransfection of the HNF4 expression vector, consistent with the absence of an HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	167	 However, the promoter activity of the  to 194-bp fragment was increased by cotransfection with an HNF4 expression vector.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The same results were obtained using the longer fragments, indicating that HNF4 positively regulates expression of the VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Interestingly, the basal promoter activity of  to 220-bp fragment was increased in the absence of HNF4 expression, and the activity of  to 256-bp fragment was much higher.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Because a GC-rich sequence was observed in the region between  to 256 and  to 195 bp, the Sp1 family proteins might be important in activating maximal promoter activity in the presence of HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	171	View larger version (39K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Nucleotide sequence of the mouse VLACSR gene promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	173	 A, localization of HNF4-binding site and GC box in the mouse VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	174	 B, numbering of nucleotides is relative to the translation start site (nucleotide +1, arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The asterisk marks the transcription start sites.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The putative binding site for HNF4 at  to 162 and  to 150, and GC box at  to 238 and  to 229 are indicated by boldface and underlined, respectively.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	177	  To determine whether HNF4 can bind to the HNF4-binding site in the mouse VLACSR promoter, gel shift analysis was performed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Liver nuclear extracts from H4Flox mice contained proteins that bound to the HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Binding was diminished by the addition of excess amounts of unlabeled VLACSR probe (wild-type) but not by the mutated probe, indicating that a protein specifically bound to this site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	180	 3C, lanes 2 and 3, the lower arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Furthermore, these bands were supershifted by the addition of anti-HNF4 antibody, indicating that the protein bound to this HNF4-binding site was indeed HNF4 (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	182	 However, supershifted bands were not detected using liver nuclear extracts from H4LivKO mice (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	183	 3C, lane 9) and no specific complex, indicated by the lower arrow, was detected using the labeled mutated probe (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	184	 These results indicate that the HNF4-binding site in the mouse VLACSR promoter is capable of binding HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	185	To determine whether disruption of the HNF4-binding site and GC box decreases the promoter activity, mutations were introduced into the HNF4-binding site and GC box in the mouse VLACSR ( to 1014/ to 47)-luciferase construct (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	186	 4B, when HepG2 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the HNF4 mutant ( to 1014/HNF4 Mut) was decreased as compared with the wild-type construct ( to 1024/WT).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The promoter activity of the GC box mutant ( to 1014/GC box Mut) was further decreased, and the double mutants for both the HNF4-binding site and GC box ( to 1014/HNF4/GC box Mut) had almost no promoter activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	188	 When CV-1 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the HNF4 mutant ( to 1014/HNF4 Mut) was decreased to 40% as compared with the wild-type fragment ( to 1014/WT) in the presence of HNF4 (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The basal activity of the GC box mutant ( to 1014/GC box Mut) was decreased to the same level as the promoterless vector, but the activity was still increased by HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Furthermore, introduction of mutations into the binding sites of both factors ( to 1014/HNF4/GC box Mut) caused a marked reduction of promoter activities even in the presence of HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	191	 These results indicate that the HNF4 and a GC box-binding protein can activate expression of the VLACSR gene, but both are needed for the maximal activation.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	192	Expression of the Mouse BAT Gene Is Directly Regulated by HNF4 In order to investigate why the expression of BAT was reduced in H4LivKO mice, the promoter region of the mouse BAT gene was cloned (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	193	 An HNF4-binding site was found between  to 68 and  to 56 from the transcription start site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	194	 However, the promoter activity of the 3078-bp fragment between the beginning of intron 1 and translation start site was not induced in HepG2 and CV-1 cells by cotransfection with HNF4 (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	195	 To determine whether HNF4 has the potential to activate the mouse BAT promoter, several BAT promoter-luciferase reporter plasmids were constructed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	196	 When HepG2 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the  to 136-bp fragment containing a putative HNF4-binding site was higher than that of the promoterless construct (pGL3/basic) and the  to 52-bp fragment (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The promoter activities of the longer fragments were much higher than that of the  to 136-bp fragment.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	198	 To determine whether this effect was due to HNF4, CV-1 cells were used.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The promoter activity of the  to 52-bp fragment was unchanged by cotransfection of the HNF4-expression vector, consistent with the absence of an HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, the promoter activity of the  to 136-bp fragment was increased by HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The same results were obtained from experiments using the longer fragments.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	202	View larger version (38K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Nucleotide sequence of the mouse BAT gene promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	204	 A, localization of HNF4-binding site in the mouse BAT gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The asterisk marks the translation start site in exon 2.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	206	 B, numbering of nucleotides is relative to the transcription start site (+1, arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The putative binding site for HNF4 at  to 68 and  to 56 is indicated by boldface and underlined.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	208	  To determine whether HNF4 can bind to the DR1-like elements in the mouse BAT promoter, gel shift analysis was performed (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Liver nuclear extracts from H4Flox mice contained proteins that bound to the HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Binding was diminished by the addition of excess amounts of unlabeled BAT probe (wild-type) but not by the mutated probe, indicating that a protein specifically bound to this site (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	211	 6C, lanes 2 and 3, the lower arrow).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Furthermore, these bands were supershifted by the addition of anti-HNF4 antibody, indicating that the protein bound to this HNF4-binding site was indeed HNF4 (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Supershifted bands were not detected using liver nuclear extracts from H4LivKO mice (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	214	 6C, lane 9), and no specific complex, indicated by the lower arrow, was detected using the labeled mutated probe (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	215	 These results indicate that the HNF4-binding site in the mouse BAT promoter is capable of binding HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	216	To determine whether disruption of the HNF4-binding site decreases the promoter activity, the same mutations used in Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	217	 6C were introduced into the HNF4-binding site in the mouse BAT ( to 602/+178)-luciferase construct (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	218	 7B, when HepG2 cells were used for transient transfections, the promoter activity of the mutated  to 602-bp fragment ( to 602/Mut) was decreased to 25% as compared with the wild-type fragment ( to 602/WT).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	219	 When CV-1 cells were used, the promoter activity of the mutated fragment was decreased to 15% by cotransfection of HNF4 as compared with the wild-type fragment (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	220	 7C), indicating that the HNF4-binding site is important for activation of the mouse BAT promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	221	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   BAs are synthesized by steroid nucleus and side chain hydroxylation of cholesterol followed by -oxidation of the side chain.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Because serum BA levels are significantly increased and expression of OATP1 and NTCP was decreased in liver-specific HNF4-null mice (10), HNF4 is likely a critical transcription factor regulating genes involved in BA biosynthesis.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In this study, HNF4 was also found to control the BA conjugation pathway by direct binding to the promoter regions of both the VLACSR and BAT genes and activation of their transcription.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	224	Because the levels of unconjugated (free) BAs are very low in gallbladder bile (22), increased levels of unconjugated BAs in liver-specific HNF4-null mice appear to be due to decreased expression of VLACSR and BAT.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Because VLACSR and BAT are preferentially expressed in liver (18, 19) as well as HNF4, HNF4 is a central factor in the regulation of VLACSR and BAT in vivo.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	226	 An HNF4-binding site and a GC-rich region were identified in the promoter region of the mouse VLACSR gene.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Indeed, HNF4 binds to this HNF4-binding site, and the promoter activities were dependent on this site and expression of HNF4.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Furthermore, a GC-rich sequence was also important for maximal activation of the VLACSR gene because the mutated GC-rich sequence reduced its basal promoter activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	229	 It was reported that HNF4 and Sp1, a prototypical GC box-binding protein, binds to promoter regions of genes, including apolipoprotein C-III and CYP27, and increases their expression (23, 24).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	230	 In the mouse VLACSR promoter, HNF4 can still activate promoter activity when mutations were introduced into the GC box, but the resultant activity was much lower when compared with that of the wild-type promoter.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	231	 This result indicates that cooperative binding of HNF4 and Sp1 to the promoter might be required for maximal induction of VLACSR expression in the liver.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Furthermore, the expression of sterol carrier protein x, which is involved in the side chain -oxidation of BA, was also reduced in liver-specific HNF4-null mice, and Sp1 was identified as a critical factor regulating the sterol carrier protein x gene in an HNF4-independent manner (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Because expression of Sp1 and Sp3, typical GC box-binding proteins, was unchanged and VLACSR expression is markedly reduced in liver-specific HNF4-null mice (data not shown), post-transcriptional modification of Sp1 and/or Sp3 could reduce the expression of VLACSR in these null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	234	In addition to increased unconjugated BAs in serum, glycine-conjugated BAs such as GDCA and GCDCA were significantly increased in the gallbladder of liver-specific HNF4-null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Because mouse BAT has no glycine conjugation activity (19), expression of an unidentified BAT gene might be activated in H4LivKO mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Actually a few mouse genes that exhibit similarity to mouse BAT were cloned, but their function is still unknown.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Expression of one of these genes (GenBankTM accession number NM_145368 [GenBank] ) was found to be increased in the livers of H4LivKO mice (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	238	 However, it remains unclear whether this gene encodes an enzyme with glycine conjugation activity.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Furthermore, the physiological role of increased GDCA and GCDCA in H4LivKO mice also remains unclear, but these BAs in the intestinal lumen might change many aspects of intestinal and whole body cholesterol homeostasis.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	240	Recently it was reported (25) that a mutation of the BAT coding sequence causes human familial hypercholanemia that is characterized by elevated serum BA, and serum of homozygous individuals for this mutation contains only unconjugated BAs.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Because serum unconjugated BAs are increased, but most BAs in the gallbladder are conjugated forms in liver-specific HNF4-null mice, protein and enzyme activity of VLACSR and BAT might still be active in these mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	242	 In human disease, mutations in the HNF4-binding sites were reported in HNF1, blood coagulation factor VII, and IX (9).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Because HNF4 regulates many liver-enriched genes, human diseases might be found to be caused by mutations of the HNF4-binding sites in the VLACSR and BAT genes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	244	It was reported that the expression of BAL and BAT is induced by treatment with ligands for the farnesoid X receptor (FXR) in rat, and this induction was due to the binding of FXR to FXR-binding sites in their promoter regions (26).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Because this phenomenon was not observed in mouse, regulation of both genes by FXR exhibits a species difference between rat and mouse (26).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Actually, neither VLACSR nor BAT gene was induced in wild-type mice treated with cholic acid, a ligand for FXR (data not shown).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Unlike other nuclear receptors including FXR, HNF4 is constitutively activated in vivo and in vitro without exogenous compounds (9).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Thus, HNF4 positively regulates the basal levels of expression of the VLACSR and BAT genes.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	249	 It may also be involved in the regulation of transporters such as OATP1 and NTCP that are required for hepatocyte uptake of conjugated BAs from the portal circulation (Fig.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	250	View larger version (25K):    FIG.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Schematic representation of regulatory targets of HNF4 in bile acid transport and conjugation.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Bile acids, conjugated by VLACSR and BAT, are exported from hepatocytes by transporters such as bile salt export pump located at the canalicular membrane.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Most bile acids are recycled and transported from the portal circulation back into hepatocytes by transporters including NTCP and OATP1 located at the basolateral membrane.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Expression of OATP1, NTCP, VLACSR, and BAT is reduced in liver-specific HNF4-null mice.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Note that HNF4 directly regulates the expression of VLACSR and BAT via HNF4-binding sites in their promoters.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	256	  Many nuclear receptors including FXR are involved in regulating the BA biosynthesis pathway and transport system (6, 14, 15).
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Thus, these nuclear receptors also might have important roles in inducing or repressing the expression of VLACSR and BAT to regulate the BA conjugation pathway.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	258	   FOOTNOTES   * The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	259	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	261	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Laboratory of Metabolism, Center for Cancer Research, NCI, National Institutes of Health, 9000 Rockville Pike, Bldg.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	262	: 301-496-9067; Fax: 301-496-8419; E-mail: fjgonz{at}helix.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	263	1 The abbreviations used are: BAs, bile acids; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4; BAL, bile acid-CoA ligase; BAT, bile acid-CoA:amino acid N-acyltransferase; VLACSR, very long chain acyl-CoA synthase-related; NTCP, sodium taurocholate cotransporter polypeptide; OATP1, organic anion transporter polypeptide 1; LC-MS/MS, liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry; MCA, muricholic acid; GDCA, glycodeoxycholic acid; GCDCA, glycochenodeoxycholic acid; TCA, taurocholic acid; T--MCA tauro--muricholic acid; TDCA, taurodeoxycholic acid; TCDCA, taurochenodeoxycholic acid; WT, wild-type; FXR, farnesoid X receptor.
0.22037566.14583614.html.plaintext.txt	264	   REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Vlahcevic, R.
