0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Integrase of the Long Terminal Repeat-Retrotransposon Tf1 Has a Chromodomain That Modulates Integrase Activities* Amnon Hizi1 and Henry L.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Section on Eukaryotic Transposable Elements, Laboratory of Gene Regulation and Development, NICHD, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, June 10, 2005 , and in revised form, August 11, 2005.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Chromodomains in a variety of proteins mediate the formation of heterochromatin by interacting directly with histone H3, DNA, or RNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	4	 A diverse family of long terminal repeat (LTR)-retrotransposons possesses chromodomains in their integrases (IN), suggesting that the chromodomains may control integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The LTR-retrotransposon Tf1 of Schizosaccharomyces pombe is highly active and possesses a chromodomain in the COOH terminus of its IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	6	 To test this chromodomain for a role in integration, recombinant INs with and without the chromodomain were assayed for activity in in vitro reactions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The full-length IN had integration activity with oligonucleotide substrates that modeled both the insertion reaction and a reverse reaction known as disintegration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The INs of retroviruses possess an additional activity termed 3' processing that must remove 2-3 nucleotides from the 3' ends of the viral cDNA before insertion can occur.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These additional nucleotides are added during reverse transcription because of the position of the minus strand primer downstream of the LTR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The position of the primer for Tf1 suggests no nucleotides are added 3' of the LTR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	11	 It was therefore surprising that Tf1 IN was capable of 3' cleavage.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The most unexpected result reported here was that the IN lacking the chromodomain had significantly higher activity and substantially reduced substrate specificity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These results reveal that both the activity and specificity of enzymes can be modulated by their chromodomains.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	14	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Post-translational modifications of histones, such as the acetylation or methylation of lysines, establish the accessibility of DNA to the transcription machinery (1-3).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Conserved domains that recognize these specific modifications exist in a variety of factors that interact with the histones and propagate the structures of chromatin (4-6).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	16	 A large family of proteins that regulate chromatin structure bind specifically to histone H3 with methylated lysines using a conserved module called a chromodomain (6, 7).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although all the chromodomains studied thus far function to regulate chromatin structure, sequence analyses revealed large families of long terminal repeat (LTR)3-retrotransposons with chromodomains in the COOH termini of their INs (8, 9).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	18	 This is intriguing because it suggests that the transposons acquired chromodomains to regulate integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	19	LTR-retrotransposons are closely related to retroviruses.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Both types of elements encode Gag, protease, reverse transcriptase, and IN proteins and both depend on IN to insert their cDNA into the genome of a host cell.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The LTRs, positioned at the ends of the cDNA, are subdivided into an upstream segment, U3, a central region, R, and a downstream segment, U5.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	22	 A large number of biochemical studies with purified IN have characterized the chemistry of insertion (10-12).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The INs of retroviruses have two activities that are necessary for the integration of the viral cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	24	 At first, 2 or 3 nucleotides are removed from the 3' ends of the LTRs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	25	 This site-specific nucleolytic cleavage or "3' processing reaction" is required to position the "CA" dinucleotides at the 3' ends of the cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The CA dinucleotides are conserved among all retroviruses and their position at the 3' ends of the cDNA is required for the second step of retrovirus integration, the "strand transfer reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	27	" During this second step, the 3' hydroxyls of the terminal "A" act as nucleophiles in a pair of transesterification reactions that cleave the phosphodiester bonds in the target DNA and simultaneously make a covalent bond between the 3' ends of the viral DNA and the 5' ends of the target DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	28	In retroviruses, the minus strand primers initiate reverse transcription 2 or 3 nucleotides from the LTR and this results in additional nucleotides at the cDNA termini that IN removes during the processing reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In the case of most LTR-retrotransposons the minus strand primers initiate reverse transcription with no added nucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	30	 As a result, these LTR-retrotransposons are thought to proceed to the strand transfer reaction without a processing step (13).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	31	The INs of retroviruses have three protease-resistant domains and the functions of these domains have been studied extensively (12, 14, 15).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The NH2-terminal domain contains a conserved motif similar to zinc fingers.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Although this domain does bind zinc, little else is known about its function.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The central domain is the catalytic core that contains highly conserved acidic residues, Asp, Asp, and Glu, that are juxtaposed on an RNase H-like fold.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	35	 These three amino acids are conserved in all the INs of retroviruses, LTR-retrotransposons, and DNA transposons (16).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The central domain of HIV-1 IN was shown to be sufficient for catalytic activity in in vitro assays for the reverse reaction of strand transfer known as disintegration (17).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The COOH-terminal domain is less well conserved but has nonspecific binding activity to DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Although the structure of individual domains has been determined for several INs, no single structure yet contains all three domains (18).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	39	Tf1 of Schizosaccharomyces pombe is one of the LTR-retrotransposons that contains a chromodomain at the COOH terminus of IN (8).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Its high level of transposition activity allows Tf1 to be studied as a model for reverse transcription and integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Expression of Tf1 from a high copy plasmid results in the formation of virus-like particles, the reverse transcription of the Tf1 mRNA, and the integration of the cDNA into intergenic sequences (19-21).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	42	 A novel mechanism of self-priming initiates minus strand reverse transcription from the upstream LTR (22).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	43	 After initiation, reverse transcription proceeds through the same intermediates typical of other LTR elements.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The IN of Tf1 that inserts this cDNA into the genome of S.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	45	 pombe contains putative zinc binding, catalytic core, and COOH-terminal domains that are necessary for integration (23).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Mutation analysis indicated that its high level of activity and the tools available to study it make Tf1 uniquely suited for examining the function of the chromodomain in integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	47	In this report the activities of Tf1 IN and the function of its chromodomain were studied.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	48	 IN and IN without the chromodomain (CH-) were expressed in bacteria and purified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Biochemical assays for disintegration and strand transfer showed that IN possessed substantial activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Because Tf1 cDNA was predicted to terminate with CA, it was surprising that IN also had strong 3' processing activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	51	 This indicates that the position of the minus strand primer relative to the LTR is not sufficient to predict the presence of processing activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The most unexpected result was that CH- had significantly higher specific activity than IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In addition, CH- was much less dependent on specific sequences at the termini of the donor DNA than was IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	54	 These results reveal that the chromodomain in the Tf1 IN modulates both the level and specificity of integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	55	   EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Plasmid Constructions and Cell Growth The construction of pHL2468, the plasmid for the expression of the full-length Tf1 IN has been previously described (19).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Briefly, the IN-coding DNA segment of Tf1 was amplified by PCR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The resulting fragment was flanked with SalI sites that were introduced into the BamHI site of pET15B and sequenced.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The NH2 terminus of the Tf1 IN was predicted based on the amino terminus of the IN from a closely related element, Ty3 (24).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The NH2 terminus of the recombinant Tf1 IN started with the sequence TDDFK- and the COOH terminus ended with the sequence -NNLNI.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The resulting protein was 477 residues long and was fused at its amino terminus to a 21-residue peptide containing the His6 tag and the thrombin cleavage site.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The plasmid expressing CH-, pHL2469, generated by a similar method.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The CH-, coding DNA segment was amplified by PCR with the primers HL1167 and HL1168, using the Pfu Turbo thermostable DNA polymerase (Stratagene).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The DNA generated was cleaved with NdeI and BamHI, cloned into the vector pET15b, and sequenced.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The CH- protein had the same amino terminus as the full-length IN but ended with the sequence -RHNSE.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Altogether CH- was 406 + 21 (tag) residues long.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Both plasmids were introduced into the strain BL21.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The bacteria were grown in LB broth supplemented with 100  microg/ml of carbenicillin.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The culture temperature was 32  degrees C and the cells were grown until they reached an A600 of about 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Induction was performed with 1 mM isopropyl 1-thio--D-galactopyranoside for an additional period of 3 h at 32 degrees C.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The cells were harvested, and the pellets were stored at -80  degrees C.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	71	Purification of the Recombinant Full-length IN and CH- Proteins All steps were performed at 4  degrees C, unless otherwise stated.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	72	Lysis of the Bacteria The bacterial pellets were brought up in 50 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 8.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	73	1 M NaCl, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	74	 After a thorough mixing, the solutions were kept for 15 min on ice followed by the addition of more NaCl to a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Then, the solutions were sonicated on ice, followed by the addition of Triton X-100 to a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	76	 We have found that the presence of this detergent is critical to dissociate the recombinant INs off the bacterial DNA (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The insoluble material was removed by ultracentrifugation for 1 h in the Beckman SW28 rotor at 26,000 rpm and the clear yellowish supernatants were subjected to affinity purification.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	78	Affinity Purification on Sepharose-Co2+ Columns Sepharose-Co2+ columns (BD Talon, BD Biosciences) with bed volumes of 5 ml were equilibrated with 50 mM sodium phosphate, pH 8.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	79	5 M NaCl, 10% (v/v) glycerol, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	80	1% Triton X-100, and then loaded with the supernatant from the ultracentrifugation.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The column was then washed twice, once with 50 mM sodium phosphate, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	82	1% Triton X-100, and the second with the same buffer, supplemented with 20 mM imidazole.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Elution was performed with the same buffer but with a final concentration of 50 mM imidazole.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The fractions were all analyzed by SDS-PAGE, and the peak IN protein fractions were pooled and dialyzed against 50 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	85	5, 10% glycerol, 10 mM MgSO4, 1 mM EDTA, 2 mM dithiothreitol, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The proteins were fully soluble after this dialysis.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	87	Heparin-Sepharose Column Purification Five-ml heparin-Sepharose (6, Fast Flow, Amersham Biosciences) columns were pre-washed with about 100 ml of the same buffer used for dialysis, and then loaded with the dialyzed protein solution.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The same buffer was also used for extensive washing (about 500 ml) of the column after loading was completed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Finally, the proteins were eluted off the affinity resin with a similar buffer, supplemented with NaCl at a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The recombinant INs emerged off the columns at sharp peaks with protein concentrations as high as 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The proteins were stored at -80  degrees C in small aliquots.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Each aliquot was thawed only once for conducting the enzymatic assays.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	93	Oligonucleotides All oligonucleotides were gel purified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Their sequences and designations are presented in the supplemental material.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	95	Substrates Used in IN Assays The appropriate DNA oligonucleotides were 5' end-labeled.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	96	4  microg of each oligo were 32P end-labeled using 20 units of T4 polynucleotide kinase (New England Biolabs), and 100  microCi of [-32P]ATP in a final volume of 20  microl using the buffer supplied.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	97	 After an incubation of 1 h at 37 degrees C, 1  microl of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	98	25 M EDTA was added to each sample and the mixtures were treated for 5 min at 95  degrees C to inactivate the enzyme.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	99	 After adding NaCl to a final concentration of 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	100	1 M and increasing the volume to 40  microl, the labeled DNA was annealed to three times the equimolar ratio of the appropriate non-labeled DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	101	 After 5 min at 95  degrees C, the mixtures were allowed to cool slowly to room temperature for about 2 h.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The duplexes generated were then stored at -20  degrees C and were used after freezing and thawing for up to 1 month.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	103	Assays for IN Activities Unless otherwise stated, assays of IN and CH- were performed in final volumes of 20  microl containing 25 mM MOPS-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	104	2, 4% (w/v) polyethylene glycol 8000, 10% (v/v) glycerol, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	105	25% (v/v) of freshly prepared dimethyl sulfoxide, and 1 mM MnCl2.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Each reaction mixture contained between 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	107	2 and 1  microg of the enzymes and 1 pmol of the labeled DNA substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Incubations were performed for 1 h at 37  degrees C, and reactions were stopped by adding 10  microl of formamide loading buffer (95% formamide, 20 mM EDTA, 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	109	5 mg/ml xylene cyanole FF) to each sample.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The samples were then treated for 3 min at 95  degrees C, quickly cooled on ice and loaded on an 8 M urea, 13.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	111	5% (w/v) polyacrylamide sequencing gel in Tris borate/EDTA buffer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	112	 After electrophoresis, the wet gels were subjected to phosphorimaging, using an Amersham Biosciences Storm 840 instrument.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	113	View larger version (26K):    FIGURE 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	114	 SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of the purified recombinant Tf1 proteins.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The purification of the Tf1 IN and CH- proteins was performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	116	" One  microg of each purified protein and a mixture of size markers (M) containing 1  microg of protein in each band were loaded onto a 10% polyacrylamide-urea gel.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Following electrophoresis the proteins were stained with Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	118	  Purified recombinant HIV-1 IN (a generous gift of R.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Craigie) was assayed with the specified substrates under the optimal conditions of this enzyme that differ from those suitable to the Tf1 enzymes.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Reactions were performed each in 20  microl of 25 mM MOPS-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	121	1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, 10% glycerol, 10 mM -mercaptoethanol, 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	122	 All other steps, including preparation of the substrates, incubation times, and analyses of the reaction products were performed as described for the Tf1 INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	123	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Recombinant IN and CH- of Tf1 Have Significant Levels of Disintegration Activity To investigate the function of the chromodomain in Tf1 IN we studied the integration activities of the full-length IN and of a truncated IN that lacked the chromodomain (CH-).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Both proteins were expressed with His6 tags in bacteria and were purified to a high degree using chromatography with Co2+-agarose (Talon, BD Biosciences) followed by chromatography with heparin-Sepharose (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	125	Under in vitro conditions INs can catalyze the reverse of DNA strand transfer in a reaction designated disintegration (10).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	126	 This activity can be assayed using oligonucleotides that mimic a single ended insertion (25-27).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The disintegration activity of Tf1 IN was studied first because the substrate sequence and structural requirements for this reaction are less stringent than those for the forward reactions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	128	The model substrate designed to measure disintegration activity is shown in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The 5' end of the target DNA was labeled with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The reaction results in a concerted cleavage-ligation where the donor DNA is excised and the disrupted target is repaired.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This results in the production of a 63-nt product labeled with 32P at its 5' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Because of its size, the 63-nt product could be readily distinguished from the initial species labeled with 32P, the 20-nt substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Separate substrates were designed that mimicked either the U3 or U5 ends of the Tf1 LTR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The IN and CH- proteins produced substantial amounts of the 63-nt product using either the U3 or U5 substrates (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	135	 We tested whether the disintegration substrates as designed for Tf1 IN could be recognized by another IN, that of HIV-1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Interestingly, HIV-1 IN is at least as active with the U3 and U5 substrates as the two Tf1 INs (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	137	 This is despite the low homology between the Tf1 and HIV-1 sequences at the ends of their donor DNAs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (39K):    FIGURE 2.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The disintegration assay of Tf1 IN and CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	140	 A, schematic of the disintegration reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The substrates for disintegration were oligonucleotides that mimicked one end of the Tf1 DNA inserted into a target.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The 5' end of the target DNA, indicated with an asterisk, was labeled with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The disintegration reaction results in the cleavage of the phosphodiester bond 3' to the terminal sequence, ACA, and the ligation of the labeled oligonucleotide to the remainder of the target molecule.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This led to an increase in the length of the 5' end-labeled oligonucleotide from 20 to 63 nt.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	145	 B, the disintegration activity of Tf1 IN, CH-, and HIV-1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Enzymatic reactions were conducted with equal amounts of the U3 or U5 substrates and 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The reaction products were resolved by electrophoresis on a urea-polyacrylamide sequencing gel.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The control lane shows a reaction mixture incubated with no enzyme and the U3 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The control with the U5 substrate looked the same as the U3 (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The molecular weight markers (M) were HinFI fragments of X174 that were labeled on their 5' ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	151	  To optimize the reaction conditions we measured the influence of NaCl, MnCl2, and MgCl2 on the activities of IN and CH- (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	152	 NaCl greatly inhibited the activities of both proteins and a strong preference for MnCl2 over MgCl2 was observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The highest disintegration activity was obtained with 25 mM MOPS-NaOH, pH 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	154	2, 4% polyethylene glycol 8000, 10% glycerol, 5 mM dithiothreitol, 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Other additives, often used to enhance IN activities, such as, bovine serum albumin, spermidine, Triton X-100, or Me2SO at final concentrations above 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	156	25% were all found to inhibit the Tf1 INs (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	157	Having established the assay conditions for the Tf1 IN and the CH enzymes, dose-dependent reactions were performed with increasing amounts of each protein.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The quantitative data presented in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	159	 4 show that for the U3 substrate the activity of IN increased with protein content up to 275 ng, whereas no maximum was observed with the U5 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The data with CH- revealed the surprising result that the CH- protein was substantially more active than the full-length IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Although this was true for both the U3 and U5 substrates, it was with the U3 substrate that CH- exhibited the greatest increase in activity over that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	162	Recombinant IN and CH- Possess Strand Transfer Activities Strand transfer assays are a more relevant measure of IN activities because they represent the forward reaction of integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The strand transfer activities of IN and CH- were assayed to determine whether these proteins were capable of mediating integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The substrates for these assays were double-stranded oligonucleotides designated to mimic either the U3 or U5 ends of Tf1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Initially, we used double-stranded oligonucleotides with blunt ends that terminated with the CA dinucleotide (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The oligonucleotide with the 3' CA was labeled at its 5' end with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Strand transfer results in the insertion of the oligonucleotides into other identical molecules and as a result oligonucleotides are created that are both bigger and smaller than their original size (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	168	 We found that the conditions established for the disintegration reaction are also optimal for the strand transfer activity of the Tf1 enzymes (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (17K):    FIGURE 3.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The effect of NaCl and divalent cations on the disintegration activities of IN and CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	171	 These assays were performed with the U3 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The reaction products were subjected to electrophoresis and the gels were scanned with a phosphorimager.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	173	 A, the dependence of disintegration activity on NaCl.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Increasing amounts of NaCl were added to the reaction mixtures.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Reactions were performed with 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The disintegration activity is expressed for each point as a percentage of the maximal activity observed at the lowest NaCl concentration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	177	 B, the effects of divalent cations on the disintegration activity of Tf1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The disintegration activity of 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	179	1  microg of Tf1 IN was measured with increasing concentrations of either MnCl2 or MgCl2.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The levels of conversion were calculated as described in A.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The activity for each divalent cation is expressed as a percentage of maximal activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	182	 C, the effects of divalent cations on the disintegration activity of CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The disintegration activity was assayed and quantified as described in B, except that each reaction contained 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	184	 5B shows that relative to protein dose, both the IN and CH- generated oligonucleotide products longer than the original U3 and U5 substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The lengths of these products varied because the integration into the acceptor DNA was relatively random.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	186	 However, it was apparent for both IN and CH- that with the U5 substrate there were preferred positions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Interestingly, a significant fraction of the extended products were longer than twice the size of the 24-nt substrate and products as long as 70-mers were observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This indicates that both versions of Tf1 INs were capable of three or more integration events in which products of the first round of integration served as substrates for further integration events.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	189	 To our knowledge, such multiple round integrations have not been reported for other INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	190	We tested whether the chromodomain played a role in strand transfer by comparing the activity of IN to CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	191	 To evaluate the levels of strand transfer activity we calculated the amount of the oligonucleotide species longer than 24 nt as a percentage of the total amount of the labeled oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	192	 5C shows that CH- was substantially more active than IN with both the U3 and U5 ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The elevated activity of CH- correlated well with the results of the disintegration assays.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	194	 However, the difference between the strand transfer activity of CH- and IN was more pronounced than observed for disintegration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The maximal differences in activity between CH- and IN were approximately 7- and 4-fold when observed with the U3 and U5 end-derived substrates, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	196	 These results indicate that the presence of the chromodomain inhibits both the disintegration and strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (18K):    FIGURE 4.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The disintegration activities of IN and CH- in assays with increasing amounts of protein.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The reactions were conducted with either the U3 or U5 substrates and increasing amounts of Tf1 IN or CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The proteins were diluted in the buffer used to store the proteins (50 mM HEPES-NaOH, 10% glycerol, 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	201	05% Me2SO, 2 mM dithiothreitol, and 0.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	202	2) and equal volumes of the protein samples were added to each reaction.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	203	 After the reaction, products were subjected to electrophoresis and the gels were scanned with a phosphorimager.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	204	  CH- and IN Possess 3' End Processing Activity It is currently thought that the role of the 3' end processing activity of INs is solely to remove the 2 or 3 nucleotides 3' of the CA that result from the position of the minus strand primer 2 or 3 nucleotides downstream of the first LTR.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The primer for the minus strand of Tf1 is positioned adjacent to the LTR so it is predicted that no processing activity is required (28, 29).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	206	 However, sequences of Tf1 cDNA extracted from particles revealed the surprising result that 85% of the 3' ends had one or more untemplated nucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	207	4 Because these nucleotides are added to the 3' ends after the CA dinucleotide, they are expected to block integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	208	 We therefore speculated that Tf1 IN would have a processing activity that would remove these nucleotides to expose the CA dinucleotides and allow integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	209	We tested IN and CH- for the 3' processing activity using the assay already described for the strand transfer activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In this case, the 5' end-labeled substrates contained nucleotides positioned 3' to the critical CA (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Processing activity would cause a reduction in length of the labeled substrate after the extra sequences are removed from the 3' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	212	Processing the U5 End of the LTR The IN and CH- enzymes were tested for processing activity using a set of substrates that mimicked the U5 end of the LTR with sequences that extended past the conserved CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Each of the oligonucleotide pairs were designed such that processing activity that removes nucleotides 3' of the CA would produce the same 24-nt product.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The 3' end extensions were either in the form of a single-stranded overhang (Ov) beyond the CA or they were base paired in the form of a blunt end (Bl).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The sequences of the extensions were chosen based on their presence at the 3' ends of the DNAs that were isolated in vivo from particles.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	216	 For example, the most prominent sequences observed after the U3 and U5 ends were "TT" and "AT," respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	217	4 In addition, longer stretches of "T"s were observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	218	As indicated by the 24-nt product, both IN and CH- exhibited processing activity that specifically removed the nucleotides 3' of the CA (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The processing activity of IN produced the 24-nt sequence as the dominant product from the substrates with "tt," "at," "ttt," and "ttttt" as single-stranded extensions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	220	 In the one case of a substrate with a Bl end ("at"), IN generated the 24-nt species along with several other smaller products.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	221	 These additional products are seen to a lesser extent with the other substrates and are likely because of nonspecific nuclease activity of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	222	 This type of nonspecific activity is observed with other INs (30).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	223	 It is reported that a variety of INs possess an intrinsic DNA hydrolysis or alcoholysis activity that is responsible for nonspecific nuclease activity similar to what we observed (31).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	224	View larger version (41K):    FIGURE 5.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The strand transfer activities of IN and CH-.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	226	 A, a schematic diagram of the strand transfer assay of the Tf1 IN and CH- enzymes with pre-processed substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	227	 B, the electrophoretic analyses of the products of the strand transfer reactions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	228	 For the U3 end, oligonucleotide HL1034 was 5' end-labeled and annealed to oligonucleotide HL1033.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	229	 For the U5 end, oligonucleotide HL1039 was 5' end-labeled and annealed to oligonucleotide HL1040.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Decreasing amounts of each enzyme were incubated with either substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The products were resolved electrophoretically.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The lanes marked 0 contained a reaction incubated with no enzyme.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The following are the lane numbers and the amounts of protein, expressed in  microg, used for each reaction: for IN: 1, 1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The protein dilutions were done as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The size markers included a disintegration reaction performed with U5 substrate and Tf1 IN, as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Also included as markers was the X174 DNA cleaved with HinFI and 5' end-labeled.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	237	 C, quantitative analyses of strand transfer activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The radioactivity in the gel shown in B was scanned with a phosphorimager.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The radioactivity in all the bands larger than 24 nt was calculated as the percentage of the total radioactivity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The activities are expressed as the percent of conversion.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	241	  For retrovirus INs, the product of the processing activity is the only substrate suitable for strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Therefore, reactions with efficient processing activity also exhibit strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The processing activity of Tf1 IN with either the "at " or "tt" extensions was high and strand transfer was detected (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The processing activity with the 3- and 5-nucleotide extensions was less efficient and no strand transfer was observed.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Thus, the IN of Tf1 was similar to INs of retroviruses in that processing was required for strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	246	The amounts of processed products accumulated by CH- were similar to that of IN (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	247	 However, CH- generated substantially more products of strand transfer than IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The levels of these strand transfer products greater than 24 nt were quantified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The activity of CH- with all substrates was significantly higher than that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	250	 For example, the activities with the tt-Ov was 57% and with at-Ov was 38% relative to that produced with the pre-processed substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The comparable figures for IN were 11 and 15%, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Because the increase in strand transfer requires enhanced 3' end processing, these data indicate that the 3' end processing activity of CH- is higher than that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	253	The efficient processing of the U5 substrates suggested that the Tf1 proteins specifically recognized and removed the extensions beyond the CA dinucleotide.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	254	 To test whether other sequences in the substrate were recognized, IN and CH- were assayed for activity using a substrate with the U5 sequence of HIV-1 (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The HIV-1 substrate was 21 nt long and had the physiological GT extension 3' of the CA dinucleotide.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Processing activity would reduce the 21-nt species to 19 nt.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Compared with the processing activity of HIV-1 IN with this substrate, the Tf1 proteins exhibited very little activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	258	 This indicates that in addition to the CA dinucleotide, the Tf1 proteins recognize sequence in the U5 substrate specific for Tf1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	259	 It was also seen that HIV-1 IN did not utilize the Tf1 pre-processed substrates (data not shown).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	260	Processing the U3 End of the LTR Retroviral INs have processing activities that remove extensions 3' of the CA from both the U5 and U3 ends of the cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Because the Tf1 proteins were found to have processing activity on the U5 end, we tested whether they could also process extensions from the U3 end of Tf1.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The results show that both CH- and IN can remove nucleotides 3' of the CA in the U3 sequence (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	263	 As seen with the U5 substrates, the shorter extensions on the U3 substrates were processed more efficiently than those with longer extensions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The cleavages of the Ov versions were somewhat more efficient than the Bl counterparts.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	265	The processing activity of CH- with 3-, 5-, and 6-nucleotide extensions was significantly greater than that of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	266	 However, comparing the activities of the proteins with the shorter extensions was complex because the strong strand transfer activity of CH- reduced the accumulation of the processed species.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	267	 To approximate the processing activities of IN and CH-, the levels of strand transfer were quantified.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	268	 As found above for the U5 substrates, CH- exhibited substantially higher levels of activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	269	 For example, the activities with tt-Ov was 88%, with tt-Bl was 32%, and with ttt-Ov was 19% of that produced with the pre-processed substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	270	 The comparable figures for IN were 11 and 4%, and not detectable, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	271	Strand Transfer Activities Require Pre-processing of the Extensions 3' to CA The processing activities of IN and CH- were estimated by measuring the products of the subsequent strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	272	 This was done because the products of processing can be readily converted by strand transfer activity into larger oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	273	 However, the accumulated products of strand transfer would be an overestimate of processing if the Tf1 proteins could mediate strand transfer with substrates that retained nucleotide extensions 3' to the CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	274	 To test this possibility, strand transfer reactions were conducted with substrates that possessed a2',3'-dideoxynucleotide at their 3' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Unless removed by processing, this substrate would lack the necessary 3' hydroxyl and as a result it would block strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	276	View larger version (49K):    FIGURE 6.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	277	 The 3' end processing and strand transfer activities with the U5 substrates of Tf1 and with an HIV-1 substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	278	 A, a schematic diagram of the 3' processing assay shows the oligonucleotides annealed to mimic the U5 and U3 ends of Tf1 DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	279	 The asterisk indicates the 5' end of the oligonucleotide with the conserved CA labeled with 32P.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	280	 B, the electrophoretic analyses of the reaction products of the 3' processing assays.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Reactions were conducted with equal amounts of the specified substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The sequence from the 3' end of the substrates are shown above the lanes and extensions 3' to the conserved ACA are indicated in lowercase.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The substrate with the pre-processed end (ACA) was blunt ended and was the same one used in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Substrates marked with Bl are double-stranded oligonucleotides with blunt ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Those marked Ov have 3' overhangs corresponding to the sequence in lowercase.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Other reactions were performed with a blunt ended substrate that mimics the U5 end of HIV-1 DNA with the additional two nucleotides, gt, 3' to the conserved CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	287	 To generate this substrate the oligonucleotide RZ132 was 5' end-labeled and annealed to oligonucleotide RZ61.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The enzymatic reactions performed with Tf1 IN, Tf1 CH-, and HIV-1 IN were marked with a +, and those without enzyme were marked with a -.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The positions of the labeled oligonucleotides are indicated as 24 or 21 nt for the Tf1 or HIV-1 substrates, respectively.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	290	  The experiment described in Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	291	 8 tested the U3 substrate of Tf1 that had 3' ends with the sequence "-ACA-tt(dd)c.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	292	" This substrate was compared with the control substrate that ended with a "c" instead of (dd)c.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Two variants of each DNA, one with a single-stranded Ov and the other with the Bl configuration were tested.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The CH- protein exhibited high levels of strand transfer with the blocked substrate ACA(t)2ddc-Ov, which were not significantly different from that with the unblocked DNA, ACA(t)2c-Ov.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	295	 This indicated that the strand transfer occurred only after an efficient removal of the blocking sequence.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	296	 The strand transfer activity with the Ov substrates was substantially greater than seen with the Bl versions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	297	 The full-length IN did not show significant activity with either the modified or unmodified substrates (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	298	The Strand Transfer Activity of Tf1 IN but Not CH- Specifically Requires That "ACA" Be Present at the 3' End of the Substrate The strand transfer activities of retrovirus and retrotransposon INs require that the highly conserved CA dinucleotide be present at the 3' end of the donor substrate (30).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	299	 We tested whether the IN of Tf1 had this same requirement for CA and whether the chromodomain contributed to this specificity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	300	 IN and CH- were tested for whether each of the last three nucleotides of the LTRs, ACA was necessary for strand transfer (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	301	 The substrates were based on the U3 double-stranded donor used in Figs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	302	 7 and 8 that lacked extensions 3' of the ACA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Thus, no 3' processing was required.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Single, double, and triple substitutions were made in the ACA to test the dependence on this triplet.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	305	 All the modifications introduced in the sequence led to a dramatic reduction of the strand transfer activity of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	306	 In sharp contrast to IN, CH- was capable of strand transfer with most of the substituted substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Except for the substrate in which all three terminal nucleotides were flipped (tgt), CH- had greater than 10% of the activity observed with the unsubstituted substrate.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	308	 The most striking difference between CH- and IN was with the substrate with a -1 transition (AtA).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	309	 CH- retained 50% of the activity observed with the ACA terminus, whereas the full-length IN had just 1% activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	310	 This large difference in the specificity of the two related proteins shows that IN was far more stringent than the CH- counterpart in selecting the DNA donor with the correct 3' end.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	311	View larger version (83K):    FIGURE 7.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The 3' processing and strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN and CH- with U3 substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	313	 The reactions were conducted with equal amounts of the specified substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	314	 The labeling of the substrates above each lane is as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	315	 The reactions performed with the specified enzymes are marked with + and those without enzyme are marked with -.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	316	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   In this study the IN of the LTR-retrotransposon Tf1 was produced as a recombinant, soluble and enzymatically active protein.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Tf1 IN exhibited in vitro all the enzymatic activities expected for an IN from either a retrovirus or an LTR-retrotransposon.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The presence of a chromodomain in the COOH terminus of Tf1 IN provided a unique opportunity to study the impact of such a domain on IN activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Our results demonstrate that the chromodomain had a surprising influence on the specific activity of the IN as well as on its recognition of donor DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	320	Although the disintegration activity may not have direct biological relevance, it is particularly useful for biochemical characterization of INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	321	 It provides a highly sensitive assay for the cleavage-ligation activity of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	322	 The disintegration assay developed here for Tf1 IN was used to optimize the reaction conditions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	323	 The increased activities of Tf1 IN with low concentrations of NaCl (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	324	 3A) were similar to what was observed with retroviral INs (26, 33).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Because magnesium is thought to be the important divalent metal in vivo, the preference Tf1 IN had for manganese might be the result of structural defects in the recombinant protein.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	326	 However, the preference for manganese could be a common property of INs as the INs of HIV-1 and murine leukemia virus also exhibit strong preferences for manganese over magnesium in vitro (26, 33).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The ability of HIV-IN to react efficiently with the Tf1 substrate (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	328	 2) suggested that the disintegration activity of HIV-1 IN had little sequence specificity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	329	 This is consistent with data from several studies indicating that beyond the requirement for the CA, the disintegration activity of retroviral INs is not sequence specific (25, 34-36).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	330	The full-length version of Tf1 IN was found to have substantial levels of strand transfer activity with both the U3 and U5 substrates.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The genomes of eukaryotes accumulate large numbers of inactive retrotransposons.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	332	 The strand transfer assay is a stringent test of IN function, and the activity of Tf1 IN detected here indicates that this protein was fully active.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Strand transfer assays with substrates containing nucleotides 3' to the CA revealed that the Tf1 IN also had 3' processing activity (Figs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	334	 This was observed with U3 and U5 substrates and with single and double-stranded extensions.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	335	 As is the case with the 3' end processing activity of HIV-1 IN, extensions longer than 2 nucleotides were more readily removed when they were single-stranded than when double-stranded (37).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	336	View larger version (88K):    FIGURE 8.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	337	 The 3' end processing and strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN and CH- with substrates that contained blocked 3' ends.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Substrates ending with a 3'-terminal dideoxy C are indicated by ddc.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	339	 The experiment was performed and the annotations are as described in the legend to Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	340	  In one respect, the processing activity was quite unexpected.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	341	 It was thought that the 3' end processing activity of retroviruses and LTR-retrotransposons is required only in the cases where the priming of minus strand reverse transcription adds nucleotides beyond the conserved CA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	342	 For Tf1, the 3' end of the minus strand primer is immediately adjacent to the U5 sequence of the upstream LTR (28, 29).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	343	 As a result, no extensions and no processing were thought to occur.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	344	 However, recent analyses of Tf1 cDNA extracted from particles revealed that 85% of the U3 and U5 ends terminated with nontemplated nucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	345	4 The processing activity of IN observed here could in theory remove these 3' extensions and allow the bulk of the cDNA to participate in integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	346	 This model raises the question why would nontemplated nucleotides be added just so they could be removed by IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	347	 One possibility is that the nontemplated nucleotides could prevent aberrant annealing of the 3' end to sequences in the opposite LTR and its subsequent extension.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	348	 As a result, the nontemplated nucleotides would protect the completed cDNA until IN initiates 3' processing.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	349	 Another possibility is that the nontemplated nucleotides could protect the conserved CA from attack by nonspecific 3' exonucleases.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	350	View larger version (64K):    FIGURE 9.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	351	 The strand transfer activities of Tf1 IN and CH- with U3 substrates that contained sequence modifications of the terminal ACA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	352	 The modifications were marked by lowercase letters.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	353	 The activities with the modified substrates were compared with that of the pre-processed substrate (ACA).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	354	 All substrates tested possessed blunt ends and were used in equal amounts.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	355	 The reactions were conducted either in the presence of the specified enzyme (+) or in the absence of enzyme (-).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	356	  The LTR-retrotransposon Ty3 of Saccharomyces cerevisiae does contain an IN with 3' processing activity and this was predicted based on the position of its minus strand primer (38).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Nevertheless, most other LTR-retrotransposons such as Ty1 have minus strand primers immediately adjacent to the U5 sequence of their LTR and are not thought to have processing (39).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	358	 The finding that Tf1 IN has processing activity brings into question the predicted lack of processing activity in the INs of the other LTR-retrotransposons.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Approximately 25% of Ty1 cDNA terminates with nontemplated nucleotides (40).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	360	 The cDNA with the nontemplated additions could participate in integration only if the IN has processing activity.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	361	 However, analyses of Ty1 IN failed to detect processing activity (41, 42).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	362	The removal of nontemplated nucleotides by IN may also occur with retroviral cDNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	363	 In vitro experiments show that HIV-1 reverse transcriptase possesses terminal transferase activity that adds nontemplated nucleotides to the 3' end of the nascent DNA (43-45).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	364	 A time course of reverse transcription during HIV-1 infection identified a prominent species of cDNA that had one nucleotide extra on the 3' end of the plus strand (46).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	365	 This led the authors to propose that the extra nucleotide was the result of nontemplated addition and that the 3' processing activity of IN removed it.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	366	Perhaps the most striking results presented in this report indicate a role for the chromodomain in modulating integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Although removing 15% of IN might be expected to reduce activity substantially, the deletion of the chromodomain resulted in a intriguing increase in the disintegration and strand transfer activities.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	368	 CH- also had greater 3' processing activity than IN, assuming that the greater amounts of strand transfer products generated were all derived from processed oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Evidence supporting this assumption was that oligonucleotides with the blocking nucleotide (dd)c 3' of the CA were just as efficiently converted into products of strand transfer by CH- as oligonucleotides without the (dd)c block (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	370	 These data indicate that the chromodomain of Tf1 IN negatively modulates the IN activities.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	371	In addition to its role in limiting integration activity, the chromodomain had a significant impact in restricting the sequence at the 3' end of the donor DNA that could function in strand transfer.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Only when the chromodomain was present was there a strict requirement for the ACA at the 3' end of the donor DNA (Fig.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	373	 The strong specificity of the intact IN is in contrast to the IN of Ty1, which in similar types of assays can tolerate many alterations in the 3' end of the donor DNA (42).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	374	 However, INs of retroviruses, such as HIV-1, lack chromodomains and yet exhibit strict requirements for the sequences at the 3' end of the donor DNA (35, 37).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Thus, the chromodomain is not the only means for INs to achieve this strict requirement for the CA at the 3' end of donor oligonucleotides.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Therefore, it appears that in the case of Tf1 IN, the chromodomain evolved independently as a means of restricting donor sequences.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	377	Both contributions of the chromodomain, limiting IN activity and increasing sequence specificity, may result from a single mechanism that restricts access to the active site of IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Although there are several examples of chromodomains that interact directly with histone H3, the lack of histone proteins in our assays indicates such an interaction is not required for the restrictive properties of the Tf1 chromodomain.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Functional analyses of several chromodomains recently revealed an unexpected diversity of interaction targets such as DNA and RNA (7).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	380	 It is possible that the chromodomain of Tf1 restricts IN activity through interactions with the donor DNA.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Regardless of the mode of inhibition, there is the interesting possibility that in vivo, the inhibition is regulated.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	382	 One intriguing hypothesis is that the chromodomain does interact with histone H3 and it is this interaction at the target site that relieves the inhibitory function of the chromodomain.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	383	 The chromodomain of HP1 forms an organized cluster of strands and helices in response to its interaction with the NH2 terminus of H3 (32, 47).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	384	 This dramatic reorganization is consistent with a role in regulating integration.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	385	Although chromodomains are known to exist in many INs of LTR-retrotransposons (8, 9), the results reported here are the first direct effort to identify the function of the chromodomain in IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	386	 The restrictive role of the chromodomain identified here may very well be true for the other chromodomain containing INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	387	 In addition to INs, chromodomains have been identified in several other enzymes.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	388	 The H3 lysine 9-specific histone methyltransferase Su(var)3-9, the ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling factors, CHD, the DNA methyltransferase CMT, and the histone acetylase CDY, are all enzymes that contain chromodomains (7).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	389	 In light of the restrictive function of the chromodomain in Tf1 IN, it will be interesting to test how the chromodomains in these other proteins affect their enzymatic activities.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	390	The poor solubility of the recombinant INs studied thus far has been a major obstacle in producing high resolution structures.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	391	 High concentrations of salt or the introduction of amino acid substitutions have been necessary to solubilize individual domains of INs.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	392	 A number of structures have been determined for each of the three domains of the INs from the retroviruses HIV-1, simian immunodeficiency virus, avian sarcoma virus, and Rous sarcoma virus (18).
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	393	 However, the lack of a structure for an intact IN makes it difficult to model the spatial relationships between the three domains.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	394	 During the purification of Tf1 IN it became clear that this IN was substantially more soluble than other integrases previously studied.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	395	 It is possible that this solubility will lead to the first crystal structure of a full-length IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	396	 This would serve as a significant leap in understanding the structures of INs in general and more specifically, of HIV-1 IN.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	397	 A structure of an intact IN would substantially facilitate the design and development of new drugs against HIV IN and, thus, contribute to the ongoing fight against AIDS.
0.25489283.16188891.html.plaintext.txt	398	   FOOTNOTES   We dedicate this article to the memory of our colleague and good friend, Dr.
