0.32730934.11069927.html.plaintext.txt	370	Copyright   2001 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	0	COUP-TF interacting protein 2 represses the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription in human microglial cells Celine Marban1, Laetitia Redel1, Stella Suzanne1, Carine Van Lint2, Dominique Lecestre1, Sylvette Chasserot-Golaz3, Mark Leid4, Dominique Aunis1, Evelyne Schaeffer1 and Olivier Rohr1,5,*.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	1	1INSERM unite 575 Pathophysiology of Nervous System, Centre de Neurochimie 5 rue Blaise Pascal, 67084 Strasbourg, France 2Institute for Molecular Biology and Medicine, Laboratory of Molecular Virology 12 rue des Professeurs Jeener et Brachet, 6041 Gosselies, Belgium 3Unite CNRS UPR 2356 5, rue Blaise Pascal, 67084 Strasbourg, France 4Laboratory of Molecular Pharmacology, College of Pharmacy and Environmental Health Sciences Center, Oregon State University Corvallis, Oregon 97331-3507, France 5IUT Louis Pasteur de Schiltigheim, 1 Allee d'Athenes 67300 Schiltigheim, France.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	2	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel: +33 388 45 66 01; Fax: +33 388 60 08 06; Email: rohr{at}neurochem.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) gene transcription is characterized by two temporally distinct phases.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	5	 While the initial phase relies solely on cellular transcription factors, the subsequent phase is activated by the viral Tat transactivator.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We have previously reported that the subsequent phase of viral gene transcription can be repressed by the chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF)-interacting protein 2 (CTIP2) in human microglial cells [O.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Here, we demonstrate that CTIP proteins also repress the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription, mainly supported by the cellular transcription factors Sp1 and COUP-TF in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	8	 We report that CTIP2 represses Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and viral replication as a result of physical interactions with COUP-TF and Sp1 in microglial nuclei.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Using laser confocal microscopy CTIP2 was found to colocalize with Sp1, COUP-TF and the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1, which is mainly detected in transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Moreover, we describe that CTIP2 can be recruited to the HIV-1 promoter via its association with Sp1 bound to the GC-box sequences of the long terminal repeat (LTR).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Since our findings demonstrate that CTIP2 interacts with the HIV-1 proximal promoter, it is likely that CTIP2 promotes HIV-1 gene silencing by forcing transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic environment to the viral LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	12	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) is associated with a spectrum of neurological damage, ranging from acute encephalopathies to AIDS dementia (1,2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The CNS constitutes a sanctuary and a reservoir for the virus despite antiretroviral therapies (3).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Microglial cells, the CNS resident macrophages, may be particularly suitable for this purpose because they are long lived, HIV productive for several weeks and relatively immune to virus-induced cytopathology [reviewed in (4)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Since microglial cells are the primary targets of HIV-1 productive infection within the CNS (5,6), investigation on HIV-1 repression in these cells are important for the global understanding of HIV pathogenesis and for the development of anti-HIV strategies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	16	HIV-1 gene transcription is a key step in the control of the virus life cycle [reviewed in (7)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Viral gene transcription is characterized by two temporally distinct phases.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The initial phase occurs immediately after integration and relies solely on cellular transcription factors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Most of the transcripts cannot elongate efficiently and terminate rapidly after initiation.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	20	 However, a few transcripts elongate throughout the genome, resulting in transcription and expression of the viral transactivator Tat.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The subsequent phase of transcription occurs when enough Tat protein has accumulated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Tat binds to TAR, recruits pTEFb complex and dramatically stimulates HIV-1 gene transcription [reviewed in (8,9)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	23	We have previously studied some of the cellular transcription factors that impact HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor I (COUP-TFI)/Ear3, Arp1/COUP-TFII and Ear2/COUP-TFIII proteins are the three members of the COUP-TF orphan nuclear receptors superfamily.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	25	 We have described that the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TFI/Ear3 (10,11) is expressed in numerous human CNS cell lineages, including microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	26	 COUP-TFI is an activator of HIV-1 gene transcription in oligodendrocytes (12), microglia (13) and T lymphocytes (14).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Moreover, we have revealed the importance of functional interactions between the nuclear factor for interleukin 6 (NF-Il6), Sp1 and COUP-TFI in the regulation of the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription in brain cells (15).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The transcription factor Sp1 is one of the crucial cellular proteins for efficient HIV-1 gene transcription (16 to 18).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	29	 A number of studies have reported that Sp1 can serve as an anchor for indirect binding of other transcription factors to the HIV-1 long terminal repeat (LTR) region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In all cell types, an interaction between Sp1 and Tat is required for optimal HIV-enhancer activation (19).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Moreover, Sp1 is able to recruit the Cyclin T1 subunit of P-TEFb to the LTR, which helps to bypass a requirement for TAR/Tat and promotes processive transcription without Tat (20).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In microglial cells, the main HIV-1 target cells in the brain (6), Sp1 anchors COUP-TF (13) and NF-IL6 (15) to the three GC-boxes adjacent to the viral CATA box.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The CATA box is used instead of the TATAA box for optimal HIV-1 gene transcription and replication (21).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	34	 We have shown that Sp1 and COUP-TF interact and cooperate in the transcriptional activation of HIV-1 gene transcription (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Moreover, COUP-TF can substitute to Sp1 association with the viral Tat protein to restore Tat function and HIV-1 replication in microglial cells (22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	36	 These results highlight the key roles of Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins in HIV-1 expression in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	37	Members of the COUP-TF family have been shown to bind related zinc finger proteins named COUP-TF-interacting protein 1 (CTIP1) and 2 (CTIP2) that are highly expressed in brain and immune systems (23,24).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Recent results support the selective contribution of these proteins in the development and function of the nervous and immune systems (24).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We recently described that the nuclear cofactor CTIP2 inhibits the subsequent phase of HIV-1 gene transcription and viral replication by relocating the viral transactivator Tat protein to transcriptionally inactive regions of chromatin via Hp1 (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In the present work, CTIP2 overexpression leads to the repression of HIV-1 replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In contrast, CTIP1 was unable to affect Tat function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Using confocal microscopy to visualize Tat subcellular distribution in the presence of each CTIP proteins, we found that CTIP2, but not CTIP1, leads to the disruption of Tat nuclear localization and to its recruitment within CTIP2-induced nuclear ball-like structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In addition, we showed that CTIP2 and Hp1 associate with Tat to form a three-protein complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	44	 These findings suggest that the inhibition of HIV-1 expression by CTIP2 correlates with the recruitment of Tat within CTIP2-induced structures and its relocalization within inactive regions of chromatin.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	45	On line with this study, we noticed that CTIP proteins also affect HIV-1 gene transcription in the absence of Tat, which means that CTIP proteins may also impair endogenous cellular transcription factor functions of importance for the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	46	Here, we report that CTIP proteins repress HIV-1 gene transcription via the proximal LTR region which binds Sp1 and COUP-TF transactivators.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Since COUP-TF and Sp1 cellular transcription factors are two of the major contributors to HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells, we have postulated that Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated LTR-driven activation may be impaired by CTIP1 and CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	48	 We report here that both CTIP1 and CTIP2 repress Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated stimulation of HIV-1 gene expression.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Since the CTIP2 repressive activity is much stronger than the CTIP1-mediated inhibition of HIV-1 replication, we focused our study on CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	50	 CTIP2-mediated repression of Sp1 and COUP-TF functions results from direct physical interactions of these cellular transcription factors with CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Association with CTIP2 forces Sp1 and COUP-TF relocation to CTIP2-induced subnuclear structures containing the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Moreover, CTIP2 can be recruited to the HIV-1 promoter by a physical association with Sp1 bound to the GC-box regions of the LTR.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Since Sp1 or COUP-TF transcription factors are necessary for the Tat function in microglial cells (22), CTIP2-mediated repression of COUP-TF and Sp1 functions may largely contribute to the previously described CTIP2-mediated impairment of Tat activity and viral replication in microglial cells (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	54	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Plasmids Most of the constructs used in our assays were described previously: HIV-1 (LAI) 5' LTR chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (pLTR-CAT) (22), pGC-WAP-CAT (26), pLTR-LUC 287 to 535 (13), pLTR-CAT mutGC and pLTR-CAT GC (22), pcDNA3, full-length constructs HA-CTIP1, Flag-CTIP2 and GST-CTIP2 (23), deletions constructs Flag-CTIP2 (25), RSV-COUP-TF, CMV-Sp1, GST-COUP-TF1, GST-COUP-TF2 and GST-COUP-TF3 (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	55	Several plasmids were kindly provided by the following investigators: GST-Sp1 constructs were provided by H.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Rotheneder (Vienna, Austria) (27) and pLTR-LUC by C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	57	 pNL4-3 (28) was obtained through the AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, division of AIDS, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), NIH.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	58	To construct RFP-CTIP2, the expression vector Flag-CTIP2 was digested with EcoRI and the CTIP2 insert was subcloned into the EcoRI site of the pDSRed vector (Clontech).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The GFP-Sp1 was constructed by isolating the XhoI to HindIII Sp1 insert from the GST-Sp1 expression vector and subcloned into the XhoI to HindIII sites of the pEGFP-C1 vector (Clontech).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	60	Cell culture The human microglial (provided by M.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Tardieu, Paris, France) (29), the TZM-bl (30 to 32) and the HEK 293T cell lines were maintained in DMEM containing 10% fetal calf serum and 100 U/ml penicillin to streptomycin.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	62	Viral replication Microglial cells cultured in 12-well plates were transfected using the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method with HIV-1 pNL4-3 (1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	63	5  microg), CMV-Sp1 (1  microg) or RSV-COUP-TF (1  microg) plasmids and the indicated HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 expression vectors (0.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Total amounts of DNA were identical in each experiment.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Compensations were made by adding the corresponding empty vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Each transfection was carried out in duplicate and repeated a minimum of three separate times with two different plasmid preparations.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	67	 HIV-1 replication was monitored as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	68	CAT assays Microglial cells cultured in 12-well plates were transfected using the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method with pLTR-CAT (3  microg), pGC-WAP-CAT (3  microg) or pLTR-CAT GC (3  microg), CMV-Sp1 (1  microg) or RSV-COUP-TF (1  microg) plasmids and the indicated HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 (0.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	69	5 or 1  microg) expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Total amounts of DNA were identical in each experiments.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Compensations were made by adding the corresponding empty vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Each transfection was carried out in duplicate and repeated a minimum of three separate times with two different plasmid preparations.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	73	 CAT assays were carried out using standard techniques.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	74	Co-immunoprecipitation assays Microglial cells cultured in 100 mm diameter dishes were transfected using LipofectamineTM 2000 Reagent (Invitrogen) with the indicated Flag-CTIP2 (30  microg).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Twenty four hours post-transfection, the cells were washed twice with cold phosphate-buffered saline, harvested and prepared for nuclear extracts (12).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Nuclear proteins were first diluted in TNE buffer [50 mM Tris, pH 8, 1% Nonidet, 2 mM EDTA, protease inhibitors cocktail (Roche)], cleared with Protein A/G Plus-Agarose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and finally incubated overnight with primary antibodies: anti-Sp1 (Sigma), anti-COUP-TF (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Mertz, Madison, WI) or anti-Hp1 (kindly provided by R.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Losson, IGBMC, Strasbourg, France).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The extracts were then immunoprecipitated by the addition of Protein A/G Plus-Agarose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	80	 After extensive washing with TNE buffer, the immunoprecipitates were processed for SDS to PAGE and western blot analysis.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	81	Glutathione S-transferase (GST) pull-down assays Production of GST fusion proteins was described previously (13) and visualized by Coomassie blue staining.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The 35S-labeled proteins were prepared by in vitro transcription and translation using the TNT  T7 Coupled Wheat Germ Extract System (Promega).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	83	 GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	84	SDS to PAGE and western blot analysis SDS to PAGE was performed using standard techniques.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Proteins were detected using antibodies directed against the Flag epitope (M2 mouse monoclonal; Sigma), against the COUP-TF protein (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Mertz) and against the Sp1 protein (Sigma).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Proteins were visualized by chemiluminescence using the Super Signal Chemiluminescence Detection System (Pierce).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	88	Electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) The probe used in our experiments has been described previously (13) and corresponds to the three Sp1 binding sites of the HIV-1 proximal LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Once produced, GST fusion proteins were eluted in glutathione buffer (50 mM Tris, pH 8, 20 mM reduced glutathione).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Purified Sp1 (Promega) and GST fusion proteins were then incubated with the 32P-labeled probe in binding buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	91	5 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT and 10% glycerol) at 4 degrees C for 15 min.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	92	 For supershift experiments, GST fusion proteins were incubated with the primary antibodies: anti-COUP-TF (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Mertz), anti-CTIP2 and anti-Sp1 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) for 16 h before adding the probe.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	94	 EMSA assays were performed as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	95	Indirect immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy Microglial cells cultured in 48-well plates were transfected or not using LipofectamineTM 2000 Reagent (Invitrogen) with Flag-CTIP2, RFP-CTIP2 and/or GFP-Sp1 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Cells were fixed and permeabilized as described previously (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The coverslips were then incubated for 1 h at room temperature with primary antibodies directed against COUP-TF (Santa Cruz Biotechnology or kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Mertz), Sp1 (sigma) and Hp1 proteins and/or against the Flag epitope (M2 mouse monoclonal; Sigma).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The primary immunocomplexes were revealed by CY2- or CY3-labeled secondary anti-species antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The stained cells were analyzed by confocal microscopy using a Zeiss laser scanning microscope (model 510 invert) equipped with a Planapo oil (63x) immersion lens (numerical aperture = 1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	101	Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays TZM-bl and HEK 293T cells cultured in 100 mm diameter dishes were transfected using the calcium phosphate coprecipitation method with the indicated pLTR-LUC, pLTR-CAT mutGC and Flag-CTIP2 (30  microg) expression vector.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	102	 ChIP assays were performed using the ChIP Assay Kit (Upstate) 48 h post-transfection.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The primary antibodies used for the ChIP were anti-Sp1 (Upstate), anti-Hp1 (Upstate), anti-COUP-TF (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and anti-Flag M2 mouse monoclonal (Sigma).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	104	 DNA was subjected to PCR amplification using a 5' primer (5'-GATAAGGTAGAAGAGGCC-3') corresponding to the LTR sequence located 293 nt downstream of the transcriptional start site and a 3' primer (5'-CTAACCAGAGAGACCCAGTAC-3') corresponding to a region just upstream of the transcriptional start site.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The resulting PCR product (307 bp) was analyzed by agarose gel electrophoresis and ethidium bromide staining.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Three separate experiments were performed.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	107	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   CTIP1 and CTIP2 proteins repress HIV-1 gene transcription via the LTR proximal region As previously shown, CTIP1 and CTIP2 proteins inhibited the LTR-driven transcription in transient transfection assays (Figure 1, lanes 2 and 3) (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	108	 To delineate the LTR region responsible for CTIP1- and CTIP2-mediated HIV-1 gene transcriptional repression, microglial cells were transfected with a 5' deleted pLTR-CAT reporter plasmid in the presence or absence of CTIP1 and CTIP2 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Deletion of the 5' region downstream of the two proximal GC-box sequences did not affect CTIP1 and CTIP2 ability to repress LTR-driven CAT activity (Figure 1, lanes 5 and 6), indicating that CTIP proteins repressive function can be mediated by the proximal region of the LTR encompassing two GC-box sequences, the CATA sequence (21) and the TAR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	110	 We have previously observed that the cellular transcription factors, Sp1 and Sp3, are directly bound to the LTR GC-box sequences in microglial cells (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Moreover, the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF is indirectly anchored to this region via its association with Sp1 (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	112	 We have largely described that Sp1 and COUP-TF transcription factors are two of the major contributors to the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells (9,13,22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Taken together, these findings strongly suggest that CTIP repressive activity may result from impairment of endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF protein functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (12K):    Figure 1 CTIP1 and CTIP2 proteins repress HIV-1 gene transcription via the proximal LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Microglial cells were transfected with 3  microg of pLTR-CAT or 3  microg of pLTR-CAT (287 to 535) in the presence or absence of 1  microg of HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Two days post-transfection, CAT activities were measured and expressed relative to the CAT activity obtained with pLTR-CAT alone with the standard deviations indicated (values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	117	  CTIP1 and CTIP2 cofactors inhibit Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and related viral replication To decipher the mechanism whereby CTIP proteins affect the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription, we investigated the impacts of CTIP proteins on Sp1 and COUP-TF functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Microglial cells were transfected with pLTR-CAT plasmid together with the vectors expressing COUP-TF (Figure 2A) or Sp1 (Figure 2B) proteins and with increasing amounts of HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The two proteins were able to repress COUP-TF- and Sp1-mediated stimulations of CAT activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	120	 As a control, we performed western blot experiments, indicating that COUP-TF and Sp1 expressions were not downregulated but slightly upregulated by the cofactors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Since overexpression of COUP-TF and Sp1 stimulates HIV-1 gene expression, this modest upregulation could not be responsible for the CTIPs repressive function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	122	 To correlate CTIP1 and CTIP2 repressive activity on LTR-driven transcription to the level of HIV-1 replication, we studied their impacts on Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated stimulations of viral replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Cells were transfected with HIV-1 pNL4-3 and COUP-TF (Figure 2C) or Sp1 (Figure 2D) expression vectors in the presence of increasing amounts of CTIP1 or CTIP2 expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The level of viral replication was investigated by quantifying p24 Gag expression in the culture supernatants 2 days after transfection.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	125	 While both CTIP1 and CTIP2 inhibited COUP-TF (Figure 2C) and Sp1 (Figure 2D) activation of HIV-1 NL4-3 replication, the strongest repression was observed with CTIP2 (Figure 2C and D, lanes 6 to 8), indicating that the repressing activity of CTIP2 on HIV-1 replication cannot be explained only by its previously described capacity to repress the viral Tat protein (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	126	 These results strongly suggest that CTIP1 and CTIP2 repress the initial phase of HIV-1 gene transcription through direct or indirect interactions with endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	127	View larger version (32K):    Figure 2 CTIP1 and CTIP2 inhibit Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and related viral replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Microglial cells were cotransfected with 3  microg of pLTR-CAT (A and B) or 3  microg of pNL4-3 (C and D), 1  microg of RSV-COUP-TF (A and C) or CMV-Sp1 (B and D) expression vectors and increasing amounts of HA-CTIP1 or Flag-CTIP2 (0.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	129	 (A and B) Two days post-transfection, CAT activities were measured and expressed relative to the value obtained with pLTR-CAT alone with the standard deviation indicated (values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Western blot experiments were performed on nuclear extracts with antibodies directed against COUP-TF or Sp1 proteins as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (C and D) Two days post-transfection, culture supernatants were analyzed for p24 Gag contents and expressed relative to the value obtained with pNL4-3 alone taken as 1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Depending on the cell confluency, this value varied between 500 and 5000 pg/ml.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	134	  The HIV-1 Tat function and the subsequent phase of the HIV-1 gene transcription also depend on Tat association with Sp1 or COUP-TF in microglial cells (22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Since CTIP2-mediated repressive activities are much stronger than those observed for CTIP1 and since CTIP2, but not CTIP1, inhibits the subsequent phase of the HIV-1 gene transcription, we focused our mechanistic investigation on CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	136	CTIP2 interacts with COUP-TF and Sp1 in vitro by two interfaces To decipher the mechanism whereby CTIP2 represses COUP-TF and Sp1 stimulatory activities, we first examined whether these proteins were able to interact in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	137	 GST pull-down assays were performed with in vitro translated 35S-labeled CTIP2 and equal amounts of full-length or truncated GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1 fusion proteins (Figure 3A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Results show that CTIP2 bound specifically to GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1 (Figure 3A, lanes 3 and 8, respectively) but not to the control GST protein (Figure 3A, lanes 2 and 7, respectively).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Approximately 2 to 5% and 1 to 2% of the 35S-labeled CTIP2 interacted with GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Moreover, the 49 to 148 region of COUP-TF (Figure 3A, lane 5) and the 622 to 788 region of Sp1 (Figure 3A, lane 11) were still able to mediate association with CTIP2, indicating that CTIP2 interacted with the N-terminal region of COUP-TF and the C-terminal region of Sp1, both of which include zinc finger domains.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (22K):    Figure 3 CTIP2 interacts in vitro with COUP-TF and Sp1 by two interfaces.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	142	 (A) Upper panels: schematic representation of the COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins; lower panels: GST pull-down assays were performed with 35S-labeled CTIP2 incubated with GST (lanes 2 and 7) or GST fusion proteins of the indicated COUP-TF domains (lanes 3 to 5) or Sp1 domains (lanes 8 to 11).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Approximately 1% of the total 35S-labeled CTIP2 obtained was loaded as input control (lanes 1 and 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	144	 (B) GST pull-down assays were performed with 35S-labeled full-length or truncated CTIP2 proteins incubated with GST (lanes 2 and 5), GST-COUP-TF (lane 6) or GST-Sp1 (lane 3) fusion proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Approximately 1% of the total 35S-labeled proteins used were loaded as input control (lanes 1 and 4).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Representative Coomassie stainings of GST, GST-Sp1 and GST-COUP-TF proteins were presented (B lower panels).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	147	  To precisely delineate the region of CTIP2 protein that associates with Sp1 and COUP-TF, GST pull-down assays were performed with full-length GST-COUP-TF or GST-Sp1 fusion proteins and a series of in vitro-translated 35S-labeled full-length and deletion mutants of CTIP2 (Figure 3B).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The full-length as well as deletion mutants starting at position 350, 610 and 717 did mediate interaction with GST-COUP-TF (Figure 3B, lane 6) and GST-Sp1 (Figure 3B, lane 3) but not with the control GST protein (Figure 3B, lanes 2 and 5).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	149	 These results show that CTIP2 is able to interact with Sp1 and COUP-TF via its C-terminal zinc finger domain region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	150	 We have previously shown that CTIP2 harbors two independent interaction domains with the viral Tat protein (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	151	 This prompted us to determine whether an additional interaction interface was located in the N-terminal or the central region of CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	152	 To this end, GST pull-down experiments were performed with additional deletion constructs.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	153	 As expected, the deletion mutant 350 to 716 was not able to interact with COUP-TF and Sp1, confirming that the C-terminal region of CTIP2 containing residues 717 to 813 mediates binding to these transcription factors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	154	 However, the 1 to 354 and the 145 to 434 constructs appeared to be able to restore interactions, suggesting that the central region of CTIP2 located between the residues 145 and 354 might be sufficient for COUP-TF and Sp1 association.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	155	Thus, these findings indicate that CTIP2 interacts in vitro with the zinc finger domains of COUP-TF and Sp1 by two interfaces located in the central region (residues 145 to 354) and the C-terminal region (residues 717 to 813).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	156	CTIP2 colocalizes with Sp1 and COUP-TF within Hp1-associated structures To visualize the association of CTIP2 with Sp1 and COUP-TF within the nucleus, Flag-CTIP2 transfected microglial cells were observed by immunofluorescence confocal laser microscopy (Figure 4A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	157	 As previously described (25), anti-Flag immunostaining of Flag-CTIP2 revealed the formation of CTIP2-induced nuclear ball-like structures in microglial cells nuclei (Figure 4A, images 3, 8 and 13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Flag-CTIP2 appeared as concentrated at the periphery but absent within the structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Interestingly, observations of RFP-CTIP2 (Figure 4B, images 1 and 5) fusion protein revealed the presence of CTIP2 at the periphery but also within the previously described nuclear structures, suggesting that the Flag epitopes within these ball-like structures were probably not accessible to the anti-Flag antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	160	 To control the nuclear location of RFP-CTIP2 expression, cells were transfected with RFP-CTIP2 and GFP-Lamin B expression vectors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	161	 As previously described (25), CTIP2-induced nuclear structures were located in the nucleus of microglial cells (C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In the absence of CTIP2, endogenous COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins were expressed in the nucleoplasm with a speckled and diffused staining pattern (images 1 and 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Moreover, in the presence of Flag-CTIP2, these transcription factors were at least partially located to CTIP2-induced nuclear structures (Figure 4A, images 2 and 7).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Endogenous Sp1 (Figure 4A, images 9 and 10) and COUP-TF (Figure 4A, images 4 and 5) proteins colocalized with CTIP2 at the periphery of the immunostained structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Up to 87 and 70% of endogenous COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins colocalized with CTIP2, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	166	 No staining was observed inside the ball-like structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	167	 We have reported that CTIP2 relocates the viral Tat transactivator to the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1 (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Endogenous Hp1 exhibited a diffused and speckled nuclear distribution in the absence of CTIP2 (Figure 4A, image 11).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	169	 To visualize the presence of Hp1 in CTIP2-induced structures in the absence of Tat, we performed immunodetection of endogenous Hp1 in microglial cells expressing Flag-CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	170	 As shown in Figure 4A (images 14 and 15), endogenous Hp1 colocalized with CTIP2, suggesting that endogenous COUP-TF, Sp1 and Hp1 proteins are relocated to the same CTIP2-induced nuclear structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	171	 To address whether COUP-TF and Sp1 also colocalized with CTIP2 inside the ball-like structures, we performed immunodetection of the endogenous COUP-TF protein with other different polyclonal antibodies (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Mertz) in the presence of RFP-CTIP2 and GFP-Sp1 fusion proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	173	 As shown in Figure 4B (image 2), endogenous COUP-TF was observed inside the structures, confirming that the epitope accessibility to the antibodies is determinant to COUP-TF immunodetection.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Since RFP-CTIP2 was expressed in ball-like structures (Figure 4B, images 1 and 5), GFP-Sp1 expressed alone was localized in the nucleoplasm with a diffused staining pattern (Figure 4B, image 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Moreover, in the presence of RFP-CTIP2, GFP-Sp1 is relocated to CTIP2-induced structures (Figure 4B, image 3).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	176	 COUP-TF and GFP-Sp1 relocation was not restricted to the periphery of the CTIP2-induced nuclear structures, since they were also detected inside the structures as shown by the presence of white staining resulting from colocalized red, blue and green staining (Figure 4B, image 4).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Thus, endogenous Sp1 proteins were probably relocated within the heterochromatic structures too.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	178	 However, they remained unaccessible to the currently used antibodies (Figure 4A, images 7 and 9).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	179	 These results strongly suggest that the cellular transcription factors, Sp1 and COUP-TF, associate with CTIP2 in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	180	View larger version (37K):    Figure 4 CTIP2 colocalizes with Sp1 and COUP-TF within Hp1-associated structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	181	 (A) Microglial cells were transfected or not with Flag-CTIP2 as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	182	 After being treated, endogenous Sp1, COUP-TF and Hp1 proteins were immunodetected with primary anti-COUP-TF (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) (images 1 and 2), anti-Sp1 (images 6 and 7) and anti-Hp1 antibodies (images 11 and 12).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Overexpressed Flag-CTIP2 was detected with antibodies directed against the Flag epitope (images 3, 8 and 13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The primary immunocomplexes were revealed by CY2- or CY3-labeled anti-species secondary antibodies (green or red staining).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Mask column (images 5, 10 and 15) shows the colocalized CY2 and CY3 stainings.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	186	 (B) Microglial cells expressing RFP-CTIP2 (image 1) and GFP-Sp1 (image 3) were subjected to endogenous COUP-TF immunodetection with anti-COUP-TF antibodies (kindly provided by J.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	187	 COUP-TF immunocomplexes were stained by CY5- (blue staining) labeled anti-species secondary antibodies (image 2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Pattern of RFP-CTIP2 and GFP-Sp1 expressed alone are presented on images 5 and 6, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (A and B) Coverslips were subjected to confocal microscopy analysis.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	190	  CTIP2 interacts with Sp1, COUP-TF and Hp1 in microglial cells We have observed that CTIP2 colocalizes with Sp1, COUP-TF and the heterochromatin-associated protein HP1 in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	191	 To test whether Sp1, COUP-TF, CTIP2 and Hp1 are present in the same complex, we performed co-immunoprecipitation experiments on microglial nuclear extracts expressing or not the Flag-CTIP2 protein (Figure 5A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Anti-Flag western blot immunodetections performed on anti-COUP-TF (lanes 3 and 4), anti-Sp1 (lanes 6 and 7) and anti-Hp1 (lanes 9 and 10) immunoprecipitated nuclear extracts indicated that CTIP2 interacted with COUP-TF (lane 4), Sp1 (lane 7) and Hp1 (lane 10) in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	193	 As a control, experiments performed on CTIP2 non-expressing extracts (lanes 3, 6 and 9) or on non-immune serum (NIS) immunoprecipitated nuclear extracts (lanes 2, 5 and 8) confirmed the specificity of the Flag immunodetection and the specificity of the COUP-TF, Sp1 and Hp1 immunoprecipitation experiments, respectively.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Thus, CTIP2 may be able to recruit a protein complex, including the three proteins in the nucleus of microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	195	 To address how CTIP2 links COUP-TF and Sp1 to Hp1, we performed competition pull-down assays (Figure 5B).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	196	 GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1 fusion proteins were incubated with both 35S-labeled CTIP2 145 to 434 and CTIP2 717 to 813 in the presence of increasing amounts of 35S-Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Results clearly show that CTIP2 145 to 434 remained bound to GST-COUP-TF and GST-Sp1, while CTIP2 717 to 813 was displaced by Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This displacement increased the amount of GST fusion proteins available for the CTIP2 145 to 434 binding.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Hp1 competed for COUP-TF and Sp1 binding to the C-terminal domain of CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	200	 These findings indicate that the 145 to 434 region of CTIP2 has a stronger binding affinity for COUP-TF and Sp1 than the 717 to 813 domain, which preferentially binds Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Thus, CTIP2 may link COUP-TF and Sp1 bound to the 145 to 434 domain and Hp1 bound to the 717 to 813 domain.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	202	 To precisely examine the formation of a ternary complex between Sp1, COUP-TF and CTIP2, we performed GST pull-down experiments of mixed 35S-labeled-Sp1 and -COUP-TF proteins with GST-CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	203	 As shown in Figure 5C, Sp1 and COUP-TF interacted together with CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Moreover, addition of increasing amounts of 145 to 434 CTIP2 or COUP-TF proteins did not compete each other for Sp1 binding (Figure 5D).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Thus, COUP-TF and CTIP2 do not compete for Sp1 binding in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Taken together, those findings strongly suggest the formation of a ternary complex occurring between Sp1, COUP-TF and CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	207	View larger version (22K):    Figure 5 CTIP2 interacts with COUP-TF, Sp1 and Hp1 in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (A) Nuclear extracts of microglial cells expressing (lanes 2, 4, 5, 7, 8 and 10) or not (lanes 3, 6 and 9) Flag-CTIP2 were immunoprecipitated with antibodies directed against COUP-TF (lanes 3 and 4), Sp1 (lanes 6 and 7) or Hp1 (lanes 9 and 10) proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Proteins were separated by SDS to PAGE and western blot analysis with anti-Flag antibodies were performed.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (B) GST pull-down competition assays were performed with equal amounts of 35S-labeled 145 to 434 and 717 to 813 CTIP2 proteins and increasing amounts of 35S-labeled Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Proteins were incubated with GST-COUP-TF or GST-Sp1 fusion proteins as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (C) GST pull-down assays were performed with equal amounts of 35S-labeled Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins and GST or GST-CTIP2 fusion proteins as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (D) GST pull-down competition assays were performed with the indicated amounts of 35S-labeled 145 to 434 CTIP2 and COUP-TF proteins and GST-Sp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	214	 (A to D) Approximately 1% of the total 35S-labeled proteins used were loaded as input control.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	215	  CTIP2 is anchored to the HIV-1 LTR by direct interactions with Sp1 bound to the LTR proximal region CTIP proteins are DNA-binding proteins, which bind a consensus sequence related to the canonical GC-box (33).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Moreover, we have previously described that COUP-TF activates HIV-1 transcription by direct protein to protein interactions with Sp1 bound to the proximal region of HIV-1 LTR (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The association of CTIP2 with Sp1 and COUP-TF (Figure 5) led us to examine how CTIP2 interacts with the HIV-1 LTR to promote viral repression.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	218	 To do that, we performed EMSA experiments with pure Sp1 proteins and bacterially produced GST-CTIP2 and GST-COUP-TF proteins that were incubated with a 32P-labeled probe corresponding to the three Sp1 binding sites (GC-box) of the HIV-1 LTR proximal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	219	 As expected, Sp1 bound to the probe to form a shifted nucleoproteic complex (Figure 6A, lanes 1 and 7).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Interestingly, addition of GST-CTIP2 (lane 2) or GST-COUP (lane 3) but not GST (lane 4) separately promoted the formation of supershifted complexes, indicating that, as previously reported for COUP-TF (13), CTIP2 was anchored to the LTR by a physical interaction with Sp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	221	 As a control, GST-COUP-TF and GST-CTIP2 proteins, incubated alone, were unable to directly interact with the probe (lanes 5 and 6).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	222	 To confirm whether COUP-TF, CTIP2 and Sp1 form a ternary complex, we performed additional gel shift experiments in which increasing amounts of CTIP2 proteins were added to the binary Sp1/COUP-TF complex (lanes 9 and 10).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	223	 As shown, the shifted complex formed by COUP-TF and Sp1 bound to the template (lane 8) was supershifted by increasing the amount of CTIP2 in a dose-dependent manner.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Moreover, the intensity of the supershifted complexes also increased with CTIP2 quantity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Those findings are in favor of the formation of a ternary complex anchored to the HIV-1 Sp1 binding sites.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	226	 To precisely examine this complex, the mixed three proteins were incubated with their respective antibody.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	227	 EMSA experiments demonstrated that the complex observed in the presence of the three proteins (Figure 6A, lane 10 and Figure 6B, lane 1) was supershifted by the antibodies directed against CTIP2 (Figure 6B, lane 2) and COUP-TF (Figure 6B, lane 3) but not by non-immune serum (Figure 6B, lane 5) confirming the presence of the two proteins in the complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Moreover, incubation of the mixed three proteins with the anti-Sp1 antibodies (Figure 6B, lane 4) inhibited the formation of the nucleoprotein complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Thus, impairing Sp1 binding to the proxixmal region of the HIV-1 LTR results in the total abolition of the CTIP2 and COUP-TF ability to bind this region of the viral promoter.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	230	 These results confirm that both CTIP2 and COUP-TF interact with Sp1 bound to the LTR in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Previously published EMSA experiments performed with nuclear extracts of microglial cells have revealed that this region of the viral promoter binds the cellular transcription factors, Sp1 and Sp3, in microglial cells (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	232	 EMSA experiments performed with nuclear extracts of microglial cells expressing CTIP2 could not allow us to observe CTIP2 indirect binding to the LTR (C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	233	 To bypass this technical issue and to address whether CTIP2 interacts with the viral promoter in vivo, ChIP assays were conducted on TZM-bl cells, which contain a chromatin-integrated LTR, and on transiently transfected HEK 293T cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Although the nature and/or the extent of chromatin formation on transiently transfected templates likely differ from that of chromosomal genes, previous reports have validated ChIP studies in transiently transfected cells (34,35).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The amplified proximal LTR region includes the three Sp1 binding sites but not the previously described COUP-TF binding site (12).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	236	 As expected, in the absence of CTIP2, both endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF interact with the proximal LTR region in chromatin-integrated (Figure 6C) and transiently transfected contexts (Figure 6D, left panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Moreover, the presence of CTIP2 did not abolish Sp1 and COUP-TF recruitment (Figure 6C, row 2 and Figure 6D, left panel row 3) in agreement with the in vitro results described above.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	238	 However, in the presence of CTIP2, a lesser extent of template was immunoprecipitated with the antibodies directed against Sp1 and COUP-TF in the context of the integrated LTR (Figure 6C, row 2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The same observations were made with the antibodies directed against Sp1 in the transiently transfected LTR context (Figure 6D, left panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	240	 As shown in Figure 6C and D (left panel), CTIP2 interacted with the proximal region of the viral promoter.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	241	 In addition, mutation of the Sp1 binding sites abolished the interaction of Sp1, COUP-TF and CTIP2 with this region of the viral LTR (Figure 6D, right panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Taken together, our in vitro and in vivo findings suggest that the Sp1-mediated recruitment of CTIP2 to the LTR occurs in a cellular context.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	243	 We could not detect Hp1 interactions with the proximal region of the LTR in the absence of CTIP2, suggesting that CTIP2 significantly increase the recruitment of Hp1 to the HIV-1 proximal promoter (Figure 6D, left panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In addition, mutation of the Sp1 binding sites also abolished CTIP2-mediated recruitment of Hp1 (Figure 6D, right panel).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Since Hp1 associates with heterochromatic regions, it is likely that CTIP2 promotes transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic environment to the viral LTR region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	246	View larger version (31K):    Figure 6 CTIP2 is anchored to the HIV-1 LTR by direct interactions with Sp1 bound to the LTR proximal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	247	 (A and B) EMSA experiments were performed using purified Sp1, GST, GST-COUP-TF and GST-CTIP2 fusion proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Proteins were incubated with a 32P-labeled probe corresponding to the three Sp1 binding sites located downstream of the LTR (LAI) TATAA sequence.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	249	 (A) Increasing amounts of GST-CTIP2 proteins correspond to 5  microl (lane 9) and 10  microl (lane 10) of the used GST-CTIP2 preparation.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Supershift experiments performed in (B) were carried out with non-immune serum (lane 5) and with antibodies directed against CTIP2 (lane 2), COUP-TF (lane 3), and Sp1 (lane 4).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The specific shifted and supershifted complexes are presented.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	252	 (C) The TZM-bl cells, which contain a stably integrated LTR, were transfected or not with 30  microg of the indicated Flag-CTIP2 expression vector.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	253	 (D) HEK 293T cells were transfected with 5  microg of the indicated pLTR (left panel) or pLTR mutGC (right panel) constructs and 10  microg of Flag-CTIP2 expression vector if indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	254	 (C and D) Input lanes correspond to positive controls conduced with a fraction of the lysates used for the immunoprecipitation.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Control lanes correspond to negative controls, in which immunoprecipitation reactions were performed without antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Anti-Flag, anti-Sp1, anti-COUP-TF and anti-Hp1 lanes represent amplification reactions from samples immunoprecipitated with the indicated antibodies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Results are representative of three independent experiments.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	258	  Sp1 binding sites are dominant and sufficient but not absolutely necessary for transcriptional repression mediated by CTIP2 To address the importance of the HIV-1 LTR GC-box sequence for CTIP2 repressive function, we have transfected microglial cells with the pGC-WAP-CAT reporter plasmid in the presence of Sp1 and CTIP2 expression vectors (Figure 7A).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	259	 As expected, this heterologous promoter, containing three consensus binding sites for Sp1, was highly inducible by ectopic Sp1 overexpression (lane 3).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Interestingly, overexpression of CTIP2 also repressed Sp1-mediated transcriptional stimulation in the context of the GC-WAP promoter (lane 4), indicating that Sp1 binding sites were sufficient for CTIP2 activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	261	 These results also suggest that CTIP2 may be able to repress transcription of other Sp1-sensitive cellular genes.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	262	View larger version (12K):    Figure 7 Sp1 binding sites are dominant and sufficient but not absolutely necessary for transcriptional repression mediated by CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	263	 (A) Microglial cells were transfected with 3  microg of pGC-WAP-CAT reporter vector and 1  microg of expression vectors as indicated.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	264	 (B) Microglial cells were transfected with 3  microg of pLTR-CAT, pLTR-CAT mutGC or pLTR-CAT GC and 1  microg of the indicated Flag-CTIP2 vector.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Two days post-transfection, CAT activities were measured and expressed relative to the value obtained with the reporter plasmids pGC-WAP-CAT or pLTR-CAT alone with the standard deviations indicated (values correspond to an average of at least three independent experiments carried out in duplicate).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	266	  To decipher whether CTIP2 repressive function is exclusively mediated by the Sp1 binding sites, we have further examined the LTR sequences responsible for CTIP2-mediated transcriptional repression.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	267	 To do that, we have transfected microglial cells with pLTR-CAT vectors containing mutated or deleted GC-boxes in the presence or absence of CTIP2.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	268	 As previously shown, CTIP2 expression resulted in a strong repression of the basal LTR-driven CAT activity (Figure 7B, lane 2).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Mutation (lane 3) or deletion (lane 5) of the Sp1 binding sites resulted in a  > 90% impairment of the LTR transcriptional activity, confirming the importance of endogenous Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins, which bind to this region and stimulate the initial phase of LTR-driven transcription in microglial cells (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Surprisingly, CTIP2 was still able to repress the low remaining transcriptional activity of the mutated (lane 4) and of the deleted (lane 6) LTR, suggesting that CTIP2 may also affect HIV-1 gene transcription via association with some other cellular transcription factors yet to be characterized.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	271	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   In a recent work, we have revealed the importance of the cellular transcription factors, Sp1 and COUP-TFI/Ear3, in the regulation of HIV-1 gene transcription and replication in microglial cells (13).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	272	 We have shown that the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF associates and cooperates with Sp1 in the activation of LTR-driven transcription.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	273	 CTIP1 (Bcl11a, Evi9) and CTIP2 (Bcl11b, Rit1ss) are related transcriptional regulatory proteins that have been shown to bind members of the COUP-TF family (23).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	274	 In a more recent work, we have described that the nuclear cofactor CTIP2 inhibits the subsequent phase of HIV-1 gene transcription by relocating the viral Tat protein to transcriptionally inactive regions of chromatin via Hp1 (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	275	Here, we addressed the mechanism whereby CTIP2 impairs the initial phase (prior to Tat expression) of HIV-1 gene transcription in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	276	We report that CTIP proteins inhibit Sp1- and COUP-TF-mediated activation of HIV-1 gene transcription and replication in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	277	 To decipher the mechanism whereby CTIP2 alters COUP-TF and Sp1 functions, we examined whether these proteins interact in vitro and in cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	278	 GST pull-down experiments revealed that CTIP2 associates with the N-terminal region of COUP-TF and with the C-terminal region of Sp1 in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	279	 In this way, CTIP2 presents two interfaces for Sp1 and COUP-TF interactions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	280	 COUP-TF and Sp1 proteins bind the central and the C-terminal region of CTIP2 in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	281	 These results are consistent with the previously reported interface domains of Arp1 (COUP-TFII) with CTIP1 (23).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Confocal microscopy observations of COUP-TF and Sp1 location in the presence or absence of CTIP2 reveal that CTIP2 colocalizes with COUP-TF and Sp1 within nuclear ball-like structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Moreover, the heterochromatin-associated protein Hp1 is also present in these structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	284	 There are three Hp1 protein family members in mammals, Hp1, Hp1ss and Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The Hp1 isoform is mainly detected in transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic region (36).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Thus, the colocalization of CTIP2 with endogenous Sp1, COUP-TF and Hp1 proteins as reported here strongly suggests that these proteins are relocated to transcriptionally inactive regions of heterochromatin in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Those CTIP2-induced structures may represent a new class of nuclear structures (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Moreover, our observations may favor the hypothesis, suggesting that the formation of nuclear bodies inhibits HIV-1 gene transcription by sequestering a variety of factors required for transcriptional activation [reviewed in (37)].
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	289	Co-immunoprecipitation data indicate that the described subnuclear colocalization results from physical interactions between Sp1, COUP-TF, Hp1 and CTIP2 in the nucleus of microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Since Hp1, Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins associate with CTIP2 in microglial cells, we address their respective interaction interfaces in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Our findings show that the central zinc finger domain of CTIP2 may preferentially bind Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins, while the C-terminal region may bind to Hp1.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	292	 In the presence of the viral Tat transactivator, CTIP2 also associates with Hp1 via its C-terminal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Taken together, these findings suggest a permanent association of CTIP2 with Hp1 via its C-terminal region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The central domain of CTIP2 may be reserved for the interactions with the functionally repressed transcription factors.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Our observations indicate that COUP-TF and Sp1 could bind together to CTIP2 and that COUP-TF and CTIP2 do not compete for Sp1 binding.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Those findings suggest the formation of a ternary complex, including COUP-TF, Sp1 and CTIP2 proteins.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Thereby, CTIP2 links these transcriptional activators to transcriptionally repressed heterochromatic region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	298	 CTIP1 and CTIP2 proteins have been described as sequence-specific DNA-binding proteins (33).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	299	 The core-binding site identified in this study is highly related to the canonical GC-box sequence.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Since Sp1 anchors COUP-TF to the GC-box sequence of the viral LTR region (12), we addressed how CTIP2 interacts with the HIV-1 promoter.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Our findings demonstrate that CTIP2 is not able to directly bind the three viral GC-box sequences in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	302	 CTIP2 is recruited to the HIV-1 LTR via its association with Sp1 bound to this region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Moreover, CTIP2 is not in competition with COUP-TF for Sp1-mediated anchorage to the viral promoter, indicating that the three proteins are linked together to the LTR in vitro.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	304	 The ChIP experiments conducted in a cellular context confirm that CTIP2, Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins do bind the proximal region of the HIV-1 promoter in chromatin-integrated and non-integrated contexts.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	305	The surprising reduction of Sp1 or COUP-TF binding to the viral promoter in the presence of CTIP2 apparently does not agree with the in vitro observations.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	306	 We show that Sp1 anchors CTIP2 and COUP-TF to the HIV-1 LTR and that Sp1 binding to the GC-box sequence is necessary for CTIP2 recruitment to this region.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Nevertheless, since Sp1 and COUP-TF proteins are not accessible to their related antibodies in the CTIP2-induced nuclear structures, one wonders whether the observation of reduced binding to the LTR may result from protein sequestration and/or chromatin environment.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	308	 ChIP experiments also indicate that CTIP2 promotes Hp1 recruitment to the LTR encompassing the Sp1 binding sequences.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Mutation of the Sp1 binding sites abolished this recruitment.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Taken together, these results suggest that the Sp1-mediated anchorage of CTIP2 to the HIV-1 LTR region may recruit a large complex that promotes Hp1 association, heterochromatin environment and viral gene transcriptional silencing.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	311	 In Jurkat cells, CTIP2 associates with the histone deacetylase SirT1 in a large complex.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	312	 CTIP2-mediated recruitment of SirT1 to promoter template results in a deacetylation of the bound histones H3 and H4 and in a transcriptional repression (35).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	313	 The chromatin structure close to the HIV-1 gene promoter is involved in viral post-integration latency phenomenon (38).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Further studies will be necessary to examine the CTIP2-recruited complex that promotes HIV-1 gene silencing.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	315	To control whether the CTIP2 repressive function is mediated by Sp1 binding sites, we have examined its ability to repress a heterologous promoter containing three consensus GC-boxes.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Our findings reveal that GC-box sequences are sufficient for CTIP2-mediated repression of Sp1 stimulation, suggesting that CTIP2 may impact the transcriptional activity of other GC-box containing promoters.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	317	 In agreement with these observations, CTIP2 is still able to repress LTR-driven transcriptional activity of a LTR deleted downstream of the GC-box sequences.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Recruitment of CTIP1 to the template by a COUP-TF family member has been found to result in a transcriptional repression of a reporter gene harboring a COUP-TF binding site (23).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	319	 In the context of the HIV-1 promoter, deletion of the previously described COUP-TF binding site did not impact CTIP2 repressive function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Moreover, EMSA and ChIP experiments demonstrate that CTIP2 interacts with the proximal region of the LTR excluding the COUP-TF binding sequence.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Taken together, these findings indicate that the COUP-TF binding sequence, located downstream to the GC-box region, might not be implicated in the CTIP2 repressive functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	322	 As widely reported, deletion of the LTR GC-box region results in a drastic ( > 90%) reduction of the LTR-driven transcriptional activity (13 to 15,22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	323	 These observations confirm the crucial contribution of Sp1 and COUP-TF transcription factors to support viral gene transcription in microglial cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Moreover, they highlight the importance of CTIP2-mediated repression of Sp1 and COUP-TF protein functions.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Most of the 80% CTIP2-mediated reduction of the basal transcriptional level may be charged on to this repressive activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Surprisingly, CTIP2 is still able to repress the 10% remaining transcriptional activity driven by a GC-box deleted LTR, suggesting that CTIP2 may also be able to repress the expression of mutated strains of virus.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	327	 This remaining activity represents  < 10% of the global CTIP2-mediated repressive activity.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	328	Nevertheless, we have previously suggested that COUP-TF restores the viral Tat function in the context of a GC-box mutated LTR by anchoring Tat to the basal transcriptional machinery (22).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Interestingly, we observed that CTIP2 is also able to repress this functional cooperation (C.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	330	 These results suggest that, in this context, COUP-TF may bind CTIP2 via its N-terminal region and the general transcription factor TFIIB via its C-terminal part as described previously (39).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Thus, in the absence of Sp1-mediated linkage to the GC-box region of the HIV-1 LTR, CTIP2 may bypass Sp1 association by a COUP-TF-mediated linkage to the basal transcriptional machinery.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Moreover, this proposed indirect linkage might be weak since it appeared undetectable by ChIP experiments.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Along this line, CTIP2 might also associate to some other cellular transcription factors yet to be characterized.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	334	These studies fully complete those reporting CTIP2-mediated repression of the viral Tat function (25).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Since Sp1 or COUP-TF association is necessary for Tat function in microglial cells (22), it can be postulated that CTIP2-mediated impairment of Sp1 and COUP-TF function contributes to the previously observed repression of Tat function.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	336	The chromatin structure at the site of provirus integration is reminiscent to post-integration latency phenomenon (38).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	337	 In vitro, latent T-cell clones frequently contain HIV-1 genome integrated in heterochromatin structures.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	338	 This is in contrast to a productive infection where integration in or near heterochromatin is disfavored (40).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	339	 No antiretroviral drugs that are currently available can inhibit transcription of HIV RNA from the integrated HIV proviral DNA in infected cells.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Nevertheless, HDAC inhibitors are able to induce quiescent provirus, suggesting that derepression of heterochromatin structures may force viral expression from latently infected reservoirs (41,42).
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Thus, investigation on factors that may promote heterochromatin structures to the viral gene promoter, such as CTIP2, appears crucial for understanding these phenomena and for the development of new anti-HIV strategies.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	342	 At this stage, further studies will be necessary to precisely examine the CTIP2-associated enzymatic activities that promote transcriptional silencing.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	343	 In addition, since our investigations were restricted to the transcriptional step of the viral life cycle, it cannot be excluded that CTIP2 also counteracts other critical steps necessary to optimal viral replication.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	344	 This possibility needs further clarification.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	345	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   The authors thank R.
0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Losson for providing Hp1 vectors and anti-Hp1 antibodies, H.

0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	349	 The following reagents were obtained through the NIH AIDS Research and Reference Reagent Program, Division of AIDS, NIAID, NIH: TZM-bl from Dr John C.

0.29273772.15849318.html.plaintext.txt	352	 This work was supported by the Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale (INSERM), by the Agence Nationale de Recherches sur le SIDA (ANRS), by grants from the French Ministry of Research ( ACI JC 5364  to O.
