0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	0	AMP-activated Protein Kinase Regulates HNF4 Transcriptional Activity by Inhibiting Dimer Formation and Decreasing Protein Stability* Yu Holly Hong  , Usha S.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Varanasi  , Wenbo Yang  and Todd Leff   ||.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Pathology and the Center for Integrative Metabolic and Endocrine Research, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan 48201 and the Department of Molecular Science, Pfizer Global Research and Development, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48105.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, April 18, 2003 , and in revised form, May 1, 2003.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	4	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is the central component of a cellular signaling system that regulates multiple metabolic enzymes and pathways in response to reduced intracellular energy levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The transcription factor hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is an orphan nuclear receptor that regulates the expression of genes involved in energy metabolism in the liver, intestine, and endocrine pancreas.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Inheritance of a single null allele of HNF4 causes diabetes in humans.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Here we demonstrate that AMPK directly phosphorylates HNF4 and represses its transcriptional activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	8	 AMPK-mediated phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304 had a 2-fold effect, reducing the ability of the transcription factor to form homodimers and bind DNA and increasing its degradation rate in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These results demonstrate that HNF4 is a downstream target of AMPK and raise the possibility that one of the effects of AMPK activation is reduced expression of HNF4 target genes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The transcription factor HNF41 (NR2A1), a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, plays a key role in regulating the expression of metabolic genes in multiple tissues including the liver, intestine, kidney, and endocrine pancreas (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In humans, a nonsense mutation in a single allele of the HNF4 gene causes an inherited form of diabetes known as maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) (for a review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This syndrome is characterized by insufficient insulin secretion (3, 4), indicating a significant defect in pancreatic function.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Surprisingly, there is not a major deficit in liver function, despite the important role of HNF4 in hepatic gene expression (5).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These observations suggest that HNF4 regulates pancreatic genes involved in glucose sensing and/or insulin production.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This hypothesis is supported by experiments demonstrating that HNF4 regulates expression of genes encoding enzymes of glucose metabolism and insulin secretion (6 to 8).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Because MODY1 patients have a single null allele that does not produce a dominant-negative acting protein (9), the physiological abnormalities in these patients must be caused by a relatively mild (50%) decrease in the amount of HNF4 protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Taken together, these observations raise the possibility that any modification of HNF4 that causes a reduction in its transcriptional activity could have significant effects on pancreatic function.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	18	HNF4 has also been shown recently to play an important role in the regulation of hepatic glucose output, a key component of the maintenance of plasma glucose levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	19	 (10) recently demonstrated that the transcriptional regulation of gene for the key gluconeogenic enzyme phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase by cAMP was mediated by the transcriptional co-activator PGC-1 acting through HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	20	 These findings suggest that HNF4 may play a role in the transcriptional response of the liver to metabolic hormones and that factors regulating the activity of HNF4 could have an effect on hepatic glucose output.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	21	AMPK is the mammalian homolog of the yeast SNF1 protein kinase (11).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In yeast, the SNF1 complex is a nuclear protein that regulates expression of genes involved in glucose metabolism and is activated by phosphorylation when glucose is removed from the growth medium (12).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In mammalian cells, AMPK acts as a fuel sensor that monitors AMP and ATP levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	24	 It is activated by high AMP:ATP ratios during states of low energy charge.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Once activated, the enzyme reduces the activity of ATP-consuming anabolic pathways and increases the activity of catabolic ATP-producing pathways, acting to reestablish normal cellular energy balance (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Depending on the tissue, a variety of physiological circumstances can cause AMPK activation including hypoglycemia (14), ischemia (15), heat shock (16), and exercise (17 to 19).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	27	 AMPK activation has been associated with several key aspects of metabolism including exercise-induced glucose uptake and fatty acid oxidation in muscle (17, 20, 21), reduced lipid (22, 23) and glucose synthesis in liver (12, 24), and altered glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in the endocrine pancreas (14, 25).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	28	AMPK is a heterotrimer consisting of a catalytic subunit and two non-catalytic and subunits (26, 27) that exist in multiple isoforms (28 to 30).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Kinase activity is regulated allosterically by AMP binding and also by direct phosphorylation mediated by an uncharacterized AMP-sensitive protein kinase.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	30	 A potential role of AMPK in the nucleus is suggested by several observations.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The first is the similarity of the mammalian kinase to the yeast SNF1 transcriptional regulator, as described above.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Second, AMPK heterotrimers containing the 2 subunit isoform are preferentially found in the nucleus (31).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In addition, AMPK has been shown to phosphorylate the transcriptional coactivator p300 and to regulate its ability to mediate nuclear receptor transcriptional activity (32).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	34	It has been reported previously (33) that AMPK activation reduces HNF4 target gene transcription.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	35	 These findings, together with the fact that both proteins participate in the regulation of similar metabolic pathways, raise the possibility that HNF4 is directly regulated by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The experiments described here examine the possibility that AMPK phosphorylates HNF4 and regulates its transcriptional activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	37	   EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Plasmid Construction The HNF4 expression construct pH4c-WT contains a C-terminal FLAG-tagged full-length human HNF4 cDNA sequence cloned into the CMV promoter-based vector pCDNA3.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The S304A and S304D mutants were introduced into pH4c-WT using the Quik-Change site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) according to the manufacturer's instructions, and confirmed by DNA sequencing, to produce the plasmids pH4c-304A and pH4c-304D.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The pH4c series plasmids were used in experiments presented in Figs.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	40	 For experiments designed to examine HNF4 protein stability (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	41	 4, B and C), full-length N-terminal FLAG-tagged wild-type, 304A, and 304D cDNA sequences were cloned into the tetracycline-regulated vector, pTRE-shuttle2 (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA), to form pH4i-WT, pH4i-304A, and pH4i-304D.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	42	 GFP-HNF4 protein was expressed from a pCDNA3.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	43	1 vector containing an N-terminal fusion of the EGFP coding sequences (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) fused to the full-length HNF4 cDNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	44	 GST-HNF4 protein was produced from a pET23a vector (Novagen, Madison, WI) containing an N-terminal fusion of glutathione S-transferase sequences and the full-length HNF4 cDNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	45	HNF4/A to D plasmids contain PCR-amplified subfragments of HNF4 (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	46	 1C) as His and T7 tag N-terminal fusions in the pET28a vector.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The same subfragments were also cloned into the pCMV-Tag2b plasmid (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) for expression in eukaryotic cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The HNF4-responsive reporter plasmid pL854 contains promoter sequences from the human apoCIII gene ( to 854 to +22) linked to luciferase in the pGL3-basic vector (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The -galactosidase plasmid contains a CMV-driven -galactosidase gene.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	50	View larger version (31K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	51	 HNF4 is phosphorylated by AMPK in vitro.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	52	 A, autoradiogram of full-length human HNF4 phosphorylated by AMPK in an in vitro kinase reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	53	 HNF4 protein produced in an in vitro transcription/translation system was incubated with purified rat liver AMPK and [-32P]ATP.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	54	 For comparison, the same quantity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL), a known substrate of the kinase, was phosphorylated in a parallel reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	55	 B, amino acid sequence of the consensus phosphorylation site for AMPK (53), showing the three best matches in the human HNF4 sequence (bottom).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Potential phosphorylation residues are shown in boldface.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The amino acid numbers are based on GenBankTM entry XM029795.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Lower panels are Western blots (WB) showing total protein amounts in the reactions.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Numbers below each lane indicate the degree of phosphorylation relative to the wild-type protein in the absence of kinase and AMP.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The degree of phosphorylation was calculated from quantified autoradiograph and Western blot bands as the ratio of phosphorylated to total protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	70	 C, in vivo phosphorylation of the HNF4 C fragment by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	71	 BHK cells were transfected with either vector (Vec) alone or constructions producing FLAG-tagged wild-type or S304A mutant HNF4 C protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Transfected cells were treated with the AMPK activator AICAR as indicated and [32P]orthophosphate.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	73	 HNF4 C fragment protein was immunoprecipitated with anti-FLAG antibodies and subjected to electrophoresis, transfer to nitrocellulose, and autoradiography (upper panel) or Western analysis (lower panel).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	74	  View larger version (69K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Phosphorylation at Ser-304 blocks dimerization and DNA binding.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	76	 A, the phosphomimetic HNF4 S304D mutation is defective in its ability to bind DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In vitro transcription/translation reactions were programmed with plasmids producing full-length wild-type, S304A, or S304D HNF4 proteins (pH4c series plasmids) or with empty vector (Vec).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The DNA binding activities of the three HNF4 proteins were analyzed in a gel mobility shift assay using the proximal HNF4-binding site of the apoCIII promoter as labeled probe.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The lower panel is a Western blot showing the input amount of HNF4 protein used in the DNA binding reactions.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	80	 B, the S304D mutant HNF4 protein is defective in its ability to form HNF4 homodimers.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	81	 A GST pull-down assay was performed with in vitro produced GST-HNF4 fusion protein (wild-type, full-length).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The plasmid producing the 78-kDa GST fusion protein was co-translated with plasmids producing 52 kDa wild-type, S304A, or S304D as indicated in the presence of [35S]methionine.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Lanes 1 to 3 were subjected to GST pull-down procedure using glutathione beads, whereas lanes 4 to 6 were loaded directly on the gel without pull-down.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Lanes 7 and 8 are translations of the two input plasmids alone.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	85	 C, gel mobility shift assay showing that the phosphomimetic HNF4 S304D mutation is defective in forming functional dimers.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In vitro translated GFP-HNF4 fusion protein (81 kDa) and 52-kDa wild-type, S304A, and S304D mutants were co-translated as indicated and analyzed in a gel mobility shift assay.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The DNA-protein complexes with each of the possible dimer combinations is indicated on the right.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Equivalent amounts of each protein were used the DNA binding reactions as determined by Western blot analysis (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	89	 D, gel shift analysis of wild-type and mutant HNF4 proteins produced in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	90	 CHO cells were transfected with the indicated plasmids, treated with the AMPK activator AICAR as indicated, and nuclear extracts were prepared and subjected to gel mobility shift analysis using the apoCIII promoter proximal HNF4-binding site as a probe.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Equivalent amounts of nuclear extract were loaded on each lane.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	93	  View larger version (26K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Phosphorylation of HNF4 on Ser-304 reduces protein stability.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	96	 These construct(ion)s produce C-terminal FLAG-tagged HNF4.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Upper panel, anti-FLAG antibody, showing full-length HNF4 and smaller molecular weight fragments.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Lower panel is the same membrane reprobed with anti--actin antibodies as loading control.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	100	 B, Western blot showing the effect of S304 mutations on the rate of HNF4 protein degradation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	101	 CHO cells transiently transfected with pH4i plasmids (pH4i-WT, pH4i-304A, and pH4i-304D) producing N-terminal FLAG-tagged HNF4 protein under the control of a tetracycline-regulated promoter.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Cells were treated with doxycycline 18 h post-transfection to shut off expression of HNF4 protein and harvested at the indicated times thereafter.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Western analysis was performed using an anti-FLAG antibody to detect HNF4 and reprobed with anti-GFP antibody to detect the amount of EGFP protein produced from a co-transfected pEGFP-N1 reference plasmid.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	104	 C, results from a densitometric analysis of the blots in B.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The HNF4:GFP ratio was calculated for each lane, and the data for each construction was normalized to the 2-h time point that was set to 100.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The data are plotted as the log values of the relative HNF4 protein amount.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The calculated half-life values from regression lines are shown in hours.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	108	  View larger version (15K):    FIG.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Phosphomimetic S304D mutation reduces transcriptional activity of HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	110	 CHO cells were transfected with an HNF4-responsive luciferase reporter and increasing amounts (in micrograms) of either wild-type, S304A, or S304D HNF4 producing plasmids as indicated.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Relative transcription was calculated as the ratio of luciferase to -galactosidase activity (from a cotransfected reference plasmid) normalized to the activity of the vector control.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Values are the means of three replicates, and error bars represent standard deviation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	113	Cell Culture, Transfection, and Reporter Assay Transient transfections for in vivo labeling were conducted in a baby hamster kidney cell line, BHK-21, which was cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells were used in transfection for transcription assays and nuclear extract preparation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	115	 CHO cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F-12 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	116	 All transfections were carried out with LipofectAMINE 2000 (Invitrogen).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Transfections for reporter assays were conducted in 24-well plates in triplicate for each condition.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Cells were harvested at 20 h post-transfection using lysis buffer (Promega, Madison, WI), and the lysates were analyzed with Tropix Dual Light Luciferase and -galactosidase assay kit (Tropix, Inc.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	119	, Bedford, MA) using an EG and G Berthold Microlumat 96P luminometer.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	120	In Vitro and in Vivo Phosphorylation In vitro phosphorylation assays were conducted with in vitro translated proteins produced using the TNT Quick-Coupled transcription/translation system (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	121	 TNT reactions were carried out for 60 min at 30  degrees C and then immunoprecipitated by anti-FLAG (Sigma) or anti-T7 (Novagen Inc.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	122	, Madison, WI) antibodies, and protein A/G-agarose beads (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	123	 After washing five times with HNTG buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	124	5, 50 mM NaCl, 5% glycerol, 1% Triton, 1.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	125	5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA), the purified beads were subjected to an in vitro phosphorylation reaction using 100 milliunits of purified rat liver AMPK (Upstate Inc.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	126	, Lake Placid, NY) per reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Reactions were carried out in a buffer containing 5 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	128	5 mM MgCl2,50  microM ATP, 10  microCi of [-32P]ATP, and a mixture of protein kinase C/protein kinase A inhibitors, with or without of 300  microM AMP, and incubated at 30  degrees C for 30 min.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The reactions were stopped by washing the beads three times with HNTG buffer and adding 30  microl of 2x SDS loading buffer (Invitrogen).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The protein products were separated on SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose membranes, which were then subjected to autoradiography and Western blot analysis using an anti-FLAG antibody conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (Sigma), and detected with the SuperSignal West Pico chemiluminescent system (Pierce).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	131	In vivo phosphorylation labeling was conducted in BHK cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	132	S304A mutant, along with the control vector, were transfected in 100-mm plates.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Each plate was split into two 60-mm plates 16 h post-transfection.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In vivo labeling was conducted with 1 mCi (37 MBq) of [32P]orthophosphate per plate for 1 h at 40 h post-transfection, with or without of 500  microM 5'-aminoimidazol-4-carboxoxamide 1--D-ribofuranoside (AICAR).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Cells were harvested in 600  microl of HNTG buffer and mixed for 30 min at 4  degrees C.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-FLAG monoclonal antibody (Sigma) and 50  microl of protein A/G-agarose beads for 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The beads were washed five times with same buffer.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Bound proteins were eluted in 30  microl of 2x SDS loading buffer at 95  degrees C for 5 min, separated on 4 to 12% gradient SDS-PAGE gel, transferred to nitrocellulose membrane, and detected by autoradiography or Western blot using anti-FLAG antibody conjugated with horseradish peroxidase as described above.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	139	Gel Mobility Shift and Pull-down Assays CHO cells transfected with full-length, wild-type, or mutant HNF4 were harvested at 20 h post-transfection, with or without 12 h treatment of AICAR.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Nuclear extracts were prepared essentially as described (34).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The recombinant HNF4 proteins were produced in vitro using TNT Quik-Coupled transcription/translation system as described by the manufacturer (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	142	 For dimerization experiments, where different HNF4 proteins were produced from two plasmids, templates producing wild-type or mutant HNF4 proteins were used in the co-translation reactions at ratios determined in pilot translations to produce equal amounts of protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	143	 For GST pull-down assays, 25  microl of translation reactions were incubated with 15  microl of glutathione-Sepharose 4B (Amersham Biosciences) in BC-150 buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	144	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 1x protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Diagnostics)) for 30 min at room temperature on a rotary platform.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The beads were washed five times with BC-150 buffer, boiled in 25  microl of SDS sample buffer, and resolved on 4 to 20% gradient gels (Invitrogen).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Gels were stained with Coomassie Blue, incubated in Amplify (Amersham Biosciences) for 30 min, dried, and fluorographed.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	147	The synthetic double-stranded oligonucleotides used in DNA binding reaction were labeled with [-32P]dCTP using the Rediprime-II random labeling system (Amersham Biosciences).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The double-stranded DNA binding probe contains the proximal HNF4-binding site from the human apoCIII gene (35).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	149	 DNA binding reactions were carried out in 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	150	06% Nonidet P-40, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 1  microg of double-stranded poly(dI-dC), with 20,000 cpm of labeled probe (0.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	151	25 ng), and either with 2 to 5  microg of nuclear extract or 1  microl of TNT reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Reactions were incubated for 20 min at room temperature and then analyzed on precast 6% DNA retardation gels (Invitrogen) in 0.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	153	5x TBE at 125 V for 45 min at room temperature.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	154	Protein Stability Experiments For the experiments shown in Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	155	 4, B and C, CHO cells were transfected in 12-well plates as described above but using LipofectAMINE Plus (Invitrogen) with 1 ng of the tetracycline-regulated HNF4 expressing plasmids (pH4i-WT, pH4i-304A, and pH4i-304D) together with 20 ng of pTET-OFF and 40 ng of pEGFP-N1 (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA) per well.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	156	 18 h after transfection doxycycline was added (1  microg/ml) to the culture media to stop transcription of recombinant HNF4 and cells were harvested 2, 4, 6, and 8 h later by lysis in HNTG buffer.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis to detect FLAG-HNF4 and GFP protein were carried out as described above.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	158	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Activation of AMPK in cultured hepatocytes with the AMP analog AICAR caused a decrease in the activity of HNF4 target gene expression and a reduction in the amount of HNF4 (33).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	159	 To explore the possibility that these effects are due to direct regulation of HNF4 by AMPK, we tested whether AMPK could phosphorylate HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	160	 An in vitro phosphorylation assay containing full-length HNF4 and partially purified AMPK was carried out.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	161	 1A) demonstrate that HNF4 was efficiently phosphorylated by AMPK, showing approximately the same degree of phosphorylation as a similar amount of the well characterized AMPK substrate hormone-sensitive lipase.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	162	Mapping AMPK Phosphorylation Site on HNF4 When the HNF4 amino acid sequence was screened for the consensus target sequence for AMPK phosphorylation, three potential sites were found (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	163	 1B) with the best match to a site surrounding serine 304.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	164	 To determine whether any of these sites were targets for AMPK phosphorylation, they were each mutated to alanine and examined in an in vitro phosphorylation assay.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	165	 None of the mutants abolished phosphorylation by AMPK (data not shown), indicating that there are multiple AMPK phosphorylation sites on HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	166	 To examine phosphorylation of individual segments of the protein independently, four overlapping fragments of HNF4 were generated from subclones of the HNF4 cDNA (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	167	 When in vitro AMPK assays were conducted, all four subfragments were phosphorylated to some degree (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	168	 1D) and showed the expected enhancement of phosphorylation in the presence of AMP (an allosteric activator of the kinase).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	169	 However, when the results were normalized to the total amount of protein in the assay, the HNF4/C fragment (containing the Ser-304 site) showed the highest degree of AMP-dependent phosphorylation (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	170	 A significant amount of phosphorylation was also observed with the HNF4/A fragment.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The HNF4/A fragment contains one of the three potential consensus sites for AMPK (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	172	 However, mutation of threonine 15 to alanine in this sequence did not reduce the phosphorylation of the HNF4/A fragment, suggesting the presence of one or more cryptic AMPK sites in this part of the protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	173	To determine whether the C fragment is phosphorylated at the Ser-304 residue, the S304A mutant was transferred to the C fragment and examined in an in vitro phosphorylation assay.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	174	 2A, mutation of serine 304 completely abolished phosphorylation of the C fragment.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Although the Ser-304 site is also present in the D fragment (Fig 1C), it does not appear to be a good substrate for the kinase in this context as this fragment is phosphorylated to a much lower degree than the C fragment (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	176	 When the S304A mutation was examined quantitatively in the context of the full-length protein, it reduced phosphorylation by 50% (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Together, these results suggest that S304A is a phosphorylation site for AMPK in vitro and that additional sites are present in both the N and C termini of protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	178	In vivo, HNF4 is a phosphoprotein and is a substrate for multiple kinases (36, 37).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	179	 To explore the phosphorylation of HNF4 by AMPK in vivo, wild-type and S304A versions of the HNF4/C fragment were cloned into a eukaryotic expression vector and transfected into baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	180	 In vivo phosphorylation labeling was carried out with these transfected cells in the presence or absence of AICAR.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	181	 AICAR is converted in cells to the AMP analog ZMP (5'-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide-1-E-D-ribofuranotide), which activates the kinase (38).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The wild-type HNF4/C fragment was phosphorylated during the labeling reaction, and the treatment of the cells with AICAR caused an 2-fold increase of phosphorylation (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This phosphorylation was completely absent when the S304A version of the fragment was used, indicating that Ser-304 is phosphorylated in vivo by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In vivo phosphorylation experiments using the full-length HNF4 protein showed the same degree of phosphorylation for the wild-type and Ser-304 mutant protein (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	185	 This may be due to a combination of high basal phosphorylation of HNF4 by multiple kinases in vivo (36, 37) and the likelihood that there are additional AMPK phosphorylation sites on HNF4 (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	186	Functional Effects of HNF4 Phosphorylation To explore potential functional effects of phosphorylation of HNF4 at serine 304, an aspartic acid residue was introduced at this site by in vitro mutagenesis to generate a charge mimic of the phosphoserine residue.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The effect of phosphorylation at Ser-304 on the ability of HNF4 to form functional homodimers and bind to DNA was examined in a gel mobility shift assay with wild-type and the phosphomimetic S304D versions of HNF4 proteins synthesized by in vitro translation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Both the wild-type and S304A version of HNF4 bound to an HNF4-response element derived from the human apoCIII promoter (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	189	 However, the S304D mutant HNF4 showed a dramatically reduced ability to bind to DNA despite similar amounts of protein present in the reaction (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Gel mobility shift experiments using HNF4 protein that was phosphorylated by AMPK in vitro showed only a mild reduction in DNA binding activity (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The effect of phosphorylation on the ability of HNF4 to bind DNA would be less pronounced than the S304D mutation if less than 100% of the HNF4 protein is phosphorylated in the in vitro kinase reaction.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Although the efficiency of these reactions is unknown, it is likely that only a fraction of the HNF4 molecules become phosphorylated at Ser-304 leaving the non-phosphorylated protein free to form dimers and bind DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In addition, it is also possible that dimers composed of one phosphorylated and one non-phosphorylated HNF4 molecule are competent to bind DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	194	Because HNF4 binds DNA as a homodimer, the defective DNA binding of the S304D mutant could be due either to reduced dimer formation or to a diminished affinity of mutant dimers for DNA.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	195	 To examine directly the effect of the mutant on dimerization, in the absence of DNA, an in vitro association assay using 35S-labeled HNF4 monomers of different sizes was carried out.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A fusion protein of GST and wild-type HNF4 (protein size 78 kDa) was co-translated with either wild-type or mutant full-length HNF4 protein (52 kDa).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The GST-HNF4 fusion protein was purified out of the reaction with a glutathione resin together with dimerized 52-kDa wild-type or mutant HNF4.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	198	 3B) demonstrated that wild-type and S304A HNF4 readily formed dimers with the wild-type GST-HNF4 protein (arrow, lanes 1 and 2).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	199	 In contrast, the S304D protein showed a reduced ability to interact with the wild-type GST-HNF4 (compare lane 3 to lanes 1 and 2).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Densitometry analysis of the Western blot demonstrated that the lower input amount of S304D protein (lane 6) did not account for the reduction in the amount of S304D bound to wild-type GST-HNF4 protein (data not shown).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	201	To examine further the ability of dimers composed of one unphosphorylated monomer and one phosphorylated monomer to form and bind to DNA, wild-type and S304D mutant HNF4 proteins of different sizes were mixed together and the resulting dimers analyzed by gel mobility shift.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	202	 3C) demonstrate that dimers composed of one wild-type GFP-HNF4 molecule (81 kDa) and one S304D molecule (52 kDa) can form and are competent to bind DNA (lane 6) but with less efficiency than dimers of wild-type GFP-HNF4 and either wild-type or S304A HNF4 proteins (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	203	 3C, compare lane 6 to lanes 3 and 9).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	204	 3A, homodimers of S304D HNF4 failed to form (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	205	 3C, compare lane 4 to lanes 1 and 7).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Taken together, these results demonstrate that, in vitro, a negative charge on serine 304 inhibits dimer formation and that the effect is more pronounced when both monomers contain the additional negative charge.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	207	To examine the effects of Ser-304 phosphorylation on dimer formation and DNA binding in vivo, wild-type, S304A, and S304D expression constructs were transfected into CHO cells (which have very low amounts of endogenous HNF4).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	208	 After transfection, AMPK was activated by AICAR treatment, and nuclear extracts were prepared for gel mobility shift assays.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	209	 As observed in vitro the S304D phosphomimetic mutant showed reduced DNA binding activity (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In addition there is a mild reduction in DNA binding of the wild-type protein upon AICAR treatment (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	211	 3D, compare lanes 4 and 5) that did not occur in the phosphorylation-defective S304A protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	212	 However, much of this reduction in DNA binding activity correlates with changes in the amount of HNF4 present in the various transfections (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	213	 For example, the amount of S304D protein is significantly lower than the wild-type protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	214	 3D, compare lane 8 to lane 4, lower panel).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Likewise, the amount of wild-type HNF4 is reduced after AMPK activation (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	216	 3D, compare lanes 4 and 5, lower panel).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The reduction of HNF4 amounts after AICAR treatment did not occur with the phosphorylation-defective S304A mutation (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	218	 3D, compare lanes 6 and 7, lower panel) suggesting that the effect is due to phosphorylation at serine 304.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	219	 These changes in HNF4 protein amounts suggest that addition of a negative charge to serine 304 reduces the stability of the HNF4 protein in these cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	220	Potential effects of AMPK activation on HNF4 protein stability were further explored by examining the appearance of proteolytic products of wild-type and mutant HNF4 proteins in transiently transfected CHO cells treated with AICAR.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Western blot analysis shows that in the absence of AICAR detectable amounts of degradation fragments appear in only lysates from cells transfected with the phosphomimetic S304D HNF4 (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The activation of AMPK by AICAR addition induced the appearance of degradation fragments from the wild-type but not the phosphorylation-defective S304A protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	223	 These findings indicate that phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304 increased the proteolytic degradation of the protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In addition, these results strongly support the conclusion that AMPK phosphorylates HNF4 on serine 304 in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	225	 To measure the rate of degradation of wild-type and mutant HNF4 proteins, a tetracycline-regulated expression system was used to transiently express wild-type and 304 mutant HNF4 in transfected CHO cells.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	226	 18 h post-transfection, HNF4 expression was specifically extinguished by the addition of doxycycline, and the amount of HNF4 protein remaining in the cells was determined at regular intervals over the following 8 h.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	227	 4, B and C) demonstrate that the phosphomimetic S304D mutant protein was degraded more rapidly then either the wild-type or S304A proteins.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Taken together, the in vitro and in vivo results suggest that phosphorylation of HNF4 at Ser-304 has two effects on HNF4: to reduce its ability to form functional dimers, and to reduce the stability of HNF4 in vivo.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	229	The HNF4 dimerization and DNA binding results presented above predict that the AMPK-mediated phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304 would have a negative effect on its transcriptional activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	230	 To determine whether this is the case, plasmids expressing wild-type and Ser-304 mutant proteins were transfected into CHO cells together with an HNF4-responsive reporter plasmid.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	231	 As predicted from the DNA binding studies, the S304D mutant showed significantly less transcriptional activity than the wild-type HNF4 protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The S304A mutant was slightly more active than the wild-type protein suggesting the possibility that there is a basal level of phosphorylation that reduces the activity of the wild-type protein.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	233	 These results indicate AMPK-negative regulates HNF4 activity by phosphorylation of serine 304 and suggest that AMPK activity could influence the expression of HNF4 target genes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	234	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Here we report that the transcription factor HNF4 is a novel substrate of AMP-activated protein kinase.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Given the central role of AMPK in mediating the response to changes in cellular energy balance and the fact that HNF4 regulates genes involved in energy metabolism, these findings suggest a mechanism for how the expression of a specific set of metabolic genes might be linked to cellular energy status.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Although we have not directly demonstrated that AMPK regulates HNF4-mediated gene expression in vivo, a previous study reported that activation of AMPK activity in primary liver cells correlated with reduced expression of HNF4 target genes (33).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Our findings offer a potential mechanistic explanation for the relationship between HNF4 target gene down-regulation and AMPK activation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The kinase phosphorylates HNF4 on serine 304 (Figs.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	239	 1 and 2), which causes a reduction in the ability of HNF4 to form dimers and bind DNA (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	240	 In vivo, addition of a negative charge to this residue, by substitution with an aspartic acid residue, reduced the ability of HNF4 to activate transcription from a cotransfected HNF4-dependent reporter (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	241	In addition to the effects on HNF4 dimerization and DNA binding, phosphorylation of HNF4 on Ser-304, or conversion of Ser-304 to an aspartic acid, also caused an increase in the degradation rate and a reduction in the amount of HNF4 protein (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Our results are consistent with previous findings showing that activation of AMPK in primary hepatocytes resulted in a reduction in the amount of endogenous HNF4 (33).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Taken together, our findings suggest a model in which one of the branches of the AMPK signaling pathway results in the phosphorylation of HNF4 on serine 304, leading to both a reduction in the amount and activity of HNF4 and a subsequent reduction in the expression of HNF4 target genes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	244	Although the work reported here is focused on the phosphorylation of the serine 304 residue in HNF4, it is clear that this is not the only site on HNF4 that is phosphorylated by AMPK.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The HNF4/A fragment from the N-terminal half of the protein was strongly phosphorylated in vitro on a site that we were not able to map.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	246	 This site (or sites) may be responsible for the remaining phosphorylation of the full-length protein that occurs when the Ser-304 residue is mutated to alanine (Fig.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	247	 We are currently mapping the AMPK site in the N terminus of HNF4 so that we can determine their functional significance.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In addition to the regulation of HNF4 activity that we describe here, it has been reported previously that HNF4 DNA binding activity is repressed by protein kinase A-mediated phosphorylation of residues in the DNA binding domain (37).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	249	 It has also been reported that phosphorylation of HNF4 on tyrosine residues affected its transcriptional activity and sub-nuclear localization (39).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These findings, together with those reported here, suggest that that HNF4 is a highly regulated transcription factor and that multiple signaling pathways influence its activity.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	251	An interesting question concerning the phosphorylation of HNF4 by AMPK in vivo is the cellular location in which it occurs.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	252	 HNF4 is strongly associated with the nucleus, whereas most of the known AMPK substrates are cytoplasmic enzymes.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Although it is possible that HNF4 is also phosphorylated by in the cytoplasm, the most appealing compartment for the interaction would be the nucleus.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Several observations support this possibility.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	255	 First, specific isoforms of the kinase have been reported to be present in the nucleus (31, 40).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Second, other transcriptional components have been reported to be potential substrates of the kinase; the co-activator p300 (32) and the carbohydrate-response transcription factor ChREBP (41).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Finally, the yeast homolog of mammalian AMPK, SNF-1, is present in the nucleus (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	258	 13) and is associated with chromatin, possibly in a gene-specific pattern (42).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Together these observations suggest the intriguing possibility that at least some version of mammalian AMPK may be a component of the transcriptional complex on specific genes that are regulated by cellular energy balance.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	260	What would be the physiological outcome of reduced HNF4 target gene expression? The answer to this question depends on the tissue being considered.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	261	 In the endocrine pancreas, reduction of HNF4 activity would be predicted to have significant effect on the ability of the islet to secrete the appropriate amount of insulin.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	262	 This possibility is illustrated by the phenotype of MODY1 patients who have only one normal allele of the HNF4 gene and presumably a reduced amount of active HNF4 protein (3).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	263	 These patients have a defective insulin secretion in response that appears to be a primary effect of reduced HNF4 levels in pancreatic -cells (4, 43).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Consistent with the apparent role of HNF4 in pancreatic physiology are the observations that HNF4 regulates a variety of -cell genes involved in glucose sensing and insulin secretion (6 to 8).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	265	Like HNF4, AMPK also clearly plays a role in the physiology of the endocrine pancreas.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	266	 It is likely that the -cell senses glucose concentration as fluctuations in the amount of intracellular ATP generated by glucose oxidation.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The insulin secretory machinery gauges the amount of insulin to secrete by sensing these ATP level fluctuations (for review see Ref.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	268	 It is possible that the changes in cellular energy balance in -cells that occur in normal physiology have an effect on HNF4 phosphorylation and activity and that fluctuation in HNF4 activity are part of the normal physiological regulation of the islet.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Consistent with this possibility is the observation that low glucose levels induce AMPK activity in cell lines derived from pancreatic -cells and the suggestion that changes in kinase activity are involved in insulin secretion (25).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Alternatively, it is possible that AMPK-mediated changes in HNF4 activity are relevant in pathological conditions where AMPK is aberrantly activated and HNF4 activity is suppressed below normal levels.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	271	 This situation could potentially result in a physiological circumstance analogous to the MODY1 phenotype.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	272	Another tissue where AMPK-mediated changes in HNF4 target gene expression could have a significant metabolic effect is the liver.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	273	 It has been understood for many years that HNF4 plays an important role in the liver, regulating genes involved in lipid (45), amino acid (46, 47), and glucose metabolism (48, 49) and the coagulation cascade (50).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	274	 It has been reported recently that HNF4 plays a key role in the induction of hepatic gluconeogenesis by mediating the transcriptional effects of the co-activator PGC1 (10).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	275	 On the other hand, the reduction of HNF4 levels due to haploinsufficiency in MODY1 patients did not cause major liver abnormalities (5, 51), although changes in amounts of some liver-derived serum proteins were observed (52).
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	276	It is clear that an AMPK-mediated phosphorylation of HNF4 could potentially have important effects on liver and pancreatic islet physiology.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	277	 We are currently examining HNF4 phosphorylation in hepatic and pancreatic cell lines to determine whether AMPK-dependent phosphorylation of Ser-304 occurs under more physiological conditions and to ascertain the potential metabolic role of the phosphorylation events described here.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	278	   FOOTNOTES   * The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.297294.12740371.html.plaintext.txt	340	 (2000) Diabetes 49, 832 to 837[Abstract] Hardie, D.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	0	An enhancer element 6 kb upstream of the mouse HNF41 promoter is activated by glucocorticoids and liver-enriched transcription factors Alain Bailly, Maria Elena Torres-Padilla, Antoine P.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	1	Unite de Genetique de la Differenciation, FRE 2364 du CNRS, Institut Pasteur, 25 Rue du Dr Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received May 31, 2001; Revised and Accepted July 9, 2001.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   We have characterized a 700 bp enhancer element around  to 6 kb relative to the HNF41 transcription start.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	4	 This element increases activity and confers glucocorticoid induction to a heterologous as well as the homologous promoters in differentiated hepatoma cells and is transactivated by HNF41, HNF47, HNF1 and HNF1ss in dedifferentiated hepatoma cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	5	 A 240 bp sub-region conserves basal and hormone-induced enhancer activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	6	 It contains HNF1, HNF4, HNF3 and C/EBP binding sites as shown by DNase I footprinting and electrophoretic mobility shift assays using nuclear extracts and/or recombinant HNF1 and HNF41.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Mutation analyses showed that the HNF1 site is essential for HNF1 transactivation and is required for full basal enhancer activity, as is the C/EBP site.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Glucocorticoid response element consensus sites which overlap the C/EBP, HNF4 and HNF3 sites are crucial for optimal hormonal induction.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	9	 We present a model that accounts for weak expression of HNF41 in the embryonic liver and strong expression in the newborn/adult liver via the binding sites identified in the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   HNF4, a member of the steroid hormone receptor superfamily (1), is one of the first liver-enriched transcription factors (LETF) to be expressed during the course of development.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Indeed, transcripts are observed in the mouse at embryonic day (E)4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	12	5 in the extra-embryonic visceral endoderm and in embryonic tissues in the liver and gut primordia at around E8.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	13	 A somewhat earlier and overlapping expression pattern characterizes HNF3ss and HNF1ss, respectively, the only other LETF to have such precocious expression (3 to 6).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Each of the three factors is essential for normal embryogenesis: targeted mutation of the corresponding genes causes an early embryonic lethal phenotype (3 to 7), due in the cases of HNF4 and HNF1ss to disruption of visceral endoderm function, essential for the progression of gastrulation (4,5,8).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In addition, HNF4 is required for the expression of a number of essential liver functions of differentiated hepatocytes (9).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Alteration of some of these functions may be involved in maturity-onset diabetes of the young 1 (MODY1), linked to HNF4 insufficiency (10,11).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	17	 HNF4 mutations linked to MODY1 affect the coding region of the protein.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, mutations in regulatory regions of the gene may yet be identified (reviewed in 12), providing a strong impetus to locate and characterize these sequences.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In view of the importance of HNF4 for execution of the hepatocyte differentiation program, as well as its early expression pattern, the search for regulators of the HNF4 gene should inform us of the factors that are critical not only for hepatocyte differentation and function, but for endoderm formation as well.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	20	Relatively little information is available concerning the regulation of expression of the HNF4 gene.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	21	 A series of up to 10 DNase I hypersensitive sites (HS) in adult liver chromatin, spread out over 15 kb of DNA upstream of the start of transcription of HNF41, the initially isolated isoform (1), implies that its regulation is complex (13,14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	22	5 kb fragment of DNA upstream of the transcription start site and its 5' deletions to analyze expression in transient transfection assays in hepatoma cells as well as in transgenic mice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	23	 While the long fragment and deletions down to  to 228 bp showed similar activity in transient expression assays, only the long fragment conferred appropriate activity to a reporter gene in transgenic mice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These results imply that the distal HS harbor important regulatory sites for HNF41 expression.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Several splice variants of HNF4 have been described (reviewed in 12), so it is assumed that all of the HNF4 variants concern alternative splicing events within a single gene region.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	26	 However, the most recently described of them, HNF47, contains a unique sequence encoding the N-terminal portion of the protein and the 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR), implying that it is transcribed from a separate promoter (15).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	27	We have analyzed the regulatory role of distal sequences upstream of the HNF41 promoter and characterized a 700 bp enhancer conferring high activity and glucocorticoid induction to both a heterologous and the HNF41 promoter.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We have found LETF binding sites and glucocorticoid-responsive sequences essential for enhancer activity in a 240 bp sub-region.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Our results are in line with the requirement for upstream sequences for tissue-specific activity of the HNF41 promoter (14) and with glucocorticoid induction of HNF41 expression (11,15) and lead us to propose a model of biphasic regulation of this enhancer involved in HNF41 expression during liver development.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	30	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Nucleotide sequence accession number The GenBank accession number for the mouse 700 bp HNF41 enhancer is AF320052.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	31	Cell lines and culture conditions FGC4 rat hepatoma cells (16) are well differentiated whereas H5 cells (17) are dedifferentiated variants.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Cells were grown in modified Ham s F12 medium (18) containing 5% fetal calf serum.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Human epithelial carcinoma C33 cells (19) were maintained in Dulbecco s modified Eagle s medium containing 7% fetal calf serum.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	34	 All cells were cultured under humidified 7% CO2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	35	Transient transfections Fragments of the mouse HNF41 5'-region (see Figs 1A and 2A) derived from the SBII2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	36	Zhong, Yale University, New Haven, CT) were cloned in front of the herpes simplex virus thymidine kinase (tk) promoter driving transcription of the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase gene (CAT) in pBLCAT5 (20).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The 700 bp enhancer was cloned in  to 34pZLUC (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	38	8pZLUC is described in Zhong et al.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Constructs with the 700 bp enhancer and its sub-regions were checked by DNA sequencing.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Standard transfections were performed by the calcium phosphate procedure as previously described (21) using 5  microg each of reporter plasmid and internal control plasmid RSVlacZ.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Cells were harvested 64 h later.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Where indicated, 1  microM dexamethasone (Dex) was added 48 h before harvest.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In co-transfection experiments in C33 cells (15 or 6 x 105), test and control plasmids were used at 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	44	165  microg each and pBluescript plasmid was added to 3.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	45	 In some experiments, FGC4 cells (5 x 106 cells in 150  microl of medium) were electroporated with a Bio-Rad gene pulser and capacitance extender (960  microF, 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	46	2 kV), using 5  microg each of test and control plasmid.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In co-transfections, expression vectors for HNF1 (RSV-HNF1; 22), HNF1ss (RSV-vHNF1; 23), HNF41 (HNF4tag; 24), HNF47 (M.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	48	Weiss, submitted for publication) and HNF3 (a kind gift of R.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	49	Costa, University of Illinois, Chicago, IL) were used.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The expression vector promoter was kept constant by addition of appropriate vector DNA.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	51	 CAT and luciferase activities were determined as described (25,26) and ss-galactosidase activity by the standard colorimetric method.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	52	 CAT and luciferase activities were normalized to ss-galactosidase activity and calculated relative to that of pBLCAT5 or  to 34pZLUC, respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	53	View larger version (23K):    Figure 1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Enhancer activity and Dex inducibility of distal sequences upstream of the HNF41 transcription start.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	55	 (A) (Left) Scheme of the HNF41 5'-region showing positions of liver- and kidney-specific HS (13,14), a partial restriction map (B, BamHI; E, EcoRI; G, BglII; X, XbaI) and the transcription start (arrow).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	56	 (Below) Cloned restriction fragments (B1E4 was cloned in the antisense direction).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	57	 (Right) CAT activity of the corresponding reporter plasmids transfected in differentiated (FGC4) or dedifferentiated (H5) hepatoma cells or in non-hepatic cells (C33).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Values are means of three (FGC4), two to three (H5) or one to four (C33) independent experiments.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	59	 (B) Activity of the same constructs transfected in FGC4 and H5 cells treated or not with Dex.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Means  plus or minus  SD of three (FGC4) and two to three (H5) independent experiments.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	61	 (C) Activity in transfected FGC4 cells, treated or not with Dex, of a minimal HNF41 promoter ( to 34) controlled by the 700 bp enhancer, cloned in both orientations, or by HNF41 5'-sequences up to  to 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Means  plus or minus  SD of two independent experiments.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	63	  View larger version (26K):    Figure 2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	64	 (A) A 240 bp region of the 700 bp enhancer shows basal and Dex-induced enhancer activities and is transactivated by HNF41 and HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	65	 (Left) Restriction map of the enhancer with positions (in kb) relative to the transcription start and schemes of cloned sub-regions.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	66	 (Middle and right) Activities of the corresponding reporter plasmids either after transfection in FGC4, treated or not with Dex, or co-transfection of H5 with 1  microg of HNF41 or HNF1 expression vector.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Induction factor represents the ratio of CAT activity in the presence of the factor to that in the presence of the control expression vector.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	68	 For the 700 bp enhancer, the induction factor is the mean of four to five independent experiments.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Induction factors for the other fragments have been normalized to this mean value.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Blanks indicate that fragments were not tested for activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	71	 (B) The 700 bp enhancer is transactivated by HNF47 (left) and HNF1ss (right).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	72	 H5 cells were co-transfected by the B1E5B2 reporter plasmid and 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	73	3 or 1  microg of expression vector for HNF41, HNF47, HNF1ss or HNF1 as indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	74	 CAT activity is expressed as induction factor [see (A)].
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	75	  DNase I footprinting and electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) Nuclear protein extracts from FGC4 and H5 cells, treated or not with Dex (1  microM) for 2 days, and from rat liver were prepared as described previously (27) except that (NH4)2SO4 precipitation and dialysis were omitted.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Protein concentrations were measured with the Bio-Rad protein assay.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Purified recombinant truncated rat HNF1 (HNt) and rat HNF41 were kind gifts of C.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	78	Cheret (Institut Pasteur, Paris, France) and F.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	79	Ringeisen (Institut Pasteur), respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The DNase I footprinting assay was performed essentially as described previously (28), except that the binding reaction contained 85 mM NaCl and 10 mM KCl.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Proteins were incubated with labeled DNA probe (1 ng) in 12  microl for 1 h on ice before adding DNase I.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Products were analyzed on 6% polyacrylamide to 7 M urea gels.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	83	EMSA was carried out as described previously (27), with 50 mM NaCl added to the reaction mix.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Binding reactions were performed with 10  microg of nuclear protein extracted from FGC4 or H5 and 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	85	4 ng of labeled oligonucleotide.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides used contained HNF41 upstream sequences binding to HNF1 (oligo BS1, 5'-GCAAACTCATGCCCAGTTAATTTTTTAAAGCAAGACCAACAGGCTC) or protected in DNase I footprinting experiments as well as binding sites of HNF1 in the rat albumin promoter (PE56; 27), HNF3/HNF6 in the mouse transthyretin promoter, from  to 85 to  to 110 (TTR; 29 to 31), HNF3/Oct-1 and HNF6 in the 6-phosphofructo-2-kinase promoter (PFK-III and PFK-IV, respectively; 32), Oct-1 in the mouse light chain gene promoter (Oct-Ig; 32), HNF4 in the human apolipoprotein CIII promoter, from  to 67 to  to 92 (ApoCIII; 33), and in the rat (34) and mouse (35) HNF1 promoter (H1H4, 5'-GATCGGCTGAAGTCCAAAGTTCAGTCC), C/EBP in the rat albumin promoter, from  to 86 to  to 109 (DEI; 28), and of the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) in the rat tyrosine aminotransferase gene, from  to 2491 to  to 2510 (GRE; 36).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	87	 A double-stranded oligonucleotide (oligo BS1m) containing four point mutations in the HNF1 consensus site of oligoBS1 as described in the mutant PE DS 34 of PE 56 (27) was also used.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	88	 In competition experiments, 20 ng of non-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide was added to the reaction mix except as otherwise stated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	89	 A C/EBP-specific antibody (sc-61 X; Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and an antibody raised against the N-terminus of rat HNF41 (a kind gift of F.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	90	Sladek, University of California, Riverside, CA; 37) were used.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	91	Site-directed mutagenesis Site-directed mutagenesis of the B1E5B2 reporter was performed using the QuickChange kit (Stratagene).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	92	 All isolated clones were analyzed by DNA sequencing.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	93	 We introduced a clustered point mutation (38) (mutant F1m1, 5'-GGAGAGGCCAATGGCCTCGAAGCTTCCCCAGGAGGCCTCCTGCCC) or two point mutations (mutant F1m2, 5'-GGCCAATGGCCTCTAGAATAACCCAGGAGGCC) at the C/EBP consensus site in F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The HNF1 binding site BS1 was mutated using oligo BS1m.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Clustered point mutations according to the mutation of the HNF3 binding site in the TTR promoter (29) were introduced at a HNF3 consensus site in F3 (mutant F3mH3, 5'-GCTGCCTTTATCTCCCTGTGGTAAAGATCTGAATATACTCAGGCCCTGGAGCAGGGC).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Three point mutations were introduced at the center of a HNF4 consensus site (12) in F2 (mutant F2mH4, 5'-GCTGTTGACTCTTGAGCTCCGTCTTCCCTCCGGAGG).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	97	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   A 700 bp enhancer located 6 kb upstream of the HNF41 transcription start increases activity and confers Dex inducibility to heterologous and homologous promoters For transfection studies we used differentiated FGC4 rat hepatoma cells containing HNF4 transcripts synthesized only from the HNF41 promoter (M.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	98	Weiss, submitted for publication) and therefore appropriate to analyze HNF41 regulatory sequences.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Activity of two fragments covering sequences from  to 5 to  to 11 kb upstream of the HNF41 transcription start and cloned upstream of the tk promoter was examined in these cells and in dedifferentiated H5 and non-hepatic C33 cells (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Both fragments exhibited strong enhancer activity, but only in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The more active fragment was subdivided into three fragments and tested.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Essentially full activity, again limited to FGC4 cells, was conserved by the proximal fragment, B1E5.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Finally, B1E5 was divided into two fragments and full activity in FGC4 cells was retained by the more proximal fragment, B1E5B2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	104	 This fragment, covering one HS (13,14), therefore acts as a cell-specific enhancer and is referred to as the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	105	Since we had observed that transcription of the endogenous HNF4 gene of rat hepatoma cells is induced by Dex treatment (data not shown), each of the fragments was tested for Dex inducibility (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Dex induction was observed only in FGC4 (2 to 3-fold) and not in H5 cells and, with one exception, it was found only for the most active fragments.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The only fragment with low basal activity that showed inducibility was B1E4, which covers HS V (13).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	108	 This fragment has not yet been studied further.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	109	To test whether the 700 bp enhancer can act on the homologous promoter, we cloned it in front of the  to 34/+182 HNF41 sequence in plasmid  to 34pZLUC (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The 5' deletion to  to 34 retained non-tissue-specific promoter activity (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	111	 1C) the 700 bp enhancer, whatever its orientation, increased the activity of  to 34pZLUC 5-fold, while the relative activity of  to 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This last plasmid contains the 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Moreover, Dex treatment increased the activity of the 700/ to 34pZLUC constructs 2-fold, which accounts totally for the Dex induction of  to 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	114	A 240 bp region is sufficient for enhancer activity and Dex inducibility and is transactivated by HNF1 and HNF41 Deletions were performed in the 700 bp enhancer to delineate the sequences that are critical for basal and inducible expression (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Concerning the 5' and 3' deletions, in BspEI and B1E5A2 basal activity was strongly reduced compared to that of the 700 bp enhancer and hormone inducibility was abolished.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The sequences deleted between HpaI and DraI had a negative effect on both basal and induced activity because their loss led to increased activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Further deletion from DraI to AvaI caused a strong decline in both basal and hormone-induced activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	118	 An internal deletion, (BspEI to StuI), also strongly reduced both basal and induced activities compared to the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Therefore, three adjacent blocks of sequence lying between the PvuII and DraI sites are important for full basal and hormone-induced activity of the 700 bp enhancer, with the most 5' one (PvuII to BspEI) being the most critical for the Dex response.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Analysis of two central fragments, PvuII to DraI and BspEI to DraI, confirmed that an element required for hormone response is located between the PvuII and BspEI sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	121	 None of the fragments shown in Figure 2A exhibited strong enhancer activity in dedifferentiated H5 cells in the absence or presence of Dex (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	122	Because it is known that the HNF4 gene is subject to cross-regulation by HNF1 and to auto-regulation (24,39 to 42), several of the fragments were tested for transactivation by HNF1 and HNF41.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The 700 bp enhancer is transactivated by both factors in H5 (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	124	 2A) and C33 (data not shown) cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Analysis of deleted constructs in H5 cells (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	126	 2A) shows that the HNF4 response element is located between the PvuII and BspEI sites and the HNF1 element between the AvaI and DraI sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In addition, in H5 cells the 700 bp enhancer is transactivated similarly by HNF41 and HNF47 and less efficiently by HNF1ss than HNF1 (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	128	In conclusion, these results show that the 700 bp enhancer is transactivated by HNF41, HNF47, HNF1 and HNF1ss.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Furthermore, the 240 bp PvuII to DraI sequence contains HNF4 and HNF1 response elements and acts as a cell-specific enhancer whose activity is increased by glucocorticoids.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	130	Hepatoma cell nuclear proteins bind to the 240 bp enhancer DNase I footprint experiments were performed to search for binding sites of nuclear proteins in the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Figure 3A shows four footprints (F1 to F4), revealed with nuclear extract from FGC4 and H5 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Due to the location of F1 very close to the labeled end of the probe, its 3'-limit is not clearly visible.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	133	 However, using a probe labeled further downstream on the same strand we precisely located the 3'-end of F1 (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	134	 There is a surprising similarity between the footprints obtained with the two extracts.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	135	 3A and data not shown) the H5 extract is clearly less active than that of FGC4 and for F2 a greater protection by FGC4 extract is evident only at the 3'-extremity of the footprint.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	136	 As only F1 to F3 lie within the 240 bp enhancer region characterized above (see Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	137	 3C), we mapped these three footprints on the opposite strand using FGC4 extract (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The autoradiogram shows F2 and F3 at higher resolution.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In addition, Figure 3A and B shows F1 as a particularly strong footprint on both strands.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Positions and sequences of F1 to F3 are given in Figure 3C and D, along with sequences of the oligonucleotides used in the EMSA.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (31K):    Figure 3.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	142	 DNase I footprints generated by FGC4 and H5 nuclear extracts on the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	143	 (A) The BglII to AvaI fragment [see (C)], 32P-labeled on the upper strand at the 3'-end of the AvaI site was incubated in the absence (F) or presence of nuclear extract (20  microg protein) before adding DNase I at final concentrations of 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	144	7 (F) or 13 and 20 U/ml (FGC4 and H5).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	145	 G+A and T+C show chemical sequencing reaction products.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Footprints (bars) and hyperdigestion sites (arrows) generated by the FGC4 extract are indicated.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (B) The same experiment using a HindIII to BamHI fragment 32P-labeled at the 3'-end of the HindIII site (sites in the vector) and containing the PvuII to DraI fragment [see (C); lower strand labeled], and FGC4 nuclear extract.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (C) Positions of the DNase I footprints generated by FGC4 nuclear extracts in the enhancer.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (D) Sequences of the PvuII to AvaI fragment with DNase I footprints (bracketed lines) and hyperdigestion sites (arrows) on the upper and lower strand (above and below the sequence, respectively) indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Oligonucleotides used for further analysis are underlined.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	153	  In F1 a C/EBP binding site is essential for basal enhancer activity and overlaps with Dex-responsive sequences EMSA were performed with nuclear extracts from FGC4 and H5 cells treated or not with Dex and an oligonucleotide containing F1 (oligo F1) (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	154	 In FGC4 extracts a complex pattern of six bands was observed, two of which (designated 1 and 3) were restricted to these extracts.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The H5 extract showed strong bands corresponding to complexes 2 and 4 only after Dex treatment (even though Dex inducibility was restricted to FGC4 cells), while hormone treatment did not change the pattern in FGC4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Interestingly, three of the six bands observed in FGC4 were strongly represented in liver extract (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Moreover, complexes 1 and 3 appeared common between liver and FGC4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In competition experiments oligos F1 and DEI, containing the C/EBP site of the albumin promoter, displaced the bands in the three types of extracts (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In contrast, binding sites for the other LETF or GR did not compete (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Therefore, C/EBP family proteins bind to F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In agreement with this, a sequence homologous to the C/EBP binding site consensus (43) was found in the center of F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The two bands specific to FGC4 and liver extracts were shown to contain C/EBP by supershift assays: a specific antibody displaced only bands 1 and 3 in FGC4 and liver extracts and had no effect in the H5 extract (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Consequently, we conclude that C/EBP binds to F1 in FGC4 cells and the liver but not in H5 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	164	View larger version (70K):    Figure 4.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	165	 C/EBP binds to F1 in FGC4 cells and rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	166	 (A) Nuclear extracts from cells treated or not with Dex were incubated with labeled oligo F1 in EMSA as indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Numbers designate retarded protein to DNA complexes.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	168	 (B) The same experiment using nuclear extracts from rat liver and FGC4 cells.
