0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	170	 (C) EMSA of labeled oligo F1 and FGC4 nuclear proteins without (minus) or with competitor oligo F1 or oligonucleotides containing binding sites for HNF1 (PE56), HNF4 (ApoCIII and H1H4), C/EBP (DEI) and GR (GRE).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	171	 (D) EMSA with labeled oligo F1, FGC4 and H5 nuclear extracts and increasing amounts of anti-C/EBP antibody.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Antibody (1 to 3  microl, undiluted or 10-fold diluted) was preincubated with nuclear extracts as indicated for 10 min at room temperature, then reactions were completed and incubated for 30 min on ice.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Cells were treated with Dex to observe complexes 2 and 4 in H5 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Complexes 1 and 3 were supershifted by the antibody (arrowhead).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	175	  To determine whether C/EBP plays a role in enhancer activity, critical bases were mutated in the C/EBP consensus site (38) in the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The activity of the mutant reporter plasmid (F1m1) was then tested in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The mutant showed a low basal activity, reduced 6-fold compared to the wild-type (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In addition, Dex inducibility was entirely destroyed by the mutation (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The mutant sequence failed to bind proteins of FGC4 or H5 extracts, as shown by EMSA and DNase I footprint experiments (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, three of the seven mutated nucleotides in the F1m1 mutant belong to a glucocorticoid response element half-site (half-GRE) consensus overlapping with the C/EBP consensus (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Consequently, the mutation could impair binding of GR linked to the hormone.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	182	 We then performed two point mutations in the C/EBP consensus site that do not affect the half-GRE consensus but impair C/EBP binding as analyzed by competition experiments in EMSA (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This mutation diminished basal activity (mutant F1m2, Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	184	 5A, left) but caused only a weak inhibition of the Dex effect (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	185	 We conclude that the C/EBP binding site is required for full basal enhancer activity and overlaps with a half-GRE consensus site involved in hormone inducibility.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	186	 These data indicate that C/EBP is involved in enhancer activity in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	187	View larger version (18K):    Figure 5.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The C/EBP site is required for full enhancer activity and functional GRE consensus sites overlap with the C/EBP, HNF4 and HNF3 sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (A) (Left) FGC4 cells were transfected with B1E5B2 reporter plasmids, either wild-type or bearing two different mutations in the C/EBP binding site of F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	190	 An overlapping half-GRE consensus site is affected by mutation in the F1m1 but not in the F1m2 mutant.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Activity is expressed relative to B1E5B2.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The means  plus or minus  SD of three (F1m1) or two (F1m2) independent experiments are shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	193	 (Right) Same experiment except that the transfected cells were treated with Dex.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Induction factor represents the ratio of CAT activity in the presence and absence of Dex.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The means  plus or minus  SD of three (B1E5B2, F1m1) or two (F1m2) independent experiments are shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	196	 (B) The same experiment except that the B1E5B2 reporter plasmid was mutated in the HNF4 consensus site of F2 (F2mH4).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	197	 (C) The same experiment except that the B1E5B2 reporter plasmid was mutated in the HNF3 consensus site of F3 (F3mH3).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In both the F2mH4 and F3mH3 mutants GRE consensus sites are affected.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	199	 For the F3mH3 mutant, the mean  plus or minus  SD of two independent experiments is shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	200	  F2 and F3 contain HNF4 and HNF3 binding sites, respectively, both overlapping with Dex-responsive sequences An oligonucleotide spanning the more protected part of F2 (oligo F2) was used in EMSA with FGC4 extract.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Competition experiments suggested that F2 binds HNF4 weakly (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	202	 To confirm that HNF4 binds to F2, we used purified recombinant rat HNF41 and labeled oligo F2 in EMSA.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Figure 6A shows a complex which was displaced by unlabeled ApoCIII and oligo F2 but not by unlabeled HNF1 site PE56.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Moreover, antibody against rat HNF41 supershifted nearly all the complex (compare lanes anti-HNF4 + and  to ).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This figure also shows that oligo F2 binds HNF41 with an efficiency  > 60-fold lower than ApoCIII.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	206	View larger version (47K):    Figure 6.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Recombinant HNF41 binds to F2 (A) and HNF3 to F3 (B).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	208	 (A) Labeled oligo F2 and recombinant rat HNF41 (0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	209	7  microg) were incubated without (minus) or with (plus) an anti-HNF41 antibody and without (minus) or with competitor oligonucleotides.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The first lane shows migration without protein.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	211	 For the reaction with the antibody and the control, 1  microl of 10-fold diluted antibody in PBS (plus) or PBS alone (minus) was added to reaction mix that had been preincubated for 15 min on ice.

0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	217	 (B) Labeled oligo F3 was incubated without (minus) or with FGC4 nuclear extract and competitor oligonucleotides.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	218	 TTR and PFK-III contain binding sites for HNF3 and HNF6 and for HNF3 and Oct-1, respectively, whereas PFK-IV and Oct-Ig bind HNF6 and Oct-1, respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	219	  EMSA was carried out with FGC4 extract and an oligonucleotide containing F3 (oligo F3).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	220	 One complex formed, which was competed by oligo F3 and by oligos TTR and PFK-III, containing HNF3/HNF6 (30,31) and HNF3/Oct-1 (32) binding sites, respectively (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	221	 6B, left), but not by oligos PFK-IV and Oct-Ig (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	222	 6B, right), binding to HNF6 and Oct-1, respectively (32).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	223	 This shows that HNF3 binds to F3.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In support of a functional role of HNF3 binding, HNF3 transactivates the 700 bp enhancer in co-transfection experiments in C33 cells (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	225	HNF4 and HNF3 consensus sites were found in oligos F2 and F3, respectively.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	226	 To examine the functional roles of these sites, we introduced point mutations in each of them in the 700 bp enhancer and tested the resulting plasmids for basal and Dex-induced activity in FGC4 cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	227	 5B) caused a slight reduction in basal activity (left) and a significant reduction in inducibility (right).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	228	 A slight reduction in inducibility was obtained for the HNF3 mutation in F3 while the basal activity was not affected (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	229	 However, these mutations reduced but did not abolish HNF41 and HNF3 binding as analyzed by competition experiments in EMSA (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Furthermore, the HNF4 consensus site is included in a GRE consensus site which is affected by the HNF4 mutation while the HNF3 mutation touches a half-GRE consensus site.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	231	 These data show that GRE consensus sites intermingled with the LETF sites are required for maximal Dex inducibility of the 700 bp enhancer, as is the case for the C/EBP site in F1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	232	A functional HNF1 binding site is essential for basal enhancer activity The 700 and 240 bp enhancers are similarly transactivated by HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	233	 A computer search for putative HNF1 binding sites in the 700 bp sequence using a weighted matrix (44) revealed three sites with high scores.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The most upstream contains the DraI site and the three last bases of the consensus (15 bp) were replaced by vector sequence in cloned fragments cut by DraI.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The second HNF1 site is located a few base pairs downstream of the DraI site and the third lies 70 bp further downstream (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In DNase I footprinting experiments using purified recombinant truncated HNF1 protein (HNt) we demonstrated that the two most upstream consensus sites correspond to authentic HNF1 binding sites (BS1 and BS2, respectively; data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Then we tested the recombinant HNF1 protein by EMSA using double-stranded oligonucleotides containing BS1, wild-type (oligo BS1) or mutated (oligo BS1m) in order to abolish HNF1 binding (27).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	238	 A complex between HNt and labeled oligo BS1 formed which was competed by PE56 and oligo BS1, but not by oligo BS1m (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	239	 From these experiments we conclude that BS1 binds HNF1, but with an efficiency  > 16-fold lower than the high affinity PE56 oligonucleotide.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	240	 In the constructs 3' deleted at the DraI site, modified BS1 still binds to HNt but with a lower affinity (data not shown).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	241	 In EMSA using FGC4 extracts the third consensus (BS3) proved also to bind HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	242	View larger version (33K):    Figure 7.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Recombinant HNF1 binds to a site at the 3'-end of the 240 bp enhancer (A) and this site is required for HNF1 transactivation (B) and full enhancer activity (C).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	244	 (A) Purified recombinant truncated rat HNF1 was used at 0.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	245	5  microg in EMSA with the labeled oligo BS1 in the absence or presence of increasing amounts (indicated in ng) of competitor oligo PE56, BS1 or BS1m (mutated in BS1).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	246	 (B) CAT activity of reporter plasmid B1E5B2, wild-type or mutated in BS1 (BS1m*, see text), in H5 co-transfected with HNF1.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	247	 For the mutant reporter, the mean  plus or minus  SD of three independent experiments is shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Expression vector amounts are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	249	 (C) CAT activity in FGC4 of reporter plasmid B1E5B2, wild-type or mutated in BS1 (BS1m* or BS1m).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The mean  plus or minus  SD of two independent experiments is shown.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	251	  To investigate whether BS1 could mediate transactivation by HNF1 we used oligo BS1m to mutate BS1 in the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	252	 We obtained two mutant reporter plasmids of which one (BS1m*) contains an insertion of two G residues within BS1 in addition to the expected mutation.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	253	 As shown in Figure 7B, in H5 cells this mutant plasmid exhibited the same low basal activity as the B1E5B2 reporter plasmid but transactivation by co-transfected HNF1 was severely compromised, in spite of the continued presence of intact BS2 and BS3 sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Moreover, activity of both mutant plasmids in FGC4 was strongly and similarly reduced compared to the wild-type (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	255	 These results thus show that BS1 is required not only for transactivation by HNF1, but also for enhancer activity of the 700 bp region in differentiated hepatoma cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	256	In summary, we have characterized several LETF binding sites (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	257	 8A) within the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	258	 C/EBP, HNF4 and HNF3 binding sites are located in the 240 bp minimal enhancer, PvuII to DraI, whereas an HNF1 binding site overlaps its 3'-end and two other HNF1 binding sites lie further downstream.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The C/EBP site and the first (BS1) HNF1 site are required for full basal activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Several imperfect whole and half-GRE consensus sites were found in the minimal enhancer (Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Three of them, overlapping with LETF sites, are crucial for maximal hormone inducibility of the 700 bp enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	262	View larger version (14K):    Figure 8.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Overview of the  to 6 kb enhancer (A) and a model for HNF41 regulation (B).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	264	 (A) A restriction map is shown (P, PvuII; B, BspEI; A, AvaI; D, DraI; H, HpaI).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Positions of three imperfect whole and five imperfect half-GRE consensus sites in the minimal enhancer are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Protein binding sites characterized using DNase I footprinting assay and EMSA with FGC4 nuclear extract or purified recombinant proteins are represented.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Footprints F1 to F3, HNF1 binding sites and LETF binding to the sites are indicated.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	268	 (B) Schematic representation showing a model of the factors that are expressed and could bind to the HNF41  to 6 kb enhancer and promoter (14) regions, resulting in low expression during early liver development and a strong up-regulation at birth.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	269	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   In this work we have defined an enhancer element upstream of the HNF41 promoter that is active in well-differentiated FGC4 rat hepatoma cells and not in dedifferentiated variant hepatoma and non-hepatic cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Fragments covering  to 5 to  to 11 kb upstream of the transcription start site have been tested upstream of the tk promoter and full activity can be localized to a fragment of 700 bp (700 bp enhancer) at around  to 6 kb, which corresponds to a HS of both liver and kidney chromatin (13,14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	271	 This fragment increases the activity of a minimal HNF41 promoter from which the HNF1 site (14) has been deleted.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	272	 This result agrees with the requirement of upstream sequences up to  to 7 kb to obtain liver- and kidney-restricted activity of the HNF41 promoter in transgenic mice (14).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Moreover, the 700 bp enhancer mediates glucocorticoid induction, but only in differentiated hepatoma cells.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	274	 This agrees with the reported glucocorticoid induction of HNF4 expression (11,15).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	275	 The 700 bp enhancer is thus implicated in physiological regulation of HNF41 activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	276	The 700 bp enhancer contains a 240 bp core sequence sufficient for both enhancer activity and Dex induction and within which three footprints (F1 to F3) have been identified.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	277	 C/EBP binds to F1, HNF4 to F2 and HNF3 to F3.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Finally, a functional HNF1 binding site is at the 3'-end of the core sequence.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Figure 8A summarizes these data.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	280	 The sequence comprising the minimal enhancer is conserved.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Blast analysis of the mouse and human (NCBI database accession no.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	282	 AL117382) sequences showed an overall 86% identity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The F1 to F3 and HNF1 sites exhibit the highest scores (90 to 100%).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	284	 This fact implies that the HNF41 enhancer is an important element that plays a similar role in humans.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	285	The C/EBP site is the strongest footprint in the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Its mutation significantly reduces enhancer activity but only in cells that produce C/EBP, implying that this site responds specifically to binding of C/EBP.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Previously we proposed that HNF4 regulates its own expression based on studies of stable transfectants (24,42).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Our data here support such a direct auto-regulation mechanism because the enhancer core sequence contains a functional HNF4 response element.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In addition, HNF3 transactivates the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	290	 However, while mutation of the HNF4 and HNF3 sites had only small effects, the introduced mutations impaired binding of the factors only partially.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The HNF41 enhancer is strongly transactivated by HNF1 and more weakly by HNF1ss.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Transactivation by HNF1 is mediated by a weak HNF1 binding site, which is also required for high basal activity of the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	293	 A similar functional role of weak HNF1 binding sites has been reported for the mouse phenylalanine hydroxylase gene enhancer (21).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	294	 A functional HNF1 binding site in the HNF41 enhancer, in addition to the site described earlier in the promoter region (14), accords with earlier reports of cross-regulation between HNF4 and HNF1 (39 to 42).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Based on the strong response to HNF1, we propose that this factor plays a critical role in enhancer activity.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	296	In agreement with our observations, glucocorticoids have been shown to activate HNF4 expression in primary cultured rat hepatocytes (11).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Moreover, HNF41, but not HNF47, is induced by glucocorticoids in murine hepatic cells (15).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Maximal Dex induction of the enhancer requires the F1 to F3 region where three imperfect GRE and five imperfect half-GRE consensus sites were found, some overlapping with the F1 to F3 footprints (see Fig.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Although competition EMSAs using GRE failed to provide evidence for binding of GR, the presence of GRE consensus sites and responsiveness to Dex imply that GR binds to the enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Indeed, mutations introduced into LETF binding sites that affect GRE whole sites or half-sites compromised Dex induction, implying that these sites are functional.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Moreover, induction of the 700 bp enhancer was restricted to differentiated hepatoma cells, implying that a liver-specific protein(s) is required for the glucocorticoid effect.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Indeed, the LETF can synergize with GR to achieve glucocorticoid induction of the tyrosine aminotransferase (TAT) (45 to 47) and the phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) genes (48).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	303	 A similar situation appears to exist for the HNF41 enhancer.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	304	At first sight, it is surprising to observe that the major transactivators for the HNF41 enhancer are hormone-activated GR and LETF that are expressed late in development, such as C/EBP and HNF1, even though it is known that HNF4 transcripts are first detected very early (2).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	305	 However, probes that do not distinguish between the HNF41 and HNF47 isoforms were used for analysis of early embryos.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Recent work from our laboratory has revealed that expression of the HNF41 isoform is strong in the liver only at the end of fetal life and at birth, whereas the HNF47 isoform is the predominant form of HNF4 in embryonic liver (M.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	307	Weiss, submitted for publication).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	308	 The dramatic activation of HNF41 that occurs just before birth could be assured, on the one hand, by C/EBP, whose expression is also activated at birth (49), and, on the other, by glucocorticoids.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Indeed, the TAT and PEPCK genes, which like HNF41 have enhancers in which glucocorticoid hormone response modules overlap LETF sites (46 to 48), are strongly induced by glucocorticoids at birth.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	310	HNF41 is thus expressed at low levels in embryonic liver.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Binding sites in the HNF41 enhancer do include transcription factors that are present in the developing liver.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	312	 HNF3 and ss are among the first LETF to be expressed in this tissue (50).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	313	 HNF1ss, known to be expressed before HNF1 in the embryonic liver (4,5), is a transactivator of the enhancer, as is HNF47.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	314	Although many studies have contributed to the notion that the group of LETF is subject to cross-regulation and to auto-regulation (4,5,8,9,14,24,30,31,34,35,39 to 42,51 to 63), this is the first detailed study of an enhancer regulating expression of one of these factors.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Furthermore, this analysis concerns one of the first of these factors to be expressed, HNF4 (2).
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	316	 The results of this study are entirely consistent with the observed behavior of the HNF4 gene in vivo and provide a basis to explain its expression pattern.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Indeed, binding sites for essentially all of the LETF so far identified are present, including factors expressed early during development, such as HNF3 and ss, HNF1ss and HNF47, and others that are expressed a little later, such as HNF1, and in particular those that are up-regulated at birth, including C/EBP, HNF41 and, perhaps most importantly, activated GR.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Consequently, the properties of the  to 6 kb enhancer are consistent with it being involved both in the initiation of expression of HNF41 and in its maintenance.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Figure 8B presents our model of biphasic regulation of the HNF41 enhancer during liver development.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	320	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   We particularly thank Weimin Zhong and James E.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Darnell for furnishing us with the clones and plasmids for starting this work, Gerhart Ryffel for sharing unpublished data, Claire Cheret, Robert H.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Costa, Francois Ringeisen and Frances M.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Sladek for reagents and Marco Pontoglio for help in the computer search of HNF1 consensus sites.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	324	 This work was supported by grants from the Association pour la Recherche sur le Cancer and the Human Frontiers Science Program RG0303/2000-M.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	325	 was supported by a fellowship from CONACYT.
0.22947337.11522818.html.plaintext.txt	326	   FOOTNOTES   * To whom correspondence should be addressed.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	0	Orphan Receptors Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor II (COUP-TFII) and Retinoid X Receptor (RXR) Activate and Bind the Rat Cholesterol 7-Hydroxylase Gene (CYP7A)*.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, November 5, 1996, and in revised form, February 4, 1997).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	2	Diane Stroup , Maurizio Crestani and John Y.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Pathology, Northeastern Ohio Universities College of Medicine, Rootstown, Ohio 44272-0095 ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION FOOTNOTES ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS REFERENCES.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	4	The cholesterol 7-hydroxylase gene (CYP7A) is transcriptionally regulated by a number of factors, including hormones, bile acids, and diurnal rhythm.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Previous studies have identified a region from nucleotides (nt) 74 to 55 of the rat CYP7A promoter that enhanced bile acid repression of the SV40 early promoter, as assayed with a luciferase reporter gene in transiently transfected HepG2 cells.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The rat CYP7A promoter/reporter activity was strongly stimulated by cotransfection with an expression plasmid encoding the nuclear hormone receptor chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor II (COUP-TFII) in a dose-dependent manner.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Site-directed mutagenesis in the region of nt 74 to 55 altered this stimulation.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Recombinant COUP-TFII expressed in HepG2 or COS-1 cells were found to bind to nt 74 55 and nt 149 128 probes by electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) and by supershifting the corresponding band with COUP-TFII-specific antibodies.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The region of nt 176 117 was previously mapped as a retinoic acid response region and was found to bind retinoid X receptor (RXR).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	10	 EMSA supershift assays of wild-type and mutant oligomers using antibody against RXR revealed that the sequences between nt 145 and 134 were important for RXR binding.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	11	 We conclude that COUP-TFII stimulates the transcriptional activity of the rat CYP7A promoter by binding to the sequences between nt 74 to 54 and nt 149 to 128.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	12	 RXR may stimulate CYP7A gene transcription by binding to a direct repeat of the hormone response element separated by one nucleotide located at nt 146 134.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	13	Cholesterol 7-hydroxylase (EC 1.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	14	17) catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step in a pathway that converts cholesterol to bile acids.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The catabolism of cholesterol to bile acids in the liver is the main mechanism for elimination of cholesterol from the body and thus plays an important role in maintaining cholesterol homeostasis (1).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The gene CYP7A is transcriptionally regulated by a number of factors, including bile acids, cholesterol, hormones, and circadian rhythm (2-6).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	17	The CYP7A promoter structure is typical of a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase II promoter in that, upstream of the TATA box, there are several cis-acting elements that regulate the transcriptional activity of this promoter (7-9).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Transient transfection assay of chimeric CYP7A promoter/luciferase constructs in HepG2 cells revealed that the region from nt 416 to +32 of the rat CYP7A gene contained the promoter and regulatory domains conferring the activation of transcription by dexamethasone and retinoic acid and suppression by bile acids, phorbol esters, and insulin (2, 3, 9, 10).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	19	 We have mapped two footprints that are protected from DNase I digestion using rat liver nuclear extracts (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Footprint (Fp)1 A is located between nt 81 and 35, and FpB is located between nt 148 and 129.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Nucleotide sequences in these two regions are highly conserved among homologous CYP7A genes of different species.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These footprints contain liver-enriched transcription factors binding sites and hormone response elements.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	23	 A putative bile acid response element (BARE) was mapped to the FpA region, which lead us to propose that a bile acid responsive nuclear receptor may be mediating bile acid response (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	24	The molecular mechanism of bile acid repression is still unknown.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Determining what factors interact with these BARE sequences is a first step in elucidating the nature of the bile acid response.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A nuclear protein factor, which was found to bind a repeated sequence -65TCAAGTTCAAG-54 was named direct repeat binding protein (DRBP).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Binding of DRBP to BARE was diminished when liver nuclear extract prepared from rats fed deoxycholate was used in EMSA (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The sequence from nt 73 to 57 contains an imperfect direct repeat of the hormone response element (HRE, AGGTCA) separated by four nucleotides (DR4).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	29	 According to the 3-4-5 rule for the binding specificity of the steroid/thyroid hormone family of transcription factors (12), a DR4 would be predicted to act as a thyroid hormone response element, hence "7TRE" as the tentative name for this DR4 sequence (11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	30	 However, CYP7A promoter constructs containing these sequences did not respond to thyroid hormones in HepG2 cells (2).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	31	 A number of nuclear factors have affinity for DR4 sequences, including TR, XONR, and LXR that form heterodimers with RXR (13, 14).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	32	 COUP-TFII (or ARP-1) of orphan nuclear receptor family with promiscuous binding specificities also bind a DR4 sequence (15, 16).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	33	 COUP-TFs are believed to influence developmental changes, which is supported by the report that the COUP-TFII promoter responds to differentiation signal, retinoic acid (17).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Recently, we have mapped a complex retinoic acid response region located between 176 and 117 of the rat CYP7A promoter (10).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	35	Using transient transfection assay of CYP7A promoter/reporter activity in HepG2 cells, we have screened a number of known steroid/thyroid hormone nuclear receptors for their effects on gene transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	36	 COUP-TFII produced one of the strongest effects on transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Here, we provide evidence that orphan receptor COUP-TFII activates transcription of rat CYP7A by binding to nt 74 to 54 and to nt 149 to 128 and that an RXR homodimer may bind to a DR1 motif between 146 to 134.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	38	DNA oligomers were synthesized by National Biosciences (Plymouth, MN) or Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	39	 DNA restriction and modifying enzymes, reporter lysis buffer, luciferase assay system, and the reporter vectors pGL2-Basic and pGL2-Promoter were purchased from Promega (Madison, WI).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The radioactive isotopes [-32P]dCTP (3000 Ci/mol) and [-35S]dATP (1200 Ci/mmol) Sequenase sequencing grade were obtained from ICN (Costa Mesa, CA) and DuPont NEN, respectively.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The DNA purification systems used were the GeneClean kit, from BIO 101, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	42	 (La Jolla, CA), and the Qiagen plasmid kit, acquired from Qiagen Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Expression plasmids for the transcription factors were the generous gifts of Dr.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Chen for pLen4S (HNF4) and pL-H3 (HNF3), Dr.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Johnson for pMEXC/EBP (C/EBP) and pMEXCRP2.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Antiserum against COUP-TFII was a kind gift of Dr.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Affinity-purified rabbit polyclonal antibodies against RAR (sc-773; cross-reacts with RAR 1, 2, 1, 2, 1, and 2 isoforms), RXR (sc-774; cross-reacts with RXR , , and  isoforms), C/EBP (sc-61), and c-erbA1 (sc-76) were obtained from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Other reagents were from Sigma.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	49	The human hepatoma cell line (HepG2, ATCC HB8065) and African green monkey kidney cells (COS-1, ATCC CRL1650) were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, MD.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The cells were grown in a 1:1 mixture of Dulbecco's modified Eagles medium and F12, (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	51	) supplemented with 100 units/ml penicillin G-streptomycin sulfate (Celox Corp.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	52	, Hopkins, MN) and 10% (v/v) heat-inactivated fetal calf serum (JRH Biosciences, Lenexa, KS).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	53	The sequences of the CYP7A promoter from nt 200 to +32 were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using p-416/+32 (3) as the template.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Primers were designed to introduce a 5 KpnI and a 3 XhoI site for cloning into the luciferase reporter vector, pGL2-Basic (Promega) resulting in the plasmid p-200/+32.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The mutations in the sequences from nt 74 to 54 (see Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	56	 1A) were introduced by linking two fragments synthesized by PCR with mutagenic primers containing restriction sites at the 5- or 3-end and using p-416/+32 as a template.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The region from nt 74 to 54 was replaced with a SpeI site () by linking the nt 416/74 (SpeI) and nt 53(SpeI)/+32 fragments to generate p-41674/54 SpeI.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	58	 To delete the SpeI site, p-41674/54 SpeI was digested with SpeI, treated with Mung bean nuclease, and then religated to generate deletion mutant p-41674/54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	59	 p20074/54 was obtained by PCR using p-41674/54 as a template.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	60	 p-416LSM74/71 (linker-scanning mutation) was constructed by ligating a nt 70 to +32 (SpeI/XhoI) fragment to 416 74/54Spe digested with SpeI and XhoI.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	61	 p-41674/65 was isolated as a spontaneously arising deletion mutant.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	62	 p-416LSM-59/54, p-416LSM70/66, and p-416IM64/63 (insertion mutation) were constructed similarly to p-416LSM74/71.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	63	 All promoter/reporter constructs were cloned into pGL2-Basic vector.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	64	 All constructs were confirmed by sequencing with Sequenase 2.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Effect of overexpressing recombinant COUP-TFII on transcriptional activity of the nt 416 to +32 fragment of the rat CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	66	 A, schematic representation of mutations introduced into the region of nt 74 to nt 54 of the rat CYP7A promoter, as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	67	" Wild-type sequence from nt 81 to 48 is diagrammed on top.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	68	 All the clones have the promoter sequences from nt 416 to +32 ligated into pGL2-Basic.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Restriction sites are underlined, dashes in sequence represent deleted base pairs, and non-homologous sequences are indicated in lowercase letters.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The DR4 is overlined, and the direct repeat described in (11) is boxed.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	71	 B, increasing mass of the expression plasmid pTF3A encoding COUP-TFII was cotransfected with CYP7/luciferase reporter plasmids diagrammed in panel A.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The total mass of plasmid was kept constant by the addition of vector without promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Confluent monolayers of HepG2 cells were transfected with 5  microg of the indicated reporter plasmids, various amounts of pTF3A, and 0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	74	5  microg of pCMV- as described under "Experimental Procedures" and then overlaid with DMEM/F12 medium without serum after glycerol shock.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The cells were harvested 40 h after glycerol shock, and the luciferase activity was assayed and corrected for transfection efficiency with the -galactosidase activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The activation by COUP-TFII of the transcriptional activities were expressed as percentage of corrected luciferase activity without coexpressed COUP-TFII.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The percentage activation differed from wild type p  <  0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	78	01 (p-200/+32 versus p-200-74/54; p-416/+32 versus remainder of the mutants), as determined by Student's t test; error bars omitted for clarity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Data are representative of two individual experiments.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	80	 C, basal transcriptional activities of CYP7A promoter/luciferase reporter plasmids with mutations in the region from nt 74 to 54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Error bars indicate standard deviation of the triplicate samples for each construct.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	82	 *, indicates statistical significance for difference from wild type p  <  0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	83	 To control for variation in measured activities due to differences in individual plasmid preparations, relative activities of p-416/+32, p-41674/54Spe, p-41674/65, p-41659/54, p-41674/54 CYP7A promoter/luciferase gene constructs were further assayed with three separate plasmid preparations transfected in triplicate in two different experiments as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	84	" The results obtained were essentially the same as those shown in panel C.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	85	 [View Larger Version of this Image (28K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	86	Confluent cultures of HepG2 cells grown in 12-well tissue culture plates were transfected with DNA by calcium phosphate method as described previously (3, 11).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Luciferase activities were determined with the luciferase assay kit (Promega) according to manufacturer instructions using a Lumat LB9501 luminometer (Berthold Systems, Inc.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Luciferase activities were normalized for transfection efficiencies by dividing relative light units by -galactosidase activity expressed from cotransfected pCMV plasmid (Clontech).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	89	 -Galactosidase activities were determined using O-nitrophenyl--D-galactopyranoside as a substrate (18).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The average of the corrected luciferase activity from cell extracts is given, and error bars indicate the standard deviation of activity from triplicate samples.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	91	 All transfections were repeated at least two times.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Statistical significances were analyzed by Student's t test using Sigma Plot software (Jandel Scientific, San Rafael, CA).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	93	Preparation of Nuclear Extracts.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	94	Nuclei from HepG2 and COS-1 cells were isolated essentially as described (19, 20).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Recombinant COUP-TFII was prepared by transfecting confluent HepG2 or sub-confluent COS-1 cells in 100-mm tissue culture plates with 20  microg of pTF3A and 1  microg of pCMV.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The monolayers were overlaid with DMEM/F12 containing 5 mM butyric acid and 10% fetal calf serum after glycerol shock, and nuclei were harvested 40 h later.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Transfection efficiency was monitored by -galactosidase activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	98	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	99	Double-stranded synthetic probes for EMSA were prepared by heating equal molar amounts of complementary synthetic oligomers to 95  degrees C in 2  x  SSC (0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	100	0) and allowing them to cool to room temperature.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The resulting double-stranded fragments were designed with single-stranded 5 overhangs for end-labeling by incorporating [-32P]dCTP (3000 Ci/mol) with the Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Oligonucleotides blunted with non-labeled dNTPs were used as cold competitors in EMSA.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Labeled fragments were isolated from a 15% polyacrylamide gel or purified through two G-50 spin columns.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Binding reactions were initiated with the addition of 2  microg of nuclear extracts to 100,000 cpm of oligomer probe dissolved in 20  microl of buffer containing 12 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	105	9, 50 mM KCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM dithiothreitol, and 15% glycerol, and 2  microg of poly(dI-dC) poly(dI-dC).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	106	 After incubation for the time indicated in the legends to Figs.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	107	 2, 3, 4, 5, samples were run on 4% polyacrylamide gels, dried, and autoradiographed.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	108	 EMSAs were quantitated with IP Lab Gel software (Signal Analytics, Corp.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	109	, Vienna, VA) in conjunction with a PhosphorImager 445Si (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Effect of overexpressing recombinant COUP-TFII on the EMSA pattern of probes based on the sequence from nt 74 to 54.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Experiment was performed as in panel B.

0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Arrow labeled COUP-TFII/antibody indicates the band shift identified as the antibody COUP-TFII DNA complex; arrow labeled COUP-TFII corresponds to the band indicated by the arrow in panels B and C; and the arrow labeled DRBP points out the bands previously shown to bind nt 65 to 54 (panel C).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	126	 [View Larger Version of this Image (61K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	127	 EMSA in the presence of RAR-, RXR-, and COUP-TF-specific antibodies using the nt 149 to 128 probe.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	128	 EMSA was performed using nt 149 to 128 as a probe, generated by digesting the double-stranded synthetic oligomer nt 149 to 118 with MspI (diagrammed, top; imperfect HRE half-sites underlined), end-labeling as described under "Experimental Procedures," and gel isolating the nt 149 to 128 fragment.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The probe was incubated with 5  microg of nuclear extracts from untreated HepG2 cells (HepG2) or cells treated with 10  microM all-trans retinoic acid (HepG2 + retinoic acid) for 24 h before harvesting.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	130	 [View Larger Version of this Image (78K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	131	 EMSA supershift in the presence of RXR-specific antibodies using probes based on the sequence from nt 149 to 128.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Shown is the wild-type (WT) oligomer probe sequence on top with trinucleotide transversion mutations indicated below.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Numbers over lanes correspond to the nucleotides mutated according to the following rule: A to C, C to A, G to T, and T to G.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	134	 For example, 145/143 corresponds to the nt 149 to 128 probe with nt 145 G changed to T, nt 144 G changed to T, and nt 143 A changed to C.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Mutation from wild-type is indicated with lowercase letters.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Supershifted probes are indicated with arrow.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	137	 [View Larger Version of this Image (113K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	138	Activation of CYP7A Promoter Activity by Recombinant COUP-TFII and Identification of a Negative Element.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	139	Cotransfection of the rat CYP7A promoter fragment from nt 416 to +32 fused to the luciferase gene (p416/+32) (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	140	 1A) with a plasmid encoding recombinant COUP-TFII (pTF3A) was found to strongly stimulate reporter activity (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The dose-response curve resulting from cotransfecting with increasing amounts of pTF3A with p-200/+32 was indistinguishable from the stimulation curve of p-416/+32 (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	142	 1B) despite lower overall luciferase reporter activity (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	143	 1C), indicating the COUP-TF activation elements were downstream of position nt 200.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	144	 1A) reduced the stimulatory effect of COUP-TFII (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	145	To define the sequences important for COUP-TFII activation, a number of deletion () and linker scanning mutations (LSM) were introduced into the nt 74 to 54 region.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The dose-dependent stimulation of the promoter activity of the reporter plasmids by COUP-TFII fell into roughly three groups.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In the first group, the wild-type promoter fragments (p-416/+32 and p-200/+32) showed the greatest stimulation of transcriptional activity, and the effect was positive at all points of the curve (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The second group, which includes p-416LSM74/71, p-416LSM70/66, p-41674/65, p-416LSM59/54, p-41674/54, and p20074/54 displayed considerably flatter dose-response curves (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The mutations in this group destroyed one or both of the putative HRE half-sites, AGGTCA, either by completely deleting the sequence (p-41674/65, p-41674/54, and p20074/54) or by replacing the sequence with an SpeI restriction site while preserving the relative spacing of sequences on either side of the mutation (p-416LSM74/71, p-416LSM70/66, and p-416LSM59/54) (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Reporter plasmids with both HRE half-sites deleted (p-41674/54 and p20074/54) retained significant stimulation by COUP-TFII (approximately 3-4 fold), suggesting there may be additional COUP-TFII sites elsewhere in the promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Consistent with the hypothesis that the putative COUP-TFII activation elements were downstream of position nt 200, p-20074/54 was stimulated to approximately the same extent as p-41674/54, which has the same deletion but was 216 base pairs longer (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	152	The third category was represented by an insertion mutant (IM), p-416IM64/63 that displayed an activation intermediate between the first and second groups.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	153	 This plasmid, in which the HRE half-sites were intact but the spacing was increased from 4 to 5 base pairs (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	154	 1A), was strongly activated but to a somewhat lesser extent than the wild type, reaching a maximum of 1740  plus or minus  99% verses 2960  plus or minus  209%, respectively, at a transcription factor plasmid mass to reporter plasmid mass ratio of 0.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	155	The various mutations affected the basal activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Mutant reporter plasmids p-41674/54, p-416LSM74/71, p-416LSM59/54, p-41674/65, and p20074/54 had increased basal promoter activity relative to their parental plasmids (p-416/+32 and p-200/+32), as would be observed if a repressor binding site was mutated.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	157	 With one exception, the basal promoter activity also fell into three groups, corresponding with the COUP-TFII responsiveness of the reporter plasmid (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The promoter/reporter constructs with the lowest response to COUP-TFII had the highest basal activities (p-41674/54 and p-416LSM74/71).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	159	 p-416IM64/63 basal transcriptional activity was not significantly higher than the wild type.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The exception was p-416LSM70/66, which was activated by COUP-TFII to the same extent as p-416LSM59/54 and p-41674/65 but did not display the same transcriptional activation over p-416/+32.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The activation of p-41674/54 over p-416/+32 was not observed in the kidney cell line, COS-1.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	162	Interaction of COUP-TFII with the CYP7A Promoter at nt 74 to 54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	163	To determine if COUP-TF activates transcriptional activity by directly binding to the sequence between nt 74 and 54, the ability of COUP-TF to interact with the CYP7A sequences in vitro, was measured with the EMSA.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Also, other promoter fragments from nt 200 to 74 were screened to determine if there were additional COUP-TFII binding sites.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	165	Nuclear extracts were prepared from HepG2 cells transfected with pTF3A, an expression plasmid specifically encoding COUP-TFII.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The gel shift patterns of the nt 72 to 59 and nt 65 to 54 oligomers are similar in HepG2 cells, regardless of COUP-TFII overexpression (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Two extra bands were shifted with nt 74 to 53 probe that were enhanced by COUP-TFII overexpression (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The nt 74 to 53 included the putative DR4, which is overlined in Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	169	 2A; the nt 72 to 59 or nt 65 to 54 oligomers do not.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The diffuse nature of these bands was attributed to the low abundance of the nuclear factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	171	Recombinant COUP-TFII expressed in the kidney cell line COS-1, bound the nt 74 to 53 (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	172	 2C), indicating the binding of COUP-TF was not dependent on liver-specific factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The increased band shift with COS-1 extracts was attributed to the higher activity of the MT2 promoter of pTF3A, which drives transcription of the recombinant gene encoding COUP-TFII, in COS-1 cells relative to HepG2 cells.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	174	 This presumably results in higher levels of expression of recombinant COUP-TFII in this cell line.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Overexpression of COUP-TFII was associated with a reduction in DRBP binding, even in probes unable to be shifted by COUP-TFII (nt 72/59 and 65/54).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The reduction in DRBP binding may be attributed to the reduced proportion of DRBP in the given mass of protein in COS-1 nuclear extracts overexpressed with recombinant COUP-TFII.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Alternatively, if COUP-TFII interacts with DRBP in solution, the overexpressed COUP-TFII may be sequestering the DRBP and forms larger complexes with the probe nt 74/53.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	178	 COUP-TFII did not shift the probes lacking the COUP-TFII binding site (nt 72/59 and 65/54) (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	179	 It is apparent that COUP-TFII interacts with the DR4 of nt 74 to 53 and DRBP interacts with AGTTCAAG sequence (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	180	To further confirm that COUP-TFII binds to this sequence, antiserum raised against COUP-TF was added to an EMSA using the nt 74 to 55 oligomer as a probe of nuclear extract from HepG2 cells.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The band that increased in intensity when shifted by nuclear extracts from HepG2 overexpressing COUP-TFII was supershifted by the anti-COUP-TF antibody (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	182	 3), indicating that COUP-TFII was interacting directly with the region.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Extracts prepared from cells overexpressing recombinant C/EBP, LAP, HNF4, or HNF3 did not produce any changes in the band-shift pattern (data not shown), and antiserum directed against C/EBP (potential binding site at nt 52 to 41) and c-erbA (a homologue of the thyroid receptor that is regulated by phosphorylation events) did not change the gel shift pattern (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Antibody against RAR and RXR did not supershift the nt 74 to 53 probe.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	185	 However, when performed with extracts prepared from HepG2 cells treated with all trans-retinoic acid, the ligand for RAR, the nt 74 to 54 probe was weakly supershifted with anti-RXR (data not shown).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	186	 DRBP, the major nuclear factor that binds to the sequence was not affected by the antibody, indicating that the proteins responsible for that band are distinct from COUP-TFII and RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	187	 These results confirm that the COUP-TFII binds to DR4 motif, which does not bind thyroid hormone receptor.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	188	 C/EBP, LAP, HNF4, and HNF3 do not bind to this region of CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	189	Interaction of COUP-TFII and RXR with the CYP7A Promoter at nt 149 to 128.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	190	The probe nt 149 to 128 shifted one band in HepG2 nuclear extracts.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Antibody against COUP-TFII supershifted the oligomer and changed the pattern of bands as if a complex was disrupted (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The amount of probe supershifted was not increased with increasing amounts of antibody, indicating that antibody was in excess.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Antibody against RXR supershifted a band in HepG2 nuclear extract treated with retinoic acid.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The antibody directed against RAR did not supershift the probe even with extract prepared from HepG2 cells treated with all trans-retinoic acid.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Retinoic acid treatment may have increased the expression of endogenous RXR and showed the supershift with anti-RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	196	Once it had been determined that the antibody specific for RXR supershifted the nt 149 to 128 probe, nucleotides important for the binding of RXR were determined by EMSA with mutant oligonucleotides and the antibody against RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides were synthesized in which three bases were changed by transversions.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Trinucleotide mutations in nt 145 to 134 completely abolished or reduced the supershift by antibody against RXR (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Mutations in nt 133/131 did not have any effect on supershift by antibody against RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	200	 These results indicate that RXR was interacting with the DR1 motif located from nt 146 to 134.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	201	Cotransfection assays of COUP-TFII expression plasmid with wild-type and mutant CYP7A proximal promoter constructs and EMSA results indicate that COUP-TFII interacts with nt 74 to 53 and nt 149 to 128 of the rat CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The region of nt 146 to 134 was shown by EMSA to bind RXR and contains HRE half-sites separated by one nucleotide (DR1), the preferred binding site for RXR homodimer (14).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The pattern of response of the mutants in nt 74 to 54 suggested that the nt 74 to 54 was the element with the strongest potential for COUP-TF activation of transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The deletion of the sequences from nt 74 to 54 results in the increase of transcriptional activity of CYP7A promoter/reporter plasmids.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This sequence was previously found to mediate the bile acid response and to interact with DRBP, whose binding was sensitive to deoxycholate feeding in rats.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	206	 6 is a model which shows the binding sites for these transcription factors on the rat CYP7A proximal promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Interactions of transactivators COUP-TFII and RXR with DRBP and their competition for binding to these bile acid response elements may regulate the CYP7A gene transcription by bile acids and hormones.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The CCAAT enhancer binding proteins (C/EBP and C/EBP or LAP) (21) consensus binding site flank the COUP-TFII binding site at nt 74 to 54.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The C/EBP family of transcription factors are temporally regulated and are thus important developmental regulators of gene expression.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	210	 COUP-TFII may recruit C/EBP on to the apolipoprotein A1 promoter (22).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The DBP B-site, which also is the LAP binding site, was located in the nt 149 to 118 region (23).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	212	 However, antibody directed against C/EBP and LAP did not supershift the nt 149/118 probe.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	213	 This is consistent with the lack of effect of these transcription factors on CYP7A promoter activity we observed.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The juxtaposition of the COUP-TF and C/EBP binding sites at nt 74/54 and nt 149/118 may prevent the weak binding of these factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Diagram of CYP7A proximal promoter with DRBP, COUP-TFII, and RXR recognition sites indicated in relation to the transcription start site, D-site binding protein (DBP) and liver activating protein (LAP) binding sites.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	216	 DBP and LAP (C/EBP) binding sites were determined previously (4, 23).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	217	 [View Larger Version of this Image (18K GIF file)].
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	218	In light of the well-characterized negative effect of COUP-TFII on gene promoters, removing a COUP-TFII binding site in CYP7A promoter may explain the much higher activity of the deletion mutants (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	219	 However, several recent reports support our finding that COUP-TFII also can function as a transactivator (24-27).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	220	 COUP-TFII binds as a stable homodimer to many variations of GGTCA sequences in direct repeats and interferes with vitamin D3, thyroid hormone, and retinoic acid receptors by competing for the AGGTCA sites, the cognate sequences for the steroid/thyroid hormone receptors (15).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	221	 However, if the negative effect of COUP-TFII is due to interfering with a positive factor, over-expression of COUP-TFII should repress the transcriptional activity of the CYP7A promoter.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	222	 COUP-TFII activated transcription of the CYP7A promoter at all COUP-TFII expression plasmid to reporter plasmid ratios tried.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The deletion of the strong proximal COUP-TFII site at nt 74 to 55 may allow enhancers in the promoter to interact more readily with the transcriptional machinery and resulting in higher transcriptional activity.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	224	 COUP-TFII has been reported to interact with TFIIB (28) and to affect the transcriptional activity by interacting with other transcription factors.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	225	 For example, COUP-TFII is required for activation of the apolipoprotein A1 promoter by RXR (22).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	226	 As the COUP-TFII and RXR both recognized the nt 149 to 128 probe, it is possible that COUP-TFII may interact with RXR.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The heterodimer of COUP-TFII and RXR is known to bind a DR1 motif and transrepress gene transcription (13).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	228	Despite the finding that COUP-TF binds to a region responsive to bile acid repression, the role of COUP-TFII in the bile acid regulation of CYP7A is not clear and requires further study.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The region from nt 65 to 54 can confer the bile acid response to SV40 promoter, but the probe does not bind COUP-TFII in vitro (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	230	 However, the DRBP and COUP-TFII apparently share binding sequence, the 3 COUP-TFII half-site overlaps with the DRBP binding site (Fig.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	231	 COUP-TF clearly influences cholesterol metabolism, in that this transcription factor has previously been shown to affect the transcription of the promoters for apolipoprotein AI (16), apolipoprotein AII, apolipoprotein B (29), apolipoprotein CIII (29, 30) and cholesteryl ester transfer protein gene (27).
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	232	The physiological role of the sequences from nt 74 to 54 may be to restrain CYP7A expression.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	233	 This down-regulation may be necessary because of the cytotoxicity of bile acids and the need to preserve cholesterol for synthesis of steroid hormones and membrane components.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The exact interactions of the factors involved has yet to be defined; however, the data are consistent with a model in which COUP-TFII, RXR, and DRBP interact with and bind to a negative element in the region between nt 74 and 54 and a positive element from nt 149 to 118 (10) and lead to the regulation of the CYP7A gene transcription in response to signals from bile acids and hormones.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	235	 This work contributes to the increasing body of evidence indicating COUP-TF has a prominent role in transcriptional regulation of lipid metabolism and that factor binding to the nt 74 to 54 and nt 149 to 128 regions are important determinants of CYP7A transcription.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	236	*   This research was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grants GM31584 and DK44442.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	237	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
