0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	279	 267, 17617-17623 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Ladias, J.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	280	 267, 15849-15860 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Mietus-Snyder, M.
0.43622568.9092518.html.plaintext.txt	281	 12, 1708-1718 [Abstract]  1997 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	0	Identification of a Novel Sonic Hedgehog Response Element in the Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor II Promoter Venkatesh Krishnan, Gerard Elberg, Ming-Jer Tsai and Sophia Y.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, Texas 77030.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is a secreted morphogen that regulates dorso-ventral patterning within the neural tube during embryonic development.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	3	 It is well established that Shh can induce motor-neuron differentiation that coincides with the appearance of specific motor-neuron markers including chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II (COUP-TFII) and Isl1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	4	 However, the mechanism of Shh-induced signaling pathway in vertebrates is not clearly defined.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In this report we have identified COUP-TFII as a target gene for Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	6	6-kb region of the COUP-TFII promoter to identify a target element that mediates the Shh-induced activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Extensive deletions introduced within this region have further enabled us to identify a novel sonic hedgehog response element (ShhRE) in the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Point mutations introduced within the ShhRE reveal some key nucleotides that are essential for protein(s)-binding activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Finally, the ShhRE is capable of functioning as a true enhancer element and can mediate Shh-induced transactivation of reporter gene via a heterologous promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Sonic hedgehog Shh is a vertebrate member of the Drosophila segment polarity gene family and is a secreted morphogen that is responsible for providing the ventralizing signals within the neural tube (1, 2).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The Drosophila homolog of Shh, called hedgehog (Hh), is expressed as a 471-amino acid polypeptide that is subsequently cleaved at amino acid 257 by a unique autoproteolytic mechanism (3).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The C terminus of Hh harbors this proteolytic activity, and the N terminus, which includes the signal peptide sequence, is the secreted form of the protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Several reports indicate that the N-terminal 20-kDa protein harbors the signaling activity of this morphogen (4, 5).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Similar observations have been made for its murine homolog with respect to its N-terminal activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Consistent with this observation is the high degree of homology (94 to 99%) at the N-terminal 180 amino acids between mouse, chicken, and zebra fish members of the hedgehog gene family (1).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	16	It has been reported that increased Shh expression in the notochord results in the increased expression of HNF3ss in the floor plate and the subsequent appearance of other ventral markers in the neural tube (6).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	17	 This results in the suppression of the dorsalizing signals, induced by BMP-2/4 originating from the neuroectoderm (7).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The appearance of ventral markers within the neural tube establishes a dorso-ventral boundary, which is broadly described as dorso-ventral patterning.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The induction of motor neuron markers within the ventro-lateral region is coincident with this Shh-mediated activity in the neural tube.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Jessell and co-workers (8) have demonstrated that conditioned media from COS-1 cells that overexpress and secrete Shh can mediate motor neuron differentiation in naive neural plate explants.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	21	Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factors (COUP-TFs) are members of the nuclear receptor superfamily and belong to the orphan receptor subclass (9, 10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Two genes called COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII have been identified in mammals.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	23	 COUP-TFs are capable of dimerizing with the retinoid X receptor and are known to affect the regulation of retinoic acid receptor, retinoid X receptor, and vitamin D receptor responsive genes (9).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	24	 COUP-TFs in general are expressed during embryonic development and are proposed to mediate essential mesenchymal-epithelial interactions that are crucial for proper organogenesis (10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	25	 To that effect, mRNA of COUP-TFII has been detected in the mesenchymal compartment of several developing organs such as the kidney, breast, and prostate (10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	26	COUP-TFs are expressed in the developing murine central and peripheral nervous systems.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	27	 It is hypothesized that these two genes play a role in regulating the developmental fates of diencephalic neuromeres by altering the expression of some of the key factors involved in cell fate determination (11).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Most importantly, COUP-TFII mRNA is highly expressed in differentiating motor neurons within the neural tube of a developing chick embryo.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Notochord transplantation experiments suggest that this increase in COUP-TFII mRNA within the ventro-lateral region of the chick neural tube is mediated by signals derived from the notochord (12).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Hence, we hypothesize that Shh, a secreted morphogen derived from the notochord, can elicit this increase in COUP-TFII expression in differentiating motor neurons.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	31	For our studies we used the P19 mouse embryocarcinoma cells that were previously used to study the retinoid-mediated regulation of COUP-TFs (13, 14).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Also, these cells exhibit some characteristics of neuronal cells when treated for extended periods with all-trans retinoic acid (15).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	33	 For our initial experiments, conditioned medium derived from COS-1 cells transfected with a mouse Shh expression construct was applied to P19 cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Later, an Escherichia coli-expressed N-terminal 20-kDa Shh protein fragment was used in our studies.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In this report we provide evidence that Shh can induce COUP-TFII transcripts in P19 cells and evidence to implicate a novel target element on the COUP-TFII promoter that mediates this Shh-induced activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	36	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Induction of COUP-TFII mRNA Expression by Conditioned Media Containing Shh To determine whether endogenous COUP-TFII mRNA is regulated by Shh in P19 cells, we overexpressed Shh in COS-1 cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These cells have been shown to express, process, and secrete the N-terminal fragment of Shh in the medium (2).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	38	 We transfected COS-1 cells with the pBKCMV-Shh plasmid.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Conditioned medium was then concentrated to 1/20 of the volume and applied onto P19 cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Control medium obtained from COS-1 cells transfected with pBKCMV (vector backbone without Shh) was used as control.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	41	 RNA from these cells was used in a Northern blot assay.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	42	 1A, incubation of P19 cells with increasing amounts of conditioned media containing Shh N-terminal fragment results in a 5- to 7-fold increase in COUP-TFII mRNA (lanes 1, 2, and 3).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	43	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Induction of COUP-TFII mRNA by Conditioned Media Containing Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	45	A, P19 cells were treated with 200  microl (lane 2) and 400  microl (lane 3) of conditioned media containing Shh N-terminal fragment (pBKCMV-Shh).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Lane 1 is the control lane, which was conditioned media from the vector-transfected COS-1 cells (pBKCMV).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Densitometric analysis reveals a 3- to 5-fold increase in COUP-TFII mRNA levels after adjusting for the GAPDH internal control.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	48	 B, COS-1 cells were transfected with pBKCMV alone (lane 1) or pBKCMV-Shh (lane 2 and 3).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The medium was concentrated to 1/20 of the volume and separated on a 12% SDS-PAGE gel.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The gel was subsequently transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane and subjected to a Western analysis as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The 20-kDa band represents the secreted form of Shh N-terminal fragment.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Lane 3 represents a membrane that contains the same media from lane 2 except that it was probed with a primary antibody that was preblocked with the specific antigen.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	53	  To ascertain the presence of secreted Shh in the conditioned media, we performed a Western blot analysis using a polyclonal antibody that specifically recognizes the secreted N-terminal 20-kDa Shh protein fragment (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Results from these experiments suggest that immunodetectable levels of the secreted 20 kDa N-terminal fragment of Shh are only present in COS-1 cell-conditioned media transfected with the pBKCMV-Shh plasmid (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The N-terminal protein was used to block this antibody to corroborate its specificity (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Since the signaling function of Shh is restricted to this N-terminal secreted fragment, we shall refer to this fragment as Shh for the remainder of this report.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	57	Induction of COUP-TFII Promoter Activity by Conditioned Media Containing Shh To identify the mechanism of this Shh-mediated increase in COUP-TFII mRNA, we analyzed the effect of the Shh-containing conditioned media on the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	58	6-kb promoter fragment that includes the transcription initiation site of COUP-TFII was cloned upstream of the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) reporter gene (p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	59	6CII-CAT) and transfected into P19 cells (13).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	60	 2 the conditioned media containing Shh (lanes 2 and 3) can increase COUP-TFII promoter activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In a separate experiment we show that this increase can be elicited by adding 1 nM N-terminal 20-kDa Shh protein directly to COS-1 cells transfected with the p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Hence, it can be inferred that P19 and COS-1 cells possess the necessary factors to transduce the Shh signal.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	63	 These results indicate that the 1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	64	6-kb fragment of the COUP-TFII promoter harbors the target element(s) that mediates Shh activation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	65	View larger version (46K):    Figure 2.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Induction of COUP-TFII Promoter Activity by Conditioned Media Containing Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	67	P19 cells were transfected with the p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Increasing amounts of conditioned media from COS-1 cells containing Shh were added to P19 cells (lane 2; 200  microl, lane 3; 400  microl).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Conditioned medium from COS-1 cells with no Shh was added separately to P19 cells (lane 1; 400  microl) transfected with the p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	70	 A 10-fold increase was observed between lanes 1 and 3.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	71	  Deletion Analysis of the COUP-TFII Promoter To further characterize the target element(s), deletion mutants of the COUP-TFII promoter with various end points were generated.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	72	 COS-1 cells were transfected with this plasmid and treated with 1 nM Shh protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	73	 3A, the Shh-mediated increase in promoter activity was restricted to the 5' -1455 to -1212 nucleotide (nt) fragment (compare lanes 3 and 4 with the other lanes).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In contrast, the p800CII-tkCAT (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	75	 3A, lanes 5 and 6), p900CII-tkCAT (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	76	 3A, lanes 7 and 8), or the tkCAT vector backbone (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	77	 3A, lanes 9 and 10) showed no increase in CAT activity in the presence of Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (35K):    Figure 3.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Identification of a ShhRE on the COUP-TFII Promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	80	A, COS-1 cells were transfected with the following plasmids: p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	81	6CII-CAT, lanes 1 and 2; p240CII-tkCAT, lanes 3 and 4; p800CII-tkCAT, lanes 5 and 6; p925CII-tkCAT, lanes 7 and 8; and pBLCAT2, lanes 9 and 10.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Cells were treated with 1 nM Shh for 36 h, and cell lysate was assayed for enzyme activity as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	83	 A 4- to 6-fold increase in CAT activity was observed between lanes 1 and 3 and 2 and 4, respectively.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	84	 B, COS-1 cells were transfected as described earlier with the plasmids as indicated by their starting nucleotide on the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	85	 A 4- to 6- fold increase in CAT activity was observed between lanes 1 and 3 and 2 and 4, respectively.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	86	 C, COS-1 cells were transfected as described earlier with the plasmids as indicated by the region within the COUP-TFII promoter and described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	87	 A 3- to 4-fold increase was observed between lanes 1, 3, and 5 and 2, 4, and 6, respectively.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	88	  To further define the Shh response element (ShhRE), we used nested primers to PCR amplify specific 5' deleted fragments of this -1455 to -1212 region of the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	89	 These deletion fragments were subsequently cloned upstream of a tkCAT reporter, transfected into COS-1 cells, and treated with or without 1 nM Shh protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	90	 3B, deletion of the first 112 nt (from -1455 to -1343) has no effect on the Shh inducibility (compare lanes 2 and 4).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	91	 In contrast, deletion of the next 76 or 159 nt (from -1343 to -1267 or -1150) abolished Shh-dependent activation of the reporter gene (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	92	 3B; compare lanes 2, 6, and 8).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Also, cells transfected with the tkCAT vector backbone showed no increase in CAT enzyme activity in the presence of 1 nM Shh (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Results obtained from these studies suggest that the Shh-induced activity was mediated by a response element located between -1343 and -1267 of the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	95	Additional deletions were made within this region of the promoter to localize the target element that mediates Shh activation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	96	 These fragments were subsequently cloned upstream of a tkCAT reporter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	97	 COS-1 cells were transfected with these plasmids and treated with 1 nM Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	98	 3C, deletion of 27 nt from -1343 does not affect Shh activation (compare lanes 4 and 6).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	99	 However, additional removal of 18 nt (from -1316 to -1298) abolishes Shh activation (compare lanes 6 and 8).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	100	 These results indicate that the 19-bp region between nucleotides -1316 and -1298 harbors most of this activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Collectively, our results indicate that a region (-1316 to -1298) within the COUP-TFII promoter harbors a ShhRE that mediates the Shh-induced increase in COUP-TFII promoter activity that leads to increased steady-state levels of COUP-TFII mRNA.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	102	Characterization of the ShhRE in P19 Cells To further confirm that the region between -1316 and -1298 is sufficient to confer the Shh response, we used this sequence in a heterologous promoter function assay.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	103	 A 42-bp oligonucleotide (ShhRE) that includes this region and the flanking sequences was synthesized, and three copies of this oligo were placed upstream of a tkLUC reporter gene to determine whether this element confers Shh inducibility through a heterologous promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	104	 In addition, four specific mutations, M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5, were introduced along this element and three copies of each of these mutant oligos were cloned upstream of a tkLUC reporter (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The resulting plasmids were then transfected into P19 cells, and reporter gene activity in response to 1 nM Shh was analyzed.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	106	 4B, three copies of ShhRE can provide a 5- to 7-fold increase in reporter gene activity in response to Shh (compare C and Shh).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	107	 4B, the M2, M3, and M4 mutations abolish the Shh response (compare S and S M1, S M2, S M3).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	108	 In contrast the M1 and M5 mutants were still capable of mediating this Shh-induced reporter gene activity (compare S, S M1, and S M5).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	109	 These results indicate that the nucleotide sequences defined by the mutant oligos M2, M3, and M4 are important for mediating the Shh response.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Hence, the point mutations introduced within the ShhRE that abolish transactivation must affect the binding of a putative transcription factor to this DNA element.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (27K):    Figure 4.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Characterization of the ShhRE on a Heterologous Promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	113	A, Sequence information on the wild type ShhRE and mutant oligonucleotides used in a transient transfection assay.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	114	 B, P19 cells were transfected with 3XShhRE-tkCAT (lanes 1 and 2), 3XM1-tkCAT (lanes 3 and 4), 3XM2-tkCAT (lanes 5 and 6), 3XM3-tkCAT (lanes 7 and 8), and 3XM4-tkCAT (lanes 9 and 10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Cells were treated with (S) or without (C) 1 nM Shh for 24 h, and luciferase activity was measured as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Results are expressed as mean  plus or minus  SD from three separate experiments.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	117	  Electromobility Shift Assays (EMSAs) Using P19 Nuclear Extracts and Radiolabeled ShhRE To understand the nature of the protein-DNA interaction on this element, we performed EMSAs using radiolabeled ShhRE.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The resulting autoradiograph indicates that there are two specific bands (see arrows), which are specifically enriched by Shh treatment (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Also, these bands are competed by the excess unlabeled ShhRE (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	120	 As expected, the mutant oligos M2, M3, and M4, which fail to exhibit enhancer-like activity, also fail to compete for these specific complexes when used as competitors (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Also, as expected, the oligo M1 and M5, which are functional ShhREs, could effectively compete for binding to these two specific complexes (Fig.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	122	 These results suggest that any alterations in the TACATAATGCGCCG core (residues in bold) of this ShhRE results in decreased binding, which then leads to decreased enhancer activity in transient transfection assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	123	View larger version (75K):    Figure 5.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	124	 EMSA Using Radiolabeled ShhRE and Nuclear Extracts from P19 Cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	125	P19 cells were treated with (lanes 2 through 8) or without (lane 1) 1 nM Shh for 36 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Later, cells were harvested and nuclear extract was obtained.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Five micrograms of this extract were used in an EMSA using radiolabeled ShhRE, which was performed as described in Materials and Methods.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Mutant competitor oligos at 100-fold molar excess were coincubated (lanes 3 through 8) with radiolabeled probe.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The specific bands are indicated by the arrowheads.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	130	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The notochord transplantation assays on the chick neural tube provided us with the rationale to study the possible regulation of COUP-TFII mRNA by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In this experiment we observe that a dorso-laterally placed ectopic notochord can induce motor neurons in an ectopic location within the ventral tube, and this coincides with the appearance of COUP-TFII transcripts (12).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	132	 These results suggest that notochord-derived signals can induce COUP-TFII mRNA.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In this report we provide evidence to clearly indicate that COUP-TFII mRNA is up-regulated by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In addition, we have defined a novel target element within the COUP-TFII promoter that mediates most of this activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Also, the low dose of Shh, namely 1 nM, which is capable of inducing this ShhRE-mediated activity, is in close agreement with this overall effect as observed by Jessell and co-workers (16) in neural explant assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	136	The identification of this ShhRE provides us with a valuable tool to study the various signaling pathways that are induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Previously, it was reported by Ingham and his colleagues (17) that a binding site for the Ci (cubidus interruptus) protein is a consensus HhRE (GACCACCCA), since it mediates the activation of the ptc (patched) promoter by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Ptc is a downstream target gene of Hh and is part of the putative membrane-bound Shh receptor complex (18, 19, 20).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	139	 However, the exact mechanism of ptc activation via this Ci element remains to be determined.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Interestingly, the ShhRE found on the COUP-TFII promoter bears very little similarity to that of the Drosophila Ci binding site.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In our oligo competition experiments, we demonstrate that any changes in the core sequence (TACATAATGCGCCG) are deleterious to Shh-induced binding.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Also, a transcription factor data bank analysis revealed very little information as to the exact identity of the factor(s) that may bind this element.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The identification of this novel response element suggests that in higher vertebrates the pleiotropic effects of Shh can be mediated by multiple pathways, some of which may target the Gli (mammalian homolog of Ci) binding site and others may target novel elements such as the one in the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	144	 5, the DNA-binding complexes in P19 nuclear extracts are induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The precise mechanism for this increase in binding is not known.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	146	 It is possible that Shh may simply modulate the activity of this factor(s) that binds to the ShhRE.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In agreement with this possible modulatory role for Shh, the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A (PKA) has been implicated in the Hh-signaling pathway.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In Drosophila, it is believed that PKA agonists can suppress signaling mediated by Hh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Also, localized loss of PKA -/- activity in a Drosophila imaginal disc can mimic Hh activity even in the absence of Hh (21, 22).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Similar results have been obtained using a dominant negative form of PKA in the mouse dorsal central nervous system (23, 24).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	151	 These observations have led to the popular belief that reversal of a PKA-repressed pathway is one of the major mechanisms of Hh activity in Drosophila and in mammals.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	152	 However, we do not observe a significant decrease in our transient transfection assays when COS-1 cells are treated with both Shh and forskolin (90  microM) using the 3X ShhRE-tkCAT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Also, forskolin fails to decrease Shh-induced binding in an EMSA using radiolabeled ShhRE (data not shown).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	154	 These results suggest that in higher vertebrates additional pathways that are independent of PKA may also be induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The identification of COUP-TFII as a novel target gene and the characterization of a ShhRE within its promoter may allow for the unraveling of this complex pathway.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	156	Our results provide a novel target gene for Shh, namely COUP-TFII, which can be exploited to study some of the intermediate steps in the Shh-signaling pathway.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	157	 In particular, COUP-TFII is a very well characterized transcription factor whose ability to affect the function of several other nuclear receptors provides an attractive target for the pleiotropic effects of Shh signaling.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	158	 However, the expression of COUP-TFII transcripts and areas in which Shh exerts its signaling activity may be limited to a few regions within the developing embryo (1, 10).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	159	The Shh homozygous null mice display the predicted phenotype based on the expression profile of this protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The Shh null mice display a cyclopia phenotype along with a loss of maintenance and organization along the axial midline structures of the developing embryo (25).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	161	 However, in the Shh null mice we can detect some COUP-TFII transcripts (F.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	162	 This observation suggests that COUP-TFII is not exclusively regulated by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	163	 These results are not surprising since COUP-TFII is expressed throughout mouse embryonic development in a wide variety of tissues (10, 11).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Also, we and others have shown that COUP-TFs are downstream target genes of retinoic acid and that their expression is increased by treatment with both 9-cis and all-trans retinoic acid (13, 14).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	165	We have generated COUP-TFII homozygous null mice to study the possible involvement of COUP-TFII in motor-neuron differentiation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	166	 However, the COUP-TFII null mice die before 10.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Interestingly, no obvious change in the overall morphology within the ventro-lateral region of the neural tube is observed (F.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	168	 We believe that the presence of COUP-TFI transcripts in the neural tube may allow for some functional compensation of COUP-TFII, which may obscure any obvious defects in motor neuron differentiation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	169	 We are currently attempting a localized knock out of both COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII in the ventro-lateral region of the neural tube to study the possible involvement of these genes in motor neuron differentiation.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	170	Our results have provided a novel target gene for Shh signaling in P19 mouse embryocarcinoma cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Activation of COUP-TFII, which is known to harbor a trans-repressor domain in its C-terminal 15 amino acids, may have important implications in neural tube patterning (26).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Shh has been implicated in enabling the notochord-derived signals to repress the dorsalizing signals induced by BMP-2/4 from the roof plate and or the neural epithelium of the neural tube (7, 27).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	173	 It has been reported that COUP-TFI can inhibit the BMP-4 promoter in fetal rat calvarial osteoblasts (28).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	174	 It is possible that temporal induction of COUP-TFII expression by Shh may serve to mediate this very repression in specific regions that are fated to become motor neurons in the ventro-lateral region of the neural tube.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In conclusion, our results provide a novel target gene (COUP-TFII) and a novel target element (ShhRE) that seem to mediate Shh-induced COUP-TFII expression in P19 mouse embryocarcinoma cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	176	 This finding will allow for the elucidation of the numerous signaling pathways induced by Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	177	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Plasmid Constructs The mouse Shh cDNA plasmid was kindly provided by Dr.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	178	6-kb fragment of the mouse Shh plasmid was subcloned into a XhoI/EcoRI site in the pBKCMV (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) vector to generate the pBKCMV-Shh plasmid.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	179	6CII-CAT plasmid was generated as described earlier (13).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	180	6-kb promoter of COUP-TFII was cut with ApaI to generate 800-bp, 450-bp, and 240-bp fragments.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	181	 These were subcloned into a pBluescript-KS plasmid.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The 800-bp (-1212 to -412) and 240-bp (-1455 to -1212) fragments were subsequently cloned into the pBLCAT2 plasmid at the HindIII/BamHI and HindII/XbaI sites, respectively, to generate the p800CII-tkCAT and the p240CII-tkCAT plasmids.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	183	Oligonucleotide Sequences ShhRE: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	184	M1: CGGGATCC AGT GAA TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	185	M2: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC CGC ATA ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	186	M3: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC GTG ATG CGC CCG GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	187	M4: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC ATT GGA AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	188	M5: CGGGATCC AGT GGG TTC TAC ATA ATG CGC CCG GAG AGATCTTCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	189	The ShhRE, M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5 oligos were cut with BamHI and BglII and ligated to generate a 3-copy insert.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Later this multimer was excised from a gel and subcloned into the BamHI site of the ptk109 plasmid, which contains a luciferase reporter gene driven by a minimal tk promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	191	PCR Primers -808 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAG AGA GCT CAG TGA GCT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	192	+117 reverse primer: TGA AGA TCT GAG TGT GCA GC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	193	-1343 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CGG AGA GCA TTA TTC AGT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	194	-1267 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAA ACC ACT GTG CCC GAT.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	195	-1150 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAT TTA GAG GCA TCG CCA.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	196	-1316 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CGT TCT ACA TAA TGC GCC.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	197	-1298 forward primer: GCT CTA GAG CAT GCG CCG GGA GTC CCG GGT GGA C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	198	-1070 reverse primer: GAA GAT CTT CCT GGC CAC AGA GAG G.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	199	The above mentioned primers were used to PCR amplify specific regions within the COUP-TFII promoter.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	200	6-kb region was used as template, and 100 ng/ml of each of the forward and reverse primers were used in a 50- microl reaction along with 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	201	5 mM deoxynucleoside triphosphates (final concentration) and 1  microl of Taq polymerase.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Ten percent dimethylsulfoxide was included in some reactions when the regions to be amplified had a GC content that was greater than 50%.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The amplified DNA fragments were phenol- and chloroform-purified followed by an overnight restriction enzyme digest with the appropriate enzymes.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	204	 All forward primers were digested with XbaI, and all reverse primers were digested with BglII.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Later these fragments were subcloned into a pBluescript II KS plasmid vector at the XbaI and BglII sites.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	206	 T7 and T3 primers were used to sequence these PCR-amplified fragments and after verification, these fragments were subcloned into the pBLCAT2 (tkCAT) or pBLCAT3 (CAT alone) plasmid at the XbaI/BamHI site.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The resultant plasmids were sequenced using the PCR primers and were subsequently used in transient transfection assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	208	COS-1 Conditioned Media COS-1 cells were plated at a density of 2 x 106 cells per 10-cm plate.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Cells were transiently transfected using the diethylaminoethyl-Dextran method as described previously (29).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Briefly, 1  microg of pBKCMV-Shh or pBKCMV plasmid was dissolved in 60  microl Tris-borate-NaCl (TBS) buffer and was incubated along with 120  microl diethylaminoethyl-Dextran (Sigma, St.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Louis, MO; 5 mg/ml in TBS) for 30 min at room temperature.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Later, this DNA solution was mixed with 4 ml TBS buffer containing 10% NuSerum (Collaborative Biomedical Products, Bedford, MA).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	213	 This mixture was then applied to the 10-cm plate, and the cells were incubated in this mixture for 6 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Cells were shocked with 10% dimethylsulfoxide for 2 min followed by a 4-h incubation with DMEM (no serum) containing 100  microM Chloroquine (Sigma, St.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Cells were washed and fresh medium was added containing 5% FBS.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Conditioned medium was obtained after 24, 36, and 48 h and assayed by Western blot after the medium had been concentrated to 1/20 of the volume in an Amicon (Beverly, MA) concentrator.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The 48-h time point was found to be optimal for use in other assays.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	218	Northern Blot Analysis P19 cells were grown to a density of 5 x 105 cells per 10-cm plate.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Cells were used between passage numbers 5 and 20.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Late passage cells displayed significant variations in our experiments and hence were not used in these reported studies.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Conditioned media obtained from the appropriately transfected COS-1 cells were applied at a specific time point, and 40 h later total RNA was obtained using the Trizol (Life Technologies, Gaithersburg, MD) reagent.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	222	 This method is a modification of the guanidinium-HCl method of RNA isolation (30).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	223	 RNA was dissolved in 100% deionized formamide and used within a short period or stored in 70% ethanol for extended periods at -70 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Ten micrograms of total RNA were reprecipitated and washed with 70% ethanol and redissolved in diethyl pyrocarbonate-treated water.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	225	 This RNA was heated at 55 C for 15 min in loading buffer (35% formamide, 10% formaldehyde, 20 mM Na2HPO4, pH 6.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	226	8, and loading dye containing 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	227	 RNA was quick cooled on ice and loaded onto a 1% agarose gel containing 1 M formaldehyde in an SPC buffer (20 mM Na2HPO4, pH 6.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The gel was run in 1x SPC buffer and stained with ethidium bromide (0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	229	01% solution in 1x SPC) for 20 min followed by destaining for 1 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The separated RNA was blotted onto a Hybond N nylon membrane (Amersham, Arlington Heights, IL).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	231	 A RNA ladder (6  microg) was run along with each gel and was used to estimate the size of the transcript.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The membrane was UV-cross-linked (Stratalinker, Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) for 2 min and was dried in a gel dryer at 80 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The membrane was prehybridized using the QuikHyb solution from Stratagene for 1 h and was hybridized with a radiolabeled 500-bp 5'-untranslated region fragment (31) of COUP-TFII for 2 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Later, the membrane was washed twice with 2x saline sodium citrate (SSC) buffer and 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	235	 This was followed by two high-stringency washes using 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The residual SDS was removed using a quick 2x SSC wash, and the membrane was exposed to a XOMAT-AR film (Eastman Kodak, Rochester, NY) for 6 to 12 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The membrane was then stripped using 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	238	1x SSPE (sodium phosphate-EDTA), 1% SDS solution at 85 C for 15 min.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	239	 It was then rehybridized with a specific 5' 1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	240	Transient Transfection Assays COS-1 cells were transiently transfected as described earlier, using 1  microg reporter plasmid.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	241	 P19 cells were transfected using a replication-deficient adenovirus as described earlier (33).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Briefly, adenovirus (2 x 108 particles) and 100 ng reporter plasmid were incubated at room temperature for 30 min in a buffer containing 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This was followed by infection of P19 cells (400,000 cells per well) with this viral-DNA mixture for 2 h in a 37 C incubator in DMEM containing 5% FBS.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	244	 coli-expressed Shh (1 nM) was added along with the fresh media supplemented with 10% FBS after transfection and incubated for 24 h, before the cells were harvested for reporter gene activity.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	245	 A Bio-Rad (Hercules, CA) protein assay reagent was used to quantitate the amount of protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Five micrograms of cell lysate were used in a CAT assay, which was performed as described previously (34).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	247	 For the luciferase reporter gene assays, 10  microg cell lysate were incubated with the enzyme substrate in a 60- microl reaction mix according to the instructions provided in the Promega luciferase assay system kit (Promega, Madison, WI).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Enzyme activity was measured in a Monolight analytical luminometer (Analytical/Luminescence Laboratory, Ann Arbor, MI) for 5 sec and was plotted as relative luciferase units per 20  microg lysate.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	249	 2, P19 cells were transfected using 1  microg p1.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	250	6CII-CAT plasmid along with 6  microg Lipofectamine (Life Technologies) reagent in 4 ml DMEM without serum for 10 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Later cells were washed and 12 ml fresh DMEM containing 10% FBS were added along with 200  microl or 400  microl concentrated COS-1-conditioned media containing Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	252	 In parallel, 400  microl concentrated COS-1-conditioned media without Shh, along with 12 ml DMEM, were also added to P19 cells.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	253	 After 36 h cells were harvested and cell lysate was obtained.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Protein concentration was determined using the Bio-Rad protein assay reagent.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Twenty micrograms of cell lysate were used to analyze CAT activity as described earlier.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	256	EMSAs P19 cells were seeded at 5 x 105 cells per 10-cm plate in DME-F12 media with or without 1 nM Shh.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	257	 After 36 h cells were harvested and washed in PBS.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Cells were incubated in 200  microl hypotonic buffer containing 10 mM KCl, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	259	1 mM EDTA, 1 mM dithiothreitol (DTT), 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	260	5 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride, and 10 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Twenty-five microliters of 10% NP-40 were added, and the cells were vortexed for 30 sec.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Later these cells were centrifuged at 5000 rpm at 4 C to spin down the nuclei.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Nuclei were then incubated in 30  microl hypertonic buffer containing 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	264	4 M NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride, 10% glycerol, and 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	265	9, for 30 min in a gentle shaker at 4 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	266	 This mixture was centrifuged at 13,000 rpm at 4 C for 10 min, and the supernatant was immediately dialyzed for 4 h in 500 ml buffer containing 10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	267	5, 50 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, and 5% glycerol at 4 C.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	268	 A 10 kDa molecular mass cut-off membrane was used for this dialysis.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	269	 A Bio-Rad protein assay reagent was used to quantitate the amount of protein.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Five micrograms of nuclear extract were incubated along with 50,000 cpm of radiolabeled ShhRE for 15 min, in a buffer containing 10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	271	5, 80 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	272	1 mg/ml BSA, 200 ng salmon sperm DNA, 3  microg poly dG-dC, 1  microg poly dI-dC, and 5% glycerol.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	273	 One hundred molar excess of competitor oligos were incubated in the appropriate reaction mix along with the nuclear extract.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The samples were then loaded onto a 5% native polyacrylamide gel, and the protein-DNA complexes formed were separated and analyzed by autoradiography.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	275	Western Blot Analysis Conditioned media from the appropriately transfected COS-1 cells were concentrated to 1/20 the volume using an Amicon concentrator and applied onto a 12% SDS-polyacrylamide gel.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The separating gel was immediately transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane in a buffer containing 50 mM Tris, 380 mM glycine, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	277	1% (wt/vol) SDS, and 20% methanol.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The transfer was performed at 65 V for 16 h in a cold room.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	279	 To confirm complete transfer, the gel was stained with a Coomassie stain for 20 min followed by destaining in a 40% methanol-10% glacial acetic acid solution for 1 to 2 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	280	 The resultant membrane was subjected to the standard enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) Western blotting kit protocol (Amersham, Life Science).
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	281	 A rabbit polyclonal antibody that specifically recognized the N-terminal 20 kDa Shh protein (3) was used to detect the levels of N-terminal 20-kDa protein in the conditioned media.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The primary antibody was divided into two groups and was blocked with BSA or 4  microg/ml N-terminal Shh protein fragment for 2 h at 4 C with gentle shaking.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The membrane divided into two halves and was incubated with the primary antibody or the preblocked antibody at a 1:3000 dilution in 20 mM Tris, 137 mM NaCl, 0.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The membrane was washed and then incubated with a horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-rabbit secondary antibody (1:1000 dilution) for 1 h.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	285	 This was followed by another wash and incubation with the detection mix provided in the ECL kit, for 1 min.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The membrane was immediately drained and exposed to film for 30 sec.
0.22919919.9280061.html.plaintext.txt	287	 A prestained marker (Bio-Rad) was used to estimate the apparent molecular masses of the resultant bands.
