0.3001008.11117523.html.plaintext.txt	440	35 Pfahl M, Tzukerman M, Zhang X-K, Lehmann JM, Hermann T, Wills K, Graupner G 1990 Rapid procedures for retinoic acid receptor cloning and their analysis.
0.3001008.11117523.html.plaintext.txt	441	 Methods Enzymol 153:256 to 270 Lazennec G, Kern L, Salbert G, Saligaut D, Valotaire Y 1996 Cooperation between the human estrogen receptor (ER) and MCF-7 cell-specific transcription factors elicits high activity of an estrogen-inducible enhancer from the trout ER gene.
0.3001008.11117523.html.plaintext.txt	442	 Mol Endocrinol 10:116 to 1126 Krowczynska AM, Coutts M, Makrides S, Brawerman G 1989 The mouse homologue of the human acidic ribosomal phosphoprotein PO: a highly conserved polypeptide that is under translational control.
0.3001008.11117523.html.plaintext.txt	443	 Nucleic Acids Res 17:6408[Medline] Clifford J, Chiba H, Sobieszczuk D, Metzger D, Chambon P 1996 RXR-null F9 embryonal carcinoma cells are resistant to the differentiation, anti-proliferative and apoptotic effects of retinoids.
0.3001008.11117523.html.plaintext.txt	444	 EMBO J 15:4142 to 4155[Abstract] Boudjelal M, Taneja R, Matsubara S, Bouillet P, Dolle P, Chambon P 1997 Overexpression of Stra13, a novel retinoic acid-inducible gene of the basic helix-loop-helix family, inhibits mesodermal and promotes neuronal differentiation of P19 cells.
0.3001008.11117523.html.plaintext.txt	445	 Genes Dev 11:2052 to 2065[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	0	ACCELERATED PUBLICATION Crystal Structure of the HNF4 Ligand Binding Domain in Complex with Endogenous Fatty Acid Ligand* Sirano Dhe-Paganon , Karen Duda  , Melanie Iwamoto, Young-In Chi, and Steven E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Joslin Diabetes Center  and  Department of Medicine, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts 02215.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, July 23, 2002, and in revised form, August 20, 2002.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	4	HNF4 is an orphan member of the nuclear receptor family with prominent functions in liver, gut, kidney and pancreatic  cells.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We have solved the x-ray crystal structure of the HNF4 ligand binding domain, which adopts a canonical fold.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Two conformational states are present within each homodimer: an open form with  helix 12 (12) extended and collinear with 10 and a closed form with 12 folded against the body of the domain.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Although the protein was crystallized without added ligands, the ligand binding pockets of both closed and open forms contain fatty acids.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The carboxylic acid headgroup of the fatty acid ion pairs with the guanidinium group of Arg226 at one end of the ligand binding pocket, while the aliphatic chain fills a long, narrow channel that is lined with hydrophobic residues.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These findings suggest that fatty acids are endogenous ligands for HNF4 and establish a framework for understanding how HNF4 activity is enhanced by ligand binding and diminished by MODY1 mutations.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	10	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	11	Nuclear receptors are ligand-activated transcription factors that regulate such diverse physiological processes as reproduction, development, and metabolism.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Ligand binding induces conformational changes that coordinately dissociates corepressors and recruits coactivators to enhance transcriptional activity (1, 2).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Physiologically relevant ligands, which are known for less than half of the 48 nuclear receptors encoded by the human genome, include the steroid hormones, retinoids, thyroid hormone, vitamin D3, and fatty acids.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	14	 HNF4 is considered to be an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily because its endogenous ligand is not known (3).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Originally identified in liver, HNF4 is also present in kidney, gut, and pancreatic islets.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	16	 It functions in transcriptional cascades, downstream of TGF--activated SMAD signaling and GATA and HNF3/forkhead family transcription factors and upstream of the HNF1/POU homeodomain transcription factor.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In addition to HNF1, the many target genes for HNF4 in liver include coagulation factors and proteins involved in lipid and cholesterol metabolism and transport.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Selective targets present in kidney and intestine include erythropoietin and intestinal fatty acid binding protein, respectively.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Targeted disruption of Hnf4 in mice leads to defective gastrulation, underscoring an important role for HNF4 in the developing gut (4).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In humans, the clinically apparent phenotype associated with Hnf4 mutations is a Mendelian form of diabetes mellitus associated with abnormalities in lipoprotein and lipid concentrations (5, 6).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	21	Positional cloning methods revealed the relationship between HNF4 and an atypical form of diabetes referred to as maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY1) (5).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Mutations in at least six distinct genes have been linked to MODY (7).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Although MODY1 is rare ( < 20 families have been identified) (5, 8, 9), the associated phenotype is instructive.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Like other forms of MODY, MODY1 is characterized by autosomal-dominant inheritance, early onset ( < 25 years of age), and abnormal pancreatic  cell function.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Because reduced  cell function leads to insulin deficiency, it is reasonable to conclude that HNF4 activity is tightly coupled with insulin synthesis and secretion.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Since nuclear receptors are an established and valuable class of drug targets, it follows that selective agonists for HNF4 might be useful as new therapeutic strategies for improving insulin secretion in MODY patients and potentially others with more prevalent forms of type 2 diabetes.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	27	 To learn more about how HNF4 functions in health and disease, and as an important step in drug discovery, we have crystallized the ligand binding domain (LBD)1 of HNF4 and solved its three-dimensional structure.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	28	 HNF4 forms an antiparallel, three-layered  helical sandwich akin to other nuclear receptor LBDs.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The serendipitous presence of a tightly associated fatty acid in the binding pocket reveals potential mechanisms for ligand binding.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	30	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	31	Protein Production and Crystallization-- DNA encoding the LBD of rat HNF4 (residues 133-382) was subcloned into the pET 28a vector (Novagen) by PCR.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Protein was expressed in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) (Invitrogen), grown either in LB or synthetic medium containing L-selenomethionine (SeMet), and isolated from bacterial lysates using Talon cobalt affinity resin (Clontech).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The His6 affinity tag was removed with bovine thrombin (10 units/ml), and the protein was further purified by ion exchange chromatography (Mono Q fast protein liquid chromatography).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Crystals were obtained at room temperature by the vapor diffusion method in 10  microl of sitting drops containing equal volumes of protein (25 mg/ml) and crystallization buffer (0.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	35	7 M ammonium acetate, 16% MPD (2-methyl-2,4-pentanediol), and 10 mM dithiothreitol).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	36	Data Collection and Structure Determination-- Diffraction data were collected at 100 K at the National Synchotron Light Source, Brookhaven, NY (beamline X12C).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Oscillation images were collected every 1 degrees , and the data were integrated and scaled using the DENZO HKL software package (10).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The structure was determined using MAD phasing of SeMet-substituted protein.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The expected bijvoet and dispersive differences (11) based on six bound seleniums in a monomer (250 residues) were 5.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The program SOLVE (12) found 20 of 24 possible selenium sites.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The phases were improved by 4-fold averaging and solvent flattening utilizing the programs MLPHARE and DM in the CCP4 suite (13).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The model was built using O (14) and refined with CNS (15), applying restrained 4-fold non-crystallographic symmetry, overall B-factor corrections, and bulk solvent corrections (Table I).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	43	Fatty Acid Analyses-- HNF4 samples (200 mg) were combined with a 10-fold excess (v:v) of 15% NaOH in 50% methanol and heated for 30 min at 100  degrees C.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Esterification was accomplished by combining the cooled solutions with 20 volumes of 46% methanol in 6 N HCl and heating for 10 min at 80  degrees C.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The fatty acid methyl esters were extracted into 50% methyl t-butyl ether in hexane and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (Sherlock MIS; 170-270  degrees C) at the Bacterial Identification and Fatty Acid Laboratory, University of Florida (plantpath.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	46	     RESULTS AND DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	47	Domain Architecture and Structural Homology-- The amino- and carboxyl-terminal boundaries of the LBD of HNF4 were delineated from sequence comparisons with other members of the nuclear receptor family.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Although we attempted to express longer versions, including the entire LBD plus F-domain (133-455), these degraded to shorter fragments.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Since susceptibility to proteolysis suggested that the F-domain is at least partially disordered, we expressed and crystallized the LBD domain (133-382) by itself.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Crystals belonging to the tetragonal space group P41212 (unit cell: a = b = 102.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	51	7 A) reached maximal dimensions of 0.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	52	2 mm in sitting drops within 5 days.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The structure was solved using MAD phasing of selenomethionine-substituted protein (Table I).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	54	                              View this table:    Table I Data and refinement statistics.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	55	Four protein molecules are assembled in the asymmetric unit as a pair of identical homodimers.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Each LBD of HNF4 contains 9-10  helices and two  strands that adopt the helical sandwich motif common to the LBDs of nuclear receptors (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	57	 194 core  carbons of the ligand binding domains from HNF4 and RXR (Protein Data Bank number 1FBY) (16), a close structural relative, superimpose with a root mean square deviation of 1.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Following conventional nomenclature,  helix 2 (2), which is variably present in nuclear receptor LBDs, is absent in HNF4, 6 consists of a single  helical turn, and 10 and 11 are contiguous.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Acidic residues Glu261 and Asp262 create a bulge in 5 that may be important for dimerization (17).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Electron density is apparent for all residues except those at the amino (133-140) and carboxyl (368-382) termini of the domain and within the loop between  helices 1 and 3 (the 1/3 loop, residues 157-165).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	61	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	62	   Structure of the HNF4 ligand binding domain.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	63	 A, a ribbon diagram of the homodimer reveals a "LBD" fold.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Helices, shaded turquoise (1-9), yellow (10), or red (12), reveal two distinct conformations: open on the left and closed on the right.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	65	  Strands are colored green, and the fatty acids in the ligand binding pockets are colored magenta.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	66	 B, the ligand and elements of secondary structure are colored similarly in the schematic representations, with open and closed conformations in the same orientations for comparison.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	67	Fatty Acids in the Ligand Binding Pocket of HNF4-- Although we did not add potential ligands to our crystallization trials, the initial electron density maps showed density in the ligand binding pocket of the domain that was not accounted for by the protein.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The excess electron density, present in all molecules of the asymmetric unit, resembled a small molecule associated with the guanidinium group of Arg226.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization and time of flight mass spectrometric analyses of HNF4 revealed, in addition to the expected parent ion for the expressed protein, the presence of non-covalently associated saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids (data not shown).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To confirm the identities of the lipids and quantify relative amounts, purified HNF4 solutions were submitted for fatty acid analysis by GC.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Recombinant rat HNF4-(133-382) contained a mixture of fatty acids, including 16:0, 17:0 cyclo, 18:17c, and 14:0 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Similar sets of fatty acids bound a longer form of rat HNF4 containing the entire carboxyl-terminal F domain (residues 133-455, data not shown) and the LBD of human HNF4 (residues 140-382), which differs from the rat domain at seven positions (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	73	 These findings demonstrate that both human and rat proteins associate spontaneously with endogenous fatty acids and that the F domain does not influence binding.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	74	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	75	   Fatty acids bound to the HNF4 LBD.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Fatty acids were extracted from rat HNF4-(133-385), human HNF4-(140-385), and E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	77	 coli BL21 cells, converted to the corresponding methyl esters, and analyzed by GC.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The results are plotted as percentages of total and sorted according to relative abundance in bacteria.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	79	 12:0, 14:0, and 16:0 are saturated lauric, myristic, and palmitic acids, respectively; 16:17c is monounsaturated palmitoleic acid, cyclo refers to a cyclopropyl group, 2OH and 3OH have hydroxyl groups at the 2 or 3 positions, respectively, and iso has an extra methyl group on the penultimate carbon.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Both fatty acids are listed when mixtures could not be resolved.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	81	To determine whether the LBDs select specific fatty acids from the larger pool, we subjected E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	82	 coli BL21 cells to similar GC analyses (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The bacterial fatty acids present in greatest abundance also bound HNF4, although there appears to be a degree of selectivity.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	84	 For example, the fatty acids 16:0, 18:17c, 16:1 iso/14:0 3OH, and 19:0 cyclo 8c are present in greater relative abundance in the bacteria than associated with human or rat HNF4 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	85	 2) (16:1 iso and 14:0 3OH are not distinguished by GC).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In contrast, fatty acids 17:0 cyclo, 16:1 7c/15 iso 2OH, 15 iso 3OH, and 10:0 were bound to the protein in higher relative abundance than their presence in E.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Other fatty acids such as 18:17c and 14:0 were neither selected for nor against (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Therefore, although a wide range of fatty acids were found within its ligand binding pocket, HNF4 appears to exhibit selectivity toward a subset of those found in bacteria.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Future experiments with mammalian tissues are required to determine which fatty acids bind under relevant conditions and whether the capacity of HNF4 to serve as a fatty acid sensor has physiological or pathological ramifications.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	90	The fact that the fatty acids were persistently bound even after a multistep purification indicated that they were tightly associated.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	91	 This was borne out by additional attempts to strip the lipids from the protein, as the fatty acids remained associated after dialysis and gel-filtration chromatography (data not shown).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	92	The serendipitous presence of fatty acids provided an opportunity to analyze how ligands bind to HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The lipid carboxyl group was readily identified next to the side chain of Arg226 and the methylene chain could be built to C12.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Density beyond that point was weak, indicating that the remainder of the chain is either flexible or occupies multiple conformations.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The cavity has an internal volume of 370 A3, calculated by the program Voidoo (18), which is almost entirely occupied by fatty acid.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	96	 While this volume is within the normal range for nuclear receptor LBDs, the elongated, relatively linear shape of the pocket is atypical.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Both oxygens of the fatty acid head group are ion-paired with the guanidinium group of Arg226, and one oxygen forms additional hydrogen bonds with the backbone NH of Gly237 and side chain OH of Ser181 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Residues that line the internal surface of the ligand binding pocket are largely hydrophobic, including those arising from 3 (Ile175, Val178, Cys179, Met182), 5 (Leu219, Leu220, Ala223), 1 (Leu234, Leu236), 2 (Val242), loop 2/7 (Leu249), 7 (Met252, Val255, Ser256, Ile259), and 10 (Met342, Gln345, Ile346, Ile349) (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	99	 In the "closed" conformation 12 of HNF4 does not contact the ligand, in contrast with other nuclear receptors where 12 in the canonical agonist-bound conformation often does contact the agonist.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	100	View larger version (67K):    Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	101	   Ligand binding and the dimer interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	102	 A, stereo diagram of the ligand binding pocket of HNF4, with structural elements colored as described in the legend to Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	103	 B, schematic representation of interactions within the ligand binding pocket of HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Residues that interact in both open and closed forms are labeled black in a gray box, residues that interact in the closed form only are white in a gray box, and interactions found in the open form only are white in a black box.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	105	 C, interactions at the homodimer interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	106	Although HNF4 and RXR are similar in terms of amino acid sequence, their ligand binding specificities are distinct.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	107	 This is due in part to Phe313 in RXR, which points inward and directs bound 9-cis-retinoic acid upward toward 5 (19).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The corresponding residue in HNF4 is Ala223, which, presumably because of the decreased bulk of the side chain, allows the fatty acid ligand to curl downwards toward 7.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	109	 It is thus particularly interesting to note that F313A substitution in RXR leads to constitutive activation, due to the spontaneous binding of an endogenous fatty acid as we have seen for wild-type HNF4 (19).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The fatty acid in the binding pocket of RXR F313A adopts a U shape, and density is interpretable out to the C18 position.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	111	 In contrast, the side chains from residues Met182 and Met342 fill the upper portion of the HNF4 ligand binding pocket to prevent the fatty acid from looping around to form a U, and we don't see density past the C12 position.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	112	 These two methionine residues of HNF4 are unique among nuclear receptors.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	113	Helix 12 Adopts Two Conformations-- The two molecules within each dimer adopt distinct conformations.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In the first, referred to as the open state, 12 is fully extended and contiguous and collinear with 10 (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The second molecule of each homodimer adopts a closed conformation, with 12 situated against the body of the LBD.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The conformation of the "open" state is fixed by crystal packing between two open forms at an axis of symmetry.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	117	 In the closed state, residues Leu360, Leu361, Met364, and Leu365 form a hydrophobic face on 12 that interacts with a corresponding hydrophobic surface on the body of the domain created by residues from 3 (Met182, Lys183, Leu186, Leu187, Leu189, and Val190) and 4 (Leu211, Ala215, Gly216, and Leu219).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Residues Gln362 and Glu363 help to anchor 12 through hydrogen bonds with Lys350 in 10 and Arg212 in 4, respectively.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Since fatty acid ligands similarly occupy the ligand binding pockets of molecules in open and closed conformations, the structural rearrangement does not appear to be required for ligand-mediated activation as has been proposed for other nuclear receptors (17, 20, 21).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	120	 It is possible that to lock the domain in its closed and active state, both ligand and coactivator must be bound, but since our structure lacks coactivator, it does not test this hypothesis.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	121	The Dimer Interface-- As opposed to many nuclear receptors that form heterodimers, HNF4 functions primarily as a homodimer (22).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Consistent with this, the LBD of HNF4 crystallizes as a canonical homodimer with near-perfect 2-fold symmetry about the interface (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	123	 A 1156-A2 surface of each monomer is buried at the dimer interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	124	 A coiled coil interaction between 10 from each molecule dominates the interface, with hydrophobic side chain-side chain interactions (Phe325:Phe325, Leu329:Leu329, Leu330:Ile283, Leu332:Leu330, Pro333:Pro333 and Trp340:Trp340) along its length (Fig.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Intermolecular salt bridges (Glu269:Lys300, Arg303:Glu327, and Arg322:Asp312) and hydrogen bonds (Gln307:Glu327, Glu311:Gly323, and Gln336:Gln336) appear to contribute to the stability of the interface.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	126	MODY1 Mutations-- Of 14 mutations in HNF4 that have been found in patients with the MODY1 form of diabetes (5, 8, 9, 23), three encode substitutions within the LBD (V255M, E276Q, R324H).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The side chain of Val255 (in 7) points into the ligand binding cavity where it participates in ligand recognition.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	128	 While questions have been raised about functional consequences of the V255M substitution (24), the structure suggests that a methionine side chain at this position would partially occlude the ligand binding cavity and potentially alter binding affinity or specificity.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Contact between Val255 and backbone atoms of 10 in the vicinity of Met342 is also predicted to stabilize the protein fold.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Therefore, the V255M substitution might also decrease protein stability and reduce its concentration in cells or ability to homodimerize.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Side chains from the other two MODY1-associated residues, Glu276 (amino terminus of 8) and Arg324 (9/10 loop), form an ionic interaction, and Glu276 forms a second ionic interaction with Arg317 (also in the 9/10 loop).
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Neither of these residues is involved directly in ligand binding, but mutations in them may influence dimerization.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	133	 While the residues themselves are not at the dimer interface, the 9/10 loops of two molecules interact with each other.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Since the residues help tether the 9/10 loops, it is likely that loss of interactions between Glu276 and Arg324 would destabilize dimerization.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	135	Conclusions-- The LBD of HNF4 is structurally similar to the LBDs of other nuclear receptors.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The presence of a fatty acid in its ligand binding pocket is especially noteworthy and should help resolve the controversy surrounding putative ligands for HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	137	 From a structural point of view, the fatty acid appears to be an ideally suited ligand for HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The carboxylic acid headgroup of the fatty acid ion pairs with the guanidinium group of Arg226 of the protein to fix the orientation, while the aliphatic portion of the fatty acid occupies a long narrow pocket that is lined with hydrophobic side chains.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Considering this mode of binding, it is not obvious how more complex ligands might bind HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	140	 It is thus reasonable to presume that fatty acids or related molecules might be the endogenous ligands for HNF4.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The high apparent affinity of recombinant HNF4 for fatty acids suggests a similar situation for the native protein in mammalian cells, providing a mechanism for HNF4 to function as a biosensor for fatty acids within the cell.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The structural features of fatty acid binding to HNF4 provide a useful starting point for identifying potential pharmacophores, but the search may prove all the more challenging due to the kinetics of ligand binding.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Saxena of beamline X12C at the National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, for valuable assistance.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	144	* This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grant R01 DK43123 (to S.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	145	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.2872687.12193589.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.

0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	0	Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 enhances the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1-mediated activation of transcription J.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	1	INSERM Unit 459, Laboratoire de Biologie Cellulaire, Faculte de Medecine H.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Warembourg, 1 Place de Verdun, F 59045 Lille, France.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	3	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Tel: +33 3 20 62 69 51; Fax: +33 3 20 62 68 84; Email: blaine{at}lille.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	5	Received March 2, 2004; Revised April 2, 2004; Accepted April 13, 2004.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	6	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1 (HNF1) and Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 (HNF4) are two liver-enriched transcription factors coexpressed in specific tissues where they play a crucial role through their involvement in a complex cross-regulatory network.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	7	 HNF1 down regulates HNF4-mediated activation of transcription via a direct protein to protein interaction.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Here we show that HNF4 enhances the transcriptional activity of HNF1 in a DNA binding independent manner, thus indicating that it behaves as a HNF1 coactivator.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Using mutations in the ligand binding domain (LBD) of HNF4, we confirmed the involvement of the Activation Function 2 module and demonstrated the requirement of the integrity of the LBD for the interaction with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Moreover, we show that HNF4 cooperates with p300 to achieve the highest HNF1-mediated transcription rates.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Our findings highlight a new way by which HNF4 can regulate gene expression and extend our knowledge of the complexity of the transcriptional network involving HNF4 and HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	12	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1 (HNF1) and Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 (HNF4) are two liver-enriched transcription factors that are also expressed in kidney, intestine and endocrine pancreas (1).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	13	 They are involved in complex cross-regulatory networks that determine the phenotype of hepatocytes and pancreatic ss-cells (1 to 3).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	14	 HNF1 is a homeodomain-containing transcription factor (1) whereas HNF4 belongs to the hormone nuclear receptor superfamily (4).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Both transcription factors are highly conserved during evolution (4,5).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HNF1 and HNF4 directly modulate the expression of a large number of genes (4,6,7).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	17	 They can also modulate transcription indirectly through the above mentioned transcription factor network, including a HNF1-mediated negative regulation of genes activated by HNF4 (8,9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The roles of these transcription factors in vivo have been confirmed by defects linked to the invalidation of their genes in mice (10 to 14).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Further underscoring the importance of these transcription factors, mutations in HNF1 and HNF4 genes have been identified in patients with Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young, MODY3 and MODY1, respectively (15,16).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	20	 MODY1 and MODY3 mutations result in loss of function of these transcription factors (17).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Moreover, it has been reported that expression of a HNF1 dominant negative mutant linked to MODY3 led to an impaired function of pancreatic ss-cells (18).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	22	HNF1 contains two domains involved in DNA binding (an atypical homeodomain and a POU-like domain), an N-terminal dimerization domain and a C-terminal transactivation domain (1).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Several proteins interact with various HNF1 domains and play crucial roles in HNF1 function.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	24	 DcoH (Dimerization Cofactor of HNF1), is a small protein, which binds to the HNF1 dimerization domain and is involved in dimer stabilization (19).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The ability of various HNF1 domains to interact with multiple coactivators allows formation of a platform for recruitment of a transcriptional complex, leading to a strong enhancement of transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	26	 CBP/p300 interacts with both the DNA binding domain and the activation domain of HNF1 while P/CAF, SRC-1 and RAC3 interact with the HNF1 activation domain (20,21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Each of these coactivators can independently increase activation of transcription by HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In addition, they cooperate with each other to further enhance the HNF1-mediated activation of transcription (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	29	 HNF1 can also interact with GATA 4, GATA 5 and Cdx-2 transcription factors (22).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The interactions between HNF1, GATA5 and Cdx-2 lead to a cooperative enhancement of HNF1-mediated activation of transcription (22).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	31	 A synergy between HNF1 and neurogenin 3 was also recently reported (23).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	32	 HNF1 down regulates HNF4-mediated activation of transcription via a direct interaction of these transcription factors (8,9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	33	In this work, we show that HNF4 enhances the transcriptional activity of HNF1, and that the cooperation between both factors can be further enhanced by p300 recruitment.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	34	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   DNA constructs Plasmids pcDNA3 HNF42 and pcDNA3 HNF42-E276Q were previously described (24).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Plasmid pcDNA3 HNF42-D126Y was described by Oxombre et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Plasmids pcDNA3 HNF42-E262A and pGEX2TK HNF42 were described by Eeckhoute et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Plasmids pcDNA3 HNF1 and pcDNA3 HNF1-P291fsinsC, here named HNF1-AD, were generous gifts from Drs M.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Plasmids pcDNA3 HNF42-A223F and pcDNA3 HNF42-AF2mut were obtained by site-directed mutagenesis using the QuickChangeTM kit (Stratagene) to introduce the A223F or the three mutations E363K, L365Q and L366Q, respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Plasmid pM3-VP16 was from Clontech and pcDNA3-RXRss encoding the full-length human RXRss was a generous gift from Dr R.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Plasmid pGEX2TK HNF1 was prepared by a strategy identical to that used for cloning pGEX2TK COUP-TFII (24) by inserting a PCR fragment encompassing the human HNF1 cDNA.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Plasmid pCMVss-NHA p300, PGEX2TK p300(1 to 595), PGEX2TK p300(340 to 528) and PGEX2TK p300(1572 to 2370) were kindly provided by Dr S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Expression plasmids for VP16, Np300-VP16 and Cp300-VP16 were gifts from Dr D.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Plasmid pGL3 ( to 96/+11) LPK was a generous gift from Dr M.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Plasmid pGL3 ( to 341/+183) human HNF1 was a gift from Dr G.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Plasmid (GAL4)x5 TATA Luc was described by Chang and Gralla (29).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Plasmid pGL3 HNF1-TATA-Luc was cloned by inserting a double-stranded oligonucleotide encompassing the HNF1 binding site ( to 56/  to 35) of the SRC promoter into the SacI/NheI sites of the pGL3 basic vector in which the TATA box of the adenovirus major late promoter had been previously cloned as described by Suaud et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	47	 All constructs were verified by DNA sequencing.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	48	GST pull-down assays GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (24) using [35S]methionine-labelled in vitro synthesized HNF1 or HNF4 and bacterially expressed GST-fusion proteins indicated in legends to figures.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	49	Cell culture and transient transfection assays HeLa cells (5.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	50	5 x 104 cells per 24-well dish) were grown and transfected as described by Eeckhoute et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	51	 (30) with plasmid amounts indicated in figure legends.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Luciferase activities were measured using the Bright-Glo Luciferase assay system (Promega).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	53	Western blotting Western blotting performed from whole-cell extracts and using the 455 HNF4 antiserum was carried out as indicated by Eeckhoute et al.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	54	Data analysis Statistical analyses were based on Student s t-test for unpaired data using Prism software.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Statistical significance was set at ***P  <  0.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	56	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Enhancement of HNF1-mediated activation of transcription by HNF4 HNF1 and HNF4 can positively regulate one another s expression in cell types that endogenously express these two factors (3,6).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	57	 To avoid any interference with the endogenous proteins, the effect of HNF4 on the transactivation activity of HNF1 was analysed in HeLa cells.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The experiments were performed on a synthetic promoter consisting of one HNF1 binding site located upstream of the TATA box (HNF1-TATA promoter) and on the natural liver pyruvate kinase promoter ( to 96/+11) LPK containing one HNF1 binding site (site L1, position  to 96/ to 72) but lacking the HNF4 response element (28).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	59	 As expected, both promoters were activated by HNF1 but not by HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Cotransfection of HNF1 and HNF4 resulted in a marked increase in the HNF1-mediated activation of these promoters (2.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	61	4-fold activation of the synthetic and LPK promoters, respectively) (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The enhancement of the HNF1 activity was not impaired when introducing the D126Y mutation in HNF4, which significantly decreases its DNA binding and transactivation activities (25) (data not shown), thus confirming that the synergy between HNF1 and HNF4 does not require the DNA binding-dependent activities of HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	63	 This induction was not an artefact linked to expression of a protein since cotransfection of an unrelated factor failed to enhance the HNF1-mediated activation of transcription (compare the second and last columns in Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	64	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	65	 HNF4 enhanced the HNF1-dependent activation of transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	66	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of the HNF1-TATA promoter (A) or the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter (B), 15 ng of HNF1 and 20 ng of HNF4 or RXRss expression plasmids, as indicated.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	67	 (C) HNF4 was unable to cooperate with the VP16 activation domain.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	68	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of the (GAL4)x5 TATA promoter, 5 ng of GAL4-VP16 and 20 ng of HNF4 expression vectors, as indicated.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In (A), (B) and (C), the total amounts of transfected DNA were equalized with the empty expression plasmids ( to ).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Fold induction refers to the basal activities of promoters (left columns).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	72	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The extent of HNF4-mediated enhancement of HNF1-dependent activation of transcription is indicated (values above bars).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	74	 (D) In vitro interaction between HNF1 and HNF4 analysed by pull-down assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	75	 A schematic representation of the HNF1 and HNF1-AD proteins is presented, AD denotes activation domain.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	76	 [35S]methionine-labelled HNF1 or HNF1-AD was incubated with immobilized GST or GST-HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Inputs correspond to 10% of amounts of labelled proteins used in the assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	79	 (E) Requirement of the activation domains of HNF1 for the cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	80	 HeLa cells were transfected as in (A) with the indicated HNF1 constructs.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left column).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	83	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	84	  To control the possibility that HNF4 does not act as a transcriptional partner of another transcription factor, we analysed the effect of HNF4 on the VP16 activation domain fused to the GAL4 DBD (construct GAL4-VP16).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	85	 HNF4 was unable to enhance the VP16-mediated activation of transcription (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	86	 1C), thus indicating the selectivity of the cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	87	As predicted from the results of Ktistaki and Talianidis (9), we observed that full-length HNF1 and HNF4 physically interact (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Interestingly, pull-down experiments also showed that HNF1 lacking its activation domain (HNF1-AD) efficiently interacted with HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	89	 This result indicates that the sequence 1 to 291 of HNF1, containing the dimerization and DNA binding domains, is able to interact with HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	90	 This prompted us to investigate whether coexpression of HNF4 and HNF1-AD could activate the HNF1-TATA promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Despite their efficient interaction, HNF1-AD and HNF4 were unable to activate transcription (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	92	 1E), thus indicating that cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4 requires the HNF1 activation domain.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	93	AF2 is not the only sequence within the HNF4 LBD required for interaction and cooperation with HNF1 The repressive action of HNF1 on HNF4 was unambiguously shown to require the HNF4 LBD (9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	94	 However, using truncated fragments of HNF4, Ktistaki and Talianidis mapped the sequence involved in the interaction with HNF1 between residues 337 and 368, leading to the conclusion that the HNF4 AF2 activation function is necessary and sufficient for interaction with HNF1 (9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In fact, this sequence does not contain solely the AF2 (sequence 358 to 366 corresponding to helix 12 of the LBD), but also a fragment forming part of the large helix termed H10 to H11, according to conventional nomenclature (31).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Indeed, H10 and H11 are contiguous in HNF4 and form a helix that plays a key role in HNF4 function (31).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Furthermore, the integrity of this helix is crucial for protein conformation (32).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	98	 These recent findings begged a re-evaluation of the HNF4 sequence involved in interaction with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Using full-length HNF4, we analysed the effects of point mutations located in the HNF4 LBD (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	100	 2A) on the interaction and cooperation with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The E262A mutation was shown to affect HNF4 dimerization (26).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The E276Q mutation does not alter the intrinsic HNF4 transcriptional activity but impairs recruitment of HNF4 transcriptional partners (24,33).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Owing to the bulky side chain of phenylalanine, the A223F mutation was hypothesized to affect occupancy of the ligand binding pocket by fatty acids that act as structural cofactors rather than as conventional ligands (31).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Accord ingly, A223F mutation mildly impaired HNF4 transcriptional activity and interaction with coactivators (data not shown).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	105	 In the AF2 module, the acidic group of the amino acid residue side chain at position 363 and the hydrophobic nature of the amino acid residue side chain at position 365 are strictly conserved and play a key role in nuclear receptor function (34).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Residue L366 is also important since the L366Q mutation alters HNF4 transcriptional activity (35).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Pull-down assays showed that introducing three mutations E363K, L365Q and L366Q in the AF2 (HNF4-AF2mut construct) altered interaction between HNF4 and HNF1 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Note however that the decrease in interaction was mild.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	109	 This result confirms the involvement of the AF2 in the interaction between HNF1 and HNF4 but indicates that this module is not the unique sequence required for interaction between these proteins.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Interaction with HNF1 was also significantly decreased by the A223F and E276Q mutations while mutation E262A had no effect (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Consistent with data from pull-down assays, the HNF4-mediated enhancement of HNF1-dependent transcriptional activation of the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter was not impaired by the E262A mutation but was significantly decreased with the mutants A223F, E276Q and HNF4-AF2mut (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	112	 We controlled so that mutant and wild-type HNF4 were expressed at a similar level in transfected cells as shown in Figure 2D for mutants A223F and HNF4-AF2mut and in (24,26) for the mutant E276Q and E262A, respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	113	 It appears therefore that the interaction and cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1 depend on both the AF2 module (helix 12) and the integrity of the HNF4 LBD.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (23K):    Figure 2.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The AF2 is not the only sequence within the HNF4 LBD required for interaction and cooperation with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	116	 (A) Positions of mutations used in this study.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	117	 A scheme of HNF4 structure with the various domains is given: DBD, DNA binding domain; LBD, ligand binding domain; AF2, activation function 2 module.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	118	 (B) Effects of HNF4 mutations on the physical interaction with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	119	 [35S]methionine-labelled wild-type or mutated HNF4 were incubated with immobilized GST-HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Values under photographs indicate binding of HNF4 mutants relative to that of wild-type HNF4 from three independent experiments.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Inputs, corresponding to 5% of amounts of labelled proteins used in the assays, were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	123	 (C) Effects of HNF4 mutations on the cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1 on the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	124	 HeLa cells were transfected as in Figure 1B.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left column).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	127	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Statistical significance of differences with values obtained with wild-type HNF42 is indicated by stars (P  <  0.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	129	 (D) Western blotting of wild-type (WT), A223F and AF2mut HNF4 expressed in HeLa cells using the 455 HNF4 antiserum (43).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The star denotes a non-specific band obtained from HeLa cells transfected with the empty vector ( to ).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The number on the left indicates the molecular mass of a marker size in kDa.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	132	  HNF4 cooperates with the coactivator p300 to enhance HNF1 transcriptional activity Because CBP/p300 are key coactivators of HNF1, we hypothesized that cooperation between HNF4 and HNF1 could involve p300.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In the absence of HNF1, the coactivator p300 alone or coexpressed with HNF4 was unable to activate the HNF1-TATA promoter (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	134	 On this promoter, p300 slightly enhanced HNF1 transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Note that this moderate increase is due at least in part to the low ratio of p300/HNF1 expression vectors used in our experiments (3:1) compared to that used in other studies performed on other promoters [e.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	136	 We have verified that by using a higher ratio, we could obtain a stronger enhancement of HNF1 activity by p300 alone (data not shown).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Interestingly, in the presence of HNF4, p300 synergistically enhanced HNF1-mediated activation of transcription: the activity of the promoter was increased 18.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	138	7-fold higher than the additive value for the induction of HNF1 activity by p300 and HNF4 alone (1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The marked p300-mediated enhancement of cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4 could also be observed on the ( to 96/+11) LPK promoter (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	140	 On both promoters, the enhanced cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4 was significantly impaired by mutations in the HNF4 AF2 module (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	141	 These results strongly argue for the involvement of HNF4 in the p300-mediated activation of these promoters despite the absence of HNF4 response element in their sequences.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The result obtained with the HNF4-AF2mut led us to investigate whether mutations in AF2 affect p300 binding.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Pull-down experiments clearly showed a much weaker interaction of p300 with HNF4-AF2mut than with wild-type HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This result is in line with our previous observation that deletion of the AF2 resulted in a decrease in interaction (about 70%) between HNF4 and p300 (33).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Therefore, we cannot exclude that the impaired cooperativity of HNF4-AF2mut was also due to reduced p300 recruitment.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Because it has been documented that HNF4 and CBP/p300 form a transcriptionally active complex (36), we verified whether in our experimental conditions this complex was sufficient to achieve the strong cooperation.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This question was addressed by the use of human HNF1 promoter containing a HNF4 response element but lacking a HNF1 binding site.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Using the same p300/HNF4 expression vector amounts used in Figure 3A and B, cotransfection of p300 failed to strongly enhance the HNF4-mediated activation of transcription (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	149	 It appears therefore that the strong activation of transcription observed in Figure 3A and B requires a ternary complex including HNF1, HNF4 and p300.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	150	View larger version (16K):    Figure 3.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Involvement of p300 in the cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The cooperation was analysed on the HNF1-TATA and ( to 96/+11) LPK promoters, (A) and (B), respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	153	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of promoter plasmids, 10 ng of HNF1, 15 ng of HNF4 or HNF4-AF2mut and 30 ng of p300 expression plasmids, as indicated.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left column).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Values above bars indicate the enhancement of HNF1- mediated activation of transcription by HNF4 or p300 alone or in cooperation.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	157	 of three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	158	 (C) Effect of the mutations in the AF2 of HNF4 on its interaction with p300 analysed by pull-down assay.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	159	 [35S]Methionine-labelled HNF4 or HNF4-AF2mut were incubated with immobilized GST-p300(340 to 528).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	161	 (D) HeLa cells were transiently transfected with expression vector amounts indicated in (A) and 250 ng of the human HNF1 promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Fold induction, calculated from three experiments performed in triplicate refers to the basal activity of the promoter.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	163	  With the aim to investigate the mechanism underlying the p300-mediated enhancement of the cooperation between HNF1 and HNF4, we surveyed the p300 domains involved in interactions with these transcription factors.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Using a double hybrid approach, it was previously shown that the sequences 180 to 662 and 1818 to 2079 of p300 interact with the HNF1 transactivation domain (20).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Using GST pull-down assays, we mapped more precisely the amino-terminal sequence of p300 involved in interaction with full-length HNF1 between residues 340 and 528 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	166	 We also confirmed that full-length HNF1 interacts with the carboxy-terminal region of p300 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	167	 We have previously shown the ability of HNF4 to interact with the amino-terminal domain of p300 (33).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	168	 HNF4 also interacted with the p300 carboxy-terminal region as shown in Figure 4C.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The presence of multiple interaction surfaces between these proteins led us to analyse the effect of HNF4 on the recruitment of the amino- and carboxy-terminal regions of p300 to HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The strategy consisted of determining whether HNF4 affects the cooperation between HNF1 and the amino- or carboxy-terminal fragments of p300 fused to the VP16 activation domain named Np300-VP16 and Cp300-VP16, respectively (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Expression of the VP16 activation domain affected neither the basal activity of the promoter nor its activity in the presence of expression vectors for HNF1 alone or together with HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Expression of Np300-VP16 failed to affect the basal activity of the promoter and the HNF1-mediated activation of this promoter (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Similar results were obtained with expression of Cp300-VP16 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Conversely, in the presence of both HNF1 and HNF4, Np300-VP16 and Cp300-VP16 markedly enhanced the promoter activity (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	175	 These results indicate that, in a cellular context, p300 recruitment by the HNF1 to HNF4 complex can be mediated through both its amino- and carboxy-terminal regions and reinforce data obtained in Figure 3 suggesting that HNF4 improves p300 recruitment to a promoter containing a HNF1 binding site (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	176	View larger version (25K):    Figure 4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	177	 HNF4 enhanced the cooperation between HNF1 and p300 through interactions with both the amino- and carboxy-terminal sequences of the coactivator.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	178	 (A) Schematic representation of p300 fragments fused to either GST or the VP16 activation domain used in interaction studies with HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	179	 (B) Interaction of HNF1 with the amino-terminal domain of p300 analysed by pull-down assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	180	 [35S]Methionine-labelled HNF1 was incubated with immobilized GST, GST-p300(1 to 595) or GST-p300(340 to 528).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	181	 (C) Interaction of HNF1 and HNF4 with the carboxy-terminal domain of p300 analysed by pull-down assays.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	182	 [35S]Methionine-labelled HNF1 or HNF4 were incubated with immobilized GST or GST-p300(1572 to 2370).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In (B) and (C), bound proteins were analysed by SDS to PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	184	 (D) HNF4 potentiates enhancement of HNF1 activity by Np300- and Cp300-VP16.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	185	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of HNF1-TATA promoter, 10 ng of HNF1, 15 ng of HNF4 and 60 ng of VP16 or its empty vector (left), VP16 or Np300-VP16 (middle) and VP16 or Cp300-VP16 (right) expression plasmids.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In each case, the total amount of transfected DNA was kept constant using empty pcDNA3.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Fold induction refers to the basal activity of the promoter (left columns).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	189	 of at least three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	190	 (E) Mechanisms by which HNF4 could enhance HNF1 transcriptional activity.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The amino- and/or carboxy-terminal domains of p300 can be involved in p300-mediated activation of transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	192	 HNF4 could enhance p300 recruitment through direct binding to these p300 fragments and/or through an indirect effect on the HNF1 to p300 interactions.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	193	 HNF4 could also help recruitment of other coactivators to the transcriptional complex.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	194	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   It has been previously shown that HNF1 acts as a repressor of HNF4-mediated activation of transcription (8,9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	195	 In this study, we show that HNF4 can serve as a coactivator for HNF1 since HNF4 is able to enhance HNF1 activity in a DNA-binding independent manner.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A synergy between HNF1 and HNF4 can be inferred from data obtained in undifferentiated Caco-2 cells on a promoter containing binding sites for these two HNFs.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Since mutation of the HNF4 binding site did not affect this synergy, the authors suggested that this effect probably did not involve HNF4 DNA binding (37).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In light of our results, these data can now most probably be explained by the ability of HNF4 to directly act as a HNF1 coactivator.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Analysis of the physiological role of this HNF4 coactivator function in cell types that endogenously express HNF1 and HNF4 cannot be realized by conventional targeting of HNF4 expression since HNF4 also positively regulates HNF1 expression.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Therefore, this concern will first require development of an experimental model that permits to distinguish between HNF4 effects linked to regulation of HNF1 expression on one hand and to regulation of HNF1 transcriptional activity on the other hand (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	201	View larger version (11K):    Figure 5.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Cross-talk between HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The cross-talk involves both expression activation, through binding to promoters (solid lines), and modulation of the transcriptional potential, through protein to protein interactions (dotted lines), of the other HNF transcription factor.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	204	  Interplays between two transcription factors in both activation and repression of transcription have already been documented.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Indeed, cross-talk between HNF6 and HNF3ss, two other liver-enriched transcription factors, also results in opposite effects on the activities of these proteins (38).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	206	Despite their efficient interaction, HNF4 and HNF1 lacking its activation function (HNF1-AD) were unable to cooperate.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Such a behaviour is reminiscent of that of CBP and P/CAF with HNF1 (1 to 280) (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Only the simultaneous overexpression of CBP and P/CAF together with that of the truncated HNF1 could activate transcription (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	209	 This points to a critical role for the HNF1 activation domain, which could be the recruitment of other required coactivators and/or stabilization of the transcriptional complex recruited by HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	210	Our results indicate that the HNF4 AF2 is involved in interaction with HNF1, but also that other regions of the HNF4 LBD are required for full interaction between these proteins.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Ktistaki and Talianidis previously stated that the HNF4 AF2 is sufficient for interaction with HNF1 (9).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The discrepancy between their conclusion and our results is likely explained by the fact that these authors used deletion of a fragment (residues 337 to 368), which includes not only the AF2 but also part of the large helix H10 to H11, the integrity of which has meanwhile been shown to be crucial for the protein conformation (32).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	213	 We observed that two-point mutations in the HNF4 LBD, A223F and E276Q, significantly decreased interaction and cooperation with HNF1 thus demonstrating that the integrity of the HNF4 LBD is required for the synergy with HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	214	The similarity of phenotypes exhibited by diabetic patients carrying MODY1 and MODY3 mutations has been ascribed to the mutual control of transcription of HNF1 and HNF4.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The ability of HNF4 to serve as an HNF1 coactivator could provide an additional explanation to the closely related phenotypes of these MODY forms of diabetes.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Impairment of interaction and of enhancement of HNF1 transcriptional activity by the HNF4 E276Q mutation may be physiologically relevant since this mutation is correlated with MODY1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Unfortunately, the low transfection efficiency and the presence of large amounts of endogenous HNF4 in pancreatic ss-cells prevented us from analysing the effects of this mutation on the synergy between HNF4 and HNF1 in these cells.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	218	Our results support a model that involves the combined action of HNF4 and the coactivator p300 to achieve the highest rate of transcription mediated by HNF1.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Our results also strongly suggest that HNF4 improves p300 recruitment.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The synergy between HNF4 and p300 may be mediated in two ways.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The first involves simultaneous interactions of HNF4 and p300 with HNF1 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In this case, HNF4 could indirectly improve HNF1 to p300 interaction through induction of a HNF1 conformational change.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Such a mechanism is reminiscent of that of the CBP-mediated improvement of the interaction between HNF1 and P/CAF (21).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Similarly, upon docking to PPAR, PGC-1 undergoes a conformational change that permits binding of SRC-1 and p300 (39).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The second involves docking of p300 by HNF4, which is bound to HNF1 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	226	 The recruitment of p300 to the HNF1 to HNF4 complex could be mediated by its amino- and/or carboxy-terminal regions, which contain the C/H1 and C/H3 domains, respectively.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	227	 These domains are known to be involved in protein to protein interactions (40).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The presence of multiple interaction surfaces in HNF1, HNF4 and p300 most probably facilitates formation of a ternary complex formed with these proteins (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The remaining synergy between HNF1 and HNF4 after mutations in the HNF4 AF2 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	230	 3) may be accounted for by the ability of p300 to interact and activate the HNF4 AF1 (33,41) and by the fact that the two above mentioned mechanisms may not be mutually exclusive.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	231	In conclusion, our results highlight a new way by which HNF4 can regulate gene expression.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	232	 HNF4 not only directly binds to promoters but also, through interaction with other transcription factors already bound to DNA, can facilitate coactivator recruitment to further enhance transcription.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Recently, it has been shown that HNF4 also serves as coactivator for Sterol Regulatory Element-Binding protein-2 (42).
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Furthermore, our results yield insights into a higher complexity of the transcriptional network and on the primordial relationship between HNF1 and HNF4 (Fig.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In the regulatory loop between HNF1 and HNF4, HNF4 can activate both HNF1 expression and transcriptional activity.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In contrast to these additive processes, the negative effect of HNF1 on HNF4 transcriptional activity can attenuate the HNF1-mediated activation of expression.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	237	 These regulatory feedback mechanisms will have to be taken into account considering that HNF1 and HNF4 are involved in a large diversity of pathways controlling function of multiple organs, notably liver and endocrine pancreas.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Bell are acknowledged for generous gifts of plasmids.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Sacchetti for helpful discussions and I.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Briche for skillful technical assistance.
