0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	286	 (2002) Developmentally regulated N-terminal variants of the nuclear receptor HNF4alpha mediate multiple interactions through coactivator and corepressor/HDAC complexes.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	287	 (2003) Sterol regulatory element-binding protein-2 interacts with hepatocyte nuclear factor-4 to enhance sterol isomerase gene expression in hepatocytes.
0.4318962.15141028.html.plaintext.txt	288	,Jr (1990) Liver-enriched transcription factor HNF-4 is a novel member of the steroid hormone receptor superfamily.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	0	Twin Hydroxymethyluracil-A Base Pair Steps Define the Binding Site for the DNA-bending Protein TF1*.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, February 12, 1997).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Figueiredo  , Aldo Galeone  , Luciano Mayol   and E.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the  Department of Biology and Center for Molecular Genetics, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California 92093-0634 and   Dipartimento di Chimica delle Sostanze Naturali, Universita degli Studi di Napoli Federico II, Via Domenico Montesano, 49 80131 Napoli, Italy ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION FOOTNOTES REFERENCES.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	4	The DNA-bending protein TF1 is the Bacillus subtilis bacteriophage SPO1-encoded homolog of the bacterial HU proteins and the Escherichia coli integration host factor.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We recently proposed that TF1, which binds with high affinity (Kd was ~3 nM) to preferred sites within the hydroxymethyluracil (hmU)-containing phage genome, identifies its binding sites based on sequence-dependent DNA flexibility.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Here, we show that two hmU-A base pair steps coinciding with two previously proposed sites of DNA distortion are critical for complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The affinity of TF1 is reduced 10-fold when both of these hmU-A base pair steps are replaced with A-hmU, G-C, or C-G steps; only modest changes in affinity result when substitutions are made at other base pairs of the TF1 binding site.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Replacement of all hmU residues with thymine decreases the affinity of TF1 greatly; remarkably, the high affinity is restored when the two hmU-A base pair steps corresponding to previously suggested sites of distortion are reintroduced into otherwise T-containing DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	9	 T-DNA constructs with 3-base bulges spaced apart by 9 base pairs of duplex also generate nM affinity of TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We suggest that twin hmU-A base pair steps located at the proposed sites of distortion are key to target site selection by TF1 and that recognition is based largely, if not entirely, on sequence-dependent DNA flexibility.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	11	The genome of the Bacillus subtilis bacteriophage SPO1 contains 5-hydroxymethyluracil (hmU)1 in place of thymine, and discrimination between T- and hmU-containing DNA is important during phage multiplication (1, 2).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	12	 For one phage-encoded protein, the DNA-binding and -bending protein TF1, this discrimination is essentially absolute: the high affinity of TF1 (Kd order of magnitude nM) for preferred sites within the hmU-containing phage genome is greatly reduced for the corresponding T-containing DNA (3, 4).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We recently showed that the affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA is matched in T-containing DNA constructs that contain sets of two consecutive mismatches separated by 9 bp of duplex, indicating that hmU-content and appropriately placed flexible loops contribute similarly to complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	14	 We proposed, therefore, that DNA in a complex with TF1 is distorted at two sites that are separated by 9 bp of duplex DNA, sites corresponding to two hmU-A base pair steps, and that TF1 identifies its target sites through recognition of sequence-dependent DNA flexibility (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Here we examine the requirement for hmU residues across a 37-mer DNA duplex representing a preferred binding site within the phage genome (4) and specifically evaluate sequence requirements at the two inferred sites of DNA distortion.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	16	TF1 was overexpressed in Escherichia coli DL39 (6) and purified as described (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Oligonucleotides with hmU content were synthesized as described (7) and purified by high pressure liquid chromatography.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	18	 T-containing oligonucleotides were purchased and purified by denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The top strand (shared among bulge constructs) was 32P-labeled at the 5-end with T4 polynucleotide kinase.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Complementary oligonucleotides were mixed at equimolar concentrations, heated to 90  degrees C, and slowly cooled to 4  degrees C over several hours to form duplex DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	21	Electrophoretic mobility shift experiments were carried out as described (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Experiments with perfect duplex hmU- or hybrid T/hmU-DNA were done at room temperature unless noted otherwise.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Experiments with bulge constructs were performed at 4  degrees C to prevent dissociation of duplexes.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	24	 After electrophoresis, gels were dried and protein-DNA complexes were quantified using phosphorimaging.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	25	 DNA migrating between bands corresponding to free and complexed DNA was considered as free DNA (5) in calculating equilibrium dissociation constants (Kd) (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Values of Kd are reported as the average of at least three experiments  plus or minus  S.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	27	 (for closely related DNA constructs yielding suboptimal complex formation, triplicate determinations were deemed unnecessary).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	28	The sequence of a 37-mer DNA construct corresponding to a preferred binding site within the phage SPO1 genome (4) is shown in Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Because of the ability of TF1 to form nested complexes on longer DNA fragments, the length of the DNA constructs was chosen to accommodate only one TF1 dimer (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The affinity of TF1 for the 37-mer hmU-containing duplex (Kd was ~3 nM; Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	31	 1A) was reduced 10-fold upon replacement of the two hmU-A base pair steps corresponding to the potential sites of distortion with A-hmU, G-C, or C-G steps (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Altering the sequence at the center of the binding site (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	33	 1 and 2, panels C) or on the flanks, distal to the proposed sites of bending (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	34	 1 and 2, panels D), did not significantly affect complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The observed sequence specificity at proposed sites of distortion is consistent with a direct participation of hmU-A base pair steps in complex formation and DNA bending.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Sequences of 37-mer oligonucleotides.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A, the sequence of the top strand corresponding to a preferred binding site within the SPO1 genome is shown, with hmU-A base pair steps that correspond to proposed sites of distortion in boldface.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	38	 B, a 10-fold reduction in affinity is associated with replacement of target hmU-A steps.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	39	 C and D, sequences of oligonucleotides with substitutions between (C) or distal to (D) hmU-A base pair steps (substitutions are underlined).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Substitutions on the flanks target additional hmU-A base pair steps; additional substitutions were required to prevent introduction of new hmU-A steps.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Top strands shown were annealed to complementary hmU-containing bottom strands to generate perfect duplexes.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Dissociation constants, Kd nM, are shown at the right.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	43	 [View Larger Version of this Image (36K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Electrophoretic analysis of hmU-DNA titrated with TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The affinity of TF1 for the 37-mer duplex corresponding to a preferred binding site (panel A) is reduced upon replacement of hmU-A base pair steps with A-hmU (panel B).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Altering the central base pairs (GC-rich; panel C) or the sequence distal to proposed sites of DNA distortion (wild-type (wt) + GC; panel D) has little effect on complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Protein concentrations indicated below panel D are identical for all panels.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	48	 [View Larger Version of this Image (109K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	49	To evaluate the contribution of hmU residues to the DNA binding affinity of TF1, DNA constructs were designed in which central hmU-containing blocks of 13 or 11 bp, encompassing the proposed sites of DNA distortion (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	50	 3, constructs Th2 and Th3), or of 9 or 7 bp, excluding hmU-A steps that are candidate sites of specific distortion (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	51	 3, constructs Th4 and Th5), were embedded in T-containing surrounding sequence.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Constructs in which the proposed sites of distortion lie within the hmU-containing blocks (Th2 and Th3) yielded Kd = 5-6 nM compared with 3 nM for all-hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	53	 A more than 5-fold reduction in affinity was observed for DNA with shorter hmU-containing blocks (Th4 and Th5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	54	 A DNA duplex in which a central 13-bp T-containing block is flanked by hmU-containing sequence (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	55	 3, construct Th1) bound TF1 with 10-fold lower affinity relative to all-hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	56	 DNA duplexes with T or hmU content.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Blocks of hmU content are underlined.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	58	 DNA constructs are named at the left, and dissociation constants, Kd nM, are shown at the right.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The symbol  denotes complex dissociation during electrophoresis that is too rapid to allow a reliable determination.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	60	 [View Larger Version of this Image (63K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	61	For DNA with 2 4-bp hmU-containing blocks, a significantly lower affinity was observed for DNA constructs with T-A base pair steps at the proposed sites of bending (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	62	 3, constructs Th8 and Th9) than for otherwise identical constructs with hmU-A base pair steps (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	63	 3, constructs Th6 and Th7; Kd was ~5 nM).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Remarkably, TF1 was found to have essentially undiminished affinity for DNA in which the two hmU-A base pair steps are completely surrounded by T-containing DNA (Kd = 4 nM; Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	65	 We note also that the affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA and for the Th7/Th6 construct was the same at room temperature and at 4  degrees C (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	66	 A 7-10-fold reduction in affinity was observed if only one strand contained the requisite hmU-A sequence (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	67	 3, constructs Th7/T and T/Th6, and Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Our interpretation of these observations is that hmU content affords an increased flexibility that is recognized by TF1 and that hmU-A base pair steps symmetrically disposed about the center of the binding site are targets for specific distortion in the protein-DNA complex.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Twin hmU-A base pair steps corresponding to presumptive sites of distortion are required for complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA (A) is reproduced by a DNA construct in which target hmU-A base pair steps are surrounded by T-DNA (Th7/6 in B).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Constructs in which only one strand contains the hmU-A sequence have 10-fold lower affinity (Th7/T in C).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	72	 [View Larger Version of this Image (113K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The nM affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA is reproduced by T-DNA with base bulges separated by 9 bp of duplex.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The affinity of TF1 for perfect duplex hmU-DNA is reproduced by T-DNA with a set of 4-nt loops (A).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	75	 1- or 2-base bulges (lowercase c, underlined) in combination with a mismatch reproduce the nM affinity for TF1 (B), as do 2- or 3-base bulges (C).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	76	 , the same as in the legend to Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	77	 All experiments were carried out at 4  degrees C.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	78	 [View Larger Version of this Image (33K GIF file)].
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	79	The high affinity of TF1 for hmU-DNA (Kd was ~3 nM) was reproduced in T-DNA that contains two appropriately positioned flexible sites generated by sets of tandem mismatches (Ref.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Improved complex formation relative to perfect duplex T-DNA would also be expected for T-DNA constructs in which the energetic cost of bending is lessened through the incorporation of bulge-loops, i.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	81	 with nucleotides that are formally unopposed on the complementary strand (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Constructs with sets of 1- or 2-nt bulges combined with one mismatched base pair positioned 9 bp apart indeed generated high affinity for TF1 (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	83	 5B); note that sets of 2-nt loops (one mismatch) generated suboptimal binding compared with sets of 4-nt loops (two consecutive mismatches).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The high affinity of TF1 was fully restored for DNA constructs with sets of 2- or 3-nt bulges with suboptimal binding for DNA with a pair of 1-nt bulges (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Replacing the T-containing top strand of bulge constructs with the corresponding hmU-containing strand did not affect complex formation (data not shown).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Bulge-loops are considered to generate directed kinks in the helix axis (8, 9).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Consistent with the presence of such kinks, we observed a reduction in electrophoretic mobility of bulged DNA constructs, the magnitude of which depended on the size of the bulge (data not shown).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The mobility of protein-DNA complexes was similar irrespective of the nature of the DNA construct.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	89	The TF1 double mutant protein TF1 (E15G/T32I) binds DNA with ~40-fold higher affinity than does wild-type TF1 (10) due to interactions outside the central 25-bp region of the binding site (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The presence of bulge-loops in T-DNA affected the affinity of TF1 (E15G/T32I) and wild-type TF1 in similar ways, consistent with unaltered interactions for the mutant protein with a central DNA segment that includes proposed sites of bending (data not shown).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	91	The structure of TF1 reveals the presence of flexible -ribbon arms that are directly involved in DNA binding (11),2 as does the structure of the closely related HU protein (12, 13) and the recently reported structure of integration host factor (IHF) in a complex with DNA (14).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	92	 At the tip of the DNA-binding arms, TF1 contains a Phe residue at position 61 in place of the Arg found in all other members of this protein family.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	93	 TF1(F61R) has reduced preference for hmU-DNA over T-DNA (15) but was seen to retain high affinity for hmU-DNA (Kd = 9.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Substituting Phe-61 with Tyr had little effect on affinity (Kd = 6.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Replacing Phe-61 with a polar, uncharged residue (Ser or Gln) significantly reduces both DNA binding affinity and site-selectivity (15).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Notably, the affinity for hmU-DNA of both TF1(F61S) (Kd = 236  plus or minus  19 nM) and TF1(F61Q) (Kd = 685  plus or minus  48 nM) increased more than 5-fold for T-DNA with 2 3-base bulges (Kd = 36  plus or minus  2 and 90  plus or minus  7 nM, respectively; Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	97	 This is in contrast to wild-type TF1 that bound hmU-DNA and bulge-DNA constructs (1+2, 1+3, 0+2, and 0+3) with approximately the same affinity (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	98	 T-DNA with sets of 4-nt loops, which also reproduces the affinity of wild-type TF1 for hmU-DNA (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	99	 5), did not significantly enhance complex formation by TF1(F61S) (Kd was ~200 nM) or TF1(F61Q) (Kd was ~570 nM) beyond that observed with hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Apparently hmU content and flexible loops in T-DNA contribute similarly to complex formation for these TF1 mutant proteins, which are deficient in binding and bending of hmU-DNA (15, 16), whereas DNA with a static kink generates an increase in affinity.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	101	Our previous conjecture that TF1 principally identifies its preferred binding sites through recognition of sequence-dependent DNA flexure was based on an analysis of affinities for DNA constructs with sets of 4-nt loops (5).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	102	 For this mode of target site selection, the prediction would be for the sequence at the sites of distortion to significantly affect complex formation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	103	 This prediction appears to be borne out both in terms of preferred base pair steps in the context of hmU-DNA (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	104	 1 and 2) but particularly by the significant effect of hmU-A base pair steps in a T-containing surrounding sequence (Figs.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	105	 We propose that hmU content confers a site-specific flexibility on the DNA duplex that is recognized by TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	106	 hmU-A base pair steps that are situated at presumptive sites of DNA bending make the principal contributions to complex formation with TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	107	 hmU residues at other positions that generate measurable, yet suboptimal affinities, presumably do so either due to longer range effects on DNA flexure or because of alternative placement of TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	108	 An effect of hmU residues on the deformability of the double helix is corroborated by the increased affinity observed for other members of the family of type II DNA-binding proteins, HU and IHF, and for the unrelated eukaryotic protein, HMG1 (17).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Changes in complex formation by both major and minor groove-binding proteins and antibiotics induced by introduction of other modified bases have also been interpreted in terms of effects on DNA deformability by exocyclic substituents (18-20).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	110	Inferences about increased flexure of DNA containing modified bases stress the need for analysis of the associated structures and conformational energetics.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Structural nuclear magnetic resonance analysis of an A-hmU base pair flanked by G-C base pairs indicates no significant deviations from classical B-form DNA (21), although nearest neighbors do influence the structure (22).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	112	 13C or 31P nuclear magnetic resonance relaxation experiments may provide the required insights into the dynamics of duplex DNA the size of a protein binding site, features that are only poorly extractable from measurements using techniques such as fluorescence polarization and DNA cyclization (23, 24).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The suggested locations of DNA bends in the TF1 DNA complex coincide with two hmU-A base pair steps.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Considering the unique properties of the T-A step in terms of diversity of structure (25, 26), it would be of particular interest to determine whether the inherent deformability of the T-A step is accentuated in hmU-A.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	115	For a protein that bends DNA through a large angle (16), it is not surprising to find a greater affinity for DNA whose axis is kinked by unpaired bases (Fig.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Indeed, similar results have been previously reported for HU (27).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	117	 We note that T-DNA constructs with pairs of suitably placed 4-nt loops or 3-nt bulge-loops generate the same affinity for wild-type TF1.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	118	 However, different structures and energetics of deformation are indicated by the significantly higher affinity for bulge constructs of the TF1 mutant proteins TF1(F61S) and TF1(F61Q), which are impaired in DNA binding and bending.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	119	 These observations are consistent with a static kink introduced by bulge-loops compared with a looser more flexible structure imposed by symmetric loops (8, 9, 24, 28); we suggest that pre-bent DNA bulge-loop constructs also permit complex formation with certain TF1 mutant proteins, whereas binding and bending of DNA with sets of 4-nt loops (or hmU content) require a protein-mediated introduction and stabilization of DNA kinks.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	120	Replacement of Phe-61 at the tip of DNA-binding arms with a polar, uncharged residue may render TF1 mutant proteins either incapable of producing specific DNA kinks, a process which would be aided locally by the presence of DNA bulge-loops, or deficient in securing the resulting DNA conformation, demands on which would be lessened in DNA with a predisposed orientation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	121	 If TF1, like IHF, employs a totally conserved Pro residue to intercalate between specific base pairs of the binding site (14), then the deficiency of TF1(F61S) and TF1(F61Q) in DNA binding and bending may reside in their inability to stabilize a severely bent DNA conformation.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Phe-61 contributes to the striking preference of TF1 for hmU-DNA over T-DNA (15).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	123	 TF1(F61R) also has high affinity for hmU-DNA but a reduced preference for hmU-DNA over T-DNA (15).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	124	 In addition, IHF (which has higher affinity for a specific binding site in hmU-DNA compared with T-DNA (17)) relies heavily on indirect readout to recognize its binding sites (14).
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	125	 If TF1 and IHF engage their DNA targets in an isomorphous fashion, the preference for hmU-DNA characteristic of TF1 may not be due to specific interactions between Phe-61 and hmU residues of the TF1 binding site.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Rather, the inability of TF1 to stabilize a T-DNA duplex that is severely kinked through intercalation of Pro residues may be alleviated by the more pliable hmU-DNA.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	127	 On the other hand, the possibility that TF1 does use Phe-61 directly for inducing DNA kinks at two hmU-A base pair steps remains to be established or disproved by direct structure determination.
0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	128	*   This work was supported by grants to the University of California, San Diego, from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences and the University of Naples by the Ministero dell'Universita e della Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica (MURST) and Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche.

0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.23938537.9148920.html.plaintext.txt	160	 7, 343-350 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Bhattacharyya, A.

0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	0	Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 Isoforms Originated from the P1 Promoter Are Expressed in Human Pancreatic ss-Cells and Exhibit Stronger Transcriptional Potentials than P2 Promoter-Driven Isoforms J.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	1	Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale Unit 459 (J.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	2	); and Diabetes Cell Therapy Unit, ERIM 106 Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale (T.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Warembourg, Lille F 59045, France.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	4	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: B.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Laine, Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale Unit 459, Laboratoire de Biologie Cellulaire, Universite H.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Warembourg, 1 Place de Verdun, F 59045 Lille, France.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	7	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   The nuclear receptor hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF) 4 is involved in a transcriptional network and plays an important role in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Mutations in the HNF4 gene are correlated with maturity-onset diabetes of the young 1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	9	 HNF4 isoforms result from both alternative splicing and alternate usage of promoters P1 and P2.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	10	 It has recently been reported that HNF4 transcription is driven almost exclusively by the P2 promoter in pancreatic islets.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	11	 We observed that transcripts from both P1 and P2 promoters were expressed in human pancreatic ss-cells and in the pancreatic ss-cell lines RIN m5F and HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Expression of HNF4 proteins originating from the P1 promoter was confirmed by immunodetection.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Due to the presence of the activation function module AF-1, HNF4 isoforms originating from the P1 promoter exhibit stronger transcriptional activities and recruit coactivators more efficiently than isoforms driven by the P2 promoter.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Conversely, activities of isoforms produced by both promoters were similarly repressed by the corepressor small heterodimer partner.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	15	 These behaviors were observed on the promoter of HNF1 that is required for ss-cell function.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Our results highlight that expression of P1 promoter-driven isoforms is important in the control of pancreatic ss-cell function.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	17	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   HEPATOCYTE NUCLEAR FACTOR (HNF) 4 is an orphan nuclear receptor (nuclear receptor 2A1, NR2A1) that activates the expression of genes involved in the transport and metabolism of many nutrients including lipids and glucose (1, 2).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	18	 HNF4 is required for normal hepatic function (3).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	19	 It also plays an important role in pancreatic ss-cells: HNF4 directly activates the insulin gene promoter (4) and is required for glucose-induced insulin secretion (5).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Mutations in HNF4 gene are correlated with maturity-onset diabetes of the young 1, characterized by an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance, early onset (usually before the age of 25 yr), and impaired glucose-induced insulin secretion due to dysfunction of pancreatic ss-cells (6).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	21	 HNF4 is involved, together with other transcription factors including HNF1, in a complex transcription factor network that is thought to be crucial for the function of pancreatic ss-cells (7, 8, 9).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	22	In mammals, HNF4 is encoded by two different genes: HNF4 and HNF4 (10).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The HNF4 gene potentially encodes nine distinct isoforms.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Their structure and nomenclature are presented in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	25	 HNF4 isoforms result from both alternate promoter usage and alternative splicing.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	26	 1A, promoter P1 initiates transcripts that contain exon 1A (isoforms 1 to 6), whereas promoter P2 initiates transcripts that contain exon 1D (isoforms 7 to 9; Refs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Isoforms 2 and 8 are the alternatively spliced variants of isoforms 1 and 7, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	28	 They contain a 30-bp insert in their 3' sequence (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Compared with these four isoforms, isoforms 3 and 9, which have a completely different 3' sequence, are much less expressed, whereas isoforms 4 to 6 are very poorly expressed or have not yet been identified in vivo (1, 13).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The expression of HNF4 isoforms varies with development, differentiation, and tissue origin (1, 14, 15, 16).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The expression of HNF4 mainly initiates at the P1 promoter in adult liver and kidney (15).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Recently, two different groups documented the expression of transcripts of the P2 promoter in insulinoma INS-1 cells, as well as in mouse and human pancreatic islets, but did not detect transcripts of the P1 promoter, leading to the conclusion that HNF4 transcription is driven almost exclusively by the P2 promoter in the endocrine pancreas (11, 12, 17).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Strongly contrasting with these data, we observed that HNF4 transcripts initiated at the P1 promoter are substantially expressed, alongside P2 promoter transcripts, in human pancreatic ss-cells and in the rodent pancreatic ss-cell lines RIN m5F and HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Only HNF4 isoforms initiated at the P1 promoter contain the activation function module AF-1, which is encoded by exon 1A.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The AF-1 plays a key role in HNF4 transcriptional potential and in the recruitment of coactivators that are essential for HNF4 function (18, 19, 20).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We show that lack of the AF-1 in HNF4 isoforms initiated at the P2 promoter markedly decreases both the transcriptional potential and interaction with several coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Conversely, lack of the AF-1 does not affect the repression of HNF4 activity by small heterodimer partner (SHP).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	38	 This finding highlights the functional consequences of expression of the HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	39	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Expression of HNF4 transcripts in human pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	41	 A, Schematic representation of the HNF4 gene showing promoters P1 and P2 (black boxes) with their respective first exon named 1A and 1D (hatched boxes).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Lines linking exons indicate splicing events; splicing of exon 1A to exon 2 yields isoforms 1 to 3, whereas splicing resulting in insertion of exon 1B (dotted lines) yields isoforms 4 to 6.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Use of exon 1C, which has not been demonstrated, is not presented.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Splicing of exon 1D to exon 2 yields isoforms 7 to 9.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Use of a second donor site at the 3' end of exon 9 yields a 30-bp insert (squares in exon 9) in isoforms 2 and 8.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	46	 B, Schematic representation of mature transcripts of the HNF4 isoforms 1, 2, 7, and 8 showing the 30-bp insert in isoforms 2 and 8.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	47	 For clarity s sake, isoforms 3 to 6 and 9, which are expressed at low levels, are not shown.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Positions of primers used in RT-PCR are indicated.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	49	 C, RT-PCR analysis of HNF4 transcripts containing exon 1D, using primers d and b.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	50	 D, RT-PCR analysis of HNF4 transcripts containing exon 1A, using primers a and b.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	51	 E, Determination of the relative amounts of isoforms 1 and/or 7 vs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	52	 isoforms 2 and/or 8 transcripts, using primers e and f.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	53	 F, RT-PCR analysis of HNF4 transcript.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	54	 G, RT-PCR of the control ss-actin.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	55	 C to G, Lane 1, molecular mass markers (in base pairs); lane 2, human pancreatic islets; lane 3, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells; lane 4, human exocrine pancreas; lane 5, rat insulinoma RIN m5F cells; lane 6, hamster insulinoma HIT-T15 cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	56	 For all RT-PCR analyses, a negative control is shown (lane 7).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	57	 H, Lack of cross-amplification of P2 promoter transcripts by primers a+b (1 and 2, PCR was performed with cloned HNF42 and -8, respectively).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	58	 I, Control of the specificity of amplification of reverse-transcribed RNAs from human pancreatic islets by primers a+b.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	59	 1, RT-PCR was performed as in D; 2, RT-PCR was performed as in D except that the step of reverse transcription was carried out in the absence of Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	60	 RNA from three donors yielded identical results.

0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	63	     Materials and Methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Insulinoma cell lines Cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (Manassas, VA).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	64	 RIN m5F cells of rat origin (ATCC CRL-2058) were grown as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	65	 HIT-T15 cells of hamster origin (ATCC CRL-1777) were grown as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	66	Human pancreas processing Human pancreases (n = 5) were harvested from adult brain-dead donors in accord with French Regulations and with the local Institutional Ethical Committee.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Pancreatic islets were isolated after ductal distension of the pancreas and digestion of the tissue with liberase (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Mannheim, Germany) as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Exocrine fraction was obtained as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	69	Islet enrichment and single ss-cell preparation Pancreatic islet-enriched fractions (purity 90  plus or minus  5%) were obtained from semipurified preparations by "handpicking" the dithizone-stained islets under a binocular microscope.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Single ss-cell suspensions were obtained by gentle pipetting of islets for 4 to 6 min in an enzymatic dissociation buffer containing 3.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	71	6 g/liter papain (Splittix, Bio Media, Boussens, France).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	72	2 vol of the enzyme-inhibiting solution consisting of Splitstop (Bio Media) plus fetal calf serum (3/1 vol/vol, respectively), when about 80% of islet cells appeared as single cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Cell sorting was then achieved as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	74	Semiquantitative RT-PCR Total RNA was prepared using the Macherey Nagel (Duren, Germany) RNA extraction kit according to manufacturer s protocol.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Reverse transcription and PCR were performed as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	76	 21 in conditions that were adjusted to maintain the amplification within the exponential range.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Primers used for HNF4 transcripts are shown in Table 1, and primers for the coactivator peroxisome proliferator activated receptor coactivator (PGC)-1 transcripts have the following sequences: sense, 5'-gtggatgaagacggattgcc-3'; antisense, 5'-ttctagttgtctagagtcttgg-3'.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	78	 PCR products were electrophoresed in 2% agarose gel, and band intensity was analyzed on a Kaiser camera equipped with the Gel Analyst 3.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	79	01 software (both provided by Vasse SARL, Templemars, France).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	80	  Plasmid constructs Plasmid pcDNA3 human HNF42 was described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Plasmid pcDNA3 human HNF42 Y6D/F19D was obtained by site-directed mutagenesis from pcDNA3 human HNF42 F19D (20).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The human HNF48 cDNA was obtained by PCR using human HNF42 cDNA as PCR matrix.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The sense primer encompassed the sequence +1/+49 of exon 1D (11) and a sequence hybridizing to the first 23 nucleotides of exon 2, which is common to both 2 and 8 HNF4 isoforms.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The antisense primer hybridized to sequence 1412 to 1433 of HNF42 cDNA, taking adenosine of the ATG codon of initiation methionine as position 1 (27).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	85	 This cDNA was introduced in the EcoRI and XbaI sites of pcDNA3 to generate the expression plasmid pcDNA3 human HNF48.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Constructs were verified by DNA sequencing.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The human HNF1 promoter cloned in pGL3 was a gift from Dr.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Bell (Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Chicago, IL).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Plasmids expressing the fusion proteins glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-PGC-1 (36 to 797), GST-p300 (340 to 528), GST-glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein (GRIP)-1(1122 to 1462), and GST-full-length SHP were gifts from Drs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Spiegelman (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA), Grossman (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute), Stallcup (University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA), and Gustafsson (Karolinska Institute, Huddinge, Sweden), respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The expression plasmids pCMVss-NHA p300, its pCMVss control vector, and pSG5 SHP were gifts from Drs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Grossman and Gustafsson, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	93	EMSAs When used for control of specificity, HNF42 and -8 were synthesized in vitro as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	94	 EMSAs were performed as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	95	 28 using the 32P-labeled HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter and either in vitro-synthesized proteins or nuclear extracts of HIT-T15 and HepG2 cells prepared as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Supershifts were performed by incubating proteins with either the 455 antiserum (1) or the H4/55 monoclonal antibody (15) before addition of the labeled probe.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	97	Transient transfections RIN m5F cells were transiently transfected with the LipofectAmine reagent (3  microl/ microg of DNA) according to Invitrogen (SARL, Cergy Pontoise, France) recommendations.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	98	 HIT-T15 and HeLa cells were transiently transfected with the polyethylenimine reagent (4  microl/ microg of DNA) according to Euromedex (Souffelweyersheim, France) recommendations.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Normalization for differences in transfection efficiencies was performed as previously described using either the Renilla luciferase reporter plasmid in RIN m5F and HeLa cells (29) or the ss-galactosidase reporter plasmid in HIT-T15 cells (30).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Luciferase assays were performed with the Dual Luciferase kit (Promega Corp.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	101	, Madison, WI) for RIN m5F and HeLa cells and as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Statistical analysis was performed using Student s t test for unpaired data using the Prism software (Intuitive Software for Science, San Diego, CA).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	103	Western blot analysis Western assays were performed as described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	104	 26 and revealed with the 455 antiserum (1).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	105	In vitro protein-protein interaction assays GST pull-down assays were performed as described previously (26) using 35S-methionine-labeled in vitro-synthesized HNF4 and bacterially expressed GST fusion proteins.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Interactions were quantified using the ImageQuant software on a PhosphorImager apparatus (both from Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	107	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Transcripts initiated at the P1 HNF4 promoter are readily expressed in human pancreatic ss-cells Figure 1A depicts a schematic representation of HNF4 gene with P1 and P2 promoters.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Expression of P1 and P2 promoter transcripts was analyzed by RT-PCR.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Promoter P2 transcripts were selectively amplified with a sense primer hybridizing to exon 1D and an antisense primer hybridizing to exon 5 (primers d and b in Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Transcripts from promoter P1 were selectively amplified with the sense primer a hybridizing with exon 1A and primer b (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	111	 As expected from data obtained with pancreatic islets and INS-1 cells (11, 12, 17), we detected transcripts from promoter P2 in human islets, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells, and RIN m5F and HIT-T15 insulinoma cells (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	112	 In exocrine pancreas, the band corresponding to promoter P2 transcripts was barely detectable (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	113	 1C, lane 4), although the band of ss-actin had an intensity similar to that obtained from endocrine cells (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Interestingly, promoter P1 transcripts from human islets and isolated human pancreatic ss-cells yielded highly visible bands, indicating that HNF4 promoter P1 transcripts are substantially expressed in human endocrine pancreas (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	115	 1D, lanes 2 and 3, respectively).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Reproducible data were obtained from five different donors.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Similar results were obtained with RIN m5F and HIT-T15 RNA (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Again, in human exocrine pancreas, promoter P1 transcripts were expressed at very low levels (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Two other groups did not detect P1 promoter transcripts in pancreatic islets and INS-1 cells (11, 12, 17), but the following controls confirmed the accuracy of our results showing expression of the P1 promoter transcripts.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	120	 First, we checked the specificity of amplification of P1 promoter transcripts with the a+b primer set: cloned HNF42 yielded a highly visible band, but no band could be detected with cloned HNF48 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	121	 1H, lanes 1 and 2, respectively).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Second, using cloned HNF42 and HNF48, we verified that primer sets a+b and d+b exhibited similar amplification efficiency (data not shown).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Third, using human pancreatic islets, we made sure that the band obtained for P1 transcripts did not result from a genomic or plasmidic contamination during RNA isolation or reverse transcription: no amplicon could be detected when the step of reverse transcription of RNAs was performed in the absence of Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Conversely, use of another set of primers (h and g), designed to specifically amplify exon 1A and 2, yielded with RNAs from human islets a band that was not obtained when reverse transcription was omitted (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	125	 1J), thus confirming that transcripts of the HNF4 P1 promoter are readily expressed in endocrine pancreas.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	126	Human pancreatic ss-cells express HNF4 isoforms 1, 2, 7, 8, and HNF4 HNF4 transcripts from promoter P1 mainly represent isoforms 1 and 2, and transcripts from promoter P2 mainly represent isoforms 7 and 8, because we determined that very low levels of isoforms 3 to 6 and 9 were expressed in the cells tested.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Indeed, when using primers that specifically amplify isoforms 3 + 6 + 9 or isoforms 4 + 5 + 6 (couples of primers P6 + P7 and P9 + P10, respectively, described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	128	 14), only very faint bands could be detected (data not shown).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	129	 In addition, when analyzing transcripts from the P1 promoter, we failed to detect a band of 612 bp, the expected size of amplicons of transcripts containing exon 1B (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	130	 This result confirms the very low, if any, expression of isoforms 4 to 6.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	131	Because the insertion of 10 amino acid residues in the carboxy-terminal sequence of HNF42 was shown to facilitate recruitment of coactivators (31), we analyzed the expression of isoforms containing the 30-bp insert in ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Primers e and f, hybridizing to exons 9 and 10, respectively, were designed to amplify two fragments, the larger one containing the 30-bp insert of isoforms 2 and 8 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The levels of expression of isoforms 2 and/or 8 were equivalent to those of isoforms 1 and/or 7 in human pancreatic islets and isolated human pancreatic ss-cells (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Similar results were obtained with RIN m5F and HIT-T15 RNA (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	135	Next we analyzed HNF4 expression using primers that specifically amplify the carboxy-terminal domain of this isoform (Table 1).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	136	 1F show that HNF4 is well expressed in human pancreatic islets, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells, and RIN m5F and HIT-T15 cells but is poorly expressed in human exocrine pancreas.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	137	Immunodetection of HNF4 proteins originated from the P1 promoter in pancreatic ss-cells To ascertain the expression of HNF4 proteins encoded by the P1 promoter transcripts containing exon 1A, we used the monoclonal antibody H4/55, which specifically recognizes the amino-terminal sequence of isoforms 1 and 2 but not isoforms 7 and 8 (15).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Because this antibody is not suitable in Western blot assays (Ryffel, G.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	139	, personal communication), HNF4 expression was studied in EMSA performed with the HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter (HNF1 probe).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The specificity of the H4/55 monoclonal antibody was confirmed using in vitro-synthesized HNF42 and HNF48: it supershifted the complex formed with HNF42 but not that formed with HNF48 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Conversely, complexes formed with both HNF4 isoforms could be supershifted by the 455 antiserum raised against their identical carboxy-terminal sequence (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Nuclear extracts of HepG2 cells, which predominantly express HNF41 and 2, yielded a complex that could be supershifted by both the 455 antiserum and the H4/55 monoclonal antibody (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Pancreatic ss-cells express much lower amounts of HNF4 than HepG2 cells (32), which compelled us to use 4-fold higher amounts of HIT-T15 nuclear proteins than HepG2 nuclear proteins.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This accounts for the unspecific background observed when analyzing the former material (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Nevertheless, with HIT-T15 nuclear extracts, we could easily detect a retarded band (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	146	 2B, lane 1) corresponding to a complex mainly formed with HNF4: this complex exhibited the same electrophoretic mobility as that yielded by HNF4 proteins from HepG2 cells; it could be supershifted by the 455 antiserum (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	147	 2B, lane 2) but could not be obtained using a mutated HNF1 probe that is unable to bind HNF4 (data not shown).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Addition of the H4/55 monoclonal antibody resulted in a concomitant decrease in the retarded band and formation of a strong supershifted band that could not be obtained by an antibody raised against an irrelevant peptide sequence, the Xpress tag (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This result unambiguously shows endogenous expression of HNF41 and/or -2 proteins and confirms that HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts are readily expressed in the pancreatic ss-cell line HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This cell line also expresses HNF4, which, when complexed with DNA, comigrates with complexes formed between DNA and HNF41 and -2 (33).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	151	 HNF4 is not recognized by the 455 and H4/55 antibodies; this could account for the partial supershift observed in lanes 2 and 3, as previously observed with nuclear extracts of intestinal villi and crypts (33).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (47K):    Figure 2.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Immunodetection of HNF4 isoforms derived from the P1 promoter in the pancreatic ss-cell line HIT-T15.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	154	 EMSAs were performed with the HNF4 response element of the HNF1 promoter and either in vitro-synthesized HNF42 and HNF48 (A) or nuclear extracts of HIT-T15 (20  microg) and HepG2 (5  microg) cells (B).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	155	 DNA-protein complexes were incubated with either the 455 antiserum, which recognizes the common C-terminal end of isoforms 1, 2, 7, and 8, or the monoclonal H4/55 antibody, which recognizes the N-terminal sequence of isoforms 1 and 2, or the unrelated Xpress antibody.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Arrow and arrowhead denote DNA-HNF4 shifted complexes and supershifted complexes, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	157	  Weak transcriptional potentials of HNF48 produced from the P2 promoter in pancreatic ss-cells HNF41 and -2, whose transcripts include exon 1A, contain the activation function AF-1 module at their amino-terminal end (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	158	 This module includes structural motifs characteristic of acidic activators and plays a key role in the transcriptional potential of HNF4 isoforms 1 and 2 (18;19).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The amino-terminal sequence of HNF47 and -8, encoded by exon 1D, does not contain these motifs and seems to lack an activation function AF-1 module.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	160	 We addressed the consequences of this sequence difference on the HNF4 transcriptional potential in pancreatic ss-cell lines, by comparing the transcriptional activities of HNF4 isoforms 2 and 8 in RIN m5F and HIT-T15 insulinoma cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	161	 To better define the effect of lack of the AF-1 on the HNF4 transcriptional potential in these cells, we also analyzed the activity of HNF42 Y6D/F19D, which has a mutated AF-1 module (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The mutated residues are crucial for the AF-1 function in hepatoma HepG2 cells (18) and in embryonal kidney HEK 293T cells (Eeckhoute, J.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	163	 In RIN m5F cells, the HNF1 promoter was activated 6.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In HIT-T15 cells, only HNF42 activated the HNF1 promoter (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The differences in transactivation were not due to low expression of HNF48 or HNF42 Y6D/F19D (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	166	 These results support the hypothesis that the lower transcriptional activity of HNF48 is due to lack of a AF-1 module.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	167	View larger version (14K):    Figure 3.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Lack or mutation of the AF-1 activation function decreased HNF4 transcriptional potential in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	169	 A, Schematic representation of HNF42 with its AF-1 module (black box), HNF42 Y6D/F19D with the mutated AF-1 (black box with white diamonds), and HNF48 lacking the AF-1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The sequence 1 to 16 of isoform 8 (hatched box) does not share any homology with sequence 1 to 29 of isoform 2 (11 ).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	171	 RIN m5F and HIT-T15 cells (B and C, respectively) were transiently transfected with 300 ng of human HNF1 promoter-Firefly luciferase-reporter plasmid, 25 ng of the indicated HNF4 expression plasmids, and 10 ng of either pGL3-Renilla luciferase (in RIN m5F) or pCMV-ss-galactosidase (in HIT-T15).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Fold induction refers to activities without any HNF4 derivative (empty expression vector).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Error bars indicate SD values of Renilla luciferase or ss-galactosidase-normalized Firefly luciferase activities from three experiments performed in quadruplicate.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Significance of the difference with values obtained for HNF42 is indicated: ***, P  <  0.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	175	 D, Western blotting of overexpressed HNF4 proteins revealed with the 455 antiserum.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	176	  HNF48 driven from the P2 promoter exhibits reduced interaction and cooperation with several coactivators As for other nuclear hormone receptors, the HNF4 transcriptional potential is modulated by coactivators or corepressors.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The HNF4 AF-1 interacts with the coactivator p300 (18, 19, 20), as do the AF-1 of other nuclear receptors with p300 and GRIP-1 (34).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	178	 We therefore investigated the effects of lack of the AF-1 in HNF48 and mutation of this module in HNF42 Y6D/F19D on the interaction with coregulators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In this study, we included p300, GRIP-1, and PGC-1, which are HNF4 coactivators (31, 35, 36, 37), and SHP, a HNF4 corepressor (38).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	180	 GRIP-1, p300, and SHP were reported to be expressed in the endocrine pancreas (7, 39, 40), and PGC-1 expression in human pancreatic ss-cells and in insulinoma cell lines was evidenced by RT-PCR (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	181	 HNF48 interacted much less efficiently than HNF42 with p300 and GRIP-1 (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Conversely, no difference between both isoforms was observed when studying physical interaction with PGC-1 and SHP (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Results obtained with HNF42 Y6D/F19D support that the lower interaction of isoform 8 with p300 and GRIP-1 is due to the lack of AF-1 in this isoform.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	184	View larger version (35K):    Figure 4.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Effects of lack of the AF-1 activation function or of AF-1 mutation on physical interaction between HNF4 and coregulators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	186	 A, PGC-1 expression analyzed by RT-PCR.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Lane 1, Human pancreatic islets; lane 2, human exocrine pancreas; lane 3, isolated human pancreatic ss-cells; lane 4, rat insulinoma RIN m5F cells; lane 5, hamster insulinoma HIT-T15 cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	188	 B, Physical interactions with coregulators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	189	 In vitro-synthesized 35S-methionine-labeled HNF42, HNF48, or HNF42 Y6D/F19D were incubated with immobilized GST-PGC-1 (36 to 797), GST-p300 (340 to 528), GST-GRIP-1 (1122 to 1462), or GST-full-length SHP.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	190	 After extensive washing, proteins were eluted with sodium dodecyl sulfate loading buffer and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Values under photographs indicate binding of HNF42 Y6D/F19D and HNF48, relative to that of HNF42 from three independent experiments.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Inputs, corresponding to 10% of amounts of labeled proteins used in the assays, were taken into account for binding quantifications.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	193	  Next we studied the effect of lack of the AF-1 on the cooperation between HNF4 and p300 that is required for activation of transcription (35).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	194	 To circumvent technical difficulties due to cotransfection of multiple expression plasmids in pancreatic cells and to avoid interference with endogenous HNF4 and HNF4, this study was carried out in HeLa cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	195	 When p300 was not overexpressed, the HNF1 promoter was activated 5.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	196	6-fold by HNF48 and HNF42 Y6D/F19D (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The marked difference in transactivation potentials of HNF4 isoforms 2 and 8 was not due to a difference in expression of the proteins (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The coactivator p300 had no effect on the activity of the HNF1 promoter in the absence of HNF4 but enhanced the transcriptional potential of HNF42 2-fold vs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	199	2-fold for HNF48 and HNF42 Y6D/F19D, respectively (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Therefore, when the AF-1 module was either lacking or mutated, both the physical interaction and the functional cooperation between p300 and HNF4 were decreased.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	201	 As expected from results obtained in pull-down assays, the transcriptional activities of isoforms 2 and 8 were repressed to similar extents by SHP (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	202	View larger version (16K):    Figure 5.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The transcriptional potentials of HNF42 and -8 are differently enhanced by the coactivator p300 but similarly repressed by the corepressor SHP.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	204	 HeLa cells were transiently transfected with 250 ng of human HNF1 promoter-Firefly luciferase-reporter plasmid, 10 ng of Renilla luciferase expression plasmid, and either 12.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	205	5 ng of the indicated HNF4 expression plasmids together with 250 ng of p300 expression plasmid (A) or 25 ng of the indicated HNF4 expression plasmids together with 250 ng of SHP expression plasmid (B).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The total amounts of transfected DNA was equalized with the corresponding empty vectors (-).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Fold induction refers to the activity with no HNF4 and mediator.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Error bars indicate SD values of Renilla luciferase normalized Firefly luciferase activities from three experiments performed in triplicate.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The extent of activation or repression is presented (values above each bar) relative to activity of each isoform or mutant (set to 100) without cotransfected mediator.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	210	 C, Western blotting of overexpressed HNF4 proteins revealed with the 455 antiserum.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	211	     Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   In recent studies, having failed to detect transcripts from the P1 promoter in pancreatic islets and in insulinoma INS-1 cells, the authors concluded that HNF4 transcription is driven almost exclusively by the P2 promoter in pancreatic islets (11, 12, 17).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	212	 But until now, HNF4 expression was not documented in human pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	213	 In our study on human islets and isolated pancreatic ss-cells, we observed that transcripts of the P1 promoter were significantly expressed, as were those of the P2 promoter.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This indicates that HNF4 expression does not exclusively initiate at the P2 promoter in human pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Similar results were observed in the rat RIN m5F and hamster HIT-T15 pancreatic ss-cell lines.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Several controls confirmed the accuracy of our results.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Importantly, we confirmed expression of P1 transcripts in the pancreatic ss-cell line HIT-T15 by immunodetecting HNF4 proteins containing the amino-terminal sequence encoded by exon 1A.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Lack of detection of promoter P1 transcripts in islets by Ferrer s group (12, 17) may be explained by a low amplification efficiency of the P1 promoter transcripts.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	219	 This may account for the weak intensity they obtained for the exon 1A+2 band in liver, relative to that of exon 1D+2 band in islets (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	220	 17), although isoforms 1 and 2 are by far more abundant in liver than isoforms 7 and 8 in islets.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	221	 In concordance with the considerable difference in expression (32), primers amplifying exons 8 to 10 contained in the four isoforms 1, 2, 7 and 8 yielded bands of much stronger intensity for isoforms 1 + 2 in liver than for isoforms 7 + 8 in islets (Fig.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	222	A mutation in the HNF4 P1 promoter significantly decreasing the promoter s activity is associated with diabetes (41).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	223	 This suggests that promoter P1 transcription may be important for normal pancreatic ss-cell function.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In addition, a HNF42 clone was isolated from a human pancreatic islet cDNA library, also arguing for the expression of HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts in endocrine pancreas (Furuta, H.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	225	Controversial results were obtained concerning HNF4 expression in exocrine pancreas (12, 32).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	226	 We confirmed results described in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	227	 32 stating that HNF4 was poorly expressed in the exocrine pancreas.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	228	Compared with isoform 7, isoform 1 is a stronger transcriptional activator in nonpancreatic ss-cells except on promoters of genes that are expressed early in liver (15, 16, 42).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Our functional studies showed that the transcriptional potential of HNF42 was significantly stronger than that of isoform 8 in models of pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Interestingly, these results were obtained on the promoter of HNF1, which plays a crucial role in these cells (7, 9, 43, 44).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Because HNF1 expression is regulated by HNF4 in pancreatic ss-cells (5, 45), we suggest that expression of the HNF4 P1 promoter producing isoforms 1 and 2 is most probably of major importance in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	232	 From our data obtained with HNF42 containing a mutated AF-1, we can infer that the difference in transcriptional potential between isoforms 2 and 8 was due to the lack of the AF-1 module in the latter isoform.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	233	Furthermore, lack of AF-1 in HNF4 resulted in a decreased interaction with p300 and GRIP-1 coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Interaction with p300 was studied using a fragment (amino acids 340 to 528) that interacts with both the HNF4 AF-1 and AF-2 (20).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Despite interaction through the AF-2, we observed a marked decrease in binding of HNF4 lacking the AF-1, thus highlighting the substantial contribution of AF-1 to the interaction with p300.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Consistent with this result, we observed that p300 enhanced the transcriptional potential of isoform 2 more efficiently than that of isoform 8 and HNF42 with a mutated AF-1.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Interestingly, the AF-1 module is also required for the synergistic action of p300 and GRIP-1 to enhance the HNF4 transcriptional activity (42).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	238	In contrast to these coactivators, the corepressor SHP interacted similarly with HNF42 and 8 and repressed their transcriptional activity to similar extents.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	239	 This strongly suggests that SHP-mediated recruitment of transcriptional inhibitor(s) is not AF-1 dependent.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Silencing mediator of retinoic acid and thyroid hormone receptors (SMRT), another HNF4 corepressor (46), was shown to interact similarly with HNF41 and HNF47 (42).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	241	 It appears therefore that the HNF4 AF-1 interacts only with coactivators whereas the AF-2 interacts with both coactivators and corepressors in a mutually exclusive fashion.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Because the balance between coactivators and corepressors is crucial for HNF4 transcriptional activity (38, 46), lack of the AF-1 in isoforms 7 and 8 most probably results in a shift toward a lower ability to recruit coactivators and a subsequent lower coactivator-mediated enhancement of HNF4 transcriptional potential.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	243	 SHP is highly expressed in human pancreatic islets (Moerman, E.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	244	, unpublished results) and may serve as an important checkpoint to balance the activity of the transcriptional network of pancreatic ss-cells (7, 8).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In these cells in which the HNF4 AF-2 has a high probability to be occupied by SHP, the transcriptional activity of isoforms containing the AF-1 may be more efficiently enhanced by coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Thus, even if the AF-1-dependent cofactor-mediated modulations of HNF4 transcriptional activity observed in this study and in Ref.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	247	 42 remain to be shown in pancreatic ss-cells, our results strongly argue for an essential role of the promoter P1-driven HNF4 isoforms in these cells.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	248	A cross-regulatory loop between HNF1 and HNF4 has been evidenced in pancreatic ss-cells, as reviewed in Refs.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In the model proposed by Ferrer (9), activation of the HNF1 promoter by HNF4 is crucial to maintain HNF1 expression above the threshold level required to hold the HNF1/HNF4 circuit in the switch-ON state and, consequently, to avoid ss-cell dysfunction and development of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (9).
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Expression of the HNF4 P1 promoter transcripts in pancreatic ss-cells is probably crucial to maintain this circuit in the switch-ON state.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Indeed, HNF4 is expressed at a limiting amount in ss-cells, and, among isoforms 1, 2, 7, 8, and , only the first two contain the AF-1 module, which confers a stronger transcriptional potential and leads to a more efficient recruitment of coactivators.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Thus, expression of isoforms 1 and 2 is likely of crucial importance in the transcriptional network controlling pancreatic islet function.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	253	   Acknowledgments   Professors Ryffel, Spiegelman, Gustafsson, Stallcup, Bell, and Grossman are acknowledged for providing the H4/55 monoclonal antibody, pGEX-PGC1, pGEX-SHP, pGEX-GRIP-1, pGL3-HNF1, and pCMCss and pGEX-p300 plasmids, respectively.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Brand for helpful discussion and to L.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	255	   Footnotes   This work was supported by a grant from the European Foundation for the Study of Diabetes.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	256	 contributed equally to this work.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	257	Abbreviations: AF, Activation function; GRIP, glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein; GST, glutathione-S-transferase; HNF, hepatocyte nuclear factor; PGC, peroxisome proliferator activated receptor coactivator; SHP, small heterodimer partner.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	258	Accepted for publication December 24, 2002.
