0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	305	 J Biol Chem 277:44677 to 44687[Abstract/Free Full Text] Pontoglio M, Sreenan S, Roe M, Pugh W, Ostrega D, Doyen A, Pick AJ, Baldwin A, Velho G, Froguel P, Levisetti M, Bonner-Weir S, Bell GI, Yaniv M, Polonsky KS 1998 Defective insulin secretion in hepatocyte nuclear factor 1-deficient mice.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	306	 J Clin Invest 101:2215 to 2222[Abstract/Free Full Text] Hagenfeldt-Johansson KA, Herrera PL, Wang H, Gjinovci A, Ishihara H, Wollheim CB 2001 ss-Cell-targeted expression of a dominant-negative hepatocyte nuclear factor-1 induces a maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)3-like phenotype in transgenic mice.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Endocrinology 142:5311 to 5320[Abstract/Free Full Text] Gragnoli C, Lindner T, Cockburn BN, Kaisaki PJ, Gragnoli F, Marozzi G, Bell GI 1997 Maturity-onset diabetes of the young due to a mutation in the hepatocyte nuclear factor-4 binding site in the promoter of the hepatocyte nuclear factor-1 gene.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Diabetes 46:1648 to 1651[Abstract] Ruse Jr MD, Privalsky ML, Sladek FM 2002 Competitive cofactor recruitment by orphan receptor hepatocyte nuclear factor 41: modulation by the F domain.
0.29775548.12697672.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Mol Cell Biol 22:1626 to 1638[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	0	Estrogen Receptor, a Common Interaction Partner for a Subset of Nuclear Receptors Soo-Kyung Lee, Hueng-Sik Choi, Mi-Ryoung Song, Mi-Ock Lee and Jae Woon Lee.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	1	) Chonnam National University Kwangju, 500 to 757 Korea Department of Microbiology (M-R.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	2	) College of Medicine Yonsei University Seoul, 120 to 752 Korea.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Nuclear receptors regulate transcription by binding to specific DNA response elements as homodimers or heterodimers.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Herein, the yeast and mammalian two-hybrid tests as well as glutathione-S-transferase pull-down assays were exploited to demonstrate that estrogen receptor (ER) directly binds to a subset of nuclear receptors through protein-protein interactions between ligand-binding domains.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	5	 These receptors include hepatocyte nuclear factor 4, thyroid hormone receptor (TR), retinoic acid receptor (RAR), ERss, and retinoid X receptor (RXR).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In yeast cells, a LexA fusion protein to the human ER ligand-binding domain (LexA/ER-LBD) was an inert transactivator of a LacZ reporter gene controlled by upstream LexA-binding sites.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, LexA/ER-LBD differentially modulated the LacZ reporter gene expression when coexpressed with native TRs, RARs, or RXRs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Similarly, cotransfection of these receptors in CV1 cells up- or down-regulated transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	9	 From these results, we propose that ER is a common interaction partner for a subset of receptors, and these interactions should mediate novel signaling pathways in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The nuclear receptor superfamily is a group of transcriptional regulatory proteins linked by conserved structure and function (1).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The superfamily includes receptors for a variety of small hydrophobic ligands such as steroids, T3, and retinoids, as well as a large number of related proteins that do not have known ligands, referred to as orphan nuclear receptors (2).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The receptor proteins are direct regulators of transcription that function by binding to specific DNA sequences named hormone response elements (HREs) in promoters of target genes.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Nearly all the superfamily members bind as dimers to HREs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	14	 A dimerization interface has previously been identified within the DNA-binding domains (DBDs) of retinoid X receptors (RXRs), retinoic acid receptors (RARs), vitamin D receptor, and thyroid hormone receptors (TRs) that selectively promotes DNA binding to cognate HREs (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	15	 An additional dimerization interface that mediates cooperative binding to DNA, referred to as the I-box, has recently been mapped to a 40-amino acid region within the C-terminal ligand-binding domains (LBDs) of RAR, TR, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter (COUP-TF), RXR, and hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) (9, 10).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The two dimerization domains appear to work in tandem and led to a two-step hypothesis for binding of dimers to DNA (2, 9).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	17	 According to this hypothesis, the LBD dimerization interface initiates the formation of solution dimers that, in turn, acquire the capacity to bind to a number of differently organized HREs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, formation of a second dimer interface within the DBD restricts receptors to bind to only cognate HREs (2, 9).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	19	While some nuclear receptors apparently bind HREs only as homodimers, TRs, vitamin D receptor, RARs, the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), and several orphan nuclear receptors bind their specific response elements with high affinity as heterodimers with RXRs (11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Based on this high-affinity binding, such heterodimers have been considered to be the functionally active forms of these receptors in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	21	 However, RXR is not the only receptor capable of forming heterodimers with other nuclear receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	22	 TR (17, 18), COUP-TF (19, 20, 21), PPAR (22), and small heterodimer partner (SHP) (23) have been reported to form heterodimers with other receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Interestingly, although heterodimerization with RXR usually results in enhanced transactivation, COUP-TF and SHP seem to function primarily as transcriptional repressors (23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Heterodimer formation can generate many different combinations of receptors, particularly in the light of the fact that multiple genes and multiple isoforms exist for RAR, RXR, TR, COUP-TF, and PPAR.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	25	 As the expression of each isoform depends on cell type and the stage of growth and development, heterodimerization among all these receptors results in the formation of an extremely diverse group of receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In principle, the enormous number of heterodimer combinations could cover a wide range of transcriptional activities, thus generating significant diversity in gene regulation.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	27	Herein, we show that estrogen receptor (ER) directly binds, through protein-protein interactions between ligand-binding domains, to HNF4, TR, RAR, and RXR, adding a complexity to the already complicated list of the heteromeric interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We have also confirmed the results (29, 30) that newly cloned ER named ERss interacts with ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In parallel, COUP-TF (31), estrogen-related receptor 1 (ERR1) (32), and SHP (D.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Moore, personal communications) were shown to interact with ER, while this manuscript was in preparation.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We further show that coexpression of native TR, RAR, or RXR differentially regulates transactivations by ER in yeast and CV1 cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	32	 These results suggest that ER is a common interaction partner for a subset of receptors, and these interactions mediate novel signaling pathways in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	33	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   ER Interacts with a Subset of Nuclear Receptors in Yeast We found that coexpression of a previously described B42/RXR-LBD hybrid (33) stimulates the LexA/ER-LBD (a LexA fusion protein with the LBD of ER)-mediated LacZ reporter gene expression in the yeast two-hybrid tests, suggesting that ER-LBD interacts with RXR-LBD (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	34	 This LacZ expression was further stimulated approximately 1.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	35	5-fold in the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We further found that the LexA/ER-LBD-mediated LacZ expression was stimulated when coexpressed with analogous B42 fusions to several receptors, including RAR, TR, HNF4, and ERss, suggesting that ER also interacts with these receptors (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The expression was slightly enhanced by 1  microM T3 with the B42/TR coexpression, whereas it was significantly stimulated by 1  microM E2 with the B42/ERss coexpression (3-fold) (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	38	 In addition, we showed that an inert transactivator LexA/ERss stimulated the LacZ reporter gene expression approximately 6.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	39	5-fold when coexpressed with B42/ERss, confirming the recently reported ERss homodimerization (29, 30) in this yeast system (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In contrast, coexpression of B42 alone or B42 fusions to the LBDs of TRss, glucocorticoid receptor (GR), or the orphan receptor CAR (34) did not stimulate the LexA/ER-LBD-mediated LacZ expression, attesting to the specificity of these interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Similarly, expressions of all the B42 fusions alone, with no LexA fusion coexpressed, were transcriptionally inert with the LacZ reporter (data not shown).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	42	 However, the B42/TR-LBD coexpression stimulated the LexA/ER-LBD-mediated LacZ expression approximately 2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	43	5-fold in the presence of 1  microM T3, raising the possibility that TR-LBD may contain a T3-inducible interaction domain with ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	44	 From these results, we concluded that ER-LBD may interact with RAR, RXR-LBD, TR, TRss-LBD (only in the presence of T3), HNF4-LBD, and ERssL, in which LBDs are likely to be sufficient.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	45	 It is noteworthy that the LacZ expression strength by coexpression of these ER heterocomplexes was generally comparable to that of the previously described TR/RXR heterodimer (33) (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	46	 1B, compare with the results of LexA/TR-LBD and B42/RXR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Overall, the similarities in the pattern of interactions observed with LexA/ER-LBD and LexA/RXR-LBD (33, 35, 36) strongly suggest that ER, like the RXRs, is a common interaction partner for members of the receptor superfamily.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	48	View larger version (25K):    Figure 1.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	49	 ER Binds to a Subset of Nuclear Receptors in Yeast.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	50	EGY48 cells, in which ss-galactosidase expression is dependent on the presence of a transcriptional activator with a LexA DNA-binding domain, were transformed with plasmids expressing the indicated LexA and B42 chimeras.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These cells were grown in liquid culture containing galactose, since expression of the B42 chimeras is under the control of the galactose-inducible GAL1 promoter (33 ).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	52	 ss-Galactosidase readings were determined and corrected for cell density and for time of development (A415/A600) x 1000/min.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The result is the average of at least three different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	54	 A, Open bars indicate no hormone added.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Light-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Thick-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA (B42/RAR and B42/RXR-LBD) or T3 (B42/TR and B42/TR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Black bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM T3 (B42/TR and B42/TR-LBD) or 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM 9-cis-RA (B42/RAR and B42/RXR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	58	 B, Open bars indicate no hormone added.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Light-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM T3.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Thick-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Black bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	62	  To confirm whether various ligand-dependent stimulations of the LacZ expressions observed reflect genuine ligand-dependent protein-protein interactions or simply ligand-dependent transactivations mediated by the AF2 domains (1), we reexamined the LacZ expressions with two previously defined AF2 mutant receptors, LexA/TR-LBD459 (33) and B42/RXR-LBDAF2 (36).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	63	 1B, the 9-cis-RA-dependent induction of the LacZ expression observed with coexpression of B42/RXR-LBD and LexA/TR-LBD was lost when B42/RXR-LBDAF2 was coexpressed instead, whereas the T3-dependent induction was specifically lost when LexA/TR-LBD459 was used.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	64	 When LexA/TR-LBD459 and B42/RXR-LBDAF2 were coexpressed, neither T3 nor 9-cis-RA-depedent induction of the LacZ expression was observed.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	65	 These results, along with our previous finding (33) in which the interactions of LexA/TR and B42/RXR were not affected by mutations into the AF2 domain of TR, clearly demonstrate that protein-protein interaction of TR and RXR are ligand independent.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Therefore, results of the yeast two-hybrid tests should be taken with caution that they may not represent true ligand-dependent interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Thus, we further characterized these interactions using two additional methods (i.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	68	 mammalian two-hybrid tests and glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-pull downs).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	69	ER Interacts with TR, RAR, and RXR in Mammalian Cells To examine whether ER binds to these receptors in mammalian cells, we employed a mammalian two-hybrid system that reproduces the heteromeric receptor-receptor interactions (37).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	70	 2, cotransfection of CV1 cells with expression vectors for VP16/TR, VP16/RAR, and VP16/RXR significantly increased the Gal4/ER-LBD-mediated induction of the Gal4-TK-Luc reporter gene activity (4-, 7.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	71	5-fold induction, respectively).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Similar results were obtained in the presence of 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	73	1  microM cognate ligand, suggesting that they interact with each other in a ligand-independent manner.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	74	 As expected, VP16 alone was ineffective.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Thus, we concluded that ER is capable of constitutively binding to TR, RAR, and RXR in mammalian cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	76	 These results suggest that the various ligand-dependent stimulations of the LacZ expression in yeast (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	77	 1A) may have reflected ligand-dependent transactivations of the AF2 domains, as suggested by the results shown in Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (22K):    Figure 2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	79	 ER Binds to a Subset of Nuclear Receptors in Mammalian Cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	80	CV1 cells were transfected with ss-galactosidase expression vector and VP16 alone, VP16/TR, VP16/RAR, or VP16/RXR-expression vectors along with a reporter gene Gal4-TK-Luc (37 ).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Open bars indicate no hormone added, whereas hatched and black bars indicate addition of 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	82	1  microM T3 and 9-cis-RA, respectively.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Normalized luciferase expressions from triplicate samples are presented relative to the ss-galactosidase expressions, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	84	  ER Binds to TR, RAR, and RXR in Vitro To further characterize these interactions in vitro, GST-fusions to full-length rat TRss, human RAR, and RXR were expressed, purified, and tested for interaction with an in vitro-translated full-length human ER or luciferase labeled with [35S]methionine.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	85	 As expected, luciferase was not able to interact with any of the GST proteins (data not shown).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	86	 However, ER readily interacted with GST/TR, GST/RAR, and GST/RXR either in the presence or absence of ligand (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	87	 ER didn t interact with GST alone or GST/GR, as expected.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	88	 In contrast, ER bound to GST fusion to the receptor-binding domain of SRC-1 (GST/SRC-R) (38) in an E2-stimulated manner (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The percentage of total [35S]ER bound by the fusion proteins were approximately 15 to 30% of the inputs (data not shown), and the E2-dependent fold-increase in the pull-down of [35S]ER by GST/SRC-R was approximately 4- to 5-fold.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	90	 From these results, we concluded that ER constitutively binds to TR, RAR, and RXR through direct protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	91	 In particular, these results, along with the mammalian two- hybrid tests (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	92	 2), suggest that at least some of the ligand-dependent stimulation of the LacZ expression observed in the yeast two-hybrid tests (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	93	 1) should have resulted from ligand-induced transactivations rather than ligand-induced protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (20K):    Figure 3.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	95	Luciferase and ER-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation were incubated with glutathione beads containing GST alone, GST fusions to TRss (A), RAR (B), RXR (C), SRC-R and GR (D).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Beads were washed, and specifically bound material was eluted with reduced glutathione and resolved by SDS-PAGE.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	97	 (-) denotes no hormone added; 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	98	1  microM of each ligand was added as indicated.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	99	  Function of the ER Heterocomplexes We have previously shown that LexA/TR-LBD requires coexpression of native RXR for an efficient T3-dependent transactivation in yeast (33).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Similar to LexA/TR-LBD, LexA/ER-LBD alone was an inert transactivator, either in the presence or absence of E2, of the previously described LacZ reporter gene controlled by upstream LexA-binding sites in yeast (33).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	101	 To gain insights into the functional consequences of these interactions in vivo, we coexpressed holo-proteins of these ER-interacting receptors in the LexA/ER-LBD-expressing yeast cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Interestingly, RAR, RARss, RXRss, TR, or TRss dramatically enhanced the basal transcriptional activities of LexA/ER-LBD (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Coexpression of RAR led to approximately 2-fold induction in the basal transcriptional activities, which was further enhanced approximately 2-fold by addition of 1  microM 9-cis-RA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Interestingly, coexpression of RXR or RXR induced the LexA/ER-LBD-mediated LacZ expression only in the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA; i.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	105	 the basal level of expression was not affected by coexpression of these two receptors (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	106	 These results indicate that coexpression of these native receptors can differentially regulate transactivations by ER in yeast, attesting to the possible functional significance of these interactions in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	107	View larger version (34K):    Figure 4.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Modulation of LexA/ER-LBD by Coexpressed Holo-nuclear Receptors in Yeast.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	109	EGY48 cells, in which ss-galactosidase expression is dependent on the presence of a transcriptional activator with a LexA DBD, were transformed with plasmids expressing LexA/ER-LBD and the indicated holo-nuclear receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Open bars indicate no hormone added.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Light-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Thick-hatched bars indicate the presence of 1  microM 9-cis-RA (RARs and RXRs) or T3 (TRs).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Black bars indicate the presence of 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM T3 (TRs) or 1  microM E2 plus 1  microM 9-cis-RA (RARs and RXRs).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	114	 ss-Galactosidase readings were determined and corrected for cell density and for time of development (A415/A600) x 1000/min.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The result is the average of at least three different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	116	  To assess the functional consequences of these interactions in mammalian cells, TR, RAR, or RXR was cotransfected into CV1 cells along with an ER expression vector and a reporter construct controlled by ERE (ERE-TK-CAT or ERE-TK-Luc).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	117	1  microM E2 stimulated the ER-mediated reporter gene expression approximately 5- to 7-fold in the absence of cotransfected receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Coexpression of TR, however, significantly stimulated both the basal and E2-induced transactivations by ER (4- and 2-fold, respectively).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Interestingly, a weak additive effect was observed with the TR coexpression; i.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	120	 E2 plus T3 resulted in approximately 1.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	121	5-fold higher activities than E2 alone (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	122	 5A; see the results with 50 ng TR cotransfected).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Coexpression of RAR did not affect the basal level of transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	124	 However, it repressed the E2-induced transactivation almost to the basal level (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	125	 In contrast, coexpression of RXR modestly stimulated the E2-induced transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The basal level of transactivations by ER, however, was not affected by the RXR coexpression.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Similarly, coexpression of ER inhibited the 9-cis-RA-induced transactivations of a reporter construct controlled by ss-retinoic acid response element (data not shown).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In addition, cotransfection results varied depending on cell types and receptor isotypes, suggesting that other factors contribute to the final phenotype of each ER heterocomplex (M.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	129	 These results, along with the yeast coexpression results (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	130	 4), suggest that these ER heterocomplexes can differentially modulate the ER-mediated transcriptional activites in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	131	View larger version (20K):    Figure 5.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Differential Activites of the ER Heterocompexes in Mammalian Cells.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	133	CV1 cells were transfected with ss-galactosidase expression vector and increasing amounts of TR, RAR, or RXR expression vectors along with a reporter gene ERE-TK-LUC (A) or ERE-TK-CAT (B), as indicated.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Cells were unstimulated (open bars) or stimulated with 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	135	1  microM E2 (light-hatched bars), 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	136	1  microM T3 (thick-hatched bars), or 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Normalized luciferase expressions from triplicate samples are presented relative to the ss-galactosidase expressions and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	138	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   It has been demonstrated that control of E2-responsive gene regulation can be quite complex (reviewed in Ref.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Several lines of evidence indicated that gene regulation by E2 and ERE involves not only ER but also other transcription factors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	140	 For example, other nuclear receptors such as TR, RXR, COUP-TF, ERR1, and RAR have been shown to interact with EREs in addition to their cognate response elements (40, 41, 42).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In this report, we have clearly shown that ER, along with RXR, is a common interaction partner for a subset of receptors, suggesting that E2-responsive gene regulation may also involve direct protein-protein interactions with other nuclear receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In particular, it is an interesting possibility that these different ER heterocomplexes may mediate novel signaling pathways through their own DNA-binding sites that are distinct from the conventional EREs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	143	 In contrast to the broad positive effects of RXR, these ER heterointeractions led to differential regulation of the transactivations by ER (Figs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In addition, cotransfection results dramatically varied depending on cell types (CV1 vs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	145	 MCF7 cells, for instance) and receptor isotypes (M.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	146	 These differential regulations may result from direct bindings of ER heterodimers to ERE, which either positively or negatively regulates E2-induced gene expression.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Alternatively, formation of a non ERE-binding heterodimer may simply inhibit E2-induced gene expression or allow other positive- or negative-acting proteins to occupy EREs instead.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Despite our extensive efforts, however, we were not able to find any intermediate heterodimer bindings or inhibitions of ER bindings to ERE by these ER-interacting receptors in electrophoresis mobility shift assays (EMSA) (data not shown).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Similarly, heterodimers of COUP-TF/ER (31), ERR1/ER (32), and SHP/ER (D.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Moore, personal communications) readily detected in solution were not observed to bind EREs in EMSA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In parallel, two recent reports showed interaction of COUP-TF with orphan receptors nurr77 (20) and HNF4 (21) only in solution but not when bound to DNA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	152	 These results are consistent with the possibility that these ER/receptors may bind EREs as a heterodimer or a higher-order complex not stable enough to sustain in EMSA.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	153	 These weak complexes may show distinct phenotypes by differentially interacting with other proteins such as recently defined transcription cofactors, which are often receptor- and cell type-specific (reviewed in Ref.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Consistent with this possibility, xSRC-3, an SRC-1 homolog we recently isolated from Xenopus, was found to show unexpected specificity in tissue distribution and receptor interactions (44).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	155	Even though the oligomeric status of the ER heterocomplexes are not currently known, two lines of evidence attest to the specificity of the protein-protein interactions between ER and these receptors.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	156	 First, a series of chimeric HNF4s we recently constructed to define the HNF4 homodimeric interactions and RXR heterodimeric interactions (10) differentially interacted with ER (our unpublished results).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Second, we isolated a few mutant RXRs that show specifically impaired interactions with ER while maintaining wild-type interactions with other receptors (our unpublished results).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Similar to the chimeric HNF4s, these mutations also reside within the I-box of the RXR, which was recently found to be essential for homo- and heterodimer formations (9, 10), suggesting that HNF4 and RXR exploit the conventional dimerization domains (the I-box) to interact with ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Recently, the DNA-binding pattern of the RXR was shown to be regulated by ligand-dependent modulation of its oligomeric state (dimer vs.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	160	 tetramer), and the tetramerization domain was defined to be distinct from the dimerization domain I-box (45).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Thus, further mutational studies within this newly defined tetramerization domain of RXR, as well as mapping the regions of ER essential for these interactions, will be required to clearly decode the oligomeric status of these ER heterocomplexes.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	162	The LexA-based yeast two-hybrid system presents two possible complications to study protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	163	 First, the full-length LexA used in this system contains its own dimerization domain, which could complicate interpretation of the interaction results, particularly where dimerization is a prerequisite for two target proteins to interact with each other.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Second, this system cannot distinguish between genuine ligand-dependent protein-protein interactions and ligand-dependent transactivations.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	165	 For instance, the ligand-induced stimulations of the LacZ expressions when LexA/TR and B42/RXR-LBD were coexpressed were shown to reflect ligand-dependent transactivations mediated by the AF2 domains of TR and RXR (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	166	 With these complications, other methods such as the GST pull-downs should be employed to probe protein-protein interactions.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The interactions of ER with TR, RAR, and RXR were hormone-independent in both mammalian two-hybrid tests and GST pull-downs, suggesting that the seemingly hormone-dependent interactions in yeast (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	168	 1) may have been the hormone-dependent transactivations of the AF2 domains.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The T3-dependent stimulation of the LacZ expression with TR-LBD and ER-LBD coexpressed (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	170	 1A) may have also reflected the T3-dependent transactivations of the AF2 domain of TR.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The basal interactions between these proteins might have been too low to detect in the yeast system, which, however, became detectable with an aid from the activated transactivations of the AF2 domain upon T3 addition (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	172	 1A; see the results with LexA/ER-LBD and B42/TR-LBD).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	173	The physiological implications for these interactions have been accumulating.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	174	 For instance, manipulations of T3 and E2in vitro were shown to potentiate or mutually inhibit effects of gene expression (40, 46, 47).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Environmental conditions that alter levels of circulating T3, such as cold temperature, were also shown to alter E2-dependent female reproductive behavior (48, 49, 50, 51).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	176	 TR was recently shown to attenuate ER-mediated transactivations from the vit A2 consensus ERE, which is not necessarily dependent on DNA binding, as the TR DNA-binding mutant was still able to inhibit E2-dependent transactivation (52, 53).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	177	 However, under similar conditions, we observed a modest enhancement of the ERE-mediated transactivations by either liganded or unliganded ER when cotransfected with TR (Fig.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The reasons for this discrepancy are not currently known.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In addition, retinoids have been shown to inhibit the growth of hormone-dependent breast cancer cells both in vivo and in vitro (54, 55, 56).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Nonadditive inhibition has been demonstrated between retinoids and antiestrogens, suggesting that each agent may produce common antiestrogenic effects.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Recently, synergistic interactions between HNF3 and HNF4 mediating apolipoprotein AI gene expression were shown to be further potentiated by cotransfected ER (57), in which the physical association of ER and HNF4, as described in this report, may play a role.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	182	 However, the physiological implications for the ER/SHP (D.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Moore, personal communications), ER/COUP-TF (31), and ER/ERR1 (32) interactions are not currently known.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	184	In conclusion, we found that ER directly binds to a subset of nuclear receptors through protein-protein interactions between ligand-binding domains, and these ER heterocomplexes led to differential regulation of transactivations by ER.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	185	 From these results, we propose that ER is a common interaction partner for a subset of receptors, and these different ER heterocomplexes should mediate novel signaling pathways in vivo.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	186	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Hormones, Yeast Cells, and Plasmids E2, T3, and 9-cis-RA were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	187	 EGY48 cells, the lexA-ss-galactosidase reporter construct, and the LexA- and B42-parental vectors were as reported (33, 58).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	188	 LexA or B42 fusions to the LBDs of GR, CAR, HNF4, RXR and TRss as well as a B42 fusion to full-length RAR were as previously described (10, 33, 35, 36).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The entire hinge and ligand-binding domains (D, E, and F; amino acids 245 to 595) of the human ER were subcloned into EcoRI and SalI sites of the LexA-vector by PCR using EcoRI and XhoI-site bearing primers to construct LexA/ER-LBD.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	190	 LexA or B42 fusions to full-length mouse ERss (a gift from Dr.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Vincent Giguere) or human TR were similarly constructed.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Yeast expression vectors, YEP-RXR, YEP-RXRss, YEP-RXR, YEP-RAR, YEP-RARss, YEP-RAR, YEP-TR, and YEP-TRss were as described (33, 59).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Expressions of all of these holo- or chimeric receptor constructs were confirmed by Western analyses (33, 58, 59).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	194	 T7 vector to express full-length hER and expression vector for GST-fusions to full-length TRss, RXR and RAR were gifts from Dr.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	195	 David Moore at Baylor College of Medicine (36).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A PCR fragment encoding GR-LBD (human GR amino acids 484 to 777) was cloned into EcoRI and SalI restriction sites of pGEM4T (Pharmacia, Piscataway, NJ) to construct GST/GR-LBD.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Mammalian expression vectors for ER, TR, RXR, and RAR, the reporter constructs ERE-TK-CAT and ERE-TK-Luc, and the transfection indicator construct pRSV-ss-gal are as described (34, 52, 53, 58).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Vectors for the mammalian two-hybrid tests were gifts from Dr.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Ron Evans at Salk Institute (37).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	200	 All the PCR-based constructs were sequenced against any mutation that might have been erroneously introduced during amplification.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	201	Yeast ss-Galactosidase Assays The cotransformation and transactivation assays in yeast as well as quantitative liquid ss-galactosidase assays were performed with the following changes as described previously (33).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The yeast culture were initially diluted to an A600 of 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	203	05, and plated into 96-well culture dishes with the various concentrations of hormone.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The cultures were then incubated in the dark at 30 C for 16 h.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The A600 was determined, and then cells were lysed and substrate was added and A415 was read after 10 to 30 min.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The normalized galactosidase values were determined as follows: (A415/A600) x 1000/min developed.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	207	 For each experiment, at least six independently derived colonies expressing chimeric receptors were tested.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	208	Pull-Down Assays GST fusion proteins were produced in Escherichia coli and purified using glutathione-Sepharose affinity chromatography essentially as described (36).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	209	 GST proteins were bound to glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia) in binding buffer (50 mM KPO4, pH 6.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	210	0, 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 10% glycerol, 10 mg/ml E.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Beads were washed once with binding buffer and incubated for 60 min at 4 C in the same buffer with equivalent amounts of various proteins labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Nonbound proteins were removed by three washes with binding buffer without E.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	213	 coli extract, and specifically bound proteins were eluted with 50 mM reduced glutathione in 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Eluted proteins were resolved by PAGE and visualized by fluorography.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	215	Cell Culture and Transfections CV1 cells were grown in 24-well plates with medium supplemented with 10% charcoal-stripped serum.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	216	 After 24 h incubation, cells were transfected with 150 ng of ss-galactosidase expression vector pRSV-ss-gal and 100 ng of a reporter gene ERE-TK-CAT or ERE-TK-Luc, along with 10 ng ER- and increasing amounts (50 to 100 ng) of TR, RAR, or RXR expression vector.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Total amount of expression vectors were kept constant by adding decreasing amounts of the CDM8 expression vector to transfections containing increasing amounts of the TR, RAR, or RXR vector.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	218	 For the mammalian two-hybrid tests, a reporter gene Gal4-TK-Luc, vectors expressing VP16/-, VP16/TR, VP16/RAR, or VP16/RXR, and Gal4DBD/ER-LBD expression vector were used as described (37).
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	219	 After 12 h, cells were washed and refed with DMEM containing 10% charcoal-stripped FBS.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	220	 After 12 h, cells were left unstimulated or stimulated with 0.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Cells were harvested 24 h later, and CAT or luciferase activity was assayed as described (58), and the results were normalized to the ss-galactosidase expression.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Similar results were obtained in more than two similar experiments.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	223	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Drs.

0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Vincent Giguere for mERss and Dr.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Ron Evans for the mammalian two-hybrid vectors.
