0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Greene Assoc, New York Allegretto EA, McClurg MR, Lazarchik SB, Clemm DL, Kerner SA, Elgort MG, Boehm MF, White SK, Pike JW, Heyman RA 1993 Transactivation properties of retinoic acid and retinoid X receptors in mammalian cells and yeast.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Correlation with hormone binding and effects of metabolism.
0.22530045.9717844.html.plaintext.txt	295	 J Biol Chem 268:26625 to 26633[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	0	Fission yeast retrotransposon Tf1 integration is targeted to 5' ends of open reading frames Ralf Behrens*, Jacky Hayles and Paul Nurse.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	1	Imperial Cancer Research Fund, Cell Cycle Laboratory, 44 Lincoln s Inn Fields, London WC2A 3PX, UK.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received August 9, 2000; Revised and Accepted October 18, 2000.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Target site selection of transposable elements is usually not random but involves some specificity for a DNA sequence or a DNA binding host factor.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	4	 We have investigated the target site selection of the long terminal repeat-containing retrotransposon Tf1 from the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	5	 By monitoring induced transposition events we found that Tf1 integration sites were distributed throughout the genome.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Mapping these insertions revealed that Tf1 did not integrate into open reading frames, but occurred preferentially in longer intergenic regions with integration biased towards a region 100 to 420 bp upstream of the translation start site.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Northern blot analysis showed that transcription of genes adjacent to Tf1 insertions was not significantly changed.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	8	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Transposable elements are discrete DNA segments that can translocate between non-homologous insertion sites.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Although they usually insert into many different sites, most elements display some degree of target selectivity.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This serves to facilitate element propagation and to avoid insertions into essential genes of the host.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	11	 A target site may be selected through direct interactions between the transposable element and the target DNA or through its association with accessory proteins that may be element- and/or host-encoded (reviewed in 1).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	12	Well-studied examples of transposable element targeting include Drosophila P elements and the Saccharomyces cerevisiae long terminal repeat (LTR)-containing retrotransposons Ty1 to Ty5.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	13	 P elements have a preference for 5' untranslated regions and for regions 100 to 200 bp upstream of the transcription start site.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	14	 This region-specific integration can result in changes in the expression level of adjacent genes and has been exploited for genetic screens (for review see 2,3).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In the case of Ty1 to Ty4,  > 90% of native insertions in the genome are found in upstream regions of genes transcribed by RNA polymerase III (Pol III), such as tRNA genes (4).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Ty1 integrates 70 to 700 bp upstream of the transcription start site of these genes and it has been demonstrated that this is due to interactions between the retrotransposon and a component of the RNA Pol III transcriptional apparatus and/or through its recognition of chromatin structures associated with RNA Pol III transcription (5 to 9).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Furthermore, Ty1 integration also occurs within pre-existing LTRs (10), as well as upstream or within a variety of Pol II-transcribed genes which can result in alterations in the expression levels of these genes (11 to 13).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	18	 For Ty3, target specificity appears to depend on the ability of the Ty3 integration machinery to compete with Pol III for interactions with TFIIIB and TFIIIC transcription factors (14,15).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Ty3 inserts only at Pol III-transcribed genes and integrates in a site-specific manner within a few base pairs of the transcription start site.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Ty5 typically integrates near telomeres or the silent mating loci, HML and HMR (16,17), and it is thought that integration complexes recognise chromatin or other DNA-bound proteins (18).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	21	The LTR-retrotransposon Tf1 isolated from the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe (19) contains a single open reading frame (ORF) (20) encoding Gag, protease, reverse transcriptase and integrase proteins (19,21).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Tf1 integrates into genomic DNA due to transposition events, and it has been shown that this transposition activity is independent of temperature (21).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Like Ty3, Tf1 is a member of the gypsy family of transposable elements (19), but it remains to be determined whether it also has a preference for Pol III promoters.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Here we report the analysis of the target site specificity of Tf1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	25	 By examining the genomic distribution of induced transposition events we found that Tf1 is preferentially targeted to intergenic regions close to the 5' end of ORFs with no preference for pol III promoters.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	26	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Media, strains and plasmids Strains were grown in complete media (YES) and in minimal media (EMM) (22).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Amino acids and pyrimidines were supplemented at a final concentration of 225  microg/ml.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Vitamin B1 (thiamine, 15  microM) was added to EMM to repress the nmt1 promoter.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Phloxin B (Sigma) was added at 5 mg/l to facilitate screening for cdc25 revertants.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	30	 5-Fluoroorotic acid (5-FOA) (Milford Laboratories) plates were made by adding 1 mg/ml of 5-FOA to EMM.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	31	 YES + 5-FOA + G418 plates contained 1 mg/ml of 5-FOA and 0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	32	5 mg/ml (corrected for purity) of Geneticin (Gibco).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The following yeast strains were used: ura4-D18 leu1-32 h- (strain 513) and cdc25-22 ura4-297 leu1-32 h- (strain 2586).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	34	 1A) was described earlier (20).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	35	View larger version (22K):    Figure 1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Determination of genomic Tf1-neo insertions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	37	 (A) The transposition assay plasmid pHL414 contained the URA3 gene of S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	38	cerevisiae and the Tf1-neo element fused to an inducible nmt promoter.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The neo gene inserted in Tf1 confers G418 resistance.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The large white box represents the single full-length ORF of Tf1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The positions of the protein domains Gag, protease (PR), reverse transcriptase (RT) and integrase (IN) are indicated.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Triangles within grey boxes represent LTRs.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The plasmid contains an autonomous replication sequence of S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	44	 (B) Southern blot analysis of Tf1 transposition clones.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	45	 DNA from G418-resistant clones was cut with restriction enzymes as indicated, blotted, and hybridised to a Tf1-specific probe shown in the schematic presentation of the nmt to Tf1-neo fusion construct.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	46	 As controls, DNA from an isogenic strain without Tf1 insertion (wt) and from the same strain carrying the pHL414 plasmid (pHL414) in the presence of thiamine were used.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Of 40 analysed transposition clones, 10 representative clones are shown here.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Molecular weights are shown to the left of the gel.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	49	 (C) The genomic locations of induced Tf1-neo insertion events were determined using IPCR and the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	50	 IPCR primers (see Materials and Methods; RB30, RB32: primer set 1; RB20, RB39: primer set 2) and sequencing primers (SQ) are shown as arrows.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	51	 HindIII restriction sites are indicated, and genes are represented as black boxes.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	52	  Tf1 transposition assay The transposition assay was described previously (20).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Strain 513 carrying the pHL414 plasmid was first streaked out to single colonies on EMM + leucine + thiamine plates.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Individual colonies were picked and used to inoculate the growth of patches on EMM + leucine plates.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	55	 After 2 days at 32 degrees C, the patches were used to inoculate a culture of EMM + leucine at an optical density at 595 nm (OD595) of 0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	56	 These cultures were grown for another 2 days at 32 degrees C before plating on EMM + 5-FOA + uracil + leucine at a density of 500 cells per plate.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	57	 After 3 days at 32 degrees C, 5-FOA-resistant colonies were replica plated onto YES + 5-FOA + G418 plates and incubated for a further 2 days to obtain colonies that had undergone a transposition event.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	58	 From each of four independent transposition assays 10 G418-resistent colonies were picked and analysed by Southern blotting.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Small and large colonies were selected in order to take into account that Tf1 integration could have affected the growth rate of some clones.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	60	Southern blotting Southern blots (23) of genomic DNA of putative transposition clones were hybridised to a 32P-labelled EcoRI fragment (19) of Tf1 (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	61	 DNA extracted from strain 513 did not hybridise to this probe because this strain was isogenic to strain 972, which does not contain a Tf1 copy (19).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The URA3 probe used was a 1040 bp HinfI fragment of the URA3 gene (24).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	63	 A 673 bp probe of the neo gene was obtained by PCR (Expand High Fidelity PCR system, Boehringer Mannheim) using the pFA6-kanMX6 plasmid as template (25).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	64	Determination of Tf1 insertion sites To isolate regions flanking the insertion sites of the retrotransposon, 2  microg of DNA from clones shown by Southern blotting to have undergone a transposition event were digested with HindIII which cuts within the neo gene of Tf1-neo.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	65	 DNA was diluted to 1 ng/ microl, T4 Ligase (NEB) was added at 1 U/ microl and the mix was incubated at 16 degrees C overnight.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After phenol to chloroform extraction and ethanol precipitation, 100 ng of self-ligated DNA was used as template for inverse PCR (IPCR) (Expand High Fidelity PCR system, Boehringer Mannheim).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Self-ligated fragments were amplified during 35 cycles in a 50  microl reaction using either of two inverse primer sets (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Primer set 1 (annealing at 55 degrees C, 30 s) was RB30 (5'-GGAGTACGGATAAAATGCTTGATGG-3') and RB32 (5'-CGGTTTGGTTGATGCGAGTG-3') corresponding to sequences in the neo gene downstream of the HindIII site.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Primer set 2 (annealing at 53 degrees C, 30 s) was RB20 (5'-TGTCCCAGTAAGAATCACCTCTCTG-3') and RB39 (5'-AGGAGAAAACTCACCGAGGCAG-3') corresponding to a sequence in the unique EcoRI fragment of Tf1 and to a sequence in the neo gene upstream of the HindIII site in Tf1-neo, respectively.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The extension reaction was carried out at 68 degrees C with extension times chosen according to the size of the fragments, as predicted by Southern blot analysis.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	71	 PCR products were gel-purified (Qiagen) and sequenced using Big Dye Terminator cycle sequencing (Perkin-Elmer).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Oligonucleotides derived from the LTR and the neo gene were used as primers.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	73	 From the sequencing data, the Tf1 genomic insertion site was determined using the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	74	pombe genome database of the Sanger Centre (http://www.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	75	Screen for the disruption of wee1 in a cdc25 temperature-sensitive strain Strain 2586 was transformed with plasmid pHL414 and transformants were streaked out to single colonies on EMM + leucine + thiamine plates at 25 degrees C.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	76	 An individual colony was inoculated into 10 ml EMM + leucine + thiamine and grown at 25 degrees C overnight.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	77	 After washing the cells twice with water, 100 ml of EMM + leucine was inoculated at a cell density of OD595 = 0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	78	1 and incubated at the permissive temperature of 25 degrees C for 24 h.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Cells were then plated on EMM + leucine + uracil + 5-FOA + Phloxin B at a density of 107 cells per plate and incubated at the restrictive temperature of 36 degrees C for 4 days.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	80	 5-FOA resistant colonies were replica plated onto YES + 5-FOA + G418 and incubated for 2 days at 36 degrees C.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	81	 G418-resistant revertants were examined for the wee1 phenotype by light microscopy and then analysed for disruption of the wee1 gene by Southern blotting.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Genomic DNA from revertants was digested with AlwNI, blotted and hybridised to Tf1-specific and wee1-specific probes (2086 bp KpnI to BglII fragment of the wee1 ORF, see Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	83	View larger version (40K):    Figure 4.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Screen for Tf1 insertion into the wee1 gene.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The pHL414 plasmid was transformed into a cdc25 temperature-sensitive strain and transposition was induced at the permissive temperature.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	86	 G418-resistant revertants which grew at the restrictive temperature were analysed for the disruption of the wee1 gene.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Genomic DNA from such clones (m1, m2) was digested with AlwNI and analysed by Southern blotting using wee1- and Tf1-specific (see Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The blot shows that the Tf1 insertions were not on the same genomic fragment as the wee1 gene.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	89	 As control, DNA from a strain without Tf1 insertion was included (wt).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Molecular weights are shown to the left of the gel.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The wee1 ORF is presented as a box with an arrow indicating the translation start site, and the AlwNI restriction sites in the vicinity of the wee1 gene are indicated.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	92	  RNA preparation and northern blot analysis Northern blots of RNA (26) were hybridised to 32P-labelled probes prepared by random oligo priming using a Prime-It kit (Stratagene).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	93	 As a loading control, blots were either stained with methylene blue for the 1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	94	5 kb rRNAs, or hybridised to a probe of the his3 ORF (DraI to EcoRV fragment).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Probes for the following (predicted) ORFs were obtained by PCR using genomic DNA from strain 513 as template: ubc4, SPBC119.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The size of the probes ranged from 230 to 1038 bp, and they did not contain intronic sequences.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	97	   RESULTS AND DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   In order to investigate target site preference for Tf1 LTR retrotransposon insertion we used the plasmid pHL414 kindly provided by H.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Levin (20), which contained Tf1 under control of the nmt1 promoter (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The transposon contained the neo gene allowing insertional events to be selected on the basis of stable G418 resistance, and the plasmid contained the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	100	cerevisiae URA3 gene which can complement S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The plasmid was transformed into ura4 to  cells, and transposition was induced by depleting thiamine from the medium in order to activate the nmt1 promoter.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Next, cells were plated on 5-FOA to select for uracil auxotrophs to ensure that the original plasmid was lost from the cells, and colonies were selected for G418 resistance ensuring that Tf1 was still present in the cells.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Usually, G418 resistance can only occur if a Tf1 transposition event from the plasmid to the chromosome has taken place.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	104	The majority of Tf1 insertions were at different locations in the genome To investigate the distribution of Tf1 insertions within the genome we analysed 40 putative transposition events by Southern blotting (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Of these, 34 (85%) showed unique restriction patterns indicating that insertions occurred at sites distributed throughout the genome.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The remaining six insertions (15%) consisted of three pairs with each pair having an identical restriction pattern which differed from the other two pairs.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The two insertions of each of these three pairs could have occurred on the same genomic fragment.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	108	 However, they could also have coincidentally occurred on different fragments of similar size as was the case with clones 31 and 33, which showed a similar restriction pattern but mapped to different locations on chromosome I (Table 1).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Probing the blots with a URA3-specific probe gave no signal showing that the pHL414 plasmid was not present in the clones, either as free plasmid or integrated in the genome (data not shown).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	110	 We also confirmed the integrity of the transposon by reprobing the blots for the neo gene (data not shown).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	111	 These results indicate that Tf1 insertion occurs at sites distributed throughout the genome.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Location of 27 Tf1 insertion sites   Tf1 inserted preferentially in a 320 bp band at the 5' end of ORFs Next, we used IPCR and the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	113	pombe genome database to determine the genomic location of 27 Tf1 insertion sites (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The mapped Tf1 copies were flanked by 5 bp duplications of the insertion site indicating that they were the result of a true transposition event and not due to recombination (21).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	115	As shown in Table 1, all insertions occurred in intergenic regions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Our analysis of the available S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	117	Sgouros, personal communication, based on sequence information made available from the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	118	pombe Genome Project EU Consortium) suggested that 62% of the genome consists of coding sequences and from comparison with S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	119	cerevisiae we predict that ~83% of these would be non-essential (27).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Thus, we would expect that 52% of the transposition clones would have an insertion in a non-essential ORF.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Given the lack of any such event, we can conclude that Tf1 integration was not random, but was significantly biased towards intergenic regions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	122	To investigate whether the insertion of Tf1 within intergenic regions was random, we analysed the distribution of insertion sites with respect to the 5' or 3' region of the nearest gene.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	123	 In order to do so, we divided the targeted intergenic regions in half and allocated the insertions to the 5' or 3' region of the closest ORF.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	124	 On this basis, 10 of 15 insertions between tandem ORFs and all 12 Tf1 insertions between divergent ORFs mapped closer to the 5' than to the 3' end of an ORF.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Correspondingly, Figure 2A shows 22 Tf1 insertions in the 5' region and five insertions in the 3' region of an representative ORF.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The 5' region of Tf1-targeted genes had a mean size of 980 bp as determined by calculating the mean size of Tf1-targeted intergenic regions flanked by ORFs in divergent orientation (1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Thus, if transposition into the 5' region of genes was completely random, 33% of the insertions would have been found in a region of 320 bp.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	128	 However, our analysis revealed that 82% (18/22) of the insertions were in a band 100 to 420 nt upstream of the translation start site of an ORF.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	129	 This significant bias of Tf1 integration towards a 320 bp band close to the 5' end of ORFs is further supported by the lack of any insertion between convergent ORFs.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Taking into account the frequency and the average size of the different intergenic regions, we would have expected to find 10 to 11 Tf1 insertions in intergenic regions flanked by divergent ORFs (27%, 1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	131	1 kb), 12 to 13 insertions in regions flanked by tandem ORFs (45%, 0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	132	8 kb) and four to five insertions in regions between convergent ORFs (28%, 0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	133	 We found 12 insertions between divergent ORFs and 15 insertions between tandem ORFs, but no insertion between convergent ORFs (Table 1).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	134	 This suggests that Tf1 avoids convergent intergenic regions entirely, presumably because of its preference for 5' ends of ORFs.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	135	View larger version (14K):    Figure 2.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Analysis of Tf1 integration sites within intergenic regions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	137	 (A) The location of all mapped Tf1 insertion sites with regard to the closest ORF (5' or 3' end) is shown.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Bars indicate single Tf1 insertions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Long bars are used to represent two Tf1 insertions which occurred at about the same distance to the closest ORF (clone 8, 141 bp and clone 39, 144 bp; clone 2, 258 bp and clone 29, 261 bp; clone 21, 307 bp and clone 26, 308 bp).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The arrow indicates the 5' end of an ORF (grey box).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	141	 (B) Composition of 5 bp Tf1 target site duplication.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The total and average base usage at the 5 bp duplicated target site is indicated.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The total number of analysed target sites was 27 and the orientation of the target site is 5' to 3' and parallel to the Tf1 element.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	144	  If Tf1 simply had a preference for 5' ends of ORFs we would have expected that the mean size of Tf1-targeted intergenic regions would have been equivalent to the mean size of the corresponding regions in the genome.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	145	 However, we found that the mean size of Tf1-targeted intergenic regions flanked by divergent (1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	146	5 kb, n = 15) ORFs was larger than the mean size of these regions in the genome (1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	147	 This difference was highly significant for regions flanked by tandem ORFs (P  <  0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	148	01, two-tailed paired t-test), and showed a good significance for regions flanked by divergent ORFs (P = 0.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Thus, our analysis suggests that Tf1 integrated preferentially into particular large intergenic regions, and that this was not directly related to its preference for a region at the 5' ends of ORFs.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	150	We examined next whether Tf1 inserted at 5' ends of ORFs by targeting directly or indirectly a particular DNA sequence.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The retroelement did not show a preference for AT-rich regions as has been reported for Ty1 elements (28).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	152	 We determined the AT content of 64  plus or minus  1% for the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	153	pombe genome by analysing 10 randomly picked cosmids.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Regions comprising 500, 100 and 20 bp on either side of the insertion sites had an average AT content of 67  plus or minus  2%, 68  plus or minus  5% and 67  plus or minus  9%, respectively.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Analysis of the duplicated Tf1 insertion site (21) revealed no consensus sequence, but did suggest that the four bases were not used equally.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The second position was found to be enriched for T and depleted for G, the third position was depleted for G and C and the fourth position was depleted for C (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Further, the target site showed an elevated AT content at the second (74%), third (84%) and fourth (74%) position when compared to the AT content of the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	158	 To consider the possibility that Tf1 is targeted by a host DNA binding factor we searched for potential binding sites 500 bp upstream and downstream of the different insertion sites using the MACAW software as well as multiple alignment and PROFILE searches, but could not find any consensus sequence.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	159	It has been shown previously that Ty1 elements insert with high frequency within pre-existing LTRs (10).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	160	pombe Tf1 solo LTRs are distributed throughout the genome and occur at a frequency of 1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	161	5 LTRs every 27 intergenic region, as determined by our genome analysis.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The Tf1 insertions in clones 5, 15 and 40 were at a distance of 27 bp, 473 bp and 2.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	163	6 kb to a LTR, respectively, and thereby closer to a LTR than to at least one of the two adjacent ORFs.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	164	 In clone 12, Tf1 inserted even within a LTR.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Although the significance of these findings is difficult to evaluate it remains a possibility that Tf1 has a preference for LTRs, either by being targeted directly to LTR sequences or by a chromatin feature which targeted ancient retroelements to these regions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	166	For budding yeast Ty1 and Ty3 elements, a preference for 5' ends of tRNA genes has been reported previously (6,7).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	167	 However, we did not observe this preference for Tf1.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Furthermore, our analysis revealed that Tf1 integration was not biased towards a particular chromosome or a region on a chromosome (Table 1), with the exception of two Tf1 insertion events which occurred within a distance of 3 kb of each other (clones 21 and 39).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In this region there was no evidence for a local recombination event or the presence of particular sequences, like LTRs or rRNA and tRNA genes.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	170	Tf1 integration had no significant effect on transcription of adjacent genes It has been reported that Ty1 inserts into 5' untranslated regions and can activate, inactivate or confer constitutive expression or mating-type regulation on neighbouring transcriptional units (13).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	171	 P elements can mutate genes in a similar way by preferentially inserting into the 5' untranslated region as well as into a region 100 to 200 bp upstream of the transcription start site (2).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	172	 To analyse the effects of Tf1 insertion on the transcription of adjacent genes, we examined eight transposition clones by northern blot analysis (Table 2).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	173	 As shown in Figure 3, the changes in the transcription level of the examined genes were  < 2-fold and the size of the transcripts remained unchanged when compared to a control.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	174	 These results suggest that, unlike Ty1 and P elements, Tf1 does not preferentially target 5'-UTRs and that the retrotransposon can insert close to ORFs without interfering with transcription.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Since very little is known about the size of promoter regions in S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	176	pombe we speculate that these might be small in some genes and remain unaffected by an upstream Tf1 insertion.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Alternatively, Tf1 might have affected the function of some transcription regulation elements upon insertion, but the retroelement controls the expression of adjacent genes with its own LTR-located promoter and enhancer elements, as it has been described for Ty1 elements (29,30).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Northern blot analysis of genes adjacent to Tf1 insertions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The transcription level and the size of the transcript of the two genes adjacent to a Tf1 insertion were analysed by northern blot.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The names of the gene transcripts detected from transposition (m) and control clones (wt) are shown to the right of the gels.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	181	 No transcript was detected for SPCC777.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	182	 As a loading control, rRNA was stained with methylene blue for the 3.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	183	8 kb band, or the his3 transcript level was monitored.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	184	  Tf1 did not disrupt the wee1 ORF in a screen for cdc25 revertants To investigate the frequency of Tf1 insertion into a particular gene we screened for transposon induced revertants of a temperature-sensitive cdc25-22 mutant because generally such revertants are due to inactivation of the wee1 ORF (31).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	185	 We induced transposition from the pHL414 plasmid in a cdc25 temperature-sensitive strain at the permissive temperature, followed by selection of cells able to grow at the restrictive temperature on 5-FOA and G418.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	186	 We screened  > 8 x 106 cells carrying a Tf1 insertion and would have expected to obtain approximately 1700 Tf1 integrations in the wee1 ORF if transposition were completely random.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	187	 However, we obtained only two transposition clones which grew at 36 degrees C and their revertant phenotype was not due to a Tf1 insertion within or close to the wee1 gene as shown by Southern blotting (Fig.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This result is consistent with our previous findings that Tf1 targets 5' ends of ORFs without affecting the expression of the encoded protein.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	189	 In preliminary experiments we used a modified transposition protocol and screened for transposition clones auxotrophic for glutamate, adenine, histidine or lysine.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	190	 No auxotrophic mutants with a transposon insertion were found.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	191	Physiological stress did not alter Tf1 transposition In order to see if we could increase or randomise transposition, we induced transposition while subjecting S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	192	pombe cells to various treatments which were reported to increase transposition of Ty1 elements (32 to 34).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	193	 We investigated transposition during (i) damaging DNA with 20  microg/ml bleomycin or 4.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	194	2 mM 4-nitroquinoline-1-oxide, (ii) osmotic stress with 100 mM ss-mercaptoethanol or 10% dimethyl sulphoxide, (iii) changing the chromatin structure by depolymerising microtubules with 100  microg/ml thiabendazole or 25  microg/ml methyl-ss-cyclodextrin, (iv) meiosis, (v) nitrogen starvation, and (vi) in block and release assays using hydroxyurea and temperature shifts.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	195	 However, none of these treatments resulted in significant changes in the quantity or quality of Tf1 transposition (data not shown) as monitored by determining the transposition efficiency (21) and by using the screen for cdc25 revertants, respectively.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	196	Tf1 might target 5' ends of ORFs by interacting with a host factor We have shown that Tf1 does not insert into ORFs and that Tf1 insertion occurred preferentially in large intergenic regions, with a bias towards a 320 bp region located 100 bp upstream of the translation start site.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Northern blot analysis of genes adjacent to Tf1 insertions did not reveal any significant changes in the transcription level or size of the corresponding transcript.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Consistent with these results, we propose that Tf1 is targeted region-specific close to the 5' ends of ORFs by a DNA binding host factor.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	199	 This could be a component associated with chromatin structure because it has been shown previously that Tf1 transposition is decreased in the presence of the histone deacytelase inhibitor Trichostatin A (35).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Furthermore, the retrotransposon encodes a chromo motif (chromatin organisation modifier) (36) which could mediate interactions with chromatin-associated factors (37).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Alternatively, or in addition, a transcription-related factor could target Tf1 to 5' ends of ORFs, as it has been described for Ty1 elements (5,7 to 9,38).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	202	 In the case of Tf1, however, this factor is more likely to be associated with the Pol II transcription complex because Tf1 insertion is not biased towards Pol III-transcribed genes.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	203	 However, we failed to detect any DNA binding factor sites although these may have been too degenerate or short to be detected.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	204	pombe genome is densely packed with ORFs, the size of intergenic regions is limited (see earlier), and so larger intergenic regions may contain a higher number of target sequences for factors involved in the regulation of chromatin structure and/or transcription.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Therefore, Tf1 might preferably insert into large intergenic regions because the host factor(s) targeting the retroelement is more likely to be present in these regions.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	206	The isolation of Tf1 insertions in our study was based on the expression of the neo gene.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Thus, it is possible that some other Tf1 targets were not detected because they are in silent regions of the genome, such as the centromere, the telomeres or the mating type loci (39 to 41).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Analysis of unselected transposition events will therefore be an important task for future studies.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	209	Application of Tf1 as tool for molecular biology Transposons have proven to be very helpful molecular tools.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	210	 They have been used as insertional mutagens to tag genes (42), and to generate transcriptional and translational fusions (43).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Our analysis has shown that Tf1 is not suitable for insertional mutagenesis; however, altering the target site specificity of Tf1 through random mutagenesis might turn it into a useful tool for this application (44).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	212	 In this respect it would also be important to know whether target site specificity of Tf1 is changed in mutant strains with an altered chromatin structure, as is the case for some Ty elements (30,45 to 47).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Similarly, treating cells with Trichostatin A, which results in a reduced Tf1 transposition (35), could alter target site preference.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	214	 In addition to providing information about transposition and target site selectivity, the Tf1 system could provide a useful tool with which to probe and dissect chromatin structure in vivo as already suggested for retrotransposons (1,7,47).
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	215	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   We are grateful to H.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Levin for kindly providing the pHL414 plasmid and to John Sgouros and the Sanger Centre for provding information on the S.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We thank David Ish-Horowicz, Joyce Muller, Heidi Browing, Damian Brunner and all other members of the cell cycle laboratory for help and comments on the manuscript.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	218	 was also supported by a fellowship of Boehringer Ingelheim Fonds.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	219	   FOOTNOTES   * To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Tel: +44 20 7269 3276; Fax: +44 20 7269 3610; Email: r.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	221	   REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS AND DISCUSSION REFERENCES   1 Craig,N.

0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	224	 (eds), Molecular and Cellular Biology of the Yeast Saccharochomyces cerevisiae: Genome Dynamics, Protein Synthesis, and Energetics.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	226	 (1995) Science, 267, 1488 to 1491.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	227	 (1992) Biotechnology, 24, 122 to 139.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	228	 (1994) Yeast, 10, 1793 to 1808.
0.308273.11095681.html.plaintext.txt	229	 (1999) Science, 285, 901 to 906.
