0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	0	Peroxisome Proliferator-activated Receptor -mediated Transcriptional Up-regulation of the Hepatocyte Growth Factor Gene Promoter via a Novel Composite cis-Acting Element* Jie-Gen Jiang, Carla Johnson, and Reza Zarnegar.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Pathology, Division of Cellular and Molecular Pathology, University of Pittsburgh, School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, February 21, 2001, and in revised form, April 4, 2001.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	3	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	4	Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a pleotropic polypeptide that can function as a morphogen, motogen, mitogen, angiogen, carcinogen, and tumor suppressor, depending on the target cell and tissue.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Previous studies from our laboratory using transgenic mice have shown that HGF gene expression is tightly regulated at the transcriptional level and that the upstream regulatory elements are crucial for the control of HGF gene transcription.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In the present study, we have identified and characterized one of these elements as a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor  (PPAR)-responsive element.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	7	 This regulatory element was localized at 246 to 233 base pairs upstream from the transcription start site of the HGF gene promoter having the sequence GGGCCAGGTGACCT.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Gel mobility shift and supershift assays demonstrated that this cis-acting element strongly binds to the PPAR isoforms as well as to chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor, a member of the orphan nuclear receptor subfamily.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Mutational analysis and gel mobility band shift assays indicated that the binding site is an inverted repeat of the AGGTCA motif with two spacers (inverted repeat 2 configuration) and that the two spacers are important for PPAR binding.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This binding site overlaps with functional binding sites for activating protein-2, nuclear factor 1, and upstream stimulatory factor, and together, they constitute a multifunctional composite binding site through which these different transcription factors exert their regulatory effects on HGF promoter activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Functional assays revealed that PPAR, with its ligand, 15-deoxy-prostaglandin J2, strongly stimulates HGF promoter activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	12	 On the other hand, nuclear factor 1, activating protein-2, and chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor transcription factors repress the stimulatory action of PPAR by competing with PPAR for their overlapping binding sites.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Furthermore, for the first time, our studies demonstrate that the PPAR ligand, 15-deoxy-prostaglandin J2, induces endogenous HGF mRNA and protein expression in fibroblasts in culture.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	14	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	15	Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF)1 is expressed in the stromal cell compartment of a variety of tissues and acts on neighboring epithelial cells in a paracrine fashion.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HGF stimulates cell growth, cell motility, and morphogenesis on its target cells through binding and activating its specific tyrosine kinase cell surface receptor known as Met (1-5).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Gene knockout studies have shown that HGF has an essential role in liver growth during embryonic development (6, 7).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In adulthood, HGF also plays an important role in supporting the maintenance and renewal of cells in various organs such as liver, lung, and kidney.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	19	HGF gene expression is regulated by extracellular cues such as hormones and cytokines (8-12).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In vivo, the level of HGF mRNA dramatically increases in response to cell loss to facilitate tissue regeneration.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	21	 For example, HGF mRNA increases in the liver as well as in distal organs such as lung and spleen after loss of hepatic tissue induced by partial hepatectomy or hepatotoxin treatment.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Similarly, after injury to the lung or kidney (by toxins or by surgical procedures such as unilateral pneumonectomy or nephrectomy, respectively), HGF gene expression is induced in these organs to promote their regeneration (13, 14).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	23	Several studies have shown that HGF gene expression is controlled tightly at the transcriptional level.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In vivo analyses of HGF gene promoter regulation in transgenic mice (15) as well as in in vitro transient transfection studies have shown that important regulatory element(s) exist in the proximal promoter region of the HGF gene (16-20).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In recent studies, we have partially characterized this region and revealed that it harbors a composite element located at position 260 to 230 bp from the transcriptional start site.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We showed that this composite site binds to members of the nuclear factor 1 (NF1), activating protein-2 (AP2), and upstream stimulatory factor (USF) families to regulate HGF gene transcription.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Functional studies show that NF1 and AP2 suppress the activity of the HGF gene promoter whereas USF has an activating function (21, 22).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	28	In the present studies, we discovered that this region (260 to 230) also harbors a functional PPAR-responsive element at 246 to 233 bp from the +1 site of the HGF gene promoter having the sequence GGGCCAGGTGACCT.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	29	 This is apparently a novel PPAR site, which has an inverted RGGTCA motif with two spacer (IR2), rather than the well described DR1 (direct RGGTCA motif with one spacer) (23, 24).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Gel mobility shift and supershift assays using nuclear extracts from various sources such as whole liver, isolated non-parenchymal liver cells, fibroblast cell lines, and in vitro translated PPAR1 and PPAR2 protein demonstrated that this element binds to the nuclear receptor PPAR family.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Additionally, we found that COUP-TF, an orphan nuclear receptor, also binds to this nuclear hormone binding site and negates the stimulatory effects of PPAR.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Functional studies revealed that PPAR, with its ligand, 15-deoxy-PGJ2, strongly stimulates HGF promoter activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	33	 On the other hand, NF1 and AP2 transcription factors repress the stimulatory function of PPAR by competing with PPAR for their individual overlapping binding sites present within this composite element.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Moreover, for the first time, our studies demonstrated that the PPAR ligand, 15-deoxy-PGJ2, induces the expression of the endogenous HGF mRNA and protein in cultured fibroblasts.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	35	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	36	7 mouse HGF-CAT promoter construct (699 to +29 bp) was described in an earlier work from our laboratory (16).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	37	7 HGF-CAT/NF1-M, in which the NF1 binding site was mutated, was created by a sequential PCR mutagenesis method (21).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	38	 COUP-TFI and AP2 expression vectors were gifts from Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Tsai, Baylor Medical College, and Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Buettner at the University of Regensberg, Germany, respectively.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	41	 COUP-TFI in vitro expression vectors were from Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Xiao-Kan Zhang, University of San Diego, San Diego, CA.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Bin Gao at the Medical College of Virginia generously provided the NF1/X expression vector.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Mouse PPAR1, PPAR2, and PPAR expression vectors, as well as RXR, were generous gifts from Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Bruce Spiegelman, Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	46	Preparation of Nuclear Extracts-- Mouse NIH3T3 and 3T3-L1 fibroblasts were originally obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (Manassas, VA) and cultured in the conditions suggested by the American Type Culture Collection.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Cells were grown to ~90% confluence, washed twice with cold phosphate-buffered saline, and scraped with a rubber policeman in the same buffer.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Nuclear protein extracts were prepared as described previously (20).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Rat liver non-parenchymal cells were prepared from collagenase-perfused rat liver followed by centrifugation at 50  x  g to remove hepatocytes and were provided by Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Michalopoulos in our department.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	51	 They were used to prepare nuclear protein extract.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	52	A rat liver stellate cell line (Ito cell line) was kindly provided by Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Rojkind from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and cultured as described previously (25, 26).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	54	 For preparation of mouse liver nuclear protein extracts, livers were removed from mice and homogenized in buffer A containing protease inhibitors (20).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The nuclei were collected, and the nuclear proteins were extracted by the same method as described above.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	56	DNA Transfection and CAT Assay-- Mouse 3T3-L1 fibroblasts were cultured in 6-well plates for 24 h and then transfected with various mouse HGF promoter-CAT chimerical plasmids using the DNA calcium phosphate method according to the instructions of the CellPhect transfection kit (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) as described previously (19).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The -galactosidase reference plasmid pCH110 (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) was used as an internal control for monitoring the transfection efficiency and normalizing the data accordingly.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The amount of plasmid used per well in transfection was as follows: 5  microg of one chimerical CAT construct and 1  microg of pCH110.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After coprecipitation of the cells with DNA-calcium phosphate for 16 h in serum-containing medium, the cells were washed twice with serum-free medium and kept in serum-containing medium for an additional 24 h before harvesting for determination of CAT activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	60	 CAT activity was determined as described previously (19, 20).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Transfections were performed at least three separate times with two independent preparations of purified plasmid DNA.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	62	For cotransfection with COUP-TFI, AP2, NF1/X, RXR, and PPAR1 in 3T3-L1 cells, the amount of plasmid used per well in transfection was as follows: 5  microg of one chimerical CAT construct, 1  microg of pCH110, and different amounts of expression plasmids.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The total amount of DNA per well was equilibrated by addition of corresponding empty (no insert) expression plasmid.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	64	Oligonucleotides and Antibodies-- The following oligonucleotides and antibodies were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	65	 and used in gel mobility shift and supershift assays: NF1, 5'-TTTTGGATTGAAGCCAATATGATAA-3'; USF, 5'-CACCCGGTCACGTGGCCTACACC-3'; RXRE (DR-1), 5'-AGCTTCAGGTCAGAGGTCAGAGAGCT-3'; and anti-PPAR, anti-PPAR, anti-Sp1, anti-RXR, anti-thyroid hormone, anti-COUP-TF (which can react with both COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII), anti-nerve growth factor-induced B, and anti-vitamin D receptor antibodies.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	66	Gel Retardation Assays-- The double-stranded oligonucleotides used in gel mobility shift assays were labeled with [-32P]dCTP by end labeling with the Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The labeled oligonucleotide probes were then gel-purified and used in gel mobility shift assays as described previously (21).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Two  microg of poly(dI-dC) (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) were used as the nonspecific competitor in 10  microl of reaction mixture.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	69	 When antibodies for supershift were used, they (1  microl) were incubated with nuclear extracts at room temperature for 20 min before performing the DNA binding shift assays.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The binding reactions were carried out at room temperature for another 20 min before loading onto 5% nondenaturing polyacrylamide (19:1, acrylamide/bisacrylamide) gels.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The amount of the nuclear protein extract used in each reaction was about 4  microg, and that of the labeled probe was between 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	72	 For competition experiments, a 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled oligonucleotides was included in reaction mixtures.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	73	001 M EDTA) at a constant voltage of 210 V, dried, and autoradiographed with intensifying screens.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	74	RNA Isolation and Analysis-- Total RNA was isolated by using RNAzol B solution (Cinna/Biotecx, Friendswood, TX) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The RNA concentration was determined by measuring the absorbance at 260 nm.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	76	 For quantitative RT-PCR, 1  microg of total RNA was reverse-transcribed by using AMV reverse transcriptase (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) in reverse transcriptase reaction and amplified for 25 cycles (the number of cycles were optimized to ensure that quantitative assessment could be performed) with Taq DNA polymerase (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) per the manufacturer's instructions using primers specific to HGF (sense, 5'-ATCAGACACCACACCGGCACAAAT-3'; antisense, 5'-GAAATAGGGCAATAATCCCAAGGAA-3') or -actin (CLONTECH Laboratories).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	77	 -actin served as an RNA integrity and normalization control.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	78	In Vitro Transcription/Translation-- A transcription and translation-coupled reticulocyte lysate system was used to prepare in vitro translated COUP-TFI, mouse PPAR1, PPAR2, PPAR, and mRXR proteins from their cognate expression vectors driven by the T7 promoter (27).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Transcription/translation reactions were carried out in a 50- microl reaction volume as recommended by the supplier (Promega).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The authenticity of translation products was always confirmed in parallel experiments by including radioactive [35S]methionine and radioactive [35S]cysteine in the translation reaction followed by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and autoradiography.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Translation reactions using empty vectors were always included as negative controls in these analyses, including the gel shift assays, to exclude potential false signals.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Translation products were stored at 80  degrees C.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	83	 For each gel mobility shift assay, about 1  microl was used from each translated reaction.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	84	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	85	Identification of a Binding Site for PPAR Transcription Factor in the HGF Gene Promoter-- Our recent studies of the HGF promoter revealed that the proximal promoter region at position 260 to 230 is a multifunctional composite site to which different transcription factors such as NF1, USF, and AP2 can bind and regulate HGF gene transcription (21, 22).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	86	 During those studies, we found that distinct factor(s) also specifically bind to this element that are not related to the NF1, USF, or AP2 families (21).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Within this 30-bp region (260 to 230) of the promoter, we identified RGGTCA hexanucleotide motifs, which are potential binding sites for the nuclear hormone receptor superfamily (23, 28).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	88	 To further characterize the composite binding site and its cognate transcription factors, we radiolabeled the HGF promoter composite element (260 to 230) with 32P and used this oligonucleotide as a probe to perform gel mobility band shift assays.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In these experiments, nuclear protein extracts from 3T3-L1 and NIH3T3 fibroblast cell lines were used.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	90	 1, this DNA element forms several specific complexes, of which the major complex(es) (shown by a large arrow head) are efficiently abrogated by an excess amount of binding site for NF1 (compare lane 2 with lane 4 and lane 7 with lane 9, respectively).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The remaining two complexes, which we have labeled in the figure as C1 and C2, formed by nuclear protein extract from NIH3T3 cells, are abolished by an excess amount of USF and nuclear hormone binding sites (RXRE), respectively (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	92	 We have previously shown by super shift assays that the major complex(es) C contain NF1 isoform(s) and that the C1 complex is composed of USF1 and USF2 isoforms (21).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	93	 1, 3T3-L1 fibroblasts do not have detectable C1 and only form the C2 complex, which is totally abrogated by RXRE (DR1, direct AGGTCA repeat with one spacing) (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Thus, these results extend our previous observation and demonstrate that the complex C2 may contain nuclear hormone receptor(s), because it can be competed by a binding site having an AGGTCA motif (please see Ref.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	95	 To better define the binding site for complex C2, several mutant versions of the promoter element were synthesized (see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	96	 2E for nucleotide sequences) and used as competitors in electrophoretic mobility band shift assays using NF1-depleted 3T3-L1 nuclear protein extracts.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	97	 2A, deletion of up to 11 base pairs from the 5' region did not have a notable effect on the binding activity (because these oligonucleotides still effectively competed with the radiolabeled wild-type probe; Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	98	 2A, lanes 3 and 4, oligonucleotides designated S1 and S2).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	99	 However, when six nucleotides from the 3' region were truncated, the resulting oligonucleotide totally lost its competitive ability (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	100	 These results revealed that the binding site for C2 should be between 249 and 230.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Close examination of the promoter element (249 to 230) indicated that it harbors a potential RGGTCA inverted repetitive sequence separated by two nucleotides (IR2) (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The AGGTCA site is known as the perfect nuclear hormone binding half-site, although in almost every case, it is a variation of this sequence known as imperfect motif (28).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Indeed, comparison of the nucleotide sequence of this 31-base pair element among the mouse, rat, and human HGF promoters revealed perfect conservation of this site (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	104	 To define the binding site for the C2 complex in more detail, several mutated oligonucleotides were synthesized and used in gel shift competition assays, as above, using fibroblast nuclear extracts (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Mutations in the AGGTCA half-site in the 3' region abolished the binding capability (mutant oligonucleotides named M4 and M5 in which AGGTCA is mutated to AGGGAC and CTTTCA, respectively) (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Conservative mutations in the 5'-half-site RGGTCA motif (GGGCCA to AAGCCA or GGGAAA and also mutations in the two spacers (GG to AT) (oligonucleotides named M1, M2, and M3, respectively)) did not dramatically affect binding, because these oligonucleotides still competed with the labeled probe for binding (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	107	 However, mutation in the 5'-half-site that totally changes the hexanucleotide from GGGCCA to TTTGGC completely abolished its binding activity (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	108	 To define the role of the two spacers in the IR2 configuration, we generated additional mutant oligonucleotides as indicated in Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	109	 2E and used them as competitors.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	110	 2D, deleting of one or both spacer nucleotides (GG) dramatically reduced the binding activity (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	111	 On the other hand, mutating the two putative spacers from GG to TT did not affect the binding activity (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	112	 These results implied that the RGGTCA half-sites and the two-spacer configuration are important for binding of complex C2 to this region.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	113	 As mentioned above, it is well known that the RGGTCA is the binding half-site for some members of the nuclear receptor superfamily (23, 28).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Therefore, several antibodies against the members of the nuclear receptor superfamily were used to identify complex C2 by supershift assays using fibroblast nuclear extract; these antibodies were against retinoic acid receptor, OR-1, thyroid hormone receptor, COUP-TF, vitamin D receptor, and nerve growth factor-induced B.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	115	 None of these antibodies reacted with the C2 complex (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Further analysis using additional antibodies against other nuclear receptors revealed that anti-PPAR antibody reacted with and totally supershifted complex C2 formed by the fibroblast nuclear extracts (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Neither anti-RXR antibody nor an unrelated antibody (anti-Sp1; see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	118	 3, lanes 4 and 8) reacted with complex C2.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Taken together, the data clearly show that PPAR binds to the HGF promoter element located at 246 to 233 bp from the transcription start site.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	120	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	121	   Identification of a nuclear receptor binding site in the composite regulatory element in the HGF promoter region.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Synthetic oligonucleotides corresponding to the 31-bp DNA fragment from 260 to 230 bp in the HGF gene promoter were labeled with 32P and incubated with nuclear protein extract (NPE) from NIH3T3 and 3T3-L1 fibroblasts.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The binding reactions were performed at room temperature for 20 min in the presence of the nonspecific competitor poly(dI-dC).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Consensus NF1, USF, and RXRE (DR1), as well as unlabeled self-double-stranded oligonucleotides, were used as competitors.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The complexes labeled C and indicated by a large arrow contain NF1 isoforms; the complex labeled C1 contains USF1 and USF2 (21); and the C2 complex contains a putative nuclear receptor; F denotes free 32P-labeled oligonucleotide probe.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	126	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	127	   Characterization of the binding motif(s) for the nuclear receptor in the HGF promoter regulatory region.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	128	 A, truncated (shortened from 5' or 3' ends as indicated in E) oligonucleotides S1, S2, and S3 corresponding to the promoter element were synthesized and used as competitors in gel mobility competition assays using NF1-depleted nuclear protein extract from 3T3-L1 fibroblasts and the wild-type HGF promoter element (260 to 230) as a probe.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	129	 B, analysis of the potential RGGTCA motifs within the regulatory region (from 260 to 230 bp) of the mouse HGF gene promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	130	 RGGTCA inverted repeats separated by two nucleotides (IR2) were identified as indicated by arrows.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	131	 For comparison, the nucleotide sequences of the rat and human HGF promoter element are also presented.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The functional binding sites for NF1, USF, AP2, and an E box (i.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	133	 USF binding site) are also shown.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	134	 C, mutated oligonucleotides M1-M5 (for sequence information, please see E) were synthesized and used as competitors as described under A.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	135	 D, the S2 oligonucleotide was labeled and used as a probe with NIH3T3 nuclear extracts to further define the IR2 site.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The nuclear extract used in this gel shift assay was not depleted of NF1.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The DR1 site (direct AGGTCA motif with one spacing) was also used as competitor.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	138	 E, the nucleotide sequences of the wild-type and mutant versions of the promoter element used to define the PPAR binding site are shown.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The mutated nucleotides are underlined.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Self-competitor (wild-type unlabeled probe) was used as a positive control.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	141	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	142	   Identification of the nuclear receptor as PPAR and its binding motif as an IR2.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Supershift assays of complex C2 bound to the HGF promoter regulatory element using antibodies against various nuclear receptors as indicated in the figure.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	144	 NF1-depleted nuclear protein extracts from the NIH3T3 fibroblasts and 3T3-L1 fibroblasts were used as indicated in the figure.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	145	 C1 denotes complex C1; C2 denotes complex C2; F denotes free probe; S denotes supershift complex.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	146	Regulatory Function of PPAR and Its Ligand 15-Deoxy-PGJ2 on the HGF Gene Promoter Activity-- To demonstrate whether the PPAR binding site and its binding transcription factor PPAR have regulatory function on the HGF gene promoter, we performed cotransfection experiments with HGF-CAT promoter constructs and PPAR1 expression vector.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Because the PPAR binding site overlaps with those of NF1 and USF and because we have shown that NF1 strongly suppresses HGF gene promoter activity (21), we decided to eliminate the interference of NF1 with the PPAR function.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	148	 To do this, two different HGF-CAT constructs were generated and used: the wild-type 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	149	7 HGF-CAT construct and its mutated version, the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	150	7 HGF-CAT/NF1-M construct, in which the NF1 site is mutated but the PPAR binding site remains intact.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	151	1 HGF-CAT, which does not have the NF1 and PPAR binding sites, was also used as a negative control.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	152	 We selected the 3T3-L1 cell line because the nuclear protein extract from this cell line did not form a USF complex (C1) (see Figs.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	153	 1 and 3) with this element that may interfere with the PPAR function.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	154	 4, 15-deoxy-PGJ2, the PPAR ligand, significantly induced the promoter activities of both the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	155	7 HGF-CAT/NF1-M constructs but not the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Overexpression of PPAR1 and treatment with its ligand, 15-deoxy-PGJ2, had an even stronger stimulatory effect on both the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	157	7 HGF-CAT/NF1-M constructs (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	158	 It is believed that RXR is the functional partner of PPAR through heterodimer formation (28).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Even though we did not see an obvious supershift complex by anti-RXR antibody using fibroblast nuclear extracts (see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	160	 3), it is possible that the nuclear protein extracts from NIH3T3 and 3T3-L1 cells do not contain a sufficient amount of RXR binding activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In fact, we show that the HGF PPAR element binds to both PPAR and RXR using liver nuclear protein extract, which is presumably rich in RXR (see below).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	162	 To find out whether RXR can regulate the HGF gene promoter through binding to this IR2 element as a partner of PPAR, RXR expression vector and its ligand, 9-cis-RA, were used in cotransfection CAT assay experiments using a fibroblast cell line.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	163	 4, 9-cis-RA itself had a modest effect, but a combination of 9-cis-RA plus its receptor, RXR, strongly stimulated HGF promoter activity, similar to 15-deoxy-PGJ2 with its receptor, PPAR.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The strongest induction of the promoter was achieved by cotransfection of PPAR and RXR expression vectors in the presence of 15-deoxy-PGJ2 (the PPAR ligand) and 9-cis-RA (the RXR ligand) (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Because PPAR/RXR could induce the promoter activity of the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	166	7 HGF-CAT/NF1-M construct, these results indicate that PPAR/RXR may not only indirectly (via competing with NF1 binding), but also directly, stimulate the HGF promoter through binding to a functional RGGTCA motif in the HGF proximal promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	167	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	168	   Functional analysis of the PPAR binding site in the HGF gene promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Wild-type HGF-CAT reporter construct (0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	170	7 HGF-CAT) and the mutated HGF-CAT reporter plasmid (0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	171	7 HGF-CAT/NF1-M), which harbors a mutation in the NF1 binding site, were used to determine the function of PPAR on the activity of the HGF promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	172	 3T3-L1 cells were transiently transfected with the HGF-CAT constructs described above.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	173	 For cotransfection, 5  microg of RXR and PPAR1 expression vectors per each reaction were added.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	174	 RXR ligand, 9-cis-RA, and PPAR ligand, 15-deoxy PGJ2, were also added to activate their cognate receptors.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	175	1 HGF-CAT construct was used as a negative control.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The data are presented as relative CAT activity (percent conversion) and are from three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Error bars represent the standard deviation.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	178	Binding of the Nuclear Hormone Element with RXR, PPAR, and COUP-TF from Liver Tissue and Related Cells-- It is well known that the HGF gene is expressed in mesenchymal, but not epithelial, cells of a given tissue.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In the liver, HGF is expressed in the non-parenchymal mesenchymal cells (especially stellate cells, also known as the Ito cells or lipocytes because they store lipids and vitamin A).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	180	 We tested whether the HGF promoter element could bind to PPAR and possibly other transcription factors present in non-parenchymal liver cells.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Nuclear protein extracts from whole liver and cells isolated from liver, such as freshly isolated non-parenchymal cells, as well as an Ito cell line (25, 26), were prepared.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	182	 We then subjected these extracts to gel mobility shift assay using the HGF promoter composite site as a probe.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The probe bound to PPAR present in all three different nuclear protein extracts, as shown by supershift assays (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	184	 5, lanes 2 and 7, and data not shown for whole liver).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	185	 A surprising finding in these experiments was that this element could also strongly bind to COUP-TF, a member of the orphan nuclear receptor subfamily, which also binds to the RGGTCA motif (see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The fact that anti-COUP-TF totally supershifted the C2 complex whereas anti-PPAR partially did so (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	187	 5, compare lanes 2 and 3) suggests that PPAR and COUP-TF may form heterodimers on the HGF promoter element.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Of course, it is known that COUP-TF also forms homodimers; thus, it is likely that the C2 complex in the nuclear extract of liver cells is mainly composed of COUP-TF homodimer as well as COUP-TF and PPAR heterodimers.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	189	 On the other hand, the C2 complex produced by fibroblast nuclear extracts lacks any COUP-TF, because it did not react with anti-COUP-TF (data not shown; also see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Anti-RXR antibody was also used in these experiments, because RXR is believed to be the partner of PPAR, as mentioned above.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	191	 We did detect weak RXR binding to this element with the nuclear protein extracts from whole liver tissue (the shifted band was very faint and required a very long exposure of the film) (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Taken together, the results imply that the PPAR binding site in the HGF gene promoter also binds to COUP-TF and RXR, depending on the cell types/tissues analyzed (i.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	193	 fibroblasts versus liver cells).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	194	View larger version (61K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	195	   The IR2 element in the HGF promoter composite site binds to the nuclear receptors PPAR and COUP-TF present in the nuclear protein extracts from liver cells.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Supershift assays were carried out using various antibodies as indicated and nuclear protein extracts from an Ito cell line derived from rat liver and from freshly isolated non-parenchymal rat liver cells (NPC).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	197	 In this experiment, the HGF promoter composite element was used as a probe.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Unlabeled probe (cold self) was used as a competitor to confirm specificity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	199	 S denotes the supershifted complex.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	200	To confirm that COUP-TF truly binds to the HGF proximal promoter composite element, in vitro translated COUP-TF transcription factor was prepared and used in gel mobility shift assays.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Indeed, in vitro translated COUP-TF could specifically and avidly bind to this region, as shown in Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Unlabeled excess probe totally competed for this complex (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Moreover, anti-COUP-TF antibody reacted with and shifted this complex (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	204	 On the other hand, anti-PPAR antibody did not react with this complex (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	205	 These results prove that COUP-TF binds specifically to this region.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	206	 To define the binding motif(s) for COUP-TF in this region, gel shift competition assays were performed using the truncated oligonucleotides S1-S3 and the mutated oligonucleotides M1-M5 (see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	207	 S1 oligonucleotide retained all of its binding activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	208	 S2 oligonucleotide retained some of its binding ability, but the S3 oligonucleotide totally lost its binding ability for COUP-TF (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Similarly, the competitive ability of M1, M2, and M3 mutated oligonucleotides reduced only modestly.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	210	 However, the binding ability for COUP-TF was totally abrogated when the AGGTCA motif in the 3' end of the element was mutated (oligonucleotides M4 and M5; data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Combining all of the above results, we conclude that COUP-TF also binds to the composite site in this regulatory region of the HGF gene promoter (see Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	212	 It should be added that the specific binding of the PPAR isoforms (PPAR1 and PPAR2) to the HGF promoter element was also confirmed in a series of gel mobility band shift and super shift assays using in vitro translated mouse PPAR1, PPAR2, and RXR (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	213	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	214	   Characterization of the COUP-TF binding motif in the HGF promoter composite element.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	215	 In vitro translated COUP-TFI protein was used in these experiments.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Supershift assays were performed with antibody against COUP-TF and the wild-type HGF promoter element as a probe.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Self-competitor was used to show the specific binding of COUP-TFI with this element.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Antibody against PPAR was used as a negative control.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The COUP-TF1 complex is indicated by an arrow.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	220	 S denotes the supershift complex.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Negative controls for the in vitro translation product (empty vector control subjected to the in vitro translation reaction) and gel shift assays were also carried out to also ensure specificity (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	222	Modulation of PPAR Function on the HGF Gene Promoter by COUP-TF, NF1, and AP2-- Because our data showed that COUP-TF binds to the same binding site as that for PPAR, it is reasonable to suppose that COUP-TF homodimers could modify the stimulatory function of PPAR/RXR by competing with one another for their common binding site.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Additionally, published data demonstrate that COUP-TF can form heterodimers with RXR in solution in the absence of their binding site.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In this manner, COUP-TF sequesters RXR, preventing PPAR/RXR heterodimer formation and the stimulatory function of PPAR/RXR.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Furthermore, the binding sites for COUP-TF and PPAR/RXR overlap with the binding sites for the suppressive transcription factors NF1 and AP2.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Therefore, the functionality of this unique composite element to regulate HGF gene expression in a given tissue or cell may be dependent on the specific combination, and/or the various concentrations, of transcription factors.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	227	 To show the individual functions of these transcription factors and how they interact to exert their effects, we used the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	228	3 HGF-CAT promoter construct, which has a basal promoter and the proximal region of the HGF promoter having the composite site containing the NF1, AP2, and IR2 binding motifs.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	229	1 HGF-CAT construct as a negative control, because it only contains the basal promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	230	 7, COUP-TF dose-dependently repressed the stimulatory function of PPAR/RXR on the HGF gene promoter in the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	231	 It did not have significant repressive function on the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	232	 In similar experiments using the expression vectors for the NF1/X isoform and AP2 co-transfected with HGF-CAT constructs we found that they also inhibited the stimulatory function of PPAR/RXR on the HGF gene promoter in the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	233	3 HGF-CAT construct but not in the 0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	234	1 HGF-CAT construct (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In these experiments, empty vector controls did not have any effect on the activity of either HGF-CAT construct (data not shown).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	236	 These experiments indicate that NF1, AP2, and COUP-TFI could individually down-regulate the stimulatory function of PPAR/RXR on HGF gene expression and that they may do this through competing with PPAR/RXR for the overlapping composite binding site in the HGF proximal promoter region.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	237	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	238	   Repression of the stimulatory function of PPAR by COUP-TFI on the HGF gene promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	239	1 HGF-CAT reporter plasmids was cotransfected along with 2  microg of PPAR1, 2  microg of RXR, and increasing amounts of COUP-TFI expression vector into the 3T3-L1 fibroblast cell line.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The activity of each promoter construct was determined and is expressed as the relative CAT activity normalized by -galactosidase.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The results are from three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Error bars represent the standard error of the mean.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	243	Induction of Endogenous HGF mRNA and Protein Expression by PPAR Ligand, 15-Deoxy-PGJ2-- To determine whether 15-deoxy PGJ2 can induce endogenous HGF gene expression at the mRNA and protein levels, we treated fibroblasts, which naturally express PPAR, with 15-deoxy PGJ2 and determined the level of HGF mRNA by semi-quantitative RT-PCR and the level of HGF protein by a very sensitive sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The results demonstrated that HGF expression is significantly up-regulated after treatment with 15-deoxy-PGJ2 (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	245	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	246	   Induction of endogenous HGF mRNA and protein by PPAR ligand, 15-deoxy PGJ2, in fibroblasts.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	247	 A, total mRNA was isolated from 3T3-L1 cells that had been treated with 15-deoxy PGJ2 for different lengths of time as indicated.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Semi-quantitative RT-PCR was carried out as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	249	" The size of the internal control -actin is 870 bp (bottom panel).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	250	 RT-PCR for HGF yields a 300-bp HGF product (top panel).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The left lane is the molecular weight marker X174/HaeIII.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	252	 B, MRC-5 human fibroblasts were cultured in 6-well plates and treated with or without (control) 15-deoxy PGJ2 in duplicates.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Culture medium was collected at the indicated time points and then subjected to a sensitive sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay using the R and D HGF enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The amounts of HGF were determined in the culture medium from the standard curve using pure HGF as a standard as recommended by the supplier.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Asterisks indicate statistically significant differences between the control and treated samples (p  <  0.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	256	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	257	In this study, we demonstrated that the nuclear receptors PPAR and COUP-TF bind to a composite regulatory element in the HGF upstream promoter region located at 246 to 233 bp from the transcription start site.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	258	 This binding site also overlaps/harbors functional binding sites for NF1, AP2, and the USF family of transcription factors (21, 22), and together, they constitute a multifunctional composite site to which these various transcription factors can bind and regulate the activity of the HGF promoter.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Cotransfection assays showed that PPAR1, with its partner, RXR, in the presence of their corresponding ligands, 15-deoxy PGJ2 and 9-cis-RA, respectively, strongly stimulated HGF promoter activity.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	260	 NF1, AP2, and COUP-TFI suppressed the stimulatory function of PPAR by competing for their individual binding sites.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Moreover, we demonstrated that 15-deoxy-PGJ2, the ligand of PPAR, induces the expression of the endogenous HGF gene at the mRNA and protein levels in cultured fibroblasts.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	262	PPAR is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily that includes receptors for the steroid, thyroid, and retinoid hormones (23, 28).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	263	 It is known that there are three related but quite distinct PPAR proteins: PPAR, PPAR, and PPAR.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Two forms of PPAR, 1 and 2, exist as products of alternative promoter usage (29, 30).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Like other members of this superfamily, PPAR contains a central DNA binding domain that binds to a cis-acting element in the promoter of its target genes.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Most of the PPAR response elements described are composed of a directly repeating core site separated by one nucleotide (RGGTCA-N-RGGTCA) called DR1 (24, 28).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Interestingly, the PPAR response element in the HGF promoter region is an inverted repeating core site separated by two nucleotides (GGGCCA-NN-TGACCT) that we have called IR2.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Published data indicate that PPAR heterodimerizes with RXR and that the PAR/RXR heterodimer binds to its response element and activates its target genes (23, 31).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Our results indicated that the IR2 site in the HGF gene promoter also binds to RXR, though very weakly.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Generally, RXR is said to be a silent partner.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Nonetheless, there are several examples in which RXR can be an active partner (31).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Similarly, both RXR and PPAR in the RXR/PPAR heterodimers bound to the IR2 element in HGF gene promoter region are independently responsive and are synergistically activated in the presence of both ligands, 15-deoxy PGJ2 and 9-cis-RA.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	273	PPAR plays an essential role in cell growth and differentiation as well as in oncogenesis.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Controversies exist on whether PPAR acts as a tumor promoter or tumor suppressor.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	275	 For example, ligand activation of PPAR causes most, but not all, colon cancer cell lines to undergo a differentiating response and reverse their malignant phenotype (32).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Paradoxically, ligand activation of PPAR in min mice, an animal model for familial adenomatous polyposis, seemed to cause increased polyposis (33, 34).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	277	 It is demonstrated that loss-of-function mutations in PPAR are also associated with human colon cancer (35).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	278	 It is not clear whether this association between colon cancer and PPAR is involved in HGF expression in colon cancer tissue, because HGF expression is also aberrant in colon cancer tissues.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Additionally, HGF can also function paradoxically as a tumor suppressor and tumor promoter in different settings (2, 3).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Little is known about the target genes activated by PPAR; our present findings shed significant light on the matter in the sense that HGF may mediate some of the functions of PPAR in tissue growth and differentiation and in cancer.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	281	Like HGF, PPAR is expressed in various tissues, but predominantly in the mesenchymal cells, namely adipocytes/fibroblasts (36).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Interestingly, in the liver, HGF is expressed in a specialized fibroblastic cell type called Ito cells, which are also known as lipocytes (because they store lipids and vitamin A).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Like HGF, PPAR is also expressed in the placenta, and its deficiency leads to placental dysfunction and death by E10 (37).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	284	 A qualitatively similar placental abnormality has been seen in RXR knockout mice, suggesting that these phenotypes may be due to impaired PPAR-mediated signaling in the placenta (37).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Interestingly, HGF knockout mice revealed that homozygous HGF mutant embryos have severely impaired placentas with markedly reduced numbers of labyrinthine trophoblast cells, and the embryos die before birth by E15 (6, 7).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Combining these data, it seems possible that HGF may be one of the mediators of the growth regulatory action of PPAR/RXR.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	287	So far, we have identified several functional regulatory elements and their binding transcription factors that act on the HGF gene promoter (Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Based on the current findings and previous published results, we believe that transcriptional regulation of the HGF gene is very complex and is dependent on the combination of all of these transcription factors, including COUP-TF, CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein, Sp1, estrogen receptor, NF1, AP2, USF, and PPAR (15-22).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	289	 CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein , SP1, estrogen receptor, USF, and PPAR are positive regulators.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	290	 COUP-TF, AP2, and NF1 are mainly negative regulators.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	291	 COUP-TFs can compete with both estrogen receptor and PPAR for their respective binding sites and suppress the stimulatory functions of both estrogen receptor and PPAR in the presence of their own ligands (estrogen and 15-deoxy PGJ2, respectively).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	292	 This result implies that COUP-TFs and the NF1 family play an important role in regulation of HGF gene expression.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	293	 As mentioned above, PPAR and CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein  are believed to play an important role in adipocyte differentiation (38).
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Interestingly, we noted that in the 3T3-L1 fibroblasts that differentiate into adipocytes when placed in differentiation medium, a marked increase in PPAR and CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein  binding to the HGF promoter elements occurred and is depicted in Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	295	 The increase in the binding activity correlated well with an increase in HGF and HGF receptor (Met) expression in these cells, implying that the HGF/Met signaling system may have a role in adipocyte differentiation.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	296	 A summary of the positive and negative regulators of the HGF gene promoter that we have identified and characterized thus far is presented in Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	297	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	298	   A diagram depicting several functional cis-acting elements and their cognate transcription factors within the murine HGF promoter region.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	299	 NHR, nuclear hormone receptor; Rep, an unknown repressor; GTF, general transcription factors; C/EBP, CCAAT; IL-1, interleukin 1; TNF, tumor necrosis factor ; EGF, enhancer-binding protein .
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Tsai for providing us with the COUP-TFI expression vector and the antibody against COUP-TF, Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Rojkind for the Ito cell line, Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Xiao-Kan Zhang for the in vitro transcription/translation vector for COUP-TFI, and Dr.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Spiegelman for PPAR and RXR expression vectors.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	304	 DeFrances for critical review of this manuscript.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Michalopoulos for valuable discussions and continuous enthusiasm during the course of this work.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	306	* This work was supported by Grant R01ES 06109 from NIEHS, National Institutes of Health (to R.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	307	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	308	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.

0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	313	: 412-648-8657; Fax: 412-648-1916; E-mail: rezazar@pitt.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	314	Published, JBC Papers in Press, April 5, 2001, DOI 10.
0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	315	The abbreviations used are: HGF, hepatocyte growth factor; bp, base pair(s); NF1, nuclear factor 1; AP2, activating protein-2; USF, upstream stimulatory factor; PPAR, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor; IR, inverted repeat; COUP-TF, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; RT-PCR, reverse transcription-PCR; kb, kilobase pair(s); PGJ2, prostaglandin J2; RXR, retinoic X receptor; RA, retinoic acid.

0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	352	 268, 26817-26820[Abstract/Free Full Text] 37.
