0.25199053.11292834.html.plaintext.txt	354	Copyright   2001 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	0	Activation of the Insulin Gene Promoter through a Direct Effect of Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4* Reut Bartoov-Shifman, Rachel Hertz , Haiyan Wang , Claes B.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Wollheim , Jacob Bar-Tana , and Michael D.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Biological Chemistry, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 76100, Israel, the   Department of Human Nutrition and Metabolism, Faculty of Medicine, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 91120, Israel, and the   Division of Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Internal Medicine, University Medical Center, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, February 15, 2002, and in revised form, May 1, 2002.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	4	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	5	Maturity onset diabetes of the young, subtype 1 (MODY1), is associated with defective glucose-dependent insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	6	 MODY1 is caused by mutation in the transcription factor hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	7	 To understand better the MODY1 phenotype, we tested whether HNF4 was able to modulate directly the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Transfection of cultured 293T cells with an HNF4 expression vector led to 10-fold activation of a cotransfected reporter plasmid containing the rat insulin I gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Computer analysis revealed a potential HNF4-binding site between nucleotides 57 and 69 of the promoter; mutation of this sequence led to reduced ability of HNF4 to activate the promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The ability of HNF4 to bind this sequence was confirmed using gel shift analysis.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In transfected INS-1 beta cells, mutation of either the HNF1 site or the HNF4 site in the insulin gene promoter led to 50-75% reduction in reporter gene activity; expression of dominant negative HNF4 led to significant reduction in the activity of wild type and both mutated promoters.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Thus, in addition to the previously described indirect action of HNF4 on insulin gene expression mediated through elevated HNF1 levels, HNF4 also activates the insulin gene directly, through a previously unrecognized cis element.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	13	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	14	In adult mammals, the insulin gene is expressed exclusively in the beta cells of the endocrine pancreas (1-3).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This selectivity is controlled primarily at the transcriptional level through well defined promoter elements (4-6).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Although a number of transcription factors have been defined that interact with the insulin promoter and activate it in synergistic fashion (7-10), the action of these factors alone is not sufficient to explain the remarkable degree of cell specificity observed in vivo (9).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Most likely, additional transcription factors participate in achieving specificity.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	18	MODY1 is a monogenic form of diabetes characterized by impaired glucose-dependent insulin secretion in the absence of insulin resistance in peripheral tissues (11, 12).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	19	 This indicates that a beta cell defect is the primary cause of MODY and implies that MODY genes have a role in insulin production and/or secretion.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Consistent with this is the fact that four of the five known MODY subtypes are caused by mutations in distinct transcription factors expressed in pancreatic beta cells (13).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The striking MODY phenotype caused by such single gene disorders provides clear evidence of the important role of each of these transcription factors in beta cell function.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	22	MODY1 is caused by mutation in HNF4, a transcription factor of the nuclear receptor subfamily (14).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	23	 At least eight different mutations have been identified in MODY1 patients (15).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Four mutations result in truncated HNF4 proteins, of which two are nonsense mutations (14, 16), and two are frameshift mutations (17, 18).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The other four mutations are missense mutations that affect various domains of the HNF4 protein (19-22).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	26	MODY3 is caused by mutation in the HNF1 gene encoding a transcription factor of the homeodomain family (23).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Like HNF4, HNF1 is expressed in liver and beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In fact, HNF1 was shown to be a direct transcriptional target of HNF4 in liver (24).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Furthermore, a mutation in the HNF4-binding site in the HNF1 gene promoter produces a MODY phenotype (25).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Consistent with these observations, MODY1 and MODY3 show a similar clinical phenotype.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Recent studies (26) have shown that induction of dominant negative (DN) HNF1 in beta cells leads to alterations in expression of a number of beta cell genes including the insulin gene.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Because DN-HNF4 led to reduced activity of the Hnf1 promoter and reduced insulin mRNA levels (27), it was hypothesized that HNF4 increases insulin mRNA levels indirectly by increasing HNF1 levels, which in turn activate the promoter through binding to an HNF1 consensus sequence (28).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	33	Recently, however, strong evidence has been obtained indicating that this hypothesis may be an over-simplification and that the actual relationship between HNF4 and HNF1 may be more complex; it has been shown (29, 30) that P2, the major promoter of the Hnf4 gene in beta cells, is regulated by HNF1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Therefore, activation of beta cell genes by HNF4 may involve more than a simple transcriptional regulatory cascade mediated through HNF1, as previously envisaged.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	35	In this study, we have examined this idea through a detailed analysis of the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In addition to confirming that HNF4 activates insulin gene expression in an indirect fashion, through an HNF1-binding site, we have identified a novel cis element in the insulin gene promoter, which mediates direct activation of the promoter by HNF4 in beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	37	     EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES Cell Culture.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	38	293T, HeLa S3 Tet-Off (CLONTECH PT3001-1), and COS7 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, penicillin (200 IU/ml), and streptomycin (100  microg/ml).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	39	 INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells (27) were cultured in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 25 mM HEPES, 2 mM L-glutamine, 1 mM sodium pyruvate, 50  microM 2-mercaptoethanol, penicillin (200 IU/ml), and streptomycin (100  microg/ml) supplemented with 150  microg/ml G418 and 100  microg/ml hygromycin.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	40	LUC, a plasmid containing the luciferase (LUC) gene controlled by the rat insulin I gene promoter, was generated by replacement of the SV40 promoter of pGL3-promoter vector (Promega) with the insulin promoter fragment (410 to 1).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	41	LUC is the plasmid pGL3-promoter vector (Promega), containing the luciferase gene controlled by the SV40 early promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	42	LUC contains the luciferase gene controlled by the RSV promoter (31).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	43	LUC contains the luciferase gene controlled by -actin promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	44	LUC contains the luciferase gene controlled by CMV enhancer and herpes simplex virus-thymidine kinase (TK) promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The reporter plasmids Synt 5 LUC, Synt 6 LUC, Synt 7 LUC, and Synt 8 LUC contain the luciferase gene controlled by Synt 5-8 block replacement mutants of the rat insulin I promoter (5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	46	LUC was generated by PCR-mediated site-directed mutagenesis of pGL3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The nucleotides mutated (57 to 69) were ACGGCAAAGTCCA to CATTACCCTGAAC.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	48	LUC was generated by subcloning of the mutated insulin promoter from 410MFInsLUC to pGL3-promoter vector (Promega).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The nucleotides mutated (222 to 218) were TTAAT to GTCCG.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The Renilla luciferase internal control plasmid pRL.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	51	RSV contains the Renilla luciferase coding sequence from pRL null vector (Promega) controlled by the RSV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	52	HNF4 encodes rat HNF4 controlled by the SV40 early promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	53	HNF4 encodes rat HNF4 controlled by the CMV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	54	PDX1 is a PDX1 expression vector controlled by the CMV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	55	E2A is a mouse E2A (E47) expression vector (9) controlled by the CMV promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	56	BETA is a BETA2 expression vector encoding hemagglutinin epitope-tagged BETA2 controlled by the CMV promoter (9).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	57	Transfections of 293T, HeLa, and COS7 cells were carried out by the calcium phosphate coprecipitation technique (32).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	58	 4-7 h after addition of DNA, cells were exposed to 20% glycerol in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for 2 min.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Cells were harvested 40-48 h after transfection, and cell extracts were assayed for reporter enzyme activity.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	60	 INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells (27) were transfected using electroporation as follows.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cells were suspended in 450  microl of cold phosphate-buffered saline (calcium/magnesium-free), and plasmid DNA dissolved in 50  microl of H2O was added.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Cells were incubated on ice for 10 min, then transferred to 4-mm gap cuvettes (BTX), and pulsed for 6 ms at 320 V/cm, 975 microfarads using an ECM 830 pulse generator.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	63	 For induction of DN-HNF4, cells were incubated with 1  microg/ml doxycycline for 24 h prior to transfection.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	64	Following transfection, cell extracts were prepared by 3 cycles of freeze-thawing, followed by centrifugation to remove cell debris.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The firefly and Renilla luciferase assays were carried out as follows: extracts containing 5-50  microg (2-5  microl) of protein were added to 50  microl of firefly luciferase assay buffer (Promega E1501) or 100  microl of Renilla luciferase assay buffer (33).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The samples were placed in a luminometer (LUMAC Biocounter M2500), and light output was determined over a 10-s interval.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Statistical significance was evaluated by t test using InStat software.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	68	Oligonucleotides were synthesized corresponding to the HNF4 binding element (HBE) region (5'-gatccGCCCTTAATGGGCCAAACGGCAAAGTCCAGGGa-3') from the rat insulin I promoter (5) (positions 86 to 53) and C3P region (5'-agctGCAGGTGACCTTTGACCAGCTc-3') from the rat ApoCIII promoter (34).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Radioactive probes were generated by incubation of the appropriate annealed oligonucleotides (5 pmol) in the presence of 50  microCi of [-32P]dATP (3,000 Ci/mmol), 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	70	25 mM dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP, and 5 units of DNA polymerase I (New England Biolabs, Klenow fragment) for 40 min at room temperature.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The radiolabeled oligonucleotides were separated from free nucleotide by spin dialysis using Sephadex G-50.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Specific activity obtained was typically ~2,000 cpm/fmol.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	73	Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	74	Cells were transfected with 10  microg of expression plasmids as described above.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Whole cell extracts (10-15  microg of protein) were incubated for 10 min on ice in binding buffer (10 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	76	8, 50 mM KCl, 10% glycerol, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 2.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	77	5 mM MgCl2) containing 600 ng of poly(dI dC) and 600 ng of poly(dA dT) (Sigma) in a final assay volume of 14  microl.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Subsequently, 1  microl of 32P-labeled probe was added (~10 fmol), and incubation was allowed to continue on ice for an additional 25 min.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Samples were subsequently resolved on 6% polyacrylamide gels (37.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	80	5:1 acrylamide/bisacrylamide) in 45 mM Tris borate, 1 mM EDTA (0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	81	5 x  TBE) at 184 V for 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The gel was dried, and the labeled DNA-protein complexes were visualized by autoradiography.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	83	 In supershift experiments, 1  microl of anti-HNF4 antiserum or preimmune serum was added after the first 10 min of incubation, and the mixture was incubated for an additional 10 min before addition of the 32P-labeled probe.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	84	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	85	HNF4 Can Activate the Insulin Gene Promoter-- Because HNF4 was previously shown to affect insulin mRNA levels in beta cells (27), its involvement in the direct transcriptional regulation of the insulin gene was examined.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	86	 293T cells were transfected with a reporter plasmid encoding the luciferase gene controlled by the rat insulin I gene promoter (410 to 1) in the presence or absence of an HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For comparison, cells were also transfected with luciferase reporter plasmids controlled by no promoter or by other promoters as follows: RSV, -actin, CMV.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	88	TK, and SV40 in the presence or absence of HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	89	 HNF4 activated transcription of the insulin gene promoter 9.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	90	 1) but did not activate the other promoters tested, indicating that this activation is specific.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Similar results were obtained upon transfection of HeLa cells (not shown).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	92	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	93	   Activation of the insulin gene promoter by HNF4 protein.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	94	 293T cells were transfected with 1  microg of luciferase reporter plasmid containing either no promoter (pGL3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	95	basic), the rat insulin I gene promoter (pGL3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	96	Synt), or one of the following promoters: SV40, RSV, -actin, or CMV.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	97	TK in the presence of 1  microg of HNF4 expression plasmid (pcDNA3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	98	HNF4) or empty expression plasmid control.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Results are expressed as the ratio of luciferase activity observed in the presence as compared to the absence of HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	101	 of at least three independent transfection experiments for each reporter plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The asterisk indicates statistical significance (p  <  0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	103	0001) in the presence compared to the absence of HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	104	Identification of the Region in the Insulin Gene Promoter Important for HNF4 Activation-- In order to characterize further this HNF4-dependent activation, the insulin gene promoter was scanned for the presence of an HNF4 consensus binding sequence using TESS software (www.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Such a consensus site was found between nucleotides 57 and 69 (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	106	 2), suggesting the presence of an HNF4-binding site in the promoter of the insulin gene.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	107	 To determine whether this putative HNF4-binding site is necessary for HNF4 activation of the insulin gene promoter, we examined the ability of HNF4 to activate the insulin gene promoter mutated at this site.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Four block replacement mutants of the insulin promoter, spanning the consensus binding sequence and designated Synt 5-8, were used (5) (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	109	 As before, 293T cells were transfected with reporter plasmids encoding the luciferase gene controlled by the wild type rat insulin I promoter or by one of its mutated variants, Synt 5-8, in the presence or absence of HNF4 expression plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	110	 HNF4 activation of mutants Synt 5 and Synt 8, in which mutations are located outside the putative HNF4-binding site, was not reduced compared with wild type promoter activation.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	111	 In contrast, mutation Synt 6 and Synt 7, each abolishing a part of the HNF4 consensus site, showed significantly attenuated activation (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	112	 These results indicate that the nucleotides mutated in mutants Synt 6 and Synt 7 are important for HNF4 activation of the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	113	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	114	   A consensus binding site for HNF4 in the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	115	 An HNF4 consensus site (boldface letters) is located between nucleotides 57 and 69 and adjacent to PDX1-binding site (boldface letters).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Block replacement mutants of the insulin promoter, designated Synt 5-8 (5), were generated by mutation of all nucleotides of the relevant portion of the wild type sequence as follows: A  C and G  T.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The location of the HBE probe is also shown.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	118	View larger version (42K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	119	   Block replacement mutations in the HNF4 consensus binding site in the insulin gene promoter reduce HNF4 activation of the promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	120	 293T cells were transfected with 1  microg of luciferase (LUC) reporter plasmid containing the wild type rat insulin I promoter or each of the block replacement mutants Synt 5-8 in the presence of 1  microg of HNF4 expression plasmid (pcDNA3.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	121	HNF4) or empty expression plasmid control.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The nucleotides mutated in Synt 5-8 are 43 to 53, 54 to 63, 64 to 68, and 79 to 88, respectively (5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Results are expressed as the ratio of luciferase activity observed in the presence as compared to the absence of HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	125	 of at least three independent transfection experiments for each reporter plasmid.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Asterisks indicate statistical significance (p = 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	127	0006 for Synt 7) compared with the values obtained for wild type promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	128	HNF4 Can Bind the Insulin Gene Promoter-- We next tested the ability of HNF4 to bind to the putative binding sequence in the insulin gene promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	129	 An EMSA was performed using a probe containing the putative HNF4-binding site, designated the HBE element (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Whole cell extracts were made from HeLa cells transfected with HNF4 expression plasmid and from untransfected HeLa cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Incubation of transfected extracts with the radiolabeled HBE probe resulted in a strong band that was absent when extracts from mock-transfected cells were used (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Competition with unlabeled HBE oligonucleotide abolished this band (lane 3).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Addition of anti-HNF4 serum generated a supershifted band that was not observed with preimmune serum, confirming the presence of HNF4 in the complex (lanes 4 and 5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Apolipoprotein C III (ApoCIII) is a well characterized target gene of HNF4 (35, 36).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Competition with unlabeled oligonucleotide containing the C3P element, an HNF4-binding site in the ApoCIII gene promoter (37), also abolished the observed band (lane 6).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Competition with increasing amounts of unlabeled HBE and C3P probes indicates that HNF4 affinity to its binding site in ApoCIII gene is higher than its affinity to the binding site in the insulin gene (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	137	View larger version (44K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	138	   HNF4 can bind the insulin gene promoter, as demonstrated in EMSA.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	139	 A, whole cell extracts from mock-transfected HeLa cells (lane 1) or HeLa cells transfected with HNF4 expression vector (lanes 2-6) were incubated with 32P-labeled HBE probe and separated on a non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Specificity of binding was analyzed by adding 100- or 60-fold molar excess of unlabeled HBE probe (lane 3) or C3P probe (lane 6), respectively.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The formation of an immune complex is shown with the addition of anti-HNF4 serum (lane 4) and compared with the addition of preimmune serum (lane 5).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	142	 B, affinity of HNF4 to HBE probe is lower than its affinity to C3P probe.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Whole cell extracts made from untransfected COS7 cells (lane 1) or COS7 cells transfected with HNF4 expression vector (lanes 2-10) were incubated with 32P-labeled HBE probe and separated on a non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Competition was performed using 10-, 20-, 50-, and 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled HBE oligonucleotide (lanes 3-6, respectively) or 3-, 10-, 20-, and 50-fold molar excess of unlabeled C3P oligonucleotide (lanes 7-10, respectively).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	145	HNF4 and Other Insulin Gene Transcription Factors-- E2A (38-40), BETA2 (NeuroD) (41, 42), and PDX1 (also known as IPF1, STF1, and IDX1) (43-45) are well characterized insulin gene transcription factors that can synergistically activate the insulin gene promoter when cotransfected to HeLa cells with a reporter gene controlled by the promoter; however, when the insulin promoter construct is transfected to beta cells, it is ~4 times more active (9).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	146	 This implies that additional factor(s), present in beta cells, may be important for insulin gene regulation.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In light of our data showing that HNF4 can bind and activate the insulin gene promoter, its possible cooperation with the other three known insulin gene transcription factors was examined.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	148	 293T cells were transfected with a luciferase reporter plasmid controlled by the rat insulin I gene promoter and with expression plasmids encoding the four transcription factors E2A, BETA2, PDX1, and HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Expression of HNF4 with E2A, BETA2, and PDX1 produced a synergistic activation of the insulin gene promoter that was ~2-fold higher than the activation generated by the three factors alone (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Similar results were obtained upon transfecting HeLa cells (not shown).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	151	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	152	   A, HNF4 enhances the insulin gene promoter activation generated by E2A, BETA2, and PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	153	 293T cells were cotransfected with 1  microg of luciferase reporter plasmid containing the rat insulin I promoter in the presence or absence of 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	154	1  microg of expression vectors encoding HNF4, E2A, BETA2, and PDX1 as indicated.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Results are expressed relative to the activity observed in the presence of E2A + BETA2 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Each bar represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The asterisk indicates statistical significance (p = 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	158	005) compared with the value obtained upon transfection with E2A + BETA2 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	159	 B, HNF4 enhances PDX1 activation of the promoter in a synergistic manner.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	160	 293T cells were cotransfected with 1  microg of luciferase reporter plasmid containing the rat insulin I gene promoter in the presence or absence of 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	161	1  microg of expression plasmids encoding the indicated transcription factors.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Results are expressed relative to the activity observed in the presence of HNF4 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	164	 of 8 independent transfection experiments.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Asterisks indicate statistical significance (p  <  0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	166	0001 for HNF4 and for PDX1) compared with HNF4 + PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	167	To investigate further this augmented activation generated by HNF4, the effect of HNF4 and PDX1 was tested in the absence of E2A and BETA2.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	168	 293T cells were cotransfected with a reporter plasmid encoding the luciferase gene controlled by the rat insulin I promoter and with expression vectors encoding PDX1 and HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Expression of HNF4 and PDX1 generated synergistic activation of the promoter (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Synergistic activation was also observed in HeLa cells (not shown).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	171	 This cooperativity of HNF4 with PDX1 is probably responsible for the synergistic activation observed previously upon coexpression of HNF4 with E2A, BETA2, and PDX1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	172	Mechanism of Action of HNF4 in Beta Cells-- Expression of dominant negative HNF1 in the beta cell line INS-1 reduced the expression of several beta cell genes, including the insulin gene (26), and has similar effects to that of dominant negative HNF4 (27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Furthermore, HNF4 is a transcription activator of HNF1 (24, 27), and mutations in HNF1 are responsible for MODY3 (23).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	174	 This raises the possibility that HNF4 may activate the insulin gene indirectly, through Hnf1 gene function.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In non-beta cells, the HNF4-dependent activation we observed (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	176	 1) may be mediated in part through HNF1, but the substantial reduction in the activation of promoter mutated in the HNF4-binding site (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	177	 3) indicates that a significant portion of the effect is mediated directly.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	178	To assess the significance of the HNF4 site in the insulin gene promoter in beta cells, and to test whether in beta cells HNF4 activates the insulin gene promoter directly or indirectly through HNF1, we used INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells, a derivative of INS-1 cells that contains a plasmid encoding doxycycline-inducible dominant negative HNF4 (27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This dominant negative protein possesses a functional dimerization domain but lacks a DNA binding domain and therefore suppresses activity of the endogenous wild type HNF4.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Luciferase reporter plasmids controlled by wild type rat insulin I gene promoter or by promoter mutated either in HNF1- or HNF4-binding sites were electroporated into these cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In the absence of doxycycline (i.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	182	 no expression of DN-HNF4), mutations in either the HNF4 site or the HNF1 site led to reduced activity of the insulin gene promoter (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Thus both sites are important for full transcriptional activation in beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	184	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	185	   Effect of DN-HNF4 on wild type and mutated insulin gene promoter in beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	186	 A, luciferase reporter genes containing wild type insulin gene promoter (wild type, WT) and insulin gene promoter containing mutations in the HNF1 site (HNF1) or HNF4 site (HNF4) were electroporated into INS-1 DN-HNF4 26 cells in the presence (light bars) and absence (dark bars) of doxycycline (Dox.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Cells were harvested 48 h following electroporation, and normalized luciferase activity was determined.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Results are expressed relative to the activity obtained for wild type promoter in the absence of doxycycline.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Each data point represents the mean  plus or minus  S.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	190	 of at least three independent electroporation experiments.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Asterisks indicate statistical significance (p = 0.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	192	02 for HNF1) in the presence compared to the absence of doxycycline.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	193	 B, model depicting possible effects of DN-HNF4 on insulin gene expression.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	194	To confirm the role of HNF4 and to distinguish between a direct action of HNF4 as compared with an indirect action mediated through HNF1, we compared the activity of wild type and mutated promoters in the presence and absence of doxycycline.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	195	 If HNF4 acts exclusively in an indirect manner, through HNF1, induction of DN-HNF4 should not affect the activity of promoter mutated at the HNF1 site.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In fact, induction of DN-HNF4 significantly reduced the activity of both the wild type promoter and promoter mutated in the HNF1-binding site (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	197	 6A), confirming the involvement of HNF4 in insulin promoter activation, and showing that at least part of this effect does not involve HNF1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Furthermore, expression of DN-HNF4 led to significant reduction in activity of a promoter fragment mutated in the HNF4 site (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	199	 6A), confirming that HNF4 also increases insulin gene transcription through an indirect effect via HNF1 (Fig.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Although this experimental system does not permit quantitative comparison of the relative contribution of the direct effects as compared with the indirect effects of HNF4, the significant DN-HNF4-dependent reduction in observed activity for both the HNF1 and HNF4 promoter clearly indicates that both effects are substantial.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	201	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	202	Identification of HNF1 and HNF4 as the mutated genes responsible for MODY3 and MODY1, respectively, has prompted efforts to establish the precise role of these factors in health and disease.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Because the MODY phenotype involves a primary defect in beta cells, the defective function of these transcription factors must be manifested in these cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Indeed, expression of DN-HNF1 and DN-HNF4 leads to clear alterations in expression of key beta cell genes, including the insulin gene (26, 27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Because previous studies have shown that HNF4 is an activator of HNF1 (24) and that MODY3 can be caused by mutation in an HNF4-binding site in the HNF1 promoter (25), it was proposed that the effect of HNF4 on the insulin gene promoter is indirect, mediated through activation of HNF1 (27).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	206	In this report, we have examined the above hypothesis.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Expression of DN-HNF4 in beta cells led to reduced activity of both wild type insulin gene promoter and promoter mutated in the HNF1-binding site, strongly suggesting the presence of an HNF4-binding site elsewhere in the promoter region.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Indeed, we identified such a sequence between nucleotides 57 and 69 of the promoter, and we were able to show that it is capable of binding HNF4 in vitro.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	209	 We further showed that this site is essential for full activation of the promoter in beta cells and for efficient HNF4-dependent activation in non-beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Expression of DN-HNF4 in beta cells also led to reduced activity of a promoter construct bearing mutations in the HNF4 site.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The data therefore indicate that in addition to the previously recognized indirect action of HNF4 on insulin gene expression mediated through HNF1, there is also a direct action mediated through binding to the novel HNF4 consensus sequence in the promoter.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	212	These results are consistent with recent reports (29, 30) indicating that the epistatic relationship between HNF4 and HNF1 in beta cells is more complex than previously appreciated and may differ from that in liver.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	213	 It has been shown that the Hnf4 promoter contains an upstream beta cell-specific promoter whose activity is regulated by HNF1.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This promoter also contains a binding site for PDX1, mutations in which strongly correlate with the diabetic phenotype in a MODY family (30).
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Taken together, the data are consistent with the idea that HNF1, HNF4, and PDX1 participate in a complex autoregulatory transcriptional network that controls many of the functional properties of developing and mature beta cells.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Of central importance in this regard is the insulin gene, whose expression is modulated by all three factors.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Interestingly, we have observed synergistic activation of the insulin gene promoter by HNF4 and PDX1, which have adjacent binding sites in this promoter, thus adding an additional level of complexity to the transcriptional control network.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The current results indicating that HNF4 activates the insulin gene through both direct and indirect actions will permit a more detailed understanding of the MODY phenotype.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Gerber for assistance with plasmid construction and Dr.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Dikstein for gifts of plasmids.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	221	* This work was supported in part by grants from the Roy and Ellen Rosenthal Family Foundation, the Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities (to M.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	222	), and Swiss National Science Foundation Grant 32-49755.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	223	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	226	Holds the Marvin Meyer and Jenny Cyker Chair of Diabetes Research.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	227	 To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	228	: 972- 8 934 3597; Fax: 972- 8 934 4118; E-mail: m.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	229	Published, JBC Papers in Press, May 6, 2002, DOI 10.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	230	The abbreviations used are: MODY, maturity-onset diabetes of the young; HNF4, hepatocyte nuclear factor 4; DN, dominant negative; HNF1, hepatocyte nuclear factor 1; EMSA, electrophoretic mobility shift assay; RSV, Rous sarcoma virus; CMV, cytomegalovirus; TK, thymidine kinase; LUC, luciferase; HBE, HNF4 binding element.
0.21709998.11994285.html.plaintext.txt	231	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.
