0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcriptional Regulation of the Hepatocyte Growth Factor Gene by the Nuclear Receptors Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcription Factor and Estrogen Receptor*.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, August 17, 1996, and in revised form, October 22, 1996).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	2	Jie-Gen Jiang , Aaron Bell , Youhua Liu and Reza Zarnegar  .
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the Division of Cellular and Molecular Pathology, Department of Pathology, School of Medicine, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261 ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES RESULTS DISCUSSION FOOTNOTES Acknowledgments REFERENCES.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	4	Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a multifunctional cytokine that controls the growth and differentiation of various tissues.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Previously, we described the existence of a negative cis-acting regulatory element(s) within the 1- to 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	6	7-kilobase pair (kb) portion of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In the present study, we show that the repressor element is located at position 872 to 860 base pairs and comprises an imperfect estrogen-responsive element 5-AGGTCAGAAAGACCA-3.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	8	 We demonstrate that chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF), a nuclear orphan receptor belonging to the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor superfamily, through binding to this site effectively silences the transcriptional activity of the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	9	 We show that estrogen receptor, on the other hand, relieves the repressive action of COUP-TF, resulting in the induction of the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Using mice transgenic for either 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	11	7 kb of the HGF promoter region linked to the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter gene, we found that injection of estradiol stimulates HGF promoter activity in tissues such as the mammary gland and ovary of mice harboring 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	12	7 kb of the mouse HGF promoter region.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Potential involvement of the CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein (C/EBP) family of transcription factors in the regulation of HGF gene expression is also discussed.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	14	Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF)1 was originally identified as the major mitogenic component of serum and platelets for normal adult rat hepatocytes (1, 2).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Further investigations revealed that HGF is a multifunctional cytokine with a broad range of target cells (3, 4).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HGF elicits its biological effects through binding to and activating a specific transmembrane tyrosine kinase (4-6) known as Met (HGF receptor) (7).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	17	 HGF gene expression is tightly regulated at the transcriptional level and is restricted to stromal cells such as fibroblasts, macrophages, leukocytes, and endothelial cells in various tissues.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Numerous studies have shown that this growth factor is involved in the growth and regeneration of several organs (8-10).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In response to tissue loss, such as in the case of partial hepatectomy or hepatotoxin injury, the level of HGF mRNA dramatically increases in the liver as well as in other organs such as the lung and spleen (9, 10).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	20	 HGF mRNA also increases in the remaining kidney or lung after unilateral nephrectomy or pneumonectomy, respectively (9, 10).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Recent investigations in transgenic mice homozygous for a null mutation in the HGF gene (knock-out mice) have proved that HGF is essential for the development of various tissues such as liver, muscle, and placenta (11, 12).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	22	HGF expression is modulated by several cytokines and hormones.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	23	 For example, it has been shown that in MRC-5 fibroblasts and HL-60 cells HGF expression is down-regulated by transforming growth factor 1 and dexamethasone or by coculture with epithelial cells (13-15).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In contrast, phorbol esters, interleukin-1, or tumor necrosis factor  increase HGF mRNA level (16-19).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Overexpression of HGF mRNA in various neoplastic tissues has also been reported.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	26	 To understand the transcriptional regulation of HGF, the sequences of the human, rat, and mouse HGF gene promoters have been determined and the major transcriptional start sites have been mapped (20-23).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Several potential regulatory sites including NF-IL6 (also known as C/EBP) were identified in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter by our laboratory (22) as well as by others (20-24).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We reported the identification and partial characterization of a transcriptional repressor in the promoter of the mouse HGF gene (25).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	29	 We also localized a negative regulatory region in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter residing at position 1 to 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In the current study, we show that COUP-TF binds to an imperfect estrogen response element (ERE) in this region and represses HGF promoter activity.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We show that high expression of the estrogen receptor counteracts the suppressive action of COUP-TF by competing for the same binding site.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	32	COUP-TF, which belongs to the orphan nuclear receptor family, was originally found through its interaction with a response element in the chicken ovalbumin gene promoter (26, 27) and has been shown to play both positive and negative roles in gene regulation upon binding to its cognate DNA regulatory element (28).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The COUP-TF family (which consists of COUP-TF I and COUP-TF II) binds to the AGGTCA repeat sequence, which also is the DNA half-site for several other nuclear receptors such as the estrogen receptor (ER), vitamin D3 receptor, thyroid hormone receptor, retinoic acid receptors (RAR and RXR), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor, and hepatic nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) (28-31).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In previous studies we reported that estrogen stimulates HGF mRNA expression in mouse ovaries (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Our current results implicate COUP-TF as a potent repressor of HGF gene transcription and provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms that regulate HGF gene expression.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	36	4 mouse HGF-CAT (1386 to +29), 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	37	0 mouse HGF-CAT (964 to +29), and 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	38	7 mouse HGF-CAT (699 to +29) constructs were prepared as described (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	39	85 mouse HGF-CAT construct was made by double digesting the 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	40	4 mouse HGF-CAT construct with HindIII/AflII.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	41	85 mouse DHGF-CAT construct harboring an internal deletion was generated by digesting the 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	42	0-kb HGF-CAT construct with AflII and BstXI.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Blunt ends were created by either Klenow polymerase or T4 DNA polymerase, and the corresponding fragments were purified by agarose gel electrophoresis and then ligated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	44	 For heterologous promoter constructs, synthesized oligonucleotides HERE1 and HERE2 were inserted into the BglII site of the pCAT promoter (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	45	Cell Culture, DNA Transfection, and CAT Assay.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	46	Human endometrial carcinoma RL95-2 cells, human hepatoma HepG2 cells, and mouse fibroblast NIH3T3 cells were obtained from American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, MD) and cultured as described previously (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	47	 For transfection, the recipient cells were cultured in six-well plates for 24 h and then transfected with various mouse HGF promoter/CAT chimeric plasmids and heterologous promoter constructs using the DNA calcium phosphate method according to the instructions of the CellPhect transfection kit (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The -galactosidase reference plasmid pCH110 (Pharmacia) was used as an internal standard for transfection efficiency.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	49	 After cell transfection was carried out for 16 h, the cells were washed twice with serum-free medium.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Complete medium containing 10% fetal calf serum was then added, and the cells were incubated for an additional 24 h before harvesting to test for CAT activity.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	51	For co-transfection experiments of NIH3T3 cells with pHEO, the human estrogen receptor expression plasmid, and pRS-COUP, the human COUP-TF expression plasmid, phenol red-free medium and charcoal-stripped fetal calf serum were used.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The amount of plasmid used in transfection was 5  microg of one chimerical CAT construct, 1  microg of pCH110, and different amounts of estrogen receptor or COUP-TF expression vectors as indicated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Protein concentration was used as a standard for transfection efficiency in the co-transfection experiments including those with the COUP-TF expression vector.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	54	 CAT activity was determined by a modified assay as described previously (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Transfection experiments were performed at least three separate times with two independent preparations of purified plasmid DNA.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	56	Preparation of Nuclear Extracts.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	57	Human endometrial carcinoma RL95-2 cells, human hepatoma HepG2 cells, and mouse fibroblast NIH3T3 cells were originally obtained from ATCC.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Cells were cultured under conditions described previously (22, 32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The nuclear extracts were prepared as already reported (25).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Briefly, cells growing to about 90% confluence were washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline and dislodged with a rubber policeman into phosphate-buffered saline.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cells were pelleted by low speed centrifugation, resuspended in 5 volumes of Buffer A containing protease inhibitors (10 mM HEPES (pH 7.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	62	2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	63	5 mM dithiothreitol, plus 1  microg each of leupeptin and chymostatin per ml) and then placed on ice for 10 min.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Immediately after lysis, the solution was transferred to a glass Dounce homogenizer and homogenized with 10 up and down strokes using a type B pestle.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The nuclei were collected by centrifuging for 15 min at 3,300  x  g and resuspended in the same volume of Buffer B as Buffer A.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Buffer B was the same as Buffer A except Nonidet P-40 was omitted.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	67	 After the nuclei were recovered by centrifugation, Buffer C (20 mM HEPES (pH 7.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	68	2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	69	5 mM dithiothreitol, plus 1  microg each of leupeptin and chymostatin per ml) was added to resuspend the nuclei.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Nuclear protein was extracted with Buffer D (the same as Buffer C, but substituting 10 mM KCl for 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The extracted nuclei were centrifuged for 45 min at 50,000  x  g at 4  degrees C, and the supernatant was then collected and dialyzed against 60 mM KCl-TGM (10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	72	6), 10% glycerol, 3 mM MgCl2, 3 mM EGTA buffer using a mini-dialysis system (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The insoluble materials were removed by centrifugation, and small aliquots of protein extract were quickly frozen and stored at 80  degrees C after the protein concentration had been determined by protein assay (Bio-Rad).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	74	Rat liver nonparenchymal cells were isolated by differential centrifugation of the collagenase-digested rat liver perfusate (provided by George Michalopoulos, Department of Pathology, University of Pittsburgh).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Cells were washed twice with cold phosphate-buffered saline and then used to make nuclear extracts with the method described above.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	76	The following oligonucleotides were used in gel mobility shift assays: vitellogenin A2 ERE (VitA2ERE), 5-GATCTAGGTCACAGTGACCTA-3 (33); and COUP, 5-GATCTTTCTATGGTGTCAAAGGTCAAACT-3 (30).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The following sequences were derived from the mouse HGF gene promoter (22): HERE1, 5-GATCAAGGTCAGAAAGACCAT-3; HERE2, 5-GATCTGGTCAATCTAACCA-3; AP1, 5-GATCTGCCTTGACTTAGCGAG-3; IL-6RE, 5-GATCAGAGCTGGGATCTG-3; CRE, 5-GATCTTAAGACGTCATTTA-3; NF-IL6, 5-GATCCTTCTGAGGAAAGCTGC-3; GRE, 5-GATCTTCTGGTGCTATTTCTTCTCATT-3; and TIE, 5-GATCGGGCGAATTGGTGTTCTGC-3.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	78	A DNA fragment corresponding to nucleotide position 964 to 812 bp of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene was isolated from the chimeric 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	79	4 mouse HGF-CAT construct (22) by restriction digestion with AatI/AflII.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The 154-bp fragment was purified and labeled with [-32P]dATP (3,000 Ci/mmol, Amersham Corp.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	81	) by filling in and blunt ending with Klenow enzyme (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The double-stranded oligonucleotides used in gel shift assays were also labeled with 32P by end labeling with T4 kinase.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The labeled probes were then gel purified and used in gel mobility shift assays as described previously (25).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Two micrograms of poly(dI-dC) (Pharmacia) were used as the nonspecific competitor in 10  microl of reaction mixture.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	85	 When antibodies were used in supershift experiments, they (1  microl) were incubated with nuclear extracts for 15 min at room temperature before carrying out DNA binding shift assays.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The binding reactions (20  microl total volume/reaction) were carried out at room temperature for 20 min before loading on 5% nondenaturing polyacrylamide (19:1 acrylamide/bisacrylamide) gels.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The concentration of nuclear protein extracts used in each reaction was 2  microg and that of the labeled probe was between 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	88	 For competition experiments, a 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled DNA fragments or oligonucleotides was included in the reaction mixture.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	89	001 M EDTA) at a constant voltage of 190 V, dried, and autoradiographed using intensifying screens.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	90	Transgenic mice harboring various lengths (2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	91	1 kb) of the HGF promoter region fused to the CAT reporter gene were recently generated and characterized in our laboratory.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	92	2 Two different HGF-CAT transgenic mouse lines were used in the present study to evaluate HGF promoter activity in response to estradiol.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	93	7 HGF-CAT transgenic mouse lines (three different founders) harbor 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	94	7 kb of the HGF promoter that contains the HERE1 element.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	95	7 HGF-CAT transgenic lines (two different founders) carry 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	96	7 kb of the HGF promoter region that lacks the HERE1 element.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Transgenic mice were maintained in animal facilities at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	98	 All animal experiments were conducted in accordance with National Institutes of Health standards established by the "Guidelines for the Care and Use of Experimental Animals.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	99	" Mice were injected subcutaneously with 100 mg of 17-estradiol (Sigma) per kg of body weight in a volume of 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	100	1 ml of buffered saline containing 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	101	 At 24 h after injection, groups of eight animals were killed by cervical dislocation, and the ovary and other organs were dissected and immediately frozen for CAT assays.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	102	Identification of a cis-Acting Repressor in the HGF Promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	103	We previously reported the existence of a negative regulatory region in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene located between nucleotides 964 and 699 bp (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	104	 To further define this region, two additional HGF-CAT chimeric constructs containing a 5 deletion (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	105	85 HGF-CAT) or an internal deletion (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	106	85 DHGF-CAT) were generated by using the restriction enzyme AflII (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Four different HGF-CAT chimeric constructs, 1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	108	7 HGF-CAT, were subsequently tested for promoter activity by transfection into human endometrial carcinoma RL95-2 cells, human hepatoma HepG2 cells, and mouse fibroblast NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Promoter activity of each construct as determined by CAT assays revealed that the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	110	85 HGF-CAT constructs had consistently stronger promoter activity than the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	111	 These results suggest that the region between nucleotides 964 and 812 bp contains a negative cis-acting element(s) and that a negative trans-acting factor(s) may interact with this 154-bp DNA fragment to repress HGF gene transcription.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Localization of a cis-acting repressor element in the 5-upstream flanking region of the mouse HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Mouse HGF-CAT constructs consisting of a series of 5 deletions or an internal deletion were transiently transfected into NIH3T3, HepG2, and RL95-2 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Graphical representation of relative CAT activity after normalization against -galactosidase is shown.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The results presented here are the average from at least three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The transfected plasmids were from two independent preparations.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Numbers indicate the insert sizes (kb) of the mouse HGF promoter region 5 to the CAT reporter gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	118	 DNA fragments were inserted in correct (5 to 3) orientation relative to the transcription initiation site, and the nucleotide boundaries were confirmed by sequencing.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	119	 [View Larger Version of this Image (18K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	120	trans-Acting Factors Interact with the cis-Acting Negative Element in a Distinct Binding Region.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	121	To examine whether trans-acting factors specifically bind to the 154-bp DNA fragment, we performed gel mobility band shift analysis using the end-labeled 154-bp fragment with nuclear protein extracts from NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Examination of the DNA-protein complexes by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis under nondenaturing conditions revealed a prominent and specific band with a slow electrophoretic mobility.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	123	 This complex was totally abrogated in the presence of 100-fold molar excess of the unlabeled "self" probe competitor (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Since computer analysis of the nucleotide sequence of this DNA fragment identified consensus binding sites such as ERE and CRE, we carried out gel mobility band shift assays in the presence of synthetic oligonucleotides corresponding to the individual consensus sequences HERE1 and CRE and other potential binding sites that are present in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	125	 2, the binding was completely abolished when a 100-fold molar excess of the HERE1 oligonucleotide (872 to 860 bp) was added to the reaction mixtures (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	126	 On the other hand, the CRE oligonucleotide at a 100-fold molar excess did not compete for this binding site (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Other oligonucleotides found in the mouse HGF promoter corresponding to GRE, TIE, AP1, IL-6RE, NF-IL6, and HERE2 (a mutated version of HERE1) also failed to compete with the 154-bp DNA fragment for binding to the nuclear protein present in NIH3T3 cells (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	128	 We confirmed these results by DNase I footprinting analysis using NIH3T3 cells and mouse liver tissue nuclear protein extracts.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Taken together, these data suggest that the HERE1 (nucleotides 872 to 860, 5-GGTCAGAAAGACC-3) is involved in the formation of the protein-DNA complex.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	130	 This binding sequence is similar to the estrogen response element (5-AGGTCANNNTGACCT-3, see also Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Specific interaction of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene with a negative regulatory activity in nuclear protein extracts.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The 154-bp DNA fragment that exerted negative regulatory function was labeled with 32P and incubated with nuclear protein extract (NPE) from NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The binding reactions were performed at room temperature for 20 min in the presence of the nonspecific competitor poly(dI-dC).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Several double-stranded synthetic oligonucleotide sequences including HERE1, GRE, CRE, TIE, AP1, IL-6RE, NF-IL6, and HERE2 were added to the reaction mixture to compete for binding as indicated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	135	 C, binding complex; F, free 32P-labeled DNA probe.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	136	 [View Larger Version of this Image (76K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Synthetic mouse HERE1 sequence confers repression on a heterologous promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Shown on the left is the diagrammatic representation of the chimeric CAT constructs.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Synthetic oligonucleotides corresponding to the mouse HERE1 and HERE2 were cloned into a position upstream of the SV40 promoter (SV).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	140	 These constructs were transiently transfected into NIH3T3 cells followed by CAT assay as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	141	" Depicted on the right is a graphic representation of relative promoter activity as determined by CAT assays.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Each bar represents the mean of three independent transfection experiments.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The nucleotide sequences of wild type ERE (VitA2ERE), mouse HERE1, and mouse HERE2 are shown for comparison.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	144	 [View Larger Version of this Image (27K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	145	To assess the functionality of this element, synthetic HERE1 and HERE2 (a mutated version of HERE1, 5-GGTCAATCTAACC-3) oligonucleotides were linked to the heterologous pCAT promoter reporter gene (Promega), which contains the SV40 promoter, and the promoter activity in three different cell lines using transient transfection and CAT assays was determined.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The results are summarized in Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	147	 HERE1 efficiently repressed the SV40 promoter activity in HepG2, RL95-2, and NIH3T3 cells, whereas HERE2 (which failed to specifically bind to the nuclear protein, Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	148	 2, lane 11) did not have any function.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	149	 These results indicate that HERE1 negatively modulates HGF promoter activity and that this element functions not only in the context of the autologous promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	150	 1) but also in the context of a heterologous promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	151	Identification of the Binding Protein(s) as COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	152	To identify the HERE1 binding protein(s), labeled HERE1 was used as a probe in gel mobility shift assays with the nuclear extracts from NIH3T3 and RL95-2 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In NIH3T3 nuclear extract, the specific complex was abolished by unlabeled HERE1, VitA2ERE (wild type ERE), and COUP binding sites (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	154	 4A, lanes 3-5) but not by HERE2 and GRE (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	155	 We used COUP binding site because it is well known that COUP-TF binds to the AGGTCA motif regardless of its configuration (single half-site, direct as well as indirect repeats, and various spacings) (29).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Although RL95-2 cell nuclear extract formed two different bands with the HERE1 probe, these bands were totally abolished by 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled HERE1, VitA2ERE, and COUP oligonucleotides (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	157	 4A, lanes 9-11) but not by HERE2 and GRE (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	158	 It is known that RL95-2 and NIH3T3 cells express small amounts of ER, and that the major function of ER in the transcriptional regulation of target genes is induction (30, 32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Given the fact that COUP-TF mainly exerts repression on its target genes through binding to VitA2ERE (30, 35, 36), we opted to determine if the protein complex formed by HERE1 is COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	160	 To test this possibility, we performed supershift assays using antibody against COUP-TF, estrogen receptor, or nonimmune serum using the labeled HERE1 as probe.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	161	 4, anti-COUP-TF antibody totally abrogated complex formation between the HERE1 probe and nuclear proteins from different sources such as NIH3T3, HepG2, RL95-2 (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	162	 4B), and nonparenchymal liver cells (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	163	 4C) that are known to express the HGF gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The anti-ER antibody and nonimmune control serum did not show any effects (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	165	 These results demonstrate that the orphan nuclear receptor COUP-TF binds to the HERE1 site of the HGF promoter region.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	166	 It is of interest to note that HERE1 and HERE2 also bind to the estrogen receptor if this receptor is highly expressed (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	167	 We previously demonstrated this by using extract from RL95-2 cells that were transfected with an ER expression vector (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Taken together, our findings indicate that HERE1, like VitA2ERE, interacts with both ER and COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Identification of the protein(s) binding to the HERE1 element as COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	170	 A, the HERE1 element was labeled with 32P and incubated with nuclear protein extracts from NIH3T3 or RL95-2 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides including self, COUP, VitA2ERE, HERE2, and GRE were added to the reaction mixture to compete for binding as indicated (100 x ).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	172	 B and C, supershift of HERE1 bound to nuclear protein(s) from NIH3T3, HepG2, RL95-2, and rat liver nonparenchymal cell (NPC) nuclear extracts by anti-COUP-TF antibody is shown.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Anti-ER antibody and normal rabbit serum were also used for comparison.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The binding assays were done as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	175	" C, specific complex; NS, nonspecific complex; F, free 32P-labeled DNA probe; Ab, antibody; S, normal rabbit serum.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	176	 [View Larger Version of this Image (49K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	177	Modulation of HGF Promoter Activity by COUP-TF and ER.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	178	To test whether the estrogen receptor relieves the repression of the HGF promoter activity mediated by COUP-TF, we co-transfected various HGF-CAT chimeric constructs with an estrogen expression vector into NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	179	 5, the promoter activity of the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	180	0 HGF-CAT constructs that contain HERE1 increased in the presence of ER in a dose-dependent manner.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	181	 However, the activity of the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	182	7 HGF-CAT constructs were not affected by ER since they do not contain the HERE1 region (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Similar results were obtained when HERE1 was tested for its responsiveness to ER in the context of the SV40 heterologous promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	184	 CAT assays of NIH3T3 cell extracts co-transfected with the chimeric constructs HERE1-SV40-CAT and HERE2-SV40-CAT revealed that addition of increasing amounts of the estrogen receptor expression vector not only overcame the suppressive function conferred to the SV40 promoter by COUP-TF bound to HERE1 but also highly stimulated SV40 promoter activity (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Interestingly, HERE2 did not suppress the SV40 promoter (since it does not bind COUP-TF; see Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	186	 2, lane 11) but it bound ER with low affinity as we reported previously (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Furthermore, overexpression of COUP-TF (pRS-COUP) in NIH3T3 cells counteracted the stimulatory function of ER on HERE1 but had no effect on the HERE2-SV40-CAT construct (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	188	 These results demonstrate that the mouse HGF gene is transcriptionally suppressed by COUP-TF via binding to the HERE1 element at nucleotide 872 bp in the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	189	 High expression of ER counteracts the suppressive function of COUP-TF by competing with ER for binding to HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Overexpression of ER relieves the repression of the HGF promoter exerted by COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Four different HGF-CAT constructs (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	192	0 HGF-CAT) were co-transfected with various concentrations of pHEO, the human estrogen receptor expression vector, as indicated into NIH3T3 cells in the presence of estradiol (107 M).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	193	 CAT activity was normalized by -galactosidase activity, and the relative CAT activities are presented as the averages from three independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	194	 [View Larger Version of this Image (48K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	195	 COUP-TF and estrogen receptor counteract one another's effects through binding to HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A, chimeric SV40-CAT plasmids containing HERE1 and HERE2 were co-transfected with increasing amounts of ER expression vector into the NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The estrogen response of the HERE1-SV40-CAT and HERE2-SV40-CAT constructs was then examined by CAT assay.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	198	 SV40-CAT plasmid was included as a control.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The activity of each construct was normalized against -galactosidase activity, and relative CAT activities are presented as the averages from three independent experiments.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	200	 B, overexpression of COUP-TF repressed the ER-dependent, estrogen-stimulated response of HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Chimeric plasmids (same as in A) were co-transfected with the estrogen receptor expression vector pHEO (0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	202	2  microg/well) and various concentrations of pRS-COUP, the COUP-TF expression vector, in NIH3T3 cells.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	203	 CAT activity was normalized against protein concentration, and the relative CAT activities are presented as the averages from at least three independent experiments.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Estradiol concentration was 107 M.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	205	 [View Larger Version of this Image (30K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	206	Stimulation of the Mouse HGF Promoter in Transgenic Mice by Estradiol.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	207	We previously showed that injection of estradiol into mice dramatically stimulated HGF mRNA expression in mouse ovary (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Our present data reveal that the molecular mechanism by which estradiol stimulates the HGF promoter is through the counteraction by ER of COUP-TF, which directly down-regulates the mouse HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Only high levels of ER counteract the suppression caused by COUP-TF bound to HERE1.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	210	 To further confirm that HERE1 is functional and responsible for the stimulation of HGF mRNA by estradiol in vivo, we analyzed transgenic mice that harbor 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	211	7 kb of the mouse HGF promoter linked to the CAT reporter gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	212	7 HGF-CAT promoter construct in transgenic mice that carries the HERE1 element was up-regulated in the mammary tissue and ovary after injection of estradiol (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	213	 On the other hand, the activity of the 0.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	214	7 HGF-CAT construct that does not contain the HERE1 element did not change upon treatment with estradiol (data not shown).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	215	 This result strongly suggests that in vivo high expression of ER counteracts COUP-TF and stimulates HGF mRNA expression.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Estradiol stimulates HGF promoter activity in transgenic mice.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Cell extracts for CAT assays were prepared from mammary gland, adjacent skin, and ovary from 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	218	7 HGF-CAT transgenic mice that harbor 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	219	7 kb of the HGF promoter region and from nontransgenic mice after injection of 17-estradiol (100 mg/kg of body weight) or control saline solution.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Fifty micrograms of total protein extract from each tissue were subjected to CAT assay.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	221	 A graphic representation of relative CAT activity after normalization for protein concentration is shown.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The results presented are the average from at least three groups of mice.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	223	 TG, transgenic mouse; NTG, nontransgenic mouse; AS, adjacent skin of mammary gland; MG, mammary gland; OV, ovary tissue; E2, 17-estradiol.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	224	 [View Larger Version of this Image (16K GIF file)].
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	225	Our previous studies have shown that a negative regulatory element is located within 964 to 699 of the 5-flanking region of the mouse HGF gene (22).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	226	 In this region, an estrogen response element (HERE1) was identified that binds to ER and is responsible for the estradiol stimulation of the mouse HGF promoter in RL95-2 cells co-transfected with an ER expression vector (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	227	 We now show that this same element binds with high affinity to the nuclear orphan receptor COUP-TF, which belongs to the steroid/thyroid receptor superfamily, and silences the activity of the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	228	 We demonstrate that the estrogen receptor competes with COUP-TF for binding to this site, thereby relieving the repressive action of COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	229	There are two imperfect EREs found in the mouse HGF promoter region that we have called HERE1 and HERE2 (22, 32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	230	 HERE1 is localized in the 5-flanking region and HERE2 is in the first intron of the HGF gene.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	231	 By using gel mobility band shift and supershift assays, we demonstrated that HERE1 is similar to the ERE found in the vitellogenin (vit) gene (37) and that it binds not only to ER but also to COUP-TF (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Co-transfection of ER or COUP-TF expression vectors in NIH3T3 cells revealed that HERE1 confers the repressive function of COUP-TF to the heterologous SV40 promoter and that not only did ER overcome the suppression of COUP-TF but it also stimulated the SV40 promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	233	 In the homologous mouse HGF promoter, ER only counteracted the negative effects of COUP-TF (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	234	The molecular mechanisms of COUP-TF-mediated transcriptional repression are partially understood.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	235	 COUP-TF acts via several different mechanisms to inhibit target gene transcription including competition with other nuclear receptors for the occupancy of DNA binding sites, active repression of basal transcription, active repression of transactivator-dependent transcription, quenching of transactivator-dependent transcription, transrepression of activated transcription, and titration of the common coregulator RXR (31, 38).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Our data shown here reveal that COUP-TF may down-regulate the mouse HGF promoter by active repression of basal transcription because HERE1 suppresses the basal SV40 promoter and that ER may activate HGF transcriptional activity by replacing COUP-TF and relieving the promoter from repression (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	237	 COUP-TF belongs to the orphan (thus far, no ligand has been found that can bind and directly regulate the activity of this factor) nuclear receptor family and resembles the thyroid hormone receptor/steroid hormone receptor superfamily (31, 36).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The mode by which it represses its target gene involves the binding of COUP-TF to the AGGTCA motif arranged in various configurations (i.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	239	 direct repeats (DR) or inverted repeats (IR) with different numbers of spacers ranging from 0 to 8 nucleotides) (31).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Interestingly, the AGGTCA half-site depending on its configuration forms the response elements for other nuclear receptors such as the estrogen receptor (which binds to IR3), thyroid hormone receptor (which binds to IR0 or DR4), retinoid receptors (RAR, which binds to IR0 and DR2, and RXR, which binds to DR5 and DR1), vitamin D receptor (which binds to DR3), HNF4, and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (31).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	241	 It is believed that COUP-TF directly competes with these receptors for binding to the AGGTCA sequence and thus inhibits their transactivating functions.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Suppression by COUP-TF is also achieved in part through heterodimerization of COUP-TF with RXR (which is the essential transactivating partner for vitamin D3 receptor, thyroid hormone receptor, and RAR), thereby titrating RXR to a transcriptionally inactive complex (31, 38).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	243	 It is tempting to speculate that in addition to ER other members of the nuclear receptor family mentioned above may bind to the COUP-TF binding site in the HGF promoter HERE1 and thus activate HGF transcription in a tissue-specific manner.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The COUP-TF site in the HGF promoter, however, is composed of an estrogen response element (IR3) and apparently binds only to the estrogen receptor.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	245	Previous observations in our laboratory showed that administration of 17-estradiol to immature female mice caused a significant induction of HGF mRNA in the ovaries (32).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The tissue- and cell type-specific expression of the mouse HGF gene by estrogen may be due to different amounts of hormone receptors in these tissues, as shown by other studies (37).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Our present studies show that high expression of estrogen receptor in NIH3T3 cells is sufficient to counteract the suppression of COUP-TF on the mouse HGF promoter (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	248	 HGF promoter activity or lack thereof in transgenic mice also supports this hypothesis because estradiol stimulated the HGF promoter in mice carrying the 2.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	249	7 HGF-CAT construct that contains HERE1, particularly in tissues that have high expression of ER (Fig.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	250	 In this regard, it is important to understand how HGF gene expression is relieved from COUP-TF repression in other tissues in which ER may not be operational.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The factors that are known to activate HGF expression include cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor  and polypeptide growth factors such as epidermal growth factor.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	252	 These agents do not exert their gene-regulatory function directly through the AGGTCA motif, the DNA binding site for COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Although the molecular mechanisms by which these agents induce their target genes are not fully understood, it is well established that they utilize members of the AP1, C/EBP, nuclear factor B (NFKB), and signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) family of transcription factors.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Indeed, in our previous report (22) we demonstrated that several NF-IL6 (C/EBP) response elements exist in the 5-flanking region of the HGF promoter region and that IL-6 induces HGF promoter activity in a stromal (fibroblast) cell line stably transfected with an HGF-CAT chimeric construct.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In our very recent investigations using gel shift, supershift, and CAT assays, we have found that functional C/EBP binding sites exist in the HGF promoter.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	256	 We also found that co-transfection of expression vectors encoding C/EBP or C/EBP with HGF-CAT vectors dramatically (more than 20-fold) stimulates the transcriptional activity of various HGF-CAT promoter constructs (even those constructs that do not contain COUP-TF binding sites, thus indicating that promoter activation is not due to interference with COUP-TF binding).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	257	3 These observations provide an explanation for how the HGF promoter is released from repression exerted by negative acting factors such as COUP-TF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The C/EBP family of transcription factors is known to consist of regulators of important cellular functions ranging from metabolism to cell growth to differentiation.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	259	The physiological significance of the transcriptional regulation of the HGF gene by ER and COUP-TF also remains to be elucidated.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Nevertheless, it has been shown that both HGF and COUP-TF play an important role during embryonic development.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	261	 COUP-TFs are differentially expressed in a restricted manner during organogenesis (40).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Both COUP-TF I and COUP-TF II genes are essential since COUP-TF I mutants die prenatally and COUP-TF II mutants die in utero (41).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Additionally, HGF is believed to be one of the major mediators of stromal-epithelial interactions controlling growth and morphogenesis of various tissues such as breast (39).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Studies on the embryological development of such tissues have revealed that steroid hormone-induced ductal morphogenesis and growth is accomplished via the interactions between the stromal and epithelial compartments of these tissues (34).
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Therefore, the functions of COUP-TF and ER during development may be mediated in part by their ability to regulate HGF gene expression.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Our data shown here shed light on the significant interplay among transcription factors such as ER, COUP-TF, and C/EBP and polypeptide growth factors such as HGF.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	267	*   This work was supported by Grant CN#55D from the American Cancer Society and Grant R01ES 06109 from the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (to R.
0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.43641222.9020096.html.plaintext.txt	276	 1    The abbreviations used are: HGF, hepatocyte growth factor; COUP-TF, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor; ERE, estrogen-responsive element; HERE, HGF estrogen-responsive element; ER, estrogen receptor; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; kb, kilobase pair(s); bp, base pair(s); CRE, cAMP-responsive element; GRE, glucocorticoid-response element; IL, interleukin; IL-6RE, IL-6-responsive element; RAR, retinoic acid receptor; RXR, retinoid X receptor; TIE, transforming growth factor  inhibitory element; DHGF, deleted HGF promoter construct; VitA2, vitellogenin A2; DR, direct repeat(s); IR, inverted repeat(s); AP1, activated protein 1; NF-IL6, nuclear factor-interleukin 6; C/EBP, CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	0	Essential Role of Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor II in Insulin Secretion and Insulin Sensitivity Revealed by Conditional Gene Knockout Pascale Bardoux1, Pili Zhang1, Daisy Flamez2, Anais Perilhou1, Tiphaine Aguirre Lavin1, Jean-Francois Tanti3, Karine Hellemans4, Emmanuel Gomas1, Cecile Godard1, Fabrizio Andreelli5, Maria Antonietta Buccheri1, Axel Kahn1, Yannick Le Marchand-Brustel3, Remy Burcelin6, Frans Schuit4, and Mireille Vasseur-Cognet1.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Department of Genetic Development and Molecular Biology, Universite Rene Descartes, Institut Cochin, INSERM U567 (Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale), Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique-UMR 8104, Paris, France 2 Diabetes Research Center, Faculty of Medicine, Vrije Universiteit Brussel Laarbeeklaan, Brussels, Belgium 3 Faculte de Medecine, INSERM U568, Nice, France 4 Gene Expression Unit, Afdeling Biochemie, Campus Gasthuisberg, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Leuven, Belgium 5 Service de Diabetologie-Nutrition, Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Bichat-Claude Bernard, Paris, France 6 Unite Mixte de Recherche 5018, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique-UPS, IFR 31, Paul Sabatier University, Toulouse, France.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT RESULTS AND DISCUSSION RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS REFERENCES   Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II (COUP-TFII) has been implicated in the control of blood glucose by its potent effect on expression and signaling of various nuclear receptors.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	3	 To understand the role of COUP-TFII in glucose homeostasis, conditional COUP-TFII-deficient mice were generated and crossed with mice expressing Cre under the control of rat insulin II gene promoter, resulting in deletion of COUP-TFII in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Homozygous mutants died before birth for yet undetermined reasons.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Heterozygous mice appeared healthy at birth and showed normal growth and fertility.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	6	 When challenged intraperitoneally, the animals had glucose intolerance associated with reduced glucose-stimulated insulin secretion.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Moreover, these heterozygous mice presented a mild increase in fasting and random-fed circulating insulin levels.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In accordance, islets isolated from these animals exhibited higher insulin secretion in low glucose conditions and markedly decreased glucose-stimulated insulin secretion.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Their pancreata presented normal microscopic architecture and insulin content up to 16 weeks of study.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Altered insulin secretion was associated with peripheral insulin resistance in whole animals.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	11	 It can be concluded that COUP-TFII is a new, important regulator of glucose homeostasis and insulin sensitivity.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	12	The function of differentiated ss-cells is dependent upon a network of transcription factors that are required for the expression of key genes involved in glucose sensing, insulin biosynthesis, and regulated exocytosis (1 to 4).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Disturbance of this network, even by mutations causing a modest decrease in the protein level, has been shown to lead to important clinical manifestations such as diabetes and/or obesity.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	14	Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II (COUP-TFII; also called NR2F and ARP-1) is an orphan member of the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor superfamily that binds DNA by a Zn-finger DNA binding domain (5).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	15	 COUP-TFII is generally considered to be a functional transcriptional repressor of genes controlled by nuclear hormone receptors such as peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors and hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)-4, which are well known to play important roles in the glucose-responsive phenotype of ss-cells (6,7).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The possibility that COUP-TFII might play a role in glucose homeostasis is supported by in vitro studies suggesting that this protein is involved in regulating insulin gene expression in pancreatic ss-cells (8) but also in the expression of several other genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism (9,10).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	17	 It has been shown that COUP-TFII is expressed in the early developing endocrine pancreas and in mature differentiated islet cells (11).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, until now the potential function of COUP-TFII in pancreatic ss-cells remains unknown.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	19	 One way to address this issue is to generate COUP-TFII-deficient mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Since global COUP-TFII deficiency results in embryonic lethality (12), we generated in this study a conditional knockout of the COUP-TFII gene using the Cre-loxP system.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Our data show that inactivation of one COUP-TFII allele in ss-cells results in disturbed insulin secretion and peripheral insulin resistance.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	22	   RESULTS AND DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT RESULTS AND DISCUSSION RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS REFERENCES   Conditional inactivation of COUP-TFII in pancreatic ss-cells.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	23	 To achieve conditional knockout of the COUP-TFII gene in pancreatic ss-cells using the Cre-loxP system, we first generated heterozygous COUP-TFII floxed (fl)/wild-type (wt) mice carrying one fl and one wt COUP-TFII allele (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Genotype analysis of the offspring by intercrossing these mice indicated that both homozygous COUP-TFII fl/fl and heterozygous COUP-TF fl/wt pups were present at normal Mendelian frequency at days E11.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	25	 However, half of the COUP-TFII fl/fl pups died after birth (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The surviving homozygous COUP-TFII fl/fl mice were indistinguishable from their wt littermates by visual inspection; they were fertile and had a normal lifespan.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	27	View larger version (30K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Assessment of COUP-TFII deletion in pancreatic ss-cell and extrapancreatic cells of Rip2-Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	29	 A: Schematic representation of the genomic structure of COUP-TFII: (a) shows the genomic map of the wt COUP-TFII allele.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The lower panels show the targeted locus before (b) and after (c) excision of the neomycin selection cassette (Neo) that is flanked by one loxP upstream and two loxP sites downstream of exon 1 and also shows the position of the different primers used in the PCR analysis.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	37	  View larger version (15K):    FIG.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	40	5 days post coitum and after birth.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Values in parentheses indicate the Mendelian frequencies expected from these breedings.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	42	  Mice carrying COUP-TFII gene inactivation in the pancreatic ss-cells were generated by breeding homozygous COUP-TFII fl/fl mice with transgenic mice expressing Cre driven by the rat insulin II promoter (Rip2-Cre) generated by Magnuson and colleagues (13,14).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	43	COUP-TFII fl/wt females were mated to COUP-TFII fl/wt males to generate mice with different genotypes.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	44	COUP-TFII fl/fl mice were embryonic lethal.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Since there are no precedents for embryonic lethal phenotypes resulting from ss-cell-specific gene deletions, this lethality, together with the observations of Magnuson and colleagues (14), led us to examine possible Cre-induced deletion of the floxed COUP-TFII allele in other tissues than endocrine pancreas.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Multiplex PCR analysis was performed on DNA prepared from liver, hypothalamus, brain, and spinal cord (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	47	 We detected gene deletion in the spinal cord from the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	48	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, while we previously demonstrated that the COUP-TFII gene is expressed in the ventral neural tube at 9.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Therefore, extrapancreatic COUP-TFII gene knockout could contribute in the observed lethality of homozygous Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	50	Multiplex PCR analysis of DNA prepared from islets isolated from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	51	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice confirmed that one floxed allele was deleted (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	52	 As judged by immunoblotting, COUP-TF levels were decreased by 45% in nuclear extracts prepared from islets from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	53	 1C, lane 2) compared with wt mice (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	54	 These results indicate that Cre-induced recombination in heterozygous Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	55	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice leads to an efficient inactivation of the COUP-TFII gene in ss-cells.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The expression of COUP-TFI, a closely related family member, was not altered, suggesting that adaptative upregulation of this isoform does not occur (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	57	View larger version (12K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Steady-state mRNA levels of target genes in Cre+/ to .

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	64	  Finally, to understand the lethality of some COUP-TFII fl/fl pups, we examined whether inclusion of the loxP sites might interfere with COUP-TFII gene expression.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Semiquantitative RT-PCR analysis using the A5HF and R5HF primers showed that liver and kidney mRNA was decreased by 20% in heterozygous floxed mice with respect to normal animals (data not shown).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Accordingly, COUP-TFII protein analyzed by Western blot was also slightly decreased (by 10 to 20%) in hepatocyte nuclear extracts of heterozygous floxed mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Therefore, the floxed COUP-TFII allele is hypomorphic, which could explain the death of some homozygous floxed COUP-TFII pups.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	68	The present study was carried out in the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	69	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, in which the floxed allele is inactivated in the Cre-expressing cells and shows to be hypomorphic only in other tissues.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Therefore, the COUP-TFII protein is expected to be decreased by half in the former cells and by 10 to 20% in the latter ones.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	71	 All results obtained from the mutant Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	72	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice were compared with both control (Cre+/ to  or wt) and COUP-TFII fl/wt mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	73	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice exhibit altered insulin secretion after glucose challenge.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Body weight, food intake, and body composition, as assessed by biphotonic absorptiometry, in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	75	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice were comparable to the three groups of mice, suggesting that energy metabolism in these animals is not grossly abnormal (Fig.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	80	01) than control and COUP-TFII fl/wt mice.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	111	  COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency leads to impaired insulin secretion in isolated islets.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	112	 To identify the consequence of COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency at the level of the ss-cell secretory function, we studied glucose- and L-arginine-induced insulin release in an islet perifusion protocol (15).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In the basal state, measured in 3 mmol/l glucose, Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	114	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets showed a trend (not significant) to release more insulin than the COUP-TFII fl/wt islets, especially at early time points in the perifusion protocol (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Upon glucose challenge, a profound defect in insulin release was observed.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In COUP-TFII fl/wt islets, glucose induced insulin release in a concentration-dependent manner between 5 and 10 mmol/l glucose; whereas, Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	117	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets showed virtually no response to 7.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	118	5 mmol/l glucose, while their response to 10 and 20 mmol/l glucose was only one-third of that seen in the control islets (Figs.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Finally, the insulin secretion in response to the combined stimulation of 20 mmol/l arginine with 10 mmol/l glucose was also significantly lower in the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	120	 As the stimulation by arginine was similar in COUP-TFII fl/wt and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	121	 5B), we conclude that in Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	122	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets, the glucose-induced insulin secretion is specifically affected.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	123	View larger version (36K):    FIG.

0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	129	  These abnormalities of the insulin secretion by COUP-TFII-deficient islets were not associated with altered islet morphology (data not shown).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Intensity of insulin and glucagon immunostaining appeared normal, as was the estimated size of the insulin storage pool (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In addition, the insulin and glucagon mRNA concentrations, assessed by semiquantitative RT-PCR (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	132	 7), were not changed in mutant mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	133	 This suggests that the reduced insulin release from Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	134	COUP-TFII fl/wt islets is unlikely to be caused by abnormalities in insulin or glucagon gene expression.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The ss-cell mass, estimated by quantitative morphometric analysis, showed no differences between wt, COUP-TFII fl/wt, and Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	136	View larger version (10K):    FIG.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Pancreatic insulin content, ss-cell mass, and ss-cell density in 14-week-old mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Results are the mean values  plus or minus  SE for three to five animals per genotype.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	139	  The effects of COUP-TFII haploinsufficiency in ss-cells on the expression of genes critical for glucose sensing and insulin secretion were examined by semiquantitative RT-PCR experiments.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	140	 All the transcripts studied were similarly abundant in controls (wt and COUP-TFII fl/wt mice) and heterozygous mice, except the glucose-responsive gene encoding GLUT2, whose mRNA abundance was significantly increased (by 60%) in the islet cells of knockout animals (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The GLUT2 transporter has been shown to play a key role in murine ss-cells for glucose signaling to insulin secretion (16) but is not rate limiting for glucose entry to ss-cells (17).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Nevertheless, increased abundance of the GLUT2 mRNA in the islets of the Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	143	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice could result from a decreased repression by COUP-TFII, maybe acting as a hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)-4 competitor (7).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	144	 More biology of the ss-cell and genomewide expression analysis in purified pancreatic ss-cells will be necessary to enable us to further define more systematically potential mediators of glucose recognition in our model.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	145	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice exhibit altered insulin sensitivity in vivo.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Since altered insulin secretion can modify insulin sensitivity in vivo, an insulin tolerance test was performed showing that Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	147	COUP-TFII fl/wt animals were resistant to the glucose-lowering effect of exogenous insulin (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The normal insulin sensitivity of the COUP-TFII fl/wt mice allowed us to rule out a role of the hypomorphic floxed allele by itself.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Interestingly, in isolated soleus muscle, basal and insulin-stimulated glycogen synthesis is similar when wt is compared with COUP-TFII fl/wt or Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	150	COUP-TFII fl/wt mice, indicating that insulin resistance is unlikely a primary defect in skeletal muscle (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In addition, primary abnormalities in hepatocytes can be ruled out, since mice with the hepatocyte-specific conditional COUP-TFII gene inactivation exhibit normal insulin sensitivity (M.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	152	In conclusion, the observed insulin resistance in heterozygous mice could be, at least in part, the consequence of persistent higher insulin levels.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In some mice models and in humans, chronic hyperinsulinemia was shown to be a self-perpetuating cause of the defects in insulin action and not only a compensatory response to insulin resistance (18 to 21).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Our results demonstrate that a heterozygous COUP-TFII deletion in islet ss-cells leads to an impaired glucose sensitivity and then to an abnormal insulin secretion and secondary insulin resistance.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The results obtained in vivo and in isolated islets allow us to exclude any participation of the autonomic nervous system in the alteration of insulin secretion.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	156	 In addition, pleiotropic effects of reduced intracellular COUP-TFII activity on ss-cell metabolism, which may be detrimental to the generation of ATP, seem to be excluded since genes analyzed by RT-PCR show no major change in expression level.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Moreover, as COUP-TFII deficiency is genetically imposed upon ss-cells, we interpret the lack of -cell response to hypoglycemia as secondary e.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	158	, caused by a high rate of insulin release.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	159	 It is well known that ss-cells can suppress -cell function (22).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Tissue-specific deletion of HNF-3ss in pancreatic ss-cells in mice suggested in vivo coupling of -cell function to ss-cells (23).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	161	 It is worthy of note that the abnormalities due to a partial COUP-TFII deficiency in pancreatic ss-cells mimic some of the disorders observed in type 2 diabetic patients.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	162	   RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT RESULTS AND DISCUSSION RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS REFERENCES   Gene targeting and conditional allele generation.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	163	 A mouse 129SV PAC genomic clone containing the entire COUP-TFII gene was isolated by screening the RPCI21 library (from the resource center of the German Human Genoma Project).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	164	 A conditional allele was generated by flanking the first exon with loxP sites for the Cre recombinase.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	165	 A loxP site was inserted into a BglII site located 445 bp upstream of the Met-ATG codon, and the pgk-neo selection gene flanked by two additional loxP sites was introduced into a NdeI site located in the first intron.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The targeting construct was obtained after digestion by HindIII-AvrII, and the insertion was electroporated into CK35 embryonic stem cells (24).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	167	 After selection, the genotype of G418-resistant clones were identified by Southern blot analysis after XbaI digestion using an external flanking 5' EcoRI-EcoRI DNA fragment as a hybridization probe, after SpeI digestion using an external 3' noncoding DNA fragment and after PCR analysis.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Ten percent of correctly recombined clones were identified.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Cre-mediated recombination was obtained after electroporation of 107 recombinant embryonic stem cells using 4  microg pIC-Cre vector (25).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Of 288 clones isolated after Cre expression, 4 had lost the selection gene, as identified by Southern blot analysis of XbaI-digested DNA with E1 probe.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Two clones containing an fl first exon were isolated.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Mice strains carrying a COUP-TFII fl allele were established on a mixed C57BL/6N x 129SVJ background.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Genotyping was performed by PCR analysis using DNA isolated from the tail tip of newborn mice using the primers flanking the 5' loxP site: A5HF, GCA AGT CGA TTG TCT GGC TTC; R5HF, AAC TCC TCC GCT GCA CAC TA.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	174	Rip-Cre-mediated recombination of the COUP-TFII gene.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Transgenic mice expressing Cre recombinase under the control of rat insulin II promoter (Rip-Cre transgenic line [13,14]) were used to produce COUP-TFII ss-cell-specific inactivation.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The intercrossing COUP-TFII fl mice and Rip2-Cre mice were genotyped by PCR using the primers described above and primers against the Cre transgene and an internal upstream stimulatory factor 1 control as described previously (26).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Cre recombination efficiency was assessed on liver, brain, spinal cord, hypothalamus, and islet DNA prepared from isolated islets, as described below, and by PCR.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The first one, 5' to the loxP site (1), was located in the 5' noncoding region with the sequence TGA TTT CGA TGG CTT TCC TG, while the second primer (3) was located in exon 1 with the sequence CGG AGG AAC CTG AGC TAC AC.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The third primer in intron 1 (2) was located at the 3' of the loxP site with the sequence TGC CCA CAC TTT CCT ACT CC (Fig.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	180	 An 850 bp indicated an intact exon 1 from the fl allele, an 810 bp an intact exon 1 from the wt allele, while a 500 bp indicated Cre-mediated recombination.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	181	Analysis of COUP-TFII expression by Western blotting.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	182	 A total of 1,000 islets were cultured for 16 h in Ham s F10 medium containing 10 mmol/l glucose and 10% FCS.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Nuclear proteins were prepared as described (27), and 20  microg were subjected to a standard Western blot protocol using our COUP-TF-specific antibodies at a 1:1,000 dilution (11).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Control animals used in this study were either wt or Cre+/ to .
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Adult male mice were studied at 14 to 16 weeks of age.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Animals had free access to water and standard mouse diet.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	187	 All procedures were performed in accordance with the principles and guidelines established by the European Convention for the Protection of Laboratory Animals.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	188	 For glucagon, blood samples obtained by retroorbital phlebotomy were collected in tubes containing aprotinin, and radioimmunoassay was performed (Biochem ImmunoSystems-Pharmacia and Upjohn-France).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	189	 In a fed state, blood was collected at 9:30 P.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	190	 For fasting experiments, food was removed at 9:00 A.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	191	 and the mice were kept for 4 h before blood sampling.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Plasma insulin and leptin concentrations were assessed using a rat insulin enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit (Crystal Chem, Chicago, IL) and a mouse leptin enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit (Crystal Chem), respectively.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Plasma concentrations of triglycerides, free fatty acids, glycerol, total and HDL cholesterol, and albumin were determined using an automated Monarch device (Instrumentation Laboratory, Lexington, MA).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	194	Measurement of insulin release from perifused islets.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Isolation of islets of Langerhans, overnight culture, and measurement of insulin release were carried out as described previously (15).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Approximately 200 islets were loaded onto a Biogel P2 column and preperifused for 20 min in Ham s F10 medium, supplemented with 0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	197	5% BSA, 2 mmol/l glutamine, 2 mmol/l CaCl2, and 3 mmol/l glucose equilibrated with 95% air/5% CO2.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	198	5 ml/min, pulses of 10 min were given with 7.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	199	5, 10, and 20 mmol/l glucose and 10 mmol/l glucose with 20 mmol/l L-arginine.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Samples were collected every minute and assayed for immunoreactive insulin with guinea pig anti-insulin serum (Linco Research, St.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	201	 As islet insulin contents between models were similar, results were expressed as percentage of islet insulin content.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Insulin was extracted by sonicating the Biogel P2 containing the islets in 5 ml of 2 mmol/l acetic acid/0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	203	Immunohistochemistry, quantification of ss-cell mass, and ss-cell density.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	204	 ss-Cell mass was determined as described previously (28) by insulin immunostaining (Dako) on 10 subsequent sections of pancreas tissue separated by  > 50  microm followed by measurement of the surface area of the sections using Biocom VisioL@b 1000 software.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	205	 ss-Cell mass was calculated by multiplying the pancreatic weight by the relative ss-cell volume.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	206	 ss-Cell density was assessed by counting the number of nuclei in a 30,000- microm2 islet total area that contained only insulin-positive cells.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Values are the means  plus or minus  SE in five mice of each genotype.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Total pancreatic islet RNA isolated using Trizol (Gibco-BRL) were treated with RNase-free DNase-I before use for semiquantitative RT-PCR.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The PCR cycle numbers were estimated for each primer pair to assure linear range amplification.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	210	 All results were verified in seven control COUP-TFII fl/wt and mutant mice.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	211	 We quantified bands using a STORM850 PhosphoImager and Image-Quant 5.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	212	Determination of glycogen synthesis in isolated muscle.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The two soleus muscles were isolated as described previously (29) and incubated with or without 10 nmol/l insulin for 60 min at 37 degrees C in 1 ml of Krebs-Ringer bicarbonate buffer (pH 7.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	214	3) supplemented with 1% BSA and with 3-[3H] glucose (5 mmol/l, 1  microCi/ml).
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Muscles were dissolved in 1 N NaOH, aliquots were spotted onto Whatmann paper, and the filters were washed three times in ice-cold 60% ethanol before counting.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Statistical analyses were carried out using an unpaired two-tailed Student s t test for dual samples and Mann-Whitney for groups, and null hypothesis was rejected at 0.
0.4186047.15855320.html.plaintext.txt	218	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   This work was supported by INSERM (Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale), l Association de Langue Francaise pour l Etude du Diabete et des Maladies Metaboliques (grant from ALFEDIAM-Glaxosmithkline), the Ministry of the Flemish Community (Geconcerteerde Onderzoeksacties no.

0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received October 15, 1999; Revised and Accepted November 19, 1999.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   The hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)4, a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily, regulates genes that play a critical role in embryogenesis and metabolism.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Recent studies have shown that mutations in the human HNF4 gene cause a rare form of type 2 diabetes, maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY1).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	5	 To investigate the properties of these naturally occurring HNF4 mutations we analysed five MODY1 mutations (R154X, R127W, V255M, Q268X and E276Q) and one other mutation (D69A), which we found in HepG2 hepatoma cells.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Activation of reporter genes in transfection assays and DNA binding studies showed that the MODY1-associated mutations result in a variable reduction in function, whereas the D69A mutation showed an increased activity on some promoters.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	7	 None of the MODY mutants acted in a dominant negative manner, thus excluding inactivation of the wild-type factor as a critical event in MODY development.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	8	 A MODY3-associated mutation in the HNF1 gene, a well-known target gene of HNF4, results in a dramatic loss of the HNF4 binding site in the promoter, indicating that mutations in the HNF4 gene might cause MODY through impaired HNF1 gene function.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Based on these data we propose a two-hit model for MODY development.
