0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	10	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   In vertebrates the tissue-specific transcription factor hepatocyte nuclear factor (HNF)4 is expressed in liver, kidney, gut and endocrine pancreas (1,2).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	11	 HNF4 as a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily is designated NR2A1 (3) and belongs to the 2A subfamily together with HNF4ss (4) and HNF4 (5) as its closest related genes in Xenopus and mammals, respectively.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	12	 HNF4 was initially described as an orphan receptor lacking an identified ligand, but recently fatty acyl-CoA thioesters have been proposed as ligands (6).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The DNA-binding domain of HNF4 consists of two zinc finger motifs that specifically interact with a DNA element found in many promoters and enhancers of target genes.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These target genes encode serum proteins as well as enzymes involved in lipid, amino acid and glucose metabolism, but also the tissue-specific transcription factor HNF1 (1).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Based on the HNF4 binding site in the HNF1 promoter, a regulatory hierarchy has been proposed with HNF4 playing a superior role (7).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	16	 However, as the HNF4 promoter contains an HNF1 binding site, a reverse regulatory cascade may also be possible (8).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The gene regulatory potential of HNF4 has been clearly documented in transfection experiments where the forced expression of HNF4 activates several endogenous genes, but the extent of activation is determined by the type of recipient cell used (7,9 to 11).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	18	HNF4 also plays an important role in the early phases of embryogenesis since it is present as a maternal component in the egg of the amphibian species Xenopus (12) as well as in Drosophila (13).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In the mouse, embryonic expression of HNF4 can already be observed in the primary endoderm at day 4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Furthermore, in undifferentiated murine embryonic stem cells, the HNF4 gene is expressed by apparently using an alternative promoter (15).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The essential early function of HNF4 in mammals is proven by the fact that disruption of the murine HNF4 gene leads to embryonic lethality due to a dysfunction of the visceral endoderm (16,17).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	22	Lack of HNF4 expression is a typical feature of human renal cell carcinoma (18), but so far no tumour-associated mutations have been found (our unpublished data).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In contrast, mutations in the human HNF4 gene cause maturity onset diabetes in the young (MODY1), a rare form of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (19).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	24	 This disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, affects people usually under the age of 25 years and is characterised by defective secretion of insulin by the ss-cells of the pancreas (reviewed in 20).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The mutants described so far include two nonsense mutations, R154X (21) and Q268X (19), and two frameshift mutations, F75delT (22) and K99fsdelAA (23), which all result in truncated HNF4 proteins.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In addition, five missense mutations have been identified, G115S, R127W (24,25), V255M (26), E276Q (27) and V393I (28), that affect various domains of the HNF4 protein.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	27	 As HNF4 is not only expressed in the ss-cells (1), mutated HNF4 proteins are expected to have pleiotropic phenotypes.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	28	 However, no additional severe clinical phenotypes have been reported in mutant carriers, except secondary complications associated with diabetes itself.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Recently, a MODY1-associated decrease in triglyceride concentration was observed in diabetic patients that is considered to be an effect of impaired expression of hepatic apoCIII and apoB (23).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	30	 MODY3, with identical clinical features to MODY1 patients, is associated with mutations in the gene encoding the tissue-specific transcription factor HNF1 (reviewed in 20).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This fact supports the hypothesis that HNF4 and HNF1 cooperate in a network of transcription factors (2) and is strengthened by the finding of a MODY3 mutation in the HNF4 binding site of the HNF1 promoter (29).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	32	In the present work we have analysed the functional activity of several MODY-associated HNF4 mutations as well as a novel mutation found in the human hepatoma cell line HepG2.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	33	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Plasmid constructions Expression vectors.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	34	 To construct the pOP-mycHNF42 expression vector the myc tag containing a hexameric repeat of the Myc epitope was amplified from the pCS2+MT vector (30) with the 5' primer (5'-ATAAGAATGCGGCCGCGCTATGG-AGCAAAAGCTC-3') and 3' primer (5'-ATAAGAATGGCGGCCGCTCTAGAGGGGTACCAGGCCTTG-3') introducing two NotI (underlined) sites and a KpnI site (italic), respectively.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The NotI fragment of the PCR product was used to replace the cat gene of the pOP13CAT expression vector (Stratagene).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The human HNF42 cDNA was amplified from the RcHNF42 expression vector (5) with a 5' primer generating a KpnI site (italic) (5'-GGGGTACCATGCGACTCTCCAA-AACC-3') and the SP6 primer (5'-CTATTTAGGTGACACTATAG-3') and cloned as a KpnI to NotI fragment in-frame downstream of the myc tag.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	37	 PCR was performed with Taq DNA polymerase (Gibco BRL) under standard conditions.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	38	HNF4 mutants were generated by site-directed mutagenesis (Quick ChangeTM site-directed mutagenesis kit; Stratagene) on the pOP-mycHNF42 construct using the following primer pairs: D69A, 5'-GAGCTGTGCCGGCTGCAAG-3', 5'-CTT-GCAGCCGGCACAGCTC-3'; R154X, 5'-GTCCTGTCCTG-ACAGATCACC-3', 5'-GGTGATCTGTCAGGACAGGAC-3'; V255M, 5'-GATGAGCCGGATGTCCATACG-3', 5'-CGTA-TGGACATCCGGCTCATC-3'; E276Q, 5'-GATGACAATC-AGTATGCCTACC-3', 5'-GGTAGGCATACTGATTGTCA-TC-3'; Q268X, 5'-CGATCTGCAGCTCCTAGAAGGG-3', 5'-CCCTTCTAGGAGCTGCAGATCG-3'; R127W, 5'-CGG-GACTGGATCAGCACTCG-3', 5'-CGAGTGCTGATCCAG-TCCCG-3'.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The authenticity of all DNA fragments amplified by PCR was verified by sequencing.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The H4-tk-luc (31) and HNF1( to 594/ to 207)lucI (32) reporter gene constructs were described pre-viously.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To establish the rat apo-AI( to 1000/+14)lucI reporter gene the apo-AI promoter (33,34) was cloned from genomic DNA of C2 cells by PCR, with the primer (5'-CGCGGATCCGCGTTAGCGTTGCCAACACAGGGT-3' and 5'-CGTAA-GCTTCTCCCCCGGAGCTCTCCAACA-3') introducing BamHI and HindIII restriction sites (underlined), respectively, that were used to insert the promoter fragment (nucleotides  to 1000 to +14) into the pXP1 luciferase vector (35).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The human HNF1 promoter was amplified from a 6 kb genomic fragment subcloned into Bluescript SK+ that was previously isolated from a genomic phage library.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The primers used for this PCR were a T3 primer (5'-CATTAACCCTCACTAAAGGGA-3') and a primer introducing a 5' HindIII restriction site at +138 nt from the transcription start site (36).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	44	 A SacI to HindIII frag ment (nucleotides  to 325/+138) was cloned into a luciferase reporter gene vector based on pGL-Basic II (a gift from Ludger Klein-Hitpass) and named hHNF1( to 325/+138)lucII.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The hHNF1( to 325/+138)mut reporter was made by site-directed mutagenesis as described above using the primers 5'-GCTGAAGTCCCAAGTTCAGTCCC-3' and 5'-GGGACTG-AACTTGGGACTTCAGC-3'.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The exchanged nucleotides are underlined and represent the MODY3 mutation found in the HNF1 promoter (29).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The authenticity of all DNA fragments amplified by PCR was verified by sequencing.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	48	Cell culture, transfection and immunofluorescence 293 E1A-transformed embryonic human kidney cells and HeLa cells were cultured at 37 degrees C in Dulbecco s modified Eagle s medium (DMEM) with penicillin (100 U/ml), strep tomycin (100 U/ml) and 10% heat-inactivated foetal calf serum (Biochrome).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	49	 For transient transfection of 293 cells the DNA calcium phosphate co-precipitation method was used (37).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Twenty micrograms of expression vector were transfected in a 10 cm cell culture dish with 0.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	51	1 mM chloroquine to obtain optimal transfection efficiency.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	52	HeLa cells were transfected with Lipofectamine (Gibco BRL) using 2  microg reporter gene, 0.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	53	3  microg expression vector and 6  microl Lipofectamine in a 3.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	54	 In all transfection experiments the final DNA concentration was equalised by the addition of pOP13 vector.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	55	Immunofluorescence was performed essentially as previously described (38) using HeLa or 293 cells transfected in a 3.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	56	 An aliquot of 250  microl of hybridoma supernatant of the monoclonal myc-specific antibody (9E10) diluted 1:4 with culture medium was used as the primary antibody.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The Cy3-conjugated secondary antibody (code no.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	58	 415-166-100; Jackson ImmunoResearch) was visualised by fluorescence microscopy.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	59	Extract preparation and gel shifts High salt nuclear extracts of cultured cells and gel shift assays were performed as described (4).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The reaction mixture for gel shifts contained 2  microg of total protein, 150 ng of salmon sperm DNA and 104 c.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	61	 of 32P-labelled H4 oligonucleotide (37).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	62	 For competition experiments oligonucleotides containing the wild-type and the mutated HNF4 binding site of the human HNF1 promoter were used (5'-CGGCTGAAGTCCAAAGTTCAGTCCCTTCGT-3', 5'-CTAGACGAAGGGACTGAAC-TTTGGACTTCAGCCGAGCT-3').
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	63	 In the mutated oligo nucleotide the underlined base was changed from an A and T to a C and G residue, respectively.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Competition was performed with 0.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	65	5  microl rat liver nuclear extracts per reaction (39) using labelled wild-type oligonucleotide (104 c.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	66	) and increasing amounts of unlabelled wild-type or mutant oligonucleotide.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The total amount of unlabelled DNA was kept constant at 150 ng by adding salmon sperm DNA.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	68	Western blotting Western blotting was performed using the anti-myc tag antibody (9E10) as the primary antibody and a horseradish peroxidase antibody as the secondary antibody, which was detected using the ECL system (Amersham).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Pellets were incubated with DNase I prior to SDS to PAGE.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	70	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Mutation in the HNF4 gene of the human hepatoma cell line HepG2 In a search for mutations in the HNF4 gene in various tumour cell lines of human origin we observed altered migration of the PCR-amplified fragment of exon 2 upon denaturing gel electro phoresis.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Direct sequencing of this PCR product revealed an A as well as a C residue at a position 206 bp downstream of the translation start site in the coding strand of the HepG2 DNA, whereas only the nucleotide A was found in the SK-RC-8 cell line that was used as a control.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Thus codon 69 encodes the usual aspartic acid (GAC = D) as well as the amino acid alanine (GCC = A).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The heterozygosity at codon 69 was initially found in a HepG2 cell line maintained in our laboratory for several years, but was also present in a HepG2 sample obtained from CLS (passage 30; Cell Line Services, Heidelberg, Germany) as well as the HepG2 variant C3A obtained from the ATTC (CRL-10741; American Tissue Type Collection, Manassas, USA).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Thus, we conclude that the heterozygous D69A mutation is a feature specific for the human hepatoma cell line HepG2.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	75	The mutation D69A changes an amino acid in the P-box (CDGCKG) of the first zinc finger of the DNA-binding domain (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	76	 This element is identical in all members of the HNF4 gene family and has been considered as a hallmark for this nuclear receptor subfamily (1).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	77	 To investigate whether the mutated allele is transcribed, we amplified cDNA from HepG2 RNA using a primer pair specific for exons 2 and 4 of the HNF4 gene.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Sequencing of the PCR product revealed an A as well as a C at nucleotide position 206, implying transcription of both alleles.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	79	View larger version (35K):    Figure 1.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Naturally occurring mutations within the human HNF4 gene.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The domain structure of the HNF4 protein is given (1).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The D69A mutation found in HepG2 cells affects an amino acid within the P-box of the first zinc finger of the DNA-binding domain.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The diabetes-associated mutations whose functional properties are analysed in this paper are given.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	84	  The D69A mutation has not been detected in any MODY-associated family (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	85	A MODY3-associated mutation destroys the HNF4 binding site in the HNF1 promoter The concept that HNF4 and HNF1 act together in the same pathways is strengthened by the fact that HNF1 represents the MODY3 gene.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In MODY3 patients mutations have not only been found in the open reading frame of the HNF1 gene, but also at nucleotide  to 58 of the promoter region (29).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	87	 This region is highly conserved between Xenopus and mammals and corresponds to a HNF4 binding site (37).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	88	 To analyse the effect of this mutation we prepared a HNF1 promoter to luciferase reporter gene containing the sequence from  to 325 to +138 of the human HNF1 gene as well as a corresponding construct containing the MODY3 mutation (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In transfection experiments using HeLa cells that lack endogeneous HNF4 proteins, the wild-type HNF1 promoter-driven luciferase activity was stimulated up to 35-fold with increasing amounts of an expression vector encoding HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	90	 In contrast, the reporter containing the MODY3 mutation was stimulated by, at most, 4-fold with addition of the HNF4 expression vector (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	91	 This demonstrates that the single nucleotide change at  to 58 leads to a dramatic loss in the activation potential of the HNF1 promoter by HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	92	 To analyse whether this effect mainly represented the loss of binding of HNF4 to this site we performed bandshift assays using the corresponding labelled oligonucleotide and rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Figure 2C demonstrates a DNA to protein complex up-shifted with an antibody specific for HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	94	 This complex was competed out efficiently by adding increasing amounts of the unlabelled oligonucleotide, whereas the addition of an unlabelled competitor representing the mutated HNF4 binding site had no effect.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	95	 From the input of the oligonucleotides as competitors, we estimate that the MODY3 mutation in the HNF4 binding site reduces the binding affinity of HNF4 by at least a factor of 30.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Based on this finding the HNF1 promoter is a valuable reporter to analyse the function of HNF4 derivatives within a natural promoter context.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	97	View larger version (31K):    Figure 2.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The MODY3 mutation of the HNF4 binding site in the HNF1 promoter results in a loss of function.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	99	 (A) Schematic representation of the hHNF1( to 325/+138)lucII construct containing the human HNF1 promoter is given.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The HNF4 binding site with the MODY3 mutation at  to 58 of the human HNF1 promoter (29) is marked.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	101	 (B) Comparison of transactivation of the wild-type (wt) and mutant (mut) HNF1 promoter in transient transfection assays by increasing amounts of expression vector encoding wild-type HNF4 in HeLa cells.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The total amount of transfected DNA was adjusted by adding pOP13 vector DNA.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Fold induction refers to the activity seen without HNF4 expression vector.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The error bars indicate the standard deviation of six determinations.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	105	 (C) Gel shift experiments were done with 0.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	106	5  microl of rat liver extract using a labelled HNF4 binding site as probe.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The retarded DNA to protein complex and the supershift obtained by an HNF4-specific antibody are marked with an arrow and an arrowhead, respectively.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The addition of increasing amounts of unlabelled wild-type or mutated oligonucleotide representing the HNF4 binding site in (A) is given.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	109	  The transactivation potentials of the HNF4 mutants To assess the functional consequences of the mutations in the HNF4 gene we introduced the six mutations shown in Figure 1 into an expression vector encoding a myc-tagged human HNF4 protein.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Two of these mutants, R154X and Q268X, are nonsense mutants resulting in truncated proteins, whereas the others are missense mutants.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Initially we transfected saturating amounts of the expression vector together with the luciferase reporter gene containing either four HNF4 binding sites in front of the thymidine kinase promoter or the human HNF1 promoter extending from  to 325 to +138.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The data given in Figure 3 show that the missense mutant R127W retains ~50% of wild-type activity whereas the three missense mutants, V255M, E276Q and D69A, are as active as the wild-type.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In contrast, both nonsense mutants, R154X and Q268X, have completely lost their transactivation potential.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	114	 To look for more subtle changes in the activity of the mutated HNF4 proteins we performed saturation curves with the missense mutants using increasing concentrations of the corresponding expression vectors and compared them to the wild-type.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Figure 4A shows that the R127W mutant was less active at all concentrations tested, whereas the V255M and E276Q mutants gave decreased transactivation values only at low expression vector input.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	116	 However, the performance of the D69A mutant was identical to the wild-type protein.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The experiments shown in Figure 4A were performed with the luciferase reporter containing the human HNF1 promoter, but identical results were obtained using the reporter containing four HNF4 binding sites linked to the thymidine kinase promoter.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	118	 As the mutant D69A did not show any difference in its transactivation potential, we tested two further luciferase reporter constructs known to be activated by HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Using the Xenopus HNF1 promoter (37) as well as the rat apolipoprotein AI promoter (33,34) the D69A mutant was 2- to 3-fold more active than the wild-type (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	120	View larger version (68K):    Figure 3.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Transactivation potential of wild-type and mutated HNF4 in transient transfection experiments at saturation.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The reporter constructs hHNF1( to 325/+138)lucII (A) and H4-tk-luc (B) were co-transfected into HeLa cells with saturating amounts of expression vector (300 ng) encoding wild-type or the mutated HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Fold induction refers to the activity without any HNF4 derivative.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The error bars indicate standard deviation of six determinations.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	125	  View larger version (20K):    Figure 4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Saturation curves of transactivation potential of wild-type and mutated HNF4 in transfection assays.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	127	 (A) Increasing amounts of the expression vectors encoding the HNF4 mutants as given were co-transfected with the reporter construct hHNF1( to 325/+138)lucII.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The dotted and the solid lines represent the activity of the mutant and the wild-type, respectively.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	129	 (B) The expression vector encoding the HNF4 mutant D69A was co-transfected with either the Xenopus HNF1( to 594/207) promoter construct or the rat apoAI ( to 1000/+14)lucI reporter.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Fold induction refers to the activity without any HNF4 derivative and the error bars indicate standard deviation of six determinations.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	131	  The mutated HNF4 proteins do not act as dominant negative factors As HNF4 acts as a homodimer, we wondered whether the mutated factors have a dominant negative effect on the wild-type protein.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Using the HNF1 promoter-driven luciferase reporter we transfected the expression vector encoding wild-type and/or the R127W mutant into HeLa cells.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	133	 As Figure 5A illustrates, the transactivation potential of a mixture containing 30 ng wild-type and 30 ng mutant gave transactivation as expected from the potentials of both components alone.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Even when the amount of mutant compared to the wild-type was increased, transactivation was always as expected from the individual components (data not shown).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Identical data were obtained for all the other missense mutants.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Using the nonsense mutant R154X, which has no transactivation potential (see Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	137	 3), the addition of 30 ng mutant to 30 ng of the wild-type did not alter transactivation of the wild-type factor, as shown in Figure 5B.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Even a 3-fold excess of mutant to wild-type factor failed to change the activity mediated by wild-type HNF4 (data not shown).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Similarly, the Q268X mutant also did not interfere with the transactivation potential of wild-type HNF4 in co-transfection experiments (data not shown).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	140	View larger version (42K):    Figure 5.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Transactivation potential of co-transfected wild-type and mutant HNF4 on the human HNF1 promoter.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Co-transfection of wild-type HNF4 and either R127W (A) or R154X (B) was done with the amount of expression vector given.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	143	 In each experiment the amount of reporter gene construct and total DNA transfected was constant.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Fold induction refers to the activity with no HNF4 derivative and the error bars indicate standard deviation of six determinations.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	145	  The nonsense mutants R154X and Q268X are deficient in DNA binding The nonsense mutations R154X and Q268X encode truncated HNF4 proteins that retain the entire DNA-binding domain (see Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	146	 To investigate the DNA binding properties of the mutants we prepared extracts from 293 cells transfected with the corresponding expression vector.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In western blots using an antibody specific for the myc tag we could detect the R154X mutant protein in the nuclear salt extract and the insoluble pellet, as for all the other mutants.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	148	 However, the Q268X mutant protein could only be seen in the insoluble pellet and not in the nuclear salt extract (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This insolubility of the Q268X protein has also been reported elsewhere using the rat protein as backbone (40).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Therefore, in band shift assays no binding to an oligonucleotide containing an HNF4 binding site was detected with nuclear salt extracts for the Q268X mutant.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In contrast, the R154X mutant showed a retarded band, although exclusively in the lane with the antibody, indicating a weak DNA binding that is stabilised upon antibody binding.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Efficient binding was obtained by all extracts transfected with either the wild-type transcription factor or the missense mutants of HNF4 (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	153	View larger version (48K):    Figure 6.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Western blot and gel shift assay with nuclear extracts from transfected 293 cells.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	155	 293 human embryonic kidney cells were transfected with expression vectors encoding wild-type or mutant HNF4 and nuclear salt extracts were prepared after 24 h for western blots (A) or gel retardation assays (B).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The pellet fractions of the salt extracts were solubilised by DNase I digestion and used for western blots.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Only the pellet fractions of E276Q and Q268X are shown.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	158	 To visualise the transfected HNF4 variants the myc-specific antibody 9E10 was used in the western blots, whereas the monoclonal antibody H4/55, raised against amino acids 1 to 114 of rat HNF4 (18) was used in the gel retardation assays.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The band of  < 36 kDa detected in the western blot of the pellet fractions is non-specific as it is also seen in untransfected cells.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	160	  Cellular localisation of the HNF4 mutants To monitor whether the mutated HNF4 proteins show a distinct distribution within the cell, we determined the cellular localisation by immunofluorescence in transfected HeLa and 293 cells using the antibody specific for the myc tag.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Wild-type HNF4 was found in 95 to 98% in the nuclear compartment and the same distribution was found for all the missense mutants (data not shown).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	162	 On the other hand the myc tag antibody rarely detected any signal derived from the transfected nonsense mutants R154X and Q268X in HeLa cells (data not shown).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	163	 As both truncated proteins can be detected in western blots derived from transfected cells, we assume that the myc tag is not accessible for immunohistochemistry by the antibody in both these constructs.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	164	   DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   By screening the HNF4 gene in human carcinoma cell lines we identified the D69A mutation of the HepG2 hepatoma cell line.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	165	 As this mutation affects an allele that is expressed in the cell line and increases the transactivation potential of the HNF4 protein on some promoters, this finding is most relevant, as HepG2 cells are one of the most frequently used human models for hepatic cell function.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The HepG2 cell line was established in 1980 (41).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Our efforts to identify whether the mutation was already in the germline or occurred either during tumour development or during establishment of the cell line were unsuccessful due to a lack of appropriate material.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	168	 However, this mutation has not been observed in any MODY patient to date and we did not identify any other mutation in the HNF4 gene in other human hepatoma cells analysed (unpublished data in collaboration with D.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The D69A mutation alters an amino acid in the P-box of the first zinc finger.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	170	 As this residue is conserved in all HNF4 proteins from insects to mammals (1), we would assume that it plays a crucial role.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Our transfection experiments showed that it has an increased activity on some promoters.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	172	 However, the effect is quite small and one may wonder why this residue has been conserved throughout evolution.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	173	We also investigated the functional consequence of a mutation in the HNF4 binding site of the promoter of the HNF1 gene that was identified in a MODY3 family (29).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	174	 By gel retardation assays we could show that the mutated HNF4 binding site has an at least 30-fold lower affinity for HNF4 compared to the wild-type binding site.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Consistent with this dramatically reduced binding, in transfection experiments we observed that the mutated promoter can hardly be stimulated by HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	176	 This finding establishes that the MODY3 mutation generating a mutated HNF4 binding site largely destroys the ability for transactivation by HNF4 and thus represents a loss of function mutation of the HNF1 gene.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	177	 It gives further evidence that HNF4 and HNF1 cooperate in ss-cells of the pancreas and thus both genes constitute a sensitive target for the development of diabetes.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Furthermore, the result indicates that the HNF1 promoter is a relevant reporter to assay the function of HNF4 mutants in transfection experiments.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The importance of the HNF4 binding site in the HNF1 promoter has been shown in transgenic Xenopus, as a mutated HNF4 binding site of the Xenopus HNF1 promoter precludes expression of the HNF1 promoter transgenes in the pronephros (42).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	180	Our functional analysis of mutated HNF4 proteins that occur in MODY patients reveals a broad range of effects on the performance of this transcription factor.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The two nonsense mutants R154X and Q268X lack any transactivation potential and do not interfere with the activity of the wild-type factor.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	182	 This conclusion had previously been made in a report investigating Q268X function (40,43).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	183	 As Q268X has the potential to heterodimerise with the wild-type HNF4 protein in vitro, it has been proposed that the inability of the mutant to affect the activity of the wild-type in vivo may be due to an altered subcellular localisation of the mutant compared to the wild-type.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The truncated proteins derived from Q268X and R154X both retain the DNA-binding domain, but only R154X binds DNA in a gel retardation assay (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	185	 This finding is in agreement with a systematic deletion analysis of the various domains of HNF4 (44): in the absence of the C-terminal sequence (amino acids 340 to 465) the sequences located carboxyl to residue 174 inhibit DNA binding of these truncated HNF4 variants.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	186	 According to this result the DNA binding activity observed for the R154X mutant is expected.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	187	In contrast to the nonsense mutants, the three missense mutants also associated with diabetes retain substantial transactivation potential (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In fact, at saturation the mutants V255M and E276Q gave identical transactivation compared to the wild-type and only differed by a decreased activity at low expression vector input.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Under the same experimental conditions the mutant R127W gave a 2- to 3-fold lower transactivation at all concentrations tested.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	190	 After completion of our work a functional analysis of the same three missense mutants has been published (45).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The lack of any functional defect in the R127W and V255M mutants in this report may have been overlooked by the use of a single concentration of expression vector in the transfection assay.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	192	 More significantly, these authors found no transactivation for the E276Q mutant.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	193	 This discrepancy may be explained by the fact that they introduced the mutation into the HNF4 protein of the rat, since the human protein carrying the same mutation was found to be active by another group (46), in agreement with our finding.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In fact, these authors (46) have established that a major effect of the E276Q mutant involves an impaired synergy of the mutated factor with the chicken ovalbumin upstream transcription factor II (COUP TFII).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	195	 A fourth MODY missense mutant of HNF4, V393I, has been shown to have a 2-fold reduced transactivation activity (28).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Thus all missense mutants associated with diabetes have a reduced transactivation potential, whereas the missense mutant we found in HepG2 cells has an increased activity on at least some promoters (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	197	Taken together these functional data on the various HNF4 mutants associated with diabetes show a very broad effect on the activity of the transcription factor.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The only consistent feature that can be observed is a loss of function.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Mixing a transcription factor with reduced transactivation potential with the wild-type factor yields an intermediate activity if assayed at saturation but an additive value at sub-saturating conditions (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Such a behaviour is expected for a transcription factor acting as a dimer.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Surprisingly, none of the naturally occurring mutants analysed exhibited a clear dominant negative effect (Fig.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	202	 5B) that would involve inactivation of the wild-type factor, although such a mechanism seems quite probable for a transcription factor acting as a dimer.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Since different artificial mutants of HNF4 have been generated in several laboratories that act as dominant negative factors on the wild-type factor (43,47 to 49), we speculate that such mutations are not compatible with human development, as they would inactivate essential functions of the wild-type factor.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This assumption is strengthened by the fact that knockout mice die at early embryonic stages prior to gastrulation (16).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	205	 However, it is quite puzzling that a loss of function mutation of one allele in the presence of a wild-type allele leads to the development of a disease.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Assuming a gene dosage effect one would expect clinical differences between the nonsense mutations that destroy the gene, e.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	207	 R154X and Q268X, and the missense mutations that hardly affect the function of HNF4.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Such differences are not apparent, but could be hidden by the individual differences between the various patients.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	209	 As MODY1 patients are not born with diabetes and initially have no measurable abnormal function in the ss-cells of the pancreas, it seem unlikely that the mutated HNF4 is deficient in a specific function such as interaction with COUP-TF (46).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	210	 It is more probable that additional events occur with time.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Therefore, we speculate that the function of the wild-type allele is occasionally lost in ss-cells, involving either a somatic mutation or some epigenetic event.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	212	 We imagine that this loss of function of the wild-type allele leads to some selective advantage, thus allowing overgrowth of the original ss-cell population.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Such a scenario is reminiscent of the development of tumours in inherited cancer syndromes where one tumour suppressor allele is mutated in the germline and inactivation of the wild-type allele is a major step in tumour formation (50,51).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Such a two-hit model also seems to occur in non-malignant diseases, most notably in inherited human autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which is characterised by loss of or a mutation in the normal allele (52,53).
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Clearly, such a speculation on the mechanism of MODY development has to be verified by more direct approaches.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	216	 It would be crucial to show that expression of the wild-type HNF4 gene in ss-cells of MODY patient is gradually lost.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	217	 However, such an analysis cannot be readily performed in the human system.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Furthermore, one should identify HNF4-dependent processes that maintain the balance between proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis within the pancreatic ss-cell population.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	219	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   We thank Hassan Nakhei for preparing the rat apo-AI( to 1000/+14)lucI reporter, Fabian Esser for liver nuclear extracts and Bernhard Horsthemke for the human genomic library to isolate the HNF1 promoter.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	220	 This work was supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (Ry 5/4-1) and the British Diabetic Association.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	221	   FOOTNOTES   * To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Tel: +49 201 723 3110; Fax: +49 201 723 5905; Email: gerhart.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	223	de Present address: Ira Lemm, McArdle Laboratory for Cancer Research, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	224	   REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   1 Sladek,F.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	225	 (1994) Liver Specific Gene Expression.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	226	3 Nuclear Receptors Nomenclature Committee (1999) Cell, 97, 161 to 163.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	227	 (1998) Nature, 392, 512 to 516.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	228	 (1992) Nature, 355, 457 to 461.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	229	 (1997) Development, 124, 279 to 287.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	230	 (1996) Nature, 384, 458 to 460.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	231	 (1999) Diabetes, 48, 423 to 425.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	232	 (1997) Diabetes, 46, 1652 to 1657.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (1997) Diabetologia, 40, 980 to 983.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	234	 (1997) Diabetologia, 40, 859 to 862.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	235	 (1997) Diabetes, 46, 1648 to 1651.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	236	 (1996) Development, 122, 1975 to 1984.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (1988) Biotechniques, 6, 454 to 458.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (1997) Diabetes, 46, 528 to 535.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	239	 (1998) Diabetes, 47, 985 to 990.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	240	 (1980) Science, 209, 497 to 499.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	241	 (1999) Diabetes, 48, 1459 to 1465.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	242	 (1999) Diabetes, 48, 1162 to 1167.
0.38261595.10606640.html.plaintext.txt	243	 (1997) Science, 278, 1043 to 1050.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	0	The COUP-TF nuclear receptors regulate cell migration in the mammalian basal forebrain Marco Tripodi*, Alessandro Filosa*, Maria Armentano and Michele Studer.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	1	TIGEM (Telethon Institute of Genetics and Medicine), Via P.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Castellino 111, 80131 Napoli, Italy.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	3	Author for correspondence (e-mail: studer{at}tigem.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	4	   SUMMARY TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Conclusions REFERENCES   Cells migrate via diverse pathways and in different modes to reach their final destinations during development.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Tangential migration has been shown to contribute significantly to the generation of neuronal diversity in the mammalian telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	6	 GABAergic interneurons are the best-characterized neurons that migrate tangentially, from the ventral telencephalon, dorsally into the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, the molecular mechanisms and nature of these migratory pathways are only just beginning to be unravelled.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In this study we have first identified a novel dorsal-to-ventral migratory route, in which cells migrate from the interganglionic sulcus, located in the basal telencephalon between the lateral and medial ganglionic eminences, towards the pre-optic area and anterior hypothalamus in the diencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Next, with the help of transplantations and gain-of-function studies in organotypic cultures, we have shown that COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII are expressed in distinct and non-overlapping migratory routes.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Ectopic expression of COUP-TFs induces an increased rate of cell migration and cell dispersal, suggesting roles in cellular adhesion and migration processes.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Moreover, cells follow a distinct migratory path, dorsal versus ventral, which is dependent on the expression of COUP-TFI or COUP-TFII, suggesting an intrinsic role of COUP-TFs in guiding migrating neurons towards their target regions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Therefore, we propose that COUP-TFs are directly involved in tangential cell migration in the developing brain, through the regulation of short- and long-range guidance cues.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	13	Key words: COUP-TFs, Cell migration, Forebrain, Mouse.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	14	   Introduction TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Conclusions REFERENCES   It is well recognized that both radial and tangential migration contribute significantly to neuronal diversity within the telencephalon (reviewed by Marin and Rubenstein, 2003).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Projection neurons originate in the ventricular zone of the cortical anlage (pallium) and migrate radially to form the developing cortex, while GABAergic interneurons originate in restricted regions of the ventricular zone of the subcortical telencephalon (subpallium) and migrate tangentially to reach their final destination, in defined telencephalic regions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Within the subpallium, the medial ganglionic eminence (MGE) appears to be the major source of cortical interneurons (Anderson et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Furthermore, it has been shown in vivo that neurons that derive from the lateral ganglionic eminence (LGE) and the caudal ganglionic eminence (CGE) contribute to the generation of projection neurons in the striatum and GABAergic interneurons in the cortex, respectively (Nery et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Although there is an overlap in the structures populated by neurons originating from all three ganglionic eminences (GEs), the nuclei derived from the progeny of each eminence are distinct and can vary in their neurochemical profiles (Nery et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	19	 As a further source of cellular diversity, the anterior entopeduncular area, which is located between the MGE and the hypothalamus, contributes to the generation of oligodendrocytes in the cortex and hippocampus (He et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Therefore, interneurons and oligodendrocytes appear to follow a mainly ventral-to-dorsal migratory route before reaching their target tissues, and it is not known whether these cells can also migrate in a dorsal-to-ventral direction.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The identification of other migratory pathways, such as the gangliothalamic body connecting the GEs with the thalamus (Letinic and Kostovic, 1997; Rakic and Sidman, 1969), and the rostral migratory stream between the LGE and the olfactory bulb (Altman, 1969; Lois and Alvarez-Buylla, 1994; Luskin, 1993), makes it plausible that the GEs generate neurons directed to other embryonic brain regions besides the dorsal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	22	As suggested by various studies, directional migration can be achieved by short-range guidance cues and by long-range diffusible gradients (Tessier-Lavigne and Goodman, 1996).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Contact guidance relies on a permissive environment, on which gradients of diffusible guidance molecules can be superimposed, to achieve directional migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	24	 However, the distribution and molecular nature of short- and long-range molecules, and the substratum that interneurons use in their migration towards the cortex, are poorly understood.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Motogenic factors, such as hepatocyte growth factor and the neurotrophin molecules BDNF and NT4, have been shown to influence the numbers of cells migrating away from the subpallium (Polleux et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Guidance molecules with repulsive and attractive activities are likely to be involved in guiding migrating cells from the subpallium to the pallium, and within the subpallium (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	27	 For the substratum, one report has shown that blocking the function of the TAG1 adhesion molecule results in a marked reduction in GABAergic neurons in the cortex (Denaxa et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	28	 However, in Tag1 mutant mice, there is no major alteration in the tangential migration of interneurons (Marin and Rubenstein, 2003), and treatment of cortical slices with phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C (PI-PLC), an enzyme that cleaves GPI-anchored proteins, such as TAG1, does not alter interneuron migration (Tanaka et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Therefore, nothing is known about the nature of short-range guidance contact cues involved in tangential migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	30	The nuclear orphan receptor COUP-TFI favours migration of neurons through an integrin-dependent mechanism in cell cultures (Adam et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Overexpression of COUP-TFI in retinoic-acid-treated neuronal aggregates coated with different cell substrata, such as polylysine, laminin or fibronectin, results in a higher rate of migration compared with controls, whereas overexpression of a mutated form of COUP-TFI has no effects on cell migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Moreover, increased levels of vitronectin, an extracellular matrix (ECM) molecule involved in neurite extension, motor neuron differentiation and possibly neuronal migration, are detected both in aggregate and monolayer cell cultures after overexpression of COUP-TFI.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	33	 This, and the data that show that COUP-TFI stimulates transcription from the vitronectin promoter in vitro, strongly suggests a role of COUP-TFI in the regulation of ECM synthesis during the process of neuronal migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Although COUP-TFI has been shown to be involved in cortical regionalization and axon pathfinding in the developing telencephalon (Zhou et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	35	, 2001), its role in promoting cell migration in vivo has not been established so far.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	36	Here, we show that COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII are expressed in migrating cells in specific pathways in the basal telencephalon of mouse embryos at a stage when interneuron migration is robust.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Moreover, expression of COUP-TFI in the cortex co-localizes with the GABAergic marker calbindin, suggesting that a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells in the cortex are GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	38	 With the help of transplantation and tracing techniques in organotypic slice cultures, we first show the presence of a dorsal-to-ventral migratory pathway that originates in the region of the interganglionic sulcus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	39	 We then demonstrate that COUP-TFI is expressed in the basal telencephalon in neurons not only migrating dorsally towards the cortex, but also ventrally towards the pre-optic area (POa) and the hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Finally, by ectopic expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII in the GEs, we show an increased rate of migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	41	 While COUP-TFI appears to control dorsal and ventral migration in the basal telencephalon, COUP-TFII is more specific in modulating tangential migration into the intermediate zone of the cortex, suggesting distinct functions of COUP-TFs in regulating cell migration in the developing forebrain.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	42	   Materials and methods TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Conclusions REFERENCES   Generation of polyclonal antibodies of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII To eliminate any possibility of crossreactions between the antibodies against COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII, and to identify the less conserved, more exposed and immune-reactive regions of the proteins, we performed an in-silico analysis using Blastp, PredAccServer (Protein Hydropathic Profile) and Antigenic (following Kolasker-Tangaonkar algorithm) software.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	43	 GST-fusion proteins were produced using the pGEX cloning vector, in which the N-termini of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII, comprising the first 203 amino acids, were cloned into the EcoRI-SphI (for COUP-TFI) and the MslI-SphI (for COUP-TFII) restriction sites of pGEX.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The fusion proteins were grown in BL21 cells, and purified by affinity chromatography on glutathione-coated columns before being injected into rabbits.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The immunization protocol consisted of five rounds of injections before the final bleeding, and it was carried out by Primm srl, Milan, Italy.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The specificities of the antibodies were tested by blocking them with their respective immunogens, and using them in control frozen sections.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	47	 No signals were detected (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	48	Slice culture experiments Organotypic slice cultures of embryonic mouse telencephalon were prepared as previously described (Anderson et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Brain slices 250  microm thick were used for the grafting experiments (see below), for tracing with the fluorescent carbocyanide dye 1,1'-dioctadecyl 3,3,3',3'-tetramethylindocarbocyanine perchlorate (DiI; Molecular Probes), and for electroporation and lipofectamine injections (see below).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	50	Grafting experiments For the grafting experiments, the MGE, the LGE, or the region at the MGE/LGE border (MLGE) were removed from the donor brain slices derived from a green fluorescent protein (GFP)-expressing transgenic embryo (Hadjantonakis et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	51	, 1998) and transferred to the same position in a host wild-type brain slice.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The chimaeric slices were examined 1 hour after the transplant under a stereoscope with a GFP filter, to confirm that the transplants were successfully and correctly integrated into the host; slices where the grafts did not integrate, or integrated in an incorrect location, were not used for this study.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The medium was changed every day, and after about 60 hours the slices were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	54	Electroporation and lipofectamine-mediated injection For the fate map, a GFP-expressing vector was electroporated into the GEs of embryonic day (E) 13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	55	5 brain slices using the same method and conditions as described previously (Stuhmer et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	56	 For the gain-of-function approach, we used the PolyFect Transfection Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany), containing 250 ng/ microl of the expression vectors (CMV-GFP or CMV-COUP-TFs-IRES-GFP).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Full-length mouse COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII (kindly donated by M.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Tsai, Baylor College, USA) were cloned into the BamHI-XhoI sites of the pIRES-hrGFP-2a expression vector (Stratagene, California, USA).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	59	 We injected the constructs into the desired region of the brain slices, under microscopic guidance with a micro-syringe (Hamilton, Reno, Nevada, USA) held by a micromanipulator system using a 33-gauge blunt-ended needle (Hamilton).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The slices were then cultured for 60 hours, fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, and either observed by confocal microscopy (Leica DMIRE2) or embedded in OCT for further sectioning in a cryostat.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	61	Immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence The brains were sectioned and treated for immunostaining according to standard procedures.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Combined immunohistochemistry and in-situ hybridization on cryosections were carried out as described previously (Hirsch et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The times of incubation with the primary antibodies ranged from 90 minutes (anti-COUP-TFs, anti-reelin) to overnight.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The following antibodies were used: rabbit -COUP-TFI (1:500), rabbit -COUP-TFII (1:1000), mouse -reelin (clone G10, 1:500; kind gift of A.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Goffinet), mouse -calbindin (clone CB-955, Sigma, 1:500), mouse -GABA (clone GB-69, Sigma, 1:1000) and mouse -ss-tubulin type III (clone SDL.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Sections were alternatively incubated in a biotinylated secondary antibody (Vector, 1:200) and processed by the ABC histochemical method (Vector) or with a fluorescent secondary antibody (Molecular probes 1:400; Alexafluor 488 -rabbit, Alexafluor 594 -rabbit, Alexafluor 594 -mouse) for 1 hour at room temperature.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The immunohistochemistry-treated sections were dried, dehydrated and mounted on a coverslip with Permount (Fisher); the immunofluorescence-treated sections were mounted with Vectashield (Vector).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The GFP was detected by its endogenous fluorescence.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	69	Cell counting In the grafting experiments, the cells were counted on images obtained from 6  microm sections of the slices that were acquired with a CCD camera attached to a conventional microscope.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To count the cells, a standardized box (a 40x enlargement of the slice) was used; for each transplant, three sections were evaluated, and for each section, the cells in two different regions were counted.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In the gain-of-function experiments, an image of the whole slice was obtained by confocal microscopy, after reconstruction of all of the confocal planes.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The GFP-positive cells that migrated towards the cortex or towards the POa were counted on this reconstructed image, and normalized for the total number of GFP-positive cells [e.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	73	 cortex/(cortex + basal ganglia), or POa/(POa + basal ganglia)].
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The data from control and overexpressing cells within the same slice were compared, and paired Student's t-tests were used for the analysis.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	75	   Results TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Conclusions REFERENCES   COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII are expressed in distinct domains in the developing telencephalon To analyse the expression of COUP-TFs at a cellular level in the developing telencephalon, we generated polyclonal antibodies against COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Because of the high sequence homology between COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII and the other members of the steroid/thyroid superfamily, we chose the N-termini of the proteins, as these show the highest sequence divergence (see Materials and methods for more details).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Western blotting and immunohistochemistry demonstrated no crossreactivities between the two members of the family (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	78	To study the expression profile of both COUP-TFs during the period of neural migration, we performed immunohistochemistry on E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	79	5 mouse forebrains, when tangential migration is well pronounced.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	80	 At this stage, COUP-TFI expression was localized to all layers of the neocortex, to the piriform cortex, to the ventricular and subventricular zones of the LGE, to the ventricular zone of the MGE, to the POa, and in scattered cells in various regions of the basal telencephalon (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	81	 By contrast, COUP-TFII expression was mainly restricted to the marginal zone of the neocortex and to the piriform cortex and POa of the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Scattered COUP-TFII-positive cells were also identified in the LGE, at the cortico-striatal boundary, and in the intermediate zone of the neocortex (arrowheads in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII was also seen in the interganglionic region where the MGE and LGE are fused, but before the appearance of the CGE (asterisk in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	84	 For convenience, we will define this area as the `MLGE border' henceforth.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Double labelling for COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII and COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII highlighted an increased expression of COUP-TFs in this region (insets in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	86	View larger version (87K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	87	 COUP-TFs are expressed in migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Adjacent coronal sections of an E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	89	5 mouse brain at a medio-caudal level immunostained with anti-COUP-TFI (A) and COUP-TFII antibodies (A').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The asterisks in A and A' indicate expression in the interganglionic region (the `MLGE').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The insets show an enlargement of this region after double labelling of COUP-TFs (COUP-TFI mRNA/COUP-TFII antibody in A; COUP-TFI antibody/COUP-TFII mRNA in A').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The arrow in A indicates the expression boundary of COUP-TFI at the level of the medial cortex, whereas in the same region COUP-TFII is expressed in the putative cortical hem region (ch in A').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	93	 An arrow in A' indicates expression in the marginal zone of the ncx, and the arrowheads show expression at the cortico-striatal boundary and in the intermediate zone of the ncx.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	94	 (B-B''') Two different enlargements of the regions indicated in A and A'.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Most COUP-TF-positive cells show a polarized soma (arrows in B-B'''), indicative of migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	96	 (C-C') Expression of COUP-TFs in the POa region.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Note that COUP-TFI is mostly restricted in the ventricular zone and in two streams of migrating cells, as indicated by the arrows.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	98	 High expression of COUP-TFII is mainly localized in the mantle zone and in a dorsally migrating stream (arrow in C').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	99	 ch, cortical hem region; cp, choroid plexus; LGE, lateral ganglionic eminence; MGE, medial ganglionic eminence; mz, mantle zone; ncx, neocortex; pcx, piriform cortex; POa, pre-optic area; VZ, ventricular zone.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	100	  Higher magnifications of the region between the MLGE border and POa showed that the scattered COUP-TF-positive cells were grouped into streams of cells with polarized bodies, indicative of migrating neurons (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Although both proteins were localized in the same area, double detection of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII indicated that expression in these populations overlapped only partially (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In the POa region, COUP-TFs presented complementary expression (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	103	 While COUP-TFI was expressed at high levels in the ventricular zone and in streams of cells oriented dorsally and ventrally (arrows in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	104	 1C), COUP-TFII was mainly expressed in the mantle zone and in cells dorsal to the POa region (arrow in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	105	 An additional complementary expression was evident at the level of the caudomedial wall of the telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	106	 While cortical COUP-TFI expression stopped abruptly at the level of the hem region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	107	 1A), COUP-TFII was specifically expressed in this region and in the choroid plexus (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	108	In summary, COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII showed distinct and mostly non-overlapping expression profiles in the developing telencephalon at E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Furthermore, COUP-TFs appeared to be expressed in migrating cells at the stages in which several tangential migratory pathways within the developing telencephalon are well pronounced.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	110	COUP-TFs are detected in specific and non-overlapping cellular populations in the developing cortex To characterize the types of cells in which COUP-TFs are expressed, we performed a series of double immunofluorescence studies for both COUP-TFs and cell-type-specific markers (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (130K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	112	 COUP-TFI is expressed in GABAergic interneurons, while COUP-TFII is expressed in Cajal-Retzius cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Double immunofluorescence of COUP-TFs (green) and cell-type-specific markers (red) in coronal sections of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	114	 COUP-TFI (A,B), but not COUP-TFII (D,E), co-labels with calbindin in the MZ of the ncx (A,D) and of the pcx (B,E).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	115	 COUP-TFII (F,G,H), but not COUP-TFI (C,I) co-labels with reelin in the MZ of the neocortex (C,F) and in the caudomedial cortical wall (G-I).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The inset in G is a schematic diagram of the section, and indicates the position of panels (G-I).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The arrows indicate double-positive cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Note that in H, all the cells are double positive, while in I none of the cells are double positive.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	119	 MZ, marginal zone; ncx, neocortex; pcx, piriform cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	120	  The expression data described previously suggested that COUP-TFs are expressed in migrating neurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	121	 To test this hypothesis, we used an antibody against calbindin that labels a subpopulation of GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	122	5, the majority of calbindin-positive cells co-labelled with COUP-TFI-positive cells in the neocortex and piriform cortex (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	123	 2A,B), but not with COUP-TFII-positive cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Similar results were obtained with an anti-GABA antibody (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Thus, in the marginal zone of the cortex, GABAergic neurons are positive for COUP-TFI and negative for COUP-TFII.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	126	 To assess whether COUP-TFII-positive cells in the marginal zone were rather Cajal-Retzius cells, we used an antibody against reelin.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	127	 All COUP-TFII-positive cells co-expressed reelin (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	128	 2F), whereas no COUP-TFI-positive cells were positive for reelin in the cortex (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	129	5 co-localization of COUP-TFII and reelin was also detected in the caudomedial wall of the telencephalic vesicles (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	130	 2G,H), which has been recently described as one of the sources of Cajal-Retzius cells (Takiguchi-Hayashi et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	131	 This is not the case for COUP-TFI, in which no co-expression of COUP-TFI and reelin has ever been detected in this region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	132	Taken together, these data strongly suggest that in the cortex COUP-TFI is expressed in GABAergic interneurons, whereas COUP-TFII is expressed in Cajal-Retzius cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	133	COUP-TFI, and not COUP-TFII, is expressed in neurons migrating tangentially from the basal telencephalon to the cortex We have previously shown that some COUP-TFI-positive cells in the cortex are GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	134	 It is now well established that the GEs are the major source of most neocortical interneurons (reviewed by Corbin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	135	, 2001; Marin and Rubenstein, 2001).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Therefore, to assess whether COUP-TFI-positive cells located in the basal telencephalon are interneurons migrating to the cortex, a series of grafts from the GEs of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	137	5 GFP-expressing transgenic brain slices were homotopically transplanted into wild-type E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	138	 3A); expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII was subsequently monitored in adjacent sections of the same slices.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	139	 An example of an MLGE graft is shown in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	140	 3B, which demonstrates the fate of fluorescent cells after 60 hours of incubation, at which point GFP-positive cells were distributed in the mantle layer of the basal telencephalon and in various layers of the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	141	 High magnification of the lateral and medial cortex showed that GFP-positive cells were present in the marginal and intermediate zones (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Interestingly, some GFP-positive cells were also present in deeper layers, with a radial orientation towards the surface of the cortex (arrows in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	143	 These cells were previously reported to migrate from the marginal zone to the ventricular zone before moving radially, to take up their positions in the cortical anlage (Nadarajah et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	144	 After double labelling with anti-COUP-TFI, 75% of the GFP-positive cells (n=250) were also positive for COUP-TFI, including the ventricle-directed cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Adjacent sections of the same grafted brain slices showed no co-localization of COUP-TFII and GFP (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	146	 This is in agreement with the observation that COUP-TFII-positive cells in the cortex are non-GABAergic, and therefore do not originate from the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Thus, our data confirm that COUP-TFI in the cortex is expressed in GABAergic interneurons originating from the subpallium, whereas COUP-TFII expression has a pallial origin.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	148	View larger version (113K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	149	 COUP-TFI-positive cells in the MZ of the cortex originate from the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	150	 (A) A grafting experiment performed at E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	151	5, in which dorsally migrating cells are analysed.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The box delineates the area shown in C-H.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	153	 (B) Example of an MLGE transplant that shows GFP-positive cells migrating dorsally into the ctx, laterally into the pcx, and ventrally into the POa/hypo.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (C-H) Double immunofluorescence for GFP (green) and COUP-TFs (red) shows that GFP-positive cells originating from the graft are double positive for COUP-TFI in the MZ (arrowheads in C-E) and in the ventricle-oriented cells deriving from the MZ (arrows in C-E).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Arrows in insets show labelling of cells in the intermediate zone (IZ).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	156	 (F-H) Double immunofluorescence of GFP (green) and COUP-TFII (red) shows no co-localization of these two proteins.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	157	 ctx, cortex; MZ, marginal zone; pcx, piriform cortex; POa/hypo, pre-opic area/anterior hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	158	  COUP-TFI is expressed in neurons migrating tangentially towards ventral regions of the telencephalon In the transplantation experiments described above, we observed that when the grafted region included the MLGE region, a significant number of neurons also migrated towards the piriform cortex and towards more ventral regions, such as the POa and the anterior hypothalamus (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In some grafts, GFP-positive cells were also identified in the POa (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	160	 4B), suggesting that cells deriving from the interganglionic region migrate in various directions: dorsally, laterally and ventrally.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	161	 By double labelling GFP-positive cells with anti-COUP-TFI and anti-COUP-TFII antibodies, we found double-positive cells for COUP-TFI, but not for COUP-TFII, in this ventral migratory path (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	162	 This suggests that a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells located in the POa/anterior hypothalamus might originate from the GEs.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Furthermore, some of these migrating cells were neurons, as demonstrated by the double staining of GFP with the neuronal marker Tuj1 (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Finally, a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells in the ventral stream was positive for GABA (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	165	 4F), suggesting that some ventrally migrating cells are GABAergic interneurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	166	View larger version (111K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Dorsal-to-ventral migration within the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	168	 (A) A grafting experiment performed at E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	169	5, in which ventrally migrating cells are analysed.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The box delineates the area shown in C-E''.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	171	 (B) Example of a graft in which GFP-positive cells have reached the POa.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Arrows in C show co-localization of COUP-TFI (red) with GFP (green), whereas no co-labelling with COUP-TFII (red) has been identified (D) within the migratory cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	173	 (E-E'') Arrows in (E'') indicate that migrating cells are neurons by double labelling of GFP (green) with Tuj1 (red).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	174	 (E'') is a merge of panels (E) and (E').
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	175	 (F) Double immunofluorescence of COUP-TFI (green) and GABA (red) shows that some COUP-TFI-positive cells (arrows) are GABAergic in the ventral migratory stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	176	 (G) By electroporation of a GFP-expressing construct into the MLGE region, GFP-positive cells migrate ventrally, and these cells express COUP-TFI (arrows in H).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Similarly, by inserting a DiI crystal into the MLGE region, fluorescent cells are detected ventrally, in the POa/hypothalamic region (I).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	178	 These cells co-express COUP-TFI (J).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The arrow indicates a leading process.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Note that the diffuse red signal in J is the result of the DiI signal after fixation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	181	  To validate the origin of this ventral stream, we used two further experimental approaches.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	182	 We first electroporated a GFP expression vector into the MLGE region of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	183	5 brain slices and followed the fate of the electroporated cells after 60 hours of incubation (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	184	 GFP-positive cells located ventrally with respect to the injected side showed a leading process and co-labelled with COUP-TFI, but not with COUP-TFII (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Similarly, upon placing a crystal of DiI in the MLGE region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	186	 4I), fluorescent cells were subsequently identified in more ventral regions, and these cells were positive for COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The morphology of the DiI/COUP-TFI-positive cells fits well with the morphology of tangentially migrating cells observed by other authors (Nadarajah and Parnavelas, 2002).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Indeed, the nuclei of these cells were oriented in the sense of the migration and had a process lagging behind the soma (arrow in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	189	Finally, to assess whether ventrally directed migration also originates from more caudal levels, we grafted the CGE of a GFP E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	190	5 mouse brain to a wild-type brain of the same stage (n=5) (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	191	 After 60 hours of incubation, GFP-positive cells migrated out of the graft into two main streams: a medial stream directed towards the third ventricle, and a lateral stream directed laterally and ventrally into the hypothalamic region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Both streams contained single neurons with short and polarized leading processes indicative of migrating cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Adjacent sections of the same brain slices showed co-labelling of GFP with COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	194	 5C,D), whereas no COUP-TFII-positive cells were co-localized with GFP-positive cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	195	View larger version (121K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Cells originating from the caudal ganglionic eminence can migrate ventrally.
