0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	197	 (A) Summary of the type of graft and the results obtained after 60 hours of incubation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	198	 (B) A caudal ganglionic eminence (CGE) transplant shows GFP-positive cells migrating ventrally in two streams: a medial stream and a lateral stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The arrows indicate that a few cells have reached the anterior hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	200	 (C-F) Double immunofluorescence of GFP (green) and COUP-TFI (C,D) or COUP-TFII (red); E,F) on adjacent sections of the graft shown in B.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Note that all GFP-positive cells have a leading process oriented ventrally (arrows), but that only COUP-TFI is double positive for GFP (insets in C,D).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	202	 ant hypo, anterior hypothalamus; LS, lateral stream; MS, medial stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	203	  Taken together, these data show that cells located in the basal telencephalon migrate tangentially not only dorsally into the developing neocortex, as previously described, but also ventrally into the basal diencephalon, including the pre-optic and hypothalamic regions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Furthermore, our results show that COUP-TFI, but not COUP-TFII, is expressed in these populations of migrating neurons, suggesting a functional role of COUP-TFI in the patterning of tangential migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	205	Ectopic expression of COUP-TFI in the basal telencephalon promotes cells to migrate in both dorsal and ventral directions At this stage, we have demonstrated that a subpopulation of COUP-TFI-positive cells in the basal telencephalon are cells that are in the process of migrating; however, this does not demonstrate that COUP-TFI is directly involved in migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	206	 To address this issue, we set up a functional assay in E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	207	5 brain slice cultures, in which we ectopically expressed COUP-TFI in the GEs at different dorso-ventral and antero-posterior locations.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The migrating cells were followed after 60 hours of incubation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	209	 On one side, and as a control, we injected a construct expressing GFP under the control of a CMV promoter, while on the contralateral side, we injected a construct expressing COUP-TFI followed by an IRES-GFP sequence.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In this way, we could follow the fate of the injected cells by following GFP fluorescence in the same slices (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	211	 6B shows the average value of GFP-positive cells in the cortex and POa, expressed as a percentage of the total number of positive cells (for control 2838 cells, and for COUP-TFI 2318 cells; n=25; see also Materials and methods for details).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	212	 In all the cases examined, the COUP-TFI-injected sides showed a statistically significant increase in the number of cells in the cortex, compared with the control side (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Ventral migration was observed only in caudal sections in which the constructs were focally injected into the subventricular zone of the MLGE region (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	214	 In controls, 24% and 17% of GFP-positive cells were scored on average in the cortex and in the POa, respectively (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	215	 6B), whereas the non-migrating cells were maintained in compact clusters next to the injection site.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The injection of a CMV-COUP-TFI-IRES-GFP construct into the contralateral side of the same slices resulted in GFP-positive cells that were more dispersed in the mantle layer (arrowheads in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	217	 6D), and that were still in the process of migrating dorsally towards the marginal zone of the cortex and ventrally towards the POa (arrows in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Moreover, a higher number of GFP-positive cells were scored in the cortex and in the POa (72% and 46%, respectively), compared with the control side.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Thus, in the presence of higher levels of COUP-TFI, injected cells showed significantly increased spreading and migrating, compared with the normal situation (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	220	 6B), suggesting that COUP-TFI modulates cell migration in the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	221	View larger version (73K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	222	 COUP-TFI modulates dorsal and ventral migration in brain slices.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	223	 (A) Summary of the type of experiments performed on E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	224	 On one side, a GFP-expressing vector is injected as a control, while on the contralateral side an injection of a COUP-TFI-IRES-GFP expressing vector shows an increased rate of migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	225	 (B) The average value of the GFP/GFPtot ratio (black columns) or the GFP-COUP-TFI/GFPtot ratio (white columns) of all of the injected slices, calculated independently in the cortex or ventrally in the POa (see also Materials and methods).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Bars indicate standard errors of the mean.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In the COUP-TFI injected side, 72 plus or minus 4% of the GFP-positive cells migrate into the cortex, versus 24 plus or minus 4% of the GFP-positive cells in the control side.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	228	 For the POa ectopic expression of COUP-TFI, 46 plus or minus 3% of the GFP-positive cells were induced to migrate, versus 17 plus or minus 3% in the control situation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Significant P-values are indicated (for the cortex P=0.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Example of a control (C) and a COUP-TFI overexpressing (D) brain slice after 60 hours of incubation.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The vectors were focally injected into the MLGE region.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Note that in the control situation (C), a few cells were found in the cortex (C'), while the majority remain compacted in the injection point.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (D) After injection of high levels of COUP-TFI into the MLGE region, the GFP-positive cells are more dispersed (arrowheads) around the injection point, and a more pronounced contingent of cells migrates in the dorsal and ventral directions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	234	  Ectopic expression of COUP-TFII in the ganglionic eminences induces a higher rate of migration into the intermediate zone of the cortex Next, we tested whether COUP-TFII was also able to promote cell migration in the basal telencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	235	 We generated an additional construct in which the COUP-TFII-IRES-GFP cassette was under the regulation of the CMV promoter.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The control CMV-GFP- and CMV-COUP-TFII-IRES-GFP-expressing constructs were injected into the subventricular zone of the striatum on opposite sides of E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	237	 7B shows that in the presence of ectopic expression of COUP-TFII, the average number of GFP-positive cells found in the cortex (60%, of a total number of 467 cells) was significantly higher than in the control situation (32%, of a total number of 875 cells).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	238	 An example of an injection performed in the whole striatum is shown in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	239	 As expected, a high number of GFP-positive cells migrated out of the injection point into the marginal and intermediate zones of the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	240	 After injection of the COUP-TFII-expressing construct, a statistically significant increase in the GFP-positive cells was found uniquely in the intermediate layer of the neocortex, and no GFP-positive cells were ever identified in the marginal zone (arrowheads and asterisk in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	241	 However, and by contrast to previous experiments, no GFP-positive cells were ever located ventrally in the POa region, even if we focally injected the construct into the MLGE region (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Thus, ectopic expression of COUP-TFII in the basal telencephalon promotes migrating neurons to undertake a preferential route into the intermediate zone of the neocortex by avoiding the marginal zone, suggesting a cell-autonomous property of COUP-TFII in guiding cortical neurons into a specific layer of the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	243	View larger version (83K):    Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	244	 COUP-TFII regulates migration into the intermediate zone of the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	245	 (A) Summary of the type of experiments performed on E13.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The respective vectors are depicted to the left of each part of the diagram.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	247	 (B) The average values of the GFP/GFPtot ratio (black column) and the COUP-TFII-GFP/GFPtot ratio (white column) in the cortex of all of the injected slices.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Bars indicate standard errors of the mean.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In the COUP-TFII injected side, 60 plus or minus 4% of the injected cells migrate into the cortex, versus 25 plus or minus 5% of the GFP-positive cells in the control side.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Examples of control (C) and COUP-TFII mis-expressing (D) brain slices in which the vectors have been injected into the Str.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	251	 (C) Arrows indicate GFP-positive cells in the MZ, whereas arrowheads indicate the IZ migratory stream.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	252	 (D) Arrowheads indicate a higher amount of GFP-positive migrating cells in the IZ of the neocortex, whereas no cells are seen in the MZ (asterisk).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Dotted line shows the putative boundary between neocortex and striatum.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	254	 All the cells external to the dotted line have been counted as cells located in the cortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	255	 IZ, intermediate zone; MZ, marginal zone; Str, striatum.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	256	     Discussion TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Conclusions REFERENCES   Interneurons can migrate dorso-ventrally from the telencephalon to the diencephalon Cell migration within the telencephalon can be subdivided broadly into radial, and non-radial or tangential.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	257	 While radial migration uses the radial glia as a scaffold upon which cortical neurons migrate to the developing cortical plate, GABAergic interneurons originate in the GEs and use tangential migration to migrate over long distances to reach their destinations in the cortex (Marin and Rubenstein, 2003; Rakic, 1990).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	258	In this report, we have identified a novel migratory path, which to our knowledge has never been reported before.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Using grafting experiments, DNA electroporation and tracer injections, we have shown that cells located in the interganglionic region, where the MGE and LGE fuse together, have the capability of migrating ventrally towards the pre-optic and hypothalamic regions of the diencephalon (Figs 3, 4, 5).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	260	 As this path originates from the interganglionic region at specific caudal levels, it is very likely that it has been missed in other studies using similar approaches (Anderson et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The novelty of this path is twofold: first, cells migrate tangentially from dorsal to ventral, along the subventricular zone of the MGE, i.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	262	 in opposite directions with respect to the MGE-derived cortical interneurons; and second, these cells exit the basal telencephalon and migrate into the basal diencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	263	 These cells are different from the gonadotropin-releasing hormone neurons, which originate in the olfactory placode and migrate along the vomeronasal nerve fibres until they reach the POa and hypothalamus (Wray et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Migration of GABAergic neurons from the GEs to the dorsal thalamus has been observed in human brains; however, rodent embryos did not reveal a similar migratory pathway (Letinic and Rakic, 2001).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	265	 With the help of retroviral cell tracing, Marin and collaborators (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	266	, 2000) have shown that cells emanating from the MGE and the adjacent POa/anterior entopeduncular area express the transcription factor Nkx2.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	267	1 and migrate to the developing striatum, where they differentiate into local circuit neurons.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	268	 It would be interesting to find out whether Nkx2.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	269	1 is also involved in the opposite migratory path described in this report.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	270	Furthermore, we have shown that cells originating from the CGE migrate via different streams into the basal diencephalon, and in particular into the hypothalamus (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	271	 As opposed to the MLGE transplant, in which the stream of ventrally migrating cells is quite compact, cells migrating out of the CGE take a medial and latero-ventral route.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	272	 We do not know the fate of these ventrally migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	273	 In-vivo ultrasound-guided labelling or transplantation (Nery et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	274	, 2001), in which total cortices are manipulated in toto and characterized at later stages, would help us to understand the final destinies of these migrating cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	275	Is the basal telencephalon only chemorepulsive? Transplantation experiments and co-culture assays have shown that the POa and hypothalamic regions prevent interneurons from migrating in a ventral direction by secreting repulsive molecules that are responsible for the dorsal migration of interneurons towards the cortex (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	276	 However, the cues mediating this action have not been identified yet.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Here, we show that cells originating from more dorsal and caudal regions are capable of migrating ventrally towards the POa/anterior hypothalamus.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	278	 How do we reconcile these different results? First, the previous studies showed that the majority of interneurons that originated from the MGE avoided migrating in ventral directions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This is what is expected for a circumscribed graft in a section where the two GEs are well separated (Marin et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, the dorsal-to-ventral cell migration that we describe in this report originates from a restricted region, the interganglionic sulcus, at more caudal levels.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	281	 It is plausible that in order to follow the migration that originates in the MGE and LGE, this region was not included in other studies.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Therefore, we hypothesize that cells originating from different rostrocaudal levels can have different responses to the same environment by expressing position-dependent receptors.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Accordingly, COUP-TFs are not expressed in ventrally migrating cells at more rostral levels, where the two GEs are well separated (data not shown).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Thus, the POa and hypothalamus can have different roles, repulsion versus attraction, according to the type of cells they encounter.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	285	A novel role for COUP-TFs in neuronal migration in the developing forebrain COUP-TFs are orphan nuclear receptors of the steroid/thyroid superfamily shown to be involved in neurogenesis, axogenesis and neural differentiation (Park et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	286	 In the cortex, COUP-TFI is mainly known for its role in regionalization and in guidance of thalamocortical projections (Zhou et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	287	, 2001), whereas COUP-TFII is a fundamental player in angiogenesis and heart development (Pereira et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	288	 In this report, we have provided the first insights into the functional roles of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII in neuronal migration in vivo.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In a previous report, it was shown that COUP-TFI could regulate cell adhesion mechanisms required for the differentiation of embryonal carcinoma cells (Adam et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Because of the substrates on which cells were plated, it was suggested that COUP-TFI could modify the synthesis of ECM molecules, making cells autonomous for migration and spreading.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Our expression data in vivo and our functional data in organotypic cultures support these results in a context in which cell migration assumes a fundamental role in achieving neuronal diversity.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	292	 By using these different approaches, we have first shown expression of COUP-TFs in highly motile neurons, such as GABAergic and reelin-positive cells (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	293	 2); we have then confirmed the co-localization of COUP-TFI in migrating neurons in a series of grafting experiments (Figs 3, 4, 5); and finally, we have directly demonstrated a role of COUP-TFs in modulating cell migration in a gain-of-function approach (Figs 6, 7).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Our data also demonstrate that COUP-TFs can control directional migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Indeed, cells expressing higher levels of COUP-TFs (and thus GFP) not only tend to spread and lose their aspect of aggregates, but also follow specific migratory pathways (dorsal and/or ventral) that are intrinsic to cells expressing COUP-TFs (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	296	Therefore, we hypothesize a dual role for COUP-TFs.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	297	 First, they should regulate short-range cues, such as ECM and/or adhesive molecules, and in this way modulate the neighbouring environment.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Changes in a permissive environment would allow random dispersion of migratory cells.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Indeed, in the absence of COUP-TFI, GABAergic cells do migrate into the cortex, although in a less organised fashion than in the normal situation (M.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Therefore, we favour the hypothesis that COUP-TFI is involved in modulating cell migration, more than inducing cells to initiate migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	301	Second, we propose that COUP-TFs control diffusible guidance molecules, and/or their receptors, involved in cell migration.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Indeed, ectopic expression of COUP-TFI led to the correct directional migration of the targeted cells, i.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	303	 dorsal into the cortex and ventral into the POa (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	304	 6D), suggesting that cells over- or mis-expressing COUP-TFI were able to respond to COUP-TFI-dependent guidance cues.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	305	 More striking is the behaviour of MGE-migrating cells after mis-expression of COUP-TFII.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	306	 In this case, neurons that were committed to migrate into the marginal and intermediate layers of the neocortex (see control in Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	307	 7C) migrated at higher rates solely into the intermediate layer, avoiding specifically the marginal layer (Fig.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	308	 7D), suggesting that COUP-TFII regulates guidance cues required for migration into the intermediate zone of the neocortex.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	309	 This behaviour is in accordance with the COUP-TFII expression pattern and the grafting experiments described in this study.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Indeed, COUP-TFII-positive cells in the marginal zone are Cajal-Retzius cells, as seen by the co-expression with reelin, and it is now well established that Cajal-Retzius cells originate exclusively from the pallium (Hevner et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	311	, 1999; Takiguchi-Hayashi et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	312	   Conclusions TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion Conclusions REFERENCES   In summary, our data show a novel role for the COUP-TF nuclear receptors in tangential migration in the developing forebrain.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	313	 COUP-TFI has previously been reported to be required in axon guidance in the telencephalon and romboencephalon (Qiu et al.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Here, we show that COUP-TFs are involved in modulating the rates and directions of tangentially migrating cells from the basal telencephalon to the cortex, and from the basal telencephalon to the basal diencephalon.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Interestingly, the cells follow a migratory path that is dependent on the expression of COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII, suggesting an intrinsic role for COUP-TFs in guiding migrating cells towards their target region.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Finally, we speculate that COUP-TFs are regulators of a series of factors, such as short-range, non-diffusible contact guidance cues and long-range, diffusible guidance cues.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	317	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank A.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Nagy for the GFP-expressing mice, A.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Goffinet for the anti-reelin antibody and M.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Tsai for the COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII full-length cDNAs.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Fishell for helpful comments on the manuscript, and to the whole Studer laboratory for fruitful discussions.
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	322	 This work was supported by the Telethon Foundation and by the Fondo per gli Investimenti della Ricerca di Base (FIRB RBNE01WY7P; RBAU01RW82 and RBNE01BBYW).
0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	323	   Footnotes   * These authors contributed equally to the work.

0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Modes of neuronal migration in the developing cerebral cortex.

0.31626305.15548577.html.plaintext.txt	350	 The caudal ganglionic eminence is a source of distinct cortical and subcortical cell populations.

0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	0	Identification of Critical Residues for Heterodimerization within the Ligand-Binding Domain of Retinoid X Receptor Soo-Kyung Lee, Soon-Young Na, Han-Jong Kim, Jaemog Soh, Hueng-Sik Choi and Jae Woon Lee.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	1	L) Chonnam National University Kwangju 500 to 757, Korea.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	2	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Nuclear receptors regulate transcription by binding to specific DNA response elements as homodimers or heterodimers with the retinoid X receptors (RXRs).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	3	 The identity box (I-box), a 40-amino acid region within the ligand-binding domains of RXRs and other nuclear receptors, was recently shown to determine identity in the heterodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Here, we dissected this region in the yeast two-hybrid system by analyzing a series of chimeric receptors between human RXR and rat hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4), a distinct member of the nuclear receptor superfamily that prefers homodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	5	 We found that the C-terminal 11-amino acid region of the RXR I-box was sufficient to direct chimeric receptors based on the HNF4 ligand-binding domain to heterodimerize with retinoic acid receptors or thyroid hormone receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Furthermore, we identified the hRXR amino acids A416 and R421 of the 11-amino acid subregion as most critical determinants of heterodimeric interactions; i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	7	 mutant HNF4s incorporating only the hRXR A416 or R421 heterodimerized with retinoic acid receptor.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	8	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The nuclear receptor superfamily is a group of transcriptional regulatory proteins linked by conserved structure and function (1).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The superfamily includes receptors for a variety of small hydrophobic ligands such as steroids, T3, and retinoids, as well as a large number of related proteins that do not have known ligands, referred to as orphan nuclear receptors (2).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The receptor proteins are direct regulators of transcription that function by binding to specific DNA sequences named hormone response elements (HREs) in promoters of target genes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Nearly all the superfamily members bind as dimers to DNA elements.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	12	 While some apparently bind only as homodimers, thyroid hormone receptors (TRs), vitamin D receptor (VDR), retinoic acid receptors (RARs), the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor, and several orphan nuclear receptors bind their specific response elements with high affinity as heterodimers with the retinoid X receptors (RXRs) (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Based on this high-affinity binding, such heterodimers have been considered to be the functionally active forms of these receptors in vivo.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These heterodimers display distinct HRE specificities to mediate the hormonal responsiveness of target gene transcription, in that distinct HREs are comprised of direct repeats (DRs) of a common half-site with variable spacing between repeats playing a critical role in mediating specificity (2, 9).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Accordingly, RARs activate preferentially through DRs spaced by two or five nucleotides, whereas VDR and TR activate through DRs spaced by three and four nucleotides, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	16	 RXR-peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor heterodimers as well as RXR homodimers activate preferentially through DRs spaced by one nucleotide (referred to as DR1).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In addition to DRs, response elements composed of palindromes as well as inverted palindromes referred to as everted repeats (ER) have been shown to mediate transcriptional activation by RXR-RAR and RXR-TR heterodimeric complexes (9).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Such DNA-binding flexibility stands in contrast to the steroid hormone receptors, which bind exclusively as homodimers to inverted repeats (IR) spaced by three nucleotides (10).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	19	Some orphan nuclear receptors bind DNA as homodimers.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In contrast with the steroid receptor homodimers, orphan receptor homodimers can bind to both palindromic and DR-response elements.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In particular, the hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) binds as a homodimer to DR1 and is a strong constitutive transcriptional activator (11).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In contrast with HNF4, homodimers of the chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factors (COUP-TFs) such as EAR2, EAR3, and ARP1 are potent dominant repressors of both basal transcription and transactivation by several receptors, including RXR, RAR, VDR, and TR (12).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Repression of these pathways by COUP-TF is believed to be accomplished in part by direct competitive binding and by the presence of a strong carboxy-terminal repressor domain (13).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Interestingly, COUP-TF has an ability to heterodimerize with RXR, thereby titrating RXR into a transcriptionally inactive complex (14).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	25	A dimerization interface has previously been identified within the DNA binding domains (DBDs) of RXRs, RARs, VDR, and TRs that selectively promotes DNA binding to cognate direct repeat HREs (15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	26	 An additional dimerization interface that mediates cooperative binding to DNA, referred to as the I-box, has recently been mapped to a 40-amino acid region within the carboxy-terminal ligand binding domains (LBDs) of RAR, TR, COUP-TF, and RXR (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In contrast to the interface within the DBDs, this dimerization motif promotes cooperative binding with similar efficiency to all three classes of repeats, DR, IR, and ER.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The two dimerization domains appear to work in sequence and led to a two-step hypothesis for binding of heterodimers to DNA (2, 21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Accordingly, the LBD dimerization interface initiates the formation of solution heterodimers that, in turn, acquire the capacity to bind to a number of differently organized repeats.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	30	 However, formation of a second dimer interface within the DBD restricts receptors to bind to DRs.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	31	The I-box sequences are fairly well conserved among a subset of nuclear receptors including HNF4, a member of the homodimer subclass (11).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	32	 This led us to test whether the I-box region of the HNF4 plays a similar role in the homodimeric interactions and, more importantly, to determine whether differences between the I-box sequences contribute to the preferences of HNF4 for homodimerization and RXR for heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	33	 To answer these questions without complications associated with HRE binding and the dimerization interface within the DBDs, we exploited the yeast two-hybrid system in which LBDs of nuclear receptors are fused to either the DNA binding domain of the bacterial repressor LexA or the B42 transcriptional activation domain, as previously described (22, 23, 24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In this report, the HNF4 I-box was found to be sufficient for the homodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In addition, an 11-amino acid subregion within the RXR I-box was found to be essential for the heterodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	36	 From mutational analyses, the RXR amino acids A416 and R421 of the 11-amino acid subregion were also identified as particularly critical determinants of the heterodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	37	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   The HNF4 I-Box Is Sufficient to Mediate the Homodimeric Interactions To characterize dimerization properties of nuclear receptors, we exploited the yeast two-hybrid system that has been previously described (22, 23, 24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	38	 In the host strain used in this system, expression of ss-galactosidase (ss-Gal) is controlled by upstream LexA DNA-binding sites (operators).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Thus, this yeast strain depends on transcriptional activation by a LexA protein for expression of ss-Gal.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	40	 A series of nuclear receptors were fused to the full-length LexA repressor or the B42 transactivation domain.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	41	 As previously described (23, 24), LexA or its fusions to most nuclear receptors are transcriptionally inactive in yeast.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Protein-protein interactions between nuclear receptors, however, can bring the B42 transactivation domain to the LexA sites and activate the expression of the ss-Gal construct.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The LexA portion of such chimeras contains its own dimerization domain and directs high-affinity binding to the LexA operators as a dimer, regardless of the status of dimerization between nuclear receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Therefore, an important merit of this system is the fact that dimerization properties of nuclear receptors can be directly assessed without complications associated with HRE binding.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	45	 However, it should be noted that the exact nature of these interactions, for instance as to dimer vs.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	46	A dimerization interface referred to as the I-box has recently been mapped to a 40-amino acid region within the carboxy-terminal LBDs of RAR, TR, COUP, and RXR (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The I-box sequences are moderately conserved among a subset of nuclear receptors including the homodimerizing HNF4, leading us to test whether the HNF4 I-box region plays a similar role in the homodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	48	 To this end, we constructed a series of chimeras between HNF4 and RXR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	49	 PCR was used to construct B42/HNF, a chimeric protein consisting of the B42 transactivation domain fused to the entire hinge and LBDs (D, E and F, amino acids 106 to 455) of the rat HNF4 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Chimeric receptors B42/H/X-298/389, B42/H/X-338/429, B42/X-HHH, B42/H-XXX, and B42/X/H-428/339 were similarly constructed (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Western blot analyses were executed to confirm that expression levels for all the mutants constructed were comparable (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	52	 LexA/HNF4 showed some constitutive transcriptional activity in yeast, which was approximately 3.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	53	5-fold higher than that of LexA alone (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	54	 1B, coexpression of B42/HNF led to approximately 5.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	55	5-fold enhancement of this constitutive activity, faithfully reflecting the HNF4-HNF4 homodimeric interactions in this yeast system.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Furthermore, coexpression of B42/H/X-338/429 or B42/X-HHH led to approximately 4- and 7-fold enhancements of the transcriptional activity of LexA/HNF4, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	57	 In contrast, the RXR I-box could not substitute the HNF4 I-box for the homodimeric interactions, as shown by inabilities of B42/H/X-298/389, B42/H-XXX, and B42/X/H-428/339 to enhance the transcriptional activity of LexA/HNF4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	58	 These results demonstrate that the HNF4 I-box is indeed a sufficient and transferable interaction interface for the homodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	59	View larger version (34K):    Figure 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The I-box Directs Specificity in Dimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	61	A, Schematic diagrams for chimeric nuclear receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Diagram shows chimeras containing the indicated amino acids derived from RXR (open) and HNF4 (stippled), where the I-box domains are highlighted (dotted in RXR and hatched in HNF4).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Numbers refer to the amino acid boundaries of the receptor fragments consisting of the hinge and ligand binding D/E domains, the I-box domain, and the C-terminal F domain.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	64	 B, Dimerization probed by the yeast two-hybrid system.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Host cells in which ss-galactosidase expression is dependent on the presence of a transcriptional activator with a LexA DBD were transformed with plasmids expressing the indicated LexA or B42 chimeras and grown in liquid culture containing galactose, since expression of the B42 chimeras is under the control of the galactose-inducible GAL1 promoter (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	66	 ss-Galactosidase readings were determined and corrected for cell density and for time of development (A415 nm/A600 nm) x 1000/min.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Fold-activations by each B42 chimera are calculated by defining the reporter activity in the presence of B42/- as 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The result is the average of at least six different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	69	  As expected, B42/RXR was able to interact with LexA/RAR and LexA/TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	70	 1B), and similar results were observed with chimeric receptors containing the RXR I-box sequences such as B42/H/X-298/389, B42/H-XXX, and B42/X/H-428/339 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In these interactions, LexA/RAR, which includes a full-length RAR in contrast to LexA/TR and other LexA chimeras consisting of only LBDs, shows higher ss-Gal activities than LexA/TR, probably due to the AF1 activation domain in the RAR A/B domains (25).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Since LexA/TR and LexA/RAR show similar basal activities in yeast, this difference results in higher fold-activations with LexA/RAR than LexA/TR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	73	 For instance, coexpression of B42/RXR conferred approximately 44-fold activation to LexA/RAR and approximately 11-fold activation to LexA/TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	74	 It is noteworthy that incorporation of only the RXR I-box sequences conferred to the resulting chimera the ability to heterodimerize with RAR and TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	75	 1B, compare interactions with B42/HNF and B42/H-XXX).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Thus, we conclude that the RXR I-box was indeed a transferable interaction interface for heterodimerization, as reported previously (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	77	Localization of a Critical Region of the RXR I-Box for Heterodimerization As shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	78	 2, there is a high degree of sequence homology between the RXR I-box and the HNF4 I-box sequences.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Nevertheless, the HNF4 I-box directs homodimerization, while the RXR I-box directs heterodimerization (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Thus, we set out to dissect the RXR I-box region to identify sequences critical for heterodimerization by sequentially transferring part of the RXR I-box sequences into corresponding regions of the HNF4, or vice versa.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	81	View larger version (23K):    Figure 2.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Amino Acid Sequences of the I-Box Region.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	83	The I-box regions of USP (amino acids 429 to 468), human RXR (amino acids 389 to 428), and rat HNF4 (amino acids 299 to 338) are shown.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Helix 9 (H9) and helix 10 (H10), which were recently shown to constitute an interaction interface in the crystal structure of the RXR LBD (27), as well as the three most C-terminal (7, 8, 9) of the nine heptad repeats previously shown to be involved in dimerization (30 to 32), are indicated.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Sequence homology determined with the NIH BLAST program is indicated between sequences of two receptors, in which + indicates conservative changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Amino acids that are conserved between USP and RXR but not in HNF4 are shaded.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Three artificial blocks designated to facilitate subsequent chimera constructions are boxed.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	88	  Examination of the I-box sequences reveals a high level of conservation between RXR and its Drosophila counterpart ultraspiracle (USP) (26), which heterodimerizes with many different members of the superfamily.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Therefore, amino acids of the I-box critical for heterodimerization should be conserved between RXR and USP (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	90	 To facilitate analyses, we artificially divided the I-box region into three separate subregions each containing two to four residues that are conserved betwen RXR and USP but not in HNF4 (shaded in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	91	 These subregions were sequentially exchanged between B42/HNF and B42/X/H-428/339, resulting in a series of eight B42-fusion constructs shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Western blot analyses were executed to confirm that expression levels for all the mutants constructed were comparable to each other (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (39K):    Figure 3.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	94	 An 11-Amino Acid Subregion of the RXR I-Box Directs the Heterodimeric Interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	95	A, Schematic diagrams for chimeric nuclear receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Diagram shows chimeras containing the indicated amino acids derived from RXR (dotted) and HNF4 (hatched).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Three smaller areas (stippled) around the three blocks subjected to exchanges are identical between RXR and HNF4, as shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	98	 B, Dimerization properties of each chimera with LexA/HNF4, LexA/TR, and LexA/RAR were probed by the yeast two-hybrid system, as described in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Fold-activations by each B42 chimera are calculated by defining the reporter activity in the presence of B42/- as 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The result is the average of at least six different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	101	 3B, two things were evident from analyses of these chimeric receptors in the yeast two-hybrid system (22, 23, 24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	102	 First, none of the chimeric receptors was able to enhance the constitutive transcriptional activities of the LexA/HNF4, demonstrating that substitution of any of these HNF4 subregions with that of the RXR I-box blocked homodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	103	 This suggests that important residues for the homodimeric interactions are present throughout the entire HNF4 I-box.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Second, the C-terminal 11-amino acid subregion of the RXR I-box was sufficient to direct chimeric receptors to heterodimerize with RARs or TRs; i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	105	 B42/H-HHX, B42/X-HHX, B42/H-XHX, and B42/X-XHX efficiently interacted with LexA/RAR and LexA/TR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	106	Identification of Critical Amino Acids Responsible for Heterodimerization As shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	107	 4, the 11-amino acid subregion of RXR is identical to that of HNF4 with the exception of five residues (RXR A416, K417, R421, A424, and R426).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Among these, RXR K417, A424, and R426 (indicated by arrowheads in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	109	 4) are conserved changes from HNF4: i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	110	 HNF4 has glutamic acid, threonine, and glutamine (HNF4 E327, T334, and Q336) at these positions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	111	 However, RXR A416 and R421 (shaded in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	112	 4) that are conserved in USP are nonconserved changes from HNF4: i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	113	 HNF4 has glycine and leucine (HNF4 G326 and L331) at these positions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In contrast, COUP-TFs have glycine and arginine, and RARs and TRs have proline and lysine at these positions (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Accordingly, these two residues were identified as primary candidates for determining the heterodimerizing properties of the RXR I-box and subjected to mutational analyses.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (21K):    Figure 4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Amino Acid Sequences of the 11-Amino Acid Subregion of Various Receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	118	Rat HNF4 (amino acids 326 to 336), human RXR (amino acids 416 to 426), USP (amino acids 456 to 466), human COUP-TF (amino acids 363 to 373), human RAR (amino acids 375 to 385), and rat TRss (amino acids 419 to 429) are shown.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Two amino acids of this subregion that are conserved between USP and RXR but not in HNF4 are shaded.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Three amino acids that are conserved changes between RXR and HNF4 are indicated as open arrows.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	121	 5A, we introduced a series of point-mutations into the 11-amino acid subregion in the context of HNF4 resulting in three quadruple mutants (AR-AR, AR-KR, and AR-KA), three triple mutants (AR-K, AR-A, and AR-R), two double mutants (AR and PR), and three single mutants (A326, P326, and R331).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Interactions of these point-mutants with LexA/HNF4 were largely unaffected among single, double, and triple mutants with an exception of AR-K, as shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	123	 All the quadruple mutants were not able to interact with LexA/HNF4 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	124	 In contrast, quadruple mutants AR-KA and AR-KR showed relatively strong interactions with LexA/RAR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Quaduple mutant AR-AR, all the triple mutants, double mutant AR, and, most surprisingly, two single mutants (A326 and R331) were also able to interact with LexA/RAR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	126	 These interactions were relatively weak, but highly specific, as these mutants did not show any interactions with LexA/GR either in the presence or absence of its ligand, deoxycortisol (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Addition of the RAR ligands, all-trans-retinoic acid or 9-cis-retinoic acid, did not affect the interactions (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The inherently weaker interactions of LexA/TR with the heterodimerizing chimeras, however, were not evident with these point-mutants.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	129	 In contrast, as expected from their RAR-based mutations, P326 and PR that incorporate both P326 and R331 were not able to stimulate ss-galactosidase activities above that of B42/HNF when coexpressed with LexA/RAR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Western blot analyses were executed to confirm that the expression levels for all the mutants tested were indeed comparable (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	131	View larger version (25K):    Figure 5.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Point Mutants of the 11-Amino Acid Subregion of the HNF4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	133	A, The HNF4 G326, E327, L331, T334, and Q336 subjected to point mutagenesis are as indicated (conserved changes by open arrows and nonconserved changes by closed arrows, determined with the NIH BLAST program).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	134	 All the point mutants are identical to B42/HNF except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Dashed positions are identical to HNF4 residues.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	136	 B, Dimerization properties of point mutants with LexA/HNF and LexA/RAR were probed by the yeast two-hybrid system, as described in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	137	 All the point mutants are identical to B42/HNF except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Fold-activations by each B42 chimera are calculated by defining the reporter activity in the presence of B42/- as 1.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The result is the average of at least six different experiments, and the SDs are less than 5%.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	140	 C, Western blot analysis of the yeast strain EGY48 transformed with plasmids encoding indicated B42 chimeras was executed as described (23).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	141	 All the point mutants are identical to B42/HNF except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Equivalent amounts (10  microg) of crude extracts for these samples as well as null extracts were examined using an antibody directed against Flu-tag, as described previously (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	143	  To confirm the interactions observed in yeasts, we incubated a glutathione S-transferase (GST) alone, GST-HNF, GST-RXR, GST-H-HHX, GST-AR, GST-A326, or GST-R331 with TR-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	144	 All the point-mutants were identical to GST-HNF except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	145	 6, TR-LBD bound specifically to GST-RXR and GST-H-HHX, but not to GST-HNF or GST alone, independently confirming the yeast results.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In addition, TR-LBD was able to show relatively week but specific binding to GST-AR, GST-A326, and GST-R331.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In yeasts, these weak interactions were only evident with LexA/RAR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	148	 5), probably due to the AF1 activation domain in the A/B domains (25).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	149	 As expected, luciferase labeled with [35S]methionine interacted with none of the GST proteins.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Similar results were also obtained with RAR-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Overall, these results, along with the yeast results, indicate that the RXR amino acids A416 and R421 are most critical to determine identity in the heterodimeric interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (35K):    Figure 6.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	153	Luciferase and TR-LBD labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation were incubated with glutathione beads containing GST alone, GST fusions to HNF4-LBD (GST/HNF), RXR-LBD (GST/RXR), H-HHX (GST/H-HHX), A326 (GST-A326), R331 (GST/R331), and AR (GST/AR).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	154	 All the point mutants are identical to HNF4-LBD except the indicated amino acid changes.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Beads were washed, and specifically bound material was eluted with reduced glutathione and resolved by SDS-PAGE.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	156	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   A dimerization interface has been identified within the DNA binding domains (DBDs) of RXRs, RARs, VDR, and TRs that selectively promote DNA binding to cognate direct repeat HREs (15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Another dimerization interface referred to as the I-box has recently been mapped to a transferable 40-amino acid region within the carboxy-terminal LBDs of RAR, TR, COUP-TF, and RXR, which mediates cooperative binding to DNA (21).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	158	 In contrast to the interface within the DBDs, this dimerization motif promotes cooperative binding with similar efficiency to all three classes of repeats, DR, IR, and ER.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In the recently described crystal structure of the RXR LBD (27), a rotationally symmetrical dimerization interface was formed mainly by helix 10 (H10) and, to a lesser extent, helix 9 (H9) and the loop between helix 7 (H7) and helix 8 (H8).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The I-box nicely overlaps with H9 and H10 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	161	 2), whose sequences are well conserved among a subset of nuclear receptors including HNF4 (11) and COUP-TF (12) that prefer to homodimerize.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In addition, the crystal structures of RAR and TR LBDs (28, 29) demonstrate that the I-box regions adopt a structure similar to that of the RXR (27) in an overall common fold that can be summarized as an -helical antiparallel sandwich composed of 12 -helices (H1-H12).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	163	 As expected from this common fold and the conservation of the I-box sequences, the HNF4 I-box was expected to play an important role in the HNF4-HNF4 interactions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	164	 1, the HNF4 I-box region is indeed sufficient for the homodimeric interactions (see the results with B42/H/X-338/429 and B42/X-HHH in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	165	 However, residues critical for homodimerization are clearly different from those for heterodimerization, since the HNF4-HNF4 interactions were not affected by any of the HNF4 point-mutations replacing the two residues found to be critical for the heterodimeric interactions (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	166	 One potential explanation of the inability of B42/H-HHX and similar mutants (shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	167	 3) to interact with LexA/HNF4 is that the overall structure of the chimeras is disrupted.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	168	 However, this is ruled out by the ability of the chimeras to interact with LexA/RAR (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	169	The results described here define an 11-amino acid subregion of the I-box as a major determinant of dimerization specificity.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	170	 This is consistent with the fact that this subregion is contained within H10 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	171	 2), a major interface in the recently described crystal structure of the RXR LBD (27) and overlaps with heptad 9 previously shown to be critical for both homo- and heterodimerization of RXR (30, 31, 32).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	172	 We also found that a chimeric RAR construct containing the RXR 11-amino acid subregion readily interacted with RAR, lending further support for the importance of this subregion for the heterodimeric interactions (our unpublished results).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Within this subregion, RXR amino acids A416 and R421 are particularly critical, consistent with the fact that these two residues are conserved between RXR and USP, but not in the homodimerizing HNF4.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	174	 4, HNF4 has glycine and leucine, while COUP-TF has glycine and arginine at these positions, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In contrast, RAR and TR, heterodimeric partners of RXR, have proline and lysine at these positions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	176	 As expected, mutant HNF4s incorporating only the RXR A416 or R421 heterodimerized with RAR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	177	 However, these and other HNF4 point-mutants we constructed showed distinct interactions with different receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	178	 R331, which resembles COUP-TF at the two target positions, weakly interacted with LexA/RXR (data not shown), consistent with a recent finding in which COUP-TF was shown to have an ability to heterodimerize with RXR (14).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	179	 In contrast, PR, which resembles RAR and TR at these positions, did not interact with LexA/RXR (data not shown).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Similarly, AR with the RXR sequences at these two positions interacted less efficiently with LexA/RAR than single mutants A326 or R331 (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Overall, these results suggest that the two residues (RXR A416 and R421) are clearly important for identity in heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Finally, it should be noted that changes of these two residues alone were not sufficient to switch specificity in the dimeric interactions (i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	183	 from homodimerization to heterodimerization).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The change of specificity in dimerization was achieved with at least three mutations incorporated, as shown by AR-K, which weakly interacts with LexA/RAR, but not with LexA/HNF (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Similarly, all the quadruple mutants changed specificity in dimerization (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	186	 5B; compare results with LexA/HNF4 and LexA/RAR).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	187	 It is also noteworthy that the effects of substitutions with the corresponding RXR sequences on the heterodimerizing potential of the resulting HNF4 chimeras are largely accumulative: i.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	188	 A326, R331, AR, AR-K, AR-A, AR-R, and AR-AR show relatively weak fold-activations with LexA/RAR (3- to 7-fold, as shown in Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	189	 5B), while the quadruple mutants AR-KR and AR-KA, as well as the quintuple mutant B42/H-HHX (Fig.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	190	 3B), which incorporates all the five RXR amino acids of the 11-amino acid subregion, showed much stronger fold activations with LexA/RAR (23-, 21-, and 43-fold activations, respectively).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Accordingly, identity seems to be determined in the context of the overall structures in relation to neighboring residues, rather than solely by nature of the two residues.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	192	 In addition, it will be interesting to test effects of the identified mutations in the context of full-length receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	193	In conclusion, we have identified an 11-amino acid subregion of the RXR I-box as a critical domain for the heterodimeric interactions and specifically identified two residues in this subregion as determinants of heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Recently, we introduced random mutations into these two residues of RXR in an effort to make mutant RXR more selective in the process of heterodimerization.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Consistent with the importance of these residues in heterodimerization, we were indeed able to find a series of mutant RXRs with significantly altered specificity (S.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	196	 To understand in detail how these two residues fit into the overall structure of the I-box in each nuclear receptor and how they direct specificity in dimerization, more mutational studies as well as more structural information will be required.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	197	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Hormones Deoxycortisol, 9-cis-retinoic acid, and all-trans retinoic acid were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co (St.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	198	Yeast Cells, Plasmids, and Expressions EGY48 cells [MATleu2-his3-trp1-ura3-LEU2::pLexA-op6 LEU2(UASLEU2)], the lexA-ss-galactosidase reporter construct, and the LexA- and B42-parental vectors were as reported (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	199	 LexA or B42 fusions to the full-length RAR and the LBDs of GR, RXR, HNF4, and TR were as previously described (23, 24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Two subsequent PCR steps according to a strategy that has been described (33) were employed for all the following plasmid constructions, by using Vent Polymerase (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) capable of proofreading to minimize unwanted mutations.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	201	 A forward vector primer (B42 primer; 5'-GCC TCC TAC CCT TAT GAT-3') plus a reverse mutagenic primer (5'-CTT GAT CTT CCC GGG GTC ACT CAG-3') and a forward mutagenic primer (5'-CTG AGT GAC CCC GGG AAG ATC AAG-3') plus a reverse vector primer (ADH primer; 5'-GAC AAG CCG ACA ACC-3') were used to amplify B42/HNF-wild type as a template DNA at annealing temperature of 55 C.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Both PCR products were mixed in an equal molar ratio and amplified using the B42 and ADH vector primers.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Accordingly, B42/HNF includes a SmaI site just upstream of the HNF4 I-box, in which codons for amino acids Pro 296 (CCA) and Gly 297 (GGC) were silently changed to CCC (Pro) and GGG (Gly) to facilitate further subclonings.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	204	 B42/H/X-298/389 encodes rat HNF4 amino acids 106 to 298 followed by human RXR amino acids 389 to 462 to the C terminus.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Similarly, B42/H/X-338/429 encodes HNF4 amino acids 106 to 338 followed by RXR amino acids 429 to 462 to the C-terminus.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	206	 B42/X-HHH is identical to B42/RXR except that RXR amino acids 389 to 428 were replaced by HNF4 amino acids 299 to 338.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	207	 B42/H-XXX is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 299 to 338 were replaced by RXR amino acids 389 to 428.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	208	 B42/X/H-428/339 encodes RXR amino acids 198 to 428 followed by HNF4 amino acids 339 to 455 to the C terminus.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	209	 B42/H-XHH is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 299- 308 were replaced by RXR amino acids 389 to 398.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Similarly, B42/H-HXH is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 312 to 322 were replaced by RXR amino acids 402 to 412, while B42/H-HHX is identical to B42/HNF except that HNF4 amino acids 326 to 336 were replaced by RXR amino acids 416 to 426.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	211	 B42/H-XHX is identical to B42/H-HHX except that HNF4 amino acids 299 to 308 were further replaced by RXR amino acids 389 to 398.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	212	 B42/X-XHH, B42/X-HXH, B42/X-HHX, and B42/X-XHX are identical to B42/H-XHH, B42/H-HXH, B42/H-HHX, and B42/H-XHX, respectively, except that HNF4 amino acids 106 and 299 were replaced by RXR amino acids 198 to 389.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	213	 A326 and P326 are identical to B42/HNF except that amino acid Gly 326 was replaced by Ala and Pro, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	214	 R331 is identical to B42/HNF except that amino acid Leu 331 was replaced by Arg.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	215	 AR and PR are identical to R331 except that amino acid Gly 326 was further replaced by Ala and Pro, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	216	 AR-R, AR-A, and AR-K are identical to AR except that amino acids Gln 336, Thr 334, and Glu 327 were replaced by Arg, Ala, and Lys, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	217	 AR-AR is identical to AR-A except that amino acid Gln 336 was replaced by Arg.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Similarly, AR-KR and AR-KA are identical to AR-K except that amino acid Gln 336 and Thr 334 were further replaced by Arg and Ala, respectively.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	219	 All the constructs described here were sequenced to prevent any unwanted PCR mutations.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	220	 In addition, expression levels of all the B42 chimeras were determined using a monoclonal antibody directed against Flu-tagging (gift of Dr.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Kyung-Lim Lee) that resides just upstream of the B42 transactivation domain, as described (22).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	222	 HNF4 sequences from B42/HNF, B42/RXR, B42/H-HHX, A326, R331, and AR were transferred to pGEX4T1 (Pharmacia, Piscataway, NJ) to express GST fusions.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Vector for in vitro translation of the TR-LBD was as previously described (24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	224	Yeast ss-Galactosidase Assays The cotransformation and transactivation assays in yeast were performed as described previously (23).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Quantitative liquid ss-galactosidase assays were performed with the following changes as described (23).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	226	 The yeast culture was initially diluted to an A600 nm of 0.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	227	05 and plated into 96-well culture dishes with the various concentrations of hormone.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The cultures were then incubated in the dark at 30 C for 16 h.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The A600 nm was determined, and then cells were lysed and substrate was added and A415 nm was read after 10 to 30 min.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The normalized galactosidase values were determined as follows: (A415 nm/A600 nm) x 1000/min developed.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	231	 For each experiment, at least six independently derived colonies expressing chimeric receptors were tested.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	232	Pull-Down Assays GST fusion proteins were produced in Escherichia coli and purified using glutathione-Sepharose affinity chromatography essentially as described (24).
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	233	 GST proteins were bound to glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia) in binding buffer (50 mM KPO4, pH 6.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	234	0, 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 10% glycerol, 10 mg/ml E.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Beads were washed once with binding buffer and incubated for 60 min at 4 C in the same buffer with equivalent amounts of various proteins labeled with [35S]methionine by in vitro translation.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Nonbound proteins were removed by three washes with binding buffer without E.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	237	 coli extract, and specifically bound proteins were eluted with 50 mM reduced glutathione in 0.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Eluted proteins were resolved by PAGE and visualized by fluorography.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	239	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Dr.
