0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Genes Dev 7:1411 to 1422[Abstract] Zechel C, Shen X-Q, Chambon P, Gronemeyer H 1994 Dimerization interfaces formed between the DNA binding domains determine the cooperative binding of RXR/RAR and RXR/TR heterodimers to DR5 and DR4 elements.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	266	 EMBO J 13:1414 to 1424[Abstract] Zechel C, Shen X-Q, Chen J-Y, Chen Z-P, Chambon P, Gronemeyer H 1994 The dimerization interfaces formed between the DNA binding domains of RXR, RAR and TR determine the binding specificity and polarity of the full-length receptors to direct repeats.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	267	 EMBO J 13:1425 to 1433[Abstract] Predki PF, Zamble D, Sarkar B, Giguere V 1994 Ordered binding of retinoic acid and retinoid x receptors to asymmetric response elements involves determinants adjacent to the DNA binding domain.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Mol Endocrinol 8:31 to 39[Abstract] Rastinejad F, Perlmann T, Evans RM, Sigler PB 1995 Structural determinants of nuclear receptor assembly on DNA direct repeats.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Nature 375:203 to 211[CrossRef][Medline] Perlmann T, Umesono K, Rangarajan PN, Forman BM, Evans RM 1996 Two distinct dimerization interfaces differentially modulate target gene specificity of nuclear hormone receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Mol Endocrinol 10:958 to 966[Abstract] Gyuris J, Golemis E, Chertkov H, Brent R 1993 Cdi1, a human G1 and S phase protein phosphatase that associates with Cdk2.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Cell 75:791 to 803[Medline] Lee JW, Heyman RA, Moore DD 1994 A chimeric T3 receptor constitutively bound to DNA requires retinoid x receptor for hormone-dependent transcriptional activation in yeast.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Mol Endocrinol 8:1245 to 1253[Abstract] Lee JW, Ryan F, Swaffield J, Johnston S, Moore DD 1995 Interaction of thyroid hormone receptor with a conserved transcriptional mediator.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Nature 373:91 to 94 Folkers GE, Van der Leede BM, Van der Saag PT 1993 The retinoic acid receptor beta 2 contains two separate cell-specific transactivation domains at the N-terminus and in the ligand-binding domain.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Mol Endocrinol 7:616 to 627[Abstract] Yao TP, Segraves WA, Oro AE, McKeown M, Evans RM 1992 Drosophila ultraspiracle modulates ecdysone receptor function via heterodimer formation.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Cell 71:63 to 72[Medline] Bourguet W, Ruff M, Chambon P, Gronemeyer H, Moras D 1995 Crystal structure of the ligand-binding domain of the human nuclear receptor RXR-alpha.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Nature 375:377 to 382[CrossRef][Medline] Renaud J-P, Rochel N, Ruff M, Vivat V, Chambon P, Gronemeyer H, Moras D 1995 Crystal structure of the RAR-gamma ligand-binding domain bound to all- trans retinoic acid.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Nature 378:681 to 689[CrossRef][Medline] Wagner RL, Apriletti JW, McGrath ME, West BL, Baxter JD, Fletterick RJ 1995 A structural role for hormone in the thyroid hormone receptor.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Nature 378:690 to 697[CrossRef][Medline] Forman BM, Yang C-R, Au M, Casanova J, Ghysdael J, Samuels HH 1989 A domain containing leucine-zipper-like motifs mediate novel in vivo interactions between the thyroid hormone and retinoic acid receptors.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Mol Endocrinol 3:1610 to 1626[Abstract] Zhang XK, Salbert G, Lee MO, Pfahl M 1994 Mutations that alter ligand-induced switches and dimerization activities in the retinoid X receptor.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Mol Cell Biol 14:4311 to 4323[Abstract] Leng X, Blanco J, Tsai SY, Ozato K, O Malley BW, Tsai MJ 1995 Mouse retinoid x receptor contains a separable ligand-binding and transactivation domain in its E region.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Mol Cell Biol 15:255 to 263[Abstract] Higuchi R 1990 Recombinant PCR.
0.43481085.9514150.html.plaintext.txt	282	 In: Innis MA, Gelfand DH, Sninisky JJ, White TJ (eds) PCR Protocols, A Guide to Methods and Applications.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcriptional activation by hepatocyte nuclear factor-4 in a cell-free system derived from rat liver nuclei Srinivas Harish, Tasneem Khanam, Sendurai Mani and Pundi Rangarajan*.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Biochemistry, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received December 4, 2000; Revised and Accepted January 10, 2001.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Hepatocyte nuclear factor-4 (HNF4) regulates gene expression by binding to direct repeat motifs of the RG(G/T)TCA sequence separated by one nucleotide (DR1).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In this study we demonstrate that endogenous HNF4 present in rat liver nuclear extracts, as well as purified recombinant HNF4, activates transcription from naked DNA templates containing multiple copies of the DR1 element linked to the adenovirus major late promoter.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Recombinant HNF4 also activates transcription from the rat cellular retinol binding protein II (CRBPII) promoter in vitro.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The region between  to 105 and  to 63 bp of this promoter is essential for HNF-mediated transactivation.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The addition of a peptide containing the LXXLL motif abolished HNF4-mediated transactivation in vitro suggesting that LXXLL-containing protein factor(s) are involved in HNF4-mediated transactivation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	8	 This is the first report on transactivation by HNF4 in a cell-free system derived from rat liver nuclei.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	9	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Transcription factors belonging to the steroid/nuclear hormone receptor superfamily regulate gene expression in response to a variety of signaling molecules (such as steroids, thyroid hormone, retinoids, vitamin D3 and lipid metabolites) by binding to specific response elements (REs) of their target genes (1 to 3).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These REs include direct repeats of RG(G/T)TCA with 0 to 5 base spacing, palindromic RG(G/T)TCA without any spacing or single half sites (2,3).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Of these REs, direct repeats of RG(G/T)TCA with one base spacing (DR1) appear to be highly promiscuous, as they bind a number of nuclear receptors including RXR, hepatocyte nuclear factor-4 (HNF4), COUP-TFI, apolipoprotein regulatory protein 1 (ARP-1/COUP-TFII) and the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) (3,4).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	12	 These transcription factors bind to DR1 as homodimers (RXR, COUP-TFI, ARP-1 and HNF4) or heterodimers (PPAR to RXR, RAR to RXR, COUP-TFI to RXR and ARP-1 to RXR) and, as a result, genes harboring the DR1 element in their promoters can be activated constitutively by HNF4, repressed by COUP-TFI and ARP-1 or activated by the ligands of PPAR and RXR (5 to 10).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Nucleotides at base positions 1, 2 and 4 of the core motif, the spacer sequence and the location of the element within a proper promoter context were shown to determine the selective binding of these transcription factors (10).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In addition, relative abundance of these transcription factors in a given tissue also plays a major role in the regulation of their target genes (5,7).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	15	Several studies demonstrate that protein to protein and protein to DNA interactions of the nuclear receptors binding to the DR1 element result in positive or negative regulation of several hepatic genes (5,6,11).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	16	 For example, HNF4, ARP-1 and COUP-TFI compete for binding to a DR1 element within the apolipoprotein CIII promoter and while HNF4 stimulates transcription, ARP-1 and COUP-TFI function as transcriptional repressors (5,6).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although COUP-TFI is generally known as a transcriptional repressor, it has been shown to activate transcription from the SV40 promoter as well as from a DR1 element present in the promoter of the gene encoding ornithine transcarbamylase (12).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In the case of the gene encoding murine cellular retinol binding protein II (CRBPII), an HNF4/ARP-1 RE was shown to function as a promiscuous binding site for RXR and is inducible by retinoic acid only in cells expressing low levels of HNF4/ARP-1 (7).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Co-expression of PPAR and HNF4 results in suppression of HNF4-mediated transactivation from the acyl CoA oxidase promoter and only HNF4 but not PPAR can activate transcription from the apolipoprotein CIII promoter (11).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Similarly, ARP-1 or COUP-TFI repress HNF4-mediated transactivation from the human factor IX promoter and impaired HNF4 binding is one of the factors responsible for down-regulation of factor IX expression (13).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These studies suggest that cross-talk amongst DR1-binding nuclear receptors can lead to significant differences in the level of expression of their target genes in different tissues.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The fact that almost all the receptors that bind to the DR1 element are expressed in liver (7) suggests that transcription of their target genes will ultimately depend on the concentration and affinity of these receptors for their recognition sites, as well as protein to protein interactions with other factors binding to proximal and distal regulatory elements.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Thus, regulation of hepatic gene expression by these DR1-binding nuclear receptors appears to be a complex process.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	24	Most of the data on cross-talk amongst receptors binding to the DR1 element is generated from studies involving co-transfection of reporter plasmids and plasmids expressing nuclear receptors.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	25	 However, many control mechanisms that operate in differentiated tissues do not operate in the rapidly dividing cells in culture and, even when appropriate cell lines exist, all the regulation exerted on endogenous genes may not be reproduced on transfected DNA (14).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This is especially true in the case of liver cells, which rapidly lose transcription factors involved in the regulation of liver-specific genes such as albumin when cultured in vitro (14).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	27	 One of the alternative methods involves the study of transcriptional regulation of genes in vitro using nuclear extracts prepared from differentiated tissues.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Cell-free extracts prepared from rat liver nuclei have been extensively used for the study of tissue-specific regulation of several hepatic genes (15 to 17).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	29	 However, there has been no report on transactivation by nuclear receptors binding to the DR1 element in liver nuclear extracts despite the fact that several of these receptors are expressed in high levels in liver and are involved in the regulation of expression of hepatic genes (7,18 to 21).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	30	 As a first step towards understanding the mechanism of hepatic gene regulation by DR1 element-binding nuclear receptors, we developed a cell-free transcription system utilizing nuclear extracts derived from rat liver and examined DR1-dependent transactivation by HNF4 in vitro.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We demonstrate that endogenous HNF4 present in rat liver nuclear extracts and purified recombinant HNF4 activate transcription from DR1 elements linked to the adenovirus major late promoter (AdMLP) and the native rat CRBPII promoter.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Addition of a peptide containing the LXXLL motif abolished HNF4-mediated transactivation in vitro, indicating that LXXLL containing co-activator(s) may be involved in HNF4-mediated transactivation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	33	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   Construction of plasmid templates for in vitro transcription Plasmids containing the minimal AdMLP linked to a 260 (pAdMLP260) or 380 bp (pAdMLP380) G-free cassette were used as control templates for in vitro transcription as described previously (22,23).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	34	 A consensus DR1 element was synthesized as complementary oligonucleotides 5'-gatcAAGGTCAAAGGTCACTCGC-3' and 5'-gatcGCGAGTGACCTTTGACCTT-3'.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The RXRE from the rat CRBPII promoter (8) present between  to 639 and  to 605 bp was synthesized by complementary oligonucleotides 5'-gatcGCTGTCACAGGTCACAGGTCACAG GTCACAGTTCA-3' and 5'-gatcTGAACTGTGACCTGTGACCTGTGACCTGTGACCTGC-3'.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The half-site sequence in each of the complementary oligonucleotides is indicated in bold.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	37	 These oligonucleotides with gatc overhangs were phosphorylated at their 5'-ends.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Equimolar amounts were annealed as previously described (24) and cloned upstream of the AdMLP at the BamHI site of pAdMLP380.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Clones containing four copies of the DR1 element or two copies of CRBPII-RXRE oriented in the same direction were identified by dideoxynucleotide sequencing and designated pDR1-AdMLP380 and pRXRE-AdMLP380, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The CRBPII promoter region between  to 987 and +1 bp was amplified from pCRBPIICAT (8) in a PCR reaction using the primer pair 5'-GCCAAGCTTGGATCCGTCTGAGCTGAA-3' (P1) and 5'-GGGAAATATAGGGGAGACTG-3' (P2).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The G-free cassette was PCR-amplified from pAdMLP380 using the primers 5'-TATATTTCCCAAATCTATC-3' (P3) and 5'-AGTCGAATTCCCCGG GAGTGGAATGAGAAATGA-3' (P4).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The PCR products obtained from these two reactions were purified and used as templates in another PCR reaction in which P1 and P4 were used as primers.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The final PCR product consisting of 987 bp of the rat CRBPII promoter linked to a 300 bp G-free cassette was digested with BamHI and EcoRI and cloned into the BamHI- and EcoRI-digested pUC19 plasmid.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The nucleotide sequence of the final construct (p987CRBPII300) was verified by dideoxynucleotide sequencing.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The region between  to 987 and  to 746 bp of the CRBPII promoter was deleted by digesting p987CRBPII300 with SphI.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The resulting vector was purified on agarose gels and religated to generate p747CRBPII300.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Similarly, the construct p313CRBPII300 containing 313 bp of the CRBPII promoter was generated by PstI digestion of p987CRBPII300 followed by ligation of the purified vector.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	48	 For the construction of p105CRBPII300, a PCR reaction was carried out with the primers 5'-ATGCCGGGATCCAAGGGCAATTCCTTTGAGTTGGG-3' and P4 using p987CRBPII300 as template.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The PCR product was digested with BamHI and EcoRI and cloned into the BamHI- and EcoRI-digested pUC19 plasmid.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	50	 p53CRBPII300 was constructed by a similar strategy except that the primers 5'-AAGCCCGGGATCCTTTATACACCTGGTCCACTAA-3' and P4 were used for PCR amplification.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	51	Overexpression and purification of receptors The cDNA encoding HNF4 was amplified from pLEN4S-rHNF4 (20) using the primers 5'-CGCGGATCCATGCATCACCATCACCATCACGACATGGCTGACTACAGT-3' and 5'-CCGGAATTCCTAGATGGCTTCCTG-3'; the histidine codons are underlined.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The PCR product was restricted with BamHI and EcoRI and cloned into BamHI- and EcoRI-digested pThioC vector (Invitrogen) to generate pThioHNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The plasmids were transformed in Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3) (pLysS) (Novagen).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Recombinant protein expression was induced with 0.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	55	5 mM isopropylthiogalactoside (Sigma) and cells were resuspended in lysis buffer (25 mM Tris to HCl pH 7.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	56	1 mM PMSF and 10 mM ss-mercaptoethanol).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Cells were lysed by repeated freezing and thawing and the cell lysate was obtained after centrifugation at 30 000 r.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	58	 in an ultracentrifuge (Beckman) for 30 min at 4 degrees C using a Ti50 rotor.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The lysate obtained from a 1 l culture was loaded onto a 10 ml heparin to agarose (Sigma) column equilibrated with lysis buffer.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	60	 After washing, the bound protein was eluted with a buffer containing 25 mM Tris to HCl pH 7.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	61	4, 600 mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, 0.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	62	1 mM PMSF and 10 mM ss-mercaptoethanol.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The eluate was incubated with 100  microl of Ni2+-nitrilotriacetic acid (Ni2+-NTA) agarose beads (Qiagen) for 1 h at 4 degrees C.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	64	 After washing with a buffer containing 25 mM Tris to HCl pH 7.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	65	5, 600 mM NaCl, 20 mM imidazole, 0.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	66	1 mM PMSF and 10 mM ss-mercaptoethanol, the bound protein was eluted with the same buffer containing 250 mM imidazole.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The eluate was dialyzed against a buffer containing 25 mM HEPES to KOH pH 7.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	68	1 mM EDTA, 10 mM ss-mercaptoethanol, 10% glycerol and 0.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	69	2 mM PMSF and the protein was stored at  to 80 degrees C in aliquots.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	70	Preparation of rat liver nuclear extracts and cell-free transcription Rat liver nuclear extracts were prepared essentially as described previously (15 to 17).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The final preparation was stored in aliquots at  to 80 degrees C for up to 6 months.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Transcription reactions were performed in a buffer containing 25 mM HEPES pH 7.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	73	4, 25 mM KCl, 6 mM MgCl2 and 3% glycerol supplemented with 2.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	74	0 mg/ml of rat liver nuclear extract, 20 U of RNasin (Pharmacia), 100  microM 3'-O-methyl-GTP (Pharmacia), 10  microCi of [-32P]UTP (800 Ci/mmol; NEN-DuPont), 35  microM UTP, 0.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	75	0  microg of test DNA template and/or 0.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	76	5  microg of control DNA template in a final reaction volume of 20  microl.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In experiments involving addition of recombinant receptors, the recombinant proteins were first incubated with the plasmid DNA templates for 15 min at 30 degrees C and then added to the reaction mixture containing the rest of the components.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Transcription reactions were carried out at 30 degrees C for 45 min.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Reactions were stopped by the addition of 280  microl of a solution containing 250 mM NaCl, 1% SDS, 20 mM Tris to HCl pH 7.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	80	8, 5 mM EDTA, 20  microg of yeast tRNA and 30  microg of Proteinase K.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After incubation at 37 degrees C for 30 min, samples were extracted twice with 250  microl of phenol to chloroform to isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) by vortexing.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The RNA in the aqueous phase was precipitated with 2 vol of ethanol and pelleted by microcentrifugation.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The pellet was dried and resuspended in 10  microl of 80% formamide and the products were separated by electrophoresis in 5% denaturing polyacrylamide (acrylamide to bisacrylamide, 20:1; 7 M urea) gels for 2 h at 200 V in 1x Tris to borate to EDTA buffer.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The gels were dried and exposed to Biomax-MR autoradiography film (Kodak) at  to 80 degrees C with an intensifying screen for 8 h.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Quantitation was performed by densitometric scanning of the autoradiograms or by exposure of the dried gels to phosphorimager screens, gathering data on a Fijix BAS-1000 phosphorimager and analysis by MacBAS version 2.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	86	 All the cell-free transcription experiments were repeated at least twice with two different batches of rat liver nuclear extract preparations and the representative data is presented in this paper.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	87	DR1 oligonucleotide affinity chromatography of rat liver nuclear extracts Complementary oligonucleotides correponding to the CRBPII-RXRE (see above) were kinased, annealed, concatamerized and coupled to cyanogen bromide-activated Sepharose 4B (Sigma), essentially as described previously (24).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The Sepharose beads (1 g), corresponding to 3 ml of swollen resin, were coupled to 200  microg of the oligonucleotides.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	89	 For the depletion of HNF4 and other DR1-binding receptors present in rat liver nuclear extracts, the extract was incubated with a given quantity of the oligonucleotide affinity resin for 30 min at 4 degrees C.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	90	 After microcentifugation at 4 degrees C, the supernatant was transferred to a fresh tube and used directly in cell-free transcription assays.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Aliquots of each batch of nuclear extract were subjected to western blot analysis using antibodies against HNF4 (445; a kind gift of Frances Sladek, University of California, Riverside, CA) (20) before and after binding to the oligonucleotide resin.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Extracts that showed a substantial decrease in HNF4 levels ( > 90%) were used in in vitro transcription reactions.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	93	Peptide synthesis Peptides corresponding to amino acids 685 to 699 of SRC-1 of the sequence ERHKILHRLLQEGSP that can interact with nuclear receptors in a ligand-dependent manner as well as a mutant peptide of the sequence ERHKILHRAAAEGSP that has been shown to be incapable of interacting with nuclear receptors (25,26) were purchased from Xcyton (India).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	94	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   DR1-dependent transcriptional activation in rat liver nuclear extracts Liver is enriched in several DR1 binding nuclear receptors that have been shown to be involved in the regulation of several hepatic genes.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	95	 However, the ability of these receptors to activate transcription in a cell-free system derived from rat liver nuclear extracts has not been reported.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	96	 In this study, we first examined transactivation by endogenous DR1-binding hepatic nuclear receptors from naked DNA templates in a homologous cell-free system derived from rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	97	 A series of plasmid templates were constructed for use in cell-free transcription (see Materials and Methods).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Plasmids containing the minimal AdMLP linked to a 260 (pAdMLP260) or 380 bp (pAdMLP380) G-free cassette were used as control templates.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The pDR1-AdMLP380 and pRXRE-AdMLP380 test templates contain four copies of the consensus DR1 element or two copies of the CRBPII-RXRE upstream of the AdMLP-linked to 380 bp G-free cassette, respectively (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Transcription reactions contained both specific and control templates and fold activation was calculated as the ratio of 32P-labeled RNA obtained from the specific template to that obtained from the control template.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Rat liver nuclear extracts capable of accurate transcription initiation by RNA polymerase II were prepared (15 to 17) and cell-free transcription assays were carried out with pDR1-AdMLP380 and pRXRE-AdMLP380 as test templates along with pAdMLP380 or pAdMLP260 as control templates.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The results presented in Figure 1B indicate that pDR1-AdMLP380 (lanes 2 and 3) and pRXRE-AdMLP380 (lanes 4 and 5) are transcribed 3- and 5-fold higher than the control templates, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 and pRXRE-AdMLP380 was always higher than that from the control templates and varied from 3- to 8-fold in different batches of extract.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Thus, the endogenous DR1-binding transcription factors present in rat liver nuclear extracts can selectively activate transcription from these templates.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (41K):    Figure 1.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Transactivation by DR1-binding proteins present in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	107	 (A) Schematic representation of plasmid templates used in cell-free transcription.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Plasmids containing AdMLP linked to G-free cassettes 260 or 380 bp in length were used as control templates.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Four copies of DR1 element or two copies of the CRBPII-RXRE were cloned upstream of the AdMLP linked to a G-free cassette of 380 bp length.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	110	 (B) Cell-free transcription assays were performed (as described in Materials and Methods) with the control templates pAdMLP380 and pAdMLP260 (lane 1), pDR1-AdMLP380 and pAdMLP260 (lanes 2 and 3) or pRXRE-AdMLP380 and pAdMLP260 (lanes 4 and 5).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The arrow and asterisk represent transcripts generated from 380 and 260 bp G-free cassettes, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Addition of 9-cis-RA (10 to 5 M) had no significant effect on transactivation from pDR1-AdMLP380 (lane 3) or pRXRE-AdMLP380 (lane 5).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	113	  Transactivation by recombinant HNF4 in rat liver nuclear extracts It has been reported that recombinant HNF4 expressed and purified from bacterial extracts can activate transcription in nuclear extracts derived from HeLa cells, a cell type that does not express HNF4 (27).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The fact that liver nuclear extracts can support DR1-dependent transcription in vitro encouraged us to study transactivation by recombinant HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	115	 We overexpressed full-length HNF4 (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	116	coli and purified the protein by chromatography on a heparin to agarose column followed by chromatography on an Ni2+-NTA column (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Addition of recombinant HNF4 to rat liver nuclear extracts resulted in activation of transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Thus, both the endogenous HNF4 present in rat liver nuclear extracts and the recombinant HNF4 can activate transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	119	 2C, compare lane 2 with lanes 3 and 4).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	120	 We then examined the ability of recombinant HNF4 to activate transcription from rat liver nuclear extracts with depleted levels of the endogenous DR1-binding proteins.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Incubation of liver nuclear extracts with DR1-oligonucleotide affinity resin resulted in significant depletion of HNF4 levels as evident from western blotting of extracts before and after depletion (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	122	 3A; compare lane 1 with lane 2).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	123	 A similar decrease was also observed in the case of RXR, which also binds to the DR1 element (data not shown).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The ability of such an extract to activate transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 was examined in an in vitro transcription reaction.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The results indicate that transactivation from pDR1-AdMLP380 is drastically reduced in the extracts with depleted levels of endogenous DR1-binding proteins (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	126	 3B, compare lane 2 with lane 4).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Addition of recombinant HNF4 to such extracts resulted in a dose-dependent increase in transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 but not from pAdMLP260 (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	128	 3C, compare lane 1 with lanes 2, 3 and 4).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Taken together, the results presented in Figures 2C and 3C indicate that recombinant HNF4 can activate transcription in the presence or absence of endogenous DR1-binding proteins, including HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	130	View larger version (24K):    Figure 2.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Transactivation by recombinant HNF4 in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	132	 (A) Schematic representation of HNF4 consisting of 455 amino acids.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	133	 (B) SDS to PAGE analysis of recombinant His-tagged, thio-HNF4 overexpressed and purified from bacterial extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Lane M, molecular weight markers; lane 1, recombinant HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	135	 (C) Cell-free transcription reactions were carried out in the absence (lanes 1 and 2) or presence of 30 (lane 3) or 45 pmol (lane 4) of recombinant HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The arrow and asterisk represent transcripts generated from 380 and 260 bp G-free cassettes, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	137	  View larger version (15K):    Figure 3.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Depletion of endogenous DR1-binding proteins such as HNF4 in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	139	 (A) Western blot analysis of rat liver nuclear extract with anti-HNF4 antibodies before (lane 1) or after (lane 2) incubation with DR1-oligonucleotide resin.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	140	 (B) Cell-free transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 and pAdMLP260 templates before (lanes 1 and 2) or after (lanes 3 and 4) depletion of endogenous DR1-binding proteins in rat liver nuclear extract.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	141	 (C) Cell-free transcription from pDR1-AdMLP380 and pAdMLP260 templates in extracts depleted of endogenous DR1-binding proteins in the absence (lane 1) or presence (lanes 2 to 4) of recombinant HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The arrow and asterisk represent transcripts generated from 380 and 260 bp G-free cassettes, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	143	  Transactivation from native rat CRBPII promoter by recombinant HNF4 The plasmid templates used thus far contain multiple copies of the DR1 element or CRBPII-RXRE cloned upstream of a heterologous promoter (AdMLP) and thus may not reflect the regulation from a DR1 element in the context of a native promoter.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	144	 We therefore examined transactivation from a native promoter containing DR1 elements.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	145	 We selected the rat CRBPII promoter since it has been shown to contain promiscuous binding sites for HNF4, ARP-1, RXR and COUP-TFI at  to 639 (RE1),  to 105 (RE2) and  to 62 bp (RE3) (7,8) (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Different regions of the CRBPII promoter were cloned upstream of a 300 bp G-free cassette (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	147	 4A) and transactivation from these templates by recombinant HNF4 was examined in rat liver nuclear extracts depleted of endogenous DR1-binding proteins.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The results indicate that recombinant HNF4 activates transcription from plasmid DNA templates containing  to 987,  to 747,  to 313 and  to 105 bp (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	149	 4B, lanes 2, 4, 6 and 8, respectively) of rat CRBPII promoter.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A drastic reduction in HNF4-mediated transactivation was observed in the case of p53CRBPII300, which contains  to 53 bp of CRBPII promoter (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Thus, a region between  to 105 and  to 54 bp is essential for HNF4-mediated transactivation of rat CRBPII promoter in the cell-free system.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	152	View larger version (75K):    Figure 4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	153	 HNF4 activates transcription from rat CRBPII promoter in the cell-free system.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (A) Schematic representation of the rat CRBPII promoter containing putative RA REs (RE1, RE2 and RE3) as previously described (7,8).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The internal restriction sites in the CRBPII promoter are indicated.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The plasmid p987CRBPII300 containing 987 bp of rat CRBPII promoter linked to a G-free cassette 300 bp in length was constructed by PCR using pCRBPIICAT (8) as template.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	157	 All other constructs were generated from this plasmid either by making use of the internal restriction enzyme sites in the CRBPII promoter or by PCR using appropriate primers (see Materials and Methods).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	158	 (B) Cell-free transcription reactions were carried out with rat liver nuclear extracts depleted of endogenous DR1-binding proteins in the presence of p987CRBPII300 (lanes 1 and 2), p747CRBPII300 (lanes 3 and 4), p313CRBPII300 (lanes 5 and 6), p105CRBPII300 (lanes 7 and 8) or p53CRBPII300 (lanes 9 and 10).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Recombinant HNF4 (45 pmol) was added as indicated.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	160	 pAdMLP380 was used as control template in all the reactions.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The arrow and asterisk indicate transcripts arising from 380 and 300 bp G-free cassettes, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	162	  Addition of a peptide containing the LXXLL motif inhibits HNF4-mediated transactivation in the cell-free system Recent studies indicate that coactivators such as RIP-140, TIF-1, SRC-1, CBP and GRIP-1 are involved in transactivation by nuclear receptors (28,29).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Amongst these, SRC-1, CBP and GRIP-1 have been shown to play a role in HNF4-mediated transactivation (30 to 32).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	164	 These coactivators contain a short sequence motif, LXXLL, that is necessary and sufficient to mediate the binding of these proteins to liganded nuclear receptors.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Short peptides containing this motif have been shown to compete with these coactivators for nuclear receptor binding (25,28 to 33).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	166	 We therefore examined the effect of addition of a peptide containing the LXXLL motif on HNF4-mediated transactivation in the cell-free system.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	167	 We synthesized a peptide containing the LXXLL motif and another one containing mutations in and around the LXXLL motif (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	168	 When equimolar amounts of these peptides were added to the cell-free transcription reactions, HNF4-mediated transactivation from p105CRBPII300 (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	169	 5B, lane 2) and pDR1AdMLP380 (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	170	 5C, lane 2) was inhibited by the wild-type peptide containing the LXXLL motif (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	171	 5B and C, lanes 6 to 8) but not by the mutant peptide (Fig.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (47K):    Figure 5.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Addition of a peptide containing the LXXLL motif results in the repression of HNF4-mediated transactivation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	174	 (A) Sequences of the peptides added to the cell-free transcription reactions.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The amino acids corresponding to the LXXLL motif are underlined.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	176	 (B) HNF4-mediated transactivation from p105CRBPII300 template (lane 2) is repressed by the wild-type peptide (lanes 6 to 8) but not by the mutant peptide (lanes 3 to 5).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	177	 All the tubes contained pAdMLP380 as did the control template.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Rat liver nuclear extract with depleted levels of endogenous DR1-binding proteins was used in this experiment.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The arrow and asterisk indicate transcripts arising from 380 and 300 bp G-free cassettes, respectively.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	180	 (C) HNF4-mediated transactivation (lane 2) from pDR1-AdMLP380 is repressed by the wild-type peptide (lanes 6 to 8) but not by the mutant peptide (lanes 3 to 5).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Rat liver nuclear extract without depletion of endogenous DR1-binding proteins was used in this experiment.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	182	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES   One of the characteristic features of nuclear receptors is their ability to regulate gene expression by binding to unique REs in the promoters of their target genes (1).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	183	 However, certain REs are recognized by more than one receptor and in such cases co-existence of these receptors in the same cell type results in cross-coupling of nuclear receptor signaling (2,3).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	184	 For example, promiscuous binding of HNF4, RXR, COUP-TFI, ARP-1 and PPAR-RXR to DR1 elements present in the promoters of several genes can alter their gene expression patterns in different tissues (4 to 21).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Liver is an ideal tissue to study cross-talk amongst DR1-binding nuclear receptors since a majority of such receptors are expressed in liver and are implicated in the regulation of several hepatic genes (34).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	186	 So far, there has been no report on the study of DR1-mediated in vitro transcription using cell-free extracts derived from rat liver.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In this study, we demonstrate that endogenous DR1-binding transcription factors present in rat liver nuclear extracts can activate transcription in vitro.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Addition of recombinant HNF4 to this cell-free system results in enhancement of DR1-mediated transcription over and above that observed with endogenous HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Depletion of endogenous DR1-binding proteins abrogates DR1-dependent transactivation and addition of recombinant HNF4 to such extracts restores DR1-dependent transactivation.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	190	 These observations indicate that HNF4 is the major transcription factor involved in DR1-dependent transactivation in this cell-free transcription system.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	191	 HNF4 activates transcription from the rat CRBPII promoter as well, which harbors promiscuous binding sites (RE1, RE2 and RE3) for several DR1-binding transcription factors (7).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Deletion of a region containing RE1 and RE2 has no effect on HNF4 activation of the CRBPII promoter.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	193	 However, deletion of a region containing RE3 results in a drastic decrease in HNF4-mediated transactivation.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Thus, RE3 present between  to 105 and  to 52 bp is the major cis-acting element involved in HNF4-mediated transactivation of the rat CRBPII promoter.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	195	 These results are significant in view of the conflicting reports on murine CRBPII gene regulation (7,8).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	196	 While RE1 was shown to mediate 9-cis-retinoic acid (RA)-dependent transactivation of the rat CRBPII gene by RXR in F9 cells (8), RE2 and RE3 were identified as the major regulatory elements of the mouse CRBPII gene (7).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Our results indicate that RE1 and RE2 are dispensable and RE3 is the major regulatory element through which HNF4 activates rat CRBPII gene transcription.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	198	 While our results are in agreement with those reported by Nakshatri and Chambon (7), we wish to point out that the CRBPII gene is expressed only in the neonatal liver and adult intestine but not in the adult liver.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Thus, while HNF4 is able to activate CRBPII gene transcription in rat liver nuclear extracts, tissue-specific gene silencing mechanisms that are operational in vivo may prevent HNF4 from activating CRBPII gene transcription in the adult rat liver.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The fact that DR1-dependent transactivation can be restored in liver nuclear extracts with depleted levels of endogenous DR1-binding proteins by the addition of recombinant HNF4 indicates that this cell-free system can be used to further dissect the mechanism of hepatic gene regulation by HNF4 without interference from other DR1-binding receptors.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	201	 To this end, we examined the role of coactivators in HNF4-mediated transactivation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Research in the last decade has led to the identification of several nuclear receptor coactivators (NCoAs) as well as nuclear receptor corepressors (29).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Analysis of domains involved in the interaction between NCoAs and nuclear receptors indicated that an LXXLL motif is both necessary and sufficient for ligand-dependent interaction of several NCoAs with nuclear receptors (25,28 to 33).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Since several NCoAs contain an LXXLL motif, we examined the involvement of such protein factors in HNF4-mediated transactivation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Our study indicates that a peptide containing the LXXLL motif inhibits HNF4-mediated transactivation in vitro.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	206	 It is logical to conclude that the repression is due to competition between an endogenous LXXLL-containing coactivator(s) and the peptide for binding to HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Thus, an LXXLL-containing coactivator(s) appears to be involved in HNF4-mediated transactivation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	208	 These results are significant in view of the reports that LXXLL-containing coactivators, such as CBP, SRC-1 and GRIP-1, have been shown to be involved in HNF4 function in vivo (30 to 32).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Whether these coactivators are involved in transactivation by HNF4 in rat liver nuclear extracts is not clear.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Our attempts to characterize the coactivator involved in transactivation by HNF4 in rat liver nuclear extracts have not been successful thus far.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Addition of antibodies to CBP or SRC-1 did not affect HNF4-mediated transactivation in this cell-free system under conditions where addition of HNF4 antibodies readily inhibited transactivation from pDR1-AdMLP380 (data not shown).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Thus, further studies are needed to characterize the coactivator(s) involved in HNF4 activation in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	213	This study clearly demonstrates that the cell-free system derived from rat liver nuclear extracts can be a useful tool for the study of regulation of hepatic gene expression by DR1-binding nuclear receptors in general and HNF4 in particular.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	214	 While we have focussed our attention on HNF4 activation in this study, this cell-free system can also be used to study transactivation by other DR1-binding nuclear receptors such as RXR, ARP-1, COUP-TF, PPAR-RXR etc.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	215	 We have used only naked DNA templates in this study but it will be interesting to study transcriptional regulation by HNF4 from chromatin templates in rat liver nuclear extracts.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The ligand-independent activation of HNF4 demonstrated in this study also opens up new opportunities to study the role of ligands in modulating HNF4 function since long-chain fatty acyl-CoA thioesters were shown to modulate HNF4 function in HeLa nuclear extracts (35).
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The cell-free system described in this study differs from that derived from HeLa cells in that the latter does not express HNF4.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Since HNF4 is a major regulator of several hepatic genes, a cell-free system derived from liver is well suited for the study of hepatic gene regulation by HNF4 and identification of its ligands.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	219	   ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS   We thank Ronald M.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	220	Evans for providing the cDNA clones of HNF4, RXR, COUP-TFI and the rat CRBPII promoter, Frances Sladek for the HNF4 antibodies and G.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	221	Padmanaban for his help and advice.
0.48113066.11222753.html.plaintext.txt	222	 This work was supported by a research grant from the Department of Science and Technology, New Delhi, India.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	1	Equipe Information et Programmation Cellulaire (F.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	3	), Unite Mixte de Recherche 6026 Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Universite de Rennes I, Campus de Beaulieu, 35042 Rennes Cedex, France; Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics (P.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	4	), Arrhenius Laboratories for Natural Sciences, Stockholm University, Stockholm SE-106 91, Sweden.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Dr.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Gilles Salbert, Equipe Information et Programmation Cellulaire, Unite Mixte de Recherche 6026 Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Universite de Rennes I, Campus de Beaulieu, 35042 Rennes cedex, France.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	7	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor I (COUP-TFI) is an orphan member of the nuclear hormone receptor superfamily that comprises key regulators of many biological functions, such as embryonic development, metabolism, homeostasis, and reproduction.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Although COUP-TFI can both actively silence gene transcription and antagonize the functions of various other nuclear receptors, the COUP-TFI orphan receptor also acts as a transcriptional activator in certain contexts.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Moreover, COUP-TFI has recently been shown to serve as an accessory factor for some ligand-bound nuclear receptors, suggesting that it may modulate, both negatively and positively, a wide range of hormonal responses.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In the absence of any identified cognate ligand, the mechanisms involved in the regulation of COUP-TFI activity remain unclear.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The elucidation of several putative phosphorylation sites for MAPKs, PKC, and casein kinase II within the sequence of this orphan receptor led us to investigate phosphorylation events regulating the various COUP-TFI functions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	12	 After showing that COUP-TFI is phosphorylated in vivo, we provide evidence that in vivo inhibition of either MAPK or PKC signaling pathway leads to a specific and pronounced decrease in COUP-TFI-dependent transcriptional activation of the vitronectin gene promoter.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Focusing on the molecular mechanisms underlying the MAPK- and PKC-mediated regulation of COUP-TFI activity, we show that COUP-TFI can be directly targeted by PKC and MAPK.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These phosphorylation events differentially modulate COUP-TFI functions: PKC-mediated phosphorylation enhances COUP-TFI affinity for DNA and MAPK-mediated phosphorylation positively regulates the transactivation function of COUP-TFI, possibly through enhancing specific coactivator recruitment.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	15	 These data provide evidence that COUP-TFI is likely to integrate distinct signaling pathways and raise the possibility that multiple extracellular signals influence biological processes controlled by COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	16	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   THE NUCLEAR RECEPTOR superfamily encompasses many ligand-activated transcription factors in addition to also a large number of proteins whose ligands are unknown and which are thus termed orphan receptors (1, 2).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These receptors play crucial roles both as transcriptional activators and repressors, and are regulators of a wide range of biological functions including development, metabolism and reproduction.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Among nuclear orphan receptors, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factors (COUP-TFs) are encoded by distinct genes sharing an exceptionally high degree of sequence homology (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The expression patterns of COUP-TFs have been extensively studied in several divergent species and appear to be relatively similar, suggesting a conservation of COUP-TF function throughout evolution.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Although each COUP-TF has its own distinct expression pattern during embryonic development and in adult mice, these patterns are often overlapping and both genes are widely expressed in the developing central nervous system (8, 11, 12, 13).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These findings suggest a functional redundancy among COUP-TFs, which are classically considered to act as key factors during neurogenesis.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Overexpression of COUP-TFs and gene disruption experiments performed in Drosophila, Xenopus, and mouse, define a major role of these orphan receptors in the formation of the anterior brain in tetrapods, in the patterning of the eye in the fly, and in the modulation of axogenesis and cranial neural crest cell behavior in mammals, respectively (3, 9, 14, 15, 16).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The recent finding that COUP-TFI function is required for cortical layer IV cell survival through correct guidance and connection of axons from mouse thalamic neurons supports the hypothesis that COUP-TFI functions in the transcriptional control of axon guidance cues (17).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Aside from neuronal expression patterns, COUP-TFs show overlapping, yet distinct, expression patterns in many tissues during development, suggesting their involvement in organogenesis (8, 13).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Consistent with a role for these nuclear receptors accessory to neurogenesis, recent data show that COUP-TFII is involved in angiogenesis, vascular remodeling, and heart development (16, 18).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	26	Initial studies identified COUP-TFs as transcriptional activators (19, 20, 21, 22); nevertheless, COUP-TFs can repress the transcriptional activation mediated by a number of ligand-bound nuclear receptors, including VDR, TRs, RXRs, and RARs (23, 24, 25, 26).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A functional cross-talk between COUP-TFs and retinoid-signaling pathways during development has been proposed, based on the comprehensively documented antagonistic effects of COUP-TFs on retinoid-dependent gene expression, and the observation that COUP-TF genes are themselves targeted by retinoids (7, 8, 15, 27, 28).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	28	 However, recent data indicate that the orphan receptors can also serve as accessory factors for some ligand-bound nuclear receptors such as GR, ER, and RAR (29, 30, 31).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	29	 In some specific promoter contexts, COUP-TFs are thus able to enhance the ligand-induced transactivation function of these various receptors, suggesting that COUP-TFs may be required for effectively establishing the cues for certain genetic responses after exposure of the cell to a ligand.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In this respect, it is not surprising that common phenotypes, such as similar bone fusions, are generated in COUP-TFI-/- and RAR1-/-/RARss-/- independent knockout experiments (16, 32).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The recent finding that COUP-TFI is required for the induction of growth inhibition and apoptosis by retinoic acid in cancer cells further substantiates a positive interaction between COUP-TFs and retinoid receptors in vivo (31).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	32	With very few exceptions, most ligand-dependent nuclear receptors can be activated in a ligand-independent manner through phosphorylation events (33).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	33	 As an example, ER can activate transcription after phosphorylation, independent of supplemented E2 (33, 34, 35, 36, 37).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In a similar manner, many other ligand-regulated nuclear receptors are either activated or repressed through phosphorylation events (33, 34), and these regulatory mechanisms seem relevant also to the orphan receptors such as Nur77/NGFI-B, HNF-4 or ROR (38, 39, 40, 41).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Although COUP-TFs were cloned more than 10 yr ago, a ligand has yet to be elucidated or characterized, suggesting that COUP-TFs could be true orphan nuclear receptors.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The presence of several putative phosphorylation sites for MAPKs, PKC, and casein kinase II (CKII), within its sequence led us to postulate that COUP-TFI could be targeted by cellular kinases.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	37	 In this report, we demonstrate that COUP-TFI can be directly phosphorylated by PKC and MAPK, these phosphorylation events differently modulating COUP-TFI functions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	38	 COUP-TFI is thus likely to be regulated by extracellular signals transduced through distinct phosphorylation pathways.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	39	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Two Nuclear Receptor Half-Binding Sites within the Vitronectin (Vn) Gene Promoter Mediate Transcriptional Activation by the Orphan Nuclear Receptor COUP-TFI Previously, we have shown that COUP-TFI can transactivate the mouse Vn gene promoter in P19 embryonal carcinoma cells (42).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Figure 1 demonstrates that the ability of COUP-TFI to activate this promoter is not restricted to P19 cells considering the observation of the similar induction in COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To delineate the promoter sequences involved in this phenomenon as well as the mode of activation by COUP-TFI, we mutated individually or in combination the two consensus (TGACCC) half-binding sites for nuclear receptors present in the mouse promoter referred to as NR1 and NR2 (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Whereas the NR2 half-site could generate a direct repeat with a 3-bp spacer (DR-3) when combined to the degenerated TGACTT sequence located downstream of the NR2 site, no TGACCC-related sequence could be found in the vicinity of the NR1 sequence (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Thereby, both consensus half-sites could organize a DR-66 element stably interacting with COUP-TFI dimers.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	44	 When cotransfected in COS-7 cells with a COUP-TFI expression vector, the promoter in which the NR1 site was mutated was activated at a much lower level compared with its wt counterpart (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Mutation of the NR2 site moderately reduced COUP-TFI-induced activation (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The double NR1/NR2 mutant did not show a greater reduction of COUP-TFI-induced activity compared with the single NR1 mutant (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	47	 These data strongly suggest that the NR1 site prevails over the NR2 site for COUP-TFI activation of the Vn promoter in COS-7 cells.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Because COS cells are known to overproduce proteins encoded by transfected vectors, the relatively high amounts of COUP-TFI expressed in COS-7 cells could have attenuated the impact of the mutations introduced in the Vn gene promoter.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Based on this observation, we transfected P19 cells with the different mutants to verify their ability to be activated by COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In this cellular context, both NR1 and NR2 mutations reduced COUP-TFI activation by 50%.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	51	 When combined, the NR1 and NR2 mutations resulted in a loss of COUP-TFI activation by 78% (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	52	 1C), suggesting that binding to both sites is required for COUP-TFI transactivation in P19 cells.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Consistent with the transfection data indicating that the NR1 site is involved in the Vn gene promoter regulation, we observed that COUP-TFI could effectively interact as a dimer (as suggested by the position of the protein/DNA complex) with the NR1 half-site in EMSA experiments (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Although COUP-TFI was able to interact with the NR1-containing oligonucleotide, it conferred low affinity for this element judged by the observation that cold NR1 is a poor competitor compared with the high affinity DR1 binding element (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	55	 These experiments clearly indicate that COUP-TFI could transactivate the mouse Vn gene promoter through direct binding to at least one low affinity site including the NR1 sequence, and possibly to a second site composed of the NR2 element.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	56	 However, the residual activation by COUP-TFI observed with the double mutant suggests that other undetected binding-sites could be recognized by the orphan receptor, or that part of the COUP-TFI activity could be unrelated to DNA binding as previously shown in other contexts (43).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	57	View larger version (49K):    Figure 1.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The COUP-TFI Orphan Receptor Activates the Mouse Vn Gene Promoter through Direct Binding to a Consensus Half-Site.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The induction obtained with the wt promoter in the presence vs.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	68	 in the absence of COUP-TFI expression vector was set to 100% of activation.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Results are shown as the mean  plus or minus  SEM of 12 (COS-7 cells) or 6 (P19 cells) values obtained in three and two independent experiments, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	71	 EMSA analysis of COUP-TFI binding to the NR1 element is shown in panel D.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	72	 WCEs from COS-7 cells transfected with empty pcDNA3 (first lane) or pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI (other lanes) were incubated with the 32P-labeled double-stranded NR1 oligonucleotide and the complexes were resolved by nondenaturing electrophoresis.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The position of the specific COUP-TFI/NR1 complex, as assessed by supershifting analysis with the anti-hCOUP-TFI antibody (Ab), is indicated by an arrowhead.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Nonspecific bands are indicated by asterisks.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	75	 To estimate the affinity of COUP-TFI for the NR1 sequence, increasing amounts (2- to 10-fold molar excess) of NR1, DR1, and AP1 cold competitor oligonucleotides were added.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	76	  Prediction of Multiple Putative Phosphorylation Sites for Distinct Signaling Pathways within the Human COUP-TFI Sequence and in Vivo Phosphorylation of COUP-TFI As shown in Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	77	 2A, in silico analysis of the human COUP-TFI protein sequence revealed several putative phosphorylation sites targeted by distinct cellular kinases, namely CKII, PKC, and proline-directed kinases such as MAPKs.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The consensus phosphorylation sites were defined as S/TXXD/E for CKII (44), S/TXR/K for PKC (45), and PX1-2S/TP for the three distinct MAPK pathways identified in mammalian cells (46).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	79	 These pathways include members of the extracellular signal-regulated kinases ERK1/p44MAPK and ERK2/p42MAPK, the Jun NH2-terminal kinase and the p38 kinase (47, 48, 49).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The three putative MAPK phosphorylation sites identified within the human COUP-TFI sequence were found to be highly conserved throughout evolution (8), and were clustered in the amino-terminal A/B domain (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The putative CKII and PKC phosphorylation sites, some of which were also evolutionarily conserved (8), were in contrast distributed throughout the COUP-TFI sequence (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The DNA binding domain (DBD) contained exclusively PKC target sites, whereas the A/B and the putative ligand binding domain (LBD) of the receptor displayed both CKII and PKC potential target sequences (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The presence of several putative phosphorylation sites for various cellular kinases in the human COUP-TFI sequence raises the possibility that, similar to posttranslational modifications described for several nuclear receptors, COUP-TFI could be a phosphoprotein in vivo, whose activity may be regulated by specific phosphorylation events.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	84	 To test this hypothesis, we cloned the human COUP-TFI cDNA encoding residues 57 to 423 in frame with the glutathione-S-transferase (GST) coding sequence of the mammalian expression vector pBC/GST.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	85	 After mutation of the PKA site present in the GST sequence, the recombinant vector was transfected in COS-7 cells.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	86	 32P-Labeled orthophosphate was then added to label phosphoproteins in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Cell extracts were purified on glutathione-agarose beads and analyzed in SDS-PAGE.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The positions of GST and GST::COUP-TFI were determined by western blotting with an anti-GST antibody (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Results indicate that both GST and GST::COUP-TFI had been labeled in vivo (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Although a slight incorporation of 32P was observed for GST, the GST::COUP-TFI fusion protein was approximately 90 times more radioactive than free GST, indicating that COUP-TFI is indeed a phosphoprotein in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	91	View larger version (29K):    Figure 2.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The Human COUP-TFI Sequence Contains Multiple Putative Phosphorylation Sites and Is Phosphorylated in Vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	93	A, Positions of potential target sites for CKII (black arrowheads), PKC (open arrowheads), and MAPK (gray arrowheads) identified within the sequence of the human COUP-TFI receptor.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	94	 B, In vivo phosphorylation of COUP-TFI.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Proteins were extracted and purified on glutathione-agarose beads before SDS-PAGE.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	97	 a, Autoradiogram; b, Coomassie Brilliant blue staining of the gel.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The positions of GST and GST::COUP-TFI were assessed by Western blot with anti-GST antibodies (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The autoradiographic signals as well as the protein levels were quantified to estimate the relative specific activity of the labeled proteins.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	100	 These activities are expressed as OD arbitrary unit per picomole of protein.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	101	  Multiple Phosphorylation Pathways Regulate COUP-TFI-Mediated Transcriptional Activation of the Vn Gene Promoter The functional relevance of phosphorylation events for the regulation of COUP-TFI activity was first assessed by using specific inhibitors for the three above described kinases in transfection experiments (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	102	 COS-7 cells were cotransfected with the COUP-TFI-dependent reporter gene Vn-luciferase (Luc) (containing the wt Vn gene promoter sequence, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	103	 1), in the presence or absence of increasing amounts of human COUP-TFI expression vector.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Cells were treated, or not treated, with DRB (5-6-dichloro-1-ss-D ribofuranosyl benzimidazole), a CKII inhibitor (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	105	 3A), or the p42MAPK/p44MAPK signaling pathway-specific inhibitor PD980059, or the PKC inhibitor GF 109203X (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Consistent with our previous results, cotransfection with increasing amounts of COUP-TFI expression plasmid led to a dose-dependent induction of reporter gene activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Neither the basal nor the stimulated transcriptional activity of the reporter gene was modified by treatment of the cells with DRB (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The expression level of COUP-TFI was also unaffected by this treatment (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Based on these experiments defining that inhibition of the CKII pathway in vivo does not affect COUP-TFI-mediated transcriptional activation, it seems unlikely that this kinase regulates COUP-TFI function.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Whereas basal activity was not altered, treatment of the cells with PD980059 led to a significant decrease (76% inhibition of the activation) in reporter gene activity observed in the presence of 50 ng of COUP-TFI expression vector (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	111	 As assessed by Western blotting, this inhibition was not due to a decrease in nuclear receptor expression (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The inhibitory effect of the specific MAPK inhibitor on the induction of the Vn gene promoter by COUP-TFI was not restricted to COS-7 cells as similar results were obtained in experiments utilizing P19 cells (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	113	 3B, treating cotransfected COS-7 cells with GF 109203X in the absence of expression vector did not influence basal activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	114	 In contrast, GF 109203X induced a marked reduction (60% inhibition of the activation) in the reporter gene activity observed in the presence of 50 ng of COUP-TFI expression vector (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Concurrent with the previous observation, the inhibition of COUP-TFI- induced reporter gene activity was not due to a reduced expression of COUP-TFI in COS-7 cells treated with GF 109203X (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Thus, the blocking of either the p42MAPK/p44MAPK or the PKC signaling pathway results in a strong inhibition of the COUP-TFI-dependent transcription, suggesting that COUP-TFI function may be positively regulated by these kinases in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	117	View larger version (33K):    Figure 3.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Specific Inhibitors of MAPK and PKC Decrease COUP-TFI-Mediated Transcription.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	127	  View larger version (58K):    Figure 5.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The Selective Inhibitor of PKC Specifically Decreases COUP-TFI Binding to DNA in a Dose-Dependent Manner.
