0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	130	 COS-7 cells were untransfected (lanes 1) or transfected with pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI expression vector (lanes 2 to 6) and treated in the absence or presence of increasing amounts of the indicated kinase inhibitors.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	131	 WCEs were then incubated with the 32P-labeled double-stranded NR1 oligonucleotide.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The position of the specific COUP-TFI/NR1 complex (as assessed by supershifting analysis with the anti-hCOUP-TFI antibody, lanes 3) is indicated by an arrowhead, whereas nonspecific bands are indicated by asterisks.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The expression level of COUP-TFI in the WCEs used for EMSA was controlled by Western blotting (lower panels) with the anti-HA antibody.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The position of COUP-TFI receptor is indicated by an arrowhead, whereas nonspecific bands are indicated by asterisks.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	135	  To determine the functional requirement of the phosphorylation-mediated regulation of COUP-TFI activity, similar cotransfection experiments were performed using expression vectors encoding truncated COUP-TFI receptors (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The COUP-TFI 57 to 423 protein is truncated at the amino-terminal region of the A/B domain, lacking a putative CKII and PKC phosphorylation sequence (S7), as well as two amino-terminal (T51 and T54) MAPK phosphorylation sites.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	137	 In addition to these four sites, the COUP-TFI 84 to 423 protein, which is deleted of almost the entire A/B domain (86 first amino acids), is devoid of the third putative MAPK phosphorylation site (T63) and of a CKII phosphorylation site (T66).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Western blotting showed that all the three constructs were efficiently expressed in COS-7 and displayed similar expression levels (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Independent of the amount of expression vector used, COUP-TFI 57 to 423 was able to stimulate the reporter gene activity to a similar extent to that observed with the equivalent dose of wild-type (wt) COUP-TFI expression vector (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Moreover, both PD980059 and GF 109203X efficiently counteracted the reporter gene activation mediated by 50 ng of COUP-TFI 57 to 423 expression vector.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This observation suggests that the region spanning residues 1 to 56 of COUP-TFI, including one PKC and two MAPK potential phosphorylation sites, is dispensable for transactivation and is not involved in the regulation of COUP-TFI activity by the PKC and MAPK pathways.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Cotransfection of COS-7 cells with increasing amounts of COUP-TFI 84 to 423 expression vector resulted in a weak stimulation of the reporter gene (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Experiments run in P19 cells gave similar results (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	144	 These data suggest that residues 57 to 83 play a crucial role, directly or indirectly, in the COUP-TFI-mediated transactivation, and raise the possibility that the third (T63) MAPK phosphorylation site could be a hierarchal requisite for COUP-TFI activity and for the MAPK-mediated regulation of the nuclear receptor functions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	145	 This was, to some extent, confirmed by the observation that PD980059 is significantly less efficient in inhibiting the COUP-TFI 84 to 423-mediated transcriptional activation than it is in decreasing COUP-TFI 57 to 423-induced activation (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Indeed, the inhibition of COUP-TFI 84 to 423 and COUP-TFI 57 to 423 activity due to PD980059 was 58% and 89%, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The residual effect of PD980059 on COUP-TFI 84 to 423-mediated transactivation suggests the involvement of an additional nonconsensus MAPK phosphorylation site located between residues 84 to 423, or that MAPK indirectly modulates COUP-TFI activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Finally, in cells cotransfected with 50 ng of COUP-TFI 84 to 423 expression vector, treatment with GF 109203X reduced the reporter gene activity to the basal level (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This last result implies that the potential phosphorylation site(s) targeted by PKC are located outside of the A/B domain (i.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	150	 All together, these findings strongly suggest that COUP-TFI activity is positively regulated by phosphorylation events in vivo, events that may be mediated by the p42MAPK/p44MAPK and PKC pathways.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	151	In Vitro Dephosphorylation Inhibits COUP-TFI Binding to Its DNA Target Sequences In an attempt to identify the functions of COUP-TFI that are controlled by phosphorylation events, we first focused on DNA binding activity, and investigated whether in vitro dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI could affect its ability to bind DNA elements (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In this study, COUP-TFI was expressed in COS-7 cells and whole-cell extracts (WCEs) from either untransfected or COUP-TFI-expressing cells were treated in vitro with calf intestinal phosphatase (CIP).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	153	 4A, incubation of untreated WCEs from COUP-TFI-expressing cells with labeled double-stranded DR1 oligonucleotide led to the formation of a complex species shifted in EMSA experiments as a single band (indicated by an arrowhead).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Supershifting experiments with anti-COUP-TFI antibody reduced the electrophoretic mobility of the retarded complex, confirming the presence of COUP-TFI in this complex.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In vitro treatment of the WCEs prepared from COUP-TFI-expressing cells with CIP buffer alone or CIP buffer and phosphate had no effect on the intensity of the shifted band, showing that neither of the compounds affected the binding of COUP-TFI to DNA elements.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	156	 In contrast, treatment of WCEs with CIP strongly decreased the intensity of the shifted band, providing evidence for a CIP-mediated decrease in the formation of the COUP-TFI/DR1 complex.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The hypothesis that CIP-mediated dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI inhibited nuclear receptor binding to specific DNA elements was further substantiated by the observation that addition of phosphate to the dephosphorylation mixture abolished the effect of the CIP.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	158	View larger version (29K):    Figure 4.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI Inhibits Its Ability to Bind DNA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	160	Effects of the in vitro treatment with CIP on COUP-TFI binding to DNA were assessed by EMSA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Equivalent amounts (2  microg) of WCEs from untransfected (lanes 1) or COUP-TFI-expressing COS-7 cells (lanes 2 to 7) were incubated with CIP buffer (lanes 4 to 7), in the absence (lanes 4 and 5) or presence (lanes 6 and 7) of CIP (2.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	162	5 U) and of a competitive inhibitor of CIP (NaPO4, lanes 5 and 7).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Control incubations (lanes 1 to 3) were performed in the absence of CIP buffer.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The samples were then incubated with the 32P-labeled double-stranded DR1 or NR1 oligonucleotides indicated at the bottom of the gels.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The position of the specific retarded complex (as assessed by supershifting analysis with the anti-hCOUP-TFI antibody, lanes 3) is indicated by an arrowhead, whereas nonspecific bands are indicated by asterisks.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	166	  Similar gel shift experiments were performed using the most proximal half binding site for nuclear receptors (NR1) identified within the Vn gene promoter as a probe (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	167	 4B), or other COUP-TF recognition sequences such as EREs (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI-containing cell extracts systematically reduced COUP-TFI binding to these various response elements (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The CIP-mediated inhibition of DNA binding was also observed with COUP-TFI 84 to 423 (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	170	 These data suggest that COUP-TFI specific DNA binding activity can be directly and positively regulated by phosphorylation events in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	171	In Vivo Inhibition of the PKC Signaling Pathway Specifically Decreases the DNA Binding Activity of COUP-TFI The potential effects of CKII, MAPK, and PKC kinase inhibitors on COUP-TFI specific DNA binding function were assessed by EMSA experiments (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	172	 COS-7 cells were transfected with COUP-TFI expression vector, and subsequently treated or untreated with increasing amounts of the different kinase inhibitors described above.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	173	 WCEs from untransfected or COUP-TFI-expressing cells were then incubated with the labeled double-stranded NR1 oligonucleotide.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Neither the vehicle alone nor any of the tested concentrations of DRB significantly modified the intensity of the specific shifted band (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	175	 As assessed by Western blotting, the amounts of DRB did not affect the expression of COUP-TFI in COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Similar results were obtained using the selective p42MAPK/p44MAPK inhibitor PD980059 (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Conversely, treating the transfected cells with the selective PKC inhibitor GF 109203X did influence binding of COUP-TFI to specific DNA elements (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Indeed, treatment of the cells with increasing amounts of PKC inhibitor led to a pronounced and gradual decrease in the intensity of the specific shifted band (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This reduction of COUP-TFI binding to DNA was not due to a decreased expression of the nuclear receptor in the treated cells, as revealed by Western blotting (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Similar results were obtained with the three kinase inhibitors using the DR1 oligonucleotide as a probe (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	181	 These observations clearly indicate that the specific inhibition of the PKC pathway significantly reduces COUP-TFI binding to distinct response elements, raising the possibility that PKC can positively regulate the DNA binding activity of COUP-TFI in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	182	PKC Phosphorylates COUP-TFI in Vitro and Enhances Its Binding Affinity for DNA To support the previous observations, we wanted to determine if PKC could directly target COUP-TFI and subsequently regulate its binding to DNA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The ability of purified PKC to phosphorylate COUP-TFI in vitro was assessed by in vitro phosphorylation assays performed with bacterially expressed COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein was incubated in the absence or presence of increasing amounts of purified PKC.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	185	 In all reactions, -32P ATP was used as a donor of phosphate and PKC-mediated phosphorylation was monitored by the incorporation of 32P.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	186	 As expected, no 32P incorporation was detected when GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 was treated in the absence of purified kinase.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In contrast, incubation of GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 with increasing amounts of PKC allowed a dose-dependent incorporation of 32P, leading to the gradual appearance of a band of the expected molecular weight (indicated by an arrowhead).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Because the GST moiety was not phosphorylated by purified PKC (data not shown, see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	189	 7B), these data show that PKC directly and specifically phosphorylates COUP-TFI at one or more target sites located between residues 57 and 423 in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	190	View larger version (29K):    Figure 6.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	219	  In an attempt to confirm that PKC positively regulates COUP-TFI binding to DNA, in vitro phosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein was subsequently submitted to EMSA experiments (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	220	 In the first set of experiments, increasing amounts of unphosphorylated or in vitro phosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein were incubated with labeled double-stranded DR1 oligonucleotides (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Independent of the amount of GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein used, the intensity of the specific shifted band was consistently higher for the phosphorylated protein than for its unphosphorylated counterpart (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The intensity of the shifted band was quantified by phosphoimaging and normalized with that of the corresponding free probe.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Results were expressed in % of bound/free probe, with the binding of 20 ng of phosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein to the DR1 oligonucleotide being normalized to 100%.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	224	 This analysis confirmed that the DNA binding ability of the phosphorylated fusion protein was more than 2-fold greater than that of the unphosphorylated protein (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	225	Because these data suggested that phosphorylation of COUP-TFI modulated the affinity of the receptor for DNA, we designed gel shift experiments to calculate the dissociation constant (Kd) of PKC-phosphorylated vs.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	226	 unphosphorylated COUP-TFI 57 to 423 association with DNA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Ten nanograms of recombinant protein were incubated with increasing amounts of DR-1 probe (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	228	 After electrophoresis, the bound probe and the free probe were quantified with a phosphoimager using Fujifilm FLA-300 and Image Gauge 3.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The ratio of bound/free probes was plotted against the bound probe concentration, allowing the calculation of the Kd for COUP-TFI/DNA interactions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Linear transformation clearly revealed the existence of two different protein species that differed in their ability to bind DNA in the PKC-modified sample, thus generating a kink in the curve.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	231	 In the specific experiment shown in Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	232	 6C, unphosphorylated COUP-TFI had a Kd value of 1.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	233	8 nM, and PKC-modified COUP-TFI had Kd values of 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	234	0 nM, suggesting that when the phosphorylated form of COUP-TF interacts with DNA, it binds with the lowest Kd value.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Such experiments were replicated several times with different preparations of GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 protein.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The average Kd calculated from these experiments was 2.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	237	33 nM (n = 6) for unphosphorylated COUP-TI and 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	238	1 nM (n = 5) for PKC-phosphorylated COUP-TI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	239	 These data clearly demonstrate that COUP-TFI can be directly targeted by PKC in vitro, and that PKC-mediated phosphorylation enhances the affinity of the nuclear receptor for DNA by approximately 3-fold.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	240	Enhancement of COUP-TFI DNA Binding Activity by PKC Is a Direct Mechanism that Is Likely to Be Mediated by Phosphorylation within the DBD Having demonstrated that COUP-TFI 57 to 423 is a substrate for PKC in vitro and that phosphorylation enhances the binding of the nuclear receptor to DNA, it was of interest to determine whether the PKC-mediated phosphorylation events affected DNA binding function directly or indirectly (i.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	241	 via the dimerization function).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The potential effects of PKC-mediated phosphorylation on the ability of the GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein to retain 35S methionine-labeled in vitro translated COUP-TFI were determined by GST pull-down assays (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Bacterially expressed GST and GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion proteins were treated in vitro in the absence or in the presence of purified PKC before incubation with 35S methionine-labeled COUP-TFI-programmed lysate.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	244	 7A, the unphosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein retained a significant amount of 35S methionine-labeled COUP-TFI when compared with the input lane, showing that phosphorylation is not required for dimerization of the nuclear receptor.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In vitro phosphorylation of the GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion protein by purified PKC did not affect the amount of labeled COUP-TFI retained by the fusion protein bound to glutathione-agarose beads (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The PKC-induced enhancement of DNA binding is therefore unlikely to result from an increase in the ability of COUP-TFI to homodimerize.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	247	 To further delineate the mechanism of this PKC-mediated regulation, we aimed to map the functional domain(s) of COUP-TFI that were targeted by PKC in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	248	 COUP-TFI functional domain mapping was assessed by using various truncated bacterially expressed GST::COUP-TFI fusion proteins (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Glutathione-agarose beads containing either GST, GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57, GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153 or GST::COUP-TFI 153 to 423 fusion proteins were incubated with purified PKC in the presence of -32P ATP (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The GST moiety and the GST::COUP-TFI 153 to 423 fusion protein were not phosphorylated by the purified PKC.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	251	 In contrast, incorporation of 32P was observed when the GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57 and the GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153 fusion proteins were incubated with the purified PKC, but not when the kinase was omitted in the reaction mixture (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The positions of the specific bands corresponding to the phosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57 and GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153 were assessed by Coomassie Brilliant blue staining (data not shown) and are indicated by an open and gray arrowhead, respectively (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	253	 We can therefore conclude that multiple functional domains of COUP-TFI are selectively phosphorylated by PKC in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Consistent with the result that PKC positively regulates the DNA binding activity of COUP-TFI without affecting its dimerization function, we provide evidence that the DBD of COUP-TFI, but not its LBD, is directly targeted by PKC.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Mass spectrometry confirmed the effect of PKC on the phosphorylation status of the DBD and allowed to specifically identify the modified amino acid residues (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Phosphorylation of S94 or S113 could not be detected in these experiments, but mass spectrometry data showed definitively that T121 was phosphorylated by PKC.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Mass spectrometry data indicated a posttranslational modified peptide at position mass 927.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The spectra showed an additional peak +80 Da at 1007.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	259	5 indicating a phosphorylation modification at the T121 position.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The presence of both peaks at m/z = 927.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	261	4 indicates that both unphosphorylated and phosphorylated COUP-TFI are present after PKC action, which is consistent with what we observed in gel-shift experiments.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	262	 These data demonstrate that T121 is a target for PKC in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	263	MAPK Directly Targets Distinct Phosphorylation Sites within COUP-TFI in Vitro Previous results strongly suggested that the p42MAPK/p44MAPK signaling pathway could also be involved in the regulation of COUP-TFI activity in vivo, possibly through phosphorylation events occurring in the A/B domain.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	264	 To investigate this hypothesis further, we performed in vitro phosphorylation assays to determine which functional domain(s) of COUP-TFI could be targeted by the purified MAPK (ERK2/p42MAPK) in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	265	 8, the GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57 (open arrowhead) and GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153 (gray arrowhead) fusion proteins were labeled, whereas the GST::COUP-TFI 153 to 423 protein did not incorporate 32P in the presence of purified MAPK.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	266	 These data clearly show that purified ERK2/p42MAPK directly targets COUP-TFI in vitro, through at least two distinct phosphorylation sites located between residues 1 to 57 and 57 to 153, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	267	 In light of our previous results, it was particularly tempting to speculate that the third putative MAPK phosphorylation site (T63) identified within the C-terminal region of the A/B domain of COUP-TFI could be involved in the regulation of COUP-TFI activity by the MAPK (p42MAPK/p44MAPK) signaling pathway in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	268	View larger version (31K):    Figure 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	269	 MAPK Directly Targets COUP-TFI in Vitro at Multiple Phosphorylation Sites.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	270	The ability of purified MAPK to phosphorylate bacterially expressed truncated COUP-TFI proteins in vitro was monitored by incorporation of 32P.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Glutathione-agarose beads containing 250 ng of bacterially expressed GST (lane 1), GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57 (lane 2), GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153 (lane 3), or GST::COUP-TFI 153 to 423 (lane 4) fusion proteins were incubated in the presence of 25 ng of purified MAPK and -32P ATP (5  microCi).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE, the positions of the phosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57 and GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153 fusion proteins being indicated by an open and a gray arrowhead, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	273	  Cell-Specific Enhancement of COUP-TFI Transactivation Function through Phosphorylation of Its Amino-Terminal T63 Residue by the MAPK Pathway Considering that treatment with a specific MAPK inhibitor resulted in a pronounced decrease in the COUP-TFI-mediated transcriptional activation of the Vn gene promoter in vivo (see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	274	 3B), various experiments were completed to delineate the function(s) of COUP-TFI that could be targeted by the MAPK-mediated phosphorylation events.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Transfection experiments performed in COS-7 cells revealed that neither the deletion of the A/B domain of COUP-TFI (i.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	276	 deletion of residues 1 to 84, encompassing the three conserved putative MAPK target sites), nor treatment of cells expressing the full-length COUP-TFI with the selective MAPK inhibitor modified the subcellular distribution of the nuclear receptor (data not shown).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Distinct sets of experiments demonstrated that in vivo inhibition of the MAPK pathway (see Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	278	 5B) and in vitro phosphorylation by purified MAPK (data not shown) did not affect the DNA binding activity of COUP-TFI, which is specifically targeted by PKC.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Our next objective was to determine whether MAPK-mediated phosphorylation could directly regulate the transactivation function of COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Based on the results obtained using COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	281	 3B) and P19 cells (data not shown) showing that COUP-TFI-dependent transcription was inhibited by deletion of the A/B domain (i.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	282	 deletion of residues 1 to 84) while remaining unaffected by deletion of the N-terminal region spanning amino acids 1 to 57, we postulated that the third consensus phosphorylation site (T63) identified within the sequence of COUP-TFI could be targeted by the MAPK pathway in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	283	 This putative MAPK phosphorylation site was therefore inactivated through replacement of the conserved threonine residue to a nonphosphorylatable alanine residue.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The ability of the mutated COUP-TFI receptor to activate the Vn gene promoter was assessed by cotransfection experiments performed in COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Cotransfection of increasing amounts of wtCOUP-TFI expression vector led to a dose-dependent increase in the Vn-Luc reporter gene activity in COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Moreover, in both cellular contexts, treatment with PD980059 significantly inhibited COUP-TFI-dependent transcription (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	287	 9A, mutation of the third putative MAPK phosphorylation site has no effect on the transcriptional activation of the Vn-Luc reporter gene mediated by COUP-TFI in COS-7 cells (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Furthermore, mutating the third putative MAPK phosphorylation site did not prevent the inhibitory effect of the MAPK inhibitor (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	289	 This was in sharp contrast to the results obtained in P19 cells.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Indeed, in this cellular context, mutation of the third MAPK phosphorylation site resulted in a significant decrease in the transactivation of the Vn gene promoter by COUP-TFI (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Furthermore, consistent with the involvement of the third MAPK phosphorylation site in the positive regulation of COUP-TFI transactivation function by the MAPK pathway in P19 cells, mutation of the conserved T63 residue completely abolished the effect of the selective p42MAPK/p44MAPK pathway inhibitor on the COUP-TFI-dependent transcription (Fig.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	292	 All together, these data demonstrate that the MAPK pathway positively regulates COUP-TFI transactivation function in the context of the Vn gene promoter in a cell-specific manner.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	293	 While this regulation is likely to be mediated through direct phosphorylation of the third evolutionarily conserved MAPK target site of COUP-TFI by the p42MAPK/p44MAPK signaling pathway in P19 cells, this phosphorylation site does not seem to be involved in the modulation of COUP-TFI transcriptional activity in COS-7 cells.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	294	View larger version (31K):    Figure 9.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Mutation of the Third Putative Target Site for MAPK (T63) Located in the N-Terminal Region of COUP-TFI Inhibits Its Transactivation Function in a Cell-Specific Manner.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	296	The evolutionarily conserved threonine residue (T63) of the third consensus MAPK phosphorylation site identified within the N-terminal A/B domain of hCOUP-TFI was mutated in an unphosphorylatable alanine residue (T63A).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	297	 COS-7 cells (A) or P19 cells (B) were cotransfected with the Vn-Luc reporter gene in the absence or presence of increasing amounts (6.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	298	25 to 50 ng) of the indicated pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI or pcNDA3-hCOUP-TFI T63A expression vectors.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Transfected cells were treated or not with the selective p42MAPK/p44MAPK pathway inhibitor (PD980059, 50  microM).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Results are expressed as fold inductions of the reporter gene activities in the presence of the various expression vectors compared with the activity in the absence of any expression vector.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Results are shown as the means  plus or minus  SEM of three values obtained in a representative experiment.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	302	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Among all posttranslational modifications, phosphorylation is a frequently occurring and a potent mechanism for the rapid modulation of transcription factor activity in response to environmental conditions and hormonal signals (50).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Most, if not all, nuclear receptors studied to date are phosphoproteins whose functions are regulated by phosphorylation.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Indeed, apart from their participation in conventional hormone-dependent activation process, phosphorylation-mediated ligand-independent regulation of nuclear receptors activity has been well documented (33, 34).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Despite these findings, such a mechanism may not be ubiquitous; indeed, the GR appears to be refractory to activation in the absence of its cognate ligand.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	306	 This mode of action seems to be relevant for most other steroid/thyroid hormone and retinoid receptors as well as for various orphan receptors (33, 38, 39, 40, 41).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The identification of several putative phosphorylation sites for CKII, PKC, and MAPK, led us to study the potential involvement of these signaling pathways in the regulation of COUP-TFI function.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Our data first show that COUP-TFI is a phosphoprotein in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Despite the observation that human COUP-TFI sequence contains eight putative target sites for CKII, our data strongly suggest that this kinase is unlikely to regulate the nuclear receptor activity, in the cellular and promoter contexts considered.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	310	 In contrast, we provide evidence for the involvement of both PKC and MAPK (p42MAPK/p44MAPK) transduction pathways in the modulation of COUP-TFI functions in vivo.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	311	Focusing on the PKC pathway, we demonstrated that selective inhibition of this pathway in vivo actively decreases COUP-TFI-dependent activation of the Vn gene promoter.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	312	 In this study, we provide data that clearly show that PKC directly targets COUP-TFI in vitro and enhances its binding to various response elements.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Precedents for both positive and negative regulations of DNA binding by phosphorylation exist for numerous nuclear receptors, including ER, GR, RAR, TR2, TRss1, Nur77/NGFI-B, and HNF-4.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	314	 These regulatory mechanisms are not yet fully understood and highly complex, as they involve a wide range of protein kinases with target sites located within, nearby, or far from the DBD.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	315	 While phosphorylation-mediated by PKA enhances GR binding to DNA (51), this kinase has been shown to inhibit binding of HNF-4 in vitro and in vivo (40).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Consistent with the involvement of the A-box in the high affinity DNA binding of HNF-4 (52), phosphorylation at a consensus PKA-dependent site located within this region results in a modification of the receptor binding to DNA (40).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Similarly, phosphorylation of NGFI-B within its A-box also decreases DNA binding (38, 39).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	318	 In both cases, the reduction of DNA binding of the receptor is likely to reflect a local effect: phosphorylations occurring nearby to the DBD could either induce a local conformational change impairing DNA recognition, inhibit protein/DNA contacts by steric hindrance, or electrostatically hinder interactions between the phosphate groups of the protein and the similarly charged phosphate backbone of the DNA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	319	 In contrast, phosphorylation of TR2, a variant of the thyroid hormone receptor, within a unique carboxy-terminal region mediated by CKII decreases its binding to DNA via a mechanism that is likely to involve a phosphorylation-induced change in the overall conformation of the protein (53).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	320	 A similar mechanism, which is likely to underlie the positive regulation exerted by CKII on the binding of ER to its response element, involves phosphorylation events occurring at an amino acid residue located within the amino-terminal A/B domain of the receptor, resulting in intramolecular interactions affecting the DNA binding domain and its function (54, 55).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	321	 In addition to these direct mechanisms, indirect phosphorylation-mediated regulations of DNA binding have also been reported; these are often due to a modulation of the dimerization interface of the nuclear receptors by phosphorylation events.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	322	 For example, phosphorylation of TRss1 enhances TRss1/RXR heterodimerization, leading to an increase in DNA binding (56, 57).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Such an indirect regulation of DNA binding is also relevant for RAR/RXR heterodimers where PKC-mediated phosphorylation event at a serine residue located in the T-box of RAR prevents heterodimerization (58, 59).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Based on the finding that the T-box of RAR engages dimerization contacts with the DBD of RXR (60), phosphorylation occurring within this region may introduce strong conformational constraints on the dimerization interface, thus impairing heterodimerization and subsequent DNA binding (58, 59).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	325	 While PKC has been shown to down-regulate DNA binding for members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, both through direct and indirect mechanisms, there is, to our knowledge, no evidence for PKC-mediated positive effects on the DNA binding of any member of this superfamily.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	326	 In this report, we demonstrate that phosphorylation of COUP-TFI by PKC increases the affinity of the orphan receptor for specific DNA elements.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Moreover, we show that the enhancement of DNA binding does not result from a modification of the ability of COUP-TFI to homodimerize, but rather appears to be a direct mechanism.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Consistent with this idea, the DBD of COUP-TFI is targeted by PKC in vitro, whereas the LBD, which contains the major homodimerization surface (61), is not.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Mass spectrometry analysis allowed us to ascertain that T121 is a target for PKC, whereas no other modifications were detected.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Although the region spanning amino acids 1 to 57 also contains at least one target site for PKC, our data demonstrate that the amino-terminal A/B domain of the nuclear receptor is dispensable for DNA binding and its phosphorylation-dependent regulation.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	331	 We propose that COUP-TFI binding to DNA is positively and directly regulated by PKC-mediated phosphorylation targeting T121 within the DNA binding domain of the receptor.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	332	COUP-TFI may integrate multiple signaling pathways considering our finding that the MAPK pathway specifically regulates COUP-TFI transactivation function.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	333	 While having no effect on nuclear translocation or DNA binding function, inhibition of the p42MAPK/p44MAPK pathway in vivo strongly inhibits the COUP-TFI-mediated transcriptional activation of the Vn gene promoter.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Moreover, we showed that ERK2/p42MAPK directly targets COUP-TFI at distinct phosphorylation sites in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	335	 While the LBD is not phosphorylated by MAPK, at least one target site is present in the amino-terminal region of the A/B domain (i.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	336	 amino acids 1 to 57) of COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	337	 The functional relevance of this phosphorylation event in vivo remains unclear because the deletion of the amino-terminal region to residue 57 does not affect the subcellular distribution, DNA binding activity and transactivation function of the receptor, or the MAPK-mediated regulation of the COUP-TFI-dependent transcription.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Other phosphorylation sites, located between residues 57 and 153, are directly targeted by ERK2/p42MAPK in vitro, and the ERK2-mediated phosphorylation event that might specifically target T63 in vivo is shown here to play an active role in cell-specific transcriptional activation by COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Such a modulation by MAPK-mediated phosphorylation could result from modifications in coactivator recruitment as previously reported for various nuclear receptors.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Indeed, ERss can be activated by the Ras-dependent MAPK pathway in the absence of its cognate ligand via direct phosphorylation within the A/B domain (62, 63).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Recent studies have shown that phosphorylation of MAPK target sites located in the AF-1 region stimulates ligand- and AF-2-independent interaction between ERss and SRC-1, thus allowing for ligand-independent activation of ERss (63).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	342	 In addition to ERss, several authors have reported observations of functional cross-talk between growth factors and ER signaling pathways, both in the absence and presence of ligand (64, 65, 66, 67, 68).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	343	 Consistent with the requirement of the AF-1 region for the activation of the apo-form ER in response to growth factors, one serine residue S118 located in the A/B domain of ER is directly targeted by the MAPK in response to EGF, and these phosphorylation events increase the AF-1 activity (66, 67, 68).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	344	 The mechanism underlying this enhancement has recently been elucidated and involves the MAPK-dependent recruitment of the coactivator p68 by the AF-1 region of ER (69).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	345	 In addition to these local effects, the MAPK pathway can, by intramolecular communication between different nuclear receptor domains, positively or negatively regulate coactivator binding by domains that are distinct from the ones targeted by specific phosphorylation events (70, 71).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	346	 For example, phosphorylation of a serine residue located within the hinge region of SF-1 is required for maximal interaction of its LBD with the coactivator GRIP-1, results in the ligand-independent activation of SF-1 (71).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Similarly, MAPK-mediated phosphorylation of a single amino acid residue in the A/B domain of PPAR alters the overall conformation of the apo-form receptor in a way that impairs ligand binding, thereby indirectly preventing the recruitment of coactivators such as SRC-1 (70).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Thus, interdomain communication allows phosphorylation events targeting the amino-terminal A/B domain of PPAR to regulate independent properties of the LBD.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	349	 This regulatory mechanism is involved in the MAPK-mediated inhibition of PPAR ligand-dependent transactivation function in response to various growth factors and cytokines, and has important repercussions on PPAR activity in vivo (70, 72, 73).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Taken together, these results show that MAPK-mediated phosphorylation events play crucial roles in the modulation of nuclear receptor/coactivator interactions, a regulatory mechanism that, according to recent data, may also be relevant to nuclear receptor/corepressor interactions (74, 75).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Further experiments will tell if ERK2 can modify COUP-TFI/coactivator interactions.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	352	Integration of multiple signaling pathways by the human COUP-TFI nuclear receptor would undoubtedly have repercussions on a wide range of biological processes that involve COUP-TFI, such as cellular growth, differentiation, apoptosis as well as embryonic development (8, 11, 13, 16, 17, 31, 76).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Results described in this study indicate that there is a possibility that a variety of extracellular stimuli, transduced by MAPK and PKC signaling pathways, participate in the multifactorial regulation of the diverse biological processes that are controlled by COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	354	   MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Chemicals and Materials The affinity-purified rabbit polyclonal anti-hemagglutinin (HA) antibody (HA-probe; Y-11) and goat polyclonal anti-human (h) COUP-TFI antibody (COUP-TFI; N-19) were from TEBU (Le Perray-en-Yvelines, France).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Klenow fragment of Escherichia coli DNA polymerase I, CIP, T4 DNA polymerase, T4 DNA ligase, and the fugene transfection reagent were from Roche Molecular Biochemicals (Mannheim, Germany).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The TNT-coupled reticulocyte lysate and purified PKC were from Promega Corp.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Recombinant MAPK, phosphatidyl serine, DRB, reduced glutathione, glutathione-agarose beads, protease inhibitors and antibiotics were from Sigma (St.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	358	 PD980059 (2'-Amino-3'-methoxyflavone) and GF 109203X (Bisindolylmaleimide) were purchased from Calbiochem (La Jolla, CA).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	359	 T4 polynucleotide kinase, culture media, and FCS were from Life Technologies, Inc.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	360	 The phosphatase inhibitors okadaic acid and sodium orthovanadate (Na3VO4), -32P ATP, -32P deoxy-CTP (dCTP), 32P orthophosphate, and 35S methionine were from ICN Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	361	 The Luc assay system was from Promega Corp.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	362	, and Luc activity was measured on a Dynatech Corp.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	363	 luminometer (Guyancourt, France).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	364	 The chemiluminescent substrate protein detection kit and the Hybond C nitrocellulose membrane were from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech (Orsay, France).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	365	Oligonucleotides Oligonucleotides were synthesized by Genset Oligos (Paris, France).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Double-stranded oligonucleotides were used for EMSA, whereas site-directed mutagenesis (SDM) was performed with single-stranded oligonucleotides, with the exception of the PKA site in pBC/GST, which was mutated by PCR.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	367	 The oligonucleotides used were as follows: DR1 (EMSA), 5'-TCGATGACCTCTGACCCA-3'; AP1 (EMSA), 5'-TCGACGCTT GATGACTCAGCCGGAA-3'; NR1 (EMSA), 5'-TCGAGGGGTTCTGGGAATGTGACCCTTTGC-3'; mutant (m)NR1 (SDM), 5'-TGCAGCAAAGTTTCACATTCCCAG-3'; mNR2 (SDM), 5'-AAAGTCAGTAGTTTCACGGGCAGGA-3'; COUP-3m (SDM), 5'-GTGCCGGGGGCGGCGGGCGCT-3'; pBC/GST-PKAm up (SDM), 5'-GGTCGTGGGATCAGAAGAGCATGCGTGCATATGGATATC-3'.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	368	 The double-stranded oligonucleotides used for gel shift assays were end-labeled with -32P dCTP by Klenow fill-in and purified on a Sephadex G-50 column.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	369	 The single-stranded oligonucleotides used for SDM were phosphorylated with T4 polynucleotide kinase and ATP before annealing to the single-stranded DNA templates.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	370	Plasmids The GST::COUP-TFI 1 to 57, GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 153, GST::COUP-TFI 153 to 423, and GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 fusion proteins were expressed in E.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	371	 coli under isopropyl-1-thio-ss-D-galactopyranoside (IPTG) induction by using the pGEX-2T plasmid (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	372	 The pGEX-2T-COUP-TFI 1 to 57, pGEX-2T-COUP-TFI 57 to 153, pGEX-2T-COUP-TFI 153 to 423, and pGEX-2T-COUP-TFI 57 to 423 recombinant plasmids contain the human COUP-TFI coding sequence, spanning amino acids 1 to 57, 57 to 153, 153 to 423, and 57 to 423, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	373	 The pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI, pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI 57 to 423, and pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI 84 to 423 expression vectors encode either the full length or various truncated human COUP-TFI constructs as fusion proteins with the HA epitope tag peptide.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	374	 The corresponding fragments of the COUP-TFI coding sequence, amplified by PCR or generated by enzymatic cleavage, were first inserted in the pACT2 vector (CLONTECH Laboratories, Inc.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	375	, Palo Alto, CA) downstream of the HA epitope coding sequence before being introduced into pcDNA3 expression vector (Invitrogen).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	376	 The pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI recombinant plasmid was used to generate the pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI T63A expression vector by site-directed mutagenesis.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	377	 For mammalian GST fusion protein expression, the PKA site of pBC/GST (77) was first mutated before the human COUP-TFI cDNA (lacking the coding region corresponding to amino acid residues 1 to 56) was inserted in HpaI-linearized vector.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	378	 The p19-Vn-Luc (Vn-Luc) reporter plasmid (78) contains the 5' flanking region (bp -528 to +47) of the mouse Vn gene, inserted in the p19-Luc plasmid (79).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	379	 For SDM of each or both of the two putative half binding sites for nuclear receptors NR1 (bp -89 to -84) and NR2 (bp -162 to -157) identified within the Vn gene promoter, the Vn gene promoter insert was transferred into the Bluescript vector (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA), which contains the f1 origin of replication and therefore allows production of single-stranded DNA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	380	 The mutated promoter sequences were then reinserted in the p19-Luc plasmid to generate the mNR1-Vn-Luc, mNR2-Vn-Luc, and mNR1/mNR2-Vn-Luc recombinant reporter genes.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	381	SDM SDM was performed as previously described (30) by using the mNR1 and mNR2 oligonucleotides on the Bluescript-Vn construct, containing the 5'-flanking region (bp -528 to +47) of the murine Vn gene, to mutate one or both of the two putative nuclear receptors half-binding sites (NR1 and NR2: TGACCCTGAAAC) identified within this promoter.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Similarly, the COUP-3m oligonucleotide was used on the pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI expression vector, encoding the full-length human COUP-TFI receptor fused to the HA epitope, to inactivate the third consensus phosphorylation site for MAPK located in the N-terminal A/B domain of COUP-TFI.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	383	 This was achieved through replacing the putative targeted threonine residue (T63) by a nonphosphorylatable alanine residue.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	384	 For all SDM reactions, 1  microg of single-stranded uracil-containing DNA templates were prepared and annealed to each corresponding mutagenic primer (10 pmol).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	385	 The annealed primer was then elongated by T4 DNA polymerase, and after ligation, the reaction mixture was used to transform E.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	386	 All resulting point mutations were confirmed by sequencing.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	387	 The two mutated Vn gene promoter inserts were then transferred into p19-Luc reporter plasmid for transfection experiments.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	388	 The QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene) was used to mutate the PKA site (S to C substitution) of pBC/GST (77).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	389	Generation of Proteins The TNT-coupled reticulocyte lysate allowed us to produce the 35S methionine-labeled COUP-TFI protein used for the GST pull-down assay.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Translation efficiencies of the 35S-labeled proteins were checked by SDS-PAGE analysis of 2  microl of translation products.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	391	 The GST and GST::COUP-TFI fusion proteins were generated using the pGEX-2T vector, which allows bacterial expression under IPTG induction.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	392	 After IPTG induction, cells were collected by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 20 min at 4 C.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	393	 The supernatant was discarded; the pellet was resuspended in NETN buffer [20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	394	5% Nonidet P-40; 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF); 10  microg/ml aprotinin; 10  microg/ml leupeptin; 10  microg/ml pepstatin], and sonicated twice for 30 sec.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	395	 The suspension was then centrifuged for 15 min at 12,000 rpm and the soluble fraction, containing the GST fusion proteins, was incubated overnight at 4 C with 100  microl of glutathione-agarose beads prepared and stored in NETN buffer.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	396	 The beads were washed twice with NETN buffer and a fraction of each sample was loaded onto an SDS-10% polyacrylamide gel and analyzed by Coomassie Brilliant blue staining.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	397	 The bead-bound GST fusion proteins were collected by centrifugation and directly used for the in vitro phosphorylation and pull-down assays.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	398	 For EMSA, the fusion proteins were eluted from the beads by competition with reduced glutathione.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Briefly, the GST fusion proteins bound to beads were incubated in 10  microl of elution buffer (Tris-HCl 100 mM, pH 8; NaCl 120 mM; 50 mM reduced glutathione) at 4 C for 30 min.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	400	 After centrifugation, a fraction of the eluted proteins was loaded onto an SDS-10% polyacrylamide gel and analyzed by Coomassie Brilliant blue staining, while remaining eluted proteins were phosphorylated in vitro and submitted to EMSA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	401	Preparation of WCEs Transfected COS-7 cells were harvested 36 h after transfection in PBS and collected by centrifugation at 2000 rpm, at 4 C for 15 min.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	402	 Cells were then resuspended in WCE buffer [20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	403	9; 2 mM dithiothreitol (DTT); 20% glycerol]-0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	404	4 M KCl, containing 5  microg/ml aprotinin, leupeptin, pepstatin and 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	405	 After three cycles freezing (-80 C) and thawing (37 C), the cellular debris were pelleted by centrifugation at 12,000 rpm for 15 min at 4 C.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	406	 The protein concentration of the supernatant was assessed by Bradford assay and ranged from 2 to 6  microg/ microl.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	407	 These WCEs were used for EMSA and Western blot analysis.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	408	In Vitro Phosphorylation of hCOUP-TFI For in vitro phosphorylation with PKC purified from rat brain, 125 to 500 ng of bacterially expressed GST and GST::COUP-TFI fusion proteins bound to beads were incubated with 5  microCi of -32P ATP in 50  microl of phosphorylation buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	409	7 mM CaCl2; 600  microg/ml phosphatidyl serine; 1 mM DTT; 50  microM ATP), in the absence or presence of increasing amounts of PKC (3.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	410	 For in vitro phosphorylation with activated recombinant MAPK, the fusion proteins were incubated with 5  microCi of -32P ATP in 50  microl of phosphorylation buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8; 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	411	5 mM EDTA; 25 mM MgCl2; 1 mM DTT; 50  microM ATP; 10% glycerol), in the absence or presence of 25 ng of MAPK.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	412	 All phosphorylation reactions were carried out at 30 C for 30 min, in the presence of proteases and phosphatases inhibitors (1  microM okadaic acid; 200  microM Na3VO4).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	413	 The glutathione-agarose beads were then washed twice with washing buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	414	02% Tween 20; 1 mM PMSF; 10  microg/ml aprotinin; 10  microg/ml leupeptin; 10  microg/ml pepstatin), solublized in 1x SDS loading buffer and heated at 100 C for 5 min.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	415	 The in vitro phosphorylated proteins were resolved in a SDS-10% polyacrylamide gel, which was dried and exposed to a radiographic film.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	416	 For the GST pull-down assay and EMSA, cold ATP (250  microM) was added instead of -32P ATP as a donor of phosphate.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	417	Mass Spectrometry Purified GST::COUP-TFI was phosphorylated by PKC (Promega Corp.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	418	) according to manufacturer s instructions and subjected to SDS-PAGE.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Samples were prepared according to Shevchenko et al.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	420	 After tryptic digest of phosphorylated and control samples, peptides were extracted and analyzed by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry using Voyager Biospectrometry Workstation with Delayed Extraction Technology (PerSeptive Biosystems, Inc.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	421	 Obtained data were analyzed using Moverz software (Proteometrics, LLC, Winnipeg, Canada).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	422	GST Pull-Down Assay For in vitro protein-protein interactions, 125 or 250 ng of unphosphorylated or in vitro phosphorylated GST::COUP-TFI fusion proteins bound to beads were incubated for 4 h at 4 C with 35S methionine-labeled in vitro-translated hCOUP-TFI in 400  microl of binding buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	423	02% BSA; 1 mM PMSF; 10  microg/ml aprotinin; 10  microg/ml leupeptin; 10  microg/ml pepstatin).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	424	 The beads were then washed with washing buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	425	02% Tween 20; 1 mM PMSF; 10  microg/ml aprotinin; 10  microg/ml leupeptin; 10  microg/ml pepstatin) and the proteins were solubilized in 1x SDS loading buffer, heated at 100 C for 5 min and resolved in a SDS-polyacrylamide gel.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	426	In Vitro Dephosphorylation of hCOUP-TFI To study the potential effect of the in vitro dephosphorylation of COUP-TFI on its ability to bind DNA, human COUP-TFI expressed in transfected COS-7 cells was treated in vitro with CIP before the EMSA protocol.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	427	 Two micrograms of WCEs were incubated with 2.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	428	5 units of CIP in 10  microl of CIP buffer (10 mM Tris-acetate, pH 8; 10 mM magnesium-acetate; 50 mM potassium-acetate), control reactions being performed without CIP buffer, or with CIP buffer but in the absence of enzyme.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Some incubations were also performed in the absence or in the presence of NaPO4 (100 mM) to inhibit the CIP activity.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	430	 All dephosphorylation reactions were carried out at 25 C for 1 h, the dephosphorylation mixture being then submitted to the EMSA protocol.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	431	EMSA EMSA experiments were performed with WCEs prepared from transfected COS-7 cells or bacterially expressed COUP-TFI proteins.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	432	 When WCEs from transfected cells treated with specific kinase inhibitors were used, the expression levels of hCOUP-TFI receptor were controlled by Western blot analysis before EMSA.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	433	 Two micrograms of WCEs from COUP-TFI-expressing COS-7 cells or increasing amounts (0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	434	625 to 20 ng) of glutathione-agarose beads-purified GST::COUPTFI fusion proteins were incubated for 20 min at room temperature with 1  microg of poly (deoxyinosine-deoxycytidine) in 20  microl of binding buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	435	5 mM MgCl2; 10% glycerol), before incubation of the samples with 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	436	2 ng of double-stranded oligonucleotide, labeled with -32P dCTP (20,000 cpm).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	437	 After 20 min at room temperature, the protein-DNA complexes were resolved on a 4% polyacrylamide gel, in 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	438	5x TBE (45 mM Tris base; 45 mM boric acid; 1 mM EDTA).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	439	 For Kd calculation, 10 ng of GST::COUP-TFI 57 to 423 were incubated with increasing amounts of 32P-labeled DR1 double-stranded oligonucleotide.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	440	 The gels were dried before autoradiography, and the intensity of the specific retarded complex was assessed by phosphoimaging.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	441	 In most of the experiments, the presence of hCOUP-TFI in the specific shifted complex was controlled by supershifting analysis, performed with 2  microg of anti-hCOUP-TFI antibody.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	442	Western Blot Analysis WCEs (10 to 30  microg) from transfected COS-7 cells were fractioned by SDS-PAGE and electrotransferred to a nitrocellulose membrane.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	443	 The membrane was stained with Ponceau S to locate the molecular weight markers and washed in PBS containing 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	444	 All washes and incubations were performed at room temperature.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	445	 The nonspecific sites on the membrane were then blocked with PBS containing 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	446	1% Tween 20, 1% BSA and 5% nonfat milk powder for 2 h.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	447	 Because the human COUP-TFI protein expressed in transfected cells was fused to an eleven amino acid peptide derived from the influenza HA protein, the membrane was probed overnight with 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	448	5  microg/ml anti-HA in PBS containing 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	449	 Immunodetection was then carried out with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat antirabbit antibodies, revealed with the electrochemiluminescence protein detection kit according to the manufacturer s protocol.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	450	Cell Culture and Transient Transfection COS-7 and P19 cells were routinely grown at 37 C in DMEM containing 10% FCS, and 100 U/ml penicillin, 100  microg/ml streptomycin and 25  microg/ml Amphotericin.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	451	 Cells were transfected in 24-well plates by using the calcium phosphate/DNA method.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	452	 Briefly, 300 ng of recombinant Vn-Luc reporter plasmids, containing either the wt (wtVn) or the mutated (mNR1-Vn, mNR2-Vn, and mNR1/mNR2-Vn) gene promoter sequences (bp -528 to +47) were cotransfected with 150 ng of pCH110 control plasmid (a ss-galactosidase expression vector).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	453	25 to 50 ng per well) of pcDNA3 expression vectors (pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI, pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI T63A, pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI 57 to 423, and pcDNA3-hCOUP-TFI 84 to 423) were cotransfected, the expression levels of the proteins being checked by Western blot analysis.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	454	 In all wells, the total amount of CMV promoter (100 ng per well) and the total amount of DNA (1  microg per well) were maintained constant through addition of pcDNA3 and of Bluescript plasmids respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	455	 After 18 h, cells were washed with PBS and fresh medium was added, the cells being harvested 36 h after the calcium phosphate/DNA precipitate was removed.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	456	 In some experiments, specific kinase inhibitors were incubated with transfected COS-7 cells during the last 4 h of culture: MEK1/2 inhibitor (PD98059 in Me2SO), PKC inhibitor (GF109203X in Me2SO) and CK-II inhibitor (DRB in ethanol) were added to the medium to give a final concentration of 50  microM, 5  microM and 50  microM, respectively.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	457	 The control incubations were performed with dimethyl sulfoxide (Me2SO) or ethanol instead of the corresponding protein kinase inhibitor, the final concentration of vehicle in any experiment never exceeding 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	458	 After harvesting the cells, 10% of the cellular extract was used to measure the Luc activity; half of the remaining extract was taken to perform the ss-galactosidase assay.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	459	 Luc activities were normalized for transfection efficiency with the ss-galactosidase activities.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	460	 For COUP-TFI expression, COS-7 cells were plated in 5-cm diameter petri dishes and transfected with 5  microg of expression plasmid by the calcium phosphate/DNA coprecipitation technique.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	461	 After 18 h, cells were rinsed with PBS and medium was renewed.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	462	 In some experiments, treatment with various specific kinase inhibitors was performed during the last 4 h of culture, under the same conditions as those described above.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	463	 To prepare WCEs, cells were harvested 36 h after transfection in PBS.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	464	In Vivo Metabolic Labeling COS-7 cells were transfected in 10 cm dishes by the fugene reagent with pBC/GST or pBC/GST-COUP-TFI 57 to 423.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	465	 After 36 h, cells were transferred in phosphate-free DMEM.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	466	 One hour later, medium was replaced by phosphate-free DMEM containing 75  microCi/ml of 32P-labeled orthophosphate.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	467	 This medium was left on the cells for 4 h.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	468	 Cells were then washed and scraped before being lysed in 20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	469	3 M NaCl; 1 mM EDTA; 2 mM DTT; 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	470	5% NP-40; 20% glycerol, containing protease inhibitors (10  microg/ml aprotinin, leupeptin, pepstatin; 0.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	471	 The cell lysate was incubated overnight at 4 C with 100  microl of a 50% glutathione-agarose bead suspension in binding buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	472	5% NP-40, and protease inhibitors).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	473	 The beads were washed twice in Washing buffer I (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	474	5% NP-40; protease inhibitors) and twice in Washing buffer II (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	475	8 M NaCl; 1% NP-40; protease inhibitors).
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	476	 The proteins bound to the beads were resuspended in 1x SDS loading buffer, heated at 100 C for 5 min and resolved in an SDS-polyacrylamide gel.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	477	 After Coomassie Brilliant blue staining and drying of the gel, the incorporation of 32P was monitored by autoradiography.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	478	 The resulting signal was quantified with Scion Image software (Scion Corp.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	479	, Frederick, MD), and normalized with the corresponding amount of purified GST and GST::COUP-TFI 53 to 423 fusion proteins.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	553	 Mol Endocrinol 7:1642 to 1653[Abstract] Delmotte MH, Tahayato A, Formstecher P, Lefebvre P 1999 Serine 157 a retinoic acid receptor residue phosphorylated by protein kinase C in vitro is involved in RXR.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	554	RAR heterodimerization and transcriptional activity.

0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	569	 J Biol Chem 272:5128 to 5132[Abstract/Free Full Text] Lavinsky RM, Jepsen K, Heinzel T, Torchia J, Mullen TM, Schiff R, Del-Rio AL, Ricote M, Ngo S, Gemsch J, Hilsenbeck SG, Osborne CK, Glass SK, Rosenfeld MG, Rose DW 1998 Diverse signaling pathways modulate nuclear receptor recruitment of N-CoR and SMRT complexes.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	570	 Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 95:2920 to 2925[Abstract/Free Full Text] Juge-Aubry CE, Hammar E, Siegrist-Kaiser C, Pernin A, Takeshita A, Chin WW, Burger AG, Meier CA 1999 Regulation of the transcriptional activity of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor by phosphorylation of a ligand-independent trans-activating domain.
