0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	572	 Mol Endocrinol 8:1774 to 1788[Abstract] Chatton B, Bahr A, Acker J, Kedinger C 1995 Eukaryotic GST fusion vector for the study of protein-protein associations in vivo: application to interaction of ATFa with Jun and Fos.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	573	 BioTechniques 18:142 to 145[Medline] Seiffert D, Curriden SA, Jenne D, Binder BR, Loskutoff DJ 1996 Differential regulation of vitronectin in mice and humans in vitro.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	574	 J Biol Chem 271:5474 to 5480[Abstract/Free Full Text] Van Zonneveld AJ, Curriden SA, Loskutoff DJ 1988 Type 1 plasminogen activator inhibitor gene: functional analysis and glucocorticoid regulation of its promoter.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	575	 Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 85:5525 to 5529[Abstract] Shevchenko A, Chernushevich I, Wilm M, Mann M 2000 De Novo peptide sequencing by nanoelectrospray tandem mass spectrometry using triple quadrupole and quadrupole/time-of-flight instruments.
0.25574476.12040019.html.plaintext.txt	576	 Methods Mol Biol 146:1 to 16[Medline].
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	0	An alternative splice variant of the tissue specific transcription factor HNF4[alpha] predominates in undifferentiated murine cell types An alternative splice variant of the tissue specific transcription factor HNF4 [alpha] predominates in undifferentiated murine cell types Hassan Nakhei, Anja Lingott, Ira Lemm and Gerhart U.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	1	Universitatsklinikum Essen, Institut fur Zellbiologie (Tumorforschung), Hufelandstra&szlig;e 55, D-45122 Essen, Germany.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received September 25, 1997; Revised and Accepted November 26, 1997.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	3	The transcription factor hepatocyte nuclear factor 4[alpha] (HNF4[alpha]) is a tissue specific transcription factor mainly expressed in the liver, kidney, intestine and the endocrine pancreas, but is also an essential regulator for early embryonic events.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Based on its protein structure HNF4[alpha] is classified as an orphan member of the nuclear receptor superfamily.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Comparing HNF4[alpha] transcription factors in the differentiated and dedifferentiated murine hepatocyte cell line MHSV-12 we identified in dedifferentiated cells the novel splice variant HNF4[alpha]7.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This variant is characterized by an alternative first exon and has a lower transactivation potential in transient transfection assays using HNF4 dependent reporter genes.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	7	 HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA and the corresponding protein are expressed in the undifferentiated pluripotent embryonal carcinoma cell line F9, whereas HNF4[alpha]1 only appears after differentiation of F9 cells to visceral endoderm.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	8	 HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA is also found in totipotent embryonic stem cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, the function of HNF4[alpha]7 seems not to be restricted to embryonic cells as the HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA is also present in adult tissues, most notably the stomach.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	10	 All these features suggest that the presence of distinct splice variants of HNF4[alpha] modulates the activity of HNF4[alpha] in a cell type specific way.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	11	Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) constitutes a transcription factor family (1 ,2 ) whose first member HNF4[alpha] has been identified as a factor interacting with promoter elements mediating liver specific transcription (3 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Based on the zinc finger motif of the DNA binding domain and on a potential ligand binding domain HNF4 is classified as a member of the nuclear orphan receptor superfamily (4 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	13	 HNF4[alpha] turned out to be present also in non-hepatic cells such as kidney, intestine, stomach and pancreas (5 -7 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The importance of HNF4[alpha] in gene control in tissues distinct from the liver has been documented by the fact that a human inherited disease is based on the expression of a mutated HNF4[alpha] gene in the endocrine pancreas leading to maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY1; 8 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In addition to the role of HNF4[alpha] as a tissue specific transcription factor it functions also in early embryogenesis: in the Xenopus egg we identified the HNF4[alpha] protein as a maternal transcription factor that contributes to the zygotic activation of the gene encoding HNF1[alpha] (9 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In mouse embryos HNF4[alpha] transcripts have been identified in the primary endoderm as early as day 4.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	17	5 and later in the liver diverticulum, the gut and nephrogenic tissues starting from day 8.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The early embryonic requirement of HNF4[alpha] is well established in the mouse, as the knock-out of the HNF4[alpha] gene leads to a disturbance of gastrulation and thus to early embryonic lethality (11 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The embryonic role of HNF4 seems to be evolutionary conserved, as maternal HNF4 mRNA has been identified in the Drosophila egg.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Furthermore, a large chromosomal deletion spanning the HNF4 locus results in defects in the gut and malpighian tubules of the developing Drosophila and these malformations are interpreted that HNF4 plays similar functions in invertebrates and vertebrates (7 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	21	In addition to HNF4[alpha] we have recently identified two other members of the HNF4 family, i.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	22	 HNF4[beta] in Xenopus (2 ) and HNF4[gamma] in humans (1 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Both these new members of the HNF4 family seem to have distinct but overlapping functions compared to HNF4[alpha], since both gene products show a differential expression pattern and a distinct transactivation potential of HNF4 dependent reporter genes.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	24	Further complexity of gene control by HNF4[alpha] transcription factors is apparently given by the differential splicing of the 10 initially identified exons of the HNF4[alpha] gene (6 ,8 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Thus far, six distinct splice variants of HNF4[alpha] have been identified in human and murine cDNA samples.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We use the nomenclature most recently used for the human splice variants (12 ): HNF4[alpha]1 represents the initially identified transcript (3 ) and HNF4[alpha]2 through HNF4[alpha]6 are the splice variants identified subsequently.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	27	 HNF4[alpha]2 is a splice variant that contains a larger exon 9 resulting in an insertion of 10 additional amino acids in the Pro-rich C-terminal part and has been identified in the rat (13 ), the mouse (14 ) and human (1 ,15 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	28	 HNF4[alpha]3 initially refered to as HNF-4C (16 ) has been identified in human liver cDNA and is characterized by a shorter and distinct C-terminus, whereas HNF4[alpha]4 found in human kidney and liver RNA contains in the N-terminal region the two additional exons 1B and 1C (1 ,12 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The fifth splice variant HNF4[alpha]5 carries the exon 1B and 1C found in HNF4[alpha]4 together with the larger exon 9 found in HNF4[alpha]2, whereas HNF4[alpha]6 combines exon 1B and exon 1C with the C-terminal truncation found in HNF4[alpha]3 (12 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	30	 We speculate that all these splice variants have unique properties allowing a modulation of the HNF4[alpha] activity.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Indeed, we have shown in transient transfection assays using HNF4 dependent reporter genes, that HNF4[alpha]4 has a lower transactivation potential compared to HNF4[alpha]2 (1 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	32	 However, it should be stressed that all these HNF4[alpha] variants have only been identified as mRNAs and the existence of the corresponding proteins has not been proven.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	33	The broad spectrum of tissues expressing HNF4[alpha] argues for a function of HNF4[alpha] in the establishment of the differentiation of various cell types, but most data concerning the role of HNF4[alpha] have been investigated in hepatic cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Most notably, the presence of HNF4[alpha] expression has been correlated with the differentiated phenotype of hepatocytes (reviewed in 17 ) .
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In fact, it has been shown that the introduction of HNF4[alpha] in dedifferentiated hepatocytes can lead to a redifferentiation as shown by the activation of several liver specific functions (18 -20 ), whereas the forced expression of a dominant negative mutant down-regulates several liver specific genes in differentiated hepatoma cells (21 ,22 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	36	In the present report we analyzed in the murine cell line MHSV-12 the highly differentiated hepatic phenotype that is reversibly decreased in serum-containing culture medium (23 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	37	 We reasoned that this change in hepatic differentiation might correlate with an altered expression of HNF4[alpha].
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Using these cells we succeeded to define a novel HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant that is expressed in a tissue specific manner and most notably found as the major component in embryonic stem cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	39	 MATERIALS AND METHODS Nucleotide sequence accession number.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	40	The sequence of the splice variant HNF4[alpha]7 was deposited in GenBank (accession number AF015275).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Cell cultures and transfections.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	42	All culture media contained penicillin (100 U/ml) and streptomycin (100 U/ml).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The MHSV-12 cell clone was maintained in the chemically defined MX83 medium supplemented with 1  microg/ml transferrin, 10  microg/ml insulin, 1  microg/ml hydrocortisone and 100 ng/ml EGF as described (23 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	44	 For splitting, the cells were trypsinized and cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) with 10% heat-inactivated calf serum for one day before adding the MX83 medium.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	45	 F9 cells were propagated on gelatine coated cell culture dishes in DMEM with 10% heat-inactivated calf serum.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	46	 To induce visceral endoderm differentiation the F9 cells were seeded into bacterial dishes in the presence of 2  x  10-7 M retinoic acid (24 ,25 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Embryonic stem cells (ES cells) (E14-1) were cultured on mitomycin-treated feeder cells in DMEM containing 15% heat inactivated fetal calf serum and supplemented with MEM non-essential amino acids (Sigma), 2 mM glutamine and 100  microM [beta]-mercaptoethanol.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	48	For transient transfection of C2 cells the DNA-calcium phosphate coprecipitation method was used (26 ), whereas for Hela and MHSV-12 cells the lipofectin transfection protocol was applied (1 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Extract preparation and gel retardation assays.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	50	High salt extracts of crude nuclear pellets of cultured cells were prepared as described (27 ) and the gel retardation assays (28 ) were performed using the HNF4 binding site of the human apolipoprotein B promoter (2 ) or the Xenopus HNF1[alpha] promoter (26 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The monoclonal antibody recognizing the A/B-domain of HNF4[alpha]1 has been described (29 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The polyclonal antibodies anti-A/B/C and anti-F were raised against the N-terminus of the rat HNF4[alpha]1 protein (29 ) and a peptide of the F-domain of the Xenopus HNF4[alpha] protein (2 ), respectively.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	53	 These polyclonal antisera were produced in rabbits by Eurogentec.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	54	For the 5' RACE, RNA was purified with the RNA-CleantmSystem (AGS, Heidelberg) from MHSV-12 cells grown in serum containing DMEM and 5  microg aliquots reverse transcribed with the HN7 primer into cDNA using the Superscripttm II plus kit (GIBCO/BRL).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The 5'-end of the cDNA was amplified with the 5'-AmpliFINDERtm RACE kit (CLONTECH) by ligating the oligonucleotide H2N-TGGGCCTCTAGACTTAAG-5' to the 3'-end of the cDNA.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	56	 This tag was used for priming with the oligonucleotide P11 (5'-ACCCGGAGATCTGAATTC-3') and the PCR product was cloned.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	57	 For RT-PCR cDNA was synthesized with random primer using 5  microg RNA.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	58	 To detect HNF4[alpha] transcripts the reverse primer HN7 (5'-CCTTAAGGCTTCCTTCTTCATGCCAGCCCGG-3') and the forward primers HN6 (5'-GGAATTCCGGCATGGATATGGCCGACTACAGCGC-') or HN18 (5'-GGGTACCCTTGGTCATGGTCAGTG-3') were used (see Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The oligonucleotide HN7 and HN6 contain linker sequences (underlined) at the 5'-end not present in the cDNA.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	60	 To quantitate GAPDH mRNA, the oligonucleotides 5'-ACCACAGTCCATGCCATCAC-3' and 5'-TCCACCACCCTGTTGCTGTA-3', were used as forward and reverse primers, respectively.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	61	 To quantitate the HNF4[alpha] transcripts as illustrated in Figures 6 and 7 the PCR reactions contained in addition of the 200  microM dNTP a labeled triphosphate, i.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	62	 1  microCi/50  microl reaction ([alpha]-32P)dCTP.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	63	 This allows quantification of the PCR fragments with a phosphor imager.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	64	 In addition this sensitive detection permits a lower cycle number and thus avoids reaching the saturation of the PCR (30 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	65	 All reactions were done at 62 and 72 degrees C for annealing and extension, respectively.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	66	 RESULTS A novel HNF4[alpha] protein in dedifferentiated hepatocytes.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	67	It is well established that the composition of the culture medium has a profound effect on the differentiation state of hepatocytes (23 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	68	 In general the presence of serum leads to substantial dedifferentiation of the hepatic phenotype.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	69	 To explore whether the cultivation conditions of hepatocytes has any effect on the expression of tissue specific transcription factors known to be responsible for the hepatic phenotype, we determined the presence of liver transcription factors in the immortalized murine hepatic cell line MHSV-12.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	70	 This cell line has been found to express most abundantly transcripts of liver specific proteins such as albumin, aldolase A and B as well as tyrosine amino transferase, but this liver specific expression pattern is reversibly decreased in serum containing medium (23 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Analyzing the expression of HNF1[alpha] in the MHSV-12 cell line cultured under various conditions we did not detect any change in this transcription factor (data not shown).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	72	 However, probing HNF4[alpha] in gel retardation assays using various antibodies we detected some significant differences: as illustrated in Figure 1 A, in extracts of MHSV-12 cells grown in serum-free MX83 medium, that maintains a highly differentiated hepatic phenotype (23 ), HNF4[alpha] could readily be detected in gel retardation experiments (lane 1) and this DNA-protein complex could be supershifted by an antibody raised against the A/B-domain or the F-domain of HNF4[alpha] (lanes 2 and 3, respectively).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	73	 In contrast, in extracts derived from MHSV-12 cells cultivated in the presence of serum, that leads to a dramatic dedifferentiation (23 ), we observed that the HNF4[alpha] protein detected in gel retardation assays (lane 4) did not react with the antibody specific for the A/B-domain of HNF4[alpha] (lane 5).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	74	 However, in the same extracts the presence of HNF4[alpha] protein could be verified with the antibody specific for the F-domain (lane 6).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	75	 These results imply that the properties of HNF4[alpha] change in MHSV-12 cells depending on the culture conditions.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The HNF4[alpha] protein of MHSV-12 cells reacts with the A/B-domain specific antibody depending on the conditions used to culture the cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Nuclear extracts of MHSV-12 cells were used for gel retardation assays with the HNF4 binding site of the apolipoprotein promoter.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The addition of specific antibodies is given and the arrow head points to the complex supershifted by the A/B-domain specific antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	79	 (A) Extracts were prepared from cells grown either in the chemically defined MX83 medium lacking serum (lanes 1-3) or in DMEM containing calf serum (lanes 4-6).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	80	 (B) Extracts were derived from cells maintained in complete MX83 medium (lanes 7 and 8) or in MX83 medium lacking either epidermal growth factor (lanes 1 and 2), hydrocortisone (lanes 3 and 4) or insulin (lanes 5 and 6).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	81	 (C) Nuclear proteins were extracted from cells grown in DMEM with 10% serum.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Dexamethasone (dex) and its antagonist RU486 were added to the cells at 10-7M and 3  x  10-4M, respectively, as indicated.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The type of HNF4[alpha] protein present in MHSV-12 cells is dependent on glucocorticoids.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	84	To identify the components in the culture medium that change the properties of the HNF4[alpha] protein, we cultivated the MHSV-12 cells in MX83 medium lacking defined components and analyzed the extracts of these cells in the gel retardation assay using the A/B-domain specific antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	85	 As Figure 1 B illustrates, the omission of hydrocortisone in the culture medium results in cell extracts with HNF4[alpha] protein that mostly cannot be supershifted by the A/B-domain specific antibody (lanes 3 and 4).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	86	 In contrast extracts derived from cultures grown in the absence of EGF (lanes 1 and 2) or insulin (lanes 5 and 6) contain HNF4[alpha] that is predominantly supershifted by the A/B-domain specific antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Consequently, the presence of hydrocortisone in the serum-free medium leads to the expression of the HNF4[alpha] form that is recognized by the A/B-domain specific antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	88	In a complementary approach we investigated the effect of the glucocorticoid hormone on HNF4[alpha] expression in MHSV-12 cells grown with serum.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	89	 As shown in the gel retardation assay of Figure 1 C, a 24 h incubation with dexamethasone leads to a substantial amount of HNF4[alpha] protein that is recognized by the A/B-domain specific antibody (lane 5).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Since this dexamethasone mediated change can be inhibited by RU486, a well known antagonist binding to the glucocorticoid receptor as a competitor of the glucocorticoid (lane 8), we assume that the effect is mediated by the nuclear hormone receptor.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	91	The findings with the cells grown without serum as well as the data with the cultures maintained in serum, both imply that a glucocorticoid mediated event alters the properties of the HNF4[alpha] protein in such a way that it is recognized by the A/B specific antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The novel HNF4[alpha]7 protein is encoded by a differential splice variant of the HNF4[alpha] gene.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	93	The differential recognition of HNF4[alpha] by the A/B-domain specific antibody could either reflect a protein modification or a change in the amino acid sequence in the N-terminus of the HNF4[alpha] protein.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	94	 To distinguish between these two alternatives we transfected an expression vector encoding the originally described rat HNF4[alpha] protein (3 ) into MHSV-12 cells grown in the presence of serum, i.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	95	 in the absence of hydrocortisone, that abolishes the supershift by the A/B-domain specific antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Analyzing increasing amounts of extracts derived from these transfected cell lines by gel retardation assays we observed a concentration dependent appearance of a HNF4[alpha] protein that can be supershifted by the A/B-domain specific antibody (marked by an arrow head in lanes 2 and 5 in Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	97	 2 ), whereas in extracts of mock transfected cells no HNF4[alpha] protein could be supershifted by the A/B specific antibody (lanes 8 and 11).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Using the F-domain specific antibody no qualitative difference could be seen between the HNF4[alpha] transfected cells and the control, but the supershifted band was stronger in the extract of the transfected cells (compare lanes 3 and 6 with lanes 9 and 12).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	99	 These results rule out the possibility that protein modification plays a major role but rather imply that the transfected HNF4[alpha] encodes a protein that is distinct in its amino acid sequence from the protein expressed in undifferentiated MHSV-12 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The transfected HNF4[alpha] protein is recognized by the A/B specific antibody in MHSV-12 cells grown in serum containing DMEM.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	101	 An expression vector encoding the rat HNF4[alpha]1 protein (HNF4[alpha]/CMV) or alternatively the Rc/CMV vector alone were transfected into MHSV-12 cells grown in DMEM with 10% calf serum.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Aliquots (2 or 4  microl) of nuclear extracts prepared from the transfected cells were analyzed in gel retardation assays with the HNF4 binding site of the apolipoprotein promoter.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The arrow marks the DNA-HNF4[alpha] complex supershifted by the antibody specific for the F-domain.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The arrow head points to the transfected HNF4[alpha] protein detected by the monoclonal anti A/B-antibody.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Comparison of the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	106	 (A) Schematic drawings of the [alpha]1 and [alpha]7 splice variants of the mouse HNF4[alpha] gene.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The boxes designate the domains of the protein as defined (3).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The position of the primers used is indicated.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	109	 (B) Alignment of the nucleotide sequence of the [alpha]1 and [alpha]7 splice variants.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The in frame stop codon TGA preceeding the open reading frame and the initiation codon ATG of HNF4[alpha]7 are underlined.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The nucleotide sequence of HNF4[alpha]1 is as published (14).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The initiation codon of HNF4[alpha]1 is based on our sequence comparisons of the HNF4[alpha] proteins of various species (1).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The position of the first intron (6) is marked by an arrow.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	114	 (C) The N-terminal part of the amino acid sequence of the [alpha]1 and [alpha]7 splice variants are aligned.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The cystein residues forming the zinc finger domain are underlined.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	116	To prove the assumption that in MHSV-12 cells the endogenous HNF4[alpha] protein differs in its amino acid sequence from the cloned sequence, we analyzed the HNF4[alpha] mRNA derived from cells cultivated in the presence of serum.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	117	 As the difference in the HNF4[alpha] protein is only detected with the monoclonal antibody raised against the N-terminal A/B-domain, we suspected a distinct 5'-end of the HNF4[alpha] mRNA.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Therefore, we generated by reverse transcription a cDNA starting in the D-domain (primer HN7 in Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	119	 3 A) and ligated this DNA at the 5'-end with an oligonucleotide that could be used as a second primer start site.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Using this 5' RACE strategy we succeeded in cloning two independent cDNA fragments, that were analyzed by sequencing.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The sequence of the longer cDNA clone, shown in Figure 3 B, revealed that the 5'-end from -107 to +47 is completely different from the published nucleotide sequence of mouse HNF4[alpha], whereas the 3'-end (nucleotide +48 to +274) is highly identical to the known sequence.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The loss of identity is exactly at the same position in the shorter cDNA clone (data not shown), thus excluding a cloning artefact.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	123	 As the loss of identity corresponds in both cases to the position of the exon 1-exon 2 boundary (6 ), we anticipate that the new cDNA encodes a novel splice variant of the HNF4[alpha] gene we refer to as HNF4[alpha]7.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	124	The 5'-end of the HNF4[alpha]7 cDNA encodes an in frame open reading frame preceeded by an in frame stop codon (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Comparing the amino acid sequence between the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 proteins, reveals that their N-termini are completely different and that the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant is, by 23 amino acids, shorter than the previously described HNF4[alpha]1 protein (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The novel N-terminal sequence of HNF4[alpha]7 shows no significant identity to any sequence in the data bank.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The balance of the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants changes with the MHSV-12 differentiation status.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	128	Comparing extracts derived from MHSV-12 cells grown without serum or in the presence of serum, we observed in western blots that HNF4[alpha] is slightly shorter in the presence of serum and thus has the size of the predicted HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant (data not shown).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The presence of this splice variant was confirmed by RT-PCR using primers specific for the [alpha]7 splice variant.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Figure 4 reveals the expression of the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant in MHSV-12 cells cultured in the presence of serum (lane 1).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Apparently significant amounts of the HNF4[alpha]7 variant are also found in cells grown in serum-free medium (lane 2).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	132	 However, these RT-PCR reactions were performed close to saturation and, therefore, heavily overestimate the amount of HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	133	 In contrast the previously described HNF4[alpha]1 splice variant is exclusively detected in MHSV-12 cells grown in serum-free medium (compare lanes 4 and 5).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	134	 These data confirm that the serum induced change in the differentiation state of the hepatic cells is accompanied by an alteration in the HNF4[alpha] splice variants.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In differentiated cells grown under serum-free conditions HNF4[alpha]1, and to a small extent HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts, are present, whereas dedifferentiated cells grown with serum contain almost exclusively the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The presence of the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants in MHSV-12 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	137	 By RT-PCR using the primer pair HN18/HN7 (lanes 1 and 2) or HN6/HN7 (lanes 4 and 5) the presence of the [alpha]7 and [alpha]1 splice variant was determined, respectively.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The RNA used was either prepared from cells grown in serumfree MX83 medium (lanes 2 and 4) or from cells maintained in DMEM with 10% serum (lanes 1 and 5).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The PCR products were separated on a 1.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	140	8% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	141	 pBR322 plasmid DNA restricted with Alw441 and Mva1 was loaded in lane 3 as size marker.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	142	The marker fragment migrating between the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 PCR product is 383bp in size.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The position of the primers is given in Figure 3A.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	144	 HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 have distinct transactivation potential.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	145	To address the question whether the novel splice variant has a differential transactivation potential we compared its transactivation potential in transfection experiments with the splice variant HNF4[alpha]1.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Using a luciferase reporter construct containing four HNF4 binding sites in front of the tk promoter (31 ) we observed in the dedifferentiated hepatoma cell line C2 that lacks HNF4[alpha], (31 ) a 2-fold lower transactivation potential of HNF4[alpha]7 compared to HNF4[alpha]1 (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In Hela cells an even greater difference in the transactivation potential between the two splice variants was observed (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In fact using high concentrations of the HNF4[alpha]7 expression vector no transactivation of the luciferase reporter was seen.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Taken together these results establish that MHSV-12 cells grown in serum, that leads to dramatic dedifferentiation of the hepatic phenotype, contain the HNF4[alpha]7 variant that has a significantly lower transactivation potential.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The HNF4[alpha]7 transcription factor is a functional transactivator with a reduced activation potential compared to HNF4[alpha]1.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (A) The dedifferentiated hepatoma cell line C2 lacking HNF4[alpha] was transiently transfected with 50 ng expression vector encoding HNF4[alpha] protein and 2  microg H4-tk-luc as a reporter, that contains four copies of the HNF4 binding site from the human [alpha]1-anti-trypsin gene in front of the thymidine kinase promoter as previously described (31).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Rc/CMV (InVitrogen) is the expression vector without insert, whereas rHNF4[alpha]1 contains the rat transcription factor (3) used to construct the mHNF4[alpha]1 and mHNF4[alpha]7 constructs.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	153	 mHNF4[alpha]1 is a mouse rat chimeric protein with amino acids 1-102 derived from the mouse [alpha]1 protein and amino acids 103 to the C-terminus of the rat protein.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	154	 mHNF4[alpha]7 is the corresponding chimeric protein containing the N-terminus of the [alpha]7 splice variant fused to the C-terminus of the rat protein.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	155	 For both these constructs the AccI site at codon 102 of the HNF4[alpha]1 protein was used (see Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	156	 (B) Increasing amounts of the expression vector encoding mHNF4[alpha]1 or mHNF4[alpha]7 were transfected into Hela cells with the H4-tk-luc reporter.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The amount of plasmid DNA was kept constant by adding Rc/CMV.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The error bars given refer to independent transfection experiments.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Tissue specific expression pattern of HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	160	 RNA isolated from mouse tissues were analyzed by RT-PCR for the presence of the HNF4[alpha]7 and HNF4[alpha]1 splice variants using the HN18/HN7 and HN6/HN7 primer pairs, respectively (see Fig 3A).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	161	 To control the quality of the RNA the presence of GAPDH mRNA was analyzed in aliquots of the same RT reactions.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The print-outs of the phosphor imager represent PCR reactions generated by using 35 (HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7) or 30 (GAPDH) cycles.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	163	 To estimate the abundance of the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts the signals were counted in the phosphor imager and corrected for the amount of GAPDH mRNA.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	164	 To ascertain that the PCR reactions were still in the linear range the values given for the high expressing tissues (liver, kidney, stomach and intestine) were calculated from experiments using only 30 cycles of amplification.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Differential expression of HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 in embryonic cell lines.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	166	 (A) The undifferentiated embryonal carcinoma cell line F9 or F9 cells differentiated during 7 days to visceral endoderm were treated with dexamethasone as indicated.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The HNF4[alpha]7 and HNF4[alpha]1 transcripts were detected by RT-PCR as in Figure 6 using 35 cycles of amplification.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The GAPDH RNA was amplified by 25 cycles.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	169	 (B) The HNF4 binding site of the HNF1[alpha] promoter was used for gel retardation assays with nuclear extracts of the F9 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The addition of the various antibodies is given.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The arrow designates the complexes containing HNF4[alpha]1 or HNF4[alpha]7, whereas the arrow head points to the supershift containing HNF4[alpha]1.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	172	 (C) RNA prepared from the embryonic stem cell line E14-1 grown on feeder cells (lane 2) or from the feeder cells alone (lane 3) was analyzed by RT-PCR for the presence of HNF4[alpha]7 (35 cycles) and GAPDH (25 cycles) mRNA as in (A).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	173	 In lane 1 no RNA was added in the RT reaction.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	174	 HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 show a distinct tissue specific expression pattern.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	175	To explore the significance of the novel HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant we investigated by RT-PCR the presence of HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts in different mouse tissues.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	176	 To allow a reliable quantification we made the PCR reaction with 32P-labeled dCTP that permits low cycling numbers and thus ensures quantitative measurements.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	177	 As shown in Figure 6 both these transcripts can be identified in the liver and the stomach (lanes 1 and 3), whereas in the kidney and to a smaller extent in the intestine only the HNF4[alpha]1 transcript can be detected.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In the pancreas only small amounts of HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts are present.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	179	 But the significance of this finding is questionable as the GAPDH mRNA cannot be seen probably because the pancreatic RNase was not sufficiently inhibited during RNA preparation.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, traces of HNF4[alpha]7 RNA were also detected in the ovary, heart, bladder and brain, where no HNF4[alpha]1 transcripts and normal levels of GAPDH RNA were observed.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Clearly, the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants are expressed differentially in the various tissues analyzed.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	182	 By quantification of the PCR products in a phosphor imager we estimate that in the stomach about a third of the HNF4[alpha] transcripts correspond to the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant (lane 3).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Furthermore, the abundance of the HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts differs by a factor of ~1000-fold between high and low expressing tissues.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	184	 HNF4[alpha]7 is expressed in embryonic stem cells of the mouse.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	185	Our initial experiments leading to the identification of the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant implied some correlation of the novel splice variant with the undifferentiated phenotype of the hepatocytes.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Therefore, we investigated the presence of HNF4[alpha]7 in the murine embryonal carcinoma cell line F9 that resembles the pluripotent stem cells of the inner cell mass of the early mouse embryo.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	187	 This cell line can can be differentiated into distinct endodermal cell types upon retinoic acid treatment.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Most interestingly these stem cells can be differentiated by retinoic acid treatment into visceral endoderm when they are cultured in suspension as aggregates and these cell types share properties of hepatocytes (24 ,32 ) .
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Based on RT-PCR we succeeded to show that undifferentiated F9 cells contain exclusively the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant ( Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	190	 7 A, lanes 1 and 2), whereas the differentiated cell population contains the HNF4[alpha]1 as well as the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants (lanes 3 and 4).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	191	 From three independent experiments we estimated by quantification in a phosphor imager a 15-fold increase in HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA upon differentiation into visceral endoderm, whereas the level of HNF4[alpha]1 transcripts increased from undetectable levels to a value ~60% of the amount of the HNF4[alpha]7 transcript.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Since in the immortalized hepatic MHSV-12 cells grown in the presence of serum, the balance between HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 is altered by the addition of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	193	 1 ), we wondered whether a similar effect is seen in F9 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	194	 As Figure 7 A demonstrates the expression pattern of HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 is not changed upon dexamethasone treatment in either undifferentiated or differentiated F9 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	195	To determine whether the presence of the HNF4[alpha]7 transcript in the embryonal cell line F9 also reflects the expression of the corresponding protein, we prepared nuclear extracts from F9 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In gel retardation assays with extracts from undifferentiated F9 cells (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	197	 7 B) we could detect a supershift with the F-domain specific antibody (lane 3) and the A/B/C-domain specific antibody (lane 4) but no reaction with the A/B-domain specific antibody (lane 2).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In contrast in F9 cells differentiated into visceral endoderm a supershift was seen with each of the three antibodies (lanes 6, 7 and 8).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	199	 This result is consistent with the RT-PCR analysis and implies that undifferentiated F9 cells contain HNF4[alpha]7 protein, whereas HNF4[alpha]1 as well as HNF4[alpha]7 proteins are present in differentiated F9 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	200	To further investigate the early embryonic expression of HNF4[alpha]7 we searched for the corresponding transcript in the totipotent embryonic stem cell line E14-1.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The RT-PCR analysis given in Figure 7 C demonstrates the presence of HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA in this embryonal stem cell (lane 2), whereas the RNA sample derived from the feeder cells used for the ES cell culture lack any HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts (lane 3).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Probing the same ES cell RNA for the HNF4[alpha]1 mRNA we did not detect any transcript (data not shown).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	203	From the analysis of both the F9 cells and the ES cells we conclude that the presence of HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA is a characteristic of undifferentiated embryonic cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	204	The novel splice variant HNF4[alpha]7 is expressed as the exclusive HNF4[alpha] transcript in the undifferentiated embryonal carcinoma cell line F9 and the ES cell line E14-1.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The transcript is also found in the hepatocyte cell line MHSV-12 that has been established by immortalization of embryonic hepatocytes.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	206	 In this immortalized hepatic cell culture HNF4[alpha]7 predominates provided these cells are cultured under conditions that lead to dedifferentiation.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In this context it is important to stress that the MHSV-12 cell line dedifferentiated by serum addition has far more hepatic characters than the dedifferentiated hepatoma cell lines C2 and H5 that both lack any HNF4[alpha] and HNF1[alpha] transcription factors (18 ,32 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	208	Recently, the expression of HNF4[alpha] has been investigated in the ES cell line D3 (33 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Under differentiating conditions allowing the formation of embryoid bodies the appearance of HNF4[alpha] RNA has been observed, but no signal was detected in the undifferentiated embryonic stem cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The lack of HNF4[alpha] transcripts in undifferentiated ES cells probably reflects the insensitivity of the Northern blots compared to our RT-PCR assay as these authors used a full length cDNA probe that would hybridize also to the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	211	The presence of HNF4[alpha]7 in various embryonic cell types suggests that this novel HNF4[alpha] splice variant has some function during early embryogenesis.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Early embryonic expression of the HNF4[alpha] gene starting in the primary endoderm at embryonic day 4.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	213	5 of the mouse has been documented by in situ hybridization (10 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	214	 As the probe used in these experiments did not differentiate between the [alpha]1 and [alpha]7 splice variant, the identity of this signal in respect to the splice variants is not clear.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	215	 However, another in situ hybridization used a genomic fragment of the exon 1 of the original HNF4[alpha] transcript (6 ) and thus, in retrospect, was a HNF4[alpha]1 specific probe.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	216	 With this probe HNF4[alpha] transcripts were first localised only on day 7 p.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	217	 in visceral extraembryonic endoderm.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This detection at a later time point in embryogenesis could well reflect the fact that this probe could not hybridize to the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Similarly, the relatively late appearance of HNF4[alpha] binding activity in gel retardation assays starting at 8.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	220	 (25 ) might also be interpreted as a lack of reactivity of the antibody with the HNF4[alpha]7 splice variant.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Therefore, by indirect evidence the earlier appearance of HNF4[alpha]7 compared to HNF4[alpha]1, we have seen in the differentiating F9 cells (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	222	 7A and B) matches the available data in the developing embryo.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	223	Analyzing 200 unfertilized mouse eggs we could not identify HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA whereas GAPDH mRNA was readily detectable (data not shown).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	224	 As unfertilized mouse eggs are about 20 times larger than the ES cells, the input RNA in the RT-PCR corresponds to ~4000 ES cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Since in such an ES cell aliquot we could identify the HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA, we assume that HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts are absent in the egg and accumulate by zygotic transcription in early mouse embryogenesis.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	226	 This is consistent with the appearance of HNF4[alpha] transcripts in in situ hybridization experiments with a probe detecting HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 only at day 4.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Therefore, it seems unlikely that HNF4[alpha] mRNA is a maternal component in mammals.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	228	 This is in contrast to Drosophila HNF4 (7 ) and Xenopus HNF4[beta] mRNA (2 ) that are known to be present as maternal transcripts.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	229	 However, the HNF4[alpha] protein itself might be a maternal component of the mammalian egg, a situation we have found for the HNF4[alpha] protein in Xenopus whose corresponding mRNA has disappeared at the egg stage (2 ,34 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	230	An early function of HNF4[alpha] gene expression in mammals has been established by the disruption of the gene that results in an impaired gastrulation and early embryonic lethality (11 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	231	 As the targeting vector used in these knock-out experiments lacked exon 2 and 3, the HNF4[alpha]1 as well as the HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts are devoid of the DNA binding domain.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Therefore, it is not clear at the moment which HNF4[alpha] transcripts plays the essential function at this early embryonic stage.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	233	 It should also be considered that the partial rescue of HNF4[alpha] knock-out embryos observed by supplementing the developing embryo with normal visceral endoderm (35 ) might be an effect relieving only one of the two HNF4[alpha] splice variants.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	234	We assume that the presence of HNF4[alpha]7 in the undifferentiated embryonal carcinoma cell line F9 and in the embryonic stem cell E14-1 reflects already some first step of embryonic gene regulation.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Consistent with this interpretation the presence of transcripts encoding the tissue specific transcription factor HNF1[alpha] has been reported in undifferentiated F9 cells (25 ,36 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Since it is well established that HNF1[alpha] is a potential target gene of HNF4[alpha] (18 -20 ,26 ,37 ), we consider the possibility that HNF4[alpha]7 triggers HNF1[alpha] expression at this early stage.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	237	 However, the significance of such a potential effect is questionable as the HNF1[alpha] transcripts are of aberrant size and no HNF1[alpha] protein can be detected in F9 cells (25 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	238	Our analysis demonstrates that HNF4[alpha]7 is not restricted to embryonic tissues as it is also found abundantly in the stomach of the adult mouse (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	239	 In contrast, in the liver and intestine, HNF4[alpha]7 transcripts constitute only a minor fraction as compared to HNF4[alpha]1 and in the ovary, heart, bladder and brain only traces can be found.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	240	 It will be most interesting to investigate whether in these tissues HNF4[alpha]7 is restricted to a subpopulation of cells, e.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	241	Our finding that the transactivation potential of the HNF4[alpha] splice variants differs in transient transfection assays and that the extent of this effect depends on the cell type used (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	242	 5 ), indicates that the two HNF4[alpha] splice variants cooperate differentially with other transcription factors.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	243	 As the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants have distinct N-termini, we expect that this domain determines the differential cooperation.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Therefore, we exclude the reported interaction with COUP-TFI and COUP-TFII (38 ) as well as the binding to HNF1[alpha] (39 ) as the mechanisms mediating the distinct properties of of HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7, since these interactions involve the C-terminus common to HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	245	 However, the specific binding observed with the basal transcription factor TFIIB (40 ) might trigger the distinct properties of the two splice variants, as the formation of this complex requires the N-terminus of HNF4[alpha] (38 ,40 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Alternatively, HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 may exert distinct activities due to differential heterodimerization with other members of the HNF4 family (1 ,2 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	247	 But we would not expect differential heterodimerization with other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, since HNF4[alpha] seems usually not to heterodimerize with these components (41 ,42 ).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	248	Analyzing the expression of the HNF4[alpha] splice variants we revealed that HNF4[alpha]7 is under a complex regulatory network.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In the hepatic cell line MHSV-12 the glucocorticoid plays a major role as the lack of this hormone seems to be a critical component for the appearance of HNF4[alpha]7.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Clearly, the glucocorticoid hormone alters the balance between the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 splice variants.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	251	 As glucocorticoids are known to trigger the final stage of hepatic differentiation at birth (43 ), we have investigated the expression of these two HNF4[alpha] splice variants.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Using liver extracts from 2 days before birth up to 2 days after birth we could not see any change (data not shown).
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	253	 In fact, as all the HNF4 binding activity observed in gel retardation assays could be supershifted by the A/B specific antibody at all stages analyzed, we have no data to support a major change in HNF4[alpha] splice variants at birth, although glucocorticoid action is an essential step at this developmental stage.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	254	 A lack of glucocorticoid control was also seen in F9 cells.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Neither in undifferentiated nor in differentiated F9 cells the addition of dexamethasone altered the level of the HNF4[alpha]1 and HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	256	 On the other hand in these F9 cells the retinoic acid mediated differentiation to visceral endoderm leads to an increase in HNF4[alpha]7 mRNA but more significantly also to the appearance of the HNF4[alpha]1 splice variant.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	257	 This change in HNF4[alpha] expression can also be seen on the protein level, as HNF4 binding activity reacting with the anti A/B antibody is only detected in the differentiated cells (Fig.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	258	Our data show that the splice variant HNF4[alpha]7 contains a distinct first exon.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	259	 As the original exon 1 of the murine HNF4[alpha] gene has been shown to contain the initiation site of the promoter (6 ,44 ), we assume that the novel exon 1 found in HNF4[alpha]7 indicates a second promoter of the HNF4[alpha] gene.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Therefore, we propose that the differential expression of the two splice variants is mainly due to the differential use of two distinct promoters of the HNF4[alpha] gene ACKNOWLEDGMENTS.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	261	Temme for instructing us to cultivate the MHSV-12 cells, B.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	262	Rickert for providing the E14-1 cell cultures, A.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	263	Poleev for some of the murine RNA samples, T.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	264	Zevnic for preparing the unfertilized mouse eggs and E.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	265	Pogge von Strandmann for critical reading of the manuscript.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	266	 This work was supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	267	 (eds), Liver Gene Expression, R.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	268	, et al (1997) Diabetes, 46, 1652-1657.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	269	 (1992) Development, 116, 783-797.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	270	 (1995) Carcinogenesis, 16, 143-145.

0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	272	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
