0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	274	de This page is run by Oxford University Press, Great Clarendon Street, Oxford OX2 6DP, as part of the OUP Journals Comments and feedback: www-admin{at}oup.
0.49359712.9421506.html.plaintext.txt	275	uk' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> Last modification: 6 Jan 1998 Copyright  Oxford University Press, 1998.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcription Activation by the Orphan Nuclear Receptor, Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter-Transcription Factor I (COUP-TFI) DEFINITION OF THE DOMAIN INVOLVED IN THE GLUCOCORTICOID RESPONSE OF THE PHOSPHOENOLPYRUVATE CARBOXYKINASE GENE* Takashi Sugiyama, Jen-Chywan Wang, Donald K.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Molecular Physiology and Biophysics, Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, Nashville, Tennessee 37232-0615.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	2	    ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	3	Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factors (COUP-TFs), orphan members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, play a key role in the regulation of organogenesis, neurogenesis, and cellular differentiation during embryogenic development.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	4	 COUP-TFs are also involved in the regulation of several genes that encode metabolic enzymes.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Although COUP-TFs function as potent transcription repressors, there are at least three different molecular mechanisms of activation of gene expression by COUP-TFs.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	6	 First, as we have previously shown, COUP-TF is required as an accessory factor for the complete induction of phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase gene transcription by glucocorticoids.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	7	 This action is mediated by the binding of COUP-TF to the glucocorticoid accessory factor 1 (gAF1) and 3 (gAF3) elements in the phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase gene glucocorticoid response unit.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In addition, COUP-TF1 binds to DNA elements in certain genes and transactivates directly.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Finally, COUP-TF1 serves as a coactivator through DNA-bound hepatic nuclear factor 4.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Here we show that the same region of COUP-TFI, located between amino acids 184 and 423, is involved in these three mechanisms of transactivation by COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Furthermore, we show that GRIP1 and SRC-1 potentiate the activity of COUP-TFI and that COUP-TFI associates with these coactivators in vivo using the same region required for transcription activation.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Finally, overexpression of GRIP1 or SRC-1 does not convert COUP-TFI from a transcriptional repressor into a transcriptional activator in HeLa cells.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	13	     INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	14	The nuclear hormone receptor superfamily is composed of many diverse subsets of transcriptional factors, including receptors for steroids, retinoids, and thyroid hormones.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Also included are a large number of structurally and functionally related transcription regulatory proteins termed orphan receptors, so named because their natural ligands have not been identified (1-3).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor (COUP-TF)1 is one of the most studied of the orphan receptors.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	17	 COUP-TFI (also termed EAR3) and COUP-TFII (also termed ARP-1) are closely related transcription factors that are expressed ubiquitously and are involved in the regulation of several important biological processes, such as neurogenesis, organogenesis, cell fate determination, and metabolic homeostasis (4-6).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Targeted disruptions of mouse COUP-TFI or COUP-TFII result in perinatal and embryonic lethality, respectively (7, 8).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	19	 COUP-TFs are also involved in the regulation of the transcription of genes that encode various metabolic enzymes such as phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK; EC 4.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	20	32), cholesterol 7-hydroxylase (CYP7A; EC 1.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	21	17) (9), and mitochondrial 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA synthase (EC 4.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	22	COUP-TFs homodimerize or heterodimerize with retinoid X receptor and a few other nuclear receptors and bind to a wide variety of response elements that contain imperfect AGGTCA direct repeats separated by a variable number of nucleotides (7, 11).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Although COUP-TF was initially identified as an activator of the chicken ovalbumin gene, COUP-TFs generally serve as negative regulators in conjunction with other nuclear hormone receptors such as retinoic acid receptor, thyroid hormone receptor, vitamin D receptor, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor, and hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF-4) (11-13).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Several mechanisms account for the repressive effects of COUP-TFs.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	25	 COUP-TFs bind to a number of nuclear hormone receptor response elements and, thus, compete with receptors for these DNA elements.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	26	 COUP-TFs may also repress transcription by forming nonproductive complexes with retinoid X receptor, the essential heterodimer partner of a number of nuclear hormone receptors.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In addition, at least two direct mechanisms of repression have been described.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In one example, termed active repression, COUP-TFs bind to specific DNA elements and repress by forming a direct interaction with corepressors such as nuclear receptor corepressor and silencing mediator for retinoic acid and thyroid hormone receptor (SMRT) (14).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Finally, COUP-TFs can repress transcription by directly binding to the ligand binding domain of nuclear hormone receptors, a process called transrepression (13, 15).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	30	COUP-TFs also activate transcription in various promoter contexts (9, 10, 16-21).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	31	 COUP-TFII stimulates the transcriptional activity of the rat CYP7A promoter by binding to the nucleotide sequence located between 74 and 54 (relative to the transcription start site), which contains a direct repeat of two hormone response element half-sites separated by 4 nucleotides (a DR4) (9).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Furthermore, COUP-TFs function as accessory factors for the hormonal response of some genes, such as the glucocorticoid response of the PEPCK and the estrogen response of the trout estrogen receptor gene (19).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Finally, COUP-TFs also can function as coactivators.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For instance, COUP-TFs potentiate HNF-4-mediated transactivation in the hepatocyte nuclear factor 1 (HNF-1) gene promoter through direct interaction with HNF-4 and without a requirement for DNA binding (17).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	35	 A similar coactivator function has been described in the vHNF (also termed HNF-1-) gene promoter, where COUP-TFs do not bind DNA directly but potentiate the transcriptional activity of the vHNF gene promoter through a DNA-independent interaction with Oct-1 (20).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	36	Our interest is directed to the role COUP-TF plays in the hormonal regulation of the PEPCK gene.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	37	 PEPCK catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate, a rate-controlling step in hepatic gluconeogenesis.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	38	 PEPCK gene transcription is positively regulated by glucocorticoids, glucagon (cAMP) and retinoic acid, whereas insulin inhibits the transcription of the PEPCK gene (22-24).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Induction of transcription of the PEPCK gene by glucocorticoids is achieved through a complex glucocorticoid response unit (GRU) (see Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The GRU includes, as a linear array from 5' to 3', two glucocorticoid accessory factor binding sites, gAF1 and gAF2,2 two glucocorticoid receptor (GR) binding sites, GR1 and GR2, and a third accessory factor binding site, gAF3 (25, 26).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	41	 An intact cAMP response element (located between 93 and 86) is also required for a full glucocorticoid response and, thus, is part of the GRU (see Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The proteins that mediate the accessory activities through gAF1, gAF2, and gAF3 have been identified.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Both HNF-4 and COUP-TF bind the gAF1 element and act as accessory factors for the glucocorticoid response (27).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	44	 A number of factors bind to gAF2, although only binding of hepatic nuclear factor 3 (HNF-3) specifically correlates with the ability of the gAF2 element to induce the glucocorticoid response (28).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	45	 COUP-TF also binds to gAF3 and acts as the accessory factor through this element (26).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Thus, COUP-TF serves as an accessory factor required for the induction of PEPCK gene transcription by glucocorticoids through both the gAF1 element and the gAF3 element (see Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	47	The goal of this study is to begin to elucidate the mechanism by which COUP-TF acts as a transactivator of transcription.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	48	 We first identify the minimal region of the molecule (amino acids 184-423) that confers the transactivation function of COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	49	 This is distinct from the previously described repression domain of COUP-TFI (13).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The activation domain mediates gAF1 and gAF3 accessory activity of the glucocorticoid response of the PEPCK gene, is responsible for transactivation through the CYP7A COUP-TFII binding site, and enables COUP-TFI to function as a coactivator for HNF-4.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	51	 GRIP1 and SRC-1 potentiate the transactivation function of COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	52	 However, in a system wherein COUP-TF is repressive, these coactivators cannot convert COUP-TFI into an activator.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	53	 GRIP1 and SRC-1 interact with COUP-TFI in vivo, and these interactions require the intact activation domain defined in the function experiments.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	54	     MATERIALS AND METHODS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	55	Plasmid Construction-- The preparation of the PEPCK promoter-CAT reporter construct (pPL32) has been described previously (29).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The plasmids pGAL4gAF1 and pGAL4gAF2 were derived from pPL32 by the polymerase chain reaction megaprimer method.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The plasmids pGAL4gAF3, pGALgAF1 gAF3, and a series of site-directed mutations of pABGAL4 COUP-TFI and pRSV COUP-TFI were constructed using the Quick Change site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The sequences of the oligonucleotides used in this study are shown in Table I.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Expression plasmids for full-length human COUP-TFI (pRSV-hCOUP-TFI) (11) and pRSV-hCOUP-TFD15 (13) were gifts of Dr.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Ming-Jer Tsai (Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Plasmids that encode GAL4 COUP-TFI chimeras, including GAL4 human COUP-TFI (pABGAL147-hCOUP-TFI) (11), pABGAL147-COUP-TFD15, and pABGAL147-COUP-TFD35 (13) were also provided by Dr.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	62	                              View this table:    Table I Oligonucleotides Used in This Study All sequences are written in the 5' to 3' direction.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	63	A KpnI/HindIII fragment of the pLcat62' (30) was inserted into the KpnI/HindIII sites of the pGL3-Basic vector (Promega, Madison, WI) to generate the LPK-LUC reporter plasmid.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Three copies of the COUP-TF binding site from the CYP7A promoter (positions 74 to 54, relative to the transcription start site) were placed upstream of the minimal L-pyruvate kinase promoter fragment within the LPK-LUC reporter plasmid to generate the plasmid CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC using oligonucleotides CYP7Aa and CYP7Ab.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The 5' overhangs of the XhoI/BamHI fragment of the (GAL4)5E1b-CAT plasmid (31) were filled-in using the Klenow reaction and subcloned into the SmaI sites of the pGL3-Basic vector (Promega) to generate (GAL4)5E1b-LUC.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	66	To generate constructs for the expression of proteins in yeast, cDNAs that encode the wild type protein or a mutation of the C-terminal region of COUP-TFI were amplified by polymerase chain reaction using the primers COUP-TFIa and COUP-TFIb, and COUP-TFIa and COUP-TFIc, respectively, that generate an EcoRI and a BamHI site.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Each polymerase chain reaction product was digested with EcoRI and BamHI and then subcloned into the pGBT9 plasmid (CLONTECH).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The resulting plasmids were named pGBT9-COUP-TFI156/423 and pGBT9-COUP-TFI156/408, respectively.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Yeast plasmids pGBD424-GRIP/FL (32) and pGAD424 SRC-1a (33) were gifts from Dr.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Michael Stallcup (University Southern California, Los Angeles, CA).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	71	The DNA sequence of all constructs was verified by dideoxy sequencing.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	72	 All oligonucleotides were produced on a Perceptive Biosystems Expedite 8909 DNA synthesizer located in the Vanderbilt University Diabetes Research and Training Center DNA chemistry core laboratory.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	73	Transient Transfection-- The maintenance and transfection of H4IIE, HepG2, and HeLa cells and the measurement of CAT activity have been described previously (25, 34, 35).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In the transfection experiments using LUC reporters, firefly luciferase activity was normalized to Renilla luciferase activity using the Promega dual luciferase kit to control for transfection efficiency.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The mammalian expression vector, pSV2GR, was provided by Dr.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Keith Yamamoto (University of California, San Francisco, CA).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	77	Yeast Two Hybrid Assays-- In vivo protein-protein interaction assays were performed using the Matchmaker yeast two hybrid system (CLONTECH).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	78	 A yeast plasmid, pGBT9-COUP-TFI156/423 or pGBT9-COUP-TFI156/408, was transformed into the yeast strain SFY526, and transformants were selected on synthetic dropout plates that contained medium lacking tryptophan.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Yeast plasmids pGAD424 GRIP1/FL and pGAD424 SRC-1a were then transformed into yeast strain SFY526 that contained either pGBT9-COUP-TFI156/423 or pGBT9-COUP-TFI156/408.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	80	 These transformants were selected on synthetic dropout plates with medium lacking leucine and tryptophan.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The colonies that grew in these selection media were subjected to liquid assays by the expression of -galactosidase, as described in the technical manual of the Matchmaker yeast two-hybrid system (CLONTECH).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	82	     RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	83	GAL4 COUP-TFI Confers Both gAF1 and gAF3 Activity-- We have previously demonstrated that the accessory factor activity of COUP-TF is required for a maximal induction of the PEPCK gene by glucocorticoids.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	84	 COUP-TF accomplishes this by binding to both the gAF1 and gAF3 elements (Refs.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	85	 We first examined whether COUP-TFI can mediate accessory activity while tethered to the GAL4 DNA binding domain (GAL4DBD) to establish a system that would allow us to map the domain required for the accessory factor activity of COUP-TF.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Constructs were made wherein either gAF1 or gAF3 alone (pGAL4gAF1 and pGAL4gAF3, respectively) or both gAF1 and gAF3 together (pGAL4gAF1 AF3) were replaced by a yeast GAL4 DNA binding site(s) in the context of the wild type PEPCK promoter-CAT fusion gene construct (pPL32) (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The substitution of gAF1 or gAF3 (or both) by the GAL4 DNA binding element resulted in a 70 to 80% reduction of the glucocorticoid response when compared with pPL32 (compare lines 2-4 with line 1 in Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	88	 This loss of function is equivalent to that obtained from mutations that abolish gAF1 or gAF3 activity (25-27, 36).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Cotransfection of a vector that encodes the GAL4DBD with the pGAL4gAF1, pGAL4gAF3, or pGAL4gAF1 AF3 reporter constructs had very little, if any, effect on the glucocorticoid response (lines 1, 3, 5, Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	90	 By contrast, cotransfection of each reporter gene and a plasmid that encodes a chimeric protein consisting of a region of COUP-TFI and the GAL4DBD (GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423) restored the glucocorticoid response to the level found in cells transfected with pPL32 (compare lines 2, 4, and 6 in Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Indeed, in the presence of GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423, the pGAL4gAF3 construct provided a glucocorticoid response that was significantly greater than that provided by pPL32.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	92	 This may be explained by the fact that COUP-TF binds with relatively low affinity to gAF3 (26).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Thus the GAL4DBD provides a higher affinity binding site for COUP-TF in the context of the pGAL4gAF3 construct than is present in the context of the wild type promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The gAF1 and gAF3 elements cannot function as accessory factor elements when either is placed in the position normally occupied by gAF2 (37).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	95	 GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423 was cotransfected with the pGAL4gAF2 reporter plasmid to determine whether the accessory activity provided by GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423 is sensitive to its location within the PEPCK gene promoter GRU.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	96	 GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423 was unable to provide accessory factor activity to the glucocorticoid response when bound to the gAF2 element (compare line 8 in Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	97	 These results indicate that GAL4 COUP-TFI confers accessory activity through both gAF1 and gAF3.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Furthermore, GAL4 COUP-TFI activity is restricted by its location within the promoter in a manner similar to the authentic COUP-TF (26).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	99	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	100	   Schematic diagram of the PEPCK gene promoter GRU.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The cis-acting elements and associated trans-acting factors required for a complete glucocorticoid response are shown.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The location of each cis-element with respect to the transcription start site is shown above the schematic of the PEPCK promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Also shown are the sequences of the gAF1 and gAF3 elements and their relative locations.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	104	 C/EBP, CAAT/enhancer-binding protein.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (49K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	106	   A GAL4 COUP-TF1 chimeric protein confers accessory activity to the PEPCK glucocorticoid response through both gAF1 and gAF3.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Mutations were made in the context of the full-length wild type (WT) PEPCK gene promoter construct, pPL32, so that gAF1 or gAF3 (or both) were replaced with the DNA binding site for the yeast transcription factor, GAL4.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	108	 As shown in panel A, the ability of the mutant constructs (lines 2-4) to confer a glucocorticoid response was compared with that of the wild-type construct (line 1).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	109	 H4IIE cells were transfected with 10  microg of the reporter plasmid and 5  microg of the pSV2GR expression vector and, where indicated, an additional 5  microg of a vector that expresses either the GAL4DBD or a GAL4 COUP-TF chimeric protein.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The cells were treated overnight with or without 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	111	5  microM dexamethasone (Dex), and CAT activity was measured in the cell extracts.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	112	 A schematic representation of the domains of COUP-TFI is shown at the top of panel B.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Vectors that express the GAL4DBD or a GAL4 COUP-TF1 fusion protein were cotransfected with the mutant reporters as described above to assess whether GAL4 COUP-TF1 can restore a complete glucocorticoid response.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The data represent the mean ( plus or minus  S.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	115	, n = 3-8) of the fold induction (dexamethasone-treated response divided by the untreated response) of CAT activity.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	116	 None of the mutations depicted affects basal expression from the reporter gene.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	117	The E/F Region of COUP-TFI Confers Accessory Activity to the Glucocorticoid Response through Both gAF1 and gAF3-- A number of constructs were made wherein portions of the D and E/F regions of COUP-TFI (see diagram in Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	118	 2B) were fused to the GAL4DBD to map the domains of COUP-TFI that confer accessory activity to the glucocorticoid response.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	119	 These constructs were cotransfected with the pGAL4gAF1, pGAL4gAF3, or pGAL4gAF1 AF3 reporter plasmids, and the ability of the various GAL4 COUP constructs to confer accessory activity to the glucocorticoid response was monitored.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The results of these experiments are summarized in Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In all tests, the expression from these three reporter plasmids was identical.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Deletion of the extreme C terminus (residues 409 to 423) resulted in a complete loss of accessory activity (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	123	 However, deletion of the D, or hinge, region (located between amino acids 156 and 183) did not affect the glucocorticoid response (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Interestingly, all of the other constructs, which represent a variety of deletions of COUP-TF, resulted in complete loss of accessory activity (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Gel shift analyses confirmed the equivalent expression of all of the GAL4 COUP-TFI mutants described in Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	126	 3, as well as the ability of these constructs to bind DNA (data not shown).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Thus, the E/F region of COUP-TFI, located between amino acids 184 and 423, is critical for the accessory factor activity provided through either gAF1 or gAF3.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	128	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	129	   The E/F region of COUP-TF1 is required for a complete induction of the PEPCK gene by glucocorticoids.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Ten  microg of the reporter constructs that contain mutations wherein gAF1 or gAF3 (or both) were replaced with the GAL4 DNA binding site were cotransfected into H4IIE cells with 5  microg of the plasmids that express various GAL4 COUP-TF1 fusion proteins and 5  microg of the pSV2GR expression vector.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The cells were treated overnight with or without 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	132	5  microM dexamethasone (Dex), and CAT activity was measured in the cell extracts.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	133	 A plus represents a complete restoration of the glucocorticoid response conferred by the GAL4 COUP-TF1 construct depicted in line 1.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	134	 A minus indicates that the fusion protein was unable to confer any accessory activity to the glucocorticoid response.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Each transfection was performed at least three times.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The basal rate of transcription from all of the reporter genes was similar in these experiments.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	137	The E/F Region of COUP-TFI Also Confers the Transactivation Activity of COUP-TFI-- The enzyme CYP7A catalyzes the first and rate-controlling step in the pathway that converts cholesterol to bile acids in the liver (9).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	138	 COUP-TF transactivates through the rat CYP7A gene promoter by binding to a sequence TGGTCActcaAGTTCA, which is comprised of two imperfect direct repeat nuclear hormone receptor half-sites separated by 4 base pairs (DR4) (9).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	139	 A construct was made wherein three copies of the CYP7A COUP-TF binding site (positions 74 to 54) were placed upstream of the minimal L-pyruvate kinase promoter fragment, which in turn was positioned 5' from the luciferase reporter gene (CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	140	 This construct was used to test whether COUP-TFI provides direct activation of transcription in the context of this heterologous promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Surprisingly, the full-length pRSV-COUP-TFI construct and the construct that has a deletion of the hinge region (pRSV-COUP-TFID167/183) increased expression from the LPK-LUC vector when cotransfected into HeLa cells (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	142	 This vector does not contain any known COUP-TF binding sites, but there could be weak or cryptic COUP-TFI binding sites, particularly since COUP-TF binds to such a wide range of sequences (7, 11).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Most importantly, the pRSV-COUP-TFI and the pRSV-COUP-TFID167/183 reporter gene vectors potentiated expression (to a much greater degree than the empty vector) of luciferase activity from the CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC reporter construct when cotransfected into HeLa cells.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In contrast, cotransfection with the C-terminal deletion mutant, pRSV-COUP-TFID15, or the internal ligand binding domain deletion mutant, pRSV-COUP-TFID184/281, did not affect expression from this reporter plasmid (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Thus, the E/F region of COUP-TFI, which is required for accessory factor activity in the PEPCK gene promoter (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	146	 3), is also important for the activating function of COUP-TFI through the CYP7A gene hormone response elements.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Furthermore, this activity does not appear to be cell-specific, as equivalent results were obtained in HeLa and H4IIE cells (H4IIE cell data not shown).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	148	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	149	   The E/F region of COUP-TF1 is required for transactivation from the DR4 element of the CYP7A gene promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A reporter construct was made wherein three copies of the DR4 element of the CYP7A gene promoter were ligated upstream of a minimal pyruvate kinase gene promoter-luciferase reporter gene (CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	151	 HeLa cells were cotransfected with 10  microg of the LPK-LUC and CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC reporter constructs with or without 5  microg of vectors that express COUP-TF1 and various mutations of that protein along with 5  microg of the pSVGR1 expression vector and 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	152	1  microg of the pRL-SV40 vector (Renilla luciferase).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Empty expression vectors were also transfected so that the total amount of DNA in each transfection experimental group was identical.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The luciferase activities were measured in cell lysates 18 h after the transfection.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The fold increase over the basal activity of LPK-LUC is indicated above each bar.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The data represent the mean firefly luciferase activity normalized to Renilla luciferase activity ( plus or minus S.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	157	) and represent at least three independent experiments.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	158	The E/F Region of COUP-TFI Potentiates HNF-4 Activity through Its Activity as a Coactivator-- COUP-TFs act as coactivators for HNF-4-mediated transactivation through elements that can bind HNF-4 but not COUP-TFs (17).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	159	 A series of expression plasmids that encode the wild type COUP-TFI or various mutations of COUP-TFI were cotransfected into HeLa cells with GAL4 HNF-4 or GAL4DBD and a reporter gene, (GAL4)5E1b-LUC, which contained five copies of the GAL4 binding site, to define the regions required for the coactivator activity of COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The activity of GAL4 HNF-4 was increased by about 30-fold when cotransfected into HeLa cells with the full-length pRSV-COUP-TFI or the pRSV-COUP-TFID167/183 constructs.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	161	 By contrast, pRSV-COUP-TFD15 and pRSV-COUP-TFID184/281 were no more effective than the GAL4DBD construct (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These observations, considered with the results described above, suggest that the functional domain(s) of COUP-TFI, and required for all three mechanisms of COUP-TF activation, is located between amino acids 184 and 423.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Furthermore, this functional property does not appear to require a specific cellular environment, since qualitatively similar results were observed when H4IIE cells were transfected (data not shown).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	164	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	165	   The E/F region of COUP-TF1 is required for coactivator activity with the orphan receptor, HNF-4.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	166	 HeLa cells were cotransfected with a reporter construct that contains five GAL4 DNA binding sites positioned upstream of the minimal E1b promoter ligated to the luciferase reporter gene, 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	167	5  microg of a construct that expresses either the GAL4DBD or the GAL4DBD ligated to HNF-4, and 5  microg of a construct that expresses COUP-TF or various mutations of that protein and 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	168	1  microg of the pRL-SV40 vector.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Empty expression vectors were also transfected so that the total amount of DNA was constant for each experimental group.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Luciferase activities were measured in the cell lysates 18 h after the transfection.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The data represent the mean of firefly luciferase activity normalized to Renilla luciferase activity  plus or minus S.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	172	 from at least three separate transfections.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	173	The Coactivators GRIP1 and SRC-1 Potentiate Transactivation by COUP-TF1-- Many nuclear hormone receptors activate transcription through an interaction with coactivators (38).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	174	 We tested whether the coactivators SRC-1 or GRIP1, known to interact with a variety of nuclear hormone receptors, could potentiate COUP-TF activation.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Expression plasmids that encode either GRIP1 or SRC-1 were cotransfected into HeLa cells with the reporter plasmid, CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC, with or without a plasmid that encodes full-length COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	176	 6, neither GRIP1 nor SRC-1 potentiated the reporter gene in the absence of expressed COUP-TFI, whereas both GRIP1 and SRC-1 potentiated the transactivation mediated by COUP-TFI expression by 2- to 3-fold.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The effects of the two coactivators were not additive when plasmids that encode them were cotransfected together with the reporter construct (data not shown).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	178	 These results suggest that the coactivators, GRIP1 and SRC-1, coactivate COUP-TFI-mediated transactivation.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This response is also not cell type-specific, as similar results were obtained when H4IIE cells were transfected (data not shown).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	180	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	181	   GRIP1 and SRC-1 potentiate the transactivation activity of COUP-TF1.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	182	 HeLa cells were cotransfected with 10  microg of the CYP7A(DR4)3LPK-LUC reporter construct, 5  microg of vectors that express either GRIP1 or SRC-1 (pGBD424-GRIP/FL and pGAD424SRC-1a, respectively (32, 33)), and 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	183	1  microg of the pRL-SV40 vector.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Luciferase activities were measured in cell lysates 18 h after the transfection.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The data represent the mean firefly luciferase activity normalized to Renilla luciferase activity ( plus or minus S.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	186	COUP-TFI Interacts with GRIP1 and SRC-1 in Vivo-- We used the yeast two-hybrid system to examine whether COUP-TFI interacts with either GRIP1 or SRC-1 and, if so, to define the regions of COUP-TFI required for this interaction.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	187	 -Galactosidase activity was induced when a chimeric fusion protein that encodes the GAL4 activation domain with GRIP1 or SRC-1 was coexpressed with GAL4DBD COUP156/423.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In contrast, the GAL4 activation domain alone did not induce -galactosidase activity (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	189	 These data indicate that the E/F region of COUP-TFI interacts with SRC-1 and GRIP1.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	190	 There was no detectable -galactosidase activity when the same experiment was performed with GAL4 COUP-TFI156/408 (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	191	 7), a result that demonstrates that the C terminal 15 amino acids are required for the protein-protein interaction between COUP-TF and the coactivators.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These results establish a correlation between the activation function of COUP-TF and the ability of COUP-TF to bind to SRC-1 and GRIP1, since the same 15 amino acid region is required for both activities.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	193	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	194	   COUP-TF1 interacts with both GRIP1 and SRC-1 in vivo.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Yeast cells were co-transformed with the plasmids pGBT9-COUP156/423, pGBT9-COUP156/408, pGAD424, pGAD424-GRIP1, and pGAD424-SRC-1, as described under "Materials and Methods.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	196	" Colonies were grown on synthetic dropout plates lacking Leu and Trp and were subjected to a liquid assay for -galactosidase (-Gal) activity.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The data represent the mean units of -galactosidase activity ( plus or minus S.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	198	) from at least three separate determinations.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	199	The C-terminal 15-Amino Acid Segment of COUP-TFI Is Required for Activation but Is Dispensable for Active Repression-- Shibata et al.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	200	 (14) demonstrate that the C terminus of COUP-TFI interacts with the corepressors nuclear receptor corepressor and SMRT, an interaction that is postulated to cause COUP-TF to function as an active repressor in a DNA-dependent manner.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	201	 (13) demonstrate that the C-terminal 15-amino acid segment could be deleted with only a slight reduction in the ability of COUP-TF to actively repress basal transcription through the thymidine kinase minimal promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Thus, with the exception of the C-terminal 15 amino acids, the region required for repression overlaps with the activation region of COUP-TFI that we defined.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	203	 We next tested whether GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423 or GAL4 COUP-TFID15 could repress basal transcription from the (GAL4)5E1b-LUC reporter gene, which contains five GAL4 DNA binding sites positioned upstream of the E1b minimal promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Cotransfection of both GAL4 COUP-TF constructs repressed the basal transcriptional activity provided by the reporter (compare lane 1 with lanes 2 and 5, Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Therefore, the C-terminal 15 amino acids are not required for repression, a result consistent with previous reports (13, 14).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	206	 These data demonstrate that the repression and activation domains of COUP-TF are different, at least by the C-terminal 15 amino acids.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	207	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	208	   The overexpression of coactivators fails to alter the active repression activity of COUP-TF1.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	209	 HeLa cells were cotransfected with 10  microg of the (GAL4)5E1b-LUC reporter construct, 0.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	210	1  microg of the pRL-SV40 vector, 5  microg of the vectors that express either the GAL4 COUP-TFI or GAL4 COUP-TFID15 chimeric proteins, and 5  microg of vectors that express either GRIP1 or SRC-1, as indicated.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Empty expression vectors were cotransfected so that the total DNA concentration was identical for each group.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Eighteen hours after the transfection, luciferase activities were measured in cell lysates.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The data represent the mean firefly luciferase activity normalized to Renilla luciferase activity ( plus or minus S.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	214	Overexpression of Coactivators Does Not Reverse the Repressive Effect of COUP-TFI-- The bifunctional activity of COUP-TF could be explained by a context-dependent equilibrium between corepressors and coactivators.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	215	 By this view, the overexpression of coactivators could allow COUP-TF to switch from a transrepressor to a transactivator (14).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	216	 As a test of this hypothesis, GRIP1 (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	217	 8, lanes 3 and 6) or SRC-1 (Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	218	 8, lanes 4 and 7) were cotransfected into HeLa cells with GAL4 COUP-TFI156/423 and GAL4 COUP-TFID15 and the (GAL4)5E1b-LUC reporter gene.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Overexpression of the coactivators did not override the active repressive effect of COUP-TF.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	220	     DISCUSSION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	221	COUP-TF, extensively studied as a repressor of transcription, also activates transcription by 1) binding to a nuclear receptor DNA response element and directly activating gene expression, as in the CYP7A gene promoter (9), 2) binding to a DNA element and indirectly influencing expression in the context of several other transcription factors, as in the PEPCK gene GRU (26, 27), and 3) by forming a protein-protein interaction with a DNA-bound factor, such as with HNF-4 in the HNF-1 gene promoter (17).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	222	 We show here by analyzing a number of deletion mutations that span the COUP-TFI molecule that a broad region located between amino acids 184-423 is required for these three activation functions.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Furthermore, this same broad region is required for the interaction of COUP-TFI with the coactivators SRC-1 and GRIP1.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	224	 It seems likely that amino acids scattered throughout this segment form the surface(s) required for direct transactivation and for the interaction with other factors.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Although all three functions are equally disrupted by these mutations, we cannot conclude that precisely the same domains are involved in each.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	226	It is perhaps not surprising that the entire E/F domain, also referred to as the ligand binding domain, is required for activation since, in other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily, this domain must be intact for transactivation (39).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In addition to transactivation, this domain provides other functions, including nuclear localization and interactions with various coactivators (40).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Although COUP is an orphan receptor that does not bind a known ligand, the other functions of the ligand binding domain may have been compromised by the different mutations that were made in the E/F domain.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The coactivators GRIP1 and SRC-1 interact with the activation function 2 (AF2) domain near the C terminus of many nuclear receptors (39).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	230	 It is noteworthy that the C-terminal 15 amino acids of COUP-TFI that are required for transactivation are not within the domain of COUP-TFI that is homologous with the AF2 domain.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	231	There is significant overlap in the amino acid segments of COUP TF1 that are involved in the opposing actions of transcription repression and activation.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The C-terminal 15 amino acid segment of the protein, which is dispensable for repression (see Fig.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	233	 13), is essential for the activation functions.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	234	 On the other hand, a deletion of the C-terminal 35 amino acids, which are apparently required for transactivation, also renders COUP-TFI incapable of serving as a repressor.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The corepressors, nuclear receptor corepressor and SMRT, bind to this 35-amino acid segment and confer the repression activity of COUP-TFI (14).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	236	 It is not clear whether other segments of the molecule are also involved in repression.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	237	 By contrast, the E/F domains of COUP-TFII, including the C-terminal 15 amino acids, are required for active repression (15).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	238	 We have not studied COUP-TFII as a transactivator, but the accumulated evidence suggests that some very subtle differences between the two COUP molecules account for quite different biologic responses.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	239	Repression and transactivation are presumably facilitated through protein-protein interactions that occur on the E/F region of COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Given that both activation and repression require overlapping sequences, there must be a mechanism in place that allows different sets of proteins to interact with COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	241	 By this view, either a coactivator complex or a corepressor complex is bound to the activation or repression domains within the ligand binding domain of COUP-TFI.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	242	 It is possible that an equilibrium exists between these two complexes so that an excess of one complex or the other determines the direction of the response.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This explanation seems unlikely for several reasons.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	244	 First, if an equilibrium between coactivator and the corepressor complexes determines the direction of the COUP-TFI response, then at a particular time in a given cell all the COUP-TFI binding sites should mediate either a positive or a negative response.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This is obviously not the case (e.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Furthermore, we show here that overexpression of SRC-1 and GRIP1 fails to switch COUP-TFI from a repressor to an activator in at least one specific instance.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	247	The local intranuclear environment may determine the direction of COUP-TFI activity.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	248	 For example, a given DNA sequence can function as an allosteric effector and influence the activity of a bound transcription factor (41).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	249	 (11) demonstrate that COUP-TFI exists in different conformations when bound to different DNA binding sites.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Hence, a specific DNA sequence may put COUP-TFI into a conformation that exposes surfaces for binding to either coactivator or corepressor complexes.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	251	 This plasticity would allow the COUP-TFI binding site from the CYP7A gene promoter, which was used in the present study, to function as a positive element, whereas another DR4 element, with a slightly different sequence, could serve as a negative element when it binds COUP-TFI (42).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	252	Protein-protein interactions in the context of a specific promoter may also be an important determinant of the direction of COUP-TFI activity.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Whether COUP-TFI acts as a coactivator for HNF-4 or as a transrepressor for nuclear hormone receptors such as retinoic acid receptor is determined by protein-protein interactions, which allow COUP-TFI to associate with either SRC-1/GRIP1 or nuclear receptor corepressor/SMRT.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The interaction of COUP-TFI with HNF-4 is of interest in this regard.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The domain required for the HNF-4 coactivator activity of COUP-TFI is also required for its interaction with SRC-1 and GRIP1 in vivo (Figs.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	256	 It is possible that COUP-TFI interacts with the E region of HNF-4 (amino acids 227-271) and thus provides a surface, either directly or indirectly through coactivators, that associates with the basal transcription machinery (17).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Interestingly, this coactivator activity of COUP-TFI is only seen in DNA sequences that are recognized by HNF-4 but not by COUP-TFI (17).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Thus, COUP-TFI may only serve as a coactivator when HNF-4 exists in a specific conformation induced by DNA binding.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Thus, although GAL4  COUP-TFI acts as a repressor in the context of the (GAL4)5E1bCAT reporter, it acts as a positive accessory factor in the context of the pGAL4gAF1 reporter (compare Figs.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Thus, the action of COUP-TFI is probably determined by the combinatorial effects of the DNA sequence to which it binds and by specific interactions with other proteins, as influenced by specific promoter contexts.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	261	COUP-TF is an important component of the PEPCK gene GRU.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	262	 In addition to glucocorticoids, PEPCK gene transcription is regulated by a number of other hormones.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Each hormone response is mediated by a set of cis-elements termed hormone response units.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Many of the elements within one hormone response unit are also components of another.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	265	 In addition, a number of these pleiotropic elements bind different sets of protein complexes.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	266	 For example, the gAF1 and gAF3 components of the GRU bind COUP-TF (gAF1 can also bind HNF-4) but are also retinoic acid response elements 1 and 2.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	267	 In this case, these two elements bind retinoic acid receptor/retinoid X receptor heterodimers and together comprise the retinoic acid response unit.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	268	 It is curious that, although very different combinations of proteins bind, the same DNA contact points are used (43, 44).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Similarly, the insulin response unit and the cAMP response unit share elements with the GRU, and again the proteins that bind to these elements are specific for the hormone response (45, 46).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	270	 This overlapping structure of the PEPCK promoter is termed a metabolic control domain, and we hypothesize that this structure allows for a complex, integrated response of the PEPCK gene, which encodes a protein essential for gluconeogenesis, to a wide variety of environmental signals (26, 37).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	271	Our current view is that different hormone response signals result in the recruitment of different sets of proteins to multiple elements within the promoter, which presumably tether different combinatorial sets of coactivators to the promoter (37).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	272	 For example, the glucocorticoid response requires the recruitment of the ligand-bound GR and associated accessory factors and coactivators to the promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	273	 The retinoic acid response requires the recruitment of retinoic acid receptor/retinoid X receptor and associated coactivators, presumably SRC-1-like coactivators.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	274	 These processes are, however, exclusive.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	275	 For example, in the case of the retinoic acid response, the GR and its coactivators are not recruited; hence, the set of proteins bound to the PEPCK promoter during a response to retinoic acid is different from the complexes recruited during a glucocorticoid response.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Indeed, the structural requirements of these responses is different, since a 5-base pair insertion between gAF2 and GR1, which effectively rotates the helix by one-half turn, decreases the glucocorticoid response but has no effect on the retinoic acid response (37).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	277	The binding (or absence of binding) of AFs to gAF1, gAF2, and gAF3 has no effect on basal activity (26-28, 37), so it was of great interest to determine whether other proteins interact with COUP-TF, HNF-4, and HNF-3 to confer accessory activity to the glucocorticoid response, particularly since these transcription factors are specifically required to confer accessory factor activity from their particular location within the promoter.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	278	 We have recently demonstrated that HNF-4 binds to both SRC-1 and GRIP1 and that these proteins act as coactivators for HNF-4-mediated transactivation in heterologous promoters and as co-accessory factors for the glucocorticoid response in the PEPCK gene promoter (47).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Here we show that the same coactivators bind to COUP-TFI and potentiate activation by COUP-TF.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	280	 (27) demonstrate that either HNF-4 or COUP-TF can act as an accessory factor through the gAF1 element.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	281	 This observation may now be explained by the observations that both COUP-TF and HNF-4 utilize the same coactivators to promote their transactivation activities (this study and Ref.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	282	In summary, we have characterized the domain required for COUP-TF-mediated transcriptional activation in three different systems and have determined that SRC-1 and GRIP1 bind to this domain and serve as coactivators.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	283	 This takes us a step closer to understanding how the complex PEPCK gene GRU is assembled and how it functions.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	284	We thank Cathy Caldwell for her excellent technical assistance, Deborah Caplenor Brown for preparation of the manuscript, and Kazuya Yamada for his invaluable advice.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	285	* This work was supported by National Institutes of Health Grant DK 35107 and the Vanderbilt Diabetes Research and Training Center Grant DK 20593).
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	286	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	289	To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	290	: 615-322-7004; Fax: 615-322-7236; E-mail: daryl.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	291	2 We originally designated the accessory factor elements AF1, AF2, and AF3 in order of their discovery.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	292	 The subsequent definition of transactivation domains of the nuclear receptor subfamily as AF1 and AF2 (48) has created a potentially confusing situation.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	293	 To avoid having to discuss the interaction of the AF1 (or AF2) transcription domain of the glucocorticoid receptor with the AF1 element (or with the AF2 and AF3 elements) in the GRU, we now designate these elements as gAF1 to denote the glucocorticoid accessory factor 1 element, etc.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	294	The abbreviations used are: COUP-TF, chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor; PEPCK, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase; CYP7A, cholesterol 7-hydroxylase; HNF, hepatocyte nuclear factor; SMRT, silencing mediator for retinoic acid and thyroid hormone receptor; GRU, glucocorticoid response unit; AF, accessory factor; gAF1, gAF2, and gAF3, glucocorticoid AF binding sites; GR, glucocorticoid receptor; GR1 and GR2, GR binding sites; GRIP1, GR-interacting protein-1; SRC-1, steroid receptor coactivator-1; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	295	    REFERENCES TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION MATERIALS AND METHODS RESULTS DISCUSSION REFERENCES 1.

0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	316	 (1989) Nature 338, 39-44[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 32.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	317	 93, 4948-4952[Abstract/Free Full Text] 33.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	318	 12, 302-313[Abstract/Free Full Text] 35.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	319	 12, 1487-1498[Abstract/Free Full Text] 38.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	320	 9, 222-232[CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] 39.
0.49796134.10652338.html.plaintext.txt	321	 12, 3343-3356[Abstract/Free Full Text] 40.
