0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Corepressor and Chicken Ovalbumin Upstream Promoter Transcriptional Factor Proteins Modulate Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor-2/Retinoid X Receptor -Activated Transcription from the Murine Lipoprotein Lipase Promoter1 Claudius E.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Robinson, Xiying Wu2, Zafar Nawaz, Sergio A.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	2	Zoology Department, University of Oklahoma (C.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	3	), Norman, Oklahoma 73019; the Departments of Surgery (X.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	4	), University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma 73190; and the Department of Cell Biology, Baylor College of Medicine (Z.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	5	Address all correspondence and requests for reprints to: Jeffrey M.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	6	, Department of Surgery, University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, P.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Box 26901, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma 73190.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	8	 E-mail: jeffrey-gimble{at}ouhsc.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	9	   Abstract Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Complex physiological stimuli differentially regulate the tissue-specific transcription of the lipoprotein lipase (LPL) gene.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A conserved DNA recognition element (-171 to -149 bp) within the promoter functions as a transcriptional enhancer when bound by the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-2 (PPAR2)/retinoid X receptor (RXR) heterodimer, but serves as a transcriptional silencer in the presence of unidentified double and single stranded DNA-binding proteins.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	11	 To address this apparent paradox, the current study examined the effect of two classes of candidate comodulatory proteins, COUP-TF (chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcriptional factor) and the corepressor SMRT (silencing mediator of retinoic acid receptor and thyroid receptor).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The expression of COUP-TF was detected by Western and Northern blots in a preadipocyte 3T3-L1 cell model during periods corresponding to increased LPL transcription.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Cotransfection of COUP-TF expression constructs in the renal epithelial 293T cell line significantly increased transcription from the LPL promoter in synergy with PPAR2/RXR heterodimers.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein specifically bound the LPL PPAR recognition element in electromobility shift assays and interacted directly with the ligand-binding domain of PPAR in pull-down experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In contrast, cotransfection of SMRT repressed PPAR2/RXR-mediated LPL transcription in the absence or presence of COUP-TFII (ARP-1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The interaction between PPAR2 and SMRT localized to the receptor-interactive domain 2 (amino acids 1260 to 1495) of the SMRT protein based on cotransfection and pull-down assays.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	17	 These in vitro data indicate that COUP-TF proteins and SMRT modulate PPAR-mediated LPL transcription in the 293T cell line.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	18	   Introduction Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   LIPOPROTEIN lipase (LPL; EC 3.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	19	34) is the enzyme that hydrolyzes triglycerides into FFA (1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	20	 It is responsible for the clearance of chylomicrons from the circulation, and its dysregulation contributes to cardiovascular disease (1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	21	 A multitude of hormonal and cytokine cues account for the complex physiological expression of LPL in mammary epithelial cells, macrophages, hepatocytes, and adipocytes (1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Nuclear hormone receptor ligands such as thiazolidinediones [peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs)] or hydrocortisone (glucocorticoid receptor) induce LPL transcription, whereas proinflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-, are inhibitory (1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These actions are mediated through specific DNA recognition elements located within the LPL promoter.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Recent studies have determined that the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor 2 (PPAR2)/retinoid X receptor (RXR) heterodimer binds to the murine and human LPL promoters between -171 to -149 bp relative to the transcriptional start site (2, 3); this identical sequence is conserved in the rat LPL promoter (4).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In cotransfection analyses performed in the 293T cell line, PPAR2/RXR binding to the murine LPL promoter increased reporter gene expression by 13-fold in the absence of exogenous ligand, with a further 2.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	26	5-fold induction upon the addition of thiazolidinediones, demonstrating that the PPAR recognition element (PPRE) acts as an enhancer (3).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	27	 However, independent transfection studies performed in HeLa cells had associated the identical sequence element (-169 to -151 bp) in the human LPL promoter with a silencer function (5).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This repressor activity was attributed to unknown double and single stranded DNA-binding proteins (5).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	29	Two classes of proteins could account for this paradoxical association of a single PPRE with both enhancer and silencer activities.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	30	 One class is the chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factor (COUP-TF) family, which includes COUP-TFI or erbA-related protein-3 (EAR3), COUP-TFII or apolipoprotein AI regulatory protein-1 (ARP-1), and EAR2 (6, 7, 8).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The COUP-TF proteins bind to nuclear receptor recognition elements separated by a single nucleotide (DR1), similar to those recognized by PPAR proteins (7, 9).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The COUP-TF proteins have been associated with both repression (reviewed in Ref.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	33	 8) and activation (8, 10, 11, 12, 13) of promoters regulated by nuclear hormone receptors.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The COUP-TF proteins are expressed in a number of tissues, including preadipocytes (8, 14).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	35	A second class of candidate proteins is the recently described corepressors (15, 16).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	36	 These proteins interact directly with nuclear hormone receptors in the absence of ligand to repress transcriptional activation from promoters regulated by nuclear hormone receptors (15, 16).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The messenger RNAs (mRNAs) of the silencing mediator of retinoic acid and thyroid hormone receptor (SMRT) and the nuclear corepressor (N-CoR) are expressed ubiquitously in all tissues examined as well as in the 293, HeLa, and 3T3 cell lines (17).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Although the PPAR2/RXR heterodimer has been found to bind strongly to SMRT and N-CoR in solution, their interactions on DNA have been reported as weak (SMRT) or nonexistent (N-CoR) (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In cotransfection analyses performed in 293T cells, SMRT exhibited less than 2-fold repression of the acyl-coenzyme A oxidase PPRE in the presence of PPAR, whereas N-CoR had no significant effect (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	40	 This led to the conclusion that weak binding between PPAR and corepressors on DNA resulted in an inability of the protein complex to repress transcription from the acyl-coenzyme A oxidase PPRE; however, "the ability of PPAR to interact with corepressor in solution raised the possibility that PPAR could repress transcription on other sites or in other cell types" (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	41	This study set out to investigate the modulatory effects of COUP-TF family members and SMRT on PPAR2/RXR-mediated transcriptional activation of the murine LPL promoter.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The data demonstrate that COUP-TF proteins potentiated PPAR2/RXR-mediated transcriptional activation in 293T cells.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In contrast, SMRT repressed PPAR2/RXR-mediated transcription from the LPL promoter, independent of the presence of COUP-TFII (ARP-1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	44	   Materials and Methods Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Materials All reagents were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Louis, MO) or Fisher Scientific International, Inc.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	46	 (Dallas, TX) unless noted otherwise.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	47	Plasmids Constructs containing varying segments of the wild-type murine LPL promoter linked to the luciferase reporter gene were prepared in the p19Luc vector (provided by D.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Helinski, University of California-San Diego, La Jolla, CA) (19) as previously described (3).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The pEF-BOS plasmid (20) was used to prepare eukaryotic expression vectors containing the following complementary DNAs (cDNAs): murine PPAR2 (21), murine RXR (22) (provided by R.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Evans, The Salk Institute, La Jolla, CA), human COUP-TFII (ARP-1) (23), human COUP-TFI (EAR-3), and human EAR-2 (24) (all human cDNAs were provided by J.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Ladias, Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, MA).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The pABgal vector was used to prepare eukarytoic expression constructs containing cDNAs encoding the following amino acids of the human SMRT protein: full-length construct (1 to 1495), 29 to 564, 565-1289, and 565-1495.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The pT7 vector was used to prepare bacterial expression constructs encoding the following amino acids of the human SMRT protein: full-length construct (1 to 1495), 29 to 564, 565-1289, 565-1495, and 1192 to 1495 (25).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The pBluescript SKII vector was used to prepare a human COUP-TFII (ARP-1) (26) bacterial expression construct; the full-length cDNA was inserted into the EcoRI site of the polylinker under the T7 promoter.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The bacterial expression vector pGEX2T containing the glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-PPAR1 ligand-binding domain fusion protein (amino acids 174 to 475; provided by S.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Kliewer, Glaxo/Wellcome, Research Triangle Park, NC) (21) was used to prepare a PPAR ligand-binding domain-GST fusion protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	57	Transient transfections The human embryonic kidney cell line 293T (27) (provided by K.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Oritani, Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation, Oklahoma City, OK), was maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS (HyClone Laboratories, Inc.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	59	, Logan, UT), 100 U/ml penicillin, and 100  microg/ml streptomycin.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	60	 A total of 8 x 104 cells in a 2-ml volume were plated in 35-mm dishes 18 h before transfection.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	61	 A calcium phosphate/DNA coprecipitate was prepared by mixing 83  microl 1 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	62	0) containing up to 12  microg DNA with 12.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	63	5  microl 2 x HEPES-buffered saline (280 mM NaCl, 10 mM KCl, 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	64	5 mM Na2PO4, 12 mM dextrose, and 50 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	65	 After 25 min, the entire volume was added to the cells in fresh medium.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After overnight incubation, the cell medium was replaced.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Cells were harvested 48 h after transfection in a 100- microl volume of 25 mM glycylglycine, 15 mM MgSO4, 1 mM dithiothreitol (DTT), and 1% Triton X-100.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Protein concentrations were determined using the bicinchonic acid method (Pierce Chemical Co.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Luciferase assays were performed over a 20-sec reaction period using aliquots of 87.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	70	5  microg protein in a 125- microl volume containing 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Assays were performed using a Monolight 2010 Luminometer (Analytical Luminescence Laboratory, San Diego, CA).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	72	 All transfection analyses were performed a minimum of three times and were analyzed by one-way ANOVA and Student-Newman-Keuls multiple comparison test.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Minimal criteria for significance were determined by P 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	74	Adipocyte differentiation and tissue culture The murine preadipocyte cell line 3T3-L1 was plated in 2 ml DMEM supplemented with 10% bovine serum, 100 U/ml penicillin, and 100  microg/ml streptomycin at a density of 2.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	75	 After 4 to 7 days, when the cells had reached confluence, the medium was replaced with fresh medium containing 10% FBS supplemented with 1  microM dexamethasone, 500  microM methylisobutylxanthine, and 5  microg/ml insulin.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Cells were maintained in this induction medium for 3 to 4 days before returning to the unsupplemented medium.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Individual cultures were harvested at varying time intervals (0 to 8 days) for RNA (in 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	78	5 ml 4 M guanidine isothiocyanate solution) or for immunoblots [in 100  microl 50 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	79	25% deoxycholate, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride, 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	80	1 mM sodium molybdate, and 1  microg/ml leupeptin and aprotinin].
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	81	Electromobility shift assays The DNA electromobility shift assays were performed using a 67-bp HindIII/SspI DNA fragment spanning bp -181 to -113 of the murine LPL promoter (3).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	82	 DNA labeling was performed using T4 polynucleotide kinase and [-32P]deoxy-ATP (ICN, Irvine, CA).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Probes were labeled to a specific activity of 105-106 cpm/pmol.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Reactions were conducted in a 30- microl volume containing 10 mM Tris (pH 8.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	85	05% Nonidet P-40, 1 mM DTT, 6% glycerol, 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	86	5 ng recombinant COUP-TFII (ARP-1; provided by R.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Kelly, Washington University, St.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Louis, MO), and 2 to 10 x 105 cpm probe for a 20-min period at room temperature.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Reactions were performed in the absence or presence of competitor DNA fragments spanning bp -181 to +187 of the LPL promoter.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	90	 In addition to the wild-type sequence, the following mutations (underlined) in the PPAR recognition element were used: DNA sequence mutation sites: wild type (-181 bp), gctttccttcctgccctttccccttcttctcgctgg; mutant A (-181 bp), gctttccttaaaaaaatttccccttcttctcgctgg (-172 to -166 bp); mutant B (-181 bp), gctttccttcctgaaaaaaacccttcttctcgctgg (-168 to -162 bp); mutant C (-181 bp), gctttccttcctgccctaaaaaaatcttctcgctgg (-164 to -158 bp); mutant D (-181 bp), gctttccttcctgccctttccaaaaaaactcgctgg (-160 to -154 bp); and mutant E (-181 bp), gctttccttcctgccctttccccttaaaaaaactgg (-156 to -150 bp).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Samples were separated on a 5% acrylamide/bis-acrylamide (24:1) gel by electrophoresis at 100 V for 3 h.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Gels were dried at 80 C for 90 min and exposed to Kodak XAR film (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	93	, Rochester, NY) for 18 h without an intensifying screen.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	94	In vitro transcription/translation In vitro transcription was performed using the T7 RNA polymerase and circular plasmids containing varying segments of the human SMRT cDNA in the pT7 vector or containing the full-length coding region of the human COUP-TFII (ARP-1) cDNA in the pBluescript SKII vector.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In vitro translation was performed with rabbit reticulocyte lysates (Promega Corp.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Protein products were radiolabeled with [35S]methionine (ICN).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Control reactions were performed with a luciferase cDNA provided by the manufacturer, which yielded a 62-kDa product.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	98	In vitro pull-down assays The pGEX2T vectors containing either no insert or the PPAR1 cDNA encoding amino acids 174 to 475 were transformed into the bacterial strain BL21 (DE3) pLysS, cultured at 20 to 24 C to an OD592 of 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	99	8, induced with a final concentration of 1 mM isopropyl ss-D-thiogalactopyranoside, pelleted by centrifugation at 4 C, and stored at -70 C.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Aliquots from 200 ml bacterial culture were suspended in 20 ml lysis buffer [50 mM Tris (pH 8.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	101	0), 250 mM KCl, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonylfluoride, and 1% Triton X-100], frozen and thawed three times, and centrifuged.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Expression of the GST fusion proteins was confirmed by electrophoresis of the lysates on SDS-PAGE gels followed by either Coomassie staining or immunoblotting with polyclonal antibodies directed against either GST or the C-terminal peptide of PPAR (28).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The cleared lysate was mixed with 300  microl prewashed glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (Pharmacia Biotech, Alameda, CA) and rocked overnight at 4 C.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	104	4 ml washing buffer [60 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris (pH 8.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	105	0), 6 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM EDTA, 8% glycerol, and 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	106	05% Nonidet P-40], 200- microl aliquots of beads were mixed with 10- microl volumes of in vitro transcribed and translated proteins and incubated overnight at 4 C.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The samples were washed five times in NENT buffer [500 mM NaCl, 20 mM Tris (pH 8.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	108	0), 6 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 1 mM EDTA, 8% glycerol, and 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	109	5% Nonidet P-40], suspended in 20  microl SDS loading buffer, heated to 95 C for 5 min, and resolved on a 12% acrylamide SDS-PAGE gel.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Control lanes contained 10% of the input labeled protein used for binding.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The gel was fixed, treated with EN3HANCE (New England Nuclear-DuPont, Boston, MA), dried at 60 C, and exposed to autoradiographic film for 1 to 7 days with an enhancer screen.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	112	Northern and Western blots Total RNA harvested from 3T3-L1 cells on days 0 to 6 was prepared as previously described (28, 29).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Northern blots were performed with aliquots of 10  microg total RNA electrophoresed on 1% agarose-0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	114	66% formaldehyde gels, transferred to ZetaProbe membranes (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	115	, Richmond, CA), and hybridized overnight at 55 C in 500 mM sodium phosphate, pH 7.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	116	4, and 7% SDS (30) with random primed radiolabeled probes for murine LPL, murine COUP-TFII, or actin (31).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Blots were washed in 40 mM sodium phosphate and 1% SDS at a maximum stringency of 55 C and exposed for 1 day with an enhancer screen at -70 C.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Western blots were performed with aliquots of 50  microg 3T3-L1 protein lysates electrophoresed on 10% acrylamide SDS-PAGE gels, transferred to nitrocellulose paper, blocked with 5% nonfat dry milk in PBS-0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	119	1% Tween (PBST), and immunoblotted overnight at 4 C with a primary rabbit antibody directed against COUP-TF (32) or C/EBP (SC061, Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	120	, Santa Cruz, CA) in 1% nonfat dry milk-PBST.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The blots were rinsed in PBST, incubated with goat antirabbit antibody coupled to horseradish peroxidase (1:10,000 dilution in PBST with 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	122	25% nonfat dry milk; Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	123	), and the protein immunostaining was detected by chemiluminescence (ECL kit, Amersham, Arlington Heights, IL).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	124	   Results Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   Effect of adipogenic agonists on expression of COUP-TFII (ARP-1) in 3T3-L1 preadipocytes Initial studies were performed to document the expression of COUP-TFII (ARP-1) mRNA and protein in response to agents known to induce LPL transcription.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Northern blot analysis demonstrated that the preadipocyte cell line 3T3-L1 rapidly increased LPL transcription after exposure to the adipogenic agonists dexamethasone, insulin, and methylisobutylxanthine (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The confluent 3T3-L1 cells expressed COUP-TFII mRNA throughout the induction period; signal remained present from days 0 to 8 (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Actin served as a control for relative RNA loading between lanes.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Western blot analysis performed with protein extracts from similarly treated cells detected COUP-TF protein throughout the induction period (0 to 48 h).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The protein remained at detectable levels for up to 96 h after induction.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	130	 This coincided with the peak expression of the late appearing adipogenic transcription factor, C/EBP (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	131	 These studies document the presence of a COUP-TF protein at times corresponding to induction of the LPL transcript in a preadipocyte cell model (33, 34).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	132	View larger version (26K):    Figure 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Evidence of COUP-TF mRNA and protein expression in preadipocyte and adipocyte 3T3-L1 cells.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	134	 The 3T3-L1 cells were induced with dexamethasone, insulin, and methylisobutylxanthine for periods of 0 to 8 days.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Cells were harvested at the indicated times for total RNA, examined as 10- microg aliquots per lane on Northern blots (A), and, for protein, examined on Western immunoblots as 50- microg aliquots per lane (B).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Equivalent Northern blots were hybridized with probes for LPL, COUP-TFII, and actin.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Western blots were examined with polyclonal antibodies directed against COUP-TF or C/EBP.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	138	  Members of the COUP-TF family activate transcription from the murine LPL promoter in synergy with PPAR2/RXR In the next series of experiments, cotransfections were designed to determine the effects of COUP-TFI (EAR3), COUP-TFII (ARP-1), and EAR2 on murine LPL transcription in the absence or presence of PPAR2/RXR (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Transfections were performed in 293T cells with the individual nuclear hormone receptor expression constructs alone or in varied combinations.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The reporter construct contained -1824 to +187 bp of the LPL promoter linked to luciferase.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The COUP-TF family members alone increased expression from the LPL promoter by less than an order of magnitude; the most potent was COUP-TFII (ARP-1; 9.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	142	9-fold activation by PPAR2 and RXR together.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Overexpression of any COUP-TF member with either the PPAR2 or RXR expression construct alone did not increase transcription further.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	144	 However, simultaneous expression of either COUP-TFII (ARP-1) or COUP-TFI (EAR3) with PPAR2 and RXR increased luciferase activity by 101- and 45-fold relative to the baseline.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Control experiments substituting vitamin D3 expression constructs for COUP-TF did not increase PPAR2/RXR-mediated activation of the LPL promoter (n = 2; data not shown).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The actions of COUP-TFII (ARP-1) were concentration dependent (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Transcription rose in a dose-dependent manner as the ratio of the COUP-TFII (ARP-1) expression plasmid was increased relative to the PPAR2 and RXR plasmids.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	148	View larger version (26K):    Figure 2.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Activation of the LPL gene promoter by COUP-TF proteins in conjunction with PPAR2 and RXR.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Cultures of 293T cells were transfected with 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	151	1  microg of the -1824 to +187 bp LPL promoter/luciferase reporter construct by calcium phosphate coprecipitation in the presence of 10% FBS.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Cells were additionally transfected with 2  microg each of pEF-BOS expression vectors containing PPAR2, RXR, COUP-TFII (ARP-1), COUP-TFI (EAR3), and/or EAR2.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	153	 All plates were transfected with a total of 12  microg DNA; the empty pEF-BOS vector was used to make up the difference in the total amount when necessary.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Fold activation is calculated relative to the luciferase baseline activity in the absence of nuclear hormone receptor expression constructs, defined as 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Data are normalized relative to a constant protein concentration per assay (87.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	156	5  microg) and represent the mean  plus or minus  SE of three experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	157	  View larger version (25K):    Figure 3.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Dose-dependent activation of the LPL promoter by COUP-TFII (ARP-1) in the presence of PPAR2 and RXR.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Individual plates of 293T cells were cotransfected with 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	160	1  microg of the -1824 to +187 bp LPL promoter/luciferase reporter construct, 2  microg each of the PPAR2 and RXR expression constructs, and increasing concentrations (0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	161	2 to 8  microg) of the COUP-TFII (ARP-1) expression construct.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The relative ratio of the COUP-TFII to PPAR2 plasmid concentrations is indicated on the x-axis.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The total concentration of DNA was held constant by addition of the appropriate amount of the empty pEF-BOS vector.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Fold activation is calculated relative to the luciferase baseline in the absence of nuclear hormone receptor expression constructs, defined as 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Data are normalized relative to a constant protein concentration per assay (87.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	166	5  microg) and represent the mean  plus or minus  SE of three experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	167	  Additional investigations examined the interaction of COUP-TFII (ARP-1) with the PPRE in the presence of PPAR2 and RXR.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Cotransfection analyses of LPL promoter deletion constructs with the combination of PPAR2, RXR, and COUP-TFII (ARP-1; Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	169	 4A) indicated that deletions between bp -181 to -101 significantly reduced the fold activation.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Levels decreased by a factor of more than 5, comparable to those observed with the same deletion constructs cotransfected with the PPAR2/RXR heterodimer alone (3).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	171	 These data suggested that the PPRE (localized to bp -171 to -149) was critical for COUP-TFII (ARP-1) activation.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Recombinant COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein directly bound to the LPL promoter PPRE in electromobility shift assays, giving rise to two mobility-shifted bands, A and B (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Competition analyses were performed with a panel of equivalent PCR-generated DNA fragments (bp -181 to +187).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	174	 These included a wild-type control and five mutants (A to E) spanning the PPRE from a 5' (mutant A) to 3' (mutant E) direction.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The wild-type control specifically competed for both complexes A and B.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In contrast, those DNA fragments containing mutations within the 14 bp at the 5'-end of the PPRE (mutants A to C) did not bind the COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Biochemical studies were performed to determine whether the PPAR and COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein interacted directly.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In vitro pull-down assays detected binding between in vitro transcribed and translated COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein and the ligand-binding domain of PPAR fused to the GST protein (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Control studies did not detect binding of the COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein with the GST protein alone.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Together, these data indicate that COUP-TFII (ARP-1) can interact with both the PPRE and the ligand-binding domain of the PPAR protein itself.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	181	View larger version (30K):    Figure 4.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Evidence for COUP-TFII (ARP-1) interactions with the LPL PPRE and PPAR2.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	183	 A, Activation analysis of LPL promoter deletion constructs by the COUP-TFII (ARP-1) expression construct.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The 293T cells were transfected with aliquots of 0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	185	1  microg LPL promoter/luciferase reporter constructs containing -1824, -564, -181, or -101 bp of the 5'-flanking region and all extending to +187 bp.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cells were cotransfected with 6  microg of the empty pEF-BOS vector or 2  microg each of the PPAR2, RXR, and COUP-TFII (ARP-1) expression constructs.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Fold activation is calculated relative to the luciferase baseline in the absence of nuclear hormone receptor expression constructs, defined as 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Results are normalized to protein concentration (which were maintained at 87.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	189	5  microg per reaction) and represent the mean  plus or minus  SE of three experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	190	 B, Effect of mutations in the PPAR2 recognition element on COUP-TFII (ARP-1) binding.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Electromobility shift assays were conducted using a 67-bp wild-type LPL promoter probe spanning bp -181 to -113.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Competition experiments were performed using PCR-generated DNA fragments of equivalent size (-181 to +187 bp) containing either the wild-type sequence or individual, overlapping 7-bp mutations (A to E) spanning the region from -172 to -150 bp, as listed inMaterials and Methods.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Reactions were conducted with recombinant COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Electromobility-shifted complexes are labeled A and B.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	195	 C, Evidence for a direct interaction between COUP-TFII (ARP-1) and the PPAR ligand-binding domain.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In vitro pull-down assays were conducted using [35S]methionine-labeled in vitro transcribed/translated COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein and bacterially expressed protein from GST vectors without insert or containing the PPAR1 ligand-binding domain (amino acids 175 to 475).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Reaction products separated on a 12% SDS-PAGE gel contain 10% of the input COUP-TFII (ARP-1) protein (I), the material bound to the control GST protein (G), and the material bound to the GST-PPAR LBD fusion protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Protein size markers are indicated.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Data are representative of two experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	200	  SMRT represses PPAR2/RXR activation of transcription from the murine LPL promoter Previous cotransfection studies by others in 293T cells had demonstrated that the corepressor SMRT bound to the PPAR2/RXR heterodimer in solution but had a minimal repressive effect on the acyl-coenzyme A oxidase PPRE (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	201	 To determine the effect of SMRT on transcription from the murine LPL promoter, the identical cell line was cotransfected with increasing amounts of the SMRT expression construct in the absence (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	202	 As the ratio of full-length SMRT expression construct was increased relative to that of the PPAR2 and RXR plasmids, the fold activation was reduced to the baseline levels observed in the absence of the PPAR2/RXR heterodimer (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Likewise, as the ratio of full-length SMRT expression plasmid increased relative to that of the COUP-TFII (ARP1), PPAR2, and RXR plasmids, the fold activation progressively decreased (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Thus, SMRT repressed transcription from the LPL PPRE independent of the presence of COUP-TFII (ARP-1).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	205	View larger version (29K):    Figure 5.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Effect of cotransfected SMRT on LPL promoter function.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Cotransfections using the 293T cells were performed using the -1824 to +187 bp LPL promoter/luciferase construct (0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	208	 All cells were transfected with 2  microg each of PPAR2 and RXR expression vectors, either alone (A) or together with 2  microg of the COUP-TFII (ARP-1) expression vector (B).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Cells were cotransfected with varied concentrations of the full-length SMRT expression construct (0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The relative ratio of the SMRT to PPAR2 (A) or of SMRT to COUP-TFII (B) plasmid concentrations is indicated along the x-axis.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The total amount of DNA transfected was held constant by addition of the empty pEF-BOS vector.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Fold activation is calculated relative to the luciferase baseline in the absence of nuclear hormone receptor expression constructs, defined as 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Results are normalized to protein concentration (which were maintained at 87.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	214	5  microg per reaction) and represent the mean  plus or minus  SE of three experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	215	  To determine the domains of SMRT critical for repression of the LPL PPRE, cotransfection experiments were performed with several SMRT deletion mutants and the wild-type PPAR2 and RXR (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	216	 In the absence of SMRT, the PPAR2/RXR expression constructs again induced luciferase activity by an order of magnitude relative to baseline.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Constructs containing either amino acids 29 to 564 or 565-1289 of SMRT reduced this fold activation by 40 to 60%.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	218	 In contrast, those constructs containing the carboxyl-terminus of the SMRT protein (amino acids 565-1495 or 1 to 1495) completely abolished this activation.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Further studies employed in vitro pull-down assays to determine whether a direct interaction existed between SMRT and PPAR (Fig.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Strong interactions (indicated by arrows A, B, and C) were observed between the ligand-binding domain of the PPAR/GST fusion protein and all in vitro transcribed and translated proteins containing amino acids 1289 to 1495 of SMRT.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Radiolabeled proteins lacking the carboxyl-terminal domain of SMRT did not bind to the PPAR-GST fusion protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	222	View larger version (42K):    Figure 6.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Localization of SMRT domain interacting with PPAR2.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	224	 A, Cotransfection analysis in 293T cells was performed with the empty pABgal expression vector (8  microg/plate) or constructs encoding the full-length (amino acids 1 to 1495) and deleted versions (amino acids 29 to 564, 565-1289, and 565-1495) of the SMRT protein together with the -1824 to +187 LPL promoter luciferase construct (0.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	225	1  microg/plate) and the PPAR2 and RXR expression constructs (2  microg/plate).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Fold activation is calculated relative to the luciferase baseline in the absence of nuclear hormone receptor expression constructs, defined as 1.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Results are normalized to protein concentration (which were maintained at 87.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	228	5  microg per reaction) and represent the mean  plus or minus  SE of three experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	229	 B, GST pull-down experiments using varied deletions of the SMRT protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Lanes on a 12% SDS-PAGE gel contained 20% of the input 35S-labeled SMRT proteins (amino acids 1 to 1495, 29 to 564, 565-1289, 565-1495, and 1192 to 1495; I), the labeled protein pulled down by the GST protein-coupled beads (G), and the GST-PPAR2 ligand-binding domain-coupled beads (P).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Protein size markers are indicated.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Data are representative of two experiments.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Arrows (labeled A, B, and C) indicate the association of the following 35S-labeled SMRT proteins with the GST protein-coupled beads in pull-down assays (lane P): A, 1 to 1495; B, 565-1495; and C, 1192 to 1495.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	234	     Discussion Top Abstract Introduction Materials and Methods Results Discussion References   PPAR interactions with COUP-TF proteins The COUP-TF proteins increased expression from the LPL promoter synergistically with PPAR2/RXR in 293T cells, and this was dependent on the presence of an intact PPRE.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	235	 This contrasts with many studies that have reported antagonistic actions between COUP-TF and PPAR when compared on a common promoter DNA recognition element.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	236	 In the majority of cases, transcription was increased by PPAR proteins and decreased by COUP-TF proteins; examples include the promoters for apolipoprotein AI (36), medium chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (37, 38), hydratase dehydrogenase (39, 40), malic enzyme (41, 42), and mitochondrial hydroxy-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A synthase (43).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	237	 In contrast, the transferrin promoter is the sole example where expression was decreased by PPAR proteins but increased by COUP-TF proteins (13).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Nevertheless, it is likely that the promoters of other hepatic proteins repressed by peroxisome proliferator compounds will exhibit this same profile; candidates include the transthyretin and 2u-macroglobulin gene promoters (44).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	239	However, the actions of PPAR and COUP-TF proteins are not necessarily antagonistic.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	240	 There are examples where both PPAR and COUP-TF actions increase transcription from a common DNA recognition element; these include the human immunodeficiency virus long terminal repeat (10) and the phosphoenolpyruvate decarboxylase promoter (11, 12, 45).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The murine LPL promoter exhibits this same pattern of regulation in the 293T cell line.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	242	This conflicting pattern of both positive and negative interactions with COUP-TF is not unique to PPAR proteins and PPREs.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Similar findings with COUP-TF have been reported for the estrogen receptor and estrogen receptor recognition elements (EREs).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In a study examining a consensus ERE, COUP-TF proteins were observed to bind to the DNA element and to repress estrogen ligand activation of a reporter gene (46).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In contrast, in studies of the intact estrogen receptor gene promoter containing an ERE, COUP-TF bound to the ERE and increased transcription in synergy with the estrogen receptor (47).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Independent of the mechanism accounting for these disparate interactions between COUP-TF and nuclear hormone receptors, the current findings support the conclusion that COUP-TF proteins can positively modulate LPL promoter transcription through the PPAR recognition element in 293T cells.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	247	PPAR2 interactions with SMRT The presence of SMRT repressed PPAR2/RXR-mediated transcription from the LPL promoter 9-fold.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	248	 This contrasts with the reported less than 2-fold repression by SMRT of transcription from the isolated acyl-coenyzme A oxidase PPRE (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	249	 As both studies employed 293T cells, this discrepancy cannot be attributed to differences in the cell model (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Instead, the DNA site itself is a more likely explanation (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The compositions of the DNA recognition element and its 5'-flanking sequences are known to influence PPAR protein binding affinity and specificity (9, 48, 49, 50).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	252	 As has been postulated previously (18), alterations in the DNA sequence could result in conformational changes in the DNA recognition element/PPAR protein complex.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	253	 This could lead to subsequent allosteric changes in the accessibility of the bound PPAR protein s corepressor-interactive domain to the SMRT protein.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Thus, the SMRT protein may regulate PPREs differentially depending on their DNA compositions and flanking sequences.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The relative stoichiometry of the SMRT protein relative to the nuclear hormone receptor proteins PPAR, RXR and COUP-TF may further contribute to the tissue-specific regulation of LPL.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Data supporting a role for SMRT as a PPAR corepressor comes from recent microinjection experiments using anti-SMRT and anti-N-CoR antibodies (51).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	257	 In cells transfected with a PPRE-directed reporter gene, injection of an anti-SMRT antibody (but not an anti-N-CoR antibody) relieved PPAR-mediated repression induced by stimulation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade (51).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	258	The current results mapping the PPAR2-interactive domain of SMRT to between amino acids 1289 to 1495 confirm and extend earlier studies (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	259	 This region corresponds to one of the two distinct receptor-interactive domains (RID) delineated in the SMRT carboxyl-terminal (RID2, amino acids 1260 to 1495) (52).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	260	 The PPAR2-interactive domain of SMRT is similar to that used by the thyroid receptor (52), but differs from those used by the retinoic acid receptor (RID1, corresponding to amino acids 1086 to 1291) (52) and by COUP-TF1 (the amino-terminal portion of SMRT) (25).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	261	In summary, this work demonstrates that COUP-TFII (ARP-1) and SMRT can modulate transcription from the LPL promoter in the presence of PPAR2 and RXR in an in vitro system.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	262	 These observations are consistent with current models suggesting that the relative stochiometry of nuclear receptors and their corepressors regulates promoter function and accounts for cell-specific gene expression (18).
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Both COUP-TF and SMRT proteins may play an in vivo role in the complex physiological regulation of LPL.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	264	 However, the current studies were limited to a single cell line.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The 293T cells constitutively express the simian virus 40 T antigen (27), and the possibility exists that this has contributed to the current findings.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Future studies will extend and test these observations in primary adipose tissues and other sites of LPL expression.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	267	   Acknowledgments   The authors thank the following individuals: D.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Webb for critical comments and review of the manuscript; P.

0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Mol Cell Biol 17:5053 to 5066[Abstract] Palmer CNA, Hsu M-H, Griffin KJ, Johnson EF 1995 Novel sequence determinants in peroxisome proliferator signaling.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	326	 J Biol Chem 270:16114 to 16121[Abstract/Free Full Text] Ijpenberg A, Jeannin E, Wahli W, Desvergne B 1997 Polarity and specific sequence requirements of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR)/retinoid X receptor (heterodimer binding to DNA.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	327	 J Biol Chem 272:20108 to 201117[Abstract/Free Full Text] Juge-Aubry C, Pernin A, Favez T, Burger AG, Wahli W, Meier CA, Desvergnes B 1997 DNA binding properties of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor subtypes on various natural peroxisome proliferator response elements.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Importance of 5' flanking region.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	329	 J Biol Chem 272:25252 to 25259[Abstract/Free Full Text] Lavinsky RM, Jepsen K, Heinzel T, Torchia J, Mullen T-M, Schiff R, Del-Rio AL, Ricote M, Ngo S, Gemsch J, Hilsenbeck SG, Osborne CK, Glass CK, Rosenfeld MG, Rose DW 1998 Diverse signaling pathways modulate nuclear receptor recruitment of N-CoR and SMRT complexes.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 95:2920 to 2925[Abstract/Free Full Text] Li H, Leo C, Schroen DJ, Chen JD 1997 Characterization of receptor interaction and transcriptional repression by the corepressor SMRT.
0.21701698.10098492.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Mol Endocrinol 11:2025 to 2037[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	0	Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young Type 1 (MODY1)-Associated Mutations R154X and E276Q in Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 4 (HNF4) Gene Impair Recruitment of p300, a Key Transcriptional Coactivator Jerome Eeckhoute, Pierre Formstecher and Bernard Laine.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	1	Unite 459 INSERM Laboratoire de Biologie Cellulaire Universite H.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Warembourg Lille, France F 59045.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	3	   ABSTRACT TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is a nuclear receptor involved in glucose homeostasis and is required for normal ss-cell function.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Mutations in the HNF4 gene are associated with maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 1.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	5	 E276Q and R154X mutations were previously shown to impair intrinsic transcriptional activity (without exogenously supplied coactivators) of HNF4.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Given that transcriptional partners of HNF4 modulate its intrinsic transcriptional activity and play crucial roles in HNF4 function, we investigated the effects of these mutations on potentiation of HNF4 activity by p300, a key coactivator for HNF4.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We show here that loss of HNF4 function by both mutations is increased through impaired physical interaction and functional cooperation between HNF4 and p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Impairment of p300-mediated potentiation of HNF4 transcriptional activity is of particular importance for the E276Q mutant since its intrinsic transcriptional activity is moderately affected.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Together with previous results obtained with chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter-transcription factor II, our results highlight that impairment of recruitment of transcriptional partners represents an important mechanism leading to abnormal HNF4 function resulting from the MODY1 E276Q mutation.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The impaired potentiations of HNF4 activity were observed on the promoter of HNF1, a transcription factor involved in a transcriptional network and required for ss-cell function.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Given its involvement in a regulatory signaling cascade, loss of HNF4 function may cause reduced ss-cell function secondary to defective HNF1 expression.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Our results also shed light on a better structure-function relationship of HNF4 and on p300 sequences involved in the interaction with HNF4.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	13	   INTRODUCTION TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF4) is a transcription factor required for normal early embryogenesis (1, 2).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	14	 HNF4 plays a central role in the coordination of a complex transcription factor network that defines the hepatocyte phenotype (3, 4, 5) and in the regulation of normal pancreatic endocrine function (6).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	15	 It controls expression of the transcription factors HNF1 and HNF6 (5, 6, 7, 8, 9); the former is required for pancreatic endocrine cell function and differentiation (10, 11), whereas the latter plays a central role in pancreatic endocrine differentiation at precursor stage (12).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	16	HNF4 is a member of the hormone nuclear receptor superfamily (13).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	17	 It has a modular structure comprising a DNA binding domain (DBD) located in the C domain and two activation function modules AF-1 (residues 1 to 24, located in the A domain) and AF-2 (residues 360 to 366, located in the E domain) (14, 15).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The HNF4 AF-2 module does not exhibit an autonomous transactivation activity and requires the sequence 128 to 366 (located in D to E domains) for its full activity (15).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Protein-protein interactions and synergies with other transcription factors such as chicken ovalbumin upstream promoter transcription factors (COUP-TFs) (16) and nuclear transcription factor Y (NPY) (17) or with coactivators of the p160 family (18, 19) and the CREB binding protein (CBP) (19, 20, 21, 22) enhance the transcriptional activity of HNF4.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	20	 CBP has been recently shown to be required for HNF4 function: through acetylation of HNF4, which is required for its nuclear retention, CBP increases HNF4 DNA binding and transcriptional activities (22).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	21	 CBP and the closely related p300 protein (together referred to as CBP/p300) (23) serve as coactivators for other hormone nuclear receptors.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	22	 CBP/p300 contains three LXXLL motifs located in the N-terminal receptor interaction domain (RID), near the C/H1 domain and in the C-terminal sequence, respectively (24) (scheme in Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Requirement of the RID in CBP/p300- mediated activation of nuclear receptors depends on nuclear receptors.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The RID, which was initially shown to interact with thyroid hormone receptor (TR) and retinoic acid receptor (RAR) homodimers (24), is required to enhance activity of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR)-retinoid X receptor (RXR) heterodimer (25) but is dispensable for enhanced transactivation by TR-RXR and RAR-RXR heterodimers (26, 27).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	25	 CBP/p300-mediated transcriptional potentiation of the activities of these two latter heterodimers requires steroid receptor coactivator-1 (SRC-1) (26).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	26	 On the other hand, CBP-mediated activation of HNF4, which acts as a homodimer (28), does not require SRC-1 (21).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The N-terminal third of CBP (sequence 1 to 771) forms a much stronger complex with full-length HNF4 than its C terminus (21).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Regions of HNF4 interacting with CBP have been mapped to the AF-1 and to the sequence required for full activity of the AF-2 [amino acids (aa) 128 to 366 (21)].
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	29	 For convenience, this latter sequence will be named D to E domains hereafter.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	30	View larger version (20K):    Figure 1.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Effect of R154X Mutation on the Functional Cooperation and Physical Interaction between HNF4 and p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	32	A, Transactivation activity of R154X, HEK 293T cells were transfected with 1  microg of HNF1 promoter and 50 ng of HNF4 expression vectors.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Fold induction refers to the activity with no HNF4 derivative.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Results are means  plus or minus  SD of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	35	 B, Enhancement of HNF4 transcriptional activity by p300 on the HNF1 promoter.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Cells were transfected as in A along with 500 ng of pCMVss p300 (+) or the empty expression vector (-).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	37	 For convenience, activities of the promoter in the presence of HNF42 alone or R154X alone were set to 100 to better visualize the difference in their potentiation by p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Results are means  plus or minus  SD of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	39	 **, Value statistically different from that observed for wild-type HNF4 (P  <  0.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	40	 C, Schematic representation of the p300 coactivator and the three GST-p300 chimeras, GST-p300(1 to 595), GST-p300(1 to 340), and GST-p300(340 to 528), used in pull-down experiments.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	41	 RID and C/H stand for receptor interaction domain and cysteine/histidine-rich domain, respectively; circles represent the LXXLL motifs.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	42	 D, Physical interaction of R154X with p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	43	 [35S]methionine- labeled HNF42 or R154X was incubated with GST or GST-p300 proteins depicted in panel C and immobilized on glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	44	 HNF4 proteins retained on beads after extensive washing were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and PhosphorImager.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Shown are a PhosphorImage and a graph representing means  plus or minus  SD of the R154X binding relative to that of wild-type HNF4 from two independent experiments performed in duplicate.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Inputs (10% of the in vitro synthesized proteins used in each incubation) were taken into account for binding quantification.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	47	 To better visualize faint bands corresponding to R154X, the intensity of the bottom part of the PhosphorImage was enhanced.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The GST proteins used in these experiments were visualized on a Coomassie blue-stained SDS-polyacrylamide gel (inset in the frame).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	49	  HNF4 is involved in glucose homeostasis, and loss of HNF4 function results in the decreased expression of genes involved in glucose transport and metabolism (6, 29) and in insulin secretion (6).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Mutations in the HNF4 gene are associated with type 1 maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY1), a monogenic form of diabetes characterized by abnormal pancreatic ss-cell function (30).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Studies of functional properties of several MODY1-associated mutations of HNF4 have shown that mutations can have variable effects on the ability of HNF4 to transactivate a reporter gene (29, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	52	 We have previously shown that mutations E276Q and R154X impair HNF4 functions.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Mutation E276Q affects the interaction and synergy with COUP-TFII, which enhances HNF4 activity on the HNF1 promoter (33).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Mutation R154X decreases the transcriptional activity of HNF4, the decrease being more pronounced in pancreatic ss-cells compared with non-ss-cells.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	55	 In addition, in the former cells, R154X exhibits a slight dominant-negative behavior (36).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	56	 HNF4 R154X has intact AF-1 and DNA binding domains but lacks the E domain, which is involved in interaction with CBP/p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The E276Q mutation is located in this E domain.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Taking into account the crucial role of CBP/p300, we investigated the effects of these two mutations on the physical interaction and functional cooperation between HNF4 and p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	59	   RESULTS TOP ABSTRACT INTRODUCTION RESULTS DISCUSSION MATERIALS AND METHODS REFERENCES   Effect of the R154X Mutation on p300 Recruitment by HNF4 We have previously shown that the R154X mutation resulted in a strong impairment of HNF4 transcriptional activity on several promoters in various cell lines.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Interestingly, the transcriptional activity of R154X remained equal to one-third that of wild-type HNF4 on the HNF1 promoter in HEK 293T cells (Ref.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	61	 We investigated whether this low transcriptional activity could be enhanced by the coactivator p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Cotransfection of p300 and HNF42 increased HNF1 promoter activity 3.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	63	8-fold over the activation by HNF42 alone (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Coexpression of p300 and R154X stimulated HNF1 promoter activity only 2.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	65	3-fold over the activation by R154X alone (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Transfection of p300 in the absence of transfected HNF4 did not increase the activity of the HNF1 promoter in HEK 293T cells (data not shown), indicating that the effect of p300 is mediated through HNF4.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	67	These results led us to compare interactions of wild-type and mutated HNF4 with p300 by pull-down assays using the three glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-p300(1 to 595), GST-p300(1 to 340), and GST-p300(340 to 528) chimeras.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	68	 GST-p300(1 to 595) contains two LXXLL motifs located in the receptor interaction domain (RID) and near the C/H1 domain, respectively, whereas GST-p300(1 to 340) and GST-p300(340 to 528) contain only one of these LXXLL motifs (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	69	 HNF42 and R154X were retained on both p300(>NOREF>1 to 595) and p30040 to 528) fragments (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Nevertheless, quantification of intensities of bands indicated that, compared with wild-type HNF42, R154X bound three times less efficiently to these two p300 fragments (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The specificity of these complexes was ascertained by the inability of GST alone to bind HNF42 and R154X (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	72	 HNF42 and R154X were not bound by the p300(1 to 340) fragment (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	73	 1D, lanes 7 and 8) although GST-p300(1 to 340) was readily expressed (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	74	A chimera comprising two copies of the HNF4 AF-1 module fused to GAL4 DBD has been shown to interact with fragment 1 to 771 of CBP (14).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	75	 R154X binding to p300 is likely mediated through the AF-1 module located in the sequence 1 to 24 since it has been shown that a HNF4 fragment spanning residues 45 to 142 does not interact with CBP (21).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	76	 To ascertain this hypothesis, the mutation F19D, which abolishes the transcriptional activity of the AF-1 module (14), was introduced in R154X.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	77	 This amino acid residue is located within the sequence (aa 13 to 24) involved in the interaction between HNF4 AF-1 and CBP (14).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	78	 2A show that mutation F19D strongly impaired the transactivation activity of R154X.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The drop in R154X-F19D activity is not due to its decreased expression (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In addition, R154X-F19D activity was poorly enhanced by p300: the activity was enhanced 1.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	81	17-fold whereas that of R154X was enhanced 2.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	82	 By pull-down experiments, we observed that the F19D mutation nearly abolished interaction of R154X with p300 (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	83	 These results confirm that AF-1 is involved in R154X transcriptional activity and in potentiation of this latter by p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	84	View larger version (28K):    Figure 2.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	85	 R154X Activities Are Markedly Decreased by Mutation of the AF-1 Module.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	86	A, HEK 293T cells were transfected as in Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	87	 1A with the indicated HNF4 expression vectors.

0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Inset, Control of protein expression.

0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	93	 HEK 293T cells were transfected as in A together with 0.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	94	5  microg of p300 or empty expression vector.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	95	 For convenience, activities of the promoter in the presence of R154X alone or R154X-F19D alone were set to 100 to better visualize the difference in -fold enhancement by p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Results are means  plus or minus  SD of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.

0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	99	 HNF4 mutants retained on beads after extensive washing were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and PhosphorImager.

0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Inputs (5% of the in vitro synthesized proteins used in each incubation) were taken into account for binding quantification.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	102	  Next we introduced the F19D mutation in full-length HNF4 to investigate the AF-1 contribution toward the potentiation of full-length HNF4 activity by p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	103	 F19D mutation resulted in a drop of 50% in the transactivation activity of HNF42 (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Conversely, the F19D mutation did not alter the p300-mediated enhancement of HNF42 transcriptional activity (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	105	 3B) despite a decrease in interaction with p300(340 to 528) (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	106	 These results show that the AF-1 is required for the full intrinsic activity of HNF4 (without exogenously supplied coactivators) but exhibits a secondary role in the p300-mediated potentiation of this transcription factor.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	107	View larger version (30K):    Figure 3.

0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Inputs (10% of the in vitro synthesized proteins used in each incubation) were taken into account for binding quantification.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	123	  Effect of the E276Q Mutation on p300 Recruitment by HNF4 In HEK 293T cells, HNF42 and HNF42-E276Q, which were expressed at the same levels (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	124	 4A, inset), exhibited similar transactivation activities on the HNF1 promoter (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	125	 On the other hand, the p300-mediated enhancement of these activities was markedly different: it was much higher for HNF42 than for its E276Q mutant (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	126	 4B), thus demonstrating that the E276Q mutation impairs the cooperation between HNF4 and p300.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	127	 We then investigated whether this impairment could be correlated with a decrease in physical interaction between HNF4 and its coactivator by pull-down experiments.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In these experiments we used GST-p300(1 to 595) and GST-p300(340 to 528) but not GST-p300(1 to 340), which could not bind HNF4 (see Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	129	 We have previously shown that wild-type and E276Q HNF42 do not bind GST (33).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The E276Q mutation significantly impaired the HNF4-p300 interaction as evidenced with both GST-p300(1 to 595) and GST-p300(340 to 528) proteins (Fig.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	131	View larger version (22K):    Figure 4.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Effect of E276Q Mutation on Functional Cooperation and Physical Interaction between HNF42 and p300.

0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Cells were transfected as in panel A along with 500 ng of pCMVss p300 (+) or the empty control vector (-).
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Results are means  plus or minus  SD of three independent experiments performed in triplicate.
