0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	340	 J Biol Chem 274:35639 to 35646[Abstract/Free Full Text] Suaud L, Formstecher P, Laine B 1999 The activity of the activation function 2 of the human hepatocyte nuclear factor 4 (HNF-4) is differently modulated by F domains from various origins.
0.53388375.11435618.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Biochem J 340:161 to 169[CrossRef][Medline].
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	0	COUP-TFII is essential for radial and anteroposterior patterning of the stomach Norio Takamoto1, Li-Ru You1, Kelvin Moses1, Chin Chiang2, Warren E.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	1	 DeMayo1,4, Ming-Jer Tsai1,4,* and Sophia Y.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA 2 Department of Cell Biology and Neurosciences, University of South Alabama, Mobile, AL 36688, USA 3 Department of Cell and Developmental Biology, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, TN 37232,USA 4 Developmental Biological Program, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	3	* Authors for correspondence (e-mail: stsai{at}bcm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	4	edu' + u + '@' + d + ''//-->; mtsai{at}bcm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	5	   SUMMARY TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion REFERENCES   COUP-TFII, an orphan member of the steroid receptor superfamily, has been implicated in mesenchymal-epithelial interaction during organogenesis.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The generation of a lacZ knock-in allele in the COUP-TFII locus in mice allows us to use X-gal staining to follow the expression of COUP-TFII in the developing stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We found COUP-TFII is expressed in the mesenchyme and the epithelium of the developing stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Conditional ablation of floxed COUP-TFII by Nkx3-2Cre recombinase in the gastric mesenchyme results in dysmorphogenesis of the developing stomach manifested by major patterning defects in posteriorization and radial patterning.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The epithelial outgrowth, the expansion of the circular smooth muscle layer and enteric neurons as well as the posteriorization of the stomach resemble phenotypes exhibited by inhibition of hedgehog signaling pathways.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Using organ cultures and cyclopamine treatment, we showed downregulation of COUP-TFII level in the stomach, suggesting COUP-TFII as a target of hedgehog signaling in the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Our results are consistent with a functional link between hedgehog proteins and COUP-TFII, factors that are vital for epithelial-mesenchymal interactions.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	12	Key words: Nuclear orphan receptor, Sonic hedgehog, Organogenesis, Stomach, Mouse, Nr2f1, Nr2f2.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	13	   Introduction TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion REFERENCES   Gut development depends upon crosstalk between endoderm and splanchnic mesenchyme cell layers along the anteroposterior axis, resulting in the subdivision of the gut into foregut, midgut and hindgut (Kedinger et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	14	, 1998a; De Santa Barbara et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The stomach becomes specified at the caudal end of foregut and emerges as a bulge of the developing GI tract (Kaufman and Bard, 1999).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The stomach then undergoes progressive remodeling and differentiation in a regionally specific fashion.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The detailed genetic and molecular pathways that direct gastric organogenesis are still unknown, but it is clear that patterning of the GI tract requires elaborate cellular communication between the epithelium and mesenchyme cell layers (Fukuda and Yasugi, 2002).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	18	Sonic hedgehog (Shh) patterns a variety of embryonic tissues, including the fore-stomach epithelium by signaling to the mesenchyme prior to organ regionalization (Chiang et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Shh-null mice exhibit inappropriate expression of alkaline-phosphatase (EAP) in the epithelium of the hind-stomach (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 2000), which is consistent with the stomach epithelium acquiring an intestinal or `posteriorized' character.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Conversely, the stomach of the activin receptor IIA and B compound mutant (ActRIIA/B mutant; Acvr2a/Acvr2b to Mouse Genome Informatics) exhibits posterior extension of the fore-stomach epithelium with expansion of Shh expression (Kim et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	22	, 2000), a process referred to as `anteriorization'.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	23	 These data suggest that Shh expression in the fore-stomach acts to induce and/or maintain non-intestinal character, resulting in the development of gastric epithelium (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	24	COUP-TF proteins are nuclear orphan receptors, highly conserved across species.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Two members have been identified in mice, COUP-TFI (Nr2f1 to Mouse Genome Informatics) and COUP-TFII (Nr2f2 to Mouse Genome Informatics).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The temporal and spatial expression pattern of COUP-TFII in mesenchyme led us to hypothesize that COUP-TFII plays a role in mesenchymal-epithelial interactions during organogenesis (Tsai and Tsai, 1997).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In the developing neural tube, Shh has been shown to regulate COUP-TFII expression during the differentiation of motoneurons (Lutz et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We have also identified a 5'-regulatory element that mediates Shh stimulation of COUP-TFII expression (Krishnan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	29	 COUP-TFII is likely to be a downstream target of Shh signaling, and the requirement for Shh in gastric organogenesis led us to infer that COUP-TFII may play a role in stomach development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	30	To circumvent the early embryonic lethality of the COUP-TFII-null mutation and to investigate its function during gastric organogenesis, we generated a conditional null mutant of COUP-TFII using the Cre/LoxP system.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Nkx3-2 (Bapx1) is a homeobox-containing gene (Tribioli et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	32	, 1997) that is coexpressed with COUP-TFII in the stomach primordium; thus, Nkx3-2Cre knock-in recombinase was used to ablate COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The stomachs of conditional mutant mice exhibited dysmorphogenesis accompanied by abnormalities of both compartmentalization and radial patterning, demonstrating a functional link between Shh and COUP-TFII.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	34	   Materials and methods TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion REFERENCES   Generation of conditional mutant of COUP-TFII Genomic DNA fragments, 7.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	35	4 kb XbaI-EcoRI from Q#10 clone and a 2.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	36	6 kb EcoRI-BamHI fragment from D-3.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	37	6RI clone containing COUP-TFII locus as described (Qiu et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	38	, 1995) were subcloned into pBlueScriptII KS(+).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The first loxP site was inserted into BglI site of 7.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	40	2 kb BamHI-SalI fragment and the NsiI site on the 2.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	41	6 kb EcoRI-BamHI fragment was modified with XhoI linker.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	42	 These four genomic fragments were reconstructed, and XhoI site on the 2.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	43	6 kb EcoRI-BamHI region was modified with linker containing ClaI site at the 3' end.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	44	 pNeoTKLoxP, a positive-negative selection cassette, was modified and ligated with lacZ from pDP46.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This NeoTKLoxP-lacZ construct was inserted into XhoI-ClaI linker at 3'-UTR.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	46	 5'-SalI site of NeoTKLoxP-lacZ was destroyed by ligation with XhoI, and ClaI site and NotI site were blunt-end-ligated after fill-in reaction.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Targeting construct consists of 4 kb 5'-arm, 6.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	48	5 kb NeoTKLoxP-lacZ and 2 kb 3'-arm, a total size of 24 kb was linearized with NotI at the 3' end.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Homologous recombination was performed in AB1.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	50	, 1997) and ES cell clones were screened by two rounds of Southern blot analysis.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Correctly targeted clones were first identified by screening XbaI digest with 5'-external and 3'-external probes (5'-ext and 3'-ext, respectively) and subsequently transfected with a Cre recombinase expression vector followed by screening HindIII digests with a 5'-internal probe (5'-int) and XbaI digest with a 3'-external probe.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Chimeric animals were generated by microinjection and germline transmission was achieved by crossing with C57Bl/6 wild-type female.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Thereafter, mutant mice carrying floxed allele were maintained in 129/B6 mixed background.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Specific primers were designed for floxed COUP-TFII genotyping by PCR.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The primer sequences were NT1 5'-CAGTCGCCTCTCCTTCTCCTTCTCC-3', NT2 5'-CATCCGGGATATGTTACTGTCCGG-3', NT3A 5'-TTCTGGTCTTCACCCACCGGTACC-3' and NT6A 5'-TGGGGAAGCTAAGTGTTGTAGTGATTCC-3'.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The sizes of the PCR product are 785 bp for wild type and 394 bp for floxed allele.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	57	Nkx3-2Cre knock-in animal was generated by homologous recombination in ES cells (K.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Cre recombinase was inserted in-frame into the exon1 of Nkx3-2 locus.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	59	 No overt phenotype was found in heterozygous animals.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	60	X-gal staining X-gal staining was performed according to the published methods (Hogan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	61	 For whole-mount staining, embryos (up to E10.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	62	5) were dissected and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, then stained in X-gal staining solution at room temperature.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Histological sections of whole-mount stained embryos were processed in Histoclear, embedded in paraffin, and sectioned at 10-12  microm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Sections were cleared with Histoclear, rehydrated and counterstained with Eosin, and mounted with Permount.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	65	5 or later) and postnatal samples were cryoprotected with 20% sucrose/PBS solution after fixation with 2% paraformaldehyde and embedded in OCT compound.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Cryostat sections (16  microm) were briefly fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde, stained in X-gal staining solution and counterstained with Eosin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	67	Histological analysis Tissues were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, embedded in paraffin and sectioned at 5 or 7  microm.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Hematoxylin and Eosin staining was carried out according to the regular protocol.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	69	 For immunohistochemistry, paraffin sections were dewaxed, rehydrated and incubated with primary antibodies.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Antibodies against human CK14 (1:500) was a gift from Dr Roop (Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Polyclonal anti-serum against PGP9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Antibodies against TUJ1 (Convance, 1:1000), GATA4 (Santa Crutz, 1:400), H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit (Affinity BioReagents, 1:500) were used in immunostaining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Texas Red-tagged Griffonia simplicifolia II (GSII) lectin was used to stain the stomach tissue.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Positive staining for CK14 and PGP9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	75	5 was visualized by using biotinylated secondary antibody and streptavidin-horseraddish peroxidase conjugate, and NovaRed (Vector) as a chromogen.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	76	 SMA-, TUJ1, GATA4 and H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit were visualized by using biotinylated secondary antibody and streptavidin-horseraddish peroxidase conjugate, and DAB (Vector) as a chromogen.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Monoclonal anti--smooth muscle actin (SMA-, 1A4, 1:1000) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and immunostaining was performed using Mouse-On-Mouse kit (Vector) according to manufacturers instruction, and detected with AlxaFluor488 (Molecular Probes).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	78	 For ultrastructural study of the disorganized smooth muscle layer, 0.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	79	5  microm semi-thin sections were stained with Toluidine Blue.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Endogenous alkaline-phosphatase staining was performed as previously described (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	81	, 2002) and counterstained with Methyl Green.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The glycoconjugated production in parietal cells of the stomach was marked by DBA lectin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Whole-mount in situ hybridization for COUP-TFII was carried out as described (Qiu et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Probe for Shh was a gift from Dr M.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Scott (Stanford University, CA).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	86	 For section in situ hybridization of Shh, E11.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	87	5 embryos were cross-sectioned and Shh expressions in the fore-stomach were detected using 35S-UTP labeled probes.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Positive signals were pseudo-colored (red) and overlaid on bright field image of Hematoxylin staining as described (Pereira et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	89	Explants culture of embryonic foregut Foreguts were dissected from E10.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	90	5 lacZ knock-in heterozygous embryos and cultured on tissue-culture insert (Corning) with defined serum-free medium (Opti-MEMI, Invitrogen Life Technologies).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Explants were incubated with vehicle (DMSO), 1, 5 and 10  microM of cyclopamine (Toronto Research Chemicals) for 48 hours, and fixed with 2% paraformaldehyde for whole-mount lacZ staining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Explants from wild-type embryos were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde and used for whole-mount in situ hybridization.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	93	   Results TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion REFERENCES   Expression of COUP-TFII in the stomach To facilitate the profiling of COUP-TFII gene expression during development, we generated a targeted vector according to a scheme diagramed in Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	94	 This targeting vector was introduced into ES cells together with Cre recombinase.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Upon recombination between the first and the last LoxP sites, COUP-TFII was deleted and the expression of lacZ reporter, inserted into the 5' untranslated region of COUP-TFII locus, was activated.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The ES cells were subsequently injected into blastocysts to generate lacZ knock-in alleles in mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	97	 lacZ gene expression is under the control of COUP-TFII promoter and its expression recapitulates the expression of the endogenous COUP-TFII gene.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Using this lacZ knock-in allele, we examined the expression pattern of COUP-TFII during gut development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	99	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Expression of COUP-TFII in the stomach using lacZ knock-in model.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Generation of the lacZ knock-in allele and generation of floxed COUP-TFII allele.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Using homologous recombination, a targeting construct containing nuclear lacZ, Neo/TK and LoxP sites were inserted into the genomic COUP-TFII locus, generating a targeted allele in ES cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Treatment with Cre recombinase and FIAU selection resulted in a lacZ knock-in allele in which lacZ gene expression was controlled by the endogenous COUP-TFII promoter when recombination took place between the first and the third loxP sites of the targeted allele.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	104	 In addition, floxed COUP-TFII ES clones that retains COUP-TFII locus but lacks selection markers were generated when recombination took place between the second and the third loxP sites.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	105	 B, BamHI; H, HindIII; S, SalI; X, XbaI.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	106	5 heterozygous COUP-TFII/lacZ knock-in embryo were stained (for 2 hours) for lacZ activity.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	107	 There is relatively high expression in the mesenchymal cells just adjacent to the epithelium.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The stomach from a 3-day-old heterozygous knock-in animal was dissected and whole-mount X-gal staining was performed.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The boundary between stomach and duodenum is indicated by arrowhead.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	110	 (D) A cryostat section of stomach from adult heterozygous knock-in animal was stained for lacZ activity (blue) and counterstained with propidium iodide (red).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	111	 DBA lectin immunostaining denotes the parietal cells (green).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	112	 There is strong X-gal staining in the base layer and negligible staining in the surface pit layer of the adult Zymogenic unit.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	113	 m, mesenchyme; e, epithelium; fs, fore-stomach; hs, hind-stomach; d, duodenum; oe, esophagus.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	114	5, X-gal staining was detected in both the epithelium and mesenchyme of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Brief staining of cryostat sections revealed that mesenchymal cells adjacent to the endoderm had higher expression of COUP-TFII than did distal mesenchymal cells, suggesting that a potential diffusible molecule, secreted from the epithelium might regulate COUP-TFII expression in the mesenchyme (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	116	 At postnatal day 3, COUP-TFII/lacZ was detected throughout the stomach (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	117	 1C), and was sharply downregulated in duodenum (red arrowhead indicates junction between stomach and duodenum).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	118	 COUP-TFII/lacZ was also expressed in the glandular epithelium of adult stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Adult glandular epithelium forms tubular structures, each of which is referred to as a zymogenic unit, which can be subdivided into four regions; a surface pit, an isthmus, a neck and a base that is located proximal to the sub mucosa (Karam and Leblond, 1993).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Strong lacZ staining was evident at the base, and much lower at surface pit layer (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	121	 To ensure COUP-TFII is also expressed in the parietal cells, we used DBA lectin for immunostaining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	122	 1D, X-gal and lectin-positive green cells colocalized, indicating that COUP-TFII is expressed in the parietal cells of the Zymogenic unit.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The expression pattern of COUP-TFII in the Zymogenic unit mimics the reported expression pattern of Shh in mouse stomach (van den Brink et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Thus, COUP-TFII is abundantly expressed from an early developmental stage in both epithelium and mesenchyme of the stomach in parallel with Shh.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	125	Nkx3-2Cre recombinase ablates COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme To examine the role of COUP-TFII in gastric development, we chose to ablate the COUP-TFII gene in a tissue-specific manner using the Cre/LoxP system.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The targeting vector depicted in Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	127	 1A, was introduced into ES cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	128	 After excision of the Neo-TK cassette by Cre-based recombination, ES cells harboring the conditional allele were generated as depicted in Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	129	 1A and used to generate floxed COUP-TFII mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	130	 An Nkx3-2Cre mouse line was also generated (K.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	131	, unpublished), which was crossed with the floxed COUP-TFII mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	132	 As lacZ is only turned on in cells with COUP-TFII locus recombined or deleted, X-gal staining can be used as a marker for successful COUP-TFII recombined or deleted cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	133	5 stomach from Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ embryo demonstrates that COUP-TFII was ablated specifically in the gastric mesenchyme (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	134	 This is expected because X-gal staining of lacZ knock-in mice is detected only in the stomach primordium (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	135	 2A) which is similar to Nkx3-2-Cre expression at E9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	136	5, as demonstrated by the product of intercrossing the Nkx3-2Cre with ROSA26 reporter strain (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	137	View larger version (74K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Ablation of COUP-TFII in the mesenchyme of the developing stomach using Nkx3-2Cre and COUP-TFII floxed mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	139	 (A) Whole-mount X-gal staining of Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ embryo, demonstrating the ablation of COUP-TFII by Nkx3-2Cre at E9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	140	 lacZ expression represents Cre-mediated recombination of floxed COUP-TFII.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	141	 (B) The expression of Nkx3-2Cre at E9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	142	5 was detected by whole-mount X-gal staining of Nkx3-2Cre/+; ROSA26R/+ embryo.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	143	 X-gal staining represents Cre-mediated ablation of an interfering stop sequence in the ROSA26 reporter gene.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Specific staining was observed in the developing stomach of both embryos.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	145	 (C) A partially dissected Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ embryo was stained by whole-mount X-gal staining, then paraffin embedded and serially sectioned.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	146	 X-gal staining indicates Cre-mediated recombination and was detected throughout the gastric mesenchyme, but not in the epithelium, demonstrating the ablation of COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme at E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Scale bars: in B, 100  microm for A,B; in C, 100  microm for C.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	148	  Conditional ablation of COUP-TFII in the gastric mesenchyme results in dysmorphogenesis and radial patterning defects of the developing stomach The size of the mutant stomach is slightly smaller when compared with the control littermate at E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Histological analysis of Hematoxylin and Eosin-stained sagittal sections of the mutant stomach showed that the epithelium is considerably thicker than the controls at E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In addition, the circular smooth layer, which is stained with -smooth muscle actin antibody, is disorganized in comparison with the controls at E13.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	151	 These abnormal morphological changes were again seen at E14.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	152	5 (data not shown), suggesting radial patterning of the stomach might be perturbed.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	153	View larger version (59K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Expansion of smooth muscle layers and enteric motoneurons in conditional mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (A-D) Embryos were obtained by mating with COUP-TFII floxed homozygous males and Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ females.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	156	 COUP-TFII floxed homozygote served as controls, and Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/flox were designated as conditional mutants.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Histological analysis of stomach dissected from E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	158	5 controls (A) and conditional mutants (B) showed that the epithelium of the conditional mutant is thicker (marked by the black arrows) in Hematoxylin and Eosin stained sagittal sections.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	159	5, the smooth muscle layers of the mutant stomach are disorganized in comparison with the controls, as seen by -smooth muscle actin immunostaining (brown) (compare C with D).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	160	 (E-H) -smooth muscle actin staining of sagittal sections of E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Smooth muscle cells were immunoassayed for -smooth muscle actin (green), and counterstained with propidium iodide (red).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	162	 White arrows indicate the extension of -smooth muscle actin staining in the submucosal mesenchyme of the conditional mutant (F).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	163	 (E,G,H) The thickened circular smooth muscle layer formation was observed in both the fore-stomach (F) and the hind-stomach (H) of the conditional mutant in comparison with the control (E,G).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	164	 (I,J) Semi-thin section semi-thin sections of the stomachs from E15.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The circular smooth muscle layer of the conditional mutant stomach (J) is disorganized in comparison with the control (I).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Enteric neurons were stained by protein gene product 9.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	167	5) antiserum (brown) and counterstained with Hematoxylin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Anti-TUJ1 antibody was employed in immunostaining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	169	 An increase of TUJ1-positive cells is shown in the conditional mutant (N) in comparison with the littermate control (M).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	170	  To further assess the potential radial patterning defects exhibited by the conditional COUP-TFII-null mutants, we examined the differentiation of smooth muscle and enteric neurons of the mutant stomach at later development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Immunostaining of -smooth muscle actin confirmed the presence of a thickened circular smooth muscle layer formation in both the fore-stomach (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	172	 3E,F) and hind-stomach of conditional mutant mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Moreover, submucosal extension of -smooth muscle actin positive cells in the mutant fore-stomach (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	174	 3F, white arrows) indicated precocious differentiation of smooth muscle cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	175	 To further demonstrate that the smooth muscle layer in the conditional mutant stomach is disorganized, semi-thin sections (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	176	 3I,J) and the ultrastructure (data not shown) of the stomachs from E15.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Again, circular smooth muscle layer of the conditional mutant stomach is disorganized (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	178	 3J) in comparison with the controls (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	179	5 as revealed by semi-thin sections.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, cellular defects, other than the disorganization of cell layers, have not been observed (data not shown).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	181	5, an enteric neuron marker, showed an increased number of positively stained cells in the conditional mutant mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	182	 To ensure there is expansion of enteric neurons in the mutant stomach, an additional neuronal marker, TUJ1 (neuronal class III tubulin-ss) was employed in immunostaining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	183	 An increase of TUJ1-positive cells is shown in the conditional mutant (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	184	 3N) in comparison with the littermate control (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Taken together, conditional ablation of COUP-TFII in the mesenchyme resulted in at least two patterning abnormalities, epithelium outgrowth and expansion of circular smooth muscle and enteric neuron, both radial-patterning defects of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The fact that COUP-TFII is only deleted in the mesenchyme compartment but the epithelium of the mutant stomach is expanded, suggesting signals from the mesenchyme is essential for proper growth of the epithelium.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	187	Anteroposterior patterning of the stomach is altered in the COUP-TFII conditional null mutant The abnormal radial patterning of the stomach manifested by the COUP-TFII mutants prompted us to assess if other patterning defects were also present in the developing mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	188	 A whole-mount view revealed dysmorphogenesis in the stomach of conditional mutants (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The anatomical demarcation between the stratifying fore-stomach epithelium and the columnar hind-stomach epithelium, referred to as `the limiting ridge' as indicated by broken line, begins to develop, forming a presumptive margin between the fore-stomach and hind-stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The size of the fore-stomach compartment and of the entire organ was noticeably reduced in the conditional mutants (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	191	 4C,D, white arrowheads indicate the junction of fore- and hind-stomach).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Detailed histological examination reveals abnormalities in both the epithelium and mesenchyme.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The glandular epithelium was thicker in mutants when compared with controls (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In control mice, the epithelium was thickest at the pyloric region (to the left of Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	195	 4E), and the thickness of the epithelium progressively decreased anteriorly (towards the right).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	196	 By contrast, the epithelium of conditional mutant mice remained thick even in more anterior regions (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The mesenchyme of the conditional mutant mice was also thickened.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The hind-stomach epithelium showed several invaginations in the control mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	199	 4G), while more extensive invagination associated with the thickened epithelial layer in the conditional mutant mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The morphological reduction of the fore-stomach and the extension of the hind-stomach suggest aberrant compartmentation of the stomach, a possible patterning defect in the anteroposterior axis.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	201	View larger version (103K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Analysis of AP patterning defects in conditional COUP-TFII mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Controls and conditional mutant embryos were obtained by mating with COUP-TFII floxed homozygous males and Nkx3-2Cre/+; COUP-TFIIflox/+ females as described in Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	204	 (A,B) Stomachs were dissected from E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	205	5 embryos and examined in whole mount under the dissecting microscope.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The presumptive margin between fore-stomach and hind-stomach is indicated by dots and is shifted slightly anteriorly in the mutant.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	207	 (C,D) Whole-mount postnatal day 28 stomachs were dissected and examined under the dissecting microscope.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Position of limiting ridge is indicated by arrowhead.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	209	 A clear anterior shift of the limited ridge is observed in the conditional mutant.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (E,F) Dissected stomachs from E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	211	5 embryos were longitudinally sectioned and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	212	 (G-H) Higher magnification of similar regions as indicated by lines in E,F.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	213	 e, epithelium; sm, smooth muscle layer; fs, fore-stomach; hs, hind-stomach; oe, esophagus; d, duodenum.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	214	  Histological analysis of whole embryo sagittal sections were carried out to examine if indeed patterning of anteroposterior axis in the conditional mutant is perturbed, Analysis of E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	215	5 conditional mutants revealed an alteration in epithelial characteristics along the AP axis (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The proximal duodenum exhibited typical characteristics for this stage in both control (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	217	 5A) and conditional mutant mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	218	 However, the pylorus of conditional mutant mice exhibited a disorganized thickened circular smooth muscle layer, with an epithelium that resembled the epithelium of the duodenum and was devoid of vacuoles (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	219	 5F), unlike the highly vacuolated control (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The hind-stomach of controls had a simple columnar epithelium with few invaginations, and a tight circular smooth muscle layer (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	221	 By contrast, the hind-stomach of conditional mutant mice exhibited a vacuolated epithelium (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	222	 5G), resembling the pyloric region of control mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	223	 5B), with numerous invaginations and a thickened but disorganized circular smooth muscle layer.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	224	 In addition, a cell layer located distal to the circular smooth muscle layer (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	225	 5G, indicated by small arrows at the bottom), where enteric neurons are normally located, was expanded in the conditional mutants.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Finally, the fore-stomach epithelium begins to stratify at E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	227	5, with characteristic rough and deep infolding that was evident in the control mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The conditional mutant mice showed similar infolding, but epithelium did not show clear signs of stratification (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	229	 In fact, the fore-stomach epithelium of conditional mutant mice more closely resembled hind-stomach epithelium (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	230	 These observable morphological changes in the compartmentation of different regions of the stomach are consistent with the notion that the stomach is posteriorized.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	231	View larger version (94K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Morphological changes in the posteriorized conditional mutant stomach: E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	233	5 whole embryos were sectioned sagittally and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin for histological assessment.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Corresponding regions in mutant and control were estimated by morphological characteristics of mesenchyme of each regions and relative location against other anatomical structures.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Oblique arrows across control and conditional mutant panels indicate changes of epithelial characteristics in the conditional mutants.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	236	 e, epithelium; sm, smooth muscle layer.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	237	  Alteration of AP patterning in the fore-stomach If AP patterning of the stomach is indeed disrupted in the conditional mutant, it is anticipated that the specification/differentiation of gastric epithelium might be affected.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	238	 To assess if the fore-stomach is altered, we examined the fore-stomach regions using the stratified epithelial cell marker cytokeratin 14 (CK14).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Immunostaining using CK14-specific antibody showed intense staining in the E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	240	5 control fore-stomach and the very anterior region of the mutant fore-stomach (data not shown).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	241	 CK14 staining remained as intense throughout the fore-stomach of the control (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	242	 However, it was barely detectable in the more caudal regions of the presumptive fore-stomach of the mutant (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	243	 6B), suggesting that the mutant stomach is posteriorized in which only the very anterior region of the stomach epithelium is stratified and expresses CK14, while the hind-stomach is morphologically expanded and is non-stratified.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	244	View larger version (113K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Marker gene analyses confirm morphological changes in the conditional mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	246	5 sagittal sections were stained for stratified epithelial cell marker CK14.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Intense staining was found in the basal cells in the control (A), while only faint staining was observed in the anterior edge of fore-stomach of the COUP-TFII conditional mutant (B).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	248	5 embryos were cross-sectioned and Shh expressions in the fore-stomach were examined by section in situ hybridization using 35S-UTP labeled probes.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Positive signals were pseudo-colored (red) and overlaid on bright-field image of Hematoxylin staining.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	250	 (E-G) Paraffin sections of E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	251	5 stomachs were stained with anti-CK14 antibody.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	252	 CK14 staining (dark brown) remained as intense throughout the fore-stomach of the control (E) and mutant (F).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Again, it was barely detectable in the more caudal regions of the stomach of the mutant (G) in comparison with similar anatomical position of fore-stomach of the control (E).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	254	  Shh has been shown to be highly expressed in the fore-stomach and can serve as a fore-stomach marker.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In the controls, Shh is highly expressed in the fore-stomach and the expression extends into the hind-stomach (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	256	 By contrast, the expression of Shh is anteriorly restricted in the conditional mutant (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The anterior restriction of Shh expression observed in the conditional mutants is similar to that detected in the stomachs of Hoxa5 mutant, indicating posteriorization of the fore-stomach (Aubin et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	258	Similar result for CK14 staining was observed at the later stage of development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	259	 CK14 staining remained as intense throughout the fore-stomach of the control and mutant at E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Again, it was barely detectable in the more caudal regions of the stomach of the mutant (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	261	 6G), in comparison with similar anatomical position of fore-stomach of the control (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	262	 This result further support the notion that the mutant stomach is posteriorized in which only the very anterior region of the stomach epithelium is stratified and expresses CK14, whereas the hind-stomach is expanded and is non-stratified.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	263	The expression of the differentiated hind-stomach markers remains unchanged in the conditional mutants As shown earlier, the radial patterning and the AP patterning of the stomach are altered in the mutants at E13.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	264	5, leading to the respective thickening of the epithelium and the expansion of the hind-stomach (Figs 3, 4, 5).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	265	 To examine if these phenotypes persist at later development, we examined the mutant stomach at E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Similar to early development, it is clear that the epithelium is thickened and the hind-stomach of the mutant is considerably expanded (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	267	 7B) in comparison with the controls (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	268	 To examine whether differentiation of the glandular epithelium is perturbed in the mutant, the expression of parietal cell marker H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit and of the glandular gastric epithelium marker GATA4 were analyzed at E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Although H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit positive parietal cells are present in the glandular gastric epithelium of both controls (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	270	 7C) and conditional mutant mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	271	 7D), the number of the parietal cells were increased in the thickened epithelial layer of the conditional mutant mice (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The expression of GATA4 in the thickened glandular epithelial layer of the mutant (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	273	 7F) is similar to that of the controls (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	274	 7E), suggesting differentiation of the glandular epithelium is unchanged in the mutant.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	275	View larger version (71K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	276	 (A,B) Dissected stomachs from E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	277	5 embryos were longitudinally sectioned and stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The thickness of the glandular epithelium is increased in the mutant stomach compared with the littermate control.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	279	 (C-F) The adjacent tissue sections between fore-stomach and hind-stomach were stained by anti-H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit antibody (C,D) and anti-GATA4 (E,F) antibodies.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	280	 The transition zone between oxyntic mucosa (os) and stratified squamous epithelium (sse) of the fore-stomach are indicated by arrows.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	281	 (G-T) Marker gene analyses in the adult stomachs: (G-L) Sections (4  microm) prepared from the stomachs of 35-day-old mice were staining with Hematoxylin and Eosin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The histological morphology of zymogenic region (G,H), mucoparietal zone (I,J) and pure mucus zone (K,L) showed no obvious difference in the conditional mutant stomach (H,J,L) and littermate control (G,I,K).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	283	 (M,N) The secreted glycoprotein of the zymogenic zone of stomachs was visualized by PAS staining and no discernable difference was observed in the conditional mutant stomach (N) and littermate control (M).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	284	 (O,P) The gastric parietal cells were stained with anti-H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit antibody.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	285	 (Q,R) The neck and pre-neck cells (red) at the gastric units showed no difference in the control (Q) and conditional mutant (R) stomachs.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	286	 (S,T) Anti-GATA4 antibody was used to mark glandular gastric epithelium.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Positive signals were found in base of glandular gastric epithelium at pure mucus zone in the control (S) and the mutant (T).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	288	  To further substantiate that differentiation of the hind-stomach is largely intact in the mutant, we examined the mutant hind-stomach at adulthood.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Histological analysis of the stomachs from 35-day-old of mutant mice and littermate controls showed no obvious difference in the hind-stomachs at the regions of Zymogenic zone (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	290	 7 I,J) and pure mucus zone (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	291	 7K,L) by Hematoxylin and Eosin.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Mucins secretion was analyzed by periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) staining and similar PAS staining was observed in both control (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	293	 To further examine if there is any changes in cell specification in the mutant hind-stomach, we employed H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit as the parietal cells marker (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	294	 7O,P), GSII as the neck and pre-neck cell marker (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	295	 7Q,R) and GATA4 as marker in the base of the pure mucus unit (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	296	 The expression profiles of all these markers are similar in the mutants when compared with the controls.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	297	 These results, taken together, support the notion that there are no cell type changes in the conditional mutant in comparison with littermate control throughout development even though there are observable patterning defects in the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	298	Alteration in the very caudal part of the mutant hind-stomach As histological analysis indicated that the very caudal part of the hind-stomach might have acquired pylorus characteristics, we used alkaline phosphatase (EAP) to determine whether hind-stomach is indeed posteriorized.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	299	 8A, EAP is mainly expressed in the duodenum and pylorus region of the controls.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	300	 By contrast, high level of EAP expression not just found in the duodenum and pylorus, but it was also found in the hind-stomach of conditional mutant mice using longitudinally sectioned E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Clear anterior extension of EAP-positive epithelium, as indicated by brackets, was found in the hind-stomach of conditional mutant mice.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Although expression of the markers H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	303	 8E,F) is no different in the regions anterior to the junction of the pylorus and duodenum from E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	304	 8D,F) stomachs, the higher level of EAP activity was again found in the mutant hind-stomach (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Taken together, the extended and high levels of EAP expression in the hind-stomach again indicate that patterning of the AP axis is abnormal in the conditional mutants.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	306	View larger version (92K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	307	 (A,B) Paraffin sections of E16.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	308	5 stomachs were stained for EAP activity.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	309	 The bracket indicates corresponding regions of the caudal end of control and mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	310	 oe, esophagus; Py, pylorus; d, duodenum.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	311	 (C,D) The junction region of the caudal end of the stomach and the duodenum show slight morphological differences.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	312	 The gastric parietal cells were stained with anti-H+/K+-ATPase ss-subunit antibody.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	313	 (E,F) Anti-GATA4 antibody was used to mark glandular gastric epithelium.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	314	 (G-J) Paraffin sections of E18.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	315	5 stomachs were stained for EAP activity.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	316	 The bracket indicates corresponding regions of the caudal end of control and mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Very low positive signals were found in glandular gastric epithelium of the control (G,I) while highly intense signals were seen in the mutant (H,J).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	318	 High magnification of the boxed corresponding regions in the control (G) and mutant (H) were shown in I and J, respectively.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Scale bar in B: 100  microm for A,B.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	320	  Does COUP-TFII mediate Hh signaling in the stomach? The radial and AP patterning defects elicited by the COUP-TFII-null mutants bear resemblance to the dysmorphogenesis of the stomach in Shh-null mutant mice (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Because of this similarity, we asked if COUP-TFII expression is altered in the Shh-null mutant.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Whole-mount in situ hybridization showed that COUP-TFII expression in the caudal region of the stomach of the Shh-null mutant is downregulated in comparison with the control littermate.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	323	 However, the expression of COUP-TFII in other regions of the stomach is only slightly downregulated (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	324	 An anterior shifting of the caudal margin of COUP-TFII expression at the gastro-duodenal junction (indicated by broken lines; presumptive gastro-duodenal junction is indicated by arrowheads based on morphology and location of the dorsal mesogastrium) was evident in the Shh-null mutant.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	325	 In addition, a significant size reduction, particularly in the fore-stomach was noted in the Shh-null mutant stomachs, even as early as E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	326	5 stage, using the esophagus as a guide (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	327	View larger version (86K):    Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Effect of inhibition of Hh signaling in COUP-TFII expression.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	329	 (A,B) Developing stomachs were dissected from E12.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	330	5 Shh wild-type and null mutant, and expression of COUP-TFII mRNA was detected by whole-mount in situ hybridization.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Caudal margins of COUP-TFII expression are indicated by dots, and presumptive anatomical boundaries between stomach and duodenum are indicated by arrowheads.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	332	 The relative size of fore-stomach is indicated by a white line at the top of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	333	 (C-F) Foregut explants were dissected from E10.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	334	5 knock-in embryos and cultured for 48 hours in increasing concentrations of cyclopamine (0-10  microM, D-F).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Strong lacZ expression was detected in the mesenchyme between lung bud and fore-stomach, as indicated by arrowhead, and cyclopamine inhibited lacZ expression in a dose-dependent manner.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	336	 oe, esophagus; fs, fore-stomach; hs, hind-stomach; dmg, dorsalmesogastrium; lb, lung bud; St, stomach; Py, pylorus; d, duodenum; e, hind-stomach epithelium.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	337	  As the presence of Ihh in the Shh-null mutant stomach (Bitgood and McMahon, 1995) might functionally compensate for Shh and influence COUP-TFII expression, we used cyclopamine to inhibit all Hh signals (Chen et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	338	, 2002) and asked if COUP-TFII expression is affected in the explants organ culture.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	339	5 lacZ knock-in embryos were cultured for 48 hours in the presence of increasing amounts of cyclopamine.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Whole-mount X-gal staining of COUP-TFII illustrated a significant dose-dependent reduction of COUP-TFII/lacZ expression, especially in the mesenchyme between lung bud and fore-stomach (indicated by arrowheads) (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	341	 At 1  microM of cyclopamine, a slight reduction of COUP-TFII mRNA, as represented by X-gal staining, was detected in the stomach explants from E11.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	342	 At 5  microM and 10  microM of cyclopamine, the reduction of X-gal staining was more pronounced in the stomach when compared with the controls (Fig.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	343	 9E,F), while COUP-TFII mRNA was not affected in lung explants (not shown).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	344	 The downregulation of COUP-TFII expression when Hh signaling is inhibited by cyclopamine substantiates the notion that Hh signaling regulates COUP-TFII expression in the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	345	   Discussion TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion REFERENCES   The lacZ knock-in mice allow us to follow the expression of COUP-TFII during gastric development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	346	 It is apparent that COUP-TFII is expressed in both the mesenchyme and the epithelium of the developing stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	347	 The graded mesenchymal expression profile, with highest levels in mesenchyme subjacent to the epithelium, suggests a diffusible molecule secreted by the epithelium may regulate the expression of COUP-TFII.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	348	 COUP-TFII is also expressed in the glandular epithelium of the stomach, with highest expression in the base where the zymogenic cells are localized, but is not expressed in the surface pit cells.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	349	 The expression patterns in the zymogenic unit resemble that of Shh (van den Brink et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Taken together of the above findings, we speculate that Shh might regulate COUP-TFII in the stomach in a similar manner as previously shown in the motoneurons (Krishnan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	351	Conditional ablation of COUP-TFII in the mesenchyme of the developing stomach by Nkx3.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	352	2 Cre recombinase firmly established that COUP-TFII is essential for radial patterning of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	353	5, it is already apparent that the circular smooth muscles layers and the enteric neurons layers are expanded and disorganized in the conditional mutants.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	354	 These defects persist at later stages of development.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Although COUP-TFII in the epithelial compartment has not been deleted, the epithelium is considerably thicker in comparison with the control littermates, indicating signals from the mesenchyme are required for appropriate epithelium growth.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The defects display by the COUP-TFII conditional mutants indicate that COUP-TFII is essential for radial patterning of the developing stomach and these defects are not seen in the compound heterozygote of Nkx3.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Instead, the inappropriate differentiation of the smooth muscles cells and enteric neurons in the mesenchyme has been shown when Hh signaling is disrupted by treatment with cyclopamine (Sukegawa et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Shh is believed to be the epithelial signal that inhibits the gut mesenchyme to differentiate into smooth cells and the neural crest cells to differentiate into enteric neurons.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	359	 Our findings indicate that COUP-TFII participates in the negative regulation of differentiation of smooth muscle cells and enteric neurons in the gut mesenchyme.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	360	 COUP-TFII can either serve as a downstream target of Hh to mediate its negative function in the gut mesenchyme or exert its effect in a pathway parallel to Hh to regulate mesenchymal differentiation.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	361	In addition to radial patterning of the stomach, COUP-TFII is also required for AP patterning of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	362	 The anterior shift of the limited ridge that divides the fore- and hind-stomach, the reduced size of the fore-stomach, the expansion of the hind-stomach and the expansion of EAP expression into the hind-stomach are all consistent with disruption of the AP axis patterning in the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	363	 However, the differentiation of the epithelium of the fore- and hind-stomach in the adult mutant remains unchanged; with all the molecular markers analyzed, even the mutant stomach is posteriorized.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	364	 The posteriorization and ectopic extended expression of EAP in the hind-stomach of the conditional mutant have been demonstrated in the Shh-null mutant mice (Ramalho-Santos et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	365	 The striking similarity of the phenotypes exhibited by conditional COUP-TFII-null mutants and animals, chick and mouse, when Hh signaling is disrupted further implicates that Hh and COUP-TFII act in the same and/or parallel pathways.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	366	Although the general slight reduction of expression of COUP-TFII in the Shh-null mutant is a little surprising, the high expression of Ihh in the expanded hind-stomach of the Shh-null mutant could have compensated for the missing Shh to induce COUP-TFII expression.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Indeed, the downregulation of COUP-TFII expression in the mesenchyme of the stomach is more pronounced in the explants treated with cyclopamine, supporting the notion that COUP-TFII is a downstream target of Hh signaling.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	368	 In addition, Shh signaling can directly activate COUP-TFII expression and Shh-N activates COUP-TFII expression in P19 cells without de novo protein synthesis (Krishnan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Furthermore, analysis of the COUP-TFII promoter has identified an ShhRE that is distinct from the defined Gli-binding site (Krishnan et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Thus, all the above results indicate that COUP-TFII mediates Hh signaling in the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Taken together, our results established that COUP-TFII is essential for radial and AP patterning of the stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Restriction of anterior Shh expression and attenuation of Shh action in the epithelium of the COUP-TFII conditional mutant, in turn, suggests a potential role for COUP-TFII in the stimulation or maintenance of Shh expression.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	373	Shh derived from the epithelium signals the mesenchyme of the stomach, but how mesenchymal factors influence endodermally expressed Shh is unclear.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	374	 The Hoxa5-null mutant phenotype provides evidence for mesenchyme-mediated regulation of Shh expression in the developing stomach (Aubin et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Similarly in chick, it was suggested that adjacent mesenchyme regulates Shh expression (Narita et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	376	 In our study, COUP-TFII was ablated in the mesenchyme and the observed dysmorphogenesis suggests that COUP-TFII potentially affects such mesenchymal factor(s).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	377	 One such candidate, Bmp4, which belongs to the TGFss superfamily, is expressed in the mesenchyme of developing murine stomach, while the chick ortholog has been demonstrated to play a role in gizzard patterning.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Bmp4 is important for mesoderm development, but because of early lethality in Bmp4-null mutants, no specific role for Bmp4 in gastric development has been elucidated (Winnier et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Interestingly, it has been shown that COUP-TFII binds to the mouse Bmp4 promoter and regulates Bmp4 promoter activity in transient transfection assays (Feng et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	380	, 1995), suggesting COUP-TFII might function through BMP signaling.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Another member of TGFss super family, activin, governs embryonic axial patterning, and restricts Shh expression in Hensen's node (Monsoro-Burq and Le Douarin, 2001).
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Furthermore, the expansion of Shh expression domain within the stomach of Acvr2a/Acvr2b mutant mice indicates a restriction of Shh in the foregut that is potentially regulated by TGFss/Bmp signaling.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	383	 As Acvr2 is able to interact with BMPs (Kim et al.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	384	, 2000), mesenchymal expressed Bmp4 may restrict Shh expression.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Alternatively, it is possible that COUP-TFII may modulate the expression of activin/activin receptor themselves.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Enhanced activin signaling may restrict the expression domain of Shh to the anterior border and perturb the epithelial growth, as seen in the conditional mutant stomach.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Further analysis of TGFss/Bmp/activin signaling in the COUP-TFII conditional mutant stomach may shed light on which mesenchymal factor(s) that regulate Shh expression are affected by the absence of COUP-TFII.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	388	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Xiaoyan Huang, Kikue Takamoto and Wei Qian for excellent technical help; Dr Milton Finegold, Mr James Barrish and the Core Morphology laboratory of the NIH Gulf Coast Digestive Disease Center for the thin-section and the EM analysis; Drs Zijian Lan, Hong Wu and Dennis Roop for various suggestion and discussion; Drs Kimi Araki, Takeshi Yagi and Matthew Scott for plasmid DNA; and Kurt Schillinger, Debra Bramblett and Peter Tsai for preparation of manuscript.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	389	   REFERENCES TOP SUMMARY Introduction Materials and methods Results Discussion REFERENCES  .
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Stomach regional specification requires Hoxa5-driven mesenchymal-epithelial signaling.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Hedgehog and Bmp genes are coexpressed at many diverse sites of cell-cell interaction in the mouse embryo.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	392	 Small molecule modulation of Smoothened activity.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Cyclopia and defective axial patterning in mice lacking Sonic hedgehog gene function.
0.25421372.15829524.html.plaintext.txt	394	 Molecular etiology of gut malformations and diseases.
